webTitle: Eye in the red

fields.headline: Eye in the red
fields.standfirst: Not so much a wheel of fortune
fields.trailText: London Eye, the giant ferris wheel on the south bank of the Thames, has made a loss of £8m in its first year of operation despite attracting 1.8m more visitors than forecast.
fields.body:
London Eye, the giant ferris wheel on the south bank of the Thames, has made a loss of £8m in its first year of operation despite attracting 1.8m more visitors than forecast.

A spokesman for British Airways, backers of the attraction, said: "The advantage to us is the promotional aspect the wheel brings." He said the attraction had been forecast to see 2.2m visitors in the first year, but 3.5m came. He expects the Eye to break even "in the medium term".

The London Eye Company's first report and accounts since it opened for business were filed last week, showing the attraction valued at £74m. The wheel made an operating profit of £5.46m in the first 10 months, but interest charges on loans from BA and Tussauds Attractions meant the business saw a pretax loss of £8m for the year. The company borrowed £68.5m from BA and £6.9m from Tussauds.

The attraction, which employs 207 people, is said to have dropped plans to float on the stock exchange. Approaches from several overseas cities to build similar wheels are thought to have made little progress.

The wheel's backers are confident that London Eye will avoid the fate of la Grande Roue de Paris, France's 60m-high millennium wheel. La Roue, in Place de la Concorde, has to the end of this month to find a new home after it was deemed out of place in the Parisian cityscape.

The London Eye has five years' planning permission, which backers hope to extend for a further 20.

webTitle: Ash's hormonally-charged punk pop

fields.headline: Ash's hormonally-charged punk pop
fields.standfirst:
Ash,
Barrowlands, Glasgow
Rating***
fields.trailText:
Ash,
Barrowlands, Glasgow
Rating***
fields.body:
Ever wish you could be 17 again? Tim Wheeler certainly does. The Ash frontman has spent his short career writing nostalgic elegies to lost adolescence and spiky outbursts of hormonally-charged punk pop.

So it comes as little surprise that tonight's audience is largely made up of under-20s. And it's clear that these fans want to revel in youthful abandon rather than wallow in teenage angst. As soon as the band take the stage, the crowd can scarcely contain their excitement: within seconds barely a body in the room resists the urge to jump around frantically.

Facilitating this kind of mania is what Ash do best. Since the release of their debut album proper, 1977, four years ago, they've carved out a niche as instigators of adolescent abandon. When they open with the blistering Girl From Mars, you can see why they inspire so much devotion. It's a frantic, exuberant collision of melody and power chords that uncannily evokes the sensation of your first cider rush.

Yet Ash seem to have decided that they want to be more than just teen figureheads: they've decided to grow up. New album Free All Angels features the band trying out a new, mature sound amid the usual high jinks. Playing around with the formula certainly adds some variety to Ash's set, but tonight's show demonstrates why this flirtation with the adult world doesn't suit them. Take the string and synth-led Candy, which emerges as a rather desperate plea from the band to be taken seriously. Or listen to the S&M-themed Submission, which Ash no doubt believe lends them an air of sleazy, seedy cool. Instead, it sounds like the work of a rather unworldly 14-year-old who's just worked out what Dad's Velvet Underground records are all about.

What's more, by over-reaching themselves, the band expose their flaws to greater scrutiny. The weakness of Wheeler's voice doesn't matter when he's belting out some teenage anthem; it does when he's trying to come over all sensitive. And although covering Weezer's Only in Dreams and Ween's What Deaner Was Talking About exposes two great songs to a wider audience, tonight's performance suggests Ash don't have quite the lightness of touch to carry it off.

However, none of this renders them any less effective as masters of the moshpit. The sonic punch of Goldfinger and Burn Baby Burn ensures that the sweat-drenched crowd return home contentedly. Why should Ash ever want to outgrow these teenage kicks?

Ash play Leicester University (01162 333111) tonight, then continue touring.

webTitle: Carmen

fields.headline: Carmen
fields.standfirst:
Festival Theatre, Edinburgh
Rating ***
fields.trailText:
Festival Theatre, Edinburgh
Rating ***
fields.body:
This is a soft-shoe Carmen, a Carmen without heels, a Carmen without Bizet. It's a folksy Carmen, and a newish one (originally performed by the Gyor Ballet in Hungary in 1997) by Robert North, artistic director of Scottish Ballet. Sadly, it's also a provincial Carmen - too clean by half and lacking in lust. Flashing eyes tried for size don't light the fire and flamenco flare-ups break the story politely, while the love affair that causes a man to kill three times and finally face execution himself fails to deliver the emotional goosebumps.

It is a shame because this production is pretty and competent, and even clever in parts. There has been no corner-cutting on research - North keeps to the original 19th-century short story by Prosper Mérimée and looks to Goya and Gustave Doré for visual inspiration. The design is neatly efficient, allowing one set of big wooden tables to become the prison, the tobacco factory, a riverbank, the bullring and the gallows just by moving them around and turning them over.

Written specially for this ballet, the score by composer Christopher Benstead illuminates the dance without overtly competing with it. In the programme he says he's looking for a filmic quality; he's got it. The music bends and turns in waves with the action, never imposing, always in step. Despite his deference, though, the music holds most of the emotional cards. Spanish songs sung with modest beauty by Annique Burms and Stephen Ashfield act as our guide to Carmen and Don Jose's feelings. Three guitars, a solo trumpet, an accordian and an ever-present percussion add a little heat. Although there is nothing grand about this interpretation - it is certainly not Carmen as we know it - Benstead delivers something soothingly attractive.

The dance, by contrast, dreams its way through love and murder with an anonymous, rather chilly detachment. Carmen's proud spirit seems tamed and Don Jose's passion hardly seems murderous. Lorna Scott and Ivan Dinev are well-matched but their title roles are set in fable rather than drama. The company are comfortable in this contemporary ballet with a flick of flamenco and folk but it does not take them to the scary, risky and, ultimately, tragic world in which a gypsy girl practises sexual freedom and dies for it.

We're told to expect passion, jealousy and obsession. The pedigree is right on paper, but this Carmen won't carry you away.

webTitle: An emotional return for Senegal's superstars

fields.headline: An emotional return for Senegal's superstars
fields.standfirst:
Orchestra Baobab,
Barbican, London
Rating***
fields.trailText:
Orchestra Baobab,
Barbican, London
Rating***
fields.body:
It was an inspired move to choose Dakar, the Senegalese capital, as the focus for the first of the Barbican's Urban Beats events, but unfortunate that this powerhouse of West African music was represented by such a lopsided, if intriguing, line-up. The best band of the night had not performed since the late 1980s, while the headline artist was a surprising disappointment. And as for Senegal's best-known singers, they were nowhere to be seen. The glorious Baaba Maal had performed elsewhere in London only the previous night, while Youssou N'Dour, who was supposed to act as MC for this show, mysteriously failed to appear.

So it was left to a group of elderly musicians to rescue the show. Back in the 1970s and 80s, Orchestra Baobab were the undisputed superstars of Senegal, even if they were then largely unknown in the west. They played a cool, carefully arranged fusion of the Latin dance styles that even then were massively popular in West Africa, and mixed the salsa and cha-cha with Senegalese influences. They split up 14 years ago, and only now were they getting together again, to celebrate the forthcoming re-release of their classic album from the early 1980s, Pirates Choice.

It was a wildly emotional occasion, particularly for the Senegalese contingent in the audience, but at first the omens did not seem good. The veteran band came on wearing their old uniforms of grey trousers and garish green, yellow and black shirts, which now made them look like some ghastly hotel outfit. But this was no mere poolside easy listening, even if many of their tuneful Afro-Latin pop songs were gently rhythmic but laid-back and languid. Guitarist Barthelemy Atisso gradually eased back into his fluid guitar solos, and Seydou Nourou Koite added cool saxophone work, while a series of band members stepped up to take the lead vocals and embellish the songs. It was a subtle, charming, triumphant reunion.

Viviane N'Dour, Youssou N'Dour's sister-in-law and one-time backing singer, who closed the show, is a Dakar superstar with the status at home of Posh Spice, and she looked the part, in her black dress and western haircut. However, she had neither the personality nor vocal range to compete either with her thunderous synthesised band, driven on by an exhilarating percussion section, or the array of griots, Senegalese traditional singers, and rappers who joined her on stage after giving free shows in the foyer during the day.

webTitle: New PO bank fails to meet Treasury standards

fields.headline: New PO bank fails to meet Treasury standards
fields.standfirst: Accounts seen as little more than an electronic benefits service
fields.trailText: The government's troubled project to create a post office bank faces fresh criticism this week - this time for offering accounts to the financially excluded which do not reach the standards demanded from the high street banks.
fields.body:
The government's troubled project to create a post office bank faces fresh criticism this week - this time for offering accounts to the financially excluded which do not reach the standards demanded from the high street banks.

The attempt to create bank accounts for about 4m social security claimants is already behind schedule and unlikely to come to fruition before the general election.

Indeed, it is still far from clear if any of the 10 main banking groups have officially signed the proposal.

Now senior sources are warning that the Department of Trade and Industry is on a collision course with the Treasury because the new, simple post office bank accounts are unlikely to meet the Treasury's Cat (charges, access and terms) standard.

The Treasury has just completed a consultation exercise with the high street banks to produce a Cat standard, which sets out the minimum requirements for these basic bank accounts.

Last year the Treasury demanded that the banks make basic accounts available through their own branches and The Post Office, which would not allow the customer to overdraw but would provide facilities to use cash machines and set up direct debits. The Cat standard is expected to require similar features, but the card account offered through the Post Office would allow account holders only to withdraw cash over its counters.

There would be no direct debit facility, making the account nothing more than an electronic benefits service.

"It is absolutely inconceivable that the Treasury will not demand that you should be able to set up direct debits from these basic bank accounts," one source said. "The government would be contravening its own guidelines."

This is the latest hurdle in the tortuous negotiations to create the universal bank, which the high street banks warned last year could carry the stigma of a poor people's bank.

The post office-based bank has two main aims; first, to provide bank accounts for social security claimants who will need one when the benefits system is automated; and second, to throw a lifeline to the 18,000-strong post office network by finding a way to plug the £400m in revenue that the Post Office will lose when social security payments are paid directly into bank accounts.

Under the deal between the banks and the government, the banks will contribute £150m a year to the Post Office. The banks will offer their basic bank accounts - with direct debit and cash machine facilities - through their own branches and The Post Office.

At the same time, the Post Office will offer its much simpler card account, which can only be used over its counters.

webTitle: Now affluence starts at £10,000 for HSBC and Merrill

fields.headline: Now affluence starts at £10,000 for HSBC and Merrill
fields.trailText: The online investment and banking venture from HSBC and Merrill Lynch - one of many new services aimed at the "mass affluent" - has slashed the amount of cash required to benefit from its upmarket service from £60,000 to just £10,000.
fields.body:
The online investment and banking venture from HSBC and Merrill Lynch - one of many new services aimed at the "mass affluent" - has slashed the amount of cash required to benefit from its upmarket service from £60,000 to just £10,000.

The new stand-alone venture, which Britain's most powerful bank and the world's biggest stockbroker are backing with £600m, is called Merrill Lynch HSBC and goes live tomorrow.

Its main offering will be an integrated online investment and banking service allowing people to buy and sell UK and US shares, hold cash accounts in different currencies and borrow against their portfolio. It has the option of a debit card and cheque book, and clients will be able to keep other money in a high interest instant access savings account.

Merrill Lynch HSBC, the 50-50 joint venture, was announced in April last year as a service which would target those with "investable assets" of between £60,000 and £300,000, who were keen to make their own investment decisions.

Since then a number of other banks including Lloyds TSB and Abbey National have also announced wealth ventures.

A report from PricewaterhouseCoopers last week concluded that too many banks were chasing the wealth of 4.5m British people with at least £50,000 to invest - a group dubbed the "mass affluent".

The decision to allow those with £10,000-plus to invest to become clients significantly widens Merrill Lynch HSBC's potential customer base, opening the doors to many thousands of small investors whose tax-free Tessa savings accounts are maturing.

The online service will be backed up by a telephone call centre and, eventually, investment centres in London and key regional locations that customers can visit.

Merrill Lynch HSBC is based in London and claims to be "the world's first global online investment and banking business". There will be similar ventures in Australia, Canada, Germany, Hong Kong and Japan.

webTitle: Bolshoi back on form

fields.headline: Bolshoi back on form
fields.standfirst:
The Bolshoi Ballet,
Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, London
Rating***
fields.trailText:
The Bolshoi Ballet,
Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, London
Rating***
fields.body:
Halfway through the opening number of the Bolshoi's second programme a disgruntled punter suddenly yelled from the stalls for the dancers "to put a bit more life into it". This was about as stupid as it was rude, given that the company were in the middle of performing Fokine's exquisite homage to Romanticism, Chopiniana (Les Sylphides). It was also blind to the fact that the dancers were looking twice as good as they had been in their dispiriting first programme. They were now a confident, vital company living up to their reputation.

It helped that the Bolshoi were performing their first complete ballet in a season otherwise composed of chunks and diverts. But the dancers also seemed to have settled past their first-night nerves. Andrei Uvarov, whose smile had looked pasted on with effort dancing the Don Q. fireworks a week ago, appeared physically and imaginatively liberated in the role of the dreaming Poet, his large, beautifully cushioned jump and elegant arms breasting the airy fantasies of Chopin's music. Svetlana Lunkina as his ballerina was even more profoundly in style, her features as delicately drawn as a Taglioni lithograph, the fine lines of her body creating an illusion of floating ease while alertly responsive to the faery charm of her character.

The Bolshoi dance Fokine's choreography on a larger scale than many companies - bolder and more athletic than the drifting modest lines of pure Romanticism. But the dancers' arms are infinitely softer and more musical than they were a decade ago, and their upper bodies subtler and more pliant. So well do they dance Fokine's choreography, it's hard to remember that this is a company whose signature ballet is the grandstanding Spartacus.

The second half of the programme returned to the irksome diverts format but despite Maria Alexandrova slamming out the Corsaire fouettes as if she were some kind of production line, the mix was better. Most fun was Gennady Yanin dancing Goleizovsky's solo Narcissus. This is nearly a classic instance of Soviet kitsch, with its combination of muscular heroics and arch dramatics, yet there are feral, archaic strains of real poetry in it and Yanin, with his wide-eyed flickering energy, vivid gesture and articulate dynamics makes the role seem alive rather than quaint history.

Until May 19. Box office: 020-7494 5064.

webTitle: Crozier in 'hush' row

fields.headline: Crozier in 'hush' row
fields.trailText: Adam Crozier, the FA's chief executive, was last night embroiled in a political row over the ill-starred Wembley redevelopment - and it seemed he would need all his famed public relations skills to emerge unscathed.
fields.body:
Adam Crozier, the FA's chief executive, was last night embroiled in a political row over the ill-starred Wembley redevelopment - and it seemed he would need all his famed public relations skills to emerge unscathed.

Reports suggested he was 'under pressure to resign' after a letter from Crozier to Culture Secretary Chris Smith - in which the FA asked the Government to help fund a new stadium while keeping sensitive details 'under wraps' until after the election - was leaked.

One report suggested Crozier had asked for an initial £150 million towards the £660 million cost of the new stadium and then provide monthly cash to save the controversial project.

But Crozier, who in a briefing with Observer Sport confirmed he wanted a partnership with government over the new Wembley, came out fighting last night.

webTitle: Glass shattered but not broken

fields.headline: Glass shattered but not broken
fields.standfirst: 'I'm 6ft 4in, have a history of scoring goals and no one marks me'
fields.trailText: 'It's down to the final minute of the final game. Absolutely astonishing stuff. Derby 0, Coventry 0; Dunfermline 1, Celtic 2. And I hope this is accurate news for Carlisle fans' sake... [takes a breath] ...Carlisle have scored in the last minute of their game against Plymouth. Unconfirmed. We hear that Jimmy Glass, the goalkeeper, has scored for Carlisle. He was taken on loan after Carlisle had sold their only goalkeeper on deadline day and the League gave them special dispensation to sign Jimmy Glass. fields.byline: Will Buckley meets the man who saved Carlisle United
fields.body:
'It's down to the final minute of the final game. Absolutely astonishing stuff. Derby 0, Coventry 0; Dunfermline 1, Celtic 2. And I hope this is accurate news for Carlisle fans' sake... [takes a breath] ...Carlisle have scored in the last minute of their game against Plymouth. Unconfirmed. We hear that Jimmy Glass, the goalkeeper, has scored for Carlisle. He was taken on loan after Carlisle had sold their only goalkeeper on deadline day and the League gave them special dispensation to sign Jimmy Glass. Now if this is the case, and we're waiting for confirmation, it would be the most staggering story of the day.' - Jeff Stelling, Sky's Soccer Saturday 8 May 1999

Perhaps sometimes it can be easier to achieve something than to capitalise on that achievement. Two years ago Carlisle goalkeeper Jimmy Glass went up for a corner in the fifth minute of injury time and scored the goal that kept his side in the League. 'No one marks you,' he explains. 'I'm six feet four inches, I've got a history of scoring goals and no one marks me. So whatever madness there is to it there's some sanity too.'

It proved to be not just 'the most staggering story of the day' but the most wonderful non-Premiership story for many a year. Yet for Jimmy Glass it was his one moment in the sun during a decade of drudgery. He is the goalkeeper who is famous for scoring one goal. Now, at the age of 27 and after being relegated with Kingstonian, he is on the verge of jacking it in. When we meet, Jimmy is on his way to Carlisle to help out a Supporters Association who have raised money to buy two seats on the board. 'I'll meet the media, do TV, go round the pubs and clubs to meet the fans. I love all that,' he says. 'It was just my luck that I became a legend as far away from my house as I possibly could.' He is effusive as he looks back on the one-shot career that came to a premature end: angry, confused, disappointed, but not bitter. Anxious to tell it as it was and is.

He was let go by Chelsea, signed as a pro by Crystal Palace, sent to Bournemouth, and then made his way to Swindon. 'I thought, "This is my step up." I got on fine with [manager] Steve McMahon to start with but for the opening match Steve played Frank Talia.' Initially, Glass fared better with new boss Jimmy Quinn. 'I played two games. We lost 4-0 to QPR in the first and in the next I was injured, there was no keeper on the bench and I had to play on and we lost 6-0. My ankle was twice the size of my head and it was obvious I wasn't fit to play and he goes to the paper and says, "Frank's playing in the next game". Oh, it's like that, is it? 'Two weeks later he said, "Carlisle have phoned, do you fancy it?" and me being uneducated in a football way said, "Sure", not knowing that they were bottom of the Third Division. And when I went to Carlisle I was shitting myself because I hadn't played any League games - well, I'd played two and let in 10 goals - and if I bollocks it up they're out of the league.' Instead, he saved them. Back to Swindon. 'Quinny said, "You've done really good, but if I get an offer you can leave." So that was Swindon.'

Swindon said Carlisle could have him for £15,000. 'Bloody non-league players go for 50k and I thought, "Crikey, show us a bit of respect, fellas," and [then Carlisle owner] Michael Knighton said he didn't want me. I was only 25, he would have made money on me.' The source of disagreement was wages. Glass wanted an extra 10 grand a year for keeping them in the League, Knighton wasn't prepared to pay. 'I'm pretty sure I wouldn't even have been top earner.' Still at Swindon. 'I played eight games and my form was picking up and we went to Bolton and we got battered. Hammered. I made five or six saves. It's pissing down with rain and this geezer hits a shot and I go down the wrong way and it's my fault and I put my hand up. That's goalkeeping. 'They nick another. We lose 2-0.

Quinn comes in and says to me "I'm embarrassed, I'm embarrassed for the fans, that's just crap". And bearing in mind I'm an argumentative sod I said very little. And then he really personally attacked me in the press.' (Pause). 'He basically just personally attacked me. And it was splashed all over the Sunday papers even though I still got Man of the Match. That was the last game I played for Swindon.'

In the Sunday Mirror it was reported that Quinn said: 'Frankly it was embarrassing. The ball was only travelling at two-and-a-half miles an hour and it's gone into our net. I may have to start looking for a new goalkeeper because this sort of thing keeps happening.' In the The News of the World , however: 'The keeper performed heroics.' Quinn never apologised. 'Once you lose your honesty it all goes Pete Tong,' says Glass. 'The damage Quinny inflicts on you goes with you.'

Glass had short spells at Cambridge and Oxford - 'They didn't even have a training ground, let alone a keeper coach.' Then Kingstonian and now... 'I've had only a year's coaching in 12 years in the game. Every club I've been at as soon as they hit financial difficulties the first thing to go is the keeper coach. I'd love to coach but not in the current climate. I'd like to run a subsidised coaching centre where the kids could go for the love of the game.

'Football is bigger than United, Beckham or Murdoch. Football's a great spectacle - a beautiful thing - and it's big ger than the Premiership. I think the FA is to blame because the game hasn't been shaped properly like in other nations. The worst thing that happened was winning the World Cup. Because we're an arrogant nation and we just stuck our head up our arses for 30 years. And now the structure is like an upside-down pyramid with everything at the top and when that collapses... '

Glass is an honest, intelligent man - qualities which probably hindered his football career but will benefit the book he is currently writing on what's wrong with the game. As he leaves he says: 'I've neither succeeded nor failed. When I'm 50 I can always get the cuttings books out and say I made history. I might be sitting in a caravan but I could always do that.'

webTitle: If it's Tuesday, this must be Bangkok

fields.headline: If it's Tuesday, this must be Bangkok
fields.standfirst: Lynn Barber  is converted from travel snob to package junkie after 'doing' Indochina in one whirlwind week
fields.trailText: Lynn Barber is converted from travel snob to package junkie after 'doing' Indochina in one whirlwind week.
fields.body:
To think how snotty I used to be about Americans who 'did' England in three days! I've just done much much worse - Indochina in a week - and of course I am now a total convert to whistlestop tourism. Everything is so clear cut. How did you like Thailand? Charming. Cambodia? Sinister. Malaysia? Rubber trees. Singapore? Fabulous. It completely banishes the fear of boredom. If you don't like somewhere - pouf! - it's gone, in the blinking of an eye; if you do like somewhere, you can tell yourself you'll come back.

All the guidebooks say you must spend at least three days or preferably a week at Angkor Wat but I found an afternoon a bit on the long side. Angkor Wat, as I'm sure you all know - though I didn't until the other day - is the flowering glory of Khmer ninth-to-thirteenth century civilisation.

It is Westminster Abbey, Chartres cathedral, Notre Dame and St Peter's laid end to end and stuck in the middle of the Cambodian jungle - which might give you some clue to its drawback. It is vast, so walking round it in the Cambodian humidity, which feels like having boiling towels clamped to your face, is not much fun.

Moreover, although it is extraordinary, impressive, awesome, etc it is not actually very beautiful. The stonework is grey and lumpy and blotched with lichen and the dark green jungle backdrop casts a gloomy shade. It reminded me of the old loaf you always find in the breadbin of a holiday cottage that hasn't been visited all winter.

Anyway, that was Friday, that was Cambodia. My tour, with British Airways Holidays, started with an overnight flight to Bangkok arriving on Thursday afternoon. In theory, I could have whisked around the city and taken in a few temples; in practice I found the luscious precincts of the Oriental Hotel rather difficult to leave. By evening I thought I should make some effort to see Bangkok so I took the hotel launch across the river to the hotel spa where I had a yummy jetlag massage in a sandalwood panelled room and fell fast asleep. Super place, Bangkok.

Next morning it was off to the airport for the short flight to Siem Reap in Cambodia. I am tempted here to make some crappy generalisation about the happy, giggling, smiling Thais and the silent, stricken, war-scarred Cambodians but given the brevity of my acquaintance with the populations of both countries, I will forbear.

Still, you can't help finding Cambodia grim after Thailand. The civil war, which wiped out a whole generation, is a very recent memory; there are posters warning about land mines everywhere (and plenty of limbless beggars who emphasise the point). Cambodia is now encouraging tourism like mad, and Siem Reap, the base for Angkor Wat, is a boom town with new hotels opening every month, but it still feels raw and provisional.

We stayed at the Grand Hotel d'Angkor, which was founded in 1932 - in the French colonial period - and has an elegant Art Deco feel. In fact it was taken over by the Khmer Rouge, used as a prison for Phnom Penh officers, few of whom survived, and was gutted and rebuilt in 1997.

On Saturday we went back to Bangkok and boarded the Eastern and Oriental Express - owned by Orient-Express - for a journey through southern Thailand and Malaysia to Singapore. Having effortlessly adjusted to the concept of whistlestop tourism, this seemed a bit slow - two whole days chuntering through Thailand? But the scenery was stunning - emerald fields with egrets and kingfishers everywhere, and prawn ponds weirdly striplit at night, fantastically shaped craggy mountains in the distance, a milky white haze at dawn. It is so beautiful, Thailand, I can see why everyone who goes gets hooked.

We stopped to see the Bridge on the River Kwai and to take a boat trip to the cemetery where many of the PoWs who worked on the death railway are buried. It is a beautiful spot - not remotely reminiscent of the bridge in the film, which was shot in Sri Lanka. The next day we entered Malaysia and saw rubber plantations. I thought rubber trees were stiff plastic things that lived in offices and needed dusting, but they are as graceful and shivery as larches.

We visited Georgetown, the old colonial capital of Penang Island, where we were whisked round in trishaws, sprawling in big comfortable armchairs with tiny old men cycling like mad behind. Then overnight through Malaysia, and across the causeway into Singapore.

The train is beautifully designed, with marquetry panelling and Art-Nouveau fittings, apparently inspired by the 1932 film Shanghai Express. The food is excellent and service impeccable but you have to be keen on dressing for dinner and sitting round sipping cocktails in a piano bar because that's what you spend most of the time doing. Frankly, I'm puzzled by this nostalgia for empire malarkey, though it is all the rage in travel brochures.

If people have a yearning to eat cucumber sandwiches and fairy cakes and call it tiffin why can't they do it back home? Raffles Hotel in Singapore is full of it, in fact is probably the toppermost of the poppermost for serious tiffin addicts, but it seems bizarre in one of the most exciting, genuinely multicultural cities of the twenty-first century. Singapore - you make my heart sing! Everyone told me I would find it dull - it is so clean and law-abiding that there is an automatic death penalty for drug trafficking, and you can go to prison for dropping litter or importing chewing-gum. Maybe it's a sign of age that I can forgo the delights of litter and chewing-gum and drug trafficking but I loved the energy of Singapore, the bristling thicket of skyscrapers in the middle, the acres of reclaimed land now green as a golf course but soon to be planted with more skyscrapers, the marina with its little pleasure boats and tourist junks, and beyond them the Lego-coloured blocks and cranes of the huge container port with dozens of supertankers queueing in the straits outside, and tier after tier of hazy Indonesian islands receding into the blue distance.

Moreover, I could see all this from my bath on the twenty-sixth floor of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. The Ritz-Carlton, Singapore, is one of the wonders of the modern world - I mean why struggle to admire ninth century Khmer civilisation when twenty-first century civilisation is so patently superior? I had a Millennia suite - a snip at £607 a night - the size of a small sheep farm, where the bath was set against a huge octagonal window so I could soak in bubbles surrounded by candles while looking over most of Singapore and a considerable chunk of Indonesia. The hotel has a new gimmick in the shape of a 'bath butler' who comes to run - sorry, 'draw' - your bath for you after consultation about the 'bath menu' - would 'Modom' like the cream bath or the traditional bubble bath or the detoxifying salt bath, etc. Luckily I was able to run my own bath and spent many happy hours in it, fantasising that I was Rupert Murdoch and shouting 'Buy! Buy! Sell! Sell!' into the mobile phone so thoughtfully provided by the hotel. (Incidentally, Rupe, Singapore television is pathetic - why haven't you done something about it? You can hardly even get CNN.)

Anyone determined to find history can find little bits of it in Singapore - the inevitable colonial quarter centring on Raffles hotel, Chinatown and Little India and the Arab quarter, all startlingly clean and tidy. But much more fun are the shopping malls, which are mostly underground - you see an escalator going down, hop on, and suddenly you are in the Chanel, Gucci, Prada, Versace mines that run for miles under Singapore and supposedly offer huge bargains. Best of all, you are never more than a few metres from great food - all the streets and shopping malls are dotted with delicious noodle bars, sushi, satay, samosa stalls, so that you can shop and snack, shop and snack, spend the whole day grazing, then end with a wonderful foot massage before tottering back to the Ritz-Carlton.

So what did I learn about Indochina? Well, not much as you can see, but it was tremendous fun. Next year: Australia in a weekend.

webTitle: Traklite sandals

fields.headline: Traklite sandals
fields.trailText: The Traklite sandal claims to offer protection for hill walkers' feet when crossing rough terrain, thanks to the incorporation of an outer toe, side and heel wall designed to to prevent chafing and blisters.
fields.body:
Fancy a hill walk but don't fancy donning your heavy hiking boots this summer?

A new kind of sandal has been developed which promises to provide all the support your feet need. The Traklite sandal claims to offer protection for hill walkers' feet when crossing rough terrain, thanks to the incorporation of an outer toe, side and heel wall designed to to prevent chafing and blisters. A cushioned midsole contains thousands of tiny air bubbles for shock absorption every time the sandal hits the ground.

The lightweight leather sandals come in two styles: the Traklite Trekker, which has a single front strap making it easier to get on and off; and the Traveller, which has double front straps for a secure fit. Now there's no excuse for wearing socks with your sandals this summer.

Available by calling Brasher Boot Company (01524 841000; www.brasher.co.uk). Traklite Travellers cost £60 a pair, while the Traklite Trekkers are £55. Both carry a two-year guarantee.

webTitle: Bonanza of cheap-flight deals to US

fields.headline: Bonanza of cheap-flight deals to US
fields.standfirst: Joanna Walters  reports on how foot and mouth has created a glut of unsold seats
fields.trailText: Florida fly-drive prices as low as £199 could be on the way back as we head for the summer and British travellers can look forward to a bargain bonanza on US flights in general.
fields.body:
Florida fly-drive prices as low as £199 could be on the way back as we head for the summer and British travellers can look forward to a bargain bonanza on US flights in general.

Transatlantic scheduled airlines are becoming nervous about thousands of empty seats left unsold for May, June and even into July as the Americans stay away from Britain because of the foot and mouth crisis.

Fares such as £299 return to Orlando for June are already emerging, down by£50-£100 on the same flights this time last year, said Andrew Boyle at the Travelcare independent travel agency chain.

He said it was likely prices would drop below £200, both for scheduled flight-only and for flight plus car-hire, before the spring was out.

'In previous years when there is too much capacity at this time, the airlines panic quite far in advance. This year they are trying to hold their nerve as they go into June, but they are starting to get jittery,' he said.

The mass market holiday brands such as Thomson and Airtours use their own charter airlines which are tailored to the the UK market and so are less likely to be affected - unless they are drawn into a price war.

But smaller operators who book holidaymakers on to scheduled flights with British Airways, Virgin Atlantic and some of the US carriers, are likely to start offering discounted fly-drives and all-in packages in the next few weeks. High street and internet agents, bucket shops, Teletext and the airlines themselves are also likely to start marketing cheap flight-only tickets.

There is also likely to be a booking lull out of the UK in the run-up to the expected general election in early June. Bookings are likely to pick up in the few weeks immediately after the election, industry observers said.

It is not just Florida where bargain hunters are likely to strike gold, although that is where most of the spare capacity is currently flying.

Michael East, of travel consultancy Eastcastle, said scheduled airlines are likely to start discounting to cities such as New York, Boston, Chicago and San Francisco.

'If there are significant price cuts to the US it will draw in people from the UK who will switch from short-haul to long-haul,' he said.

webTitle: A bad day for democracy

fields.headline: A bad day for democracy
fields.standfirst:
Noreena Hertz, academic and author of an acclaimed critique of globalisation, joined last week's May Day protesters. What she saw was an unholy alliance of police and media

Special report: Mayday
fields.trailText: Noreena Hertz,  academic and author of an acclaimed critique of globalisation, joined last week's May Day protesters. What she saw was an unholy alliance of police and media.
fields.body:
She couldn't have been more than 20. Dressed in a maroon, long-sleeved T-shirt, pink, knee-length skirt and no overcoat, she must have been freezing, because it was bitterly cold on Tuesday, May Day, the day the city at play became the city at war.

For me, this anonymous girl-woman I saw armed with no weapon other than a bunch of pink flowers and a balloon, who stood 10 inches away from a cordon of Darth Vader-helmeted riot police, staring into their eyes so courageously that I saw the policeman opposite her turn away in shame, epitomised what the protest on Tuesday had become: 'them' against 'us'. And, frankly, the 'us' on Tuesday is an 'us' that I am not proud to be part of.

That day, central London was a city under siege, not by the protesters - there were not that many of them - but by the police and the media, who outnumbered them by far. Two forces that seemed intent on pigeonholing the marchers as the great unwashed and violent to boot. Two forces often in the past at odds, but for that day united, intent on protecting property rights, not people's right to free expression.

The back-slapping we witnessed the next day - Tony Blair and William Hague's joint congratulation of the Metropolitan Police in the House of Commons, the proclaimed victory of Sir John Stevens's planning in the Mail , Guardian and Mirror , praise for Red Ken's zero-tolerance strategy - was confirmation that this take on the affair was one shared by all the powers that be, regardless of party allegiance.

If even the liberal elite marks the police's efforts as a triumph, something is clearly awry. For penning thousands of people into Oxford Circus, so that girls had to pee squatting surrounded by their friends, so that people dressed as mermaids and clowns grew thirsty and hungry, denied food or water for hours on end, so that those who only a few hours before had been peacefully dancing to the rhythm of carnival drummers were disallowed their right to be heard, is not the mark of a democratic society, but of a society that acts in the interests of the many and ignores the rights of the few.

Of course, there was always some threat of violence by a minority and I did find the masked faces of the Wombles menacing rather than funny, but nothing warranted such an overreaction by the state. The droning of the helicopters, motorcycle cavalcade after cavalcade, police van after police van, handcuffs and truncheons, the threat of rubber bullets and the ominous reality of black shields testified to the hundreds of thousands of pounds of taxpayers' money spent in the purported defence of the realm. In fact, the apparatus of the state was not being used to protect a general public interest, but that of a very particular group.

At its essence, Tuesday was not about globalisation or capitalism but them and us, those included in society versus those kept out, those served by politicians versus the politically dispossessed, a smashed shop window perceived as a greater evil than a cause left unheard.

Exclusion was the word on the protesters' lips: exclusion from the system itself and, most worryingly, from the whole political process. When I asked the bike riders and cartoon characters around me whether they were planning to vote at the forthcoming election, the question provoked much mirth. 'Vote! Why vote? What for?' a young guy who'd travelled down from Barnsley to take part in the protests asked me. This was a sentiment not particular to those youths who gathered in the rain, or the 18-year-old girls in fairy outfits and boys with 'Stop the Cuba embargo' badges, but shared by the young throughout the UK. Only 44 per cent of 18- to 24-year-olds voted at the last election, and 71 per cent of 16- to 21-year-olds feel that whoever they vote for, it would make no difference to their lives. It was our youth who stood in the rain and cold in that pen.

But it isn't only the young who feel alienated from politics: the poor and socially excluded feel the same way. I also spoke that day with homeless men, single mothers and dole claimants who shared this lack of faith in traditional politics. 'I don't believe my vote matters,' I was told repeatedly.

And indeed the correlation between low social and economic status and voter abstention is becoming ever more pronounced. In the Benwall ward of Newcastle, one of the UK's most deprived inner-city areas, where three-quarters of children live in households with no earned income, voter turnout at the 1999 local election was only 19.4 per cent.

Surely both these groups, the young and the socially and economically excluded, represent an untapped market opportunity for any political party. So why are politicians concentrating their energies on swing voters instead of trying to reach out to this group? Why do they seem intent on putting them down?

Laziness? Fear? An unwillingness to concede that the brand of capitalism now proselytised by parties of Left and Right may lie at the core of the problem? All these go some way to explaining politicians' inertness. Of course, it is undoubtedly easier to ignore this group, to act to preserve the status quo. And there is a real risk that by trying to address these constituents' concerns, a party could alienate itself from its core vote.

To tackle the needs of these non-voters, of which a visible subset were the 5,000 who chose to stand outside in the cold, we would need politicians brave enough to accept that some of the tenets they preach may be fundamentally flawed: wealth may not always trickle down, privatisation may not always be the best solution, the unchecked growing dominance of corporations may need more than the market to keep it in control.

Today's politicians have no intention of engaging in such a debate. As ideologies have converged, they have become purveyors of a homogenised politics, which fights for the middle ground and essentially represents the ever growing middle class, increasingly distancing itself from a large part of the electorate.

It is wrong to see May Day as a triumph for the state. Instead, we must see it as evidence of its failure, a sign of weakness rather than strength. Instead of celebrating a wonderful policing effort, we must ask ourselves whether our defence of orthodoxy has gone too far. Is it right that the apparatus of the state should be used not to protect but to conquer, not to include but to divide?

We need to enter into a dialogue, to air the concerns espoused that day and not shut them away. Nor must we forget the girl with the bunch of flowers and the balloon who stood in the cold and the policeman who turned his face away in shame.

webTitle: Dance masters

fields.headline: Dance masters
fields.standfirst: Rupert Mellor  visits Salvador, home to an acrobatic martial art that spawned breakdancing in the US and has now become a craze sweeping Europe
fields.trailText: Rupert Mellor visits Salvador, home to an acrobatic martial art that spawned breakdancing in the US and has now become a craze sweeping Europe.
fields.body:
It was last year's Nokia TV ad that clinched it. That lithe, tanned, laughing couple tumbling and cartwheeling in a flurry of white linen and whiter teeth, sunshine twinkling poetically on the sea behind them, officially sealed the transition of a Brazilian martial art/dance/game from underground sport to big bucks, corporate eye-candy. Capoeira, you've come a long way, baby.

A dazzlingly energetic, non-contact mix of jumps, kicks, spins and artful dodges, capoeira's exact origins aren't clear - some say it was born in Brazil, others that it was transplanted there from Angola - but this martial art grew up in the country's Bahia region among Africans taken into slavery by Portuguese traders, around 400 years ago.

With any form of combat training among black slaves strictly forbidden by the Portuguese authorities, capoeira evolved, disguising fighting moves in an acrobatic competitive dance performed to music, which kept slaves strong, and rebellion at least a possibility. Still illegal - and punishable with the amputation of an arm or leg - as recently as the Twenties, capoeira found a new direction in the decades that followed as a form of artistic expression, not to mention an exciting and demanding form of exercise.

Human traffic has taken the game global - Brazilian emigrants have set up capoeira schools all over the world. Capoeira gained a worldwide media profile in the Eighties, when American street dancers cited the game as a major influence on breaking, and now capoeira is played on New York club dance floors, taught at Eton and, of course, sells phones.

Today a gaggle of travellers wearing the T-shirt of their chosen capoeira school are a daily sight on the streets of Bahia's capital, Salvador da Bahia de Todos os Santos. They come from all over the planet to train on the game's home turf. Airtours' introduction tomorrow of a direct nine-hour weekly flight to Salvador from the UK, cutting out the usual Rio de Janeiro or São Paulo detour, which turns the trip from long-haul into a thrombosis-friendly marathon, can only swell their numbers.

Intrigued by capoeira for years, but with no experience, I made my own pilgrimage last October, armed with phone numbers for a few capoeira schools, a pair of gigantic white trousers and five words of Portuguese. The first few days of a seven-week trip to Brazil - spent on beaches and in bars in sophisticated Rio de Janeiro - did nothing to prepare me for the multisensory assault that is Salvador. This city, dogged though it is by unemployment, poverty and crime, is one sweaty, sexy, round-the-clock party.

Salvador is a unique cultural collision. It is essentially an African community (the abolition of slavery in 1888 left tens of thousands of free citizens of African descent living in Salvador, and today they make up 80 per cent of the 2 million population) spliced into a once opulent colonial city built on a dramatic series of cliffs, bluffs and steep hills, and baked for four centuries in the steamy Latin heat. The rich smells of shrimp and palm oil hang in the air - testament to the African cookery traditions central to the Bahian diet. The streets bustle with people and there's no escaping the local styles of music pouring from open-air clubs, public stages, ghetto blasters and street musicians.

And capoeira is everywhere. Circles of capoeiristas gather in the public spaces in front of poetically crumbling baroque churches, clapping, singing and playing esoteric musical instruments, while players cartwheel into the roda (circle of seated players) in pairs to play their best moves off each other. People practise all day long, backflipping on the palm-lined beaches, even sparring in the street, and everyone you meet seems to play at least a little.

In fact, as a gringo novice, the only difficulty in getting some capoeira action is the massive range of available options. Which style: Angolan (graceful, slow, low to the ground) or Regional (all-leaping, all-whirling acrobatic variety)? Which school? And how to deal with the nerve-wracking machismo of the many teachers and touts who assure you, punching their fists into their palms, 'My school is the best. The hardest. You join, yes?'

Eventually finding some teachers more sympathetic to the needs of a 33-year-old (Bahian capoeiristas start training as kids, even toddlers) looking to ease himself gently into the game, I turned up for my first Capoeira Regional class, at the Associacão de Capoeira Mestre Bimba in Pelhourinho. Being white, the oldest student by 10 years and rather taller than your average Brazilian, my lack of skill and agility was conspicuous, but even though everyone's play often had to be slowed down to accommodate me, my classmates' tolerance and support were clear. So too was their loud amusement when, within minutes of starting my capoeira career, I slipped in my own sweat and crashed to the ground.

The scariest moment was having to play in my first roda - learners have to get in the ring with everyone else from day one - to which challenge I responded by freezing to the spot for two agonisingly long minutes.

Keen to stop being the crappiest capoeirista in town I also signed up with the excellent SSA school for 10 exhausting, exhilarating classes a week. I soon got into some kind of swing. Taking a lunchtime class at Mestre Nenel at Bimba's in Pelhourinho, I'd then ride a bus down to Barra to relax on the jammed, jumping beach before the evening session with SSA's Professore Zezo. Sometimes this would take place at a swanky health club, sometimes on a basketball court, or on the unfinished concrete car park behind Zezo's mate's apartment block, or on one memorable occasion, on the beach, where under the stars, four English girls and I were good-naturedly goaded by our classmates into attempting somersaults and aerial manoeuvres too scary for gringos to contemplate on a hard floor.

Proper rodas, where the whole session is spent playing in a circle, came around once a week, and while I took a long time to feel comfortable flailing and lunging under such scrutiny, the skills and speed of the more experienced players was never anything but top-quality entertainment. My new favourite game brought with it episodes of trance-like serenity too. An hour could be spent running endlessly, all in unison, through fluid steps and moves in moonlight, the only sound the rhythmic pads and scrapes of 12 pairs of well-worn trainers on concrete.

Before I left Salvador, the moment every capoeirista secretly dreams of happened to me. Players I met all had fiercely cool capoeira names like Tigra (Tiger), Fantasma (Ghost) or Macaco (Monkey). How, I wondered, does one come by such a name? At my last class before heading back home, Helena, my partner that day in a gruelling sequence of kicks and dodges, announced: 'I know what your capoeirista name must be. You are Cous Cous!'

It wasn't quite the kick-ass alias I'd hoped for. It sure wasn't Panther. With a faint sense of foreboding, I ducked sideways to avoid the foot she was directing at my head and asked her, 'Why Cous Cous? ' She ran her finger down my sweat-dripping arm with a look of faint disgust and said: 'In Brazil cous cous is a cake you have at breakfast. You steam it, so when the cake is cooking, a lot of water comes out of it.'

Sometimes this would take place at a swanky health club, sometimes on a basketball court, or on the unfinished concrete car park behind Zezo's mate's apartment block, or on one memorable occasion, on the beach, where under the stars, four English girls and I were good-naturedly goaded by our classmates into attempting somersaults and aerial manoeuvres too scary for gringos to contemplate on a hard floor. Proper rodas, where the whole session is spent playing in a circle, came around once a week, and while I took a long time to feel comfortable flailing and lunging under such scrutiny, the skills and speed of the more experienced players was never anything but top-quality entertainment. My new favourite game brought with it episodes of trance-like serenity too. An hour could be spent running endlessly, all in unison, through fluid steps and moves in moonlight, the only sound the rhythmic pads and scrapes of 12 pairs of well-worn trainers on concrete. Before I left Salvador, the moment every capoeirista secretly dreams of happened to me. Players I met all had fiercely cool capoeira names like Tigra (Tiger), Fantasma (Ghost) or Macaco (Monkey). How, I wondered, does one come by such a name? At my last class before heading back home, Helena, my partner that day in a gruelling sequence of kicks and dodges, announced: 'I know what your capoeirista name must be. You are Cous Cous!' It wasn't quite the kick-ass alias I'd hoped for. It sure wasn't Panther. With a faint sense of foreboding, I ducked sideways to avoid the foot she was directing at my head and asked her, 'Why Cous Cous? ' She ran her finger down my sweat-dripping arm with a look of faint disgust and said: 'In Brazil cous cous is a cake you have at breakfast. You steam it, so when the cake is cooking, a lot of water comes out of it.'

webTitle: Huddersfield lose four-way fight

fields.headline: Huddersfield lose four-way fight
fields.trailText: Huddersfield's six-year stay in the First Division ended in tears, recrimination and disbelief as they lost a determined fight for survival amid ugly scenes at the McAlpine Stadium.
fields.byline: Dave Alexander at the McAlpine stadium
fields.body:
Huddersfield's six-year stay in the First Division ended in tears, recrimination and disbelief as they lost a determined fight for survival amid ugly scenes at the McAlpine Stadium.

Twelve months ago Town were edged out of a play-off place on the final day but the expression on the face of a devastated Lou Macari showed it was a very different finale yesterday.

The manager had orchestrated a dramatic comeback, losing just six matches out of 26 League games, after the club were eight points behind second bottom Stockport in November to take them clear of the bottom three and he clearly had difficulty coming to terms with yesterday's turn of events.

The Scot was subdued and found difficulty expressing his feelings but that could not be said about furious Huddersfield fans who reacted with anger to the prospect of Second Division football again after being promised so much in the past two years.

Hundreds demonstrated outside the ground where they turned angrily on chairman Barry Rubery and police had to move in to rescue the millionaire as he attempted to leave the stadium after the game.

Rubery tried to talk to the fans but when they closed in, and objects started to be thrown, police quickly escorted him back into the stadium and closed off the front of the building.

Rubery represented a bright new future when he bought the club for £15m but his misplaced optimism was evident again in his programme notes as he assured fans the club would be aiming for the First Division play-offs next season, signing off with 'I look forward to seeing you all back here in August in Division One'.

Quite a few of them will not be back for Division Two after demanding Rubery's resignation and then chanting the name of Marcus Stewart, the striker controversially sold last season when the team were in a play-off position.

The £2.5m departure of their idol to Ipswich infuriated fans who claimed the club's decline, and their antipathy towards Rubery, can be traced back to that time. But he insisted after the game he would not be resigning and added: "I take full responsibility for this."

Certainly, the near 20,000 crowd did not attach any blame to Macari, who must have been close to breaking his teetotal rule for the first time.

The way his players squandered chances, quite apart from throwing away the points by poor defending, was enough to drive the strongest manager to drink.

"We had a mountain to climb this season and we nearly got to the top but when we needed it to happen today, it didn't," he said. "But it's not just today, it's what happened earlier in the season.

"It's been a long, hard slog and the slog ended like this. The players have done well and fought well for months and it's come to such a sad end. There is absolute silence in the dressing room and a few tears, everybody is just so very disappointed at what's happened.

"It's difficult to know what to say after we got ourselves out of the bottom three. It was down to what we did today and we did not do it.

"The last six months of effort has been fantastic from everyone. Unfortunately it's come down to this today when we've failed to get what we needed."

Ironically, they were condemned by a Yorkshireman, Curtis Woodhouse, who moved to City from Sheffield United for £1m this season and came up with his first goals for the club yesterday.

Woodhouse struck in the 21st minute with Town's Andy Booth equalising in the final seconds of first-half normal time before the City midfielder pounced again just two minutes later.

His goals mean City now face Preston in the play-off semi-finals with the first leg at St Andrews.

They were already assured of a play-off place but manager Trevor Francis was coldly professional in his summary of the game. Asked if he had sympathy for Huddersfield Francis replied: "No. We came here looking to win, we wanted to finish fourth and have the second leg at St Andrews under floodlights.

"That hasn't happened but we have gone five games unbeaten. There was plenty of incentive for us to come here and try to win. I don't think we are in a better position for the play-offs than previous years, I'd be more confident if we didn't have so many injuries."

Woodhouse finished off a nine-pass City move to open the scoring, cleverly lifting his finish over keeper Nico Vaesen after it was set up by Stan Lazaridis.

Booth equalised, bundling in a dangerous cross from Ben Thornley but Town were stunned when Woodhouse stole in at the back post unmarked to head in an Andy Johnson cross.

Town missed three chances in 11 first-half minutes with Thornley's drive deflected against a post by Darren Purse in the 29th minute and Simon Baldry missing from close in after a Thornley cross a minute later. But Booth should have buried his header in the 40th minute after a perfect cross from Craig Armstrong. Instead, the big striker hit a post.

And he was guilty again in the 80th minute when a poor touch let a clear opportunity slip just yards out - and then he saw Ian Bennett pull off a point-blank stop from his header in the 87th minute.

"When you look back at the Andy Booth miss and the way we hit the post it's hard," added Macari. "We paid a price today and paid heavily."

Man of the Match: Curtis Woodhouse.

webTitle: Quick Escapes

fields.headline: Quick Escapes
fields.trailText: Under £200
fields.body:
Under £200

This time next week you could be sipping a Pastis at a street-side cafe in Paris. Eurotours (0870 333 0889, www.eurotours.co.uk) still has availability for late afternoon departures by Eurostar from 4 May for £199 per person. B&B accommodation is at the modern two-star Hotel Hameau de Paris situated in the chic 16th arrondissement area known for its classy boutiques and trendy restaurants.

Turkey: Stay in the newly-built self-catering Derya Villas near Kas, south west Turkey for £150 per person with Direct Line Holidays (020 8239 3399, www.directlineholidays.com) Temperatures are in the upper 70s during May and there are few tourists. A courtesy car will take you to the centre of Kas where you will find supermarkets, bars and restaurants. Return flights from Gatwick and accommodation based on two people sharing are included in the price.

Under £300

Suffolk: Fancy cruising round the Suffolk countryside in a head-turning Aston Martin DB6 or a Ferrari Dino? Grand Touring Club (01449 737 774, www.grandtouringclub.co.uk) is offering a 10 per cent discount on its classic car weekend breaks during May and June. A two-night break starts from £248 per person and includes hire of a classic car from a choice of seven, B&B accommodation in a guesthouse, comprehensive motor insurance, 24-hour breakdown cover, advice line and area route books.

Athens: Time Off (0870 584 6363) is offering two nights B&B accommodation at the two-star Hotel Philippos, situated at the foot of the Acropolis, from £259 per person until 16 May. Flights with Virgin Atlantic from Gatwick and transfers are included in the price.

Under £400

Italy: Peace and tranquility awaits at the four-star Hotel KingÕs Residence situated in a national park on the Palinuro Cape near Cilento. Citalia (020 8686 0677, www.citalia.co.uk) is offering seven nights for £369 per person including half-board accommodation, return flights and car hire.

Dubai: Just Dubai (020 7258 2001, www.justdubai.com) is offering three-night breaks at the Pearl Residence Apartments for £399 per person until the end of June. The price is based on four adults sharing and includes return flights from Birmingham, B&B accommodation and transfers.

Under £500 Tunisia: Spend a week at the five-star Imperial Marhaba Hotel in Port El Kantaoui between 11 and 24 May for £489 with Wigmore Holidays (020 7836 4999). The price reduces to £449 between 1 and 23 June. Return scheduled flights from Heathrow or Gatwick, transfers and B&B accommodation are included in the price.

Western Mediterranean: Festival Cruises (020 7734 0005, www.festivalcruises.com) has reduced the price of its seven-night Western Mediterranean cruise for departures on 6 and 13 May. The ex-Genoa trip takes in Rome, Naples, Malta, Tunis, Mahon in Minorca, Barcelona and Marseilles. Prices start at £445 for an inside cabin.

Under £600 Thailand: Combine Bangkok and Koh Samui in a 10-night trip departing on 16 May for £533 per person with Qantas Holidays (020 8222 9104). Passengers fly on scheduled flights from Heathrow to Bangkok where they spend three-nights at the Asia Hotel before travelling to Koh Samui for a seven-night stay at the Central Samui Village Hotel.

Las Vegas: Blow your money in the gambling capital of the world on a seven-night trip with Thomas Cook Holidays (0870 443 4446) for £589 per person. Departures are between 19 May and 30 June from Gatwick and room-only accommodation at the Riviera Hotel and Casino is included.

Dominican Republic: Lunn Poly (0870 333 4400, www.lunnpoly.com) is offering a 14-night Thomson Holiday for £569 per person for departures on 16 May from Gatwick.

Over £1,000 Mauritius: Kuoni (01306 747000, www.kuoni.co.uk) still has availability at the lively Merville Beach hotel located next to a white sandy bay for departures between 11 May and 30 June. A 12-night break starts from £1069 per person including return flights, transfers and half-board accommodation.

Bahamas: Swim with the dolphins on an eight-night trip with Discover the World (01737 218 802, www.arctic-discover.co.uk). The wild spotted dolphin congregates in the crystal clear waters of North Bimini during June. Six four-hour boat trips with experienced guides, kayaking, scuba diving and fishing are included in the £1,627 price.

webTitle: Paupers bid the princes a rude farewell

fields.headline: Paupers bid the princes a rude farewell
fields.trailText: Same division, different league, off the field at least. Across the white line, however, commitment and resolve can often amount to a stronger force than talent fitfully applied, and for 90 minutes the paupers of the First Division stuffed it up the princes good and proper.
fields.body:
Same division, different league, off the field at least. Across the white line, however, commitment and resolve can often amount to a stronger force than talent fitfully applied, and for 90 minutes the paupers of the First Division stuffed it up the princes good and proper.

Certainly any lingering fondness the Fulham players might have harboured for the Nationwide League will have been well and truly banished by their final bruising experience.

The Mariners deserved this. Collectively worth half what Fulham paid for a Latvian midfielder called Andrejs Stolcers - who was utterly ineffective yesterday - they fought like tigers to preserve the status that is crucial to the club's future.

No club in the division attracts fewer supporters than Grimsby, and to have been deprived of next year's massively increased TV money - £2.5m is the latest estimate -would have sent the club into a spiral from which it might not have been able to extract itself.

Anticipating a celebration, not to mention some decent fish 'n' chips, Fulham fans travelled to Cleethorpes in number and in plenty of time. Unfortunately it appeared the players had travelled in a similar frame of mind.

Needing a point to be safe, Grimsby set their stall out early. With Steve Livingstone as a solitary target up front, they packed midfield and defence, tackled like madmen, closed down anything that moved into their half of the pitch and defended with their lives.

Fulham, one sensed, would really rather have been elsewhere, but in Louis Saha and Luis Boa Morte they have in abundance the one thing that can frighten any team, however determined; pace.

Twice in the opening quarter they got beyond the Grimsby defence; in the 10th minute Boa Morte shot wide, and in the 19th, put clear by Saha, the Portugese striker had his shot blocked by Grimsby goalkeeper Danny Coyne.

Otherwise, for all they stroked the ball around Fulham barely threatened. Nor, it must be said, did Grimsby - except once. Shortly before the half hour, Livingstone laid the ball off for his captain Paul Groves to try his luck from 22 yards.

Groves hit it low and cleanly enough, but it was no bullet. Even so, it somehow squeezed under Marcus Hahnemann, Fulham's reserve goalkeeper.

And that, effectively, was that. Fulham went through the motions, Grimsby refused to give them a glimpse of daylight near their penalty area, and their supporters were celebrating survival with half an hour still to play.

Man of the match: Danny Butterfield (Grimsby)

webTitle: Rix can sleep in peace now the nightmare is over

fields.headline: Rix can sleep in peace now the nightmare is over
fields.trailText: From the celebrations it was easy to believe Portsmouth had won the Champions League, never mind escaped the drop again on the final day. The players cavorted as their chairman Milan Mandaric and his manager Graham Rix strode arm-in-arm towards the delirious supporters. Rix grabbed a microphone to promise: "This will not happen again."
fields.body:
From the celebrations it was easy to believe Portsmouth had won the Champions League, never mind escaped the drop again on the final day. The players cavorted as their chairman Milan Mandaric and his manager Graham Rix strode arm-in-arm towards the delirious supporters. Rix grabbed a microphone to promise: "This will not happen again."

Given that it is now three times in six seasons that Pompey have avoided falling into the Second Division on the last weekend, the fans will believe that when they see it. But next year can wait. Their team had started the afternoon in the bottom three and, once the nervous wait for confirmation that Crystal Palace had won only 1-0 at Stockport was over, everyone could salute another great escape.

"Those two or three minutes were agonising," said a drained but delighted Rix. "We had the radio on in the laundry room but I couldn't listen to it. The relief when I realised we were staying up was immense. I'll sleep well the next few weeks. It's been tough, by far the toughest few weeks I've had in football."

After the wretched 4-2 home defeat by Palace last Wednesday, Pompey knew they had to win by two more goals than Palace to be sure of survival. However, Huddersfield's defeat meant any victory would have sufficed and they rose to the occasion, managing their first win in 10 matches. Where they had been passionless in midweek, they were impressively committed here against a disappointing Barnsley side who arrived with nothing at stake.

"I thought they played some great football under intense pressure," said Rix, who claimed his two-and-a-half months in charge have felt more like 20 years.

Only after the lively Kevin Harper scored Pompey's third goal in the 75th minute could they be sure of victory, though even then Garry Brady added to the tension by getting himself sent off for butting Darren Bullock. No one could have been surprised at that. It had been a bizarre day. Before kick-off Mandaric walked on to the pitch to tell the fans he loved them and would not leave the club. Then the Serbo-American, who has invested around £22m in Pompey, joined the impressively raucous fans behind one goal for the first 40 minutes clutching a bell.

Pompey had attacked with intent from the word go. Lee Bradbury had already forced a good save out of Kevin Miller when he scored the first in the 17th minute, forcing in a Scott Hiley cross at the third attempt. Pompey had to wait until just after the hour for their second. Gary O'Neil followed up after Miller had saved from Harper and, after Barnsley had twice gone close, Harper finished from Lovell's cross to leave ears pinned to radios for news from elsewhere.

Once Palace's result and Huddersfield's defeat were confirmed, the celebrations began in earnest. Rix, like everyone else, will be praying this does not happen again.

Man of the match: Kevin Harper (Portsmouth).

webTitle: How my office was turned into a five-star bedroom

fields.headline: How my office was turned into a five-star bedroom
fields.standfirst: Tourists will sleep in the newsroom and drink in the features department. Ex-editor  Alan Ruddock on the reinvention of the Scotsman as a hotel
fields.trailText: Tourists will sleep in the newsroom and drink in the features department. Ex-editor Alan Ruddock on the reinvention of the Scotsman as a hotel.
fields.body:
For twenty-four hours I found it hard to shake off a sense of unreality. Arriving in Edinburgh to be greeted by bright sunshine was unsettling enough, but wandering around the old offices of the Scotsman, now a five-star hotel, was downright weird.

There was nothing five-star about the old building when I was there: purpose built at the start of the last century as a newspaper office, it was a phenomenon of its time. It sprawled over nine different levels, a one-stop newspaper production plant that opened straight on to the sidings at Waverley station.

It was a seamless production process, from scribbling, to hot metal, to bundles of newspapers on a train heading for far-flung parts of Scotland. Or at least the outer edges of the Lothians.

By the time I arrived as editor in May 1998, the idea of the building being purpose built for newspapers was risible. The lower levels, where the presses used to be, were dark cavernous spaces, filled with the detritus of years of newspaper production. It was a place you hurried through on your way to the car park and where, inevitably, you got lost.

The Scotsman operated from the third floor, with its departments scattered in a variety of cubby-holes and dark offices. The editor's suite was wonderfully grand, with oak-panelled walls and imposing portraits of former editors. In stark contrast, the newsroom was a dreadful place lit by mind-altering yellow uplights and was horribly overcrowded. The rest of the building, with the notable exception of the senior executives' suite, was a rabbit warren of offices spread haphazardly across the various floors.

What was ideal in the early 1900s had become unmanageable by the end of the century: there was a real sense of relief when we finally moved out in October 1999 to the sleek modernism of a new building down by the site of Scotland's new Parliament.

Quite how anybody could look at that building and see a five-star hotel was something none of us could understand at the time. The man who did was Jonathan Wix, who had already created the highly regarded 42 The Calls in Leeds. Eighteen months and £19.5 million later, he has got his five-star hotel.

Or very nearly. Although open for business, the hotel is far from finished. Builders hammer away as they rush to finish restaurants, a leisure centre complete with stainless steel swimming pool, a night club and several conference areas. Of the 68 bedrooms and suites, about 40 are ready for guests, with the rest due on stream within weeks. The ultimate deadline has to be the series of festivals that take over Edinburgh for most of August.

Soon after I arrived last Monday I started to poke around, trying to work out what had gone where. The newsroom, mercifully, is no more. In its place is a collection of bedrooms: people will now pay - rather than be paid - to sleep there. The old features department is, suitably, a bar, its wall lined with back-lit bottles of malt whiskies - it claims to have 399 in stock and on display.

My old office is a bedroom, and quite an impressive one at that. It was always an imposing room, with a sweeping view of the New Town through its three-cornered windows. It was a strange feeling, standing in the middle of that room. It used to host smoky conferences enlivened by occasional spats. In my first month at the paper I had sat dutifully by the window and listened to the Chancellor's views on macro-economics and why Scottish nationalism was a busted flush; now, the office will host excitable tourists and dour financiers unaware of what went before.

At least the original conductors' pledge, taken from the 1816 prospectus for the newspaper, is still there, looking somewhat incongruous now. Before we vacated the building I had tried, but failed, to prise it off the wall, but it wouldn't budge. I thought some loutish builder would hack it to pieces, but it has survived intact.

The same cannot be said for the roll call of editors from 1817 onwards which used to be etched on the panelling opposite what is now the bar. They have been painted over, but Andrew Buchanan, the general manager, assures me that they will be reinstated.

I was the last one on the wall, with my finish date left blank. A few months after moving to Holyrood, I had been turfed out by the paper's owners but I liked the idea that in the hotel, my editorship would seem timeless: 1998-infinity. Now it's just black paint, but I will come back to check whether Buchanan fulfils his pledge.

Judging the hotel before it is fully open, and before it has had a chance to settle down, would be harsh. It has the potential to be stunning, and to be by far the best hotel in Scotland's capital, but there is still a long way to go to fulfil that potential.

In its favour is a collection of bedrooms and suites that are individual and generally spacious: no two are the same and the peculiar contours of the building throw up some great nooks. In some rooms, roll-topped baths sit in turret spaces with spectacular views over the city.

A magnificent split-level penthouse, complete with sauna and a balcony with a barbecue and breathtaking roof-top views, will set you back £800 a night; a more modest double room £149, with options in between. All come with widescreen TV, DVD players and a remote keyboard that allows you to get on the internet.

Despite its five-star aspirations, the Scotsman has steered clear of five-star rip-offs. You will pay a fair whack for your room, but they won't insult you by charging £2 for a mini-bar Mars bar. The rooms are stocked with decent wines at normal bar prices, and snacks at shop prices. Similarly, the bar and restaurant prices are reasonable: a superb eggs benedict for breakfast is just £5, a bar bill for four drinks just £11: not what you'd expect in a normal five star.

The star attractions - fine dining room, the brasserie and bar in the dramatic old entrance hall and the leisure centre - will be ready in a couple of months and if the standards match what is already on offer in microcosm, the Scotsman won't struggle to fill its rooms.

People will quibble with some of the design and some of the colour schemes - there is a prepon derance of black and a lot of tartan - and some bizarre lights, but mostly it works.

Perhaps my approval is coloured by what went before: I know what it was like, and what has been achieved is remarkable. Those without a sense of the place's history will just judge it against the Balmoral or the Caledonian and worry about value for money. I suspect they'll get it.

The final element in the Scotsman's development will be the night club. Since a few of the rooms are already named after former editors, some wags have suggested it should be named after the paper's current publisher Andrew Neil, a Tramp habitué, and the man who dispatched me. But he will be disappointed: the hotel wants the night club pitched at the mature end of the market.

The Scotsman Hotel (0131 556 5565, www.scotsmanhotel.co.uk) has a special introductory weekend break rate of £90 till 30 June (for two sharing, including breakfast). Thereafter, double room prices start at £149

Hot off the press

Here are a few other luxury hotels that were once media haunts:

London's Langham Hilton (020 763 1000) was converted from BBC offices, canteen and studios before opening in 1991. The Palm Court tearoom was a recording studio for Radio 3. From £295 a night.

One Aldwych in London (The Leading Small Hotels of the World 0800 181123) was built in 1907 to house the Morning Post newspaper for 30 years. It opened as a hotel in 1998. From £275 a night.

Le Faubourg Sofitel Demeure Hotel in Paris (020 8283 4570) housed the offices of the Marie Claire magazine group before opening as a hotel in 1999. From Ff1,850 (£185) a room.

The Hotel Bel-Ami in Paris (Design Hotels 0800 169 8817) is in a building occupied by the National Printers in the eighteenth century. From £175 a night.

The Hotel Lindrum in Melbourne, Australia (Design Hotels 0800 169 8817) was once home to the Herald paper. From £92 a night.
