webTitle: Palace released by Freedman

fields.headline: Palace released by Freedman
fields.trailText: If Dougie Freedman does nothing else during his football career, the Crystal Palace striker's name has been etched in Selhurst Park folklore. With three minutes of a nerve-wracking final day remaining and Palace occupying the third relegation place to teeter on the brink of the Second Division, up popped the 31-year-old to break Huddersfield hearts.
fields.body:
If Dougie Freedman does nothing else during his football career, the Crystal Palace striker's name has been etched in Selhurst Park folklore. With three minutes of a nerve-wracking final day remaining and Palace occupying the third relegation place to teeter on the brink of the Second Division, up popped the 31-year-old to break Huddersfield hearts.

"Dougie said at half-time he would give us one bit of magic and it came eventually," said the visitors' caretaker manager, Steve Kember, whose post-match celebrations were interrupted by a phone call of congratulations from the former manager Steve Coppell.

"It was mission impossible when I took over, so the feeling ranks with the two promotions we achieved here when I was a player. The club has been through so much in the last two years that relegation would have been very, very tough.

The decisive goal owed much to good fortune. David Hopkin's blatant handball on the edge of his own area was missed by the officials and the Scot punted into the home half. Clinton Morrison trapped the ball, but Dougie Freedman nicked it off his toes and tore forward, teasing Rob Clare as he skipped into the area. With a clear sight on goal, the Scot ripped his shot beyond Lee Jones.

"The handball was the turning point," added Kember, who intends to apply for the vacant post, "but with five minutes to go I was starting to give up. I should have had more faith."

The shattered deadlock provoked a minor pitch invasion from the 3,000 away supporters, yet their celebrations remained horribly premature. Once Palace had survived a nerve-jangling ending - Alex Kolinko doing well to claim his team-mate Jamie Smith's header with the net gaping - there were still five minutes of tension as the closing stages of Huddersfield's defeat were relayed across the terraces. Relief brought pandemonium.

"I've never experienced anything like the few minutes after we'd finished until we heard Town's result," grinned Freedman.

"Stevie Kember has done a brilliant job since he came in last week. He just told us we were favourites to go down, so why not just pass the ball and see what happens? No pressure."

Not that many crammed inside Edgeley Park would have agreed. There were more nervous nudges than slick passing in the first half, with a succession of Palace corners bringing nothing more than booming headed clearances from County's gargantuan defenders.

For their part, Stockport muscled a way towards earning a double win-bonus. Glynn Hurst miscontrolled on the edge of the six-yard box, while the visiting support breathed a sigh of relief when Karim Fradin rose to nod Ali Gibb's corner wide of an empty net.

With news filtering through of Pompey's goal-glut on the south coast, the visitors' attacking grew more frenzied if no more potent. Yet, as the home support gleefully chanted "Cheerio", the Eagles found salvation. "We have to learn from this now," added Freedman. "A club this big should not be struggling against relegation. But we'll celebrate for now."

oThe former Crystal Palace manager Steve Coppell has turned down an offer to join Gianluca Vialli's coaching staff at Watford. "I was very flattered but it is not the sort of job I am looking for at this stage of my career," he said.

Man of the match: Dougie Freedman (Crystal Palace)

webTitle: 'Hello! I'm on the beach'

fields.headline: 'Hello! I'm on the beach'
fields.trailText: This year more British people have mobile phones than ever before. And the bad news is, they work virtually all over the world.
fields.body:
Dring-dring. Dring-dring. Dring-dring...

The theme tune of Thunderbirds, the bleating melodies of 'Für Elise', the shrill buzzing of high-pitched mobile phones. No, this isn't the 8.04am Lewisham via London Bridge commuter train but 8am on the beach at the Hyatt Regency, Sharm-el-Sheikh in the Egyptian Red Sea last week.

A slick Italian (jet black locks, shades, orange swimming trunks, tanned torso) on the neighbouring sunlounger is in full flow, gesticulating violently, earpiece plugged in, giving the appearance he is having an enthralling conversation with himself. He sits upright, eyes fixed on the horizon, A4 files scattered at his sandy toes. The phone calls continue for four hours. 'Pronto!... Ciao!' Dring dring. 'Pronto!... Ciao!'

The mobile office has taken on a new and irritating meaning. And quickly one by one other sunloungers fill up. Germans, Italians, Russians, Brits and Egyptians nattering away in full flow on their mobiles. One couple sit in their swimming togs at each end of a sunlounger chatting away to people back home, oblivious to anyone, or anything about Egypt around them. Even toddlers wander round, plastic spades pressed to ears mimicking the mobile phone show. Nobody is reading books, or entertaining their kids.

Last week saw the start of the summer holiday package season and if you think beaches mean getting away from Britain these days, think again. This year more British people have mobile phones than ever before. And the bad news is, they work virtually all over the world. A friend who came back from Australia last month said the expected highlight of the trip was ruined by mobile-phone addicts. Sitting at the top of Uluru, formerly known as Ayers Rock, fellow British backpackers passed round mobiles with more enthusiasm than a joint and excitedly shouted into mobiles: 'Mum. Guess where I am?'

Mobiles have, unfortunately, become as common as suncream. Shaun Powell, boss of the UK's biggest tour operator Thomson Holidays, warns the problem will only get worse: 'Last summer 20 per cent of holidaymakers took their mobile with them. This summer the figure will be at least 30 per cent.'

Roll on the day when beaches put up 'mobile phone-free zone' signs, like some trains which now have mobile-free carriages. And why don't holiday companies publish mobile phone-free brochures of those furthest flung places where mobiles don't work, or hotels with beaches where mobiles are banned?

It's not just other holidaymakers who don't want to be disturbed by mobile-phone freaks. I'm sure many kids whose parents no longer build sandcastles because they're too busy talking to their bosses back home or showing off to their friends will appreciate it too.

Oh yes, and before anyone mentions sunlounger-thieving Germans, beware of a new trend. We were beaten almost daily to the sunloungers in Sharm by the Rolex-wearing Russians who can now take the title for sunlounger supremacy.

webTitle: After the fall, things get even worse for Chester

fields.headline: After the fall, things get even worse for Chester
fields.trailText: Warning: Barnet supporters are advised not to read this, for this is what you could become. No, not Rushden - whose victory completed their nine-year rise from Southern League Midland Division to the football league - but Chester, relegated last season and now riven by back-stabbing and in-fighting.
fields.byline: Simon Burnton at the Deva stadium
fields.body:
Warning: Barnet supporters are advised not to read this, for this is what you could become. No, not Rushden - whose victory completed their nine-year rise from Southern League Midland Division to the football league - but Chester, relegated last season and now riven by back-stabbing and in-fighting.

After the final whistle, fans of both sides invaded the pitch and grouped in front of the main stand. The visiting majority bouncing in jubilation, home fans angrily demanding that their chairman, Terry Smith, leave.

Neither group should, of course, have been on the pitch at all, but since the stewards resigned en masse in an emotional build-up to the game there was little to stop them. Also before the match, Chester presented their player of the season award to Paul Beesley, their 35-year-old assistant manager who is currently banned from playing by Smith for "standing in the wrong positions at free-kicks". It is this kind of interference that has done most to turn the fans against him. "No one needs to run me out because I cannot leave soon enough," said Smith in his programme notes, not that it stopped anyone trying.

If the sideshow served to take attention away from the game, it was not a bad thing. It said much about the encounter that the first two goals were scored by unmarked centre-backs from set-pieces; the winner an outstanding volley from Jon Brady that Wayne Brown in the home goal seemed to wilfully ignore.

Rushden will need some improvements if they are to establish themselves in the Third Division, but in Max Griggs they have a chairman who will support Brian Talbot in his task. Smith, meanwhile, is unlikely to show his face in Chester again. It is some contrast. Barnet beware.

Man of the match: Mattie Doughty (Chester)

webTitle: Said & Done

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText: Fan slapping: it's serious
fields.body:
Fan slapping: it's serious

Eric Cantona's limp eight-month ban for jumping the wall at Selhurst Park in 1995 has been put into perspective by Cambridge City's reaction to a similar incident last week. The club were responding to top scorer Ian Cambridge strolling 30 yards to the touchline and laying into a fan during their Dr Martens League match with Dorchester Town. The forward - not highly paid, not a celebrity and not French - was immediately fined, censored and sacked. The club say he'll spend the next few weeks as groundsman until he can find another job - "but we all agree that Ian's future is not with Cambridge City". Jude Stirling's alleged attack at Brentford, meanwhile, is still under investigation.

Quote of the week

Tony Cascarino on former Chelsea colleague Glenn Hoddle:

"Paul Elliot arrived in our dressing room wearing an immaculate leather trenchcoat. Hoddle raced to the 'cover' of a bin in the corner and started shooting at him with imaginary bullets, going "pshhh, pshhh" like a five-year-old with a cowboy pistol. He was probably the unfunniest man I have ever known."

Bouncing baby Brolin

Heart-warming news from Sweden: Tomas Brolin - cult hero and roving salesman - has knocked out his first baby Brolin. The boy, who weighed in at a modest 7lb 10oz, is to be named Sebastian, and has already been tipped by the Swedish press to follow in his dad's footsteps (as a footballer, that is). The wonderkid's mum is 33-year-old Susan Hardenborg, sister of famous-in-Sweden soap actress Catherine Hardenborg, and former girlfriend of ex-wrestling world champion Frank Andersson. Last month, though, Brolin swapped Susan for 29-year-old Miss Sweden Annika Duckmark - but it was, they say, an amicable split. Susan and Tomas tell us in a joint statement: "We are very proud. We will share this wonderful responsibility." Good luck, big man - branded Observer booties are on the way.

New word of the week

Lingual dexterist and king of gaffer-speak Harry Redknapp on abuse towards Michael Carrick from West Ham's fans, which included the best new word to join the lexicon this season:

"Everyone fucking jumps all over you. They don't care he's just 19. When he gave the ball away the other week there was twenty thousand people cunting him off. He give a bad ball and they are all fucking "weeeerrrr"."

Madrid news: Jesus at it again

Jesus Gil - the Spanish underworld's Doug Ellis - has explained his decision to sack another Atletico manager. Marcos Alonso was Gil's 25th casualty since 1987 - and was lucky to survive as long as he did. 'If I'd been on top of things I would have sacked him ages ago,' says Gil. 'This season has been one disaster after another. We have said goodbye to promotion.' Atletico are now certain to spend another season outside the top flight - this was their first in 66 years. Alonso's career lasted 29 games.

Observer: new signing close

Observer Sport is close to signing Alex Ferguson as a columnist for next season. We're doing this on the basis that we've inspired both our current gaffer-columnists Gordon Strachan and Alan Smith to the bottom of their divisions, Alan has lost his job (and left the country to recuperate), and doing the same to Fergie might liven up the Premiership. Watch this space.

Said & Done: david.hills@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Millwall set their sights on further promotion

fields.headline: Millwall set their sights on further promotion
fields.trailText: After clinching the Second Division championship with an emphatic display that swept aside lacklustre Oldham, Millwall wasted no time in revealing their ambition to push for a Premiership place.
fields.byline: Christopher Stocks at the New Den
fields.body:
After clinching the Second Division championship with an emphatic display that swept aside lacklustre Oldham, Millwall wasted no time in revealing their ambition to push for a Premiership place.

"The aim is to follow in [Ipswich's] footsteps and I hate to say it but Charlton as well. That is our inspiration going into the First Division next year, we can do exactly as they've done," said the Millwall striker Neil Harris.

This Harris-inspired win saw the South London club claim their finest moment since 1988, when the likes of Teddy Sheringham, Terry Hurlock and Tony Cascarino secured promotion to the old First Division.

And in Harris, who was stripped down to his bare essentials by souvenir hunting fans in the post-match celebrations, Millwall have their finest striker since Sheringham.

With his pace, power and precision, Harris was instrumental in four of the hosts' five goals. After laying on the first for strike-partner Paul Moody he then doubled Millwall's advantage himself with a sublime chip over a helpless Gary Kelly. After the break, Steven Reid nearly broke the back of the net with a thunderous 25-yard strike from a Harris cutback.

Moody then claimed his second and the hosts' fourth from yet another Harris assist before the man of the moment sealed this rout in injury time from the penalty spot.

For Mark McGhee Saturday's result was the most satisfying of his career. "I think I rate this as highly as anything I have ever achieved," he said.

Man of the match: Neil Harris (Millwall)

webTitle: The McVeigh letters

fields.headline: The McVeigh letters: Why I bombed Oklahoma
fields.standfirst:
Read Tracy McVeigh's April 22 article in Observer Life Magazine: Dead man talking

'Dear Tracy' - by mass killer Timothy McVeigh
fields.trailText: The indepth letters Timothy McVeigh invited the Observer to look at were sent to the safekeeping of his friend Bob Papovich who had up until now been told that the correspondence was to be kept 'off-the-record'.
fields.body:
The indepth letters Timothy McVeigh invited the Observer to look at were sent to the safekeeping of his friend Bob Papovich who had up until now been told that the correspondence was to be kept 'off-the-record'.

But in a letter to Papovich written from death row on May 3, 2001. McVeigh told Papovich that these documents he had sent him contained 'the final piece missing from the "why" equation.'

In a letter to Observer journalist Tracy McVeigh, the convicted Oklahoma City bomber gave Papovich's phone number and pleaded: 'Ask him specifically for my 3-page letter "why I bombed the Murrah building'.

The following is that letter which shows the build-up of anger that McVeigh had against a US federal government 'run amok' against its citizens and the politics that led to his bombing of the Alfred P Murrah building in Oklahoma City on April 19 1995 - the second anniversary of Waco.

What McVeigh wrote:

'I explain herein why I bombed the Murrah federal building in Oklahoma City. I explain this not for publicity, nor seeking to win an argument of right or wrong. I explain so that the record is clear as to my thinking and motivations in bombing a government installation.

"I chose to bomb a federal building because such an action served more purposes than other options. Foremost the bombing was a retaliatory strike; a counter attack for the cumulative raids (and subsequent violence and damage) that federal agents had participated in over the preceding years (including, but not limited to, Waco). From the formation of such units as the FBI's Hostage Rescue and other assault teams amongst federal agencies during the 80s, culminating in the Waco incident, federal actions grew increasingly militaristic and violent, to the point where at Waco, our government - like the Chinese - was deploying tanks against its own citizens.

Knowledge of these multiple and ever-more aggressive raids across the country constituted an identifiable pattern of conduct within and by the federal government and amongst its various agencies.

'For all intents and purposes, federal agents had become soldiers (using military training, tactics, techniques, equipment, language, dress, organisation and mindset) and they were escalating their behaviour.

Therefore this bombing was meant as a pre-emptive (or pro-active) strike against these forces and their command and control centres within the federal building. When an aggressor force continually launches attacks from a particular base of operations, it is sound military strategy to take the fight to the enemy. Additionally, borrowing a page from US foreign policy, I decided to send a message to a government that was becoming increasingly hostile, by bombing a government building and the government employees within that building who represent that government. Bombing the Murrah federal building was morally and strategically equivalent to the US hitting a government building in Serbia, Iraq, or other nations.

Based on observations of the policies of my own government, I viewed this action as an acceptable option.

From this perspective, what occurred in Oklahoma City was no different than what Americans rain on the heads of others all the time, and subsequently, my mindset was and is one of clinical detachment. (The bombing of the Murrah building was not personal, no more than when Air Force, Army, Navy or Marine personnel bomb or launch cruise missiles against government installations and their personnel). I hope that this clarification amply addresses all questions.

Another letter sent to Papovich stated:

"When the post-inferno investigations and inquiries by the Executive and Legislative branches of government concluded that the federal government had done nothing fundamentally wrong during the raid of the Branch Davadians at Waco, the system not only failed the victims who died during that siege but also failed the citizens of this country. This failure in effect left the door open for more Wacos.'

McVeigh went on to the window of opportunity for federal agents to be held accountable for their crimes against "we the people" was again slammed shut during the court process when the US courts held that federal agents were not accountable for 'the massive loss of lives and property as well as an absolute denial of due process.'

"Some time after the fact they received awards, bonus pay and in some cases promotions for their disgusting and inhumane actions at Waco and Ruby Ridge.

"This was exemplified years later while I sat in prison, The Ruby Ridge FBI sniper, Lon Horiuchi, was charged by the state of Idaho for his actions.

"The federal courts threw out the charges, ruling that federal agents are immune from the laws that govern the common citizen.

'The surviving Davidians were sentenced to lengthy prison terms, despite protests from the trial jurors. The primary "checks and balances" system had again failed to correct the system.

'It was at this time, after waiting for non-violent checks and balances to correct ongoing federal abuses and seeing no such results, that the assault weapons ban was passed and rumours subsequently surfaced of nationwide, Waco-style raids scheduled for the spring of 1995 to confiscate firearms.

'These rumours were so persistent and deemed so credible that some congresswoman wrote letters to Attorney-General Janet Reno inquiring as to her intents and admonishing her to call off the raids.

"As it turns out these rumours were actually based on fact.

"Through the legal process called 'discovery' the Oklahoma City bombing defence learned that both the ATF (Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms) and the FBI had formulated raid plans for the spring of 1995 at Elohim City in eastern Oklahoma. So for those who dismiss such concerns as paranoia you need to look at the facts as they existed at the time and further reflect that the Waco raid was not imaginary - it was a real event.

"It was in this climate then, that I reached the decision to go on the offensive - to put a check on government abuse of power where others has failed in stopping the federal juggernaut run amok.

webTitle: Preston take the points, but not the playoff plaudits

fields.headline: Preston take the points, but not the playoff plaudits
fields.trailText: Preston won the phoney war ahead of the real battle in the forthcoming play-offs, but they will be wary of meeting West Brom in the final in Cardiff after being outplayed by Gary Megson's team.
fields.body:
Preston won the phoney war ahead of the real battle in the forthcoming play-offs, but they will be wary of meeting West Brom in the final in Cardiff after being outplayed by Gary Megson's team.

Graham Alexander's penalty won the game for David Moyes's team to secure a two-legged semi-final against Birmingham City. Albion now face third-placed Bolton.

With both clubs already assured of a place in the play-offs before the game, there was little to play for other than the honour of finishing fourth, fifth or sixth.

Perhaps the absence of any pressure contributed to the whirlwind start to the game made by both teams. Two clear chances were spurned before Sean Gregan broke the deadlock for Preston after less than 90 seconds.

The Albion midfielder Adam Chambers could have scored within the first 20 seconds after being released by Jason Roberts, but Preston goalkeeper David Lucas twice saved well from the youngster.

Preston responded immediately and Chambers showed great stamina by racing back to his own penalty box to block Richard Cresswell's shot from 12 yards.

From the resultant corner, however, Gregan opened the scoring when he converted Alexander's cross with a toe poke from close range. Perhaps the game did mean something after all.

A year ago, both Preston and West Brom would have gladly taken a place in the top six at this stage of the season. North End had just lifted the Second Division championship, while Albion were breathing a huge sigh of relief having narrowly avoided relegation.

Neither team wanted to show their hand ahead of the play-offs, however, and it was no surprise that both line-ups bore little resemblance to the teams that have taken Preston and West Brom into their lofty positions this season. Albion were without five regulars, while Preston were missing six of their best.

At least Preston acknowledged the fact that something needed to be done to spice up the atmosphere inside Deepdale to avoid the game resembling a pre-season testimonial. The imaginative North End PR Department had decided to make this game 'David Moyes Day' as a tribute to the young Scottish manager who has resurrected the club since succeeding Gary Peters three years ago.

Supporters were urged to dress in kilts and don ginger wigs in order to look like Moyes, while the club provided a piper for entertainment. Amazingly, hundreds of Preston loyalists answered the call and Deepdale could have been Hampden Park had the home side not been kitted out in white shirts.

West Brom seemed to benefit from the party atmosphere more than Preston, however. Despite falling behind to Gregan's goal, Gary Megson's team created the better chances and deservedly levelled through Neil Clement's free-kick.

Referee David Laws forced the Preston wall back a further ten yards following their reluctance to retreat the proper distance and Clement took advantage to float his 25-yard effort past Lucas.

The home supporters were incensed by the decision to force the wall back, but they were cheering the referee shortly after the re-start following his decision to award a penalty after Jason Van Blerk had handled David Healy's cross.

Graham Alexander has never missed a penalty for Preston and he maintained his 100 per cent record by beating goalkeeper Russell Hoult. His goal gave Preston their first victory over one of their play-off rivals this season. Three more wins and they will be in the Premiership.

West Brom manager Gary Megson said: "You never set out to lose a game and I think we both wanted to win, but there are other things to take into consideration.

"I tried to use the game as preparation for next week's play-off semi-final and that's why I took Neil Clement off. I didn't want him being sent off. I'm sure David Moyes substituted Sean Gregan for the same reason.

"We started awfully and didn't defend a corner properly. The problems from game number one are still with us in game 46 and that's something we have to put right."

Preston manager David Moyes was delighted to see his team clinch fourth place. He said: "It's a great achievement to finish fourth in the First Division. I'm really pleased because the players have been marvellous.

"It's just a pity that four teams don't go up automatically! We didn't perform in the first half, though, and West Brom were the better side. We couldn't get to grips with the game.

"Still, we go into the play-offs as the form team and I believe that everyone will want to play us. We're going in with a smile on our face because who knows when this situation will come round again?"

Man of the match: David Lucas (Preston)

webTitle: Growing Up Alone - UN appeal

fields.headline: Horrific statistics reveal toll of war on children
fields.standfirst:
More on the Unicef Appeal:
What you can do
Miyongere's story
The countries where children are most vulnerable
fields.trailText: The United Nations Children's Fund has launched an appeal, Growing Up Alone, focusing on children affected by conflicts raging across the world.
fields.body:
The United Nations Children's Fund has launched an appeal, Growing Up Alone, focusing on children affected by conflicts raging across the world.

The funds raised will be used in Unicef-sponsored projects in countries like Afghanistan, Sierra Leone and Angola - where children have been made homeless or maimed as a direct result of violence.

Later this month Unicef will publish a report showing that two million children have been killed in conflicts across the world over the past decade.

The study also reveals that because of regional fighting in countries like Afghanistan and Sierra Leone, 'for children, the world is now a more violent and volatile place than at any time since the Second World War'.

The report examines how children are forced to fend for themselves as they experience homelessness, displacement and the loss of family members.

 Two million children have been killed by conflict over the last 10 years; 12 million children have been made homeless; six million children have been injured or disabled.

 Of the world's 40 million displaced, 20 million are children. Up to 10,000 children each year are killed by landmines.

 At least 300,000 children, at any given time, are actively involved in armed conflict.

 500 million small arms and light weapons are in circulation.

 In the conflict in Sierra Leone, 30 per cent of some warring factions are thought to be children. In Liberia in 1996, 26 per cent of demobilised soldiers were children. In a study conducted in Afghanistan, 72 per cent of children interviewed had lost a family member during four years of fighting.

 Growing up alone: how you can give
Call 08457 312 312 for a 24-hour local-rate credit card donation line. Alternatively, send a cheque/postal order, payable to Unicef Appeal for Growing Up Alone: Children in Conflict, Unicef, Room OBS2, Freepost, Chelmsford CM2 8BR

Later this month Unicef will publish a report showing that two million children have been killed in conflicts across the world over the past decade. The study also reveals that because of regional fighting in countries like Afghanistan and Sierra Leone, 'for children, the world is now a more violent and volatile place than at any time since the Second World War'. The report examines how children are forced to fend for themselves as they experience homelessness, displacement and the loss of family members.  Two million children have been killed by conflict over the last 10 years; 12 million children have been made homeless; six million children have been injured or disabled.  Of the world's 40 million displaced, 20 million are children. Up to 10,000 children each year are killed by landmines.  At least 300,000 children, at any given time, are actively involved in armed conflict.  500 million small arms and light weapons are in circulation.  In the conflict in Sierra Leone, 30 per cent of some warring factions are thought to be children. In Liberia in 1996, 26 per cent of demobilised soldiers were children. In a study conducted in Afghanistan, 72 per cent of children interviewed had lost a family member during four years of fighting.  Growing up alone: how you can give Call 08457 312 312 for a 24-hour local-rate credit card donation line. Alternatively, send a cheque/postal order, payable to Unicef Appeal for Growing Up Alone: Children in Conflict, Unicef, Room OBS2, Freepost, Chelmsford CM2 8BR

webTitle: Should you book for 2002?

fields.headline: Should you book for 2002?
fields.standfirst:
The summer brochures are out and they're full of bargains, but few of us need to buy a holiday 15 months early, reports transport editor Joanna Walters
Sneak preview: what's on offer for summer 2002
fields.trailText: The summer brochures are out and they're full of bargains, but few of us need to buy a holiday 15 months early, reports transport editor Joanna Walters
fields.body:
No sooner has Britain shaken off winter and started looking forward to a summer break of sun, sea and sand than the big holiday companies launch their latest brochures - for summer 2002.

Yet many people have not booked anything for this summer yet. Patricia Yates, editor of Holiday Which? says consumers are in for a confusing time because high street travel agents are currently stocking brochures for three seasons: summer 2001, the forthcoming winter and summer 2002. 'It's a mess,' she says.

The biggest mass market tour operators - Thomson, Airtours, First Choice and JMC - have dreamed up all sorts of gimmicks to persuade consumers that they really should hurry to bag their package holiday some 15 months before they step on the plane.

Two thirds of the 10 million people who take summer packages book no more than eight months before their holiday and many like to wait until the last minute in the hope of a price war. So as the hype for next summer cranks up, the question for bargain hunters is - when is the best time to book?

Amanda Williams, head of sales at the largest independent travel agent Travelcare, part of the Co-op group, told us: 'There are many advantages of booking early, particularly if you have set dates when you want to go away, you are looking for free child places, a particular property and the best early family deals.'

But leaving a booking until the autumn or early next year does not mean that the choice of flights and accommodation will be poor, just not as good.

Williams says that average package prices have risen by no more than inflation over the past two years. Short-haul packages average around £400 per person for a week and£800 long-haul.

'My advice is to forget the discounts, which in some cases are misleading, and look at the price you will actually pay. Decide where you want to go, for the best price and widest choice in your chosen destination. You will still get a good deal for 2002 if you book this autumn or next January.'

Even booking the same hotel for the same dates can produce very different prices depending on operator and airline. Not surprisingly, Williams recommends you get your independent travel agent to do the work, comparing prices between brochures and in the computer reservations systems and, in larger branches, even surfing the internet, Teletext and digital television holiday channels for you in the shop.

Many independent operators, such as Greek specialist Kosmar, have already put together an early version of their summer 2002 programmes and put the prices in agents' reservations systems - with packages that are very competitive with the mass market. Williams advises that you ask your agent to look for such deals, because they may not be offered without prompting.

And what of the early booking offers? Given that discounts on packages for this summer hit 70 per cent in the peak booking period in January, it is obvious that even half-price offers now in some 2002 brochures will not prove the best and final deals for the bulk of holidays.

And some observers criticise early brochures because the bulk of flight times for all the charter airlines next summer will not be fixed until November. Booking especially early now to secure a civilised daytime flight does not guarantee you will not be switched to a night flight nearer the time.

Noel Josephides, managing director of holiday company Sunvil and a spokesman for the Association of Independent Tour Operators, said: 'Early booking is being rammed down people's throats, but it is a lot of eyewash. The only genuine bargains are when operators are trying to get rid of distressed stock late - and that is completely unpredictable.'

Sneak preview: what's on offer for summer 2002

* Thomson Holidays has a controversial 'no discounting' strategy on main brands Thomson Summer Sun, Far Away Shores, Florida, All Inclusive and Greece. It promises 'bottom line' rates, where the brochure price is 'competitive' with what you would pay for a similar package bought from a rival after any discount. Thomson's lowest price for next summer is £179 per person based on four adults sharing a one-bedroom apartment in Majorca for a week in October. More typical Mediterranean package prices for August start at £355.

* Airtours is launching its summer 2002 brochures on 17 May with discounts of up to 20 per cent from day one. The biggest discounts are likely to be through its Going Places agency and other 'recommended agents', which sharp-eyed consumers can spot from a special sticker in the shop window of independent agents.

* First Choice is making a big push towards families with 'early booking offers' of half-price holidays and two children for £1 on selected dates at 60 properties, especially 'family friendly' villas with pools, located away from busy roads. A limited number of free child places are on offer plus special deals for single parents. Prices for summer 2002 start at £239 per person for seven nights in Kavol, Corfu.

* First Choice's subsidiary Unijet has launched a 2002 lead-in price of £215 per person self-catering on Spain's Costa Blanca.

* JMC, the tour operating arm of Thomas Cook, has launched 10 brochures with 'money-off' savings and free child places. Early bookers are offered £300 off packages per adult couple and £400 for families.

A week in Turkey in early May 2002 costs £359 per person with £150 discount per person. The same week in Minorca is £499 per person with a £150 discount.

webTitle: Observer review: Ornamentalism by David Cannadine

fields.headline: Oh! What a lovely empire
fields.standfirst: David Cannadine celebrates our imperial past as an achievement to be savoured, not reviled, in Ornamentalism
fields.trailText: David Cannadine celebrates our imperial past as an achievement to be savoured, not reviled, in Ornamentalism
fields.body:
Ornamentalism: How the British saw their Empire
David Cannadine
Allen Lane £16.99, pp288
Buy it at a discount at BOL

We are, according to The Observer's correspondent George Orwell, 'the most class-ridden society under the sun', a nation of snobs for whom the baubles of the state exercise a unique, even a disabling, fascination. Orwell's famous verdict illuminates every sentence of David Cannadine's impressively concise analysis of Britannia's perception of her wave-ruling exertions. Class is what concerns him, class in all its complex, Hydra-headed ferocity.

Cannadine claims that Ornamentalism follows on from his Class in Britain, but, in another sense, it completes the analysis of the twentieth-century recession of British global influence he began with The Decline and Fall of the British Aristocracy (1992). Appropriately for a historian who has also written about P.G. Wodehouse, it memorialises a lost world of aristocratic fantasy.

As well as watching the Union Jack fluttering down, and sounding the 'Last Post' over a lifetime of distinguished scholarship, Ornamentalism offers a spirited riposte to, and critique of, Edward Said's celebrated Orientalism. Never mind Said's identification of the racism at the heart of the 'civilising mission', in Cannadine's imperium, in which 'analogues of hierarchy' rule OK, status is far more important than race.

Pace Said, Cannadine claims it as 'a substantial, a significant and a neglected truth' that 'the British did regard the dark-skinned members of their empire as more admirable, more important and more noble than white men'. Since this is a top-down examination of the sources, paying special attention to the captains and the kings, not their batmen or valets, this claim is hard to verify, except by a repetition of the Englishman's fascination with the toys of empire.

Not all his evidence is unequivocal. Cannadine cites the story of King Kalakaua's visit to England in 1881 as evidence of an obsession with hierarchy. When the Hawaiian king, a friend of RL Stevenson's, attended a society do, the Prince of Wales (the future Edward VII) insisted on his guest's precedence over the future Kaiser Wilhelm II with the words: 'Either the brute is a king or he's a common-or-garden nigger; and if the latter, what's he doing here?' Presumably, Professor Said would interpret this gruesome court scene differently.

Elsewhere, Cannadine's delight at the way in which the great Victorian imperialists set out to replicate abroad the god-given hierarchies they felt were threatened at home animates a narrative that is, at heart, an engaging canter through the bizarre snobberies of the 'vast, interconnected world' of the white dominions such as Australia and New Zealand, Disraeli's 'jewel in the crown', the Indian Empire, the colonial possessions like Hong Kong, Malaya and West Africa, down to the humble mandates like Jordan and Iraq.

Throughout this third British empire, quite different in scale and ambition from the first and second empires in North America, it was the export of an exclusively English hierarchy that struck fascinated observers such as Rudyard Kipling and Anthony Trollope, who noted with satisfaction that the life of an Australian landowner was indistinguishable from 'that of the English country gentleman... a century and a half ago'.

For those who were unsure of their place in this hierarchy, there was Burke. Not the Burke of the Peerage, but Burke's Colonial Gentry, a reckless genealogical tome in which socially ambitious New Zealanders could (and did) claim descent from Edward the Elder. According to Kipling, the 'analogues of hierarchy' became so accepted that mules, horses and elephants obeyed their mahoots, who obeyed their sergeants, who obeyed their lieutenants who etc... their captains, majors, colonels and brigadiers... Who all obeyed their viceroy.

And everyone looked up to the Queen-Empress. When Victoria gave thanks in St Paul's at the Diamond Jubilee of 1897, the Daily Mail, speaking, then as now, for the imperially inclined middle classes, observed that it was appropriate that 'She' had gone thither, for 'He' was the 'One Being' who was 'More Majestic Than She'.

The empire's role in adding lustre to the Crown perhaps explains the present queen's enthusiasm for that shadow of empire, the Commonwealth. There's no monarchist like a colonial monarchist. Field Marshal Smuts, when introduced to Queen Mary, graciously informed her: 'You are the big potato. The other queens are all small potatoes.'

The universal, three-in-one lubricant that oiled the wheels of this vast engine of class consciousness - and here Cannadine excels himself - was the export of snobbery on a truly industrial scale. It was snobbery that inspired Indian princelings to squander their fortunes on conspicuous consumption, for example, the Maharajah of Mysore's palace at Bangalore, a pleasure dome that seemed to rival Balmoral. It was snobbery that animated the quasi-Roman pomp and circumstance of the 1903 Coronation Durbar, a beano that satisfied even Lord Curzon's taste for ostentation. It was Curzon, aptly, who identified the glue that held the rickety structure of empire together as 'an insatiable appetite... for titles and precedence'.

Cannadine revels in the fact that scenes like the Durbar, though spectacular, were not exceptional. Throughout the empire, 'the most successful British proconsuls and imperial soldiers' became 'walking Christmas trees of stars and collars, medals and sashes, ermine robes and coronets'. These were the bejewelled footsoldiers of an imperial vision 'of the earthly realm as a global hierarchy with the sovereign [Victoria] at its head'.

Despite the rhetorical majesty of this analysis, it is hard to believe that 'ornamentalism' was the whole story of the average Briton's fascination with his empire, just as it is hard not to find Cannadine, who acknowledges his personal stake in this analysis, falling a little in love with what Joseph Conrad, in another context, called a 'fantastic invasion'.

Imperialism, as we now acknowledge, had a darker side, but Ornamentalism is not really concerned with this. In fact, if there is a minor chord to be found in this discreet hymn of celebration, it's in the closing pages, in Cannadine's appendix ('An Imperial Childhood?') in which the historian, born in 1950, places himself at that crucial junction at which the empire began to become not a presence but a memory, with bewildering speed. Ornamentalism takes its cue from class history, but it is a far cry from its hard-boiled Marxist ancestors, such as J.A. Hobson's Imperialism, and all the more enjoyable in consequence.

webTitle: A Rembrandt for the video age

fields.headline: A Rembrandt for the video age
fields.standfirst: While Bill Viola's chosen vehicle is video, his art recalls another, centuries-old medium
fields.trailText: While Bill Viola's chosen vehicle is video, his art recalls another, centuries-old medium
fields.body:
Bill Viola Anthony d'Offay, London W1, until 21 July

The most powerful show by a living artist to be seen in Britain today is at the Anthony d'Offay Gallery in London: 13 new works by the American Bill Viola, presented in near-total darkness. It is not given to many artists to be both dazzling and deep, least of all in the medium of video. But for the last quarter century, Viola has been using the newest technology to stir the oldest of emotions. Simply to describe his work as profound would be to neglect its startlingly inventive beauty.

At 50, Viola has become the Rembrandt of the video age, an artist who has done more than any of his contemporaries to advance the emotional and aesthetic content of his medium. Analogies with painting prove strangely significant in Viola's latest work. The first piece in this show, for example, takes the form of a hi-tech diptych: instead of hinged frames, two Panasonic televisions; instead of wooden panels, a pair of plasma screens.

What you see may be secular and modern - a couple having a row - but it connects back to ancient traditions of religious painting. Gradually, almost imperceptibly, the little local difficulty in this video escalates into a timeless Passion.

A man and a woman, in their separate frames, are locked in elemental anguish. As the film begins - silent, and in ultra-slow motion - it seems as though the man is launching some terrible accusation, arms spreading, mouth gaping, head flung down and back in cataclysmic outrage. She turns away, covers her ears, shudders with grief. Perhaps, you think, she is somehow to blame. But as the moments inch by, the movements stretch and swim into something less legible and far more ambiguous: are they in the same room; do they even hear each other; is he reacting to her accusations?

Opposed and yet joined: the medieval form of the diptych gives this video its metaphor. But this is no particular Adam and Eve. The extreme, almost glacial slowness of the images seems to disembody the action, to eternalise the spasm of anguish. His film visualises emotion in its universal state, all of us turning on the spit of pain, deaf to each other's suffering.

People wept to see this work on the day I visited the gallery, as if remembering their past. But the experience is also amazingly consoling, perhaps because of the beauty of these lifesize figures, shot in silver-grey, passing like astronauts or weightless divers through the ballet of their emotions. But also because the film releases you into a different future, one in which you have another chance not to cause - and thus be twinned in - misery.

This gift is not something you regularly receive from contemporary theatre or cinema, still less from a West End gallery. It might be argued that Viola borrows something from each, employing performers and assistants to film his art. But he simulates nothing. His colleagues are on their own, impelled by no more than an initial word. Which is, I think, why everything he makes is inflected by a sense of wonder and immediate surprise.

In the past, Viola has filmed mirages in the Sahara, shamen walking on red-hot coals, bison roaming the prairies. He was gripped by the renewing cycle of life, most literally in his film of the simultaneous birth of his son and passing of his mother in the great Nantes Triptych, now at Tate Modern. But Viola is not a narrative artist. His videos don't have a denouement, let alone a cinematic ending. They are phrased like music, pausing, proliferating, subsiding, only to begin again.

The medium, in short, is not his message. Although he was among the pioneers of American video art in the early Seventies, Viola had nothing to say about the squeaking gogglebox of the television age any more than the postmodern media of digicam. His images are as purely pre-rational as the painted animals in the Lascaux caves. What video gives him is the dimension of time, which he uses to spellbinding effect. In his art, a shot of a droplet gradually welling - and reflecting the world around it - can be as enthralling as any action movie.

One of the works in this show reverses the process by condensing a whole life in less than 15 minutes. Five tiny screens, about the size of a portable altarpiece, show the same women in the same room at different times of the day. The scale is renaissance and so is the scene: pale limewashed walls, bare wooden floor, a woman dressed in timeless clothes. She washes her face, takes up her sewing, writes a letter, lights candles and eventually retires to bed.

It might be the life of a saint, complete with iconographic props - the stem of lilies, the Virgin's blue cloak, the halo of candlelight silhouetting her head. But the pleasures it commands - peace, absorption, domestic ritual - aren't merely religious. Nor is this an essay on renaissance painting alone. Van Eyck, Vermeer, Utamaro, Van Gogh: each glimmering screen takes you over the threshold into the interior world of painting.

Catherine's Room is shot in real time. But the woman performs her tasks with such slow care that each screen, at any given moment, appears to be almost static. Through the window, the light shifts drowsily from morning blue to purple twilight, measuring her brief life in the sun. This is a masterpiece in miniature, compressing the richness of art, of religion, of contemplative philosophy into the short fraction of an hour. But more time is precisely what it grants in return for your attention, a pause for thought that extends far beyond the hour.

Questioned about the unusual power of his videos, Viola tends to give diffident explanations - 'The medium gives a full-body experience that is not intellectual... the technology is so sensual that people can just take pleasure from the form.' This, of course, could be said of any home movie or MTV promo; it hardly comes close to the immense skill of his work. Even when all the techniques are revealed - speed, angle, lumens, resolution - nothing is lost or explained away.

One can learn, for example, that the most affecting work in this show was made with the aid of a mirror and some water and yet none of its essential mystery is removed. Surrender is a modified diptych: one figure in a portrait-shaped screen above another, inverted, each engulfed in grief. Slowly they bow down, immersing themselves in the dark waters. Slowly they rise again, tears streaming from their eyes.

The configuration changes. The movements swim and convulse. Gradually the images break into ripples, shattered in the tidal emotion. You might see it as a human tragedy - two people forever converging, never quite meeting, locked in their own isolated minds. Or you might see it as a spiritual transfiguration, the cycle of suffering and resurrection eternalised. Either way, its overwhelming vision releases an identical grief - and accompanying compassion - in the viewer. It is the single most cathartic work I have ever seen in a gallery.

Gradually, almost imperceptibly, the little local difficulty in this video escalates into a timeless Passion. A man and a woman, in their separate frames, are locked in elemental anguish. As the film begins - silent, and in ultra-slow motion - it seems as though the man is launching some terrible accusation, arms spreading, mouth gaping, head flung down and back in cataclysmic outrage. She turns away, covers her ears, shudders with grief. Perhaps, you think, she is somehow to blame. But as the moments inch by, the movements stretch and swim into something less legible and far more ambiguous: are they in the same room; do they even hear each other; is he reacting to her accusations? Opposed and yet joined: the medieval form of the diptych gives this video its metaphor. But this is no particular Adam and Eve. The extreme, almost glacial slowness of the images seems to disembody the action, to eternalise the spasm of anguish. His film visualises emotion in its universal state, all of us turning on the spit of pain, deaf to each other's suffering. People wept to see this work on the day I visited the gallery, as if remembering their past. But the experience is also amazingly consoling, perhaps because of the beauty of these lifesize figures, shot in silver-grey, passing like astronauts or weightless divers through the ballet of their emotions. But also because the film releases you into a different future, one in which you have another chance not to cause - and thus be twinned in - misery. This gift is not something you regularly receive from contemporary theatre or cinema, still less from a West End gallery. It might be argued that Viola borrows something from each, employing performers and assistants to film his art. But he simulates nothing. His colleagues are on their own, impelled by no more than an initial word. Which is, I think, why everything he makes is inflected by a sense of wonder and immediate surprise. In the past, Viola has filmed mirages in the Sahara, shamen walking on red-hot coals, bison roaming the prairies. He was gripped by the renewing cycle of life, most literally in his film of the simultaneous birth of his son and passing of his mother in the great Nantes Triptych, now at Tate Modern. But Viola is not a narrative artist. His videos don't have a denouement, let alone a cinematic ending. They are phrased like music, pausing, proliferating, subsiding, only to begin again. The medium, in short, is not his message. Although he was among the pioneers of American video art in the early Seventies, Viola had nothing to say about the squeaking gogglebox of the television age any more than the postmodern media of digicam. His images are as purely pre-rational as the painted animals in the Lascaux caves. What video gives him is the dimension of time, which he uses to spellbinding effect. In his art, a shot of a droplet gradually welling - and reflecting the world around it - can be as enthralling as any action movie. One of the works in this show reverses the process by condensing a whole life in less than 15 minutes. Five tiny screens, about the size of a portable altarpiece, show the same women in the same room at different times of the day. The scale is renaissance and so is the scene: pale limewashed walls, bare wooden floor, a woman dressed in timeless clothes. She washes her face, takes up her sewing, writes a letter, lights candles and eventually retires to bed. It might be the life of a saint, complete with iconographic props - the stem of lilies, the Virgin's blue cloak, the halo of candlelight silhouetting her head. But the pleasures it commands - peace, absorption, domestic ritual - aren't merely religious. Nor is this an essay on renaissance painting alone. Van Eyck, Vermeer, Utamaro, Van Gogh: each glimmering screen takes you over the threshold into the interior world of painting. Catherine's Room is shot in real time. But the woman performs her tasks with such slow care that each screen, at any given moment, appears to be almost static. Through the window, the light shifts drowsily from morning blue to purple twilight, measuring her brief life in the sun. This is a masterpiece in miniature, compressing the richness of art, of religion, of contemplative philosophy into the short fraction of an hour. But more time is precisely what it grants in return for your attention, a pause for thought that extends far beyond the hour. Questioned about the unusual power of his videos, Viola tends to give diffident explanations - 'The medium gives a full-body experience that is not intellectual... the technology is so sensual that people can just take pleasure from the form.' This, of course, could be said of any home movie or MTV promo; it hardly comes close to the immense skill of his work. Even when all the techniques are revealed - speed, angle, lumens, resolution - nothing is lost or explained away. One can learn, for example, that the most affecting work in this show was made with the aid of a mirror and some water and yet none of its essential mystery is removed. Surrender is a modified diptych: one figure in a portrait-shaped screen above another, inverted, each engulfed in grief. Slowly they bow down, immersing themselves in the dark waters. Slowly they rise again, tears streaming from their eyes. The configuration changes. The movements swim and convulse. Gradually the images break into ripples, shattered in the tidal emotion. You might see it as a human tragedy - two people forever converging, never quite meeting, locked in their own isolated minds. Or you might see it as a spiritual transfiguration, the cycle of suffering and resurrection eternalised. Either way, its overwhelming vision releases an identical grief - and accompanying compassion - in the viewer. It is the single most cathartic work I have ever seen in a gallery.

webTitle: It could be worse, it could be Wembley

fields.headline: It could be worse, it could be Wembley
fields.standfirst: While the furore over a national stadium goes on, the future of London's South Bank is equally clouded by dissent and controversy
fields.trailText: While the furore over a national stadium goes on, the future of London's South Bank is equally clouded by dissent and controversy
fields.body:
London's South Bank isn't a full-blown fiasco on the scale of the great Wembley Stadium disaster. Not yet, anyway. It came pretty close a couple of years ago, but at the last moment, unlike the Football Association, its managers weren't daft enough to set about demolishing the Queen Elizabeth Hall and gutting the Hayward Gallery before they knew where the money to replace them was coming from.

But over the last dozen years or so, they have managed to work their way through three entirely different masterplans for dealing with the wilderness around Britain's most important cultural complex and making good its architectural shortcomings, squandering millions in the process.

When Rick Mather's scheme for an elevated park on top of a new home for the British Film Institute, a new concert hall and an array of shops and restaurants, each designed by different architects was unveiled last year, things looked more hopeful. There would be two so-called blade office blocks to pay for the project and Elliott Bernerd, the property-developer chairman of the South Bank Centre appointed by Tony Blair, tried to get things moving. But Bernerd has just returned to London after a period of illness only to find the whole intricate scheme threatening to unravel again over a clash between two competing architectural egos.

In Bernerd's absence, the jury set up to choose an architect couldn't agree between Rafael Vinoly, the suave fifty-something veteran responsible for the giant Tokyo Forum and head of a 150-strong architectural practice based in New York, and Foreign Office Architects, which is run by two thirtysomethings whose biggest completed building so far is the Belgo restaurant in Notting Hill. Instead of making up their minds, the jury tried to appoint both. Could they not do the job together? the South Bank Centre asked.

Vinoly makes bombastic buildings that try a bit too hard to impress, but he has got concert halls in New York and Philadelphia to his name. Foreign Office belongs to the school of Zaha Hadid and makes architecture that a decade ago would have been regarded as unbuildable but which is fast becoming fashionable. To expect the two to share the South Bank was like asking Julian Schnabel to prime canvas for Tracey Emin.

The two teams did, however, agree to give it a try. The attempt went wrong from the moment it was announced at the end of March, with both sides jockeying for position in the hope that they would end up either with the entire commission for themselves or, at least, manage to sideline their partner.

Foreign Office's publicity machine went into immediate overdrive, presenting it as the conceptual brains of the scheme and casting Vinoly as a safe pair of hands charged with realising the vision of the two young stars.

Vinoly was outraged and told everybody who would listen how angry he was by the suggestion that he was just a technician. 'There is an element of surrealism about the situation,' he says. 'We have never had the role of executive architects. To me, the jury's choice was a very puzzling decision. It's a very delicate situation, but we continue talking.'

Alejandro Zaero-Polo, one half of Foreign Office, is more blunt: 'Vinoly's position was, "I am the big guy, I make the decisions". We said no, we are not going under Vinoly's umbrella. There was a round of meetings that came close to an agreement on moving forward, but we had to say no, we can't work like this.

'The level of uncertainty is great. It is hard to say what will happen next. There could be another competition. Nobody thinks that we can carve the site into distinct buildings. And Vinoly does not want to be a production architect; I can understand that. If we come to a fair agreement, collaboration will strengthen the masterplan'.

Bernerd is meeting the two teams of architects to resolve the situation this week. He will make it clear that the South Bank expects them to work together but if they can't or won't, it reserves the right to appoint either or none of them. Bernerd hasn't got much time. The message coming from Ken Livingstone, under pressure to veto the project because it involves building on public open space, is that unless he gets a clear picture of exactly what the centre is planning to build soon, he's going to have to bow to the pressure and come out against the scheme.

And there are hints from the Department of Culture, Media and Sport that Chris Smith is none too convinced that the South Bank actually needs a new concert hall.

It is not surprising that two such different but equally ambitious architects should fall out; more worrying for the South Bank is the way in which its carefully assembled masterplan emerges from the competition. Foreign Office stuck to the spirit of the masterplan, but Vinoly came to the interview-room with a whole stack of options demonstrating how the whole thing could be done by abandoning the elevated park and the office blocks and putting the new concert hall on the ground, surrounded by a modest colonnade of shops.

Coming at the end of two long days of interviewing, it was just what the more cautious members of the jury were looking for, a simple, buildable project that they could understand. The other half of the jury was impressed by Vinoly's logic, but less so by his actual architecture and lobbied hard for Foreign Office. The deadlock was only resolved by the decision to try to get the two to work together. Accepting Vinoly's scheme, however, calls into question the whole masterplan on which so much time and effort has already been invested.

Unless Bernerd can persuade the architects to stop elbowing each other and start designing something that he can show Ken Livingstone, the whole project is likely to go the way of its ill-fated predecessors, which kept Terry Farrell and Richard Rogers tied up in knots for so long.

webTitle: Observer review: The Noonday Demon by Andrew Solomon

fields.headline: Down but never out
fields.standfirst: Poetic, vital, witty - who'd have thought depression could make such an uplifting read? Andrew Solomon anatomises his breakdowns in The Noonday Demon
fields.trailText: Poetic, vital, witty - who'd have thought depression could make such an uplifting read? Andrew Solomon anatomises his breakdowns in The Noonday Demon
fields.body:
The Noonday Demon: an Anatomy of Depression
Andrew Solomon
Chatto & Windus £20, pp560
Buy it at a discount at BOL

'Depression is the flaw in love. To be creatures who love, we must be creatures who can despair at what we lose, and depression is the mechanism of that despair,' says Andrew Solomon at the start of his magnificent book.

In his first sweeping sentences, he gathers up the themes and even the words that will resonate through the following pages of linked autobiography, history, science, analysis, wrenched and luminous meditation on life and pain. Love, loss and despair ring out their melancholy notes. In depression, he says over and over again, life loses its meaning; the 'only feeling left in this loveless state is insignificance'.

Yet The Noonday Demon stands as a testament to all those qualities that are lost during times of deathly meaninglessness: it describes numbness with vitality, wretchedness with poetry, lovelessness with passion, fear with exuberance, slack-jawed horror with wit and tenderness, deadly silence with this fervent outpouring of words. Depression is a country that the undepressed can't enter, but Solomon, who has travelled there and knows it well, bends all his energy and talent as a writer to sending us snapshots from this terrifying land (mood, he writes, 'is a frontier like deep ocean or deep space'). The result is scary but far from dispiriting; at times, Solomon's voice, calling to us from beyond the frontier, achieves a lonely rapture.

Solomon writes that depression can only be evoked by metaphors (the abyss, the edge, the darkness). The first that he uses himself is of a tree wrapped around by a vine; at some point, the vine squeezes the life out of the tree. Then he talks of angels and demons: grief is like a humble angel that leaves us with a clear sense of our own depth; depression is the (noonday) demon that leaves you appalled.

Mild depression is gradual, like rust; it is too much grief at too slight a cause. Major depression is the stuff of breakdowns, not rust, but the startling collapse of the whole system. He has been gripped by major depression himself, when he was 'asphyxiated', 'split and racked', and 'every second of being alive hurt'. There was not even enough life left for tears, just 'the arid pain of total violation'. As you fall towards this living death, he says, the first thing that goes from you is happiness. The next is the sadness that led you here. Then your sense of humour, the belief in and capacity for love. You smell sour to your self, and thinned. Your face comes apart in the mirror. You have no ability to trust, to touch, to grieve: 'Eventually, you are simply absence.'

There were many days when he couldn't move, couldn't swing his legs out of bed, couldn't control his bodily functions; he could only lie in a corner and weep. He wanted to die but didn't have the energy to kill himself. He did, however, pick up gay men whom he thought might be HIV positive and have sex with them, in the hope he, too, would become infected. Solomon is well aware of the 'preposterousness' of his depression and the uselessness of tracking its causes.

He is a wealthy, white American, a privileged, healthy, admired writer, envied by many for his success, his wealth, his luck, his apparent gaiety and ease. He has many friends. He was reasonably happy as a child, although confused about his sexuality and sometimes gripped by panic. His first major breakdown occurred after the death of his beloved mother (an assisted suicide because of her terminal cancer. He, his father and brother sat by her bed and held her hands and wept while she swallowed handfuls of pills and told them how dearly she loved them) and the publication of his first novel.

But nothing 'explains' how three times he came to be laid so low, and how now he takes pills and sees a therapist to keep the demon at bay. He offers a set of simple instructions to other sufferers (listen to people who love you, seek out memories, block out terrible thoughts as they approach, be brave, exercise, eat). His book, he insists, was not cathartic, but a way of reaching out to others in their isolation, a way of explaining them to us. At its heart, it is deeply idealistic in its intent: 'Words are strong and love is the other way forwards.'

Solomon's experience of depression, which comes like a gale force wind and departs quietly, forms only part of The Noonday Demon, though it is the emotional undertow through the whole of it. He portrays the pain of others, in different cultures and histories, showing that far from being a disease of the wealthy and the leisured classes and of modernity, it has always been with us under different names. Hippocrates wrote about it, as did Homer, Galen, Thomas Aquinas, Shakespeare, Baudelaire, Keats, Virginia Woolf and Freud.

The poor feel it (but, although depression cuts across all the classes, treatment of it does not), as do the the war-torn. He goes to Cambodia (where he was 'humbled down to the ground' by the courage of the people he met) and meets people who have lived through war and loss such as he can hardly imagine. One woman teaches him that the way through the darkness is by 'forgetting, working, loving'. He goes to Greenland, where up to 80 per cent of the population are depressed and the suicide rate is 0.35 per cent per year. He visits elderly people in homes; he goes to hospitals and slums.

He looks at the medical and alternative cures - anti-depressants, anxiety controllers, St John's Wort, exercise, work, food, massage, homoeopathy. He tries out different therapies (psychoanalysis, he says, is good at expressing depression, not good at changing it - it's like firing a machine gun at an incoming tide). He goes to talk groups. He gathers stories from all over the country, from sufferers and doctors, from people who have cut their flesh to ribbons and drunk themselves into stupors, from people who have been terribly abused, from people who have come out the other side.

More young people die of depression than of Aids, heart disease, pneumonia, cancer and strokes put together. One in 10 people in America is on drugs to help their moods. Five per cent of its teenagers are clinically depressed. Fifteen per cent of people who are depressed eventually kill themselves.

Some people kill themselves, Solomon says, to simplify things. He remembers thinking that he himself didn't have the energy to wash the dishes or take a shower, so he might as well go and die rather than face the mundane tasks that make up a day, a life. But while 'living death is not pretty, unlike dead death, it offers the hope for amelioration'.

Solomon is inclusive in his theories as well as his stories. There has long been a discussion about whether depression is an illness or an extreme version of ordinary sadness, whether it reveals or assaults a personality. Both, he says. What are the boundaries of identity, what do we mean by 'self'? If depression is 'just' chemical, so, too, is love. Medicine might release a sufferer from the trap, but it does not reinvent him or her. Depression springs like a beast from outside, yet is wired in the brain and runs through the veins. 'The real me lives in the world; the self exists in the narrow space where the world and our choices come together.' The depression he experiences is part of the man that he is.

What Solomon unequivocally and with a raw, sometimes disturbing, romanticism, believes in is the authenticity, even the gift, of his endured pain. To be happy all the time is a spooky, even terrifying idea or a form of idiocy. He quotes a Russian expression: if you wake up feeling no pain, you're dead. He quotes Ovid: 'Welcome this pain.' He believes his own grief and darkness have shown him the 'acreage and reach' of his soul. He writes that 'the individuality of each person's struggle is unbreachable' and that depression, 'like sex, retains an unquenchable aura of mystery. It is new every time'.

It is 'fire in the blood'; it nearly kills him but it produces from him words and poetry that he would not otherwise have uttered, and teaches him a better way of living and loving.

By the end of the book's long journey, he claims that he has learnt to love his depression as a way of learning to love himself. He knows it is lurking inside him still, and will one day probably ambush him again, but he closes with ardent, melancholy optimism: 'Each day I choose to be alive. Is that not a rare joy?'

webTitle: Observer review: John G by Sheridan Morley

fields.headline: All in a knight's work
fields.standfirst: Sheridan Morley has produced his authorised biography of John Gielgud in a year, but does he manage to shed any light on a great life in John G?
fields.trailText: Sheridan Morley has produced his authorised biography of John Gielgud in a year, but does he manage to shed any light on a great life in John G?
fields.body:
John G
Sheridan Morley
Hodder & Stoughton £20, pp510
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Great actors dramatise human possibilities, for good or ill. As Hazlitt said, they show us 'all that we are, all that we wish to be, and all that we dread to be'. John Gielgud, Laurence Olivier and Ralph Richardson divided this triple task between them. Richardson - a wise clown and, therefore, a definitive Falstaff - was what we are. Olivier, in the poisoned deformity of Richard III or the savagery of Othello, showed us a face we recognise with dread. It was left to Gielgud to impersonate our better selves.

He was incapable of playing evil, as a critic remarked when he attempted Shylock. (By contrast, Olivier's Shylock indulged in a Hitlerian jig of homicidal merriment when he learnt that Antonio's argosy had foundered.) His Hamlet, as Audrey Williamson said, was 'a fey, fairy prince', not Olivier's brutal joker. When young, he specialised in a refined, decorous lyricism. His Romeo was politely enamoured; Olivier's was on heat, rampant with desire. Growing older, Gielgud became an elegist, whose watery eyes and fluting tremolo voice grieved, as Alan Bennett's schoolmaster in Forty Years On or Peter Greenaway's self-disbelieving magus in Prospero's Books, over all we have lost. As an old man, he was much in demand at memorial services, and sometimes turned up at the wrong church to intone: 'Fear no more the heat of the sun' at the burials of total strangers.

When Olivier played Henry V, Charles Laughton told him: 'You are England', which is why Olivier could so shockingly embody England's post-imperial shame when he appeared in John Osborne's The Entertainer. Gielgud, by contrast, was never heroic, disliked clanking round in armour and was terrified of clambering onto horseback. (His mount rebuffed him in Mankiewicz's film of Julius Caesar and rolled over on top of the squealing thespian.) But in his own way, he helped define national identity, which is, after all, a theatrical role.

The Olivier who rallied his troops at Agincourt in the name of England and St George came from a Huguenot family. Gielgud caught the English, elegiac mood so well because he was actually a Slav. His Polish ancestry gave him (he believed) his affinity with Chekhov; and his home outside Aylesbury was transformed into a Hapsburg lodge from the last ornate days of the Austro-Hungarian empire by his louche, middle-European lover, Martin Hensler.

Before his death last year at the age of 96, Gielgud had come to embody an obsolete Englishness. 'I am hired,' he said of his brief, lucrative jobs in bad films, 'to lend a bit of elderly grandeur.' He became part of the heritage industry. Could he perhaps have been Shakespeare reincarnated? Other actors said he spoke the verse as if he had written it; Peter Hall dressed him as Shakespeare at the end of his production of The Tempest in 1974. More sardonically, Gielgud played a morose, catatonic, suicidal Shakespeare in Edward Bond's Bingo.

Symbolising stately ruin, he reminded us that this old, apparently gracious England was better dead. Hence the prissy bigotry of his Cambridge hierarch in Chariots of Fire, or his dotty radical who distributes pamphlets during the patrician carnage in The Shooting Party. As Dudley Moore's butler in Arthur, he cheerfully derided his own good breeding. While Moore romped in his tub, Gielgud fastidiously asked whether he was expected to soap the midget's dick.

Gielgud, who wanted a discreet and imperceptive apologist, nominated Sheridan Morley as his biographer 12 years ago, and constantly chided him for his slow progress: 'How old am I now, dear boy?' Eventually, Gielgud realised that Morley wanted him dead. Once Gielgud (as we say in Australia) quietly carked, Morley went to work faster than the undertaker. He began this long book on the day of Gielgud's death last May, and finished it in December (though he confidently describes the London auction of Gielgud memorabilia, which took place last month, long after the book went to press).

If I had been Morley, I would not have boasted about such meretricious haste. It shows; he has merely collaged clippings and anthologised the usual clangers. No psychological perceptions are on offer here. Intent on theatrical gossip, Morley remains unaware of the social and cultural changes which Gielgud, successively modernising himself, from his role an Oedipal drug addict in Noël Coward's The Vortex in 1925 to the shabby, poncing poetaster he played in Pinter's No Man's Land in 1975, took it on himself to act out.

Morley explains his procrastination by saying that only after Gielgud's death could he write about the crucial incident in his life, repressed in Gielgud's own recollections. This was his arrest in 1953 for importuning a decoy bobby in a Chelsea loo. But for all his sensationalism, Morley's account of the episode is unrevealing. He should have thought about the relevance of the location - Gielgud sought gratification in a lavatory because he considered sex to be relief. He was no demon lover like Olivier (and was content, by all accounts, with schoolboy fumblings). A carnal itch distracted him from his real infatuation, the theatre. At the end of his life, he said he wanted to make an advertisement for underwear, in which he intended to confide: 'At my age, all's quiet on the Y-front.' Like so much else he said in that plaintive voice, this, too, was an anthem for a departed imperial - or perhaps just imperious - glory.

Morley has wasted his access to the man, whose character and significance elude him. A great life calls for a great biographer, not an all-purpose scribbler on the fringes of luvviedom.
