webTitle: Observer review: Ungentle Shakespeare by Katherine Duncan-Jones

fields.headline: Shakespeare, our greatest skinflint
fields.standfirst: He wasn't mean with his talent, but as for the rest of his life... Katherine Duncan-Jones restores the bard to life in Ungentle Shakespeare
fields.trailText: He wasn't mean with his talent, but as for the rest of his life... Katherine Duncan-Jones restores the bard to life in Ungentle Shakespeare
fields.body:
Ungentle Shakespeare
Katherine Duncan-Jones
Arden £20, pp322

What mere human could possibly have written Shakespeare's plays? Only a silent genius could have created the world-without-end works that each generation varnishes in cultural piety. Katherine Duncan-Jones's constantly illuminating and hugely enjoyable biography restores the author and his plays to bubbly life. Shakespeare left a documentary trail, pellets of commercial and legal transaction that want only motivation. While recent biographies have either been utterly scrupulous or recklessly conjectural, Duncan-Jones is sufficiently secure in her evidence to speculate with persuasive flair.

Shakespeare's desire to be 'gentle' has nothing to do with literary emollience but with attaining gentlemanly status. She unearths his dealings with the Heralds' College, unpicking his coat of arms - a golden spear, silver-tipped, crested by a swaggering falcon. In an agonising aftermath, his contact at the Heralds was publicly discredited, casting a stain over the dramatist's right to bear arms.

Purse strings tug this story. Shakespeare gets rich through playing the marketplace, speculating on audience taste. Fashions alter, plague and authority may lock the theatre doors, and you sense a comfortable artist dogged by vulnerability. Shakespeare ducked his parish dues and passed on philanthropy, while his will is a calibration of scores tightfistedly settled. Godchildren cast into the cold, his younger daughter slighted, his wife allowed only a final twist of the knife and his second-best bed. 'Curst be he that moves my bones,' snarls his gravestone, ensuring that no relations will snuggle up for all eternity.

With sex, the author again skeeters around uncertainty, but constructs a convincing picture. Her William thrums with adolescent energies and marries Anne Hathaway when she becomes pregnant. The resented union soon loses steam, and thereafter London answers his desire. His most ardent relationships, Duncan-Jones argues, are with men. In an age of female patrons, Shakespeare dedicates amorous verse only to rakish young aristocrats: on paper at least, he builds a rhetoric of intimacy with the glamorous Earl of Southampton, blazing through his inheritance; and the Earl of Pembroke.

Friendly rivalries with younger authors seem to spur Shakespeare, writing in collaboration and competition with keen John Marston or John Fletcher. Another co-writer is fingered for leading Shakespeare astray. Pericles was composed with George Wilkins, a second-rate talent given to violence - kicking at a pregnant belly, lashing at whores from his tavern-cum-brothel. Where previous biographers dissever the Wilkins connection, Duncan-Jones implicates Shakespeare in his rough boys' games. Hanging with Wilkins in disreputable Clerkenwell, Shakespeare may have sharpened his cynicism about female integrity, and perhaps also contracted the syphilis that Duncan-Jones speculates eventually killed him.

Above all, Ungentle Shakespeare describes a theatrical career. Duncan-Jones celebrates the Stratford grammar education that helped Shakespeare join a throng of talents from the West Midlands, but pays sustained attention to the Whitsun plays and royal progresses, ladders of patronage that might have led to the London stage. She portrays Shakespeare the distinguished actor, and notes his contemporary hits. The writer first seized public imagination with rumbustious histories and their 'high-style slaughter of innocents' and became a student pin-up with Hamlet. These successes remind us that if the writer is 'ungentle', so too is his work: Kenneth Gross's intriguing study Shakespeare's Noise (University of Chicago £26.50; £11, pp282) kneads the violent language of curse, insult and vicious slander that animates the plays.

Productions of The Tempest increasingly discover an angry, troubling play. Rather than a benign Prospero dropping his staff and mulching into bucolic retirement, Duncan-Jones proposes a weary writer packing it in when the Globe burnt down during a performance of Henry VIII , and going ungently into that good night. It is hardly news that a writer may enjoy an imaginative life richer, kinder than his pragmatic circumstance. Duncan-Jones triumphantly constructs an upsetting trajectory from playful youth to rancorous skinflint, through which art matures even as character hardens.

webTitle: The acceptable face of anti-capitalism

fields.headline: The acceptable face of anti-capitalism
fields.standfirst:
Behind the protests lie real concerns that business is trying to address, says Roger Cowe

Special report: May Day 2001
fields.trailText: Behind the protests lie real concerns that business is trying to address, says Roger Cowe
fields.body:
The unacceptable face of anti-capitalism grabbed most attention last Tuesday in the ritual that is the modern equivalent of dancing round the maypole. But beyond the violent fringe of the raggle-taggle army of May Day demonstrators is a disparate but powerful coalition that cannot be dismissed as easily as were the previous generations that called for the overthrow of capitalism.

It was the appearance of the anti-capitalist demonstrators in Seattle in November 1999 that first made business leaders take notice of the concerns about globalisation. Subsequent events have maintained the pressure.

Company chairmen forced to cower behind police lines cannot help but be impressed by the strength of feeling and the powers of organisation of people who might be ignored if they contented themselves with polite protest.

Business is listening, but the demonstrations have done little to spell out to business leaders what is expected of them - beyond being a bit nicer and more generous.

The loosely knit movement is better at posing questions - questions that the business world has found difficult to answer - such as why South African Aids sufferers should be denied access to cheap treatment, and why much of the affluent world's expensive consumer goods are produced in conditions of poverty.

Such questions have transformed what had been a genteel debate within the business world on corporate social responsibility (CSR).

When he was appointed last year as the first minister in Europe to hold a CSR portfolio, the Department of Trade Minister Kim Howells saw his mission as encouraging business to do good. The Government views CSR as 'a wide-ranging agenda that involves businesses looking at how to improve their social, environmental and local economic impact, their influence on society, social cohesion, human rights and fair trade'.

The South African pharmaceutical patent affair, which saw the world's biggest drug companies back down, plus the vicious assault on Huntingdon Life Sciences and its financial backers, have demonstrated just how wide-ranging that agenda is. Then factor in the question of slave labour in cocoa plantations, the relationship between supermarkets and farmers and BP shareholders' demands for a strategy 'beyond petroleum' - and that's just in the past week or two.

The force of the attack has been strengthened because it has penetrated the system. Socially responsible investors, such as those putting pressure on BP and other oil companies, bring the arguments to the boardroom.

One response has been a drive within business for greater responsibility and openness. For example, the EU has backed a new organisation, CSR Europe, which was behind the European Parliament's first conference on corporate responsibility 10 days ago.

Former EU vice-president Etienne Davignon, who chairs CSR Europe, told the conference: 'We need to make corporate social responsibility and sustainable development, together with peace, human rights and democracy, the guiding principles of the twenty-first century.'

There is still a blindness in some parts of the business world to anything which goes beyond philanthropy. Elsewhere, however, Davignon demonstrates a growing acceptance that companies must address how they make money, not just how much they give away, and they must account for how they behave.

Self-interest is a significant driver of this growing concern. For example, companies with strong brands (such as Nike and Adidas) have realised they must protect their reputations. That means, among other things, trying to ensure suppliers do not employ children or pay low wages.

Paradoxically for the anti-capitalists, a task force headed by BT's former managing director, Bill Cockburn, recently argued that this would actually help companies make higher profits.

'This [social responsibility] isn't about making a feelgood contribution to charity,' Cockburn said in launching his report at last year's CBI conference. 'It's about the basic way of doing business and it can actually save you a lot of money.' That is not likely to please the serious anti-capitalists. But there is confusion in their ranks about what needs to be done by business.

The initial preoccupation with issues such as trade rules and mass poverty have spread to a generalised mistrust and criticism. The coalition embraces campaigns on issues such as animal welfare, climate change and genetically modified foods, but new challenges pop up almost at random.

Some critics, such as the writer Naomi Klein, have focused on accountability and transparency, but it is far from clear what is expected of business. Take the pharmaceutical affair. The big pharmaceutical companies bowed to demands to withdraw their ill-conceived legal action blocking cheap generic treatments. But the battle leaves two huge questions hanging: how do you define which countries or which sufferers are worthy of cut-price medicines? (Or why should a poor Californian die early, just because he lives in the richest country on earth.)

And if poor countries deserve cheap drugs, surely farmers, food companies, water utilities and other suppliers of life's necessities should be roped in to hand out cheap goods and services.

Part of the problem is a confusion between what business can do and what can only be changed by governments and inter-governmental agencies. The line is not clear - after all, the corporate world pushed for the intellectual property agreement that underpinned the drug companies' action in the South African courts.

But there are areas where social needs will not be met by the private sector - such as the cancellation of international debt. And there are areas where governments have to act by creating international institutions if they want some kind of control over multinationals. In the meantime, an agenda for what companies have to do can be glimpsed through the fog of anti-capitalist rhetoric.

This agenda has generated a plethora of codes, standards and schemes to flesh out such broad demands, from the UN's Global Compact to the UK's Ethical Trading Initiative. But none of these admirable efforts at clarification and codification will answer the crucial questions that GlaxoSmithKline and Tesco have both stumbled across in the last couple of weeks: what is a decent price, and how much profit is too much?

There is no simple answer but companies need to accept that the rules have changed; that profit alone is no longer enough. It requires a much fuller awareness of the business, such as knowing where your cocoa beans come from and how they are produced. And companies must openly confront the issues.

That means, first knowing, understanding and talking to critics - the ones that aren't throwing the stones and petrol bombs, that is.

Checklist for right-thinking companies

 Pay suppliers properly

 Pay workers decent wages

 Don't rip off customers or exclude those in poverty

 Cut use of natural resources, especially fossil fuels

 Cut waste and pollution

 Respect animals and the environment

 Lobby for all these things, and not against them and, by the way, also make a reasonable return for shareholders

But none of these admirable efforts at clarification and codification will answer the crucial questions that GlaxoSmithKline and Tesco have both stumbled across in the last couple of weeks: what is a decent price, and how much profit is too much? There is no simple answer but companies need to accept that the rules have changed; that profit alone is no longer enough. It requires a much fuller awareness of the business, such as knowing where your cocoa beans come from and how they are produced. And companies must openly confront the issues. That means, first knowing, understanding and talking to critics - the ones that aren't throwing the stones and petrol bombs, that is. Checklist for right-thinking companies  Pay suppliers properly  Pay workers decent wages  Don't rip off customers or exclude those in poverty  Cut use of natural resources, especially fossil fuels  Cut waste and pollution  Respect animals and the environment  Lobby for all these things, and not against them and, by the way, also make a reasonable return for shareholders

webTitle: Soros: May Day protestors do have a point

fields.headline: Soros: May Day protestors do have a point
fields.standfirst: A new coalition is needed to change the global economy in favour of the poor, the financier tells  Faisal Islam
fields.trailText: A new coalition is needed to change the global economy in favour of the poor, the financier tells Faisal Islam
fields.body:
George Soros was not among the May Day protesters penned in by police in Oxford Circus. The financier and one-time railway porter at Willesden Junction station in north London is not known for dressing in white overalls or demonstrating. But this colossus of global capitalism sympathises with some of the causes espoused by such protests around the world.

'There's considerable justification for being critical of the present arrangement [in the global economy],' he says. 'Anti-globalisation is a movement that has put Third World debt on the agenda. It may have a violent fringe, but there's some very serious forces and movements involved.'

Before meeting Soros, one expects a lesson in risk premiums, hedge funds and, above all, about being feared by the world's central bankers. What you get is more akin to philosophical treatise.

Soros' philanthropy is well documented. He has set up many foundations in the former eastern bloc, particularly the Balkans. But his staff say most of his time is taken up by concern for 'an open society and reforming the international financial institutions such as the International Monetary Fund and World Bank'.

The controversy over drugs patents is an important issue for him. 'Intellectual property rights is a good slogan for creating monopolies,' he says. It 'has been given too much weight compared to other issues.

'You really get the most out of intellectual property if other people use it. So giving ownership rights can be counterproductive. Also, it's anti-competitive, in a way. Now you need to have a patent in order to allow investment but you also have to limit this to make sure the benefits reach people.'

Soros thinks about globalisation a lot. He is reading The Great Transformation by the economic historian Karl Polanyi. Its central thesis concerns friction between the 'self-regulating market economy' and the traditional forces of 'national and social protection'. Polanyi believed capitalism to be a historical anomaly because it usurps normal social relations. 'It's a brilliant analysis of the problems of globalisation as they developed in the nineteenth century - the problems we have today are not new,' says Soros.

His critics in South-east Asia are acutely aware of the turmoil that financial liberalisation can cause. The prime ministers of Thailand and Malaysia blamed the financier for helping precipitate the 1997 Asian financial crisis. He abandoned a trip to Bangkok after protests and threats.

On the other hand, isn't talk of a reform agenda for globalisation a bit of a luxury amid fears of global recession? 'On the contrary,' Soros says, 'this is the real agenda. I think the system itself is in danger, and there's more fundamental and systemic issues than this particular economic slowdown.

'I think our existing institutions will keep the slowdown within tolerable bounds in the developed world. But it may have some more adverse consequences in the outlying parts, which have already been weakened by the emerging markets crisis.'

This is just the latest manifestation of a 'centre-periphery' problem where markets are globalised without a concomitant globalisation of power. His solution is reforms to create a fairer system of global institutions for all countries.

'We need to establish this principle, because the system is fundamentally uneven, the playing field is uneven. We have to find the incentives for good government, for instance providing budgetary support for education, which would enable those countries to eliminate child labour.'

He talks of global leaders adopting the ideas of Amartya Sen, the Cambridge-based Nobel prizewinner in economics. Sen's book, Development as Freedom, has become a manifesto of sorts for what might be termed 'progressive globalisation'. Lionel Jospin, the French prime minister, talks about it as a model. James Wolfensohn, the World Bank president, gets Sen to lecture his staff. And Gordon Brown, the Chancellor, has held seminars for him at Number 11.

Sen argues that 'to be generically against markets would be almost as odd as being generically against conversation. The freedom to exchange words, or goods, or gifts is part of the way human beings act with each other.'

Globalisation is neither new, nor necessarily bad, he says. But it must be fair. Development is more than just economic growth, and should focus on health and education. Economic reforms should not obviate the need for building these basic capabilities.

And what Sen has advocated in economics, Soros is pushing for in politics. The financier thinks that far from there being too much globalisation, the process hasn't gone far enough. Free trade in agriculture, for example, would greatly reducepoverty in poor countries. This is why 'anti-globalisation' protests may be misplaced.

'There is a strange coalition of very different forces that is united in trying to destroy or undermine our international institutions. It's very unfortunate because this combination has in fact weakened the international institutions - we don't have a viable alternative to the global economy. A breakdown in it would undermine our prosperity.

'So we need to form a different coalition which would recognise the shortcomings of the present arrangements and instead of destroying the existing institutions would create the missing ones - those that would protect human values - of democracy, environmental standards, labour standards, and what I would call a level playing field.'

But is this call for truly global governance realistic in the current international climate?

Anyone who has participated in financial markets, as Soros has, seems to develop an unalienable belief in self-fulfiling prophecies and the importance of credibility and confidence. Soros 'broke the Bank of England' in 1992, not because he had a great deal of money, but because he knew it was not credible for the UK to remain in the European exchange rate mechanism in the medium-term. His inspired gamble became a self-fulfiling prophecy.

This line of thought now applies to his views on global governance. He seems unnerved by some actions of the new Bush administration in Washington.

'A society guided by survival of the fittest is torn apart internally unless there is something that keeps it together,' he says. 'And what keeps it together best is a threat from the outside. This was provided by the Cold War, where the US could be the leader of the free world.They're hankering after that situation, so they are casting around for enemies, looking high and low, and I think by doing it they're going to find them high and low.'

Soros spoke of the damage done to European and Japanese sensibilities by Bush ending the US commitment to the 1998 Kyoto Agreement on climate change, and of deteriorating relations with China. The Americans 'put down the South Korean president when he wants to bring North Korea out from the cold, because they want to keep North Korea in the cold,' he says. But he praised Bush's citing of labour and environmental standards in his push for a free trade area for the Americas.

In a previous interview, Soros told The Observer of his partial backing for the so-called 'Tobin tax' on currency speculation. He supports debt relief and inheritance taxes, invokes a US military-industrial complex, and advocates the creation of world authorities to protect environmental and labour standards.

When you put the strands together, he sounds more and more like an Oxford Circus protester, though without the drums. 'That's overstating it. As a capitalist myself I'm definitely on the inside, but I would like to work on reforms from there, and I think those outside have some really valid points.'

He seems to be intent on reconciling globalisation and free marketeering, with a fairer world for all. As Polanyi recognised 50 years ago, if capitalism is to be more than an 'anomaly', it had better adapt to serve the needs of the many.

George Soros is the author of 'Open Society: Reforming global capitalism' , published by Little, Brown.

Soros on Soros

'I have not even a shadow of remorse for making a profit out of the devaluation of the pound. ... I didn't speculate against the pound to help England. I didn't do it to hurt England. I did it to make money.'

'I am a dissident by nature. I want a society in which dissidents can flourish.'

'Don't forget, I became a philanthropist only after I became a speculator. It is a luxury'

'I have always harboured an exaggerated view of my self-importance. I fancied myself as some kind of god or an economic reformer like Keynes, or, even better, like Einstein.'

'The new market fundamentalism is more dangerous to the world now than Communism'

webTitle: Spectre lurks at oh-so-polite G7 feast

fields.headline: Spectre lurks at oh-so-polite G7 feast
fields.trailText: The world movement against globalisation is flagging. Faced with three opportunities for disruption in a fortnight, the protesters were out in force in Quebec at the American trade summit, but, drawing breath before May-Day, they were in short supply at the spring meetings of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund in Washington last weekend.
fields.body:
The world movement against globalisation is flagging. Faced with three opportunities for disruption in a fortnight, the protesters were out in force in Quebec at the American trade summit, but, drawing breath before May-Day, they were in short supply at the spring meetings of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund in Washington last weekend.

This was just as well, because we financial commentators did not go into this business with the same motives as those colleagues who fret when they are away from a war zone. Nor did the finance ministers, central bankers and officials who take part in the regular round of international economic discussions. They are resigned to a busy life, but prefer a quiet one, too. The ritual trashing of McDonald's has yet to make it on to the ever- expanding agenda of the Group of Seven leading finance ministers.

Perhaps it was their natural pacifism that induced participants at the G7 meeting to seek headlines of the 'peace breaks out' variety. They almost succeeded. After a week during the run-up to the meeting when the International Monetary Fund was extremely critical in public of the European Central Bank's refusal to cut interest rates, the tone of the actual meeting was noticeably more restrained and polite.

The Bush administration may be at odds with Europe over everything from Son of Star Wars to global warming, but there was a lot of respectful listening on the economic front last weekend, with the British agreeably surprised at US Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill's support for their ambitious plans to reduce poverty, and the European Central Bank feeling it had received a respectful hearing for its seemingly intransigent position on interest rates.

True, there was slight embarrassment when ECB President Willem Duisenberg said the G7 had written 'it is not our intent to give directions to each other', but the implied declaration of respect for ECB independence was not in the final draft of the communiqué.

True, the British thought they had effected a minor coup in getting the G7 to agree to be 'vigilant and forward-looking' - code for urging the ECB to cut rates before eurozone inflation turns down - but it was all pretty small beer.

Negotiators and eager newshounds get overexcited at these meetings. It would be news if policy makers were not supposed to be 'vigilant and forward-looking'. What the ECB is looking forward to is the prospect of eurozone inflation getting worse before it gets better. There is every sign that earlier criticism from others has merely hardened the ECB's position.

It is different when the specific policy goals are negotiated into G7 communiqués. Some years ago, the G7 began an attack on 'money laundering', and this led to procedures which made the attack a reality. Similarly, relief of Third World debt - painfully slow though it has proved - became part of the international bureaucratic process.

There was even a breakfast meeting within the IMF headquarters where Paul Martin, the Canadian Finance Minister, and our own Gordon Brown were telling representatives of the aid agencies (generally known these days as NGOs) that they could not do what they were trying to do on the debt, poverty and health fronts without the NGOs, and an NGO representative was saying: 'We can't do what we do without you and your political leadership'.

Not only are the NGOs allowed within the building, but before one comes to the IMF and World Bank handouts (no pun intended), the document that strikes you is 'Reality Check - The need for deeper debt cancellation and the fight against HIV/Aids', a report by Drop the Debt. It tells you - within the hallowed precincts of the IMF building - that 'the World Bank and IMF preach economic integration of all countries, but only enforce trade liberalisation in poor countries'.

Well, they're working on it. The communiqué stated: 'We look forward to further discussions on moving beyond debt relief in preparation for the Genoa Summit. In this context, we underscore the importance of focusing on steps to increase opportunities for trade...'

The spectre at the feast of last week's meetings was of course the economy of the host country: the US itself. With a great sense of timing the US administration unveiled first-quarter figures suggesting that the US economic growth rate had picked up from 1 per cent a year in October-December 2000 to 2 per cent a year in January-March.

But this is not as good as it sounds. It suggests an average of 1.5 per cent over the six months, which is well below the estimated growth of productive potential (of perhaps 3 per cent) at which the economy has to grow to prevent unemployment rising.

Basically, the US economy is already in what economists call a 'growth recession'. The profits squeeze resulting from a classic business-cycle phase of overinvestment is producing a steady stream of redundancy announcements in the US and from US multinationals around the world.

The optimistic view is that as consumers 'refinance' their mortgages at lower interest rates, consumption, which weakened in the course of the first quarter, will pick up. The pessimistic view is that the redundancies caused by the 'bust' that has followed the boom will erode real incomes and consumer confidence, and prolong the growth recession.

George Bush is not thanked for having talked the recession up (and the economy down) when he came to office - a ploy that seems to have been inspired, if that is the word, by a desire to find a Keynesian justification for tax cuts long planned for dubious 'supply-side' reasons.

The tax cuts are shamelessly aimed at the rich, some of whom are even criticising them as being socially unfair. But it is interesting that they have been welcomed by Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan.

Greenspan's critics believe he has been shamelessly political in reversing his position (he used to prefer debt reduction to tax cuts) and has finally come out in his true right-wing Republican colours. But it may also be that he believes cutting interest rates in the face of the collapse of an investment boom is like Keynes's classic 'pushing on a string' and has suddenly rediscovered fiscal policy as a tool of demand management.

My own feeling is that the US economic slowdown is serious - 'the bigger the boom, the bigger the bust' - and that it is not surprising the US administration wants Europe to show some economic leadership, however discreetly the argument is now being put. In these circumstances, while affirming that it believes in 'a strong dollar' all the way to the bank, the US Treasury would probably not be averse to a gentle depreciation of the dollar against the euro, to help hard-pressed US multinationals.

As for the UK, the overvaluation of the pound becomes more and more obvious and, taken with the fall-out from the US growth recession, the outlook seems to be deteriorating fast. The G7 communiqué said: 'The [UK] slowdown appears to be only moderate' - but that was written as long as a week ago. From the Treasury's point of view this will be the 'just-in-time' election.

webTitle: Comment: Tate, our Tate

fields.headline: Tate, our Tate
fields.standfirst: What need have we of a new Wembley when as a nation, we now prefer art to footer?
fields.trailText: Take two British cultural temples. The first is bankrupt Wembley, now in the receivership of a Downing Street task force. No doubt we shall end up lumbered with Lord Foster's new national football stadium, rising from the Middlesex tundra like a giant cucumber frame. The cost will be horrific, but the public will bear anything when national pride is at stake. This time they may not. The oddest thing about the débcle is that there are so few yowls of protest at the fate of the 'Venue of Legends', actually a tacky monstrosity imbued with the stench of depression and fossilised cheeseburger.
fields.body:
Take two British cultural temples. The first is bankrupt Wembley, now in the receivership of a Downing Street task force. No doubt we shall end up lumbered with Lord Foster's new national football stadium, rising from the Middlesex tundra like a giant cucumber frame. The cost will be horrific, but the public will bear anything when national pride is at stake. This time they may not. The oddest thing about the débcle is that there are so few yowls of protest at the fate of the 'Venue of Legends', actually a tacky monstrosity imbued with the stench of depression and fossilised cheeseburger.

There is, instead, a shiver of shame over the ineptitude involved and anger over the wider implications. We can't remodel the London Underground or build the right hospitals at a fair price because the Government is in thrall to public-private partnerships. If we want a soccer venue, then the Football Association should pay for it. If we need a national sports arena, then the Government should pick up the bill and get the money back from rental. Instead, the FA, which has a Ronnie Biggs insouciance about other people's money, received £120 million in cash and then came back for an extra £150m loan.

An organisation so bloated with lucre does not make a convincing Oliver Twist, but the Government is a weak denier. It may pay up, but there won't be much applause. Even the football faithful are not clamouring to get stuck on the North Circular as a prelude to being ripped off for greasy hotdogs and watching England lose 6-1 to Croatia. Something has shifted in the national cultural psyche. Football, suddenly, is out. Art is in.

This week, a second cultural colossus celebrates its first anniversary. Tate Modern, which cost a modest £134m in grants and gifts, was expected to get 2.5 million visitors in its initial year. Instead, the total will be 5.3 million (and would have been much higher if Lord Foster's bridge had escaped the blight afflicting all British building works from suspension bridges to Acacia Avenue carports). A nation once obsessed by soccer is suddenly mad for conceptual art.

It would, of course, be absurd to suggest that audiences are interchangeable. Bankside fans may never be found wearing Union Jack boxer shorts, or chanting Eng-er-lund while ingesting chicken tikka masala and imbibing lakes of lager. They are unlikely to mistake Rauschenberg for an inhabitant of the Bayern Munich subs' bench or think that French expressionism is what leads to another red card for Arsenal's Patrick Vieira. While a football fan is not necessarily a visual arts buff, both are part of a new classlessness.

Tate Modern, initially the province of the posh of New Labour in search of free champagne, has altered. It seems shabbier, older and colonised by buggy-pushers and picnickers chewing sandwiches in corridors. The atmosphere is more Wembleyish. Some think Bankside just as lost a cause. Jed Perl lambasted it in Prospect as 'a fraud' offering a 'creepily-distorted view of twentieth-century art'. Given that the mix of styles, occasionally inchoate, is driven by the dearth of great works, why should it be popular at all? Perl's answer is that it is a 'funhouse'; part of a string of vulgar theme parks ranging from the Pompidou Centre to Frank Gehry's Bilbao Guggenheim. If the criticism is unfair, then the analysis of the allure is partly right.

When vast old institutions crumble, new places of worship spring up. In lieu of the Church of England and Marks & Spencer, there is Thorpe Park, Ikea, WalMart, Disney and now Tate Modern, spawned not by get-ahead Labour thinking but in the Prufrockish time of John Major, whose mania for art extended to a statement in his memoir that 'a visit to a museum would fill a wet day'. Despite a cultural split among the Tories (Alistair McAlpine, Thatcher's treasurer, collected Rothkos while his boss hoarded Spam), the compass needle settled on oikishness. But Blair got the backlash of the thwarted hopes of those (Tusa, Drummond, Naipaul, Sir Peter Hall) detecting in a Prime Minister who likes Ivanhoe and Bruce Springsteen the cultural sensibilities of an orang-utan. Whether or not he is a philistine, Blair seems to see the electorate as irredeemably so.

The Dome was directly targeted at a Visigoth audience in love with Butlins, Blackpool, Blue Nun, prawn cocktail, Richard and Judy, 'Nessun Dorma', Monet's waterlilies, Starbucks' latte and Captain Corelli's Mandolin. No wonder that the target audience pushed off, affronted, to Tate Modern to take in some of the Braques, Matisses and Morandis for which Blair may have little personal enthusiasm. When I interviewed its director, Lars Nittve, for the New Statesman, he said he had never met Tony Blair. How odd that a Prime Minister who has offered canapés to Chris Evans and Oasis would not wish to greet someone who rescued the Government from millennial disaster.

But perhaps Blair doesn't get it. Good museums, in the capital and the cash-starved regions, aren't simply the cod-liver oil in the national cultural diet or a poor relation. Here, a local authority may have to choose between sacking a curator or a social worker. In Europe, towns are revived and visitors pulled in by prestige projects such as the Musée des Beaux Arts in Lille. In comparison, Blair's ploy to woo tourists comprises an offer to call off the Gurkhas and stop blasting sheep. Art is what Labour should be about. It is classless, universal and, thanks to the Government's move to end charging, free at the point of delivery. It's good for regeneration. The Tate Modern figures suggest it represents a craze of Pokémon card proportions. So why are we still stereotyped as a nation of sport-crazed oiks, a tag that seems insufferably patronising when the national football coach is a cosmopolitan Swede and the Arsenal manager a multilingual Frenchman who studies philosophy?

Partly because we have a long tradition of soccer and a fractured one of art. While Europe fostered its impressionists, cubists and surrealists, we, with some exceptions, lurched straight from The Fighting Temeraire to Tracey Emin's bed. Now, suddenly, we are as likely to know what's on at the Saatchi Gallery as where Barnet are in the league. Thanks to Lottery money, the Government is finally investing more in the arts in general, albeit in a hit-and-miss way. The Bradford Life Force Centre (cost £5m) closed two months ago after attracting 62 visitors in its first week. So did the oxymoronic National Centre for Popular Music in Sheffield and the Centre for Visual Arts in Cardiff.

Duff projects aside, something is changing. We loathed the trashy Dome, we're not enthralled by the idea of a new national football stadium but we do like modern art. So, as the election campaign begins, how should the Government budget for popular taste? Tate Modern claims it needs far more money to do a good job for the community. So does the Football Association. The former wants £2m, the latter £150m. There has rarely been a better chance to do the right thing on the cheap.

webTitle: Baby at 40 will lose you friends

fields.headline: Baby at 40 will lose you friends
fields.trailText: Women who choose the increasingly popular path to middle-aged motherhood are not just taking medical risks: they are also likely to lose their closest friends.
fields.body:
Women who choose the increasingly popular path to middle-aged motherhood are not just taking medical risks: they are also likely to lose their closest friends.

The author of a study into women having babies in their late thirties, and forties, has found the extreme change of lifestyle is often harder for friends to deal with than for the new mother herself.

Madonna, Cherie Blair, Ruby Wax, Patricia Hodge, Annette Bening and Jerry Hall are among recent high-profile women in their forties who have given birth. But Corinne Sweet's forthcoming Birth Begins at Forty points out that it is not only the affluent who are going ahead with late pregnancies.

Today, 40 per cent of babies are born to women aged between 30 and 39 and a significant 2 per cent to those already in their forties. Undeterred by the greater likelihood of miscarriage and birth abnormalities, women who have enjoyed a full professional and social life in their twenties and thirties are embracing late motherhood in growing numbers. But they are frequently losing valued friendships.

'I lost two of my closest friends when I had a baby late in life,' said Sweet. 'One of them, who already had grown-up children, totally dropped me. Another told me I had become "a breastfeeding bore".'

The schism is caused, Sweet now believes, by a latent form of subconscious rivalry. 'I was deeply hurt at the time, but understood, in retrospect, that my friend was used to having me available to her and was, in a sense, experiencing a grown-up sibling rivalry with my new baby.'

Female friends of any age, Sweet points out, bond by a process of twinning. They share as much as they can and often wear similar clothes. A new baby at a late stage is a threat to this mirroring.

Helen Michaels, a teacher who had her first child last year at the age of 47, immediately noticed the impact on one of her best friends. 'I have had to meet a fresh group of women, whether I wanted to or not,' she said. 'I felt as if one of my best, funniest girlfriends no longer trusted me. She just faded out of the picture. I miss her.'

 Birth Begins at Forty is published by Hodder and Stoughton on 21 June.

webTitle: Sneak preview: what's on offer for summer 2002

fields.headline: Sneak preview: what's on offer for summer 2002
fields.trailText: * Thomson Holidays has a controversial 'no discounting' strategy on main brands Thomson Summer Sun, Far Away Shores, Florida, All Inclusive and Greece. It promises 'bottom line' rates, where the brochure price is 'competitive' with what you would pay for
fields.body:
* Thomson Holidays has a controversial 'no discounting' strategy on main brands Thomson Summer Sun, Far Away Shores, Florida, All Inclusive and Greece. It promises 'bottom line' rates, where the brochure price is 'competitive' with what you would pay for

a similar package bought from a rival after any discount. Thomson's lowest price for next summer is £179 per person based on four adults sharing a one-bedroom apartment in Majorca for a week in October. More typical Mediterranean package prices for August start at £355.

* Airtours is launching its summer 2002 brochures on 17 May with discounts of up to 20 per cent from day one. The biggest discounts are likely to be through its Going Places agency and other 'recommended agents', which sharp-eyed consumers can spot from a special sticker in the shop window of independent agents.

* First Choice is making a big push towards families with 'early booking offers' of half-price holidays and two children for £1 on selected dates at 60 properties, especially 'family friendly' villas with pools, located away from busy roads. A limited number of free child places are on offer plus special deals for single parents. Prices for summer 2002 start at £239 per person for seven nights in Kavol, Corfu.

* First Choice's subsidiary Unijet has launched a 2002 lead-in price of £215 per person self-catering on Spain's Costa Blanca.

* JMC , the tour operating arm of Thomas Cook, has launched 10 brochures with 'money-off' savings and free child places. Early bookers are offered £300 off packages per adult couple and £400 for families.

A week in Turkey in early May 2002 costs £359 per person with £150 discount per person. The same week in Minorca is £499 per person with a £150 discount.

webTitle: Sean Penn: Just don't tell him he's not angry

fields.headline: Give it up for Sean Penn
fields.standfirst: He is the most explosive actor of his generation, with a professional and personal life characterised by unparalleled intensity. But having turned 40, Sean Penn has become a non-smoking family man who likes boating and riding bikes with his kids. Just don't tell him he's not angry any more
fields.trailText: He is the most explosive actor of his generation, with a professional and personal life characterised by unparalleled intensity. But having turned 40, Sean Penn has become a non-smoking family man who likes boating and riding bikes with his kids. Just don't tell him he's not angry any more.
fields.body:
Sean Penn quit smoking on his 40th birthday, and at this moment, 26 American Spirit-less days in - nicotine patches are for wimps - he is as miserable as a happy man can be. Over lunch at an outdoor restaurant near his home in Marin County, north of San Francisco, he worries a hole in the paper tablecloth with his thumb, then works on enlarging it. His fingernails are bitten to the quick. He consumes two main courses - fried-calamari followed by a hamburger platter. Breakfast was steak and eggs and chips, coffee and Coke.

A little later in the afternoon, on the way to George Lucas's Skywalker Ranch to screen a movie by a young Israeli director who interests him, Penn stops at a drive-in for another hamburger. 'You're seeing the evidence of the post-cigarette bloat,' he says with a wan smile, sitting down with his tray.

He's probably carrying a few extra pounds, but he looks good. With his Vandyke beard, big, square head, and long, strong nose, he bears a passing resemblance to Ezra Pound in his middle years.

These are Sean Penn's middle years: how amazing. His small, sleepy blue eyes, with their perpetual look of challenge or disbelief, are fringed with fine lines. It's an arresting, monumental, worrisome face: looking at him, you think, What else could somebody with a face like this do but be a movie star?

He takes off his black leather jacket, and under the rolled-up shirtsleeve on his left forearm, I spy a large, ornate tattoo of a shackled demon with the caption DELIVER ME in Gothic letters. Deliver me from what? Evil? The celebrity press? His own demons?

As we know well by now, Sean Penn, a reasonably public figure, has mixed feelings about public exposure. As the survivor of enough unwanted publicity to last a lifetime - primarily for his pugnacity with the press during his brief and tumultuous mid-80s marriage to Madonna - he is nobody's media whore. He has a long and sensitive relationship with paparazzi (in 1987 he spent 34 days in jail for punching an amateur paparazzo, an extra who tried to take his picture on a movie set). He gives interviews sparingly and reluctantly. Yet as a performer who has consistently taken roles in challenging films, as opposed to films that earn big money, he has effectively turned himself into an actor's actor, a remote star with a lingering air of menace and inaccessibility, all of which continues to make him an object of fascination.

Soon, Penn tells me, he'll begin rehearsals for a Sam Shepard play ( The Late Henry Moss ) that will run for six weeks in San Francisco; then he'll star in an independent picture called The Assassination of Richard Nixon ('That's a good story,' he says, smiling). 'Then I should make another movie,' Penn says.

That's not make as in 'act in'. He's talking about his true love: writing and directing dark, quirky, performance-driven movies in which he does not perform. The problem thus far, however - if his first two pictures, The Indian Runner and The Crossing Guard, are any indication - is that filmmaker Penn's movies don't perform at the box office.

With his third film, The Pledge, Sean Penn is trying to rip out of the box - but by his own rules. Like The Crossing Guard, The Pledge stars Jack Nicholson and features Robin Wright Penn. Like both of his previous films, it is dark. And once again, Sean Penn will not appear in front of the cameras. Based loosely on the Friedrich Dürrenmatt novel, The Pledge is the story of a retired homicide detective (Nicholson) who can't let a long-closed child-killing case go. Tracking a suspect to the Sierra Nevada, he pursues his love of fishing while waiting to reel in the killer.

The Pledge will be distributed by a major studio, Warner Bros. It was financed by an independent production company called Franchise Pictures, was budgeted at a relatively modest $30m - $10m of which goes to pay Nicholson's full fee - and was shot on a shoestring in Vancouver. 'It's a retirement-crisis story disguised as a thriller, let's put it that way,' the writer/director says. 'I didn't get the retirement-crisis story financed, if you know what I mean. But I got it shot.' He grins.

Another quirky character study, in other words. But a quirky character study with a three-act structure and plot payoff at the end. Besides Nicholson and Wright, The Pledge also stars Vanessa Redgrave, Helen Mirren, Mickey Rourke, Harry Dean Stanton and Sam Shepard. Nevertheless, distinguished cast aside, Penn the filmmaker is realistic about the studio's involvement, and about why this might be his first project to win a wider audience. 'It's a very different kind of movie than my first two,' Penn says. 'I think everybody considers it much more accessible.'

As always, however, Sean Penn has his own version of accessibility.

There have always been demons. They were there before Penn fired a gun at press helicopters covering his 1986 wedding to Madonna; they were there before the many fist fights won and lost; they are, in the midst of his happiness, there still.

Sunset: we're driving back from the Skywalker Ranch screening - two hours of dark and quirky doings among Orthodox Jews in Jerusalem, sort of a Sean Penn movie with yarmulkes. Penn is at the wheel of his black BMW, accelerating over back-country switchbacks in central Marin. He drives to relax, but he is not an especially relaxed driver. Seat-beltless, he leans over the steering wheel, his goatee jutting defiantly as he scans the road for enemies. Passing through a small town, we soon find ourselves behind one: a very slow Mercedes. 'Come on, sir,' he moans. ' Where is it you think you're not going ?'

A long scar below his right eyebrow puts me in mind of a scene in The Crossing Guard in which Robin Wright asks ex-con David Morse about a similar scar on his forehead. Morse tells her he got it banging his head against the wall. 'You just couldn't stand jail?' Wright asks. 'No, I just couldn't stand me,' Morse says.

Penn wrote the line.

He is, by his own admission, 'a big drinker', even though the court-appointed psychotherapist he consulted after getting out of jail determined he was not an alcoholic. He tells a story against himself: during the earthquake that rattled the counties north of San Francisco in early September, 'I'd had a couple of drinks,' he says. 'I was in my editing room with some people, and suddenly everybody sat down. Fast. I thought that was odd.' He smiles.

It is tempting to think of him as a perpetual rebel, an adolescent in arrest, rather than as a 40-year-old family man - husband to Robin Wright Penn, father to their nine-year-old daughter Dylan Frances and seven-year-old son Hopper Jack. But when I ask where he's headed this evening, he says, 'I'm gonna go home and read to my kids. I tried Harry Potter, but it didn't take. Plus it was too hard to act, doing all those voices.'

It's tempting to remember all the bad behaviour, the indelible template laid down in Fast Times at Ridgemont High and Bad Boys and Racing With the Moon and The Falcon and the Snowman - the remote, sneering, mesmerising man-boy with the little, close-set eyes.

'So how was turning 40?' I ask him.

He laughs a little. 'Yeah-how about that?' he says.

'How'd it hit you?'

'Well, it was a disaster,' he says. 'I had always told myself that I really should quit smoking at 30. OK, 35. Always, 40 was: there's no choice any more, you just have to do it.'

'Why?'

'It was time not to be a slave to this nonsense, you know? I mean, if I could smoke eight cigarettes a day, I'd smoke the rest of my life. But it's worse than that with me. I smoke four packs like that .'

I ask if the birthday itself, as a landmark, was difficult.

He shakes his head. 'I don't really have a thing about that,' he says. 'I'll go 50, 60 - I don't care. This is not an area of my girlie sensibility. You know, there's that thing: what age do you see yourself as? Always felt I'm more like 76. That's when I'll say, "Oh finally!" I'll feel old at 77.'

He hasn't plucked that number out of nowhere. Penn's father, the director (and actor) Leo Penn, died at 77 - of lung cancer - two years ago. Sean, who was in the midst of shooting Woody Allen's Sweet and Lowdown in New York as his father was dying, flew back to LA every few days to be with him.

'I thought when he lost his dad, it humbled him,' Robin Wright Penn says. 'It took the edge off a little bit.'

Leo Penn's acting career ended in the early 50s when he refused to name names before the House Un-American Activities Committee and was branded a Communist. Blacklisted in the movie business, he turned to television directing. One of Sean Penn's boyhood memories is watching Elia Kazan - who did name names - shoot The Last Tycoon near the Penn family home in Malibu. One day Leo Penn walked his son down to see the set. 'My dad was a very warm, polite person, and Kazan said hello to him, and [Dad] just walked by,' he remembers.

His father's example - in every way - left a strong stamp on Penn. Trying to move from acting to directing is just the start. It's too easy to write off Penn as a self-important punk without tracking the source of his demons. Hollywood is in his blood (his mother Eileen Ryan and his younger brother Christopher are both actors), and he's furious with Hollywood.

'It just makes you angry, the idea that a guy that goes off, fights for his country, wins all kinds of medals by risking his life, and then four years later, the country says, "You can't work here,"' he says. 'And I am a total believer in: it can happen again. There's signs of it all the time. The one thing you can count on in Hollywood - across the board - is cowardice.'

'The thing that makes Sean special in Hollywood is that it takes great courage to do it on your terms, knowing you may not please the 10 guys in town that green-light pictures,' says Art Linson, who got to know Penn when he produced Fast Times and has remained his close friend for almost 20 years. 'He's not going to put out silly, likable movies so an executive at a studio will say, "Way to go, guy - let's have dinner." That takes balls. Few people in this town have the courage to be good.'

Linson is talking about both Penn's acting and his filmmaking. But none of this explains why he's always threatening to quit acting - as if it were cigarettes - when he's so brilliant at it.

'Well, I don't like it,' Penn says. 'Sometimes maybe for a week or two I like it. But there's no comparison to being able to go out and make your movie as a director. It's already a crapshoot that it's something you're interested in - that it relates to what you want to create at all. It's somebody else's trip. And then you add your bit to it. It's a great craft, it's a great interpretive art, and I'm a fan of it, but it doesn't fill any kind of need to work; it certainly hasn't filled my bank account. I just want real creative freedom without worrying about, you know, car payments.'

It's strange: his anger seems more abstract than it once was. I had expected - well, one actor who worked with him asked me, half jokingly, 'Has he punched you in the mouth yet?' It's something that's in the back of your mind when you sit down with Sean Penn. But it's hard to find the hot buttons; he's looser about himself than I thought he'd be.

'What do people get wrong when they write about you?' I ask.

'I usually read pieces about me and respond, "That sounds like the last one,"' he says. 'It's because I get off on the same thing every time, and it's redundant.' He laughs. 'I mean, it'd be more interesting to go on a fact-finding mission. Just pick the front page of the New York Times, and hop in a car, and let's really search it down. See who's fuckin' lying.'

He did something very much like this recently, he tells me, mentioning a trip he took to Selma, Alabama, with a former Black Panther named Geronimo Pratt to encourage citizens to vote in the city's mayoral election. This is mildly astonishing: I hadn't heard that Penn had done any such thing. But shouldn't I have heard? Don't celebrities always make sure they make the news for their good works? There is no mention of Penn's trip on any newspaper or wire- service database: strangely enough, he went solely for the purpose of going.

'Isn't there a potential downside in making a trip like that for somebody like you?' I ask.

'What's the downside?'

'Being perceived as a limousine liberal?'

'I am a limousine liberal,' he says.

He stops the car outside my hotel. 'Look,' he says. 'You don't have to think the world of yourself or be a great activist to do anything like that. I mean, I'm not gonna avoid idiotic comments people want to make just because you try to do something good.'

Sean Penn is trying to do something good. He's not trying to get more famous, or very rich - though he certainly wouldn't mind making enough money to stop doing the very thing we want him to continue doing. ('Give me one cheque,' he says. 'Get rid of the acting; just make movies. Just that one cheque.') Look at the pictures he's done over the past five years: Sweet and Lowdown . The Weight of Water . Up at the Villa . Hurlyburly . The Thin Red Line . She's So Lovely . Dead Man Walking . He has frequently been magnificent. He has seldom been paid in kind. For Sweet and Lowdown , he earned scale (a little more than $2,000 a week), like all actors in Woody Allen films. For Hurlyburly , he made a reported $150,000. For The Thin Red Line , he was reportedly paid $300,000, though his deal included back-end points should the picture earn money. (It didn't.) For well-distributed independent pictures such as The Weight of Water, he earns in the low millions - a quarter of what the blockbusters he regularly turns down pay.

He shrugs. 'I go broke all the time,' he says. 'I can't do what I've been doing - I keep doing projects, and not getting paid for them as an actor, and then I go out as a director...'

He trails off. And make even less is the unspoken thought. Penn developed The Pledge for a year before Warner Bros was involved; he invested a substantial amount of his own cash.

'So why not just go and play a spy for 10 million bucks?'

'I'm too rich to justify that,' he says. 'I mean, I've been the starving artist as a young actor. And if something like that was offered at the time, you know - anything, a TV series - I would've fucking done it in a flash.' He laughs. 'But once you're able to get by and do what you do, I would recommend to myself or anybody else downsizing your life first. Because you gotta believe in it on some level, or don't take the dough.'

But it's hard to downsize your life, even though fate may move it around on you. In 1996, soon after Penn and Robin Wright married, she was carjacked at gunpoint in the driveway of their Santa Monica home. The couple's two small children were in her Toyota Land Cruiser with her: Wright coolly negotiated with the carjackers to let the children go. She escaped unharmed; the crooks were apprehended. Over lunch at an outdoor restaurant near his home in Marin County, north of San Francisco, he worries a hole in the paper tablecloth with his thumb, then works on enlarging it. His fingernails are bitten to the quick. He consumes two main courses - fried-calamari followed by a hamburger platter. Breakfast was steak and eggs and chips, coffee and Coke. A little later in the afternoon, on the way to George Lucas's Skywalker Ranch to screen a movie by a young Israeli director who interests him, Penn stops at a drive-in for another hamburger. 'You're seeing the evidence of the post-cigarette bloat,' he says with a wan smile, sitting down with his tray. He's probably carrying a few extra pounds, but he looks good. With his Vandyke beard, big, square head, and long, strong nose, he bears a passing resemblance to Ezra Pound in his middle years. These are Sean Penn's middle years: how amazing. His small, sleepy blue eyes, with their perpetual look of challenge or disbelief, are fringed with fine lines. It's an arresting, monumental, worrisome face: looking at him, you think, What else could somebody with a face like this do but be a movie star? He takes off his black leather jacket, and under the rolled-up shirtsleeve on his left forearm, I spy a large, ornate tattoo of a shackled demon with the caption DELIVER ME in Gothic letters. Deliver me from what? Evil? The celebrity press? His own demons? As we know well by now, Sean Penn, a reasonably public figure, has mixed feelings about public exposure. As the survivor of enough unwanted publicity to last a lifetime - primarily for his pugnacity with the press during his brief and tumultuous mid-80s marriage to Madonna - he is nobody's media whore. He has a long and sensitive relationship with paparazzi (in 1987 he spent 34 days in jail for punching an amateur paparazzo, an extra who tried to take his picture on a movie set). He gives interviews sparingly and reluctantly. Yet as a performer who has consistently taken roles in challenging films, as opposed to films that earn big money, he has effectively turned himself into an actor's actor, a remote star with a lingering air of menace and inaccessibility, all of which continues to make him an object of fascination. Soon, Penn tells me, he'll begin rehearsals for a Sam Shepard play ( The Late Henry Moss ) that will run for six weeks in San Francisco; then he'll star in an independent picture called The Assassination of Richard Nixon ('That's a good story,' he says, smiling). 'Then I should make another movie,' Penn says. That's not make as in 'act in'. He's talking about his true love: writing and directing dark, quirky, performance-driven movies in which he does not perform. The problem thus far, however - if his first two pictures, The Indian Runner and The Crossing Guard, are any indication - is that filmmaker Penn's movies don't perform at the box office. With his third film, The Pledge, Sean Penn is trying to rip out of the box - but by his own rules. Like The Crossing Guard, The Pledge stars Jack Nicholson and features Robin Wright Penn. Like both of his previous films, it is dark. And once again, Sean Penn will not appear in front of the cameras. Based loosely on the Friedrich Dürrenmatt novel, The Pledge is the story of a retired homicide detective (Nicholson) who can't let a long-closed child-killing case go. Tracking a suspect to the Sierra Nevada, he pursues his love of fishing while waiting to reel in the killer. The Pledge will be distributed by a major studio, Warner Bros. It was financed by an independent production company called Franchise Pictures, was budgeted at a relatively modest $30m - $10m of which goes to pay Nicholson's full fee - and was shot on a shoestring in Vancouver. 'It's a retirement-crisis story disguised as a thriller, let's put it that way,' the writer/director says. 'I didn't get the retirement-crisis story financed, if you know what I mean. There have always been demons. They were there before Penn fired a gun at press helicopters covering his 1986 wedding to Madonna; they were there before the many fist fights won and lost; they are, in the midst of his happiness, there still. webTitle: Scots alarmed by race pledge refusals

fields.headline: Scots alarmed by race pledge refusals
fields.standfirst:
Special report: race issues in the UK
Special report: Scottish parliament
Special report: Conservative party
fields.trailText: A large number of Scots believe politicians who have refused to sign the Commission for Racial Equality's pre-election pledge could worsen discrimination north of the border, a poll reveals today.
fields.body:
A large number of Scots believe politicians who have refused to sign the Commission for Racial Equality's pre-election pledge could worsen discrimination north of the border, a poll reveals today.

Shadow Chancellor Michael Portillo is among the MPs who have failed to sign the agreement that commits politicians 'not to pitch one group against another for short-term political or personal gain'.

The poll carried out by Scottish Opinion for the Sunday Mail asked if racism was likely to increase 'in the light of a number of high-profile politicians refusing to sign the CRE pledge'.

While 38 per cent answered that racism was likely to increase, another 34 per cent thought it would remain at the current level. No one expected it to decrease. The pollsters asked: 'Do you think there is a problem with racism in Scotland.' Fifty-six per cent said yes.

Last week The Observer highlighted the daily abuse faced by asylum seekers in the Sighthill area of Glasgow, which has witnessed a shocking series of verbal and physical attacks.

The poll comes as the Conservative Party struggles to extricate itself from the race row that has plagued it recently. On Wednesday, Portillo travelled to Edinburgh on a pre-election campaign trip and sought to 'make clear we will not tolerate racism'.

Yet the party has struggled to overcome comments made by John Townend, the Yorkshire East MP who refused to sign the CRE pledge, and claimed not to know of 'any happy multicultural society'. The problems for the leadership deepened when the former Cabinet minister Lord Tebbit warned that multi-culturalism and devolution could foster social divisions in Britain.

William Hague has faced a war on two fronts to retain the support of those on the Left of the party, such as Lord Taylor, who last week appeared to be on the verge of leaving, and that of the party grassroots, many of whom sympathise with Townend and Tebbit.

Yet the party has struggled to overcome comments made by John Townend, the Yorkshire East MP who refused to sign the CRE pledge, and claimed not to know of 'any happy multicultural society'. The problems for the leadership deepened when the former Cabinet minister Lord Tebbit warned that multi-culturalism and devolution could foster social divisions in Britain. William Hague has faced a war on two fronts to retain the support of those on the Left of the party, such as Lord Taylor, who last week appeared to be on the verge of leaving, and that of the party grassroots, many of whom sympathise with Townend and Tebbit.

webTitle: Four arrests as National Front marches in Oldham

fields.headline: Four arrests as National Front marches in Oldham
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: A poster featuring the bruised and bloodied face of war veteran Walter Chamberlain, beaten up last month in an alleged racist attack, was brandished by National Front supporters in Oldham yesterday.
fields.body:
A poster featuring the bruised and bloodied face of war veteran Walter Chamberlain, beaten up last month in an alleged racist attack, was brandished by National Front supporters in Oldham yesterday.

Four protesters were arrested as police, who had promised 'zero tolerance' against violence, used a massive show of strength to enforce a ban on political marches in the town.

More than 500 police were deployed to prevent between 50 and 100 National Front members marching through the town.

They were protesting against alleged attacks on whites by Asians following media reports that parts of Oldham have been turned into no-go areas for whites.

Police prevented clashes between the National Front and members of the Anti-Nazi League, although a street was later cordoned off after a man was apparently stabbed. He was treated at the scene.

webTitle: This liberal deception

fields.headline: This liberal deception
fields.standfirst:
Prejudice is a dirty word. Unless liberals are talking about Islam

Special report: religion in the UK
Special report: race issues in the UK
Special report: Conservative party
fields.trailText: May 6, Cristina Odone: Prejudice is a dirty word. Unless liberals are talking about Islam.
fields.body:
How satisfying to stand on the moral high-ground and watch those terrible Tories turn the air blue with their racist insults: John Townend with his slur about a mongrel race; Sir Richard Body calling his book England for the English; and Willy Hague exposed by Lord Taylor - one of his very own - as a weakling unable to replace the lid on the Pandora's box of Conservative bigotry.

Up in north London, chattering-class liberals rub their hands with glee: oh what a sorry spectacle those Conservatives make, how superior we all are. The word 'mongrel' - or 'nigger', or 'darkie' - would never pass our lips, no-one would ever be turned away from our home or business because of their colour.

But liberal tolerance is only skin deep: when it comes to the belief system that most blacks and Asians in this country subscribe to, the bien pensants prove as prejudiced as John Townend, Lord Tebbit and Ian Paisley rolled into one. Anti-Islam is the acceptable face of racism; to give a Muslim a hard time about her faith is kosher, in a way that so much as to notice her different hue is not. Listen to the bastions of liberal Britain: Polly Toynbee, 'I am an Islamophobe'; Linda Grant, 'I am pretty Islamophobic myself'; and Andrew Marr, who in this very paper wrote of a 'thick impenetrable bubble' that separated a serious Muslim from 'planet Marr'.

Racist sentiments all. For religion is, according to Bhikhu Parekh, who chaired the Commission on the Future of Multi-ethnic Britain, a fundamental component of ethnicity; an attack on its beliefs and practices constitutes racism, he writes in Integrating Minorities (published by the ICA). In other words, spitting at someone because she's wearing a head-scarf is the same as spitting at someone because she looks Asian.

To attack other religions that ethnic minorities belong to - Hinduism and the Afro-Caribbean churches - would prove equally racist. But where Islam earns vicious words from the liberals, Hinduism with its gawdy elephant gods and the Afro-Caribbean churches with their happy-clappy guitar strumming, get away with a smirk of condescension.

This scapegoating of Muslims prompted the 1997 Runnymede report to recommend that Britain broaden its anti-racist agenda to include a campaign against Islamophobia. That report called for a ban on religious discrimination - but in the well-protected avenues where the liberal consensus flourishes, the call fell on deaf ears. These liberals defend their anti-Muslim rants by pointing out that they are equally happy to discriminate against all religions. As if their anti-Christianity offers comfort to Muslims.

No Muslim (or Christian, Hindu, or Jew) accepts this: religious discrimination, even when not rooted in racism, betrays medieval intolerance of the sort that fuelled the Inquisition and the trials of witches. It is fanned by a near-universal ignorance of the world of religion - any religion; and this ignorance forms the well-spring of fear.

The notion of a spiritual authority that commands unswerving allegiance sends shivers down the secular spine. No atheist can understand that an attack on the god you love is as devastating as an attack on the name you bear or the pigmentation you have - indeed, more so: your faith informs what you think, do, wear and say, far more than being black or being called Patel does.

Westerners mask their prejudice behind liberal posturing: in Muslim countries, they claim, women are not equal to men. Think of the Taliban women or of female circumcision practised in sub-Saharan Africa. Yet neither female illiteracy nor female circumcision has any place in the Koran; these are tribal practices, not religious. In this country, as Bhikhu Parekh reveals, Muslim girls' A-level participation rate is higher than that of white boys; and in the States, African-American women are increasingly embracing Islam, claiming they are accorded greater respect.

Another stone cast against the Muslim world is that theirs is an oppressive regime, characterised by the cruel sharia law that cuts off a thief's hand and stones an adulteress to death. Yet this portrait of brutality ignores the role that Islam has played as a movement that challenges privilege, and works for social justice. Those who toppled the Shah in Iran, and work among the Palestinians and Indonesians, may be militant Muslims to the outside world, but among Arabs they are the voice of the poor.

As for Salman Rushdie's Satanic Verses , which triggered a frenzy of righteousness and a flood of petitions among liberals from Hampstead to Hull: is a society that allows blasphemy against a god worshipped by a minority really so much better than one that censors a writer read by the intelligentsia? The liberal establishment sits on its laurels: their best friend is black, their next-door neighbour Indian, and their children don't even know what a golliwog was. Why bother to challenge those teeny prejudices one still has about Muslims?

 Cristina Odone is deputy editor of the New Statesman

webTitle: Rugby league: Scots win final

fields.headline: Scots win final
fields.trailText: Murrayfield, rather than Cardiff, will stage next April's Challenge Cup final because of the problems with the pitch at the Millennium Stadium.
fields.body:
Murrayfield, rather than Cardiff, will stage next April's Challenge Cup final because of the problems with the pitch at the Millennium Stadium.

After taking the 2000 final to Edinburgh and last week's to Twickenham, the Rugby Football League were planning to move on to Wales in 2002, and Cardiff City Council took out on advert in last Saturday's final programme 'looking forward to welcoming rugby league supporters next year'.

But Dave Callaghan, the RFL's Executive Director of Communications, said yesterday: 'We are delighted to be going back to Murrayfield.

'We had reached an advanced stage of negotiations with the Millennium Stadium in Cardiff but were unable to complete an agreement because of the Football Association's restrictions on pitch use 10 days prior to the playing of the FA Cup final. There was a real danger that our final would have fallen within that period and we could not take any risks.'

The League are now expected to go to Cardiff in 2003 and possibly 2004 with the prospects of a new national stadium at Wembley or elsewhere being ready by then looking increasingly remote.

They are also considering the venues for three Tests against Australia this autumn, although Murrayfield would now appear to be out of the running.

The decision to return to Edinburgh will be a popular one with those supporters who travelled north for last year's final between Bradford and Leeds. The early signs were not good as the game looked set to be postponed following torrential rain and flooding, but the RFL developed a good working relationship with the Scottish Rugby Union during the efforts to get the game on, and although the game was far from a classic, a good time was had by pretty much all.

Greg McCallum, the RFL's director of rugby and president of Scotland Rugby League, added: 'Going back to Murrayfield is a real lift for the sport. Our fans really enjoyed themselves when we played the 2000 final there and we've had requests to take the game back there from many different quarters.'

Meanwhile St Helens, the winners at Twickenham last Saturday, are under pressure to get their Super League season back on track following Friday night's club record 74-16 drubbing at Leeds.

Saints have arranged home games against Castleford on Wednesday and Halifax only two nights later. It is a tough schedule, especially as they now need to win both with Friday's defeat leaving them in mid-table with only nine points from eight games.

And they will have to do so without their inspirational stand-off Tommy Martyn, who has been carrying a groin injury for weeks but will now have surgery that will keep him out for at least a month.

Paul Newlove and Paul Wellens also missed the Leeds game and are unlikely to be back to face Castleford.

Leeds will go into next Friday night's televised derby against Bradford in much better spirits after a fourth consecutive victory under their new coach, Daryl Powell.

In the pick of today's games, the London Broncos take a four-match unbeaten run to Hull, who are aiming to consolidate their place in the top three.

fields.trailText: THERE WAS NOT much between Bradford and St Helens at Twickenham last Saturday, but they have been a world apart in the way they have responded to their contrasting experiences in the Challenge Cup final.
fields.body:
THERE WAS NOT much between Bradford and St Helens at Twickenham last Saturday, but they have been a world apart in the way they have responded to their contrasting experiences in the Challenge Cup final.

The Saints players were given three days off to celebrate their win, and on the evidence of their 70-point thrashing at Leeds on Friday night, they celebrated hard.

Bradford, in contrast, were straight back in action to put 50 points on Warrington on Wednesday, and last night they showed great resilience to hold off a thrilling Castleford fightback and move two points clear at the top of the Super League table.

Three times in the second half the Bulls appeared to have made the game safe, at 14-2, 22-8 and 24-16. But with Danny Orr outstanding, the Tigers would not let them relax and in the end only a desperate cover tackle by Tevita Vaikona on Darren Rogers two minutes from time denied them a famous victory.

Bradford were missing three more members of their Twickenham team - Scott Naylor, Daniel Gartner and Paul Deacon - as a result of their midweek exertions. However the signing of Graham Mackay, a veteran Australian who has spent the winter playing rugby union for Leeds, has helped them paper over the cracks.

Mackay had scored one try and made another in a brief substitute appearance against the Wolves, and here it was his lovely flicked pass in a tackle which allowed Henry Paul to open the scoring for Bradford with a 12th-minute try.

The stand-off could not convert, ending his record-breaking run of 35 consecutive successful kicks. But he was soon embarking on another with two penalties to give the Bulls an 8-0 lead. The second followed a dazzling Bradford move as they spun the ball across their own posts, and that came in response to some slick Castleford handling in a 60-metre foray.

But the Tigers, who were again missing their major Australian signing Mitch Healey because of his dodgy hamstring and lost Aaron Raper with a shoulder injury early on when he went low on Bradford's 19st prop Paul Anderson - big mistake - could not get on board until first-half injury time, when Anderson felled Orr as he chased his own kick. Castleford's young stand-off dusted himself down to kick the goal, and reduce the arrears to 8-2.

Within four minutes of the restart, strong running by Mackay and his fellow centre Lee Gilmour set up the position for Robbie Paul to expose some slack defence close to their own line, and Henry Paul's conversion took them 14-2 ahead.

Cas responded well, with Mark Lennon sending Orr sliding beside the padded post. But they conceded possession, then a penalty, straight from the kick-off, allowing Henry Paul to kick two more points for the Bulls.

James Lowes then broke the Paul family's monopoly on Bradford points by battling over from acting-half.

Even when Cas came again with a well-worked try for Jon Wells and two beautifully-struck Orr goals to cut the gap to 22-16, Henry Paul's sixth goal re-established an eight-point cushion. But a terrific break by Jason Flowers sent Richard Gay sprinting over for Castleford's third try, and in the end only Vaikona's tackle got Bradford home.

Castleford Tigers: Gay; Wells, Mather, Eagar, Rogers; Orr, Lennon; Sykes, Raper, Handford, Shaw, Fritz, Harland. Substitutes used: Sampson, Flowers, Tonks, Smith.

Bradford Bulls: Withers; Vaikona, Mackay, Gilmour, Pryce; H Paul, R Paul; Vagana, Lowes, McDermott, Radford, Peacock, Forshaw. Substitutes used: Anderson, Fielden, Parker, Sykes.

Referee: S Cummings (Widnes).
