webTitle: Rugby review: Michael Aylwin

fields.headline: White is the colour
fields.trailText: Swansea probably opened the champagne at St Helens straight after their comfortable eight-try victory over visitors Glasgow Caledonians yesterday.
fields.body:
Swansea probably opened the champagne at St Helens straight after their comfortable eight-try victory over visitors Glasgow Caledonians yesterday. But it might not have been until shortly after 7pm that they started happily necking it.

The All Whites virtually assured themselves of the Welsh-Scottish League title in the afternoon with their 54-10 victory over Glasgow. In order to be denied, they would have had to lose their last game against Bridgend next week, and second-placed Cardiff would have had not only to win their last two games but also to score something in the region of 30 tries in the process.

Unlikely, of course, but Cardiff obligingly lost the first of those two games last night, thus allowing their rivals to the west a full-on piss-up as champions outright.

Fililo Martens was Swansea's driving force at scrum-half, dealing out some hefty tackles and scoring a fine try. Geraint Lewis contributed a brace of scores and Colin Charvis, Steve Winn, Matthew Robinson, Shaun Payne and David Weatherley completed the rout.

Swansea eyes next turned to nearby Stradey Park, where Llanelli hosted the unlikely challenge of Cardiff. The visitors scored the opening try as if to make a fight of it, but by the end the futility of their task was reflected in the tailing off of their efforts and Llanelli triumphed 34-25 to end the matter.

The biggest rugby crowd of the weekend, meanwhile, was to be found at Twickenham, where 33,700 service men and women turned out to see the Navy beat the Army in their annual tussle at HQ.

Bristol winger Spencer Brown crowned his man-of-the-match performance with a try at the death to seal the Navy's 31-20 win. It hadn't all gone the Navy's way, with Howard Graham scoring a try for the Army in the first minute. But the Navy found their legs quickly to rattle up a 23-7 lead before the first half was out. The Army did recover to score before half-time, before penalties were indecisively exchanged in the second half and Brown stepped up to settle the matter.

fields.headline: Lethal Tiger cubs
fields.standfirst: Leicester  Tries: Howard, Booth.  Cons: Stimpson (2).  Pen:  Stimpson.   c  Try:  Martin.  Con:  Grayson.  Pens: Grayson (2). att: 12,000 :  Leicester: 17; Northampton: 13
fields.trailText: Leicester: 17; Northampton: 13.
fields.body:
Faced with the Heineken Cup final in two weeks and having won the Zurich Premiership, Leicester put out virtually a second team for the penultimate round of the most superfluous of the prizes open to them this season, the Zurich Championship. But still they couldn't lose. Labour were still fresh-faced in office the last time an English club won here at Welford Road.

So, now they have to go to another final, six days before the big one in Paris. Oh, well. It's the way it goes here at the Manchester United of rugby.

The few selected members of the Leicester first team seized the moment to expand their repertoire. Graham Rowntree emerged from his front-row sweatshop to become an open-air impact runner. Neil Back became the enforcer, engaging on one occasion in a flail on the floor with fellow Lion-elect Matt Dawson.

And Pat Howard expanded from instigator of all good moves to their finisher. He took an inside pass in midfield and made a mockery of Northampton's set piece defence to run through for the opening try.

This was embarrassing for the Saints. They responded through a couple of experienced players of their own. Paul Grayson, appointed kicking coach for England's tour to North America, kicked a couple of penalties, and tried to place a couple of diagonal punts into the arms of his left wing Ben Cohen. The Saints' Lion-elect did not seem in the mood to give full chase.

Allan Bateman, at the ripe old age of 36, looked the most likely to unpick Leicester's defence. He went gliding on the outside but then spoilt the effect by slinging out a couple of ugly passes. It grew worse for the venerable Welshman when he was unceremoniously bounced off in the tackle by Tim Stimpson.

The Tigers full-back fed diminutive winger Steve Booth, who cut inside Nick Beal and then took on Cohen in a dash for the corner. Booth won. This was going from bad to worse for the visitors.

Suddenly things improved in the second half. In what proved to be his farewell game, Tim Rodber stood in midfield and linked with John Leslie. The centre made ground against an outnumbered defence before releasing Italian Luca Martin for the run-in. It was about Martin's only hot spot of the day.

Another player was about to say farewell. Bateman took the ball into a tackle under the nose of Ed Morrison who instantly knew all was not well. On came the physios and off went Bateman to a reception rarely afforded by the home crowd to visitors. Bateman will finish his days back at Neath.

Grayson had converted the try to narrow the gap to a single point. But this was to be his last pot at goal. For the remaining 35 minutes Leicester generally had full control. Stimpson kicked a penalty to extend the lead to four points and just missed with two more attempts from within his own half.

He might have had a couple more conversions to attempt had his side been able to finish off two moves. webTitle: Rugby Union: Wasps full-back will be key figure today

fields.headline: Power of Sampson
fields.standfirst: Wasps full-back will be key figure today
fields.trailText: Eddie Butler says Wasps full-back will be key figure today.
fields.body:
It could be worse; the French haven't even reached the knockout stages of their club championship yet. On and on they'll go through May and into June, until the cheers of the French Open at Roland Garros announce that it really is time to bring the rugby season to a close.

At least over here, we're on the home straight to the summer lay-off. All that remains on the Countdown Calendar to One Bloody Weekend without Rugby are a Zurich Championship semi-final today, the final next Sunday and then the finals of the Heineken Cup and European Shield the weekend after that. Two more weeks of running around and then a full 10 days of nothing - unless you happen to be in a training camp before going on tour.

Since that includes every single professional player across continental Europe, bar a Latvian reserve hooker at Cote-de-Sauterne, who can't locate the document to prove that his grandmother came from Blaensychan, I think it is fair to say that we shall have to wait until Martin Johnson and his Lions come home from Australia in mid-July before entering what used to be called the close season.

But what a break awaits us then. What a stretch. Nearly a whole month off before the Middlesex Sevens kicks off another season in mid-August. Rugby can perform invasive surgery on torn medial ligaments and have a player up and running within 25 minutes; Twickenham can precision-bomb with depleted uranium proxy-forms its reactionary elements at Special General Meetings, technology can link referees and touch-judges to the Hubble space telescope, but can anyone hold to the tenet that less is more?

No. We play too much rugby. How many times must we be reminded of the 25 matches a top Australian plays compared with the 40-plus in England. And never mind the players; what about the saturated crowds? By now everyone must be out on their feet.

'No, we're really up for it,' said Jon Callard, coach of Bath who take on Wasps today in that Zurich Championship semi. 'Players and supporters. We had 7,000 at the quarter-final against Newcastle. A day out at a Twickenham final would be fantastic for the whole club.'

But can you even put half a side together?

'Well, apart from Mike Tindall and Nathan Thomas the current squad is injury-free. That's not bad, especially since mid-November we've been playing with only three props: John Mallett, Simon Emms and David Barnes. They're a bit knackered, but they're going for it as well.'

Damn. Well, what about Wasps, then? Their team include Lions Rob Henderson, Phil Greening and Lawrence Dallaglio. They're obviously all committed to all this, as well. No thoughts of a whiff here. The entire team has run into form. And free-running form at that, sweetly controlled by Alex King at outside-half. Paul Sampson at full-back has been one of the revelations of the season, a counterattacker who might make Iain Balshaw look ponderous.

Blast. Wasps are in such good nick that they are considered favourites in many quarters to be the inaugural winners of the Zurich Championship. That would do the financial fortunes of a club up for sale no harm at all. The cocktail of backroom money worries with extravagance on the field is a giddy brew, especially at a London club who have a long history of winning titles under Rob Smith, now their academy director, on pure bloody-mindedness.

And it's not as if Bath are going to try to slow the game down. Their own rich history is built on single-mindedness. And, not having won anything since the European Cup three years ago - thanks to Jon Callard, then at full-back - they've made it their mission to put that right at the end of this long season. It promises to be a bit of a thriller. Mike Catt and Balshaw against Henderson and Sampson on the clipped grass of Loftus Road. Almost unmissable, really. Hell's teeth.

webTitle: Motor racing: chips are down

fields.headline: Chips are down as computers battle for championship
fields.standfirst: The effect of F1's revised rules
fields.trailText: The 2001 world Championship will be won - or, more likely, lost - by a computer.
fields.body:
The 2001 world Championship will be won - or, more likely, lost - by a computer. The message from last Sunday's Spanish Grand Prix, the first to be run under revised rules, is that the new technology will prove more of a hindrance than a help in the short term.

The complexities of traction control, launch control and fully automatic gearboxes are such that softwear specialists sitting behind desks, rather than sportsmen sitting behind the wheel, will decide the title. The message seems to be: look after the megabytes in the hard disks and the performers in the hardhats will take care of themselves.

On the evidence of a catalogue of disasters in Barcelona, the end result might be determined by mechanical failures initiated by systems which ought to be improving performance rather than wrecking it. The fifth round of the championship turned out to be a race for the lame, Michael Schumacher taking victory on the final lap as he nursed his Ferrari past the smoking remains of Mika Hakkinen's McLaren-Mercedes.

Neither team can confirm or deny that their various woes were associated with the hazards of venturing 200 racing miles into unfamiliar technical territory. Schumacher was forced to slow by a vibration which came from a tyre turning on its rim. This sort of thing has happened before although, significantly perhaps, not on the first two sets of tyres used by Schumacher as he led the race before his second and final pit stop.

Ferrari has sent wheels and tyres back to Bridgestone for analysis in Japan. It remains to be seen if the effects of improved traction out of the corners contributed to the rubber shifting slightly on the rim and putting the wheel out of balance.

Schumacher was lucky to have almost a minute in hand over Juan Pablo Montoya's Williams-BMW, but nothing would match the good fortune associated with finding the parked McLaren less than a mile from home. It is difficult to say whether or not Schumacher would have beaten Hakkinen had the vibration problem not intervened - Ferrari technical director Ross Brawn says it was too close to call - but McLaren appeared to have marginally the better pitstop strategy, one which allowed Hakkinen to take the lead at a crucial moment. All of which, of course, made his late retirement even more difficult to bear.

The engine manufacturers had warned that the effects of eliminating wheelspin through traction control could have a dire effect on the rest of the car. With 800 bhp looking for continual release, the consequences of abruptly cutting that power, even for a nanosecond, could send vibrations through the transmission, all the way back to the gearbox - and ultimately to the list of retirements.

Another branch of electronic wizardry almost denied David Coulthard from putting that to the test when the launch control refused to operate properly as he prepared to commence the final parade lap before the start.

Despite the rather gauche suggestion by McLaren boss Ron Dennis that the Scotsman had failed to engage his brain, the more tactful answer seems to be that there was fault on both sides but that, ultimately, the system should have coped with a misunderstanding which saw the driver fail to apply the required amount of revs.

The irony is that, a first corner collision notwithstanding, Coulthard's car performed faultlessly thereafter and he picked up an extra championship point thanks to his team-mate's heartbreaking demise. On the other hand, had Schumacher not received the last-lap bonus and remained in second place, his lead over Coulthard would be five points instead of eight as they go to Austria for the sixth round next weekend.

Peering through the smokescreen created - literally, in Hakkinen's case - by these supposed advances in motor racing science, it was easy to see that the old firm of McLaren and Ferrari had remained at the front. The one disappointment was a failure by Williams-BMW to follow on from their win two weeks before in Italy. Dr Mario Theissen, BMW's motorsport director, explained that each race is a separate entity; while they got their sums absolutely right in Imola, the mathematics might not add up elsewhere.

Even so, a significant signal from Barcelona was that Michelin, the Williams tyre supplier, are some way behind Bridgestone (who support Ferrari and McLaren) despite the Spanish circuit being the first venue used this year on which the French tyre company has extensive testing knowledge.

It's true that the unseasonably low temperatures did not help Michelin. In which case, old-fashioned weather in the Austrian mountains may hinder their runners next weekend. Provided modern technology doesn't have its say first, of course.

2 D Coulthard (McLaren) 28

3 R Barrichello (Ferrari) 14

4 R Schumacher (Williams) 10

5 N Heidfeld (Sauber) 8

6 J Trulli (Jordan) 7

7= JP Montoya (Williams) 6

H-H Frentzen (Jordan) 6

9= J Villeneuve (BAR) 4

M Hakkinen (McLaren) 4

11 O Panis (BAR) 3

12= K Raikkonen (Sauber) 1

webTitle: Snooker: world championship

fields.headline: Ronnie rockets into final
fields.trailText: It has taken longer than expected but, at the age of 25, Ronnie O'Sullivan will make his debut in the final of the Embassy world championship today after beating Joe Swail 17-11 in the semi-finals. Not bad for someone who has repeatedly questioned his commitment to snooker in recent years and has often talked of retirement.
fields.body:
It has taken longer than expected but, at the age of 25, Ronnie O'Sullivan will make his debut in the final of the Embassy world championship today after beating Joe Swail 17-11 in the semi-finals. Not bad for someone who has repeatedly questioned his commitment to snooker in recent years and has often talked of retirement.

When O'Sullivan captured the UK championship title in 1993 he was still a week short of his eighteenth birthday. It was generally assumed that sooner rather than later he would add the game's ultimate prize but encroaching bouts of depression and the frustration of not being able to share moments of glory with his father, Ronnie senior, who is serving a life sentence for murder, took their toll.

'I'm surprised I haven't been in the final before,' said O'Sullivan. 'When I was younger I thought I'd have won it once or twice by now. That's not being big-headed, I'm just being honest, because I know how good I was, and I know how good I can be. But things happen.'

Although by no means on an emotional even keel this season he has finally discovered a way to convert abundant natural talent into the silverware it merits. He has won the Champions Cup, Regal Scottish Masters, China Open and Irish Masters and, by reaching the final here, is sure to exceed £500,000 in total prize money.

Yet, O'Sullivan will still view the championship as a failure if he does not overcome Matthew Stevens or John Higgins over the best of 35 frames for £250,000. 'Second place is no consolation. It must be the worst thing in the world to watch someone else pick up the trophy right next to you,' he said.

O'Sullivan's skill, finesse and potting capabilities have never been in doubt but the same cannot be said for his mental stamina. It is therefore a huge advantage that he enters the most high-profile contest on the snooker calendar relatively fresh after four comfortable victories in which no one has placed him under sustained pressure.

'A smooth run is obviously a big help,' said O'Sullivan, who always managed to keep Swail at arm's length and was engaged for only an hour yesterday in turning a commanding 15-9 overnight lead into another untroubled win. 'If you make light work of your matches here it can only be to your benefit.'

From past experience, Dennis Taylor empathises with Stevens, who is harnessing personal grief as a motivational force. Morrell, his father, travelling companion and, naturally, fiercest supporter, died suddenly in February at the age of 48 and the success of Stevens junior has evoked emotional memories for Taylor, who found himself in a similar position 17 years ago.

Taylor's mother died in September 1984. Deeply upset, he considered pulling out of the Grand Prix a month later but, on the urging of his family, eventually decided to play. The tournament yielded his first title in 13 years as a professional and, feeding off that boost of self-confidence, he famously edged black to become world champion the following year.

'I know how he's feeling,' Taylor told me. 'Every time he goes back to his seat something extra than normal will be pushing him on. I remember what I was like. There was a certain calm, a determination about me and, from what I've seen of him, Matthew's got that too.' Going into their concluding session last night, Stevens led John Higgins 13-11 and was only four frames short of returning to the final.

Last year with Morrell, a fun-loving accountant who did not fit the Monty Python stereotype of that profession, nervously willing him on backstage, Stevens lost 18-16 to Mark Williams from 13-7 up. The current season, even before his bereavement, has been unproductive for Stevens, who on arrival in Sheffield had not progressed farther than a quarter-final in anything and had succumbed to defeat in seven deciding frame finishes.

Fluency, confidence and competitive steel have all returned, though, over the past fortnight. Stevens led 10- 8, Higgins assisted by a 121 break, rallied to 10-10 but Stevens, without being responsible for a run over 39, managed to claim three of the next four to secure a two frame cushion. Having looked in peak form, Higgins was suddenly faced with the prospect of a third Crucible semi-final defeat in as many years.

While Stevens battled away with Higgins, draining each other's mental reserves, Stephen Hendry, the undisputed king of the Crucible throughout the 1990s, was back home no doubt wondering whether he will ever grace the closing weekend of the championship again. The 2000-01 season is the first since 1988-89 that Hendry has not prevailed in at least one world ranking event.

Having looked in peak form, Higgins was suddenly faced with the prospect of a third Crucible semi-final defeat in as many years. While Stevens battled away with Higgins, draining each other's mental reserves, Stephen Hendry, the undisputed king of the Crucible throughout the 1990s, was back home no doubt wondering whether he will ever grace the closing weekend of the championship again. The 2000-01 season is the first since 1988-89 that Hendry has not prevailed in at least one world ranking event.

webTitle: Racing: Side with Sayedah

fields.headline: Side with Sayedah
fields.trailText: Eddie the Shoe's insider's guide to the racing form.
fields.body:
The Sagitta 1,000 Guineas (3.45) is a hard race for form pundits as there is virtually no recent racecourse evidence to go on. Muwakleh's two wins on the dirt in Dubai, including the UAE Guineas by five and a half lengths, mark her down as smart but will she act so well on the turf?

Kieren Fallon has picked Karasta over Enthused from Michael Stoute's pair and both have strong claims, though there is a worry that the ground will not be fast enough for Enthused.

When Karasta won the May Hill Stakes at Doncaster in September, she beat Ameerat a length. The second, who has been pleasing Michael Jarvis in her preparation for today's race, met trouble in running yet is available at around four times the price of Karasta.

It is Ameerat's form that leads me to go for SAYEDAH as the value bet in the race at around 25-1. After all, Sayedah had Ameerat, again unlucky in running, back in sixth when winning the Group Two Rockfel Stakes over seven furlongs here in October and she fulfils one of the key criteria for winning this race in recent years.

All recent winners had achieved an official rating of at least 107 and on 109 Sayedah is joined by only Crystal Music (116), Enthused (116) and Autumnal (110) in today's line-up.

There are doubts about the stamina of Irish challenger, Toroca, and Stunning, from Criquette Head-Maarek's powerful French stable, should prove more dangerous. Head-Maarek has won this race three times before and expects Stunning to improve on this straight course.

Caughnawaga put up a tremendous performance at the first Newmarket meeting of the season when third behind Proceed With Care and is napped for the May Classified Stakes on his return to the Rowley Mile course at 4.20.

It was not that CAUGHNAWAGA put in a stunning form effort but that he was the most burly runner I have ever seen from Henry Cecil's yard. He should have come on a bundle for that outing, on which form he holds Jentzen.

Inchcape won a maiden over six furlongs on the same Newmarket card and should have no trouble with this extra furlong but the runner-up Indian Prince has since been well beaten at Warwick.

Putra Pekan was another to catch the eye at the Craven meeting, coming from nearly last to fifth in the handicap won by Injaaz. His only win as a two-year-old came in first-time blinkers at Chester and his style of running suggests he would benefit from the reapplication of headgear.

The 30-runner Mail On Sunday Mile Qualifier (2.30) will be filed in the too-difficult category by most. I was taken by the way MAMORE GAP ran here on his reappearance when seventh to Injaaz. He should be suited by the additional furlong and has a capable claimer taking five pounds off.

Celtic Mission looked ultra-tough when winning at Windsor and must go on the shortlist. He just about holds Pasithea on earlier Ripon form. A more speculative chance is that of Amigo, sixth behind Fully Invested and Modrik in a Lingfield maiden, who meets the runner-up, topweight here, on 22lb better terms.

Fully Invested lines up for the R L Davison Pretty Polly Stakes (3.05) along with another Oaks fancy, Head In The Clouds. These two should make the market and mean that THE BYSTANDER goes off at a decent each-way price.

webTitle: Racing: Golan hits the heights

fields.headline: Golan hits the heights
fields.trailText: An aspect of Golan's character that surely bodes well is his attitude. 'Sometimes this horse is so laid back that he has given us a scare once or twice, but going into the race I was very happy with him. He has a marvellous temperament,' his trainer says.
fields.body:
When Sir Michael Stoute says 'this colt is a very exciting prospect', immediately after it has won a Classic race, hairs rise on the neck. A cold, wet spring on Newmarket Heath has left the younger horses backward, and in the few weeks running up to the Derby some are sure to improve dramatically. Among them will be Golan, winner of the 2,000 Guineas, and now a hot favourite for the Classic at Epsom next month.

Like King's Best a year ago, Golan is trained by Stoute and ridden by Kieren Fallon. Then the jockey had come from last to first, and Golan achieved a similar victory. Drawn widest of the 18 runners, he was driven to move into the lead with less than two furlongs to run and stayed on well to resist Tamburlaine's persistent challenge.

'You won't often see a horse win a Classic like that, coming from last to first to win the way he did,' was the jockey's post-race observation. 'You might be able to do it in a handicap, but to do it in a Classic is remarkable.' Reading into the reactions of two such conservative opinions, Golan could be something special. This was Stoute's fifth 2,000 Guineas success and his enthusiasm for the winner was unconcealed.

The trainer's luck has been wretched in the first weeks of the season, but in his own words he has been careful with his horses. Golan is sure to improve for the race, only the second of his career. In his first at Chepstow last autumn he beat Clearing, who has a good chance in the French 2,000 Guineas on Sunday.

Fallon, too, has made a tardy start, taking time to reach full strength after his left shoulder was wrenched apart in a fall at Royal Ascot. He asserted recently that he would retain his jockeys' championship, barring injury. It was a bold statement, but his faith has never wavered and this victory was surely a vindication of his confidence.

Not surprisingly, Golan heads the market for the Derby, a best-priced 5-2 with Ladbrokes, Victor Chandler and Paddy Power. Galileo is second favourite, generally at 7-1, and looking through the remaining aspirants, Stoute trains two of the most promising, Dilshaan, who outstayed Tamburlaine in the Racing Post Trophy, and Dawari, whose merit will be tested in the Chester Vase on Tuesday.

Those apart, John Dunlop's Olden Times, a winner here at the Craven meeting, had the form of his victory franked by the success of Terrestrial in the first race yesterday, and Hemingway's success at York last year stays in the mind. They still have something to prove; Golan's performance in the 2,000 Guineas was an outstanding trial for the Derby, and odds of 5-2 might seem generous on 9 June.

Many winners of the Newmarket Classic have failed at Epsom; either the undulating course or the greater test of stamina exposes their inadequacies. Golan should handle the track, and there is every chance he will get a mile and a half. He is by Spectrum, who won the Champion Stakes over a mile and a quarter, out of a Generous mare. He promises to stay.

Stoute paid a compliment to Roy Carter, who has ridden Golan during the winter, and to Fallon, who has been on board for the colt's recent fast work. They have educated Golan to overcome his relative lack of experience and further progress seems inevitable.

Another aspect of Golan's character that surely bodes well is his attitude. 'Sometimes this horse is so laid back that he has given us a scare once or twice, but going into the race I was very happy with him. He has a marvellous temperament,' the trainer said.

The Ruinart Champagne Conditions Stakes gave no clue to Epsom. Terrestrial beat Prize Winner, the pair finishing clear, but neither holds an entry for the Derby. John Gosden's progressive winner could be supplemented for £75,000, but the Prix du Jockey Club is the preferred option.

'The French Derby has been the plan for some time,' he said. 'He is a good worker at home and I think we can do enough with him there. Manton has a big, right-handed bend and that will be helpful with Chantilly in mind.'

The ground might be too fast for Gosden's Crystal Music in the 1,000 Guineas today. Stoute and Fallon will be responsible for the favourite, Karasta, but the Aga Khan's filly was slightly disappointing when beaten at Longchamp on Arc day, and her odds are no longer attractive.

Godolphin's Muwakleh has been impressive in two races on the sand at Nad Al Sheba, but how she will cope with the Rowley Mile can be only a guess and Toroca will be better value. Runner-up to Regal Rose in the Cheveley Park Stakes, Aidan O'Brien's filly won comfortably on her reappearance, and has an each-way chance in an open race.

webTitle: Tattenham Corner

fields.headline: Tattenham Corner
fields.standfirst: The Observer 's weekly take on the racing scene
fields.trailText: The Observer 's weekly take on the racing scene.
fields.body:
Packing up the Showcase

British horseracing board director Paul Greeves denied last December that the Showcase race initiative, aimed at beefing up the midweek racing programme, was as good as finished.

On hearing the news that the Tote were to stop topping up the prize money for the Showcase races each day, Greeves claimed the scheme, primarily a way of getting morning betting on one event a day, was alive and kicking, while adding that 'it has suffered a little bout of ill-health'. But now comes further evidence that what we are witnessing is more like a slow, painful death. In the last fortnight there have been two days when, for the first time we can remember, no Showcase races were even scheduled. This week the Showcase tipping competition for the press was postponed until further notice.

Newbury up for the Cup

The disclosure of Newbury's plans for a £2.5m all-weather course means the proposed London track at Fairlop Waters and now the Berkshire track both clearly harbour plans to stage Europe's answer to the Breeders' Cup.

Poor excuses for losers

Racing's governing bodies in other parts of the globe don't believe punters, who fund the sport to a great extent, should put up with nonsense we have seen in this part of the world of late. Our enquiries of the racing authorities in South Africa this week have confirmed that they would have had called in the connections of Arc runner-up Egyptband, who finished second in the prestigious Prix Ganay at Longchamp last Sunday after his trainer's assistant had said before the event that the jockey 'would not give her a hard race'.

There is no doubt they would have meted out a more severe ban to jockey Lee Newman than the 14 days he got from the stewards at Bath on Tuesday following his defeat on the gambled-on Lady Two K in a race the young jockey (below) would certainly have won if he had not taken it easy in the closing stages.

The riding of Lady Two K predictably attracted plenty of publicity in the racing pages in the papers and this will no doubt affect her odds in a handicap in the near future, but the mare has improved since being stepped up in distance and she should win more races this season.

Why Chester's such a big draw

Chester takes centre stage this week and when the spotlight falls on Britain's tightest racecourse the talk on the TV (all three days are covered on Channel 4) and in the betting shops often revolves around the draw, particularly in the races over shorter trips.

But the popular racetrack is not the only British course where a horse's stalls number is vital and the draw is such an important factor that punters armed with the details of where the bias lies can definitely gain an edge.

Graham Wheldon, perhaps the leading exponent of draw analysis in this country, opened his ground-breaking tome The Effects Of The Draw two years ago with the words: 'On many British racecourses, the draw has more influence on the outcome of the races than any other single factor'.

Both that book and his updated volume, Backing The Draw For Profit, have sold out but Wheldon started a new column called Sprintline in the Racing & Football Outlook this week which seems sure to prove required reading for those seeking to profit from his knowledge.

Another book worth seeking out is Bias 2001 by David Renham which not only gives a detailed draw bias course-by-course analysis but includes perhaps the punter's Holy Grail, a winning system that Renham devised around draw bias which has recorded five winning years in a row.

You can get hold of a copy for £10 from David Renham at The Hunters, Middle Rd, Tiptoe, Hampshire S041 6EJ, on 0794-1326178 or by email at cazdeacon@aol.com.

Bull's eye for detail

In 1964 the Observer racing correspondent, the late Richard Baerlein, wrote a profile of the legendary Phil Bull (right), the man who created Timeform and who was one of the most influential figures in the sport. Or at least the readers were led to believe Baerlein penned the piece.

In fact, the late Bull, as revealed in the biography of him by Howard Wright, had come up with the questions and answered them himself. He submitted a feature which Baerlein used virtually word for word. Bull's letters to the racing press were to be used in full or not at all.

Timeform, his legacy, bear the hallmarks of his philosophy and state in the introduction to their weekly Black Book: 'In our thinking and in the setting out of our views we have aimed at precision.' So it was no doubt with some trepidation that the present incumbents watched Arkatme run at Southwell last Monday after they had said the horse 'should be written off,' missing out the vital word 'not' in the latest Black Book. Arkatme finished second.

The name game

What's in a name? Sunday racing resumes today and the bid to attract young racegoers began early yesterday at Exeter which featured the 'Clip Clops Under Fives Play Area Handicap Hurdle.' What price Bob The Builder and the Tweenies showing up soon?

webTitle: Off Screen: A round-up of sport on TV

fields.headline: Making a monkey of middle man
fields.trailText: A round-up of sport on TV.
fields.body:
Umpiring used to be a relatively untaxing way for first-class cricketers to fill in the time between the end of their playing careers and retirement. Now, being one of the men in white coats makes you a prime candidate for, well, the men in white coats. Much of this has to do with television's introduction of technology that subjects umpiring decisions to minute analysis.

This season both Channel 4, with their Hawk-Eye system, which they unveiled for the press last Friday, and Sky, with Sky Scope, are introducing technology that will put decisions under even greater scrutiny. Both systems use the latest missile-tracking technology - who said wars were being fought without regard for the enhancement of mankind? - to measure the ball's exact flight path.

'Lbw decisions are always controversial, but we can now use this system to show whether the ball would have hit the stumps,' says Barney Francis, of Sky Sports. Hawk-Eye's inventor, Dr Paul Hawkins, says Channel 4 will only show those dismissals when his system can predict with 100 per cent certainty that the batsman would have been lbw. Which is nice for those spectators who like seeing figures of authority, including the humble cricket umpire, proved conclusively wrong - ie, 99.9 per cent of us - but not particularly good for maintaining good relations in the middle.

Clearly, cricket's ruling body, the International Cricket Council, have to do something to protect umpires now that the last shred of uncertainty over decision-making may be removed. In fact the ICC have been stirred into action - that is, they are doing what governing bodies tend to do in these situations, hold a series of discussions. The first of these will take place later this month during the meeting of the ICC's Cricket Committee-Playing, which is not a title that fills you with the greatest confidence that anything progressive will get done. More reassuringly, the committee is not manned by incontinent colonels who once played a couple of games for Rutland 2nd XI, but with respected former players such as Sunil Gavaskar and Allan Border. Don't expect quick decisions, though. 'The debate on technology will be wide ranging,' says Clive Hitchcock, the ICC's cricket operations manager, 'and will reach a judgment on whether there should be more, less or the same amount of technological assistance available to umpires.' Phew, slow down lads.

Simon Hughes, the Channel 4 analyst, has teasingly suggested that the new technology could do away with umpires altogether. 'Is the game there for umpires?' he asks. He reckons players and spectators are the only ones who really matter, which is a fair point. Obviously, though, some sort of presence is required, but the answer may be for the umpires in the middle to concern themselves simply with making sure that the game runs smoothly. They would censor players for gratuitous appealing and stop bowlers running on the pitch, that sort of thing, while offering what additional information they could to the third umpire in the stands whenever there was a genuine appeal. The third umpire, equipped with the latest television technology, would then be responsible for making the final decision on all dismissals.

The venerable game of cricket has, to its credit, been more receptive than most sports to technological developments and there is no reason why it should start getting nervous about them now.

 Viewers will be treated to new aerial shots of the Wimbledon tennis championships this year - assuming the local council allow the BBC to rig up a mobile overhead camera. The idea is that the so-called wirecam will be mounted on a line running above the grounds for a distance of about a quarter of a mile, giving it views of all the courts. One has been used at the French Open for the past couple of years.

The BBC are also introducing a railcam, this time the mobile camera being mounted on a rail running across the back of the Centre Court. Interesting new angles of Patrick Rafter for the girls and Anna what's-her-name for the boys.

Phew, slow down lads. Simon Hughes, the Channel 4 analyst, has teasingly suggested that the new technology could do away with umpires altogether. 'Is the game there for umpires?' he asks. He reckons players and spectators are the only ones who really matter, which is a fair point. Obviously, though, some sort of presence is required, but the answer may be for the umpires in the middle to concern themselves simply with making sure that the game runs smoothly. They would censor players for gratuitous appealing and stop bowlers running on the pitch, that sort of thing, while offering what additional information they could to the third umpire in the stands whenever there was a genuine appeal. The third umpire, equipped with the latest television technology, would then be responsible for making the final decision on all dismissals. The venerable game of cricket has, to its credit, been more receptive than most sports to technological developments and there is no reason why it should start getting nervous about them now.  Viewers will be treated to new aerial shots of the Wimbledon tennis championships this year - assuming the local council allow the BBC to rig up a mobile overhead camera. The idea is that the so-called wirecam will be mounted on a line running above the grounds for a distance of about a quarter of a mile, giving it views of all the courts. One has been used at the French Open for the past couple of years. The BBC are also introducing a railcam, this time the mobile camera being mounted on a rail running across the back of the Centre Court. Interesting new angles of Patrick Rafter for the girls and Anna what's-her-name for the boys. jon.henderson@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Top lawyer to probe Windies 'fixes'

fields.headline: Top lawyer to probe Windies 'fixes'
fields.trailText: A leading lawyer has been appointed by the West Indies Cricket Board to investigate any allegation of match-fixing by their players.
fields.body:
A leading lawyer has been appointed by the West Indies Cricket Board to investigate any allegation of match-fixing by their players.

Elliott Mottley QC will work closely with Sir Paul Condon's anti-corruption unit based in London. He is likely to call on ace batsman Brian Lara. The former West Indies captain was accused in the Indian CBI Report of accepting $40,000 from a bookmaker to under-perform in two one-day international matches.

Lara, who denies the allegation, is also to be interviewed by Condon's team. Meanwhile, Condon has completed a report on his first six months as head of the unit, which will be published on 18 June.

He said: 'It sets out all matters of malpractice in cricket which includes what has happened, along with my recommendations to minimise malpractice in future. We are following up a whole series of allegations. Some emerged from the CBI Report, and some for other sources.A huge amount of work is underway. There are not enough hours in the day to cope with it all.'

The West Indies now join the Australian, New Zealand and Sri Lankan Cricket Boards, alongside the ECB, in launching investigations.

Condon added: 'We're supporting each and every one of those investigations. We are also actively involved with the Indian government and the Indian police. There is a major investigation going on. A line has not been drawn under any player named in the Indian CBI Report.' Condon was clearly referring to England's Alec Stewart, along with Mark Waugh (Australia), Martin Crowe (New Zealand), and Arjunda Ranatunga and Arvinda de Silva (Sri Lanka).

Condon's investigators will shortly visit Pakistan to interview 'officials'. Condon's unit, however, would comment on whether that would include Javed Miandad, the former Pakistan coach, who recently claimed that a number of his country's matches in New Zealand were fixed.

webTitle: Cricket: Students resist Wasim and Co

fields.headline: Students resist Wasim and Co
fields.standfirst:
British Universities v Pakistan
Brave students find it hard to cope with Mushtaq's spin - but much-vaunted pacemen fail to deliver
fields.trailText:
British Universities v Pakistan
Brave students find it hard to cope with Mushtaq's spin - but much-vaunted pacemen fail to deliver
fields.body:
This has been a better game of cricket than the lopsided scores suggest. On the first day the students were stage-struck by their lofty opponents as well as being unlucky to encounter a Wasim Akram in the unusual position of having to justify his place in the Test team.

But yesterday they performed like young men rather than boys and justified their presence in this fixture.

As for Pakistan they were their usual quixotic selves. They amassed a first innings lead of 242 - not so difficult when you have bowled your opponents out for 74 - but in the process they contrived to lose five wickets for six runs in the morning session.

In the afternoon their much-vaunted pace attack were unable to sweep through the students as they had done on Friday.

The tourists don't have long to establish their Test side. After this gentle opener they go to contrasting venues: spartan Derby and sylvan Canterbury. Thence to Lord's. Their likeliest line-up for the Test will include five bowlers, three of whom must be considered certainties: Waqar (he's the captain) Abdur Razzaq (because he bats so well) and Saqlain.

In all probability Wasim, will be the fourth, which leaves the final bowling place to be contested by Mohammed Sami, Shoiab Akhtar (still in Lahore but due here today or tomorrow) and Azhar Mahmood, who can bat. Of these only Sami was on view. He was undeniably brisk without living up to his sensational billing.

But if Pakistan do opt for five bowlers in their Test team they will require their lower order batsmen to be more adhesive than they were yesterday.

After a tranquil half hour they evaporated. First, Tim Murtagh found Saleem Elahi's outside edge; then Younis Khan struck an innocuous loosener from Chris Elstub to backward point, which opened up the possibility of an intriguing little duel between Wasim and the left arm spinner, Rob Fer ley. Ferley won it at a canter. Wasim had an enormous swipe at his first ball from the left armer and missed.

Soon after he had another go and sent the ball steepling in the air. It looked as if the former Pakistan captain would escape again until Joe Porter, running back from mid-on, held a brilliantly judged catch. In Ferley's next over Rashid Latif tried an extravagant sweep to a straight ball and was bowled.

Mushtaq Ahmed holed out immediately but Waqar spared his team's blushes with several uninhibited blows, which took him to a rare half-century, while Sami contrived to hit two sixes in his innings of 15.

However, these Pakistan pacemen were unable to dominate so easily with the ball in their hand. First, they were thwarted by Will Jefferson, the son of the former Cambridge University and Surrey bowler, Richard.

Will is even taller than his father, which is normally far too tall to look comfortable at the crease. But Jefferson did. He was not ruffled by the pace and cruised impressively to 40 in 12 overs. However, the students were more confused by Mushtaq Ahmed's twiddlers. Jefferson was adjudged lbw while Michael Brown, James Pyemont and Matt Banes also found wrist spin far more taxing than Pakistan pace.

webTitle: Cricket roundup: Norman Harris

fields.headline: Killeen shines in the gloom
fields.trailText: By Norman Harris.
fields.body:
Where have all the seam bowlers gone? After all, this is supposed to be the season of moisture in the turf and a tinge of green, traditionally the ingredients that excite those who like to keep the ball shiny and the seam proud.

But after the wettest 12 months ever, the scoring in the Benson & Hedges Cup group matches has, by and large, been pretty good. Perhaps one answer is that groundsmen have been getting smarter. Another reason, more difficult to fathom, is that leading seam bowlers are injured or out of sorts.

Two of them are Durham's Simon Brown and Steve Harmison. The former, on whom Durham have so much relied for their limited successes, remains out of action with a strained side. As for the lanky Harmison, whose sheer speed has excited the England management, he is considered too wayward for the one-day game and, in any case, has looked uninspired in the early season.

But these disappointments have allowed Neil Killeen to shine. He has looked sharp from his first delivery of the cold, new season. A strong, close-cropped head and muscular shoulders (he was a schoolboy javelin champion) suggest something rather violent, but his run-up and 'in his stride' delivery is impressively smooth.

He delivered the game's first ball to Leicestershire's captain, Vince Wells, at Chester-le Street and he did well to send it down at good pace and in the off-stump 'corridor'. Wells sparred; second slip Paul Collingwood took the edge.

After that, the only runs conceded by Killeen came from edges and scratchy-looking drives, and when a twisted ankle forced him to abandon his last over he had taken two for 13 off 8.3 overs. That was about three times better than any other bowler

On a pitch offering some movement Leicestershire pressed as hard as they dared, before falling to over- ambition. Darren Stephens not only batted as briskly as Danny Marsh but also outlasted the Australian. He fell, on 54, to a remarkable catch as keeper Andy Pratt, bravely standing up to Killeen, somehow managed to collect an edged drive low down.

In the end, 201 was a competitive total, especially with Durham's overseas player, Martin Love, resting a cracked finger. It looked better still when the home side also lost a wicket in the first over, Devon Malcolm's pace - and reputation, perhaps - causing Michael Gough to hesitate between back and front foot and fall lbw.

Nick Knight scored his second century in two days during Warwickshire's erratic progress to a total of 227 for eight in their Benson and Hedges Cup group game against a weakened Glamorgan at Edgbaston.

The England left-hander reached three figures for the third time this season in all competitions by making an unbeaten 107 from 144 balls after an opening partnership of 91 with Mark Wagh, who made 35.

They batted for almost half of the innings, but Warwickshire subsided to 178 for six before Keith Piper inspired a late surge with 22 from 18 balls in a stand of 43 in five overs with Knight.

Knight calmly steered his side through the various setbacks, hitting only three fours in an 85-ball half century before posting an impressive follow-up to his 101 against Northamptonshire on Friday.

Glamorgan, facing elimination at the group stage, were without captain Steve James, who aggravated a knee injury while batting against Gloucestershire on Friday, and leading seam bowler Steve Watkin because of a minor groin strain. More misfortune was then heaped on to them when all-rounder Darren Thomas withdrew from the attack after only one over because of a damaged rib muscle.

webTitle: Cricket: Stewart returns in style

fields.headline: Stewart returns in style
fields.standfirst: Surrey v Essex
fields.trailText: Surrey v Essex: DJ Rutnagur at The Oval.
fields.body:
With Alec Stewart and Mark Ramprakash in firm command of Essex's attack, Surrey, set a target of 223, were well on course to achieve a win that would almost ensure them a place in the Benson & Hedges Cup quarter-finals. Stewart, playing his first innings of the season, was in excellent fettle and Ramprakash positively imperious. They took Surrey past 100 in the 22nd over.

Essex, who needed to win this match to figure in the knock-out stage, must have been pleasantly surprised to be batting on a firm pitch with a nice carry and would have aspired to a bigger score than they achieved. Darren Robinson, who had scored a good 69 against Kent on Friday, was out in the first over, attempting a suicidal single. But that blow was softened by Nasser Hussain and Stuart Law putting on 109 for the second wicket.

Surrey's bowlers were tidy, as they had to be to prevent exploitation of the short boundary on the gasometer side. But the few loose balls were firmly put away by Hussain and Law. The Australian, who hit six fours in his 55, fairly sparkled, as he always does when he is on song. His innings came to an inglorious end, however - caught pulling at a Ian Salisbury long hop.

If Hussain was disappointed to be dismissed in the manner he was, caught behind trying to glance, he must have been delighted with his touch. A particularly stirring shot was a straight six he hit off a quite respectable ball from Martin Bicknell. Hussain had also made a half-century against Kent, but without being so delightfully relaxed and fluent as he was yesterday. His 63 made off 104 balls, was his highest score on home soil since his century against Nottinghamshire in the final match of the 1999 season.

Wickets, from Essex's point of view, began to fall with disconcerting frequency after Hussain's exit in the 34th over. Stephen Peters disappointed again, holing out to short midwicket in the 38th. Ronnie Irani, who had conjured 21 runs from 41 balls even though he was hard put to assert himself, was run out for no fault of his own.

Then Graham Napier was caught on the midwicket boundary from a pull and Essex had lost three wickets in the space of six runs. But Paul Grayson, who hit three fours in making 21 off 30 balls and Ashley Cowan staged a rally with a sprightly stand of 42.

webTitle: Cricket: Future lies in kids' gloves

fields.headline: Future lies in kids' gloves
fields.standfirst:
Alec Stewart's days behind the stumps are numbered - but who is England's next wicketkeeper?

If the glove fits
fields.trailText: Alec Stewart's days behind the stumps are numbered - but who is England's next wicketkeeper?
fields.body:
Where are they now, those glovemen of England, my Knotty and my Taylor not so long ago? As Alec Stewart, who will be 38 at his next birthday, contemplates retirement, the awful truth is that there is no one of true international class to pick up the gauntlets.

There is, of course, Gloucestershire's engagingly eccentric Jack Russell, but he's only four months younger than Stewart, has just slipped a disc lifting weights and, anyway, has declared himself unavailable for international cricket.

No, the truth is we're struggling at a time when most other countries have wicketkeepers who are major contributors, with the bat as well as behind the stumps, as is now required. Australia are particularly blessed with Adam Gilchrist, who is perhaps the most exciting member of the side that will arrive here shortly to defend the Ashes. Gilchrist's first bad run of form with the bat in the recent Test series in India just happened to mark the end of Australia's record-breaking run of wins, which most believe was no mere coincidence.

Bob Taylor, whose 57 Tests for England in the 1970s and 1980s were sullied by hardly an inelegant take or fluffed chance - the ball, the commentators liked to say, seemed to melt into his gloves - agrees that on current form the selectors will have little to choose from when Stewart goes. And it is not just the evidence of his own eyes that tells him this. 'I talk to the umpires as I go around the country,' he says. 'They see all the wicketkeepers in all the different conditions and situations, and they say that the cupboard's bare, that there's not the standard of wicketkeeping that there used to be.'

Paul Nixon of Kent, Stewart's deputy on the winter tours of Pakistan and Sri Lanka, scores highly for commitment, personality and batting ability, but his keeping is not the most reliable; Chris Read of Nottinghamshire is generally reckoned to have been promoted too early to the Test side in 1999 and has been set back by the experience; and good keepers such as Worcestershire's Steve Rhodes, Karl Krikken of Derbyshire, Adrian Aymes of Hampshire and Warwickshire's Keith Piper are either too old or not strong enough batsmen - or both - to be chosen.

All of which may turn the selectors in one of two other directions: persuading a batsman who has kept a bit to follow the Stewart route and become a specialist keeper (John Crawley and Marcus Trescothick are possible candidates here); or, which is more likely, talking Stewart into staying on until one of the younger keepers - of which the Durham University undergraduate James Foster of Essex, Sussex's Matt Prior and the Glamorgan reserve Mark Wallace are reckoned to be the pick - has proved himself.

Taylor spells out the problems of trying to convert a batsman into a wicketkeeping all-rounder: 'Any competent catcher of the ball who is a first-class cricketer can put the gloves on and keep wicket standing back. It's when you get up to the stumps that really counts. John Crawley's done it and does well standing back, and also to a degree when standing up, but the concentration that's required in Test matches when there are long periods when little's happening is not easily acquired.'

Peter Moores, the former Sussex wicketkeeper who is now that county's coach, is well placed to assess the young talent. He travelled with the England A side, who included the 21-year-old Foster, on their recent tour of the Caribbean. He also has first-hand knowledge of Prior, who is still only 19. 'James did very well on tour as a keeper and batsman,' says Moores, 'but it would be foolish to think of him as the finished article after only a handful of first-class games. What was impressive was that he improved all the time and I think his level of consistency will go up quite quickly when he starts playing regular first-team cricket.'

Moores describes the South Africa-born Prior as a confident cricketer 'who backs himself to do well'. He is as much a batsman as a wicketkeeper and has already impressed in his one first-class innings this season. 'He's loving it, he's having a ball, as he should be doing at his age,' says Moores. 'Confidence is half the battle.'

Quite why the supply line of international-class wicketkeepers has dried up is hard to tell. Taylor believes part of the problem is that England have produced so few bowling all-rounders that there has been more pressure on the wicketkeeper to score runs than was the case in his day. 'I was very fortunate in having Ian Botham around,' he says. 'Ian was the last of the bowling all-rounders. We know that the game has altered now, with wicketkeepers expected to contribute runs, but I was picked for England so many times because they knew they could rely on Ian to get wickets and runs.

'We haven't really replaced Ian since he retired. Capel, Lewis, DeFreitas, Cork, Gough - they were all supposed to be able to bat and bowl, but none of them has managed it to the same degree as Ian.'

And Taylor thinks that this pressure on wicketkeepers to be run-makers too has been detrimental. 'The expectation to perform in both departments is, it seems, proving too much.'

Steve Marsh, the long-serving Kent keeper who has given way to Nixon, thinks developing wicketkeepers has been neglected. 'Perhaps in the past we were lucky and our Test wicketkeepers just came about through natural talent,' he says. 'Now we're finding out that not enough has been done to develop new ones, because there isn't anyone who stands out at the moment.

'They'll have coaching seminars for batting, bowling and fielding, but keeping seems to be left out. The attitude is, "Oh, it'll happen." But obviously it hasn't happened. It's an area that we have to look at.'

For the moment, though, the selectors will be asking Alec Stewart not to stand too close to the heavy roller - or any other dangerous object.

webTitle: Tory row on 'illegal' £10,000 donation

fields.headline: Tory row on 'illegal' £10,000 donation
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Conservative party
Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: The Conservative Party was last night accused of taking an 'illegal' donation from a foreign company, which under a new law could lead to Tory officials facing criminal charges.
fields.body:
The Conservative Party was last night accused of taking an 'illegal' donation from a foreign company, which under a new law could lead to Tory officials facing criminal charges.

Details of all party political donations published on Friday by the Electoral Commission included a £10,000 donation on 13 March to the Tories from a financial company called First Continental Trading Europe. Although the Tories give a London address for the donor, documents from Companies House reveal this firm's 'country of origin' is the Channel Islands.

Under new laws governing the funding of political parties, donations from overseas companies, including those in the Channel Islands, are illegal. Tory chairman Michael Ancram will have to convince the Commission that the details the party gave it were a mistake and not a deliberate ploy to skirt round the rules. The party claims the listing of the foreign donation was the result of a 'clerical error'.

A spokesman said: 'The company which gave the money was in fact FCT Europe which is based in London and not First Continental Trading Europe. This is not a foreign donation but a donation from a company registered in the UK. It was just a clerical error.'

Fraser Kemp, Labour MP for Houghton and Washington East, dismissed this and called for the Tories to hand the money back. He said: 'I will be writing to the Electoral Commission and asking them to investigate this potential criminal offence.'

webTitle: Observer review: Glue by Irvine Welsh

fields.headline: Sticky whingers
fields.standfirst: Violence, sex, drugs - Irvine Welsh is up to his usual tricks in his latest, Glue, but taking longer about it
fields.trailText: Violence, sex, drugs - Irvine Welsh is up to his usual tricks in his latest, Glue, but taking longer about it
fields.body:
Glue
Irvine Welsh
Cape £12, pp469
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The title isn't explained in the text - glue is perhaps the only intoxicant substance not to find favour among the characters. Glue must refer to the aggregate of forces that keeps four Edinburgh 'schemies' - boys from the schemes, the blocks built to replace slums - connected to each other across four decades from 1970, and over 400-plus gruelling pages.

The dialect in which much of the book is written will also strike new readers of Irvine Welsh as having some of the characteristics of glue. Non-standard speech, however lively when spoken, is a slow read when phonetically rendered; it's an unavoidably bookish experience, trying to realign sounds and meanings in the mind's ear. There's an inbuilt delay, just as there was at an Australian book-signing, when Monica Dickens smilingly inscribed a customer's copy to 'Emma Chisett', not realising that she had been asked the price in an unfamiliar accent.

The book's prose resists smooth assimilation, almost in the manner of A Clockwork Orange, whose formulas the characters' speech occasionally recalls. There are also occasions when Welsh gives his characters ambitious expressions of thought, straining the dialect register. Teenaged Carl Ewart, for instance, is attracted to a girl: 'It wis Lucy ah noticed first, her white-blonde hair glowing in the sun like science-lab magnesium ignited.'

The basic materials of Glue are well summed up by Carl: 'Drunk tales, rave tales, fitba mob tales, drug tales, shaggin tales, aw the usual crap that makes life worth livin.' Add crime tales, plus tales of excreta and ejecta - shite, pish and puke - and you have the ingredients of Welsh's work since Trainspotting. What has changed is sheer length, and, to a lesser extent, ambition.

Themes of betrayal and redemption run the length of the book, though they are disguised by a number of factors. One is that the incidents get less dramatic rather than more, as time goes by. So, in the 1980 section, one of the characters is sent to prison after an assault, though he is innocent. It also features a hideous set-piece, following a robbery in which two of the four principals are involved: their older companions torture and kill a pair of guard dogs, breaking the legs of one with boltcutters before burning them both.

There's another robbery in the 1990 section, but this is in a lighter key, with two pairs of thieves converging on the same property. The main story of 2000 is comedy; an anorexic American superstar is coaxed on to the town by one of the boys, where she discovers a taste for curry and simple company.

So the texture lightens, but not the tone. Consequences loom larger, shadows cast from the long ago, and there's little to contradict the proposition that: 'Ye eywis huv tae pey fir yir fun at some point, and, generally speakin, the mair ye party, the mair ye pey.'

The 1970 prologue has done a certain amount of foreshadowing, showing us two functional fathers and two who are otherwise. The sons of the functionals, Carl Ewart and Billy Birrell, find their place in life; one as a DJ and the other briefly as a boxer, then as celebrity bar-owner, while the other two flounder: Andrew Galloway becomes a heroin addict, Terry Lawson a user of women.

This is a culture where a teenager hesitates to smile at a girl he likes because: 'Ma mates might think ah'm a poof' and where the modest mousse-and-gel dandyism of a boxer in training prompts the reflection that 'sporty cunts are the biggest closet poofs under the sun'. Apparently, you can't have the grim humour and gutter poetry of dialect without its oppressiveness.

In the 2000 section, Irvine Welsh belatedly introduces a couple of female points of view, except that these are ladettes, as stroppy and fixated as the lads. One of them is more than a match for the appalling Terry. There are disturbing signs at the end of this striking but confused and over-long book that the author, over and above his buried sentimental tenderness for the bond between male friends, is trying to turn Terry into an appealing character, someone you just can't blame for trying it on, like one of Martin Amis's louts of the life force.

webTitle: Jagger, MPs and activists unite to grab Esso tiger by the tail

fields.headline: Jagger, MPs and activists unite to grab Esso tiger by the tail
fields.standfirst:
Pressure groups hope to persuade Britons to boycott Esso this week over its opposition to the Kyoto climate deal - a move which could cost the oil giant £1bn. By Anthony Browne and Ben Summerskill

Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Pressure groups hope to persuade Britons to boycott Esso this week over its opposition to the Kyoto climate deal - a move which could cost the oil giant £1bn.
fields.body:
It is one of the very largest companies in the world. It extracts four million barrels of oil a day from beneath the Earth's surface. It has made $10,000 in profits since you started reading this article.

Now Esso - the company that tells the world to 'put a tiger in your tank' - could be brought to its knees by an alliance of environmentalists in the most profound British demonstration of consumer activism since Barclays Bank was forced to pull out of South Africa.

The biggest consumer boycott campaign for a generation will be launched this week when Greenpeace and Friends of the Earth try to force Esso, and its American parent the oil giant Exxon, to abandon its opposition to the Kyoto climate change agreements. If the initiative is successful - the two pressure groups alone have more than 500,000 British members - economists estimate that Esso sales in Britain could be reduced by more than £1 billion a year.

'Exxon gave George W Bush more than $1m towards his election campaign,' said Greenpeace director Stephen Tindale. 'As soon as he was elected, he said that the US would pull out of international agreements to stop global warming. The firm is abusing their global power to stop worldwide action on climate change.'

The Stop Esso initiative will be launched on Tuesday by Bianca Jagger. 'Too often as individuals we feel powerless,' the veteran human rights and environmental activist told The Observer. 'This campaign is a way that people can make a difference. We can say enough, we can say stop. We will make our voices heard.'

One in ten MPs have already signed a multi-party Commons motion supporting The Observer's proposal a fortnight ago that people concerned about global warning should boycott Esso. Last month John Gummer, the former Environment Minister, also urged British drivers to take their business elsewhere. The unusual public endorsement of consumer activism by a senior Conservative has bolstered the campaign.

Anna Bradley, director of the National Consumer Council, said: 'Undoubtedly consumers have the power to influence even a multinational either by causing enough embarrassment or by having sufficient impact on a company's bottom line. That is what could happen here. It remains a pity that while consumers have such enormous power they use it so rarely.'

The Kyoto Treaty was signed by former US vice president Al Gore. It committed America to a legally binding 5 per cent cut in greenhouse gases by 2010. But President Bush announced that America would abandon the agreement shortly after he became President last January.

Environmental campaigners complain that Exxon has steadfastly lobbied against the overwhelming consensus of international scientific opinion that burning oil and gas is the main cause of global warming. In contrast to other oil companies such as BP and Shell, which openly accept the need to combat global warming, Esso has made no investment in renewable forms of energy, which it has dismissed as 'fashionable'.

The UN Panel on Climate Change, comprising the world's top climate scientists, recently said that the burning of fossil fuels is raising world temperatures far faster than previously predicted. Eight of the last 10 years have been the hottest on record. The panel said that millions of lives are at risk from increasingly extreme weather, with a sharp increase in storms, floods and heatwaves.

UK government scientists already predict that, by 2080, 94 million people will be at risk from flooding every year as a result of global warming melting the polar ice caps and glaciers. Greenland may disappear as water levels worldwide rise by up to six metres. Even some British coastlines may be affected.

More than 160 governments have now acknowledged the links between fossil fuels and global warming, but in a recent statement Exxon condemned the promotion of 'scientifically unfounded scare scenarios'. As well as making direct political donations, Exxon has backed multi-million dollar campaigns organised by lobbying groups such as the American Petroleum Institute.

Exxon was originally spawned by J D Rockefeller's Standard Oil empire which was broken up by the US Supreme Court on anti-trust grounds in 1911. Eighty-eight years later, in 1999, the component parts came together again to form Exxon Mobil, now one of the largest companies in the world. It is based in Irving, in President Bush's home state of Texas.

The firm, which made worldwide profits of $12bn last year, runs exploration activities in 48 countries from America to Australia. In many sites it already faces bitter resistance to its drilling or distribution methods and their impact on local environments.

The firm is currently lobbying to be able to drill for oil in the pristine Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, the largest wilderness left in North America. Environmentalists fear that President Bush will support the scheme.

In Britain, Esso has 1,500 petrol stations, which serve around 40,000 cus tomers every hour. Yesterday a spokesman said: 'We make corporate contributions to national political parties but not specific candidates for federal office.

'We are concerned that the obligations of the Kyoto protocol to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases would impose dramatic economic costs throughout the developed world.' The company also warned that a British boycott campaign could harm independent garages operating under an Esso franchise.

Supporters of the boycott will also be asked to sign a pledge saying: 'Esso's sabotage of international action on global warming threatens life on this planet and I take that personally.' Organisers are in discussions with environmental organisations in Germany and The Netherlands and hope to roll out the campaign across Europe within weeks.

The Stop Esso campaigners insist that they will continue their protest until Esso accepts that its business contributes to global warming, and endorses the Kyoto Treaty.

Charles Secrett, director of Friends of the Earth, said: 'We simply want to demonstrate that it does not pay to put profits before our planet.

'By supporting this campaign the British public can show that it wants effective action to tackle global climate change.'

Corporates under the cosh

Benetton

Outrage over Oliviero Toscani's photographs of a man dying from Aids and copulating horses spilled over into boycotts and court cases when the company slapped up posters of death row inmates.

California called for a national boycott, Missouri filed a lawsuit and Chicago's Sears, Roebuck & Co dumped the clothes.

Benetton dumped Toscani.

Nestle

Boycotted by students since the 1970s when the Swiss multinational was exposed as a baby-milk pusher in the developing world. Tins now carry warnings that powdered milk is not a substitute for the real thing and is intended to supplement breastfeeding. Activist group Baby Milk Action is still campaigning. Nestlé is having difficulty recruiting graduates but says (mostly student) boycotts of its Kit Kats and coffee are commercially insignificant.

Wal-mart

Union-busting activities and factories in the developing world have sparked boycotts by American liberals calling for an end to the use of cheap Nicaraguan labour (oh, and protests in Nicaragua by cheap workers demanding an end to American liberals).

Barclays

The British bank had extensive interests in South Africa which it refused to withdraw for two decades while investing in businesses operating under the apartheid regime. It was subject to regular demonstrations, lost tens of thousands of potential customers and was overtaken as Britain's biggest bank. It disposed of its South African investments in the mid-1980s.

Gap

From Boston to San Francisco, Gap is under siege. Banner-waving tree-huggers supporting the redwoods (it's complicated) and school kids supporting sweatshop workers in Saipan have declared the first Saturday of every month an Anti-Gap Day of Action. Gap denies the charges of exploitation and gets on with expanding its empire and collecting the profits.

Fur

Students, supermodels and Stella McCartney have made fur the very last thing in fashion - until Yves St-Laurent and his fellow high-fashionists declared it to be just that. • Additional reporting: Oliver Morgan

Eighty-eight years later, in 1999, the component parts came together again to form Exxon Mobil, now one of the largest companies in the world. It is based in Irving, in President Bush's home state of Texas. The firm, which made worldwide profits of $12bn last year, runs exploration activities in 48 countries from America to Australia. In many sites it already faces bitter resistance to its drilling or distribution methods and their impact on local environments. The firm is currently lobbying to be able to drill for oil in the pristine Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, the largest wilderness left in North America. Environmentalists fear that President Bush will support the scheme. In Britain, Esso has 1,500 petrol stations, which serve around 40,000 cus tomers every hour. Yesterday a spokesman said: 'We make corporate contributions to national political parties but not specific candidates for federal office. 'We are concerned that the obligations of the Kyoto protocol to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases would impose dramatic economic costs throughout the developed world.' The company also warned that a British boycott campaign could harm independent garages operating under an Esso franchise. Supporters of the boycott will also be asked to sign a pledge saying: 'Esso's sabotage of international action on global warming threatens life on this planet and I take that personally.' Organisers are in discussions with environmental organisations in Germany and The Netherlands and hope to roll out the campaign across Europe within weeks. The Stop Esso campaigners insist that they will continue their protest until Esso accepts that its business contributes to global warming, and endorses the Kyoto Treaty. Charles Secrett, director of Friends of the Earth, said: 'We simply want to demonstrate that it does not pay to put profits before our planet. 'By supporting this campaign the British public can show that it wants effective action to tackle global climate change.' Corporates under the cosh Benetton Outrage over Oliviero Toscani's photographs of a man dying from Aids and copulating horses spilled over into boycotts and court cases when the company slapped up posters of death row inmates. California called for a national boycott, Missouri filed a lawsuit and Chicago's Sears, Roebuck & Co dumped the clothes. Benetton dumped Toscani. Nestle Boycotted by students since the 1970s when the Swiss multinational was exposed as a baby-milk pusher in the developing world. Tins now carry warnings that powdered milk is not a substitute for the real thing and is intended to supplement breastfeeding. Activist group Baby Milk Action is still campaigning. Nestlé is having difficulty recruiting graduates but says (mostly student) boycotts of its Kit Kats and coffee are commercially insignificant. Wal-mart Union-busting activities and factories in the developing world have sparked boycotts by American liberals calling for an end to the use of cheap Nicaraguan labour (oh, and protests in Nicaragua by cheap workers demanding an end to American liberals). Barclays The British bank had extensive interests in South Africa which it refused to withdraw for two decades while investing in businesses operating under the apartheid regime. It was subject to regular demonstrations, lost tens of thousands of potential customers and was overtaken as Britain's biggest bank. It disposed of its South African investments in the mid-1980s. Gap From Boston to San Francisco, Gap is under siege. Banner-waving tree-huggers supporting the redwoods (it's complicated) and school kids supporting sweatshop workers in Saipan have declared the first Saturday of every month an Anti-Gap Day of Action. Gap denies the charges of exploitation and gets on with expanding its empire and collecting the profits. Fur Students, supermodels and Stella McCartney have made fur the very last thing in fashion - until Yves St-Laurent and his fellow high-fashionists declared it to be just that. • Additional reporting: Oliver Morgan
