fields.body:
Sitting in the lounge of his Newmarket home, Lester Piggott is as cool and collected as he was in the saddle, the composed exterior concealing an extravagant genius that dominated British racing for almost half a century, an icon recognised simply by his Christian name. Only once since his second retirement six years ago has Lester ridden in public, a veterans' race in Australia last November, six days after he had qualified for a state pension. 'Yes, I enjoyed it, and I'd consider doing it again, given the right circumstances. I'd been riding out for William [Haggas, his son-in-law] to get myself into shape, but I wasn't 100 per cent fit. Nowhere near.' His mount, Bay Scenery, finished third. 'The horse was outpaced after 100 yards and got a long way behind,' he says curtly. 'He wanted a lot further.' Piggott returned to the unsaddling enclosure with a face like a thundercloud; winning has been the haemoglobin of his life.

The generous room, furnished in shades as sober as its owner, would be sombre from the gloom outside but for the kaleidoscope of colour on the walls Ü paintings, prints, photographs, a gallery of glory celebrating a career that yielded a record 30 Classic winners, including nine Derbies.

A new Flat season has begun, but the cream of the crop are unlikely to match last year's superb vintage. For a few hours last August Dubai Millennium and Montjeu, two horses fast enough to dominate any year, were destined for a $10m match.'It was a great year,' Piggott says, 'and if the two horses had met somewhere in July, Montjeu would have had a chance. Then Dubai Millennium broke down, and I thought Montjeu was never quite the same after his injury in the autumn. It was sad to see him beaten, but they do get beat, don't they?'

Giant's Causeway, another outstanding horse from last season, also took Piggott's fancy. 'He was very tough. In some ways he reminded me of The Minstrel [on whom Piggott won the 1977 Derby], beaten in the Guineas but he went on to win all those good races.'

Piggott was impressed. But not that impressed. 'Yes, they were top horses,' says the man probably best qualified to make historical judgments about the true qualities of British racehorses, 'but I really don't think they were any better than the ones I rode.' Indeed none of last year's champions qualifies as the best horse Piggott has seen since his retirement. That honour goes to the dynamic French horse, Peintre Celebre. 'On the day he landed the Arc in 1997, breaking the track record, he was really outstanding.'

Piggott won three Prix de l'Arc de Triomphes, the first on Rheingold in 1973. 'The mile and a half course at Longchamp is one of the hardest in the world to ride. You get a number of half turns before you get to the straight, which is relatively short.' His other two Arc winners came in 1977 and 1978 on Alleged, a horse whose quality still rings down the ages. 'He was one of the best half dozen horses I ever rode.'

Looking back, though, Piggott confesses he should have won a fourth Arc, and blames himself for his failure to win on Park Top in 1969. The Duke Of Devonshire's filly flew home in the final furlong, but could not catch the Ascot Gold Cup winner, Levmoss. 'It was my fault. She needed to be held up until the last minute, and I left it too late. If I'd moved sooner I'd have won.'

Lester Piggot rode his first winner, The Chase, at Haydock Park in 1948. He was 12 years old. Already a prodigy, the young Piggott was flouting authority long before flared trousers and nostrils assaulted the Sixties. The teenager was by many lengths the most gifted apprentice of his generation, insolently superior to some of the formulaic veterans he encountered, and they resented it. Consequently, he was suspended more times than a chorus girl's stocking.

After the King Edward VII Stakes at Royal Ascot of 1954, Piggott was wrongly blamed by the local stewards for causing a scrimmage early in the straight. The stewards of the Jockey Club, bred to stifle precocity, banned him from the racecourse for six months, and demanded that he complete his apprenticeship away from the cocoon of home. Piggott took refuge with Jack Jarvis at Newmarket.

'Life was very different then,' Piggott recalls. 'The whole racing world has changed for the better. The stewards have got camera patrols to help them, and everyone's much more aware of safety. When I was young, I didn't want to get beaten and go back with excuses. It was every man for himself. You went out to win. Yes, I did cut up one or two, and them me. But you can't do two things, do your best to win all the time, and be careful all the time.'

His disdain for authority, his palpable talent, his election as the people's jockey, made him the 'housewives' favourite'. When as an 18-year-old he landed his first Derby on Never Say Die in 1954, the winner's name celebrated the blitz mentality of a nation barely weened off ration books. A 33-1 outsider, Never Say Die should have been a good result for the bookmakers, but many thousands had backed the boy wonder and in one ride Piggott had captured the hearts and minds of punters up and down the country.

His arch opponent throughout his early career was Scobie Breasley, the best jockey to leave Australia. Breasley liked to settle horses, shave the inside rail, challenge late. 'That was his way. It was a good way, but it didn't always pay off. We rode against each other for a long time, and had the pick of the rides. We carved it up between us, really.'

In 1961 Piggott married Susan Armstrong, the daughter of trainer Sam Armstrong, and the couple moved to Newmarket. They have never left. Their first house was near Tattersalls' sales arena; they now share a luxury bungalow in Hamilton Road. He lives there with Susan in close proximity to both his elder daughter, Maureen, (who is married to William Haggas) and to Jamie, a son born to his former assistant, Anna Ludlow.

Ego drives champions, and ever since Piggott realised that he was the best he has treated the law with steadfast indifference. Regulations - be they on the racetrack, on the road, about paying taxes or in life - are obeyed only if convenient. In one race at Deauville he snatched a whip from Alain Lequeux when his own had gone flying; in another at Sha Tin, he pushed away the head of a persistent challenger with his hand. The inevitable penalties were shrugged off as inconsequential.

In 1987 he was given a three-year sentence for tax evasion, of which he served 366 days. Many thought that Piggott, who had travelled Pullman class for most of his life, would be destroyed by the experience. They failed to understand that the taciturn veil he had worn so devotedly to protect him from the public, imposed by partial deafness and a minor speech impediment, proved to be a perfect apprenticeship for the alienation of prison. 'I decided to keep my head down,' he says now, 'keep my nose clean.' The year passed; 'a waste,' he says. He survived, emerging a little softer.

Two years before going to jail Piggott had retired and taken up training. At its peak his Eve Lodge stables had housed 97 residents and sent out 34 winners, but on his release he returned home to a handful of horses, and it was not enough. In the autumn of 1990 he returned to what he knew best. Within a few days of his picking up the reins, he landed one of the most prestigious races in America, the Breeders' Cup Mile, at the age of 54. Racing celebrated the return of its fallen idol; he might have been stripped of his OBE, but to the devout congregation it was a second coming, the flair, the drive, the equilibrium seemingly undiminished by the passing of the years. Even the jockey found a smile.

He doesn't drop his guard easily, though. Those who thought David Beckham was a trifle timid when interviewed by Ali G for this year's Red Nose Day should try Lester; he makes the England football captain seem as extrovert as John McCririck.

If Lester owned a Classic colt, which present day jockey would he engage to ride? 'That's a hard one. I'm not answering that one.'

To nominate the most talented horse he rode is, he thinks, to diminish the other champions. He knows, of course, but would rather keep it to himself than offend those he has passed over. Nijinsky, who won the Triple Crown in 1970, was the most charismatic of his champions. The familiar figure of Lester's lean torso balanced against Nijinsky on the bridle was the sight of a lifetime; irons short, reins long, man and horse flowing over the turf in perfect harmony.

When most jockeys want their horses to quicken they shorten the reins and start to pump, jack-in-the-box, all action. No jockey could be more severe in a finish than Piggott, but his composure on a thoroughbred galloping at 40 miles an hour was unique. His superior judgment of pace allowed him to challenge at the optimum moment, seemingly without effort, his horse full of running, given the confidence to quicken way from the herd, to confront the unknown.

'In terms of raw ability, Nijinsky was probably the best,' he finally concedes. 'He got nervous before his races, and I was always anxious until he had jumped out of the stalls. Then he'd drop the bit and you could put him anywhere in a race. Soon after the King George he got ringworm, and ran in the St Leger, probably before he'd really got over it. It was the Triple Crown and no horse had landed it since Bahram in 1935, so you can understand why they wanted him to go. He won all right, but not as easily as people thought. '

By now Nijinsky's reputation had grown beyond peers and punters, and the Irish-trained horse had been adopted by the whole of Europe when he lined up for the Arc in October. Victory would have bestowed immortality and thousands travelled to witness the moment. It was not to be.

'The St Leger left its mark,' Piggott reflects. 'He didn't have the same feel at Longchamp. In the straight Sassafras was in the lead and I went after him. We got to the front 100 yards out, but then he went a bit to the left - he hadn't done it before - and Sassafras got back up on the line. At the time it was a catastrophe!'

Some 30 years on, he can afford a chuckle. 'Seriously, though, it was disappointing. He was unbeaten in 12 races. Everybody expected so much. The public were disappointed, but so was I. We all wanted him to win and it hurt.'

The 1968 Derby winner Sir Ivor remains another favourite. There is a film of his Classic year, still one of the best documentaries on racing, from which two truths emerge: Sir Ivor had a brilliant turn of finishing speed; and he was tough, winning the Laurel Invitation in America at the end of a gruelling season that had begun in a Guineas trial at Ascot seven months earlier. Piggott settled him so successfully at Epsom that the horse was all but asleep by the time the field swept around Tattenham Corner. 'He had a lot of speed, and I wasn't sure he'd get the trip so I held him up on the inside. With two furlongs to go Sandy Barclay was out in front on Connaught and I was still four lengths behind. I pulled him out and asked him to go, but he didn't quicken up straight away. Perhaps I'd got him a bit too relaxed. Then suddenly he just took off, flew, and won easily.'

Nijinsky and Sir Ivor were trained in Co Tipperary by Vincent O'Brien, a man as reticent yet as accomplished as Piggott himself. Together they shared nine Classic winners. Piggott's formal association with the demure Irishman began in 1966, ending a long and successful partnership with Noel Murless, the leading postwar trainer in England. Such naked disloyalty affronted a public still nursing a sense of fair play which had long been suffocated by the onslaught of the commercial imperative. They could not understand why Piggott was deserting someone who had provided him with such a regular supply of Classic winners.

The Jockey Club held an impotent inquiry, but Piggot simply wanted the freedom to pick and choose the most likely winners; he was the best, he wanted to ride the best. Those who thought his self-interest would bring about his downfall were silenced when he retained his jockeys' championship (one of nine, though it would have been many more if he had been a few pounds lighter).

'Noel was a great trainer,' Piggott recalls, 'but many of his owners had their own stallions and mares, and he was sent their stock.' The champions, though, were emerging from the sales rings of Newmarket and Kentucky. Economic power was drifting away from the aristrocracy, who could only watch helplessly as death duties destroyed the wealth which maintained large private studs. The Sport of Kings became a genetic casino for new money. The pools magnate Robert Sangster was spending millions on the progeny of the great stallion Northern Dancer in America and Piggott wanted to ride them.

'Noel was extraordinarily kind to horses, not necessarily the way they were all treated in those days. Crepello was a bit lazy, never did more than he had to, but he had tremendous speed. He had fragile tendons and broke down in the summer, but was one of the best horses I ever rode.'

Murless rated the ride Piggott gave tough little Carozza to win the 1977 Oaks for the Queen as the best he could recall, but the most memorable filly of their partnership was Petite Etoile. The grey won the 1,000 Guineas, the Oaks, two Coronation Cups and a Champion Stakes; she was never out of the first two in 19 races over four seasons in the Fifites and Sixties, but scarcely lasted a mile and a half. His gossamer rein persuaded the petulant filly that she was barely exerting herself. 'She was a right monkey at the best of times,' was Murless's euphemistic observation, but their combined finesse controlled her temperament.

Piggott's light touch could be matched by a shade of violence, and the victory of Roberto in 1972 was the most controversial of his Derbies. Bill Williamson, the colt's regular jockey, was recovering from injury and the owner wanted Piggott to ride. Lester had a reputation for easing his rivals out of the saddle, but, for once, Piggott was wrongly blamed by the press and public.

With less than two furlongs to run, Roberto was given a hefty bump by the weakening leader, Pentland Firth, at the same time as being squeezed on his outside by Rheingold, ridden by the lightweight Ernie Johnson. Rheingold was half a length ahead entering the final furlong, and should have won, but he hung into his rival, persistently bumping him.

With Rheingold so close, Piggott could not use his whip effectively until well inside the final furlong. Then, with Roberto balanced, Piggott let loose. The crack of his flailing whip cut through the roar of the stands, compelling Roberto to respond. The two exhausted colts flashed across the line eye to eye.

'The Minstrel had a hard race in the Derby, when he just got up to beat Willie [Carson] on Hot Grove, but I was harder on Roberto,' Piggott admits. 'I had to win, you know, and he wasn't doing much for me. I felt he could go faster if only he would. When we passed the post I thought I was beat, but I wasn't worried because I was sure I would get the race in the Stewards' Room.' To Lester, Roberto's reluctance justified the ferocity of his ride, one of the greatest in racing, a flagrant imposition of one man's will on history, seared in the memory as surely as an oak scorched by lightning.

In public, Piggott's temperament remained equable throughout a career peppered with injuries, with death threats, with physical deprivation. At over 5ft 7in tall, he has spent most of his life weighing 8st 4lb, two stones light, riding daily on little more nourishment than the famous regime of small coffees and large cigars. In retirement he likes ice cream, but still watches his weight. The lizard-lined face of his fifties is fuller now, the skin softer, easing the labyrinth of wrinkles.

Most days at Newmarket he calls into the Somerville Lodge stables of his son-in-law, in which he owns shares in four horses, the useful handicapper Royal Artist, and three two-year-olds, Horoscope, Prima Diva and La Perla. Last season his syndicate's colours were carried to victory by Superstar Leo in the Norfolk Stakes at Royal Ascot, the meeting at which he rode 114 winners. The owners sold their filly, prematurely as it transpired, but you can bet that Lester made a substantial profit.

He has always hated the cold, and in winter travels widely with his wife Susan. Over forty years their marriage has been tempered from passion to devotion by the flames of fame and shame. The man who was born on Guy Fawkes' Day may no longer burst into an explosion of colour and power on flying thoroughbreds, but never has he seemed so content.

Piggott on

His reputation for ruthlessness
'When I was young, I didn't want to get beaten and go back with excuses. It was every man for himself. You went out to win. Yes, I did cut up one or two, and them me. But you can't do two things, do your best to win all the time, and be careful all the time'

The best horse he has ever ridden
'In terms of raw ability, Nijinsky was probably the best. He got nervous before his races, and I was always anxious until he had jumped out of the stalls. Then he'd drop the bit and you could put him anywhere in a race'

Why he had to whip Roberto hard to win the 1972 Derby
'I had to win, you know, and he wasn't doing much for me. I felt he could go faster if only he would'

His time in jail
'I decided to keep my head down, keep my nose clean'

On Piggott

'One of the grandest sights in racing has always been to see Lester hauled before the stewards. He goes in there like Clint Eastwood, and he comes out like Clint Eastwood. Lester doesn't give a monkey's'
Bryn Crossley, jockey

'He is quite a good rider, but will never be as good as his father. Don't make a fuss, Lester is just a very ordinary boy'
His mother Iris after 12-year-old Lester made his debut

'He would lock away his Yorkie bars and cigars and when he unlocked the cupboard he would take out one piece of Yorkie at a time'
Walter Swinburn, jockey

'I have seen Steve Donoghue, Gordon Richards and the great Australian jockeys, but he was in a class of his own'
Lord Carnarvon, the Queen's racing manager

'The best jockey ever. Gordon Richards was a better rider, but Piggott was always one step ahead. He could come home in sixth, but see another horse in the pack and work out where and why it went wrong. He would go to the owner and say, "Let me ride your horse at Beverley on Tuesday and I'll win." And it would'
Terry Pritchard, agent

'I kept a scrapbook on him when I was younger. Unbelievable man. He could even think like a horse'
Graham Bradley, jockey

'He had a lot of speed, and I wasn't sure he'd get the trip so I held him up on the inside. With two furlongs to go Sandy Barclay was out in front on Connaught and I was still four lengths behind. I pulled him out and asked him to go, but he didn't quicken up straight away. Perhaps I'd got him a bit too relaxed. Then suddenly he just took off, flew, and won easily.' Nijinsky and Sir Ivor were trained in Co Tipperary by Vincent O'Brien, a man as reticent yet as accomplished as Piggott himself. Together they shared nine Classic winners. Piggott's formal association with the demure Irishman began in 1966, ending a long and successful partnership with Noel Murless, the leading postwar trainer in England. Such naked disloyalty affronted a public still nursing a sense of fair play which had long been suffocated by the onslaught of the commercial imperative. They could not understand why Piggott was deserting someone who had provided him with such a regular supply of Classic winners. The Jockey Club held an impotent inquiry, but Piggot simply wanted the freedom to pick and choose the most likely winners; he was the best, he wanted to ride the best. Those who thought his self-interest would bring about his downfall were silenced when he retained his jockeys' championship (one of nine, though it would have been many more if he had been a few pounds lighter). 'Noel was a great trainer,' Piggott recalls, 'but many of his owners had their own stallions and mares, and he was sent their stock.' The champions, though, were emerging from the sales rings of Newmarket and Kentucky. Economic power was drifting away from the aristrocracy, who could only watch helplessly as death duties destroyed the wealth which maintained large private studs. The Sport of Kings became a genetic casino for new money. The pools magnate Robert Sangster was spending millions on the progeny of the great stallion Northern Dancer in America and Piggott wanted to ride them. 'Noel was extraordinarily kind to horses, not necessarily the way they were all treated in those days. Crepello was a bit lazy, never did more than he had to, but he had tremendous speed. He had fragile tendons and broke down in the summer, but was one of the best horses I ever rode.' Murless rated the ride Piggott gave tough little Carozza to win the 1977 Oaks for the Queen as the best he could recall, but the most memorable filly of their partnership was Petite Etoile. The grey won the 1,000 Guineas, the Oaks, two Coronation Cups and a Champion Stakes; she was never out of the first two in 19 races over four seasons in the Fifites and Sixties, but scarcely lasted a mile and a half. His gossamer rein persuaded the petulant filly that she was barely exerting herself. 'She was a right monkey at the best of times,' was Murless's euphemistic observation, but their combined finesse controlled her temperament. Piggott's light touch could be matched by a shade of violence, and the victory of Roberto in 1972 was the most controversial of his Derbies. Bill Williamson, the colt's regular jockey, was recovering from injury and the owner wanted Piggott to ride. Lester had a reputation for easing his rivals out of the saddle, but, for once, Piggott was wrongly blamed by the press and public. With less than two furlongs to run, Roberto was given a hefty bump by the weakening leader, Pentland Firth, at the same time as being squeezed on his outside by Rheingold, ridden by the lightweight Ernie Johnson. Rheingold was half a length ahead entering the final furlong, and should have won, but he hung into his rival, persistently bumping him. With Rheingold so close, Piggott could not use his whip effectively until well inside the final furlong. Then, with Roberto balanced, Piggott let loose. The crack of his flailing whip cut through the roar of the stands, compelling Roberto to respond. The two exhausted colts flashed across the line eye to eye. 'The Minstrel had a hard race in the Derby, when he just got up to beat Willie [Carson] on Hot Grove, but I was harder on Roberto,' Piggott admits. 'I had to win, you know, and he wasn't doing much for me. I felt he could go faster if only he would. When we passed the post I thought I was beat, but I wasn't worried because I was sure I would get the race in the Stewards' Room.' To Lester, Roberto's reluctance justified the ferocity of his ride, one of the greatest in racing, a flagrant imposition of one man's will on history, seared in the memory as surely as an oak scorched by lightning. In public, Piggott's temperament remained equable throughout a career peppered with injuries, with death threats, with physical deprivation. At over 5ft 7in tall, he has spent most of his life weighing 8st 4lb, two stones light, riding daily on little more nourishment than the famous regime of small coffees and large cigars. In retirement he likes ice cream, but still watches his weight. The lizard-lined face of his fifties is fuller now, the skin softer, easing the labyrinth of wrinkles. Most days at Newmarket he calls into the Somerville Lodge stables of his son-in-law, in which he owns shares in four horses, the useful handicapper Royal Artist, and three two-year-olds, Horoscope, Prima Diva and La Perla. Last season his syndicate's colours were carried to victory by Superstar Leo in the Norfolk Stakes at Royal Ascot, the meeting at which he rode 114 winners. The owners sold their filly, prematurely as it transpired, but you can bet that Lester made a substantial profit. He has always hated the cold, and in winter travels widely with his wife Susan. Over forty years their marriage has been tempered from passion to devotion by the flames of fame and shame. The man who was born on Guy Fawkes' Day may no longer burst into an explosion of colour and power on flying thoroughbreds, but never has he seemed so content. Piggott on His reputation for ruthlessness 'When I was young, I didn't want to get beaten and go back with excuses. It was every man for himself. You went out to win. Yes, I did cut up one or two, and them me. But you can't do two things, do your best to win all the time, and be careful all the time' The best horse he has ever ridden 'In terms of raw ability, Nijinsky was probably the best. He got nervous before his races, and I was always anxious until he had jumped out of the stalls. Then he'd drop the bit and you could put him anywhere in a race' Why he had to whip Roberto hard to win the 1972 Derby 'I had to win, you know, and he wasn't doing much for me. I felt he could go faster if only he would' His time in jail 'I decided to keep my head down, keep my nose clean' On Piggott 'One of the grandest sights in racing has always been to see Lester hauled before the stewards. He goes in there like Clint Eastwood, and he comes out like Clint Eastwood. Lester doesn't give a monkey's' Bryn Crossley, jockey 'He is quite a good rider, but will never be as good as his father. Don't make a fuss, Lester is just a very ordinary boy' His mother Iris after 12-year-old Lester made his debut 'He would lock away his Yorkie bars and cigars and when he unlocked the cupboard he would take out one piece of Yorkie at a time' Walter Swinburn, jockey 'I have seen Steve Donoghue, Gordon Richards and the great Australian jockeys, but he was in a class of his own' Lord Carnarvon, the Queen's racing manager 'The best jockey ever. Gordon Richards was a better rider, but Piggott was always one step ahead. He could come home in sixth, but see another horse in the pack and work out where and why it went wrong. He would go to the owner and say, "Let me ride your horse at Beverley on Tuesday and I'll win." And it would' Terry Pritchard, agent 'I kept a scrapbook on him when I was younger. Unbelievable man. He could even think like a horse' Graham Bradley, jockey

webTitle: Blair overruled Brown to strike Tube deal

fields.headline: Blair overruled Brown to strike Tube deal
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Greater London authority
Special report: Livingstone's London
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Tony Blair overruled the Treasury to strike a deal with Bob Kiley over the Tube amid fears that the ongoing row would cost Labour seats in the capital.
fields.body:
Tony Blair overruled the Treasury to strike a deal with Bob Kiley over the Tube amid fears that the ongoing row would cost Labour seats in the capital.

The prime minister ended the stalemate surrounding the part-privatisation of the London Underground on Friday by agreeing that Kiley, the American transport expert hired by Ken Livingstone to run the Tube, should handle final negotiations and granting his demands for greater control over the network.

Blair has hosted two meetings with Kiley in the last fortnight and was said to 'understand' Kiley's concerns that the part-privatisation framework laid down by the Treasury might not deliver a coherent and unified system of control.

The decision will be seen by Livingstone as a sweet victory over his bitter enemy Gordon Brown, who has so far stuck resolutely to his guns in blocking Kiley's demands.

The Mayor had warned that its handling of the transport issue could backfire on Labour at the ballot box in June, pointing out that both the Tories and the Liberal Democrats were opposed to the part-privatisation.

Kiley has long argued for unified management control over the network to ensure the safety of the service.

He will now chair London Transport and handle final negotiations with the two selected consortia responsible for refurbishing the ailing system, beginning next week the process of wresting control of maintenance of trains, signals and track away from the two private consortia of internationally renowned construction firms into his hands.

He will also draw up a strict timetable of infrastructure improvements and attempt to insert a contract clause within the frameworkwhich will allow him to terminate consortia contracts if they fail to deliver.

Kiley confirmed to The Observer that he will still plough ahead with legal action against the Government if he fails to reach agreement with the preferred bidders, including Balfour Beatty who were responsible for maintaining the section of rail which caused the Hatfield train disaster last October.

'We'll know within a few weeks whether we've made progress,' he said.

Effectively, he will decide on the eve of a June election whether to take the Government to court, in a bid to exert maximum political pressure.

Livingstone welcomed the decision. 'There's now a wonderful opportunity for London to get the tube system it requires,' he added. 'This decision signals a constructive approach to devolved regional power.'

The PPP negotiating process will still take four months to resolve. If a deal is reached, board meetings will be open to the public under Kiley's system.

However there are indications that the consortia could climbdown on the issue of maintenance, a major part of their money-making potential under the deal.

The row over the Tube has raged since the Treasury imposed PPP on the deputy prime minister John Prescott four years ago. The debate goes to the heart of Labour's Third Way policy aimed at using private capital for public projects such as hospitals, roads and schools.

Under PPP the Tube network would be split into three sections, with leading construction firms investing billions to maintain and refurbish it for 30 years, while London Underground owns the rolling stock. The Treasury has agreed for the first time to give the Tube a secure income stream for over seven years.

But critics fear PPP would replicate mistakes made in the privatisation of British Rail, with lines of management control blurred and no one in overall charge.

webTitle: Gangs seek revenge in Macedonia

fields.headline: Killer gangs plot revenge in Macedonia
fields.standfirst:
Paramilitaries seek retribution for commando killings

Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: Blood still stains the floor of Ramadan Nuredini's restaurant. Masked men entered the pizzeria in the Macedonian capital, Skopje, last Tuesday and shot one of his customers.
fields.body:
Blood still stains the floor of Ramadan Nuredini's restaurant. Masked men entered the pizzeria in the Macedonian capital, Skopje, last Tuesday and shot one of his customers. They then turned on Ramadan and his grandson and beat them with baseball bats as the customer, Ismet Hoxha, a Kosovo Albanian, lay dying.

The same day 105 miles further south in the city of Bitola, a crowd of Macedonian Slavs went on the rampage, setting fire to Albanian-owned businesses and destroying 40 buildings.

The attacks followed the funerals of eight Macedonian commandos killed in an ambush by ethnic Albanian rebels a week ago. At least one victim had his head crushed with a rifle butt, excuse enough perhaps to send an angry mob on the rampage.

The work of the Skopje attackers, however, is something else: coldly planned, premeditated ethnic murder.

Just over a month ago The Observer reported a claim that a Macedonian Interior Minister had organised a meeting of leading criminals in Skopje. There they were allegedly asked to help their country by forming a group similar to Arkan's Tigers, who led the ethnic cleansing of Bosnia. Within days, graffiti appeared in central Skopje, heralding the 'People's Front of Macedonia' and the 'National Front'.

Few doubt that paramilitary-style groups are now active and eager for publicity. One even has a website, Macedonian Pride, showing armed Macedonian Action Organisation members posing for photographs.

One picture shows 20 men, wearing khaki jump-suits and red T-shirts, standing in a sunlit wood, with banners decorated with the old Macedonian flag decorating banners on either side of them. Two more photographs show some of the same group sporting a collection of semi- automatic rifles.

While no group has claimed responsibility for the killing in Skopje, suspicion has fallen on the new paramilitary-style group, and its leader Alexander Kolevski, who has already been called for questioning by police.

Blond-haired Kolevski is in his mid-thirties and has a scar across his cheek. According to him the country's politicians have gone far enough in trying to resolve the crisis by inter-party talks. Quoted in a local newspaper, Dnevnik, he says the politics can no longer solve anything. 'The Albanians have shown their true face. We are here to help out soldiers fighting at the border.'

Kolevski told The Observer he had been 'misrepresented' by Dnevnik. He had since had his summons to see the police, and said he was unable to make any further comment. Earlier, however, he had promised to take The Observer to where his men were being trained.

The Macedonian paper also refers to several other groups with similar plans and outlook as the National Front, such as the Macedonian Lions and the Blue Birds. The latter claims to have 2,200 armed men ready to fight.

Sources say the Macedonian Action Organisation is closely associated with fans from the Vardar football team in Skopje.

According to Dnevnik the group was responsible for the attack in Bitola and had planned similar mayhem in the Albanian market in Skopje for last Wednesday after a football match. The idea was dropped when the game was cancelled.

The Macedonian Ministry of the Interior denies the existence of such paramilitary groups, and says it is doing its best to stop any being created.

The new paramilitaries have capitalised on a widespread feeling among Macedonian Slavs that the government is giving too much to the country's Albanian minority, and has failed to clamp down hard enough on gunmen fighting the army.

Slav tensions have been stoked by the latest attacks by the ethnic Albanian National Liberation Army, which killed 10 Macedonian soldiers and led to the shelling of Albanian villages and rebel positions.

Macedonian intelligence sources claim the attacks were ordered by ethnic Albanian leaders from Macedonia, Serbia, Kosovo, Albania and Greece at a meeting in Switzerland on 1 April.

A senior Defence Ministry official said: 'They planned an attack close to a major town by the end of April or the first few days in May. The aim is to increase international pressure on the government to seek a political solution.'

webTitle: Ready to go to the people

fields.headline: Ready to go to the people
fields.standfirst: Blair the Bold and Tony the Timid, the Prime Minister has governed as both personalities. Now battle-scarred and four years wiser - he is 48 today - will a second term enable him to realise his vision?
fields.trailText: Andrew Rawnsley: Blair the Bold and Tony the Timid, the Prime Minister has governed as both personalities. Now battle-scarred and four years wiser - he is 48 today - will a second term enable him to realise his vision?
fields.body:
In the early hours of 2 May 1997, as swathes of Britain that had been Conservative for a generation were enveloped by his landslide, a small jet flew Tony Blair and the most intimate members of his entourage south from Sedgefield. He was about to become the first Labour Prime Minister in 18 years, enthroned at the apex of the majority greater than for any party in more than six decades. Still only 43, he would be the youngest occupant of Number 10 since Lord Liverpool in 1812. And to no one was this sensational prospect more awesome than Blair himself. As the plane sped to London, his wife grasped his hand and chatted excitedly about his 'great opportunity'. To Cherie, Tony replied: 'But I've never been in government.'

With Leo, his father, he shared similar trepidations. 'Realising that you are about to be Prime Minister is a very strange moment,' Blair reflected later. 'My dad was fabulous. He was absolutely knocked out by it. He said: "Mum would have been very proud." But he read my mood correctly. He kept saying to me during the evening: "You will do it well." He understood what I was worrying about.'

Four years on, as he prepares to launch his campaign for re-election, what everyone neglects to note is just how much of a novice to power Blair was. He had managed nothing except a hungry, skilful Opposition against an exhausted Tory Government with a death-wish. He had never seen the inside of a red box, nor given instructions to a civil servant. He had not even been a Parliamentary Private Secretary, lowest form of life on the Ministerial food chain.

It is a tribute to Blair, the ingenue of May 1997, that his total inexperience in office has never been mentioned since. As the honeymoon has steadily deflated, he has been flayed as an opportunist, an autocrat, a betrayer, a manipulator and a charlatan. In some quarters of Left and Right, the man is utterly loathed, not so much for his failures, so I sometimes think, as for being a success. What even the most vituperative opponents never say of him, as the critics did of John Major, Anthony Eden, Ramsay MacDonald, Arthur Balfour and many other previous occupants of Number 10, is that Blair is not up to doing the job of Prime Minister.

The virgin to power now wears the scars of a veteran. He has fought a war. He has sacked one of his oldest friends and closest allies. Twice. He has been blooded by short and savage crises, and toughened by long and debilitating struggles. It's there to be read in his face. The crows have splayed their feet more heavily around the eyes, the hairline is in retreat, the brow is ploughed with deeper furrows. Office has engraved itself on the man whose biggest marketing feature was once a boyishly cheesy grin. One of the most workaholic members of the Cabinet comments: 'I get completely knackered doing my job. By the end of the week, I'm a dead man walking. Tony works twice as hard as I do.'

Blair is also a more grizzled man where it doesn't show so obviously, inside his head. 'He's matured. I think his skin is a lot thicker,' says one of his intimates. 'His ability to differentiate between the important and the pressing has improved. I think he's clearer what it's all about.'

Some aspects of Blair have become more pronounced by office. 'Never forget he's a lawyer,' remarks another close aide, adding that the Prime Minister displays both sides of the legal temperament. Blair is the rapid master of a brief. Staff at Number 10 have been confounded by the time he has devoted to grappling with the minutiae of foot and mouth. He can also display a lawyer's slipperiness, skating to the edge of mendacity, and occasionally beyond it, as a refuge from uncomfortable truths.

Like his grandparents, Jimmy Lynton and Celia Ridgway, he is an actor: the consummate political actor of his era. Like them, he can play both music hall and straight drama, he can do soap TV and the ceremony of state. He surfed the sea of emoting which followed the death of Diana, still the most vivid demonstration of an intuitive grasp of what the majority want to hear coupled with a thespian ability to turn it into a performance which will be applauded. Four years of familiarity with the act has inevitably left much of the audience more contemptuous. He was humiliatingly handbagged by the massed motherlode of the Women's Institute. Yet there is still no other politician that comes close to matching his talent for the actorly aspect of politics.

In common with most thespians, he is a worrier. At times of heavy stress and frustration, his nervous energy nukes into what a Blairite Minister dubs 'Tony's meltdown moments'. Each weekend, his courtiers wait for their fax machines to spew forth the rolls of hand-written anxieties that are fretting the leader. His personal assistant, Anji Hunter, says she is alerted to the fax's arrival by her husband shouting: 'Here comes your Sunday night stream of consciousness.' Blair can spend hours agonising over every angle of a single detail of a quite obscure policy. Staff refer to 'Tony's circular discussions'. Though they are reluctant to admit it, he is as obsessive as ever about the media. As the stream of leaked memos last year helped confirm, the most image-neurotic member of the regime is the leader himself. He invented the phrase 'governing by headline', and has yet to fully grasp that it is not only undesirable but any way impossible. One Labour strategist is often in the room when it happens: ' Sky News will be on. Tony will see something he doesn't like and shout at Alastair, "Stop it!" The complaint is always the same: "Why aren't we getting our message across?"'

The surest indicator of the imminence of the election is the newspaper commentators, editors and proprietors - ah, there goes Rupert Murdoch - streaming in for audiences at Number 10. Some of the product of those chats visible in the press suggests that each visitor is hearing what is most likely to please them. Blair likes to be liked. The promiscuous politics of the 'Big Tent' is an extension of a character as much as it is a tactic to maximise support. I think there is only one member of the Cabinet who harbours really deep enmity towards this Prime Minister. That is an unusually low hate rating for a leader, and to be contrasted with the high levels of fear and loathing a lot of Ministers radiate towards the Chancellor.

Blair has always invested great faith in his ability to talk his way through dilemmas, out of trouble or into alliances. He returned from his first meeting with the Russian leader, Vladimir Putin, fizzing to aides: 'I've really made a connection.' It is a talent that he also employs cynically. Characters as diverse as Paddy Ashdown, Gordon Brown and Frank Field have been in receipt of promises from Blair which turned out to be much flakier than he had led them to expect.

'Tony thinks he can conquer the world with charm,' says a senior politician with close-up and personal experience of the technique. And he tends to be at his most querulous when he encounters problems and personalities that are impregnable to this technique. A persistent source of frustration is the lack of a reliable claque of press cheerleaders. 'There are no New Labour papers,' is a complaint as bitter as it has been regular throughout his time as Prime Minister.

Insecurity is a common feature of the family backgrounds of both Blair and his wife. It finds creative expression in his drive, focus and impatience to see results. A less attractive manifestation is an exaggerated respect for wealth, bordering on an infatuation with money. He wistfully remarked to a recent interviewer that a university chum he used 'to do discos with' was 'now worth millions'. The most surprising, and least appetising, aspect of his character exposed by office is an ethical blind-spot. Geoffrey Robinson is not the only multi-millionaire of spotty provenance to whom Blair placed himself in hock with the result that the Government is put in the dock. One of his worst meltdown moments was at the time of the Ecclestone Affair when Blair despaired to one of his closest familiars: 'This is the end. They'll get me for this.' Rather than learn from that searing lesson early in his premiership, he has allowed mudslides of sleaze to tarnish the Government, mocking the pledge to be 'purer than pure'. I was recently discussing with a senior member of the Cabinet what could erupt to harm the Government during the election campaign. Unprompted, high up on his list he volunteered 'scandal'.

In such a centralised regime, it is inevitable that Blair's personal phobias have been decisive in shaping the Government. He wondered aloud whether 'the experiences in the Eighties almost scarred me too much' after his paranoia about losing control led him into disastrously counter-productive attempts to fix devolution in Wales and London. The worst crises of the regime - the double sackings of Mandelson, the turbulent love-loathe relationship with Gordon Brown - have been generated by the emotionally fraught relationships between New Labour's founding figures.

Confronted by an external challenge, Blair usually impresses. He tends to be at his strongest in an emergency when there is no time - or it is too late - to panic. An extremely senior civil servant compares him to Margaret Thatcher in the way in which he 'throws himself' at crises. The highly exposed position he took during the war for Kosovo threatened, so he believed as did many close to him, to cost him the premiership. When aides and officials urged him not to screw his reputation to the pledge to expel the Serbs, Blair replied that he knew 'this could be the end of me', but it was 'shit or bust'. Without the instrumental role played by Britain's Christian soldier, Milosevic would still be in power today, and Kosovo would be ethnically cleansed. Clare Short, who for a long time harboured a fairly poisonous opinion of Blair, was won over to him on the simple grounds: 'He did the right thing.'

And he did the same in Northern Ireland. George Mitchell, the former American senator, is our most objective witness. He has no doubt that Blair's decision to hurl himself into the negotiations to save them from implosion was both brave and critical to the successful outcome. He was about to become the first Labour Prime Minister in 18 years, enthroned at the apex of the majority greater than for any party in more than six decades. Still only 43, he would be the youngest occupant of Number 10 since Lord Liverpool in 1812. And to no one was this sensational prospect more awesome than Blair himself. As the plane sped to London, his wife grasped his hand and chatted excitedly about his 'great opportunity'. To Cherie, Tony replied: 'But I've never been in government.' With Leo, his father, he shared similar trepidations. 'Realising that you are about to be Prime Minister is a very strange moment,' Blair reflected later. 'My dad was fabulous. He had managed nothing except a hungry, skilful Opposition against an exhausted Tory Government with a death-wish. He had never seen the inside of a red box, nor given instructions to a civil servant. He had not even been a Parliamentary Private Secretary, lowest form of life on the Ministerial food chain. As the honeymoon has steadily deflated, he has been flayed as an opportunist, an autocrat, a betrayer, a manipulator and a charlatan. fields.headline: We'll get to Britain whatever it takes
fields.standfirst:
They have no vote. But now they're at the heart of Britain's political debate. Jason Burke travels to the grim people-warehouse near Calais to find what really drives the people desperate to come to this country

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: They have no vote. But now they're at the heart of Britain's political debate. Jason Burke travels to the grim people-warehouse near Calais to find what really drives the people desperate to come to this country.
fields.body:
A cold, driving rain whips in across the fields. In the distance, the lights of Calais flicker wetly in the dusk. The roads, the ploughed earth and the thin strip of sea merge into a monotone slate grey and finally disappear into the gloom. It is nearly nine o'clock. By the roadside, Mohammed Ishaq, his wife and four children are waiting.

Tonight, like every night for the past two weeks, the six of them will be picked up and driven to the Eurostar terminal a mile or so away. They will, as they did last night and the night before, try to slip under the wire, crawl through the fencing, drop from bridges, secrete themselves in freight containers, hang from truck axles.

It is four months since they left their home in Afghanistan. They will do whatever it takes to make their way to Britain. They will keep trying, Mohammed Ishaq says, until they succeed.

A Mercedes pulls up, the family get in and are driven off. The car's headlights slice through the rain to reveal six Kosovan men walking in file along the road, two Iranians wrapped in bin-liners scrambling behind them, a dozen Kurds in a ragged cluster of soaked shell-suits and trainers, two Pakistanis picking their way between the puddles.

According to Claude Devos, 53, who runs Le Weekend bar on Sangatte's main street, these are not refugees, or economic migrants, or bogus asylum-seekers, or the poor and huddled masses. These are the advance guard of an invasion.

As the rain hammers against his bar's windows, he thumps a fist on his counter and makes his point again. 'It is absolutely like the Romans and the Gauls,' he says. 'This is the first wave of the army of Islam and we are being conquered. I am not a racist, I am not a political man, but I know I am speaking the truth.' Around the dim bar his clients nod, and tip their glasses in agreement.

Such rhetoric is not rare in western Europe. Interpol estimates that more than half a million people illegally entered the EU last year, up from 40,000 in 1993. A tabloid newspaper describes Sangatte as the 'village from hell', a 'war zone' where thousands of 'marauding' asylum-seekers wreak 'mayhem' before sneaking into Britain. Though John Townend MP received a slap on the wrist from Tory leader William Hague when he said mass immigration would turn Britain into a 'mongrel' race, no one doubts that his views are shared by many. With 75,000 people applying in the UK last year, everyone knows that asylum and immigration will be a key issue in the election.

Last week Tony Blair himself, aware that Labour is seen as weak on the issue, launched a counter-offensive. Writing in the Times, he said that the 1951 Geneva Convention that underpins the European asylum system should be mod ernised, and stressed that Labour's criticism of the Conservatives had been about 'opportunism', not racism.

The problem is that the arguments on all sides of the debate are founded on myths and prejudices that bear little resemblance to reality.

Just outside Sangatte is a huge steel warehouse where the Red Cross, on behalf of the French government, provides food, showers, toilets and beds for between 300 and 1,000 asylum-seekers. It was set up 18 months ago, when local authorities grew tired of the hordes sleeping rough in the village. Right-wing British politicians claim it is a waiting room for people attempting to enter the UK. And it is.

'If I don't see my friend the next morning, that means one of three things - he's made it across, the police have him, or something bad has happened,' said Zakar, a 26-year-old Chechen who has spent two weeks at the Red Cross centre. So far 26,000 people are estimated to have used the facility. Almost all are now in the UK. Last week there were about 300 there.

Before Eurotunnel invested £2 million in extra security and the ferry companies started testing for exhaled breath in lorry containers, most people used to spend only a few days at the centre. Now they spend several weeks. But they usually get to the UK in the end. But who are these people? Are they asylum-seekers? Are they 'bogus' economic migrants, refugees? Do any of these terms mean anything? Speak to any of those hanging around Sangatte and you get the same stories.

Few talk about persecution. Most talk about the sheer awfulness of their lives, a future which makes selling everything they had and entrusting their money and lives to criminals the best option. Mohammed Ishaq and his family are typical. They are Tajik Afghans, and thus from a minority who are discriminated against by the Taliban. But Ishaq does not mention persecution when he explains his flight. 'There are no schools in Kabul,' he says. 'There is no money. We were hungry and cold all the time. I wanted something better for my children.'

Ishaq sold his shop to raise the $9,000 (£6,400) 'fare' to England. He first travelled to Karachi, where a middleman took his cash and hid him and his family in the truck which took them through Iran and Turkey. That was in January. Now he has no money left.

'Going back is impossible, Everywhere there are problems,' he told The Observer .

By most definitions Ishaq is an economic migrant. If, when he arrives in Britain, he claims that he was 'persecuted' in Afghanistan, he will be a 'bogus' asylum-seeker.

The same can be said for many, if not most, of those in the Red Cross shelter. They do not claim to be fleeing an immediate threat of torture or imprisonment. Instead they are following the inexorable logic that determines today's immigration flows - 'they have very little; we have a lot'. Only a tiny minority are running from electrodes or helicopter gunships.

And Britain is seen as a 'soft touch'. Though some, especially from Pakistan and India, are drawn by affinities traceable to the days of Empire, many are not. Few at Sangatte speak English. Ishaq speaks only Urdu and Farsi. But he knows that in Germany asylum-seekers only get medical treatment in extreme cases, that in France identity cards make life as an 'illegal' difficult, and that in the UK financial aid for asylum-seekers is more generous then elsewhere.

But few of the myths of the Right stand up to scrutiny either. According to Devos the men who hang around outside his shop are ill-educated religious zealots. But in fact many of those in Sangatte are from monied, middle-class, literate backgrounds. They are intelligent and civil in every sense of the word. One young Afghan, from a family of businessmen, told The Observer he had sold his land to raise the $10,000 demanded by his trafficker. Many others are graduates.

'Engineers, doctors, professors, jurists, the amount of grey matter coming through here is impressive,' Michel Derr, director of the Sangatte camp, said recently.

Nor are the immigrants lazy, as many commentators would have us believe. As The Observer revealed last week, a survey by Exeter university found that most new arrivals in the UK are highly motivated and prepared to work hard for little money. Cheap labour is not their only use. By some estimates, Europe will need 75 million new workers to replenish its ageing 350 million population. The Government has admitted that Britain suffers a 'skills gap'.

Nor, despite the lurid picture painted in some British newspapers, is Sangatte a 'war zone'. There was very little 'marauding' - as one paper described it - going on last week. Devos proudly showed the cattle prod and pistol he keeps behind his till. But last week, all was quiet. Yet the atmosphere is as heavy as the rain-sodden fields that the clandestins cross each night on their way to the terminals. The young men set out from the Sangatte camp like conscripts heading into battle. They know the most dangerous part of their journey is still to come.

There have been scores killed on the lorries and the railways. Last month four Poles risked a hideous death clinging to the outside of a ferry. One man died after running out in front of a train in a bid to slow it down so his friends could clamber aboard. 'We don't know how many are hurt,' said Zakar, a 21-year-old Chechen. 'We never hear any news. If we don't see them again we just know they either made it or they are dead. That's all we want to know.'

'If I don't see my friend the next morning, that means one of three things - he's made it across, the police have him, or something bad has happened,' said Zakar, a 26-year-old Chechen who has spent two weeks at the Red Cross centre. So far 26,000 people are estimated to have used the facility. Almost all are now in the UK. Last week there were about 300 there. Before Eurotunnel invested £2 million in extra security and the ferry companies started testing for exhaled breath in lorry containers, most people used to spend only a few days at the centre. Now they spend several weeks. But they usually get to the UK in the end. But who are these people? Are they asylum-seekers? Are they 'bogus' economic migrants, refugees? Do any of these terms mean anything? Speak to any of those hanging around Sangatte and you get the same stories. Few talk about persecution. Most talk about the sheer awfulness of their lives, a future which makes selling everything they had and entrusting their money and lives to criminals the best option. Mohammed Ishaq and his family are typical. They are Tajik Afghans, and thus from a minority who are discriminated against by the Taliban. But Ishaq does not mention persecution when he explains his flight. 'There are no schools in Kabul,' he says. 'There is no money. We were hungry and cold all the time. I wanted something better for my children.' Ishaq sold his shop to raise the $9,000 (£6,400) 'fare' to England. He first travelled to Karachi, where a middleman took his cash and hid him and his family in the truck which took them through Iran and Turkey. That was in January. Now he has no money left. 'Going back is impossible, Everywhere there are problems,' he told The Observer . By most definitions Ishaq is an economic migrant. If, when he arrives in Britain, he claims that he was 'persecuted' in Afghanistan, he will be a 'bogus' asylum-seeker. The same can be said for many, if not most, of those in the Red Cross shelter. They do not claim to be fleeing an immediate threat of torture or imprisonment. Instead they are following the inexorable logic that determines today's immigration flows - 'they have very little; we have a lot'. Only a tiny minority are running from electrodes or helicopter gunships. And Britain is seen as a 'soft touch'. Though some, especially from Pakistan and India, are drawn by affinities traceable to the days of Empire, many are not. Few at Sangatte speak English. Ishaq speaks only Urdu and Farsi. But he knows that in Germany asylum-seekers only get medical treatment in extreme cases, that in France identity cards make life as an 'illegal' difficult, and that in the UK financial aid for asylum-seekers is more generous then elsewhere. But few of the myths of the Right stand up to scrutiny either. According to Devos the men who hang around outside his shop are ill-educated religious zealots. But in fact many of those in Sangatte are from monied, middle-class, literate backgrounds. They are intelligent and civil in every sense of the word. One young Afghan, from a family of businessmen, told The Observer he had sold his land to raise the $10,000 demanded by his trafficker. Many others are graduates. 'Engineers, doctors, professors, jurists, the amount of grey matter coming through here is impressive,' Michel Derr, director of the Sangatte camp, said recently. Nor are the immigrants lazy, as many commentators would have us believe. As The Observer revealed last week, a survey by Exeter university found that most new arrivals in the UK are highly motivated and prepared to work hard for little money. Cheap labour is not their only use. By some estimates, Europe will need 75 million new workers to replenish its ageing 350 million population. The Government has admitted that Britain suffers a 'skills gap'. Nor, despite the lurid picture painted in some British newspapers, is Sangatte a 'war zone'. There was very little 'marauding' - as one paper described it - going on last week. Devos proudly showed the cattle prod and pistol he keeps behind his till. But last week, all was quiet. Yet the atmosphere is as heavy as the rain-sodden fields that the clandestins cross each night on their way to the terminals. The young men set out from the Sangatte camp like conscripts heading into battle. They know the most dangerous part of their journey is still to come. There have been scores killed on the lorries and the railways. Last month four Poles risked a hideous death clinging to the outside of a ferry. One man died after running out in front of a train in a bid to slow it down so his friends could clamber aboard. 'We don't know how many are hurt,' said Zakar, a 21-year-old Chechen. 'We never hear any news. If we don't see them again we just know they either made it or they are dead. That's all we want to know.'

webTitle: FA attempts to save Wembley with bid for 2012 Olympics

fields.headline: FA attempts to save Wembley with bid for 2012 Olympics
fields.standfirst:
Original plan for an athletics stadium to be used to attract government money

Observer Wembley special report

National stadium online debate: have your say
fields.trailText: The FA is proposing a return to the original plan for an athletics stadium to be used to attract government money
fields.byline: Kevin Mitchell, Nick Mathiason and Kamal Ahmed
fields.body:
Wembley Stadium should be rebuilt as a multi-million pound football and athletics arena, which would become the centrepiece for a British bid for the Olympics in 2012, according to senior footballing sources behind the project.

The new national stadium would be backed by both the Football Association and the Government and would be the leading element of a bid supported by the Prime Minister and centred on various locations around London.

The Government is known to be interested in backing a London bid for the Games after the general election, although so far it has concentrated on developing plans for a new stadium in the east of the capital.

The Mayor, Ken Livingstone, also backs that option, arguing that building it in the less affluent East End means that it would be able to bring in extra European regeneration money.

But Adam Crozier, the chief executive of the FA, believes that the formula based around Wembley would prevent the Government being faced with the embarrassment of the bulldozers moving on to the site and no new national stadium rising in its place.

Crozier has told Home Secretary Jack Straw, who has been put in charge of rescuing the failed Wembley plans, that the move could help resolve the fiasco surrounding the development, which descended into farce last week when the FA conceded that it had failed to persuade City banks to stump up the £660 million needed for the project.

The Government has so far refused to put any of its own money into the new Wembley project, saying that football is rich enough to fund its own national stadium.

Creating a new national stadium suitable for athletics as part of an Olympic bid would allow the Government to underwrite Wembley arguing that it is a truly national project.

The FA is now prepared to contribute £100m to the cost of the development. With a Lottery grant of £120m already secured, the project would have a funding gap of £380m plus interest. The Government would probably take the lion's share of this, with City institutions taking on the remainder.

Plans for a new Wembley will include a running track, which the Culture Secretary, Chris Smith, originally excluded from the doomed project. He acted after coming under pressure from Ken Bates, the former head of the Wembley plans, who later resigned.

The FA knows that it will have a tough time convincing the Government that an Olympic bid for Wembley is the best way forward. It would jeopardise the development of the athletics stadium at Pickett's Lock, north London, which will be the venue for the world championships of 2005.

Official sources said that the Government was unwilling to give public money to the Wembley project. It would prefer a scaled down project that had fewer conference and hotel facilities based around an 80,000 seater stadium, which would only be used for football and rugby league.

Crozier admitted that mistakes had been made in the planning for Wembley but said that it was now time to 'move forward'.

He said: 'The truth is that everyone needs to hold their hands up and say that they made mistakes. Right back to the decisions that were made five or six years ago. This isn't about what's happened in the last few months. This is a result of decisions taken over a long period of time.'

Crozier said the Government would be able to buy into the new project for a few years and then sell their stake, possibly at a profit.

The FA also wants the Government, or the agency Sport England, to buy up 44 acres next to the stadium, which could be used for commercial projects.

webTitle: Foot and mouth fears grow

fields.headline: Foot and mouth fears grow over meat smuggling
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Illegal consignments of meat potentially infected with the foot and mouth virus are still being smuggled into Britain and could spark a new outbreak of the disease.
fields.body:
Illegal consignments of meat potentially infected with the foot and mouth virus are still being smuggled into Britain and could spark a new outbreak of the disease.

Customs raids on three aircraft at Heathrow Airport last week found more than half a tonne of meat in personal baggage from Nigeria, Ghana and China. All of those countries have endemic foot and mouth and illegally imported meat from the Far East is seen as the most likely source of the current epidemic.

The seized meat, known as 'bush meat', consisted of antelope, monkey, dried fish and other unidentifiable pieces. Foot and mouth can survive for six months in dried meat and officials believe the amount arriving in Britain is at least 10 times greater than what is detected at airports.

The revelations will come as an embarrassment to the Government after a week in which it declared the epidemic had been virtually brought under control. Experts warn that the massive influx of illegal meat, thought to total more than 1,000 tonnes a year, could seriously undermine the slaughter programme that has seen the flow of new cases of the virus slow to under 10 a day.

'A fresh consignment of this meat could start a new outbreak. That could happen at any time. At the same time as we are controlling the current problem, we are not doing anything to stop what may have caused it in the first place,' said Professor Joe Brownlie of the Royal Veterinary College.

Last Sunday, airport offi cials took 444kg of meat off flights from Ghana and China after searching each passenger passing through Customs. 'We only get a tiny percentage of what is coming in, and most of it is coming from areas that are considered dangerous for foot and mouth and other viruses,' said Clive Lawrance, head of Ciel Logistics, a firm that oversees the importation of perishable goods at Heathrow.

Lawrance said one bag of chicken parts confiscated on the Nigerian flight was almost completely rotten. 'It was green and smelt awful.'

Most of the meat is destined for private use or for ethnic restaurants. The trade could be worth £7 million a year.

Lawrance believes it operates with the collusion of corrupt airline officials and that most passengers carrying meat are used as 'mules' to deliver it in Britain.

Raids at Heathrow hit Ghana Airways flight 770 on 4, 12 and 15 April. On each occasion, large amounts of illegal meat were uncovered. The total haul, much of it rancid and bloody, was 698kg. Six bags of meat were also discovered abandoned by their owners in the arrivals lounge, where some of the blood had leaked on to the floor, which could be a potential source of contamination. There have been calls for Britain to adopt a regime more like that in New Zealand, where X-ray machines and sniffer dogs search for imported meat. New Zealand has never had a foot and mouth outbreak.

 Additional reporting: Brian Johnson-Thomas

webTitle: Ramblers angry as footpaths stay closed

fields.headline: Ramblers angry as footpaths stay closed
fields.standfirst:
 250,000 jobs and 3,000 businesses at risk from foot and mouth crisis
 £99 return air tickets from US forecast to boost ailing tourism
 Animal sanctuary resists cull

Special report: foot and mouth
The countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: Ramblers yesterday accused local authorities of dragging their heels over the reopening of thousands of miles of footpaths closed by the foot and mouth crisis as people headed to the country and seaside for the May bank holiday.
fields.byline: Nick Paton Walsh and Joanna Walters
fields.body:
Ramblers yesterday accused local authorities of dragging their heels over the reopening of thousands of miles of footpaths closed by the foot and mouth crisis as people headed to the country and seaside for the May bank holiday.

Only around one in five footpaths was open yesterday, causing a knock-on effect for many businesses. The Ramblers Association said areas where paths were not being reopened fast enough included Lincolnshire, North Yorkshire, Buckinghamshire, Lancashire and Durham.

Kate Ashbrook, the association's chairwoman, said: 'If not all the paths are open, it's not easy for people to find out which ones are open and people just don't go to the countryside at all. There is no excuse, particularly outside infected areas, for county councils not opening these footpaths.'

She accused councils of 'giving farmers a veto' over the reopening of paths where there was no foot and mouth risk. The Government has issued clear guidelines as to what local authorities can do and none of them is doing it and certainly not at the rate the Government expects.'

As weather forecasters predicted Mediterranean temperatures in many areas, the English Tourism Council said only 14 per cent of Britons planned a short break this month. It added that 3,000 businesses and 250,000 jobs were at risk if the Government did not award foot and mouth compensation immediately.

Consumers could, however, soon benefit from the crisis. Return air fares to the United States could plummet to as little as £99 this month as airlines fight to fill planes left half empty by Americans scared away from Britain by foot and mouth disease.

Tickets have already fallen below £200 after a dramatic fall in bookings, and travel agents predict they will collapse further within days in a price 'bloodbath'. Andrew Boyle of the Co-op's Travel care travel agency chain, said: 'We have not seen the airlines really panic yet, but I suspect someone will soon. All the others will join in within 24 hours.

Americans in particular have shied away from coming now or booking for the summer since the outbreak of the disease, causing a crisis for the tourism industry as well as for farmers. Air bookings from the US for June are said to be 40 per cent down.

Protesters yesterday continued their vigil against the cull that has so far slaughtered 2.43 million animals - according to the last Maff count, killed at the average rate of 42,000 a day. At the Mossburn Animal Centre, a refuge for rescued animals in Hightae, Dumfries and Galloway, more than 30 activists vowed to maintain a human shield around the sanctuary, which holds 14 goats, 15 pigs, four cattle and three sheep.

'The animals will be kept by us in a secure area - we will not let them die,' said Amanda Richards, 27, a spokesperson for The Group Against Sanctuary Killings. 'There is no evidence they are infected. The last outbreak was six weeks ago. They have all tested negative since then. The slaughtermen may come today, or maybe next week; either way there will be someone here to meet them.'

Yesterday, Maff officials battled to contain the disease on Exmoor. Vets visited a 1,500-head beef farm near Dulverton in an urgent operation to limit an outbreak around the Somerset village of Wiveliscombe, near Taunton, where four cases have been confirmed in the past three days. Exmoor has so far escaped the culls, and restrictions were due to be lifted there at the start of the week.

To the delight of crowds at Bristol Zoo, Wendy, a 41-year- old Asian elephant, left the enclosure she has been confined to for the past three months for the first time.

Thousands of people yesterday flocked to the Sussex coast for the start of the annual Brighton Festival. Schools each picked a theme and pupils donned colourful fancy dress costumes for the opening parade of the three-week festival, with buddhas, dragons and samba bands popular.

A Bournemouth tourist information centre spokeswoman said the town and seafront were packed 'We are much busier than the Easter bank holiday weekend.'

webTitle: Spy says McGuinness did not fire on Bloody Sunday

fields.headline: Spy says McGuinness did not fire on Bloody Sunday
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the Bloody Sunday inquiry
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: A key IRA informer, in hiding for nearly 20 years, will risk his life to tell the Bloody Sunday inquiry that former IRA commander Martin McGuinness did not fire any shots on the day of the fateful civil rights march that ended in the deaths of 14 civilians.
fields.body:
A key IRA informer, in hiding for nearly 20 years, will risk his life to tell the Bloody Sunday inquiry that former IRA commander Martin McGuinness did not fire any shots on the day of the fateful civil rights march that ended in the deaths of 14 civilians.

Speaking last week from a secret location in Britain, Willie Carlin, a former British soldier who spent more than 10 years with McGuinness and the republican terrorist movement, told The Observer that he will defy an IRA death sentence to return to his home town of Derry.

He will tell the Saville inquiry investigating the events of Bloody Sunday that allegations that McGuinness opened fire on British troops deployed against Roman Catholic demonstrators in the city in January 1972 are bogus. The British authorities at the time claimed that soldiers from the Parachute Regiment only opened fire on the demonstrators after being shot at themselves.
