webTitle: In God they trust

fields.headline: In God they trust
fields.standfirst:
While Blair and Hague court the religious vote, they should be praying the rest of us will turn out

Special report: Labour party
Special report: Conservative party
Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: May 6, Nick Cohen: While Blair and Hague court the religious vote, they should be praying the rest of us will turn out.
fields.body:
My many friends in New Labour have urged me for years to ridicule William Hague by reporting his opportunist conversion to evangelical Christianity. Now that he is wailing about the tempora and the mores, it is easy to forget that he won the Conservative leadership in 1997 by posing as a man who might outmodernise Tony Blair. He did not then see Britain as a 'foreign land' but was content to allow his fellow citizens to find their own paths to what limited happiness was on offer.

The age of consent for homosexuals should be lowered to 16, he said, and gays should be allowed to marry. ('When they're not causing harm to other people, why should we object?') The single mothers his party had hounded in office should be cherished. ('It is better for a child to have one happy parent who cares and loves him or her than to have two and suffer from domestic violence.') Hague went to the Notting Hill Carnival in shorts and baseball cap and although he looked the saddest white rasta in town that day, his desire to show a faint solidarity with black Britons was worthy.

Many of his followers were mortified. 'Why do I share a party with those who advocate sodomite marriage?' cried Norman Tebbit as his treacherous leader abandoned bigotry. Tim Montgomerie, the director of the Conservative Christian Fellowship, warned Hague that sleeping in the same bed as Ffion Jenkins before they had been united in Holy Matrimony violated 'the Christian ideal'. Only by remaining the guardian of the 'Judaeo-Christian' tradition, he added, could the leader 'attract many Christians and others of traditional belief into the activist-hungry Tory party'.

Three years on, and Hague had undergone a conversion as profound as Constantine's. In a scene beyond satire, he addressed 8,000 ecstatic evangelicals who gathered to bother God in the Butlins camp at Minehead last year. His flirtation with homosexual rights was a schoolboy phase. He had, it transpired, been opposed to repealing Clause 28 long 'before the issue became newsworthy'. He went on to offer the righteous a deal. If they voted Conservative, he would allow religious broadcasters to catch the souls and money of viewers and listeners. 'With so much material on television no parents would want their children to see, we must give a full opportunity for Christians to put forward exciting and wholesome alternatives. The next Conservative government will ensure that Christians have the same right to national and digital licences as anyone else.'

Labour's PRs were ecstatic. Hague was admitting his weakness. He had noted that the average Tory activist was a pensioner, who was not likely, what with the lumbago and shortness of breath, to be particularly active. The Conservative leadership had been forced to take Tim Montgomerie's complaints seriously, and was wooing the energetically religious. If the price of their support was abandoning tolerance and bringing tele-evangelism to Britain, Hague would pay it.

I was disconcerted to hear condemnations of apostasy fall from the lips of Tony Blair's followers. But you can't knock New Labour every week and I wrote about the Conservative Party's sinister links with the religious fundamentalists around the American Republicans. I would happily do so again, were it not for a press release dated 3 May from Janet Anderson, the Labour Broadcasting Minister. Representatives of every mainstream religion - Christian, Jewish, Hindu, Muslim, Sikh - had met her to discuss 'whether the restrictions on ownership of national broadcasting licences by religious bodies should now be relaxed due to the greater opportunities the digital age will offer,' she said. They had received a sympathetic hearing.

The porn baron, Richard Desmond, whose websites feature Grace, a 79-year-old woman, who masturbates for the delight of the audience and asks: 'Would you like a pair of my wet panties?', is allowed to own the Daily Express (and has been courted by the Godly Hague and Blair). Rupert Murdoch is allowed to own just about everything else.

Britain's media law is hardly fastidious. Tele-evangelists may exploit the terrors of the credulous, but it's hard to argue that the Universal Church of the Kingdom of God, which owns Liberty Radio, and whose teaching that the sick are possessed by demons may have led to the horrible death of Anna Climbie last year, is more pernicious than, say, the News of the World .

The Government's U-turn on religious broadcasting would matter less were it not part of a paradoxical pattern. Britain is one of the most profane societies on Earth - thank God. Yet as faith collapses, sectarians are elevated.

You always get you into trouble when you quote statistics on worship. The devout emphasise the numbers who tick boxes in hospitals or on the census form which mark them as Anglican or whatever and talk up evidence of general spiritual yearnings. Atheists can't see how you can be a conforming Christian unless you go to church. The last issue of Religious Trends , published by Christian Research, said that a mere 7 per cent of the population attends church on the average Sunday. Its editor, Dr Peter Brierley, admitted: 'All claims that Britain is a Christian nation will finally have to be given up.' Judaism is disappearing. Despite the relatively recent arrival of black Pentecostal churches, mosques and Hindu and Sikh temples, the British Social Attitudes Survey reports that the number of respondents saying they had no religion rose from 31 per cent in 1983 to 45 per cent in 1998.

For all their unpopularity, the Government is more than happy for one third of schools to be controlled by religious organisations and only the National Secular Society complains about the humiliations which follow.

Parents, it points out, debase themselves to get a child into a school which may be a few yards from their home and whose costs are paid for by their taxes. They have to protest convictions they don't have. They must attend church to worship gods they don't believe exist, and stand by while priests decide on the future of their children's education. Teachers, too, are caught. If they don't have or can't fake piety, they can be excluded from jobs in thousands of schools.

The prisons are going the same way. Religious charities and chaplains control inmates more completely than denominational schools control children. The results are often outrageous - the National Secular Society has letters from prisoners who have been denied parole for refusing to pray - but occasionally hilarious. The Home Office allowed one religious outfit, the Kairos Trust, to take over wings in four prisons. Its director, Kenner Jones, may soon be getting closer to his charges. He was convicted of embezzling funds recently and faces a custodial sentence.

The same Millbankers who implored me to have a go at the Tories, were eager to tell me about Marvin Olasky. I and other leftish hacks were more than happy to listen. Hague had invited George W. Bush's religious adviser to Britain and the man looked like a dangerous fruitcake. He didn't want to vote for women if he could possibly help it, and preached that public services and money should be given to churches.

In March, almost a year to the day after Olasky's visit to London was mocked by all good Blairites, the Prime Minister told religious charities that he had put 'misguided and outdated' principles on the need to separate church and state behind him. He now wanted the faithful to take over care for the sick, homeless, young and incarcerated. There is a fair chance that they will become part of a captive audience. Their punishment will not only include poverty or the deprivation of liberty, but being forced to nod along to dogmas most of the rest of society rejects.

The best explanation for the phenomenon of rulers embracing faith their subjects did not share was given by Edward Gibbon. When he wondered why Constantine had made Christianity the official religion of the late Roman Empire, he wrote that the Emperor found it politic to convert because: 'In the beginning of the fourth century, the Christians still bore a very inadequate proportion to the inhabitants of the empire; but among a degenerate people, who viewed the change of masters with the indifference of slaves, the spirit and union of a religious party might assist the popular leader, to whose service from a principle of confidence, they had devoted their lives and fortunes.'

The election will reveal the indifference of the public to its masters. Participation will be the lowest ever. The triangulating of the parties and their utter cynicism may well persuade a third of adults not to waste their time in the polling booths. In these circumstances professional politicians need enthusiasts to fill the emptying ranks of committed supporters. As a Conservative spin doctor at Butlins put it: 'The evangelical vote could be vital in a general election with a low turnout.'

webTitle: Death is now the only certainty

fields.headline: Death is now the only certainty
fields.standfirst: While President Bush is in the White House, the world's devotees of tax havens will still be laughing all the way to the bank
fields.trailText: May 6, Will Hutton: While President Bush is in the White House, the world's devotees of tax havens will still be laughing all the way to the bank.
fields.body:
The British and the other Europeans still don't understand. The United States has changed. Its political centre of gravity has moved away from the two liberal seaboards to the extraordinarily conservative South and Wild West, which want no truck with the outside world unless wholly on their terms. Since the Sixties, American conservatives have waged war on liberalism in any guise with an almost Leninist zeal and have now captured the American state. They intend to make victory pay.

Thus the calming official voices who argue that all incoming American administrations have teething problems with their allies and that normal relations will be established as they have before need to be disabused. Bush and those behind him intend to alter the US and the international system for good.

So the spectacle a few days ago of some hundred conservative policy-wonks, administration officials and key aides of Republican leaders of the Senate and House of Representatives crowding into what seems ,at first sight, an obscure seminar on 'tax competition' at the Heritage Foundation, one of the ringleader conservative think-tanks, is not to be shrugged off as something going on in a far-off land. It will affect us all.

US conservatives, opposed to international treaties to limit climate change, criminality and the proliferation of nuclear weapons, have another target in their sights. They want to preserve tax havens and the apparatus that supports global tax avoidance - and in truth, evasion - in the name of promoting the minimal state, 'tax competition' and 'financial privacy'. They intend to wage war against the 'international tax police' in the form of the Paris-based government club of economic forecasters, the OECD, which is working towards an agreement obliging tax havens to be more open about who is avoiding what tax in their jurisdiction. Between now and July, when the OECD is set to publish a list of rogue tax havens which will be the subject of potential trade sanctions for not co-operating, the American Right wants to wreck the initiative and is putting intense pressure on the Bush administration to pull out.

Tax havens have become indispensable instruments in the construction of a very particular global business civilisation whose ideology has it that government is illegitimate and tax avoidance is not merely an useful business ploy, but a moral imperative in order to avoid hard- earned profits being squandered by the state on welfare spending. Messrs Berlusconi and Murdoch, for example, could not have built their empires without the capacity to house their businesses and profits in offshore havens. Both see tax avoidance as the proper responsibility of any international citizen.

They are merely the most conspicuous representatives of a far broader culture. Hardly any of the Fortune 500 companies in the US and FTSE 100 companies in Britain pay remotely appropriate levels of tax given their profitability. One-third of global GDP is estimated to be directed through tax havens. Every Western industrialised country is suffering from falling tax yields from wealthy individuals and corporations as they move offshore, so displacing more tax on to average and below average earners to compensate, fuelling the growing mood that tax is too high.

The growth of the Mafia, organised crime and the drug cartels would be impossible without the capacity to shelter their profits offshore. Every African despot has salted billions away in tax havens. They are not good news.

Except in the eyes of American conservatives. Gone are the days when the American Right concentrated on making an economic case against taxation as a disincentive. The argument is still deployed, but it is now secondary to the larger proposition. All state activity diminishes the liberty of the individual; all wealth is the result of individual effort. Therefore, taxation is pernicious. It confiscates wealth that properly belong to individuals. It intrudes into our financial privacy to calculate what is due, only to finance state action that diminishes liberty and, if spent on welfare, education or health, undermines the incentive to take responsibility for ourselves. It is to be opposed to the last.

Lawrence Lindsey, Bush's national economic adviser, is a staunch advocate of financial privacy. Dick Armey, House majority leader, characterises the OECD as part of a 'a global network of tax police'. Senator Don Nickles, the assistant majority leader in the Senate, wants a reversal of an agreement that will infringe American sovereignty waged by high-tax, high-welfare Europe against low-tax countries. Even the Democrats' black caucus has joined in, seeing implicit racism in the way so many Caribbean islands have been identified as tax havens. Add in the right-wing think-tanks thundering away along with every right-wing columnist and the atmosphere is pretty feverish.

The Treasury and OECD cling to the notion that rationality will prevail, that the aim is not to prevent tax competition between countries but unfair tax competition, and that information-swapping and transparency about tax affairs - the heart of the OECD's efforts - are hardly menacing. They don't get it. There isn't a single authoritative voice in the US speaking up for the idea that taxation is a citizen's downpayment for membership of the community, that wealth creation has social as well as entrepreneurial roots and that the state is fundamentally legitimate and not a tool of socialism. Like the Labour Party, about to enter a second election pledging no rise in income tax rates, no serious challenge to the conservative worldview is mounted.

My guess is that the tax-haven initiative is a dead duck. Bush will agree neither to any action against so-called 'ring-fencing', in which tax havens offer secretly favourable treatment to companies, nor to information-swapping. which conservatives portray as an infringement of sovereignty. The best that can be hoped for is some voluntary code of best practice, a charter for the world's tax cheats.

The only hope for anything better is if the European Union insists that all companies trading within member-state jurisdictions comply with the OECD code, but that again requires Europe's politicians, especially those in Britain, to make a case for the EU.

Otherwise, Bush's good ol' boys won't give a damn.

The growth of the Mafia, organised crime and the drug cartels would be impossible without the capacity to shelter their profits offshore. Every African despot has salted billions away in tax havens. They are not good news. Except in the eyes of American conservatives. Gone are the days when the American Right concentrated on making an economic case against taxation as a disincentive. The argument is still deployed, but it is now secondary to the larger proposition. All state activity diminishes the liberty of the individual; all wealth is the result of individual effort. Therefore, taxation is pernicious. It confiscates wealth that properly belong to individuals. It intrudes into our financial privacy to calculate what is due, only to finance state action that diminishes liberty and, if spent on welfare, education or health, undermines the incentive to take responsibility for ourselves. It is to be opposed to the last. Lawrence Lindsey, Bush's national economic adviser, is a staunch advocate of financial privacy. Dick Armey, House majority leader, characterises the OECD as part of a 'a global network of tax police'. Senator Don Nickles, the assistant majority leader in the Senate, wants a reversal of an agreement that will infringe American sovereignty waged by high-tax, high-welfare Europe against low-tax countries. Even the Democrats' black caucus has joined in, seeing implicit racism in the way so many Caribbean islands have been identified as tax havens. Add in the right-wing think-tanks thundering away along with every right-wing columnist and the atmosphere is pretty feverish. The Treasury and OECD cling to the notion that rationality will prevail, that the aim is not to prevent tax competition between countries but unfair tax competition, and that information-swapping and transparency about tax affairs - the heart of the OECD's efforts - are hardly menacing. They don't get it. There isn't a single authoritative voice in the US speaking up for the idea that taxation is a citizen's downpayment for membership of the community, that wealth creation has social as well as entrepreneurial roots and that the state is fundamentally legitimate and not a tool of socialism. Like the Labour Party, about to enter a second election pledging no rise in income tax rates, no serious challenge to the conservative worldview is mounted. My guess is that the tax-haven initiative is a dead duck. Bush will agree neither to any action against so-called 'ring-fencing', in which tax havens offer secretly favourable treatment to companies, nor to information-swapping. which conservatives portray as an infringement of sovereignty. The best that can be hoped for is some voluntary code of best practice, a charter for the world's tax cheats. The only hope for anything better is if the European Union insists that all companies trading within member-state jurisdictions comply with the OECD code, but that again requires Europe's politicians, especially those in Britain, to make a case for the EU. Otherwise, Bush's good ol' boys won't give a damn.

webTitle: The beauty of slowness

fields.headline: The beauty of slowness
fields.standfirst:
Sometimes direct action is the only way - as long as it's about something serious

Special report: Mayday
fields.trailText: Sometimes direct action is the only way - as long as it's about something serious. By Henry McDonald.
fields.body:
Dodging the cars, motor-bikes and scooters racing through the narrow white-washed streets of the sixteenth-century Andalusian town we visit every year left me harbouring wicked thoughts about Professor Avenarius.

The professor is a fictional character - arguably the hero - of Milan Kundera's 1991 novel Immortality. He is a friend of the narrator and wages a one-man guerrilla campaign in Paris against motor vehicles. His principal strategy is to go out late at night and slash the tyres of cars and motorbikes, which he tells us 'have made the former beauty of cities invisible - I protest that cars have led to the eclipse of cathedrals'.

They have also led to the eclipse of beautiful villages and small towns such as the one my wife and her sister tried to walk through with their children over the last fortnight, steering prams out of the way of speed freaks determined to hare unnecessarily through streets designed for mules rather than Mercedes. Avenarius sees the car's monopolisation of the streets as the ultimate symbol of what he calls 'Diabolum' - his name for the post-modern world of globalisation, greed and speed-worship.

As we tried to avoid endless collisions with selfish, mostly young, drivers intent on colonising every inch of road and pavement, I thought that Avenarius was right. Only the fear of a spell in a Guardia Civil cell discouraged me from following his example and carrying out a tyre-slashing night raid in Nerja.

Avernaius's solo struggle against 'Diabolum' came to mind again on May Day while watching live coverage of the anti-capitalist protests in London's West End. Like the professor, the majority of those protesters want to put a brake on the break-neck, ruthless pace of life in the twenty-first century. The automobile after all is the leitmotif of speed/greed, the destruction of public environment by the privatisation of space.

At times the idealism of the anti-capitalists is misdirected, especially when it degenerates into violence. Smashing up McDonald's and scaring the hell out of the pimply proletarians who slave there hardly constitutes a stunning blow against Monopoly Capitalism. Looting and vandalism reduces sympathy for the cause. But by bringing commercial life to a temporary halt in the UK capital and other cities around the world the protesters have at least highlighted the relentless pursuit of wealth to the detriment of other more important aspects of our existence.

Like Avenarius, they merely protest even if they fail to offer a realistic economic alternative to 'Diabolum'. This is for others, such as the Jubilee 2000 campaigners who have come up with a carefully thought-out, realisable solution to debt that cripples the developing world

None-the-less, the moral anger and energy in taking to the streets is to be welcomed rather than condemned, particularly in an era where politics have been reduced to an advertising battle between two different bank managers. There was in fact evidence of the trivialisation of public debate on May Day morning itself when Radio 4's Today spent a huge chunk of the programme discussing the merits of Tony Blair's new glasses and what this phenomenon meant for British politics.

The protesters were also right to ignore Ken Livingstone's call for no mass turnout at the anti-capitalist march. How after all could they have taken Livingstone's concerns about violence and damage to property seriously, given his track record in the 1980s? It was Livingstone who invited the IRA's political representatives to the city while the Provos continued their futile, immoral bombing campaign, which caused much more death, destruction, and disruption in London than the Crusties and the anarchists of anti-capitalism ever did. People in the metropolitan glasshouse, Ken, shouldn't be throwing boulders.

The British are at least fortunate that among their country's youth, there are still legions prepared to take to the streets to defy the dull managerial political consensus in the pursuit of a noble ideal. By contrast, in Ireland the voice of moral opposition to rapacious capitalism, to the speed and greed of 'Diabolum' represented in that dreadful clichéd phrase, the Celtic Tiger, is muted.

While young people in London protested against Stock Exchange sharks and corporate fat cats, 24 hours earlier their peers went on the rampage in Dublin's O'Connell Street. The targets of their anger were not the World Bank or the WTO, but rather the gardaì and the shops along Ireland's main thoroughfare. And the reason for their booze-fuelled riot? The fact that Celtic had just beaten Rangers three-nil at Ibrox after clinching the Scottish Premier League title.

webTitle: Police 'broke the law' in May Day stand-off

fields.headline: Police 'broke the law' in May Day stand-off
fields.trailText: The Metropolitan Police was unrepentant this weekend in refusing demands by civil rights groups to apologise to bystanders penned in by riot officers at the end of last week's May Day anti-capitalist demonstrations.
fields.body:
The Metropolitan Police was unrepentant this weekend in refusing demands by civil rights groups to apologise to bystanders penned in by riot officers at the end of last week's May Day anti-capitalist demonstrations.

An estimated 2,000 people were held for up to seven hours before being released one-by-one after police searched them and took their photographs.

Lawyers acting for a group of 300 of the people trapped in Oxford Circus as the protests turned violent will this week hold a joint meeting to discuss taking legal action against the police for wrongful imprisonment.

Many of those involved have said they will drop their action if they receive an individual apology from the police.

A Met spokeswoman said last night that the police action was necessary because of the violence of a minority of protesters: 'There is no intention to apologise to those who were detained. Because of the minority, we had to detain the majority. Are they going to apologise to us for throwing bottles?'

John Wadham, director of civil rights group Liberty, which is representing some of those detained by the police, said: 'Potentially, there will be a lot more public money spent on lawyers. The way to solve the problem is to say we got it wrong. The question is: did they know what they planned to do was illegal and go ahead anyway?'

The Metropolitan Police last night confirmed that it had taken legal advice in advance of the operation to detain protesters.

But The Observer can this weekend reveal that the police had serious concerns that public order legislation was in breach of the European Convention on Human Rights. City of London police commissioner Perry Nove told The Observer he was concerned that the law that makes it an offence to organise a parade without informing the police was incompatible with the right to freedom of assembly. Further questions have been raised about the way police used blanket stop-and-search powers against anyone caught in Oxford Circus on May Day.

Helen Shields, 38, attended the peaceful protest outside Coutts Bank with two friends before following several other protesters up to Oxford Street. She is partially paralysed down her right side after falling out of a window when she was 20. She also has arthritis in one knee and walks and talks stiffly and slowly. Despite her disabilities she was not allowed to leave the police cordon at Oxford Circus. She was unable to sit down or go to the toilet, which left her in severe pain. She was finally allowed to go home at 9pm after spending almost seven hours on her feet.

'They kept us prisoners. There was no need for it. It was only a tiny minority that caused trouble. When they finally let me out, the police looked at me like I was an animal, or a common criminal,' she said.

William Eaglestone, 28, a law student at the Inns of Court School of Law, was catching a bus to Victoria Station to catch a train when it stopped along Oxford Street. He left the bus to have a look at what was going on and also found himself hemmed in by riot police. They refused to let him leave until 9pm.

Eaglestone described being caught up with some protesters who were pushing against the police lines. The crush was so tight that he could not move. 'I was pretty frightened when I got penned up against the shields. The operation was so indiscriminate, they just herded everyone who was there together and treated everyone the same,' he said.

Eaglestone said that one man next to him complained to a riot policeman that he was being crushed. 'He told him that he was being crushed twice and the policeman just told him "no you aren't, you are still breathing". It was just nuts. The police themselves were the ones breaching the peace.'

Media organisations covering the demonstrations will also be demanding to know why police refused to let journalists leave the cordons, even when shown press passes, and why they ushered the media away from witnessing the main confrontation with demonstrators outside the John Lewis store in Oxford Street.

webTitle: Computer shops to block child porn on internet

fields.headline: Computer shops to block child porn on internet
fields.trailText: High street computer retailers and software giant Microsoft are to join forces with the British police and children's charities in an unprecedented crackdown on child porn on the internet.
fields.body:
High street computer retailers and software giant Microsoft are to join forces with the British police and children's charities in an unprecedented crackdown on child porn on the internet.

For the first time, PC World, Tiny and Time have agreed that they have a responsibility for child protection when they sell computers to families. All computers are to be fitted with software to filter out child pornography and 'kite marks' for child-friendly chatrooms will be introduced. The big three, which dominate the home PC market, will develop packages to block websites with adult content and access to chatrooms which paedophiles use.

Internet service providers and software manufacturers have also agreed to tighten up controls on paedophile 'newsgroups' where subscribers can exchange images and pornography about children.

It is illegal to download images of children from the internet, but not to set up a paedophile chatroom or exchange sexual fantasies involving children.

The industry was shocked into action by the 'Wonderland' case this year, in which more than a hundred paedophiles around the world were arrested and tens of thousands of images seized in an international operation led by British police.

The proposals will be announced later this week at the launch of the Government's new Internet Task Force on Child Protection, chaired by Home Office Minister Lord Bassam. The task force includes members of the industry, seven children's charities, senior police officers and Home Office officials.

Other measures being considered by the task force include tougher legislation on internet 'grooming', in which children are lured into sexual relationships with paedophiles. Actress Emily Watson, star of the film Angela's Ashes, will tomorrow launch a campaign on behalf of the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children warning parents to be vigilant about the dangers of the Internet. The NSPCC is particularly concerned about paedophiles who persuade children to meet them after striking up an online relationship.

Meanwhile, internet company V21 has responded to the huge demand for 'safe surfing' by adapting Microsoft's Internet Explorer software to block off all unsuitable sites and claims to have created the first-ever completely safe environment for children.

However, civil rights groups last night expressed concern that measures brought in to protect children from paedophiles could be used to snoop on other kinds of internet activity and censor sites that unintentionally attracted paedophiles. Caspar Bowden of the Foundation for Information Policy Research, an internet policy think tank said: 'There is a danger that child protection concerns, fuelled by tabloid witch hunts, might develop into calls for general surveillance of private internet communications.'

The giant electrical retail Dixons group, which includes Currys and PC World, has already begun discussions with the Internet Watch Foundation, the industry's internal regulator, to develop parental guidelines for all customers of their family machines..

Dixons' corporate and public affairs director Lesley Smith said retailers recognised they had a key role in child protection. But she said: 'It is clearly in the interests of parents that we do this and we believe it is in our interests too.' She admitted that said it was difficult to develop entirely foolproof technology.

The task force is thought to favour a film-style rating system developed by the Internet Content Rating Association. Mainstream websites now label their websites according to how child-friendly they are and any adult-oriented sites can be quickly filtered out by new software.

Internet Watch Foundation spokeswoman Ruth Dixon said: 'We welcome this move. The UK is ahead of the game in bringing all the stakeholders together to protect children.'

webTitle: Microserfs should throw off their feudal chains

fields.headline: Microserfs should throw off their feudal chains
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Among the many myths that encrust the Bill Gates legend is a story of how, during a university visit, a student asked him to autograph his Windows 95 installation disk. Gates declined.
fields.body:
Among the many myths that encrust the Bill Gates legend is a story of how, during a university visit, a student asked him to autograph his Windows 95 installation disk. Gates declined.

'Why won't you sign my disk?' asked the student.

'Because it's not yours,' replied Bill.

It's probably apocryphal, but it gets straight to the nub of the matter, namely that when you pay your tithe to Microsoft all you are getting for your money is a licence to use its software under certain restrictive conditions.

These conditions include quite reasonable prohibitions against, for example, unauthorised copying of the software. But they also forbid you to make any changes to the software for any reason whatsoever. Even if you found a horrendous bug which was threatening the financial viability of your business, you would be breaking the terms of the licence to fix the bug - and laying yourself open to the risk of being sued by Microsoft for violating the terms of your 'agreement' with them.

At the same time, you would find that the 'click-through' agreement you accepted at installation time, also stipulated that Microsoft carried no liability whatsoever for consequential damage caused by bugs in its product. So it can sue you for attempting to remedy the defect, but you cannot sue it for issuing the defective product in the first place.

And just so you don't think I've just got it in for Microsoft, every other major proprietary software company pulls the same trick. I've just installed an Adobe product, for example, and the user licence makes my remaining hair stand on end.

Now I am sure that Gates and his counterparts at Adobe and elsewhere do their best, but no software is bug-free, and some bugs are very destructive. Because of my other jobs, for example, I am obliged to use Microsoft software at times.

When I was running Windows 95, my machine crashed up to four times a day - often losing data in the process - and never ran for more than 24 hours without degrading into a more or less unusable paperweight. I now run Windows 2000, which is better but still freezes several times a week, sometimes with really unpleasant consequences for work in progress.

Hundreds of millions of people all over the world are in the same boat, relying on buggy software which they are forbidden to fix (even if they could), and having signed away their right to seek legal redress for consequential damage caused by program defects.

It's a crazy, quasi-feudal system, but that, in essence, is the world we have allowed software companies such as Microsoft to create. The strangest thing of all though is not that millions of computer users have allowed themselves to become Microserfs (after all, what choice do most of them have in a world dominated by Windows software?) but that governments and public authorities seem to have walked in to the same trap. This is weird, given that they are supposed to be rigorous when spending public money on software.

Here in the UK, for example, the Government's main website (www.open.gov.uk) used to run under Linux and Apache - free software that comes with the source code and a licence allowing users to change it to suit their requirements. The site won several awards for its widespread adoption of non-proprietary standards (W3C and multiple browser support).

But now there are rumours that the new version of www.ukonline.gov.uk (designed, hosted and supported by the e-envoy's office) will run under Microsoft software. And already the much-hyped 'Government Gateway' site www.gateway.gov.uk is running on Gates's products under the same restrictive terms that afflict the rest of us.

One for the National Audit Office, perhaps?

John.Naughton@observer.co.uk

webTitle: So just how safe is the nuclear shield?

fields.headline: So just how safe is the nuclear shield?
fields.standfirst:
Secret North Korean plans for rockets trained on major US cities have given George Bush the excuse he needed to revive the Right's dream of blasting nuclear bombs out of the skies

Missile defence won't keep the barbarians out

Observer special report: The Bush files

fields.byline: Peter Beaumont, Ed Vulliamy in Washington and Paul Beaver
fields.body:
Number 26 General Plant in Kanggye in North Korea's Chagang-Do province is a vast underground complex of concrete hangars located in a forbidden zone guarded by the army. It is not marked on any map. The only visible sign of the factory on the surface is seven clusters of buildings linked by a straggle of roads. There are few places on the planet that are more secret.

Last week, the uniformed men and women who labour in the workshops and machine rooms at Kanggye found themselves at ground zero in the biggest shake-up for nuclear proliferation policy in a generation. Hidden from the eyes of the world the workers of Kanggye are building North Korea's most sophisticated missile - the Taepo Dong II - a three-stage rocket that the United States believes is capable of hurling a 750 kilo nuclear warhead across the polar wastes to hit western US cities.

Last week the Taepo Dong II - unseen, untested and unflown - became the casus belli of America's new 'cold war'. It is the reason - ostensibly at least - why President George W. Bush is preparing to tear up the 30-year-old Anti-Ballistic Missile (ABM) Treaty, cornerstone of all subsequent nuclear treaties.

It is the reason why Bush and his hawkish advisers are proposing to spend upwards of $100 billion on a sea, land and space-borne National Missile Defence umbrella - a system explicitly forbidden by the ABM treaty - whose deployment, its many critics say, risks plunging the world into a new era of weapons proliferation and nuclear uncertainty.

Ultimately, too, it is the reason for the uncomfortable position that the Government of Tony Blair finds itself in. The plan is dependent on British permission for America to upgrade its radar site at Fylingdales in North Yorkshire. Now Britain is caught between the disapproval of the rest of the world and the insistence of its most important ally.

But while Bush and his Pentagon hawks may in the end be wrong in pursuing their National Missile Defence system at risk of established and functioning nuclear treaties, the Taepo Dong II also represents a challenge to the President's critics. For it is one of the most visible signs of how the world has changed since Richard Nixon and Leonid Brezhnev sat down in 1972 and signed the ABM treaty.

Then, Warsaw Pact forces occupied half of Europe and the world was still under the shadow of the Cuban missile crisis. If Bush's plans get no further than the Senate floor he has at least opened a crucial - if angry - debate about what nuclear defences and agreements are appropriate for the New World Disorder.

On paper the National Missile Defence system should be a nuclear abolitionist's dream: a system designed to make the threat of nuclear weapons once and for all redundant. If it can be made to work it will create a network of satellites, laser-armed Boeing 747s continuously in flight, missile ships and ground missile launchers that would identify and destroy any threatening missile in flight. It is a very big if.

'If this really was an argument for making nuclear weapons obsolete, as Bush implies, then of course anyone would welcome it,' says Dan Plesch of the British American Security Information Centre. 'If there really was a death ray that could destroy nuclear missiles in flight, then who could oppose it? But it is fallible. And if it is fallible it will lead to more, not less, nuclear proliferation. If this system could work infallibly then the nuclear threat, from China, Russia, North Korea, to the US and its allies would be eradicated. Then America would not need nuclear weapons. Bush says that the quid pro quo of installing this system is that America will cut its nuclear arsenal. He is not saying he will abolish it. The logic of that would make the US the only nation on earth whose missiles could hope to hit its enemies.'

It is this that is alarming opponents of the NMD. For beneath the US-touted radicalism of a vision that Bush's advisers say would lance the threat of rogue nuclear proliferating states, while making deep unilateral cuts in America's nuclear arsenal, they fear that other more sinister agendas are at work.

When George Bush arrived at work in the governor's mansion in Texas on 30 August 1998 he was already contemplating a presidential run. He was not, however, expecting the call he received from his party's leader on Capitol Hill, Trent Lott.

Lott had news for Bush that was being greeted in intelligence circles as ominous. North Korea, said Lott, had successfully tested a medium-range missile capable of reaching targets in Japan. Governor Bush already knew what his response would be were he ever to become president. That test - and the continuing North Korean missile programme - gave him the excuse he needed to make that 'response' official policy. Last week he did just that.

The launching of the first generation prototype of the Taepo Dong I by North Korea in August 1998 was a gift for Bush and his supporters in the US defence industry and on the Republican Right. Bush and his allies - many of whom served in the administrations of Ronald Reagan and his own father - shared a common view. The thrust of US policy on nuclear defence under Clinton was all wrong with its focus on negotiated reductions and the administration's reluctance to deploy a National Missile Defence system of the kind that had become an article of faith for Republicans.

The battle for supremacy with Russia, they reasoned, had been won. The inheritors of the Soviet Union's formidable nuclear arsenal no longer posed a threat; by implication the ABM treaty was redundant. They were frustrated too by the glacial pace of nuclear disarmament negotiations stalled since the US and Russia signed (but never implemented) the Start 2 treaty in 1993.

Instead, they were fixated on the threat posed by China, a nuclear state that was not a signatory to the ABM treaty, and which they suspected of exporting nuclear and missile technology to North Korea, Pakistan, Iran and Iraq. Above all, they shared a belief in the supremacy of US military, economic and technological power that they felt was being hobbled by the collaborative rituals of negotiation that were relics of the Cold War.

If any more proof is needed of the new unilateralist mood in Washington, it is provided by evidence that the Bush administration is preparing to scale down - if not abandon - what many regard as the single most important global security programme: the co-operative effort between the US and Russia to slash the vast nuclear arsenal of the former USSR, and prevent proliferation of deadly nuclear materials.

The administration has already cut more than $100 million from the $874m spent on co-operation projects with Russia under the auspices of the Department of Energy. More ominously, it has put the programme at the core of the effort - the so called Nunn-Lugar Programme - 'under review'.

The project - which has survived all the ups and downs between Washington and Moscow - is named after the two senators who devised and direct the scheme, Republican Richard Lugar and retired Democrat Sam Nunn. It involves hundreds of US officials and contractees working at remote sites to neutralise every instrument of nuclear war.

It is due to run until 2007, and has already overseen the destruction of 5,336 warheads, 422 Intercontinental Ballistic Missiles, 367 silos, 425 cruise missiles and almost a fleet of fully-equipped and armed nuclear submarines. It was under this programme that the Ukraine, Belarus and Kazakhstan gave up their nuclear arsenals.

The administration's potential threat to the programme has detonated the most serious rebellion against the Bush White House by any senior Republican on any issue. Last week Senator Lugar gave a thunderous speech at a private function warning: 'There are no programmes as critical to US security as those aimed at containing and dismantling the nuclear, chemical and biological warfare infrastructure of the former Soviet Union. The administration must ensure that these efforts are managed efficiently and funded properly'.

In the explosion of international anger that greeted Bush's speech, Britain, which has so long cast itself as America's closest ally, has been caught in the crossfire. Despite the encouraging noises of Tony Blair and his spokesman Alastair Campbell over British collaboration with the programme, privately some senior officials and Ministers are deeply concerned.

'We are stuck with this one,' said one senior official. 'Bush has made us an offer we can't refuse. The only negotiating position open to us is to say: "What's in this for us?" We have to make the best of a bad deal.'

The best of that bad deal - say sources - is focused on two British demands: that if Britain permits the upgrading of Fylingdales, then it should also get access to more US intelligence; and over the level of protection that the US would offer Britain under the shield.

'It's not an arrangement or a deal,' said a Pentagon source last week commenting on visits by Defence Secretary Geoff Hoon and Foreign Secretary Robin Cook to Washington to discuss the plan. 'It's an accord which is necessary if the missile defence system is to be effectively operative. To be part of the shield is to be part of the intelligence system that supports it.'

A British official said: 'Both Hoon and Cook have met and talked over the benefits with their opposite numbers in the new administration. That includes the political, diplomatic and technical issues, although there is concern in Whitehall that while Russia has been embraced, the Chinese have been left in the open.'

Indeed, British policy has been moving closer towards the US position all the time. As early as last January, Hoon said he was 'sympathetic' to the US need for National Missile Defence. 'The United Kingdom views a threat to the USA's national security as being a threat to the UK's interests - and vice versa,' he said. 'When the time comes we will weigh up the benefits to the UK.'

webTitle: Emperor Bush's own Hadrian's Wall won't keep barbarians out

fields.headline: Emperor Bush's own Hadrian's Wall won't keep barbarians out
fields.standfirst:
In its rush for power the US has given the world its biggest challenge in 30 years

How safe is the nuclear shield
Observer special report: The Bush files
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Henry Porter says that in its rush for power the US has given the world its biggest challenge in 30 years.
fields.body:
What was George W. Bush doing when the Anti Ballistic Missile treaty was being signed back on 26 May 1972? Well, we can make a fair guess. He was just out of Yale and figuring out what to do with his life. At that moment Brezhnev and Nixon signed the treaty it's a bet that George's gaze was flicking between a sports game, a pretty girl and an open refrigerator. He probably didn't take much notice of the events in Moscow, but at some stage he may have grasped the treaty's underlying doctrine of Mutual Assured Destruction because there was a certain dreadful simplicity in the idea, which even the juvenile George W. Bush would have found arresting.

Thirty years later Bush comes to the White House, with no substantial achievements to his name or experience of international affairs, and announces that the ABM treaty is no longer appropriate to the modern world and the US is going to pursue its dream of a missile defence system. The reaction around the globe to his speech contained a common element and that was indignation that the fragile structures and trust of the nuclear stand-off had been ended by a man with neither the intellect nor humility which this issue requires. Slim Shady and his chainsaw were now in charge of world peace.

In an address of 1,991 words, Bush had managed to turn geopolitical orthodoxy on its head, and every leader with bombs at his disposal went to his most private councils and asked where does that leave us? What do we stand to win? What will we lose? The world was back to calculating missiles and launch times. George may be a little foggy on the issues involved, but he sure has provided the greatest challenge the world's leaders have faced in 30 years. The crucial point that few missed after Bush's withdrawal from the Kyoto Agreement is that the US is in the grip, not of isolationists, but of unilateralists who care little about world opinion and are focused on consolidating American superiority. In his address Bush included the notion of increasing world security at a time when rogue states are allegedly in a position to mount a nuclear attack but his proposal is for a national missile defence system, not a global system.

It seems the US wants the power but not the responsibilities of world leadership - a policy reminiscent of imperial Rome rather than a modern superpower. Nevertheless, the boy George seems to go along with this archaic vision. In his first 100 days he signalled to the Balkans and the Middle East that the US will not be supplying more troops for peacekeeping and the shuttle diplomacy would end. There is a new abrasiveness in dealings with the Russians and Chinese and a dismissiveness about Europe.

It is both an aggressive and defensive stance. The defensive part interestingly displays the fearfulness of many dead empires. When the Chinese started the Great Wall in 214BC and Hadrian commissioned his defensive system across northern England 300 years later they were reacting to precisely the same instinct that is driving US policy now - keeping hostile barbarians out. The Missile Defence Shield is, in military terms, a wall, albeit an exceptionally complex one which owes much to the Americans' fear of the Outside World.

But walls have a habit of being overwhelmed or side-stepped, as any historian of the Maginot line will confirm, and this wall may be avoided with low yield nuclear suitcase bombs or someone in a speedboat running round the Island of Manhattan, spraying anthrax on the shores of the unsuspecting city. So clearly, defence is not the whole story and our calculations of what is pushing Bush should include the fact that his wall will cost $60-$100 billion, most of which will be spent in the defence industries.

In Europe liberals may despair and in Russia and China nationalists and communists will fume, but we cannot complain that Vice President Dick Cheney or Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld have misled us. They have been exact and unabashed in the elucidation of their agenda. The tawdry, interest-heavy US political system, in which they have thrived for nearly 30 years, has thrown up Bush and now he in turn has thrown over the table.

The first thing Bush has done is to rob the US of diplomatic muscle. If America doesn't care what the world says, it follows that the world is going to take a good deal less interest in what America says. Within days of the speech, America lost its seat on the UN Human Rights Commission which it had held for 50 years, which shows that with this domineering posture America will have fewer opportunities to persuade.

More important is the way last Tuesday's speech sharply affects policy in China, Russia and Europe. China feels it has been placed at the focus of the Missile Defence Shield. Its relatively small number of nuclear warheads would be strategically downgraded by a shield. So, the natural course for China is to build many more weapons of different varieties, on the basis that the more they have, the more they stand a chance of reaching target area. Richard Butler, the former head of the weapons inspectorate in Iraq, says that this is precisely the opposite of what a missile defence system should achieve.

Russia has a vast number of warheads and may be soothed by Bush's reference to the possibility of a joint American-Russian missile shield. But at present there seems little hope of President Putin offering to reduce numbers, particularly as the Bush regime has removed 50 Russian spies from American soil and reopened links with Chechen guerrillas. The European powers are no less cross about America's high-handedness. France's nuclear strike force loses significance in the event of US plans going ahead. Their clout can only be assured if they pursue the idea of a European Defence Force. Rifts in the Atlantic alliance may follow. This will prove difficult for Britain which will be forced to choose between Europe and America. And that surely is the point. Even if feasible, the shield will take years to develop, during which rogue states can plan an infinite variety of terrorist attacks on the US, and China will consider increasing its arsenal. Of course, the Americans say they are anxious to consult, but why didn't they do this before committing to an idea which may not work and has simply established their credentials as one of the least responsible nations of the West?

All in all, it's been a very bad week for the world and America, though one doesn't suppose that George W. Bush has the slightest inkling of this.

webTitle: Kibbutz goes private

fields.headline: Pioneering dream ends as kibbutz goes private
fields.standfirst:
Idyll of communal living gives way to harsher modern reality

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The dwindling community of Mishmar David is on the verge of making history by becoming the first of Israel's 279 kibbutzim to be disbanded, shattering the dream of the socialist pioneers.
fields.body:
The dwindling community of Mishmar David is on the verge of making history by becoming the first of Israel's 279 kibbutzim to be disbanded, shattering the dream of the socialist pioneers.

The egalitarian way of life that came to symbolise Israel and attracted young idealistic travellers from Europe and the US has been gradually eroded at Mishmar David.

The demise of the kibbutz, which was formed in 1948, the year Israel was founded, will be almost complete this summer. The kibbutzniks expect then to have approval from the government for a shift from collective to private ownership.

Other kibbutzim will go the same way, casualties of debt, the inability to retain their young and the complex politics of the conflict with the Palestinians. The kibbutzim (Hebrew for collectives) were once the political and cultural bedrock of Israel, producing many of its top soldiers, politicians and intellectuals. Today, they are marginalised.

Zoe Nakar, 52, a Glasgow-born accountant and mother of three who has lived in Mishmar David for more than 30 years, is saddened. Sitting in her kitchen looking out over soft green fields, she said: 'I think it had to happen. I think it will happen in many more kibbutzim. Life has changed and the kibbutz has to change too.'

She is nostalgic for the communal life that has all but gone. In a version of socialism brought from eastern Europe, everyone was paid according to their needs rather than job status. The kibbutz provided education and healthcare, as well as clothes, laundry and other basics. The kibbutzniks ate together in a communal dining room, and children slept together under one roof, not with their parents.

'It is not an experiment that people tried and did not work,' said Nakar. 'For a long time, it was a solution. You can't call it a failure.'

The first kibbutz was founded in 1909. Today, out of an Israeli population of six million, there are 120,000 kibbutzniks, down from 150,000 15 years ago.

The signs of decline are all around Mishmar David: rusting farm equipment, disused buildings, unkept gardens. The dining hall and kitchen are abandoned. The kibbutz, which grows corn, avocados and grapes and has printing presses making labels for farm produce from all over Israel, has a collective debt of £18 million.

Gavri Vargil, 42, executive director of the Kibbutz Movement, admitted other kibbutzim would end up like Mishmar David, but predicted most would survive.

He said there was a political element in the decline. The kibbutzniks voted consistently for Labour: in February's election, 87.3 per cent voted for the Labour leader, Ehud Barak, and only 13.7 for the Likud candidate and eventual Prime Minister, Ariel Sharon.

Vargil said Likud, in power for most of the last 20 years, had been disastrous. Knowing there were few votes to be had among them, Likud spent billions of pounds that might have gone to preserve the kibbutzim, which are all within Israel proper, on expanding Jewish settlements on the West Bank and Gaza Strip, one of the main causes of friction with the Palestinians.

Mishmar David lies in the centre of the country, near Rehovot, south of Tel Aviv. It was set up by Romanian survivors of the Holocaust and former Israeli soldiers.

It had an influx of British immigrants in the Seventies. One of them, Mike Skyte, 47, deputy manager of the printing press, who left Leeds 24 years ago, said the decision to disband the kibbutz had been put to a vote and only one had voted against.

The intention was to build 350 new homes on what was agricultural land to sell to outsiders and pay off the debt. The rest of the land will be returned to the state.

Members will keep their own homes and be given shares in the print works. They will then be on their own, the same as every other Israeli citizen, without the safety net of the kibbutz.

Shalom Nakar, 62, who was originally from Iraq and works on the printing press, regrets the disappearance of the old ways. 'Today, there is more ego and less togetherness, less and less social life together, fewer people to come to committees to discuss important things. They prefer to watch television.'

The communal dining-room served breakfast, lunch and supper, then only lunch, and was closed down altogether in 1994. Two years ago, the members ended the system of each being paid according to need and gave people the option of having salaries, which most have taken.

Throughout Israel, the number of travellers visiting the kibbutzim has shrunk from 12,000 a year 30 years ago to 6,000-7,000 last year and, because of the intifada, down to only 500 in the first four months of this year. Skyte said Mishmar David had stopped taking temporary kibbutzniks 10 years ago because they treated it like a holiday: only two had ever stayed on.

In the kibbutz shop, Oren Singer, 16, was minding the till. He was sorry the communal way of life was coming to an end but said: 'This place is in the middle of nowhere. There are not many people my age. There is nothing to do.' Although brought up on the kibbutz, his parents are British. 'I think I might go and live in England,' he said.

Skyte said the early Zionist intellectuals had advocated that the Jews try to become like other nations rather than be different. But the kibbutzniks dared to be different.

He was sorry he and the others at Mishmar David had failed: 'We all wanted to be something special.'

webTitle: Barbara Ellen: Getting in touch with yourself

fields.headline: Getting in touch with yourself
fields.trailText: Call me a frigid old bat, but it has long been my suspicion that some people aren't sexually inhibited enough.
fields.body:
Call me a frigid old bat, but it has long been my suspicion that some people aren't sexually inhibited enough. Or should I say: sensually inhibited. Sexually uninhibited people are forever showing what they've got to people they'd like to have sex with. Whereas sensually uninhibited people are a much stranger bunch, who prefer showing what they've got to people they don't want to have sex with. Especially if they happen to be camera crews, as witnessed on the unforgettable opening episode of the series Private Parts, which dealt with the vagina.

This featured a female-awareness group 'getting in touch', quite literally, with their vaginas. Most amusingly, though splayed of leg and prodding about with no pants on, all the participants were sporting deadly serious earnest looks. Only a certain kind of woman could make touching herself up resemble a training video for Voluntary Services Overseas, and she is to be avoided at all costs. So it was that, in between gusts of helpless laughter, my friends and I concluded that it might be possible to take the vagina a bit too seriously.

Maybe someone should tell Eve Ensler. Ensler is the New York playwright and abuse survivor whose theatrical calling card is The Vagina Monologues. On the plus side, The Vagina Monologues led to V-Day, which led to millions being raised for women's charities. On the minus, I read some of the monologues online once, and they have to rate as the sorriest bunch of twee, cod-radical, self-important witterings on the front bottom ever collected. They emerged less as hymns to female genitalia than nursery rhymes chanted by a disturbed child. 'If your vagina got dressed, what would it wear?' 'If your vagina could talk, what would it say?' For any sane woman, there could be only one response, surely: 'Get your coat, vagina, we're out of here!'

I object to The Vagina Monologues on a variety of levels, the first being that I object to anything that enables self-important luvvies to feel radical and dangerous. In the US, everyone from Melanie Griffith and Winona Ryder to Susan Sarandon and Oprah Winfrey has taken part in The Vagina Monologues. Glenn Close got thousands of people to shout 'cunt' at Madison Square Gardens, which sounds quite cool until you remember that Close starred in Fatal Attraction, one of the most misogynistic movies ever made. Another sour note strikes with the inclusion of testimonies from Bosnian rape victims. As if rape only happens to the vagina and is not a crime of power and hate that affects a woman's entire being.

Whichever way you look at it, there is something sickening about academics and creatives deciding to commandeer a body part and stick their worthy flag in it, in the manner of self-promoting astronauts piling on to a much-visited moon. It's like, suddenly, the vagina doesn't belong to porn any more, they have cleansed it with their star power and given it back to the women of the world. Never mind that the classic porn 'beaver shot' doubtless popularised the vagina more than any amount of worthy celebrity circle-jerking ever could. Never mind again that some of us never forgot that we had vaginas in the first place. Considering the high rate of teenage pregnancies in this country, we could probably do with being a bit more forgetful.

Ensler hardly helps her cause, bragging in the press about how many stars she managed to get photographed wearing the regulation red boa for British V-Day. She noted smugly that the next day the newsstands resembled a 'vagina sea'. But maybe I don't want vagina seas in my newsagents, in the same way that I don't want an army of penises greeting me at the bakery. Is there indeed that much difference between Ensler's vagina sea and the tit-and-arse landscape so beloved of our tabloids?

Granted, there is work to be done on the vagina front. As Ensler says, there has to be some kind of antidote to our testosterone-addled, phallocentric universe. However, by talking about their vaginas as if they were defined by them alone, women are in danger of objectifying and fetishising their bodies as much as men. Which brings me to my final objection: that the very existence of The Vagina Monologues makes men look saner than women, something I never thought would happen during my lifetime.

The Penis Monologues, anybody? I didn't think so. Where their genitals are concerned, men aren't interested in monologues, they're into dialogue (baybee!). Which is where all the fun (and trouble) starts. For their part, women might be better served ignoring The Vagina Monologues and concentrating on the most overlooked and underrated female organ of all. The brain.

webTitle: Phil Hogan: Twenty years and counting

fields.headline: Twenty years and counting
fields.trailText: 'So what kind of anniversary is 20 anyway?' she asks. 'Actually, it's china. So I was thinking...' 'We are not going to the Chinese.' Damn.
fields.body:
My wife rings up to say she's going to be late back with the three eldest from school because she's in the middle of the road with a flat tyre and the car jacked up with the wheel off, which is all very discommoding I'm sure but who, may I ask, is supposed to give the little one his tea and bring the rabbit in out of the rain? 'Me', seems to be the answer, though it is an answer that fails to address the possibility that I might have an urgent life schedule of my own to juggle, if you don't mind.

So I duly sigh and put the crossword down and occupy my mind with chicken nuggets etc until she gets home, but of course tempus is fugiting like there's no tomorrow and needless to say she is still up to her elbows in Swarfega when our babysitter arrives, because - yes, it's our wedding anniversary and we're so excited at having had the same knives and forks for 20 years that we have decided to go out and celebrate, even though it hardly seems five minutes since the last time we had a night on the razzle, which I believe was as recently as 1997.

'So what kind of anniversary is 20 anyway?' she asks.

'Actually, it's china. So I was thinking...'

'We are not going to the Chinese.'

Damn. Still, a meal out would be an idea, though I do seem to remember the wild and crazy promise we made ourselves as fresh-faced honeymooners back in 1981 to mark this year's anniversary by returning to Peru, where we spent three weeks doing our bit to establish the breathtaking Andean uplands as a centre of excellence for altitude sickness, my lovely new bride entertaining the locals by fainting on the tarmac at Cuzco airport, me throwing up to the incidental music of indigenous nose flutes on the runaway train back down from the precipitous heights of Machu Picchu, the understandably lost city of the Incas. Ah, how little did we suspect back then with our hair full of steam that by April 2001 we would have plunged with equal spectacularity (if there be such a word, and I fear there isn't) from the panoramic vistas of unshackled frolic to the economic netherworld of the 'Oink' (one income, numerous kids), today having only £11.54 between us if you include the £10 our youngest got sent by grandma for his birthday, which I'm afraid has had to be taken into our custody until he's old enough to work out what happened to it.

But we are nothing if not determined to be weak-willed in the teeth of adversity vis-à-vis our resolution not to throw money at anything this month or any other, and are accordingly soon pigging out at our local superior eaterie, spending the Hongkong & Shanghai Banking Corporation's unlimited reserves on our fill of fine wines and gins, seared pigeon breasts stuffed with tripes and black pudding, pan-fried seahorses, Madagascan sheep's knuckle braised in Mackeson and Sauternes, topped off with organic spotted dick in a traditional pomegranate and creamed yam salsa. My wife, once I have reminded her that she is supposed to be on a diet, orders a baked mushroom of some description. And, hey, just the two of us! Of course we are a bit rusty at chatting for pleasure, but it doesn't take long before our tongues become acclimatised to the novelty of being able to finish a sentence without someone wanting to know where their skateboard is, and to her credit my wife resists the temptation to remind me to take my elbows off the table or not to talk with my mouth full of garlic mash and seasonal wild berries du jour.

Come 10 o'clock we are gazing at each other over a guttering candle, glugging down wine and exchanging reminiscences of our Big Day - a not completely unstylish marriage, if memory serves, sanctified among chums and close relatives at Marylebone registry office. Champagne and canapés afterwards. A modest wedding with no fuss, though I agree it might have been a fraction less modest if the men on my side of the family hadn't left their shirts in Yorkshire. In the car boot. Along with all the presents. Still, we got them eventually. Towels, spice rack, knives and forks...

webTitle: Sex without subtitles

fields.headline: Sex without subtitles
fields.standfirst: Somehow it's far more shocking when those moans of pleasure are in English, as they are in a clutch of new movies exploring sexuality.  Mark Morris  plays voyeur...
fields.trailText: Somehow it's far more shocking when those moans of pleasure are in English, as they are in a clutch of new movies exploring sexuality. Mark Morris plays voyeur...
fields.body:
Take a few seconds to think about this: is uncensored sex more or less acceptable with an English accent? The question was raised by something Sue Clark of the British Board of Film Classification said about Intimacy, a film destined, at least for a while, to be known as 'that film with the blow-job in it'.

This is what Clark said: 'Audiences may be used to seeing explicit sex scenes in foreign language films, such as The Idiots, which is Danish, and the Japanese film Ai No Corrida [In the Realm of the Senses], but this is the first time many will see such scenes in an English-language movie.'

Given that a wave of sexually explicit films in English is coming our way - The Center of the World , Killing Me Softly, Better Than Sex and Intimacy, which is based on Hanif Kureishi's writings - the question is now relevant in a way it hasn't been since the Seventies. Could it be true that people were happier with mysterious foreigners having real sex on film?

I asked Clark to clarify her statement. 'I thought some people might find the fact that it was in English meant the film had more impact on them. I wasn't suggesting that the language made a difference, except in the sense that if something is in a foreign language with actors you don't recognise you can slightly distance yourself from what's happening, whereas if it's in English with people you recognise and bus routes you recognise, possibly, you become more involved with the film and might find it more startling.'

While it is true that recent landmarks in cinema sex involved the anonymous orgyists in Lars Von Trier's The Idiots or the busman's holidaying porn stars of French shocker Romance, in Intimacy that's Globe Theatre artistic director Mark Rylance and Shallow Grave star Kerry Fox naked and exposed on a grubby carpet in New Cross. It is awkward and it is meant to be.

'I think sex is always difficult,' Kureishi says, 'not only for everybody in real life, but also to look at in the cinema. It's always frightening, it's always a problem and, despite the fact that people seem to talk about it a lot, and there have been dozens of films about it, the subject is never done. Somehow, violence is always easier; you always know where you stand with violence. But I think sexuality is a problem and will go on being one, whether it is Japanese, French or German.'

This much is clear: we are in an age when the boundaries of sex in the cinema are being pushed with an enthusiasm not seen since the mid-Seventies. Although the trend started in Europe, it has arrived in the traditionally more censorious English-speaking world, albeit with the help of foreigners such as Intimacy director Patrice Chereau. The Center of the World, directed by Wayne Wang and co-written by Paul Auster, will be showing at Cannes. Chinese director Chen Kaige has recently completed shooting the S&M-tinged Killing Me Softly in London with the starry pairing of Joseph Fiennes and Heather Graham.

And the highlight of the recent Australian Film Festival in London was Better Than Sex, which in a far cheerier way asks one of the same questions as Intimacy: what happens to a couple when just having pounding sex is no longer enough?

The feeling that something is going on is amplified in Britain by the fact that we can now see these films uncut. It seems like a taboo is being broken every month, with formerly unviewable erect penises sailing past the censor. As far as the British Board of Film Classification is concerned, non-violent sex in 18-certificate films stays in. 'We certainly found from our research last year that the public felt it was an issue we could leave to them, rather than interfering,' Clark explains. 'They should be the ones who decide whether they want to watch films like that. Provided that the sex doesn't involve violence or coercion towards one of the partners, we are much more relaxed about allowing it through, based on the fact that that's what the public told us they wanted.'

In the US, meanwhile, filmmakers like Wang are increasingly ignoring the ratings system altogether and releasing their films uncut and uncer tified. But The Center of the World had trouble with its trailers.

'We had to cut the trailer for this film because no theatre would play it,' Wang says. 'It has Molly Parker looking at herself in the mirror saying, "I have the hottest, wettest, tightest pussy". It's a quote from some book about stripping that girls use to pump themselves up. Nobody would show it. At the same time, you've got all this porn out there.'

The Center of the World follows the relationship between a dotcom millionaire (Peter Sarsgaard) and a stripper (Molly Parker) in a Vegas hotel room. It is the most serious explicit film made in the US in a long time, even if Wang never convinced his stars to engage in unsimulated sex for him.

'They both felt they did not want to do fake sex, like on the Playboy Channel. They wanted to make it as real as possible. The issue became whether they were really going to do it or not. In the end, they didn't. I was prepared to ask them to do it for real. At one point, I was kind of pushing for it because it really pushed the reality of what was going on between these two characters. The point of the movie is what is real about sex and what is fantasy.'

Like Intimacy, Wang's movie isn't much fun. Both fit into the tradition established by Last Tango in Paris that the more explicit an arthouse movie is the less appealing sex seems. No one would watch The Idiots or Romance to get their kicks. It's not just a question of more honest lighting or casting. Intimacy , especially, shares with Last Tango the way the sex takes place in grubby surroundings between characters who are deeply unhappy. Rylance and Fox play a couple who meet every Wednesday and have silent, anonymous sex.

'These people are using sex as an anaesthetic, as a way of forgetting themselves,' Kureishi says. 'It's not a happy fuck. The film is interested in what people use sex to do, as a way of not speaking. As a way of eliminating social intercourse as opposed to sexual intercourse, as a way of not facing other needs you might have, to have conversations with one another, or just to hold one another. In this film, though, they do get to become interested in one another.'

webTitle: Javier Bardem

fields.headline: Javier Bardem
fields.standfirst: the Spanish hunk-with-spunk
fields.trailText: Spanish hunk-with-spunk Javier Bardem
fields.body:
When the Oscar nominations were announced very early in the morning earlier this year, one name produced genuine applause from the sleepy industry types. That name was Javier Bardem, chosen for his portrayal of Cuban poet Reinaldo Arenas in Before Night Falls. It was a daring nomination for two reasons: not many people had seen Julian Schnabel's outstanding film and not many Americans had heard of Bardem. Back in Spain, it's a different business.

The Bardem family is steeped in movies: his grandfather, Rafael, appeared in 113 films. But Javier's performances in films like Jamón, Jamón and Live Flesh have made him the most famous member of the family. Now 32, he acted as a child but only chose it as a career after a few years drifting, including running a bar in Brazil. 'I went bankrupt. I spent everything on drink and partying.' The gay poet Arenas, who died of Aids, is a far cry from the bullishly macho types Bardem has often played, but his first screen kiss was with a man. 'The director, Bigas Luna, likes us to kiss with tongues. In the rehearsals, I was very shy, but this guy was [mimes enormous tongue kiss] and 'oh god, wow, man!' It was the first homosexual experience of my life. It was nice. But I hoped to do it with a woman in my next movie.'

It seems unlikely that the Americans can water down his overwhelming Spanishness - hand him a cigarette and he'll rip the filter off. But despite the big muscles, he's actually intelligent as well as highly political.

Mindful of the mixed career Pedro Almodóvar's previous leading man, Antonio Banderas, has had in Hollywood, Bardem says he would rather work with the Coen brothers than be in a blockbuster: 'I don't see myself running after Godzilla.' Anyway, he has already had all the American praise he needs. 'One of my dreams came true when Julian Schnabel showed Before Night Falls to Al Pacino. He called me at 3am and told me he liked my performance. I said, "I don't believe in God, I believe in Al Pacino".'

Five things you need to know about Javier Bardem

1. He played rugby for Spain as a teenager.

2. While making Jamón, Jamón , director Bigas Luna made Bardem stick his finger in a pig's anus 14 times.

3. His grandfather, his uncle, his mother, his sister and his brother are or were all actors.

4. He is the first Spaniard to be nominated for best actor at the Oscars.

5. Ken Loach didn't give him a part in Land And Freedom but Bardem remains a big fan.
