webTitle: Abridged too far

fields.headline: Abridged too far
fields.standfirst: Cephalonia and Cruz are gorgeous, and you may even shed a tear, but condensed Corelli isn't the epic it wants to be
fields.trailText: Peter Preston: John Madden's version of Louis de Bernières's novel is no outright disaster... The difficulty is in the might-have-beens
fields.body:
What happens when a big bestseller - full of rich characters, subplots, history and narrative drive - turns into a big (budget) movie? Captain Corelli breaks a string on his mandolin, that's what. Most of the richness, maybe inevitably, is declared surplus to screenplay requirements. Only the central core of romance remains - and that, denuded of supporting ingredients, seems thin and overblown. It drags itself into life: it does not drive.

But pause, first, in search of a fair precision. John Madden's version of Louis de Bernières's novel is no outright disaster. Cephalonia looks beautiful. So does Penélope Cruz. The action sequences towards the end are expertly handled. You won't - especially if you're one of the three people on earth who hasn't read the book - stagger out of the stalls feeling short-changed. You may even contrive a glycerine smear of a tear. The difficulty is in the might-have-beens.

It might (just might) have been possible to keep some of the texture - which means the believability and thus human warmth - of the original. But Shawn Slovo's script never begins to meet that test. Problem one: what language are this ostensible collection of Greeks, Italians and Germans supposed to be talking? Slovo and Madden settle for an all-purpose Eastern Med Esperanto, otherwise dee Eenglish with daa flexeebly transferable accent. Zorbaspeak. That makes any trip into the colloquial fraught with peril. When Corelli, as interpreter, tries to negotiate the surrender of the mayor and town council, what do they say? They say: 'fuck off.' Catch the first bus back to Camden town, mate. The words, time and again, get in the way.

So does the casting. Of course you need stars - you can't live at the box office without them - but internationalism on this scale verges on the ridiculous. An American (Nicolas Cage) as the lead Italian; a Spaniard (Cruz) as the Greek heroine with an Englishman (John Hurt) as her dad and a Welshman (Christian Bale) as her Ionian peasant lover, plus standard Brits doing their Nazi strut as Germans and real Greeks filling in the cracks in between. Problem two: your real Greeks don't look remotely like your phoney Greeks. Wrong colour, wrong bone structure - the differences fill the screen.

Try sinking yourself in the plot, then. Cephalonia 1941; the Italians - an effete gang of opera-loving layabouts - are the main force of occupation. Captain Corelli, a gentle soul who specialises in barber-shop Rossini as well as mandolin plucking, gets billetted with the fragrant Cruz and her wise old doctor dad while Bale is fighting Hitler in the North. Love does its blooming thing. Bale comes back looking baleful. Mussolini throws in the towel as the Germans turn murderously on their erstwhile allies. Add an earthquake for luck and consider: who emotes, wins. The hacking down of de Bernières - changed ending, editing so brutal that at least one crucial character, the gay Carlo who saves Corelli from the firing squad, becomes inexplicable - doesn't help. Nor does the truncation of real history and real time passing into a few glib devices. But then, gradually, it becomes evident that Madden may be trying to bypass all the difficulties and make a picture which - at heart - has very little to do with the book.

Consider his deliberately lush visual style, a constant orchestrating of sun, rocks and flowers. Who does that remind you of? Partly Claude Berri doing over Pagnol for Depardieu and Emmanuelle Beart, but most insistently this is late David Lean, this is Ryan's Daughter à la Greque. Lean had Robert Mitchum, Leo McKern, Sarah Miles and John Mills all turning on the (pretty ludicrous) Oirish, though variously transported from LA, Oz or SW5 - but nobody cared at the time. Here was Romance with sumptuous strings, and a few tremors of the Troubles dropped in for luck. Begin with cliffs, crags, the eternal sea and simple folk fuelled by simple longings and you couldn't go wrong. Synthetic settings with synthetic castings didn't matter if the hankies got drenched anyway.

Madden dutifully follows his French and English mas ters. Most of the interior shots have that Berri gloss, superior Stella Artois without a foot on the beer pump. Get the camera outside and it constantly soars (with Stephen Warbeck's strings). There's very little attempt at specific realism. Cruz is forever wandering through the glades gathering flowers or fruit in a crisp new cotton smock (from Knightsbridge, £200 and up). Cage's lurches into comedy are as over the top as John Mills's loony fisherman. Here is a nowhere island, Ruritania meets Illyria before the tempest of violence. Does Hurt, perhaps, carry a Prospero's wand in his GP's bag?

At this level, after its fashion, Captain Corelli survives gentle scrutiny. If you're not supposed to believe, then settle for a wallow through what you're supposed to appreciate. Will Cage win another Oscar? (Somebody thinks so: the US release comes only with autumn). He doesn't quite deserve to because the lighter, extrovert Corelli is beyond gelling with that blank face best suited for introversion and pain. But give him a nomination for ambition beyond the call of duty.

Is Cruz the next great female star? She's grown thin and birdlike here (almost the only sign of a wartime Cephalonia on short rations) but she remains luminous, with eyes that well with sadness and a mouth that quivers into wondrous malleability. Europe's answer to Julia Roberts. She - and the brooding Hurt - bring a touch of class. Now give her another comedy like Woman on Top and a square meal.

Back to basics, though. Some books are made to be movies, some are not. The inescapable truth about Captain Corelli's Mandolin, whatever its printed allure, is that a successful cinematic transition is almost certainly a bridge too far. The essence doesn't condense. Cut away and there are only loose ends. John Madden has tried, then, to do something else - and he's not enough of a distinctive hand to pull it off entirely. A gallant failure? Better than that: more a flawed, derivative, but occasionally rousing entertainment.

Go expecting little and you may be pleasantly surprised (especially as the second half gathers pace). Go expecting a British masterpiece to recapture the great days of epic romance and hype kebabs hope. Does the earth move here? Only on seismic orders from special effects - and nobody on a decent salary gets hurt.

webTitle: Michael Winner: Too sensitive for his shirt

fields.headline: Too sensitive for his shirt
fields.standfirst: With his fast cars, nine bathrooms, five domestic staff, excruciating films and a girlfriend half his age, Michael Winner is a man you'd just love to hate. If only he wasn't so charming
fields.trailText: With his fast cars, nine bathrooms, five domestic staff, excruciating films and a girlfriend half his age, Michael Winner is a man you'd just love to hate. If only he wasn't so charming
fields.body:
Michael Winner is wearing a tan from Morocco, a shirt from Gstaad and his heart on his sleeve. Is it possible that a man whose entire career is founded on provocation can be quite so sensitive? If it is sometimes difficult to evaluate the contribution Michael Winner has made to the worlds of film and journalism, this is because of the clouds of dust he stirs up as he passes, at speed, leaning on the horn of his £47,000 Mercedes.

Winner likes to live up to his name and that gets up people's noses. 'To me, expensive is buying a £4-million painting, a jet plane or ordering a £6,000 bottle of wine,' he remarked recently, to the sound of much gnashing of teeth.

There seems much to loathe about Michael Winner: his Toadish pleasure in his wealth ('If I could go back, I would spend much more, earlier. No question. This sounds absolutely crass, but I would have taken private planes earlier, would have had a chauffeur and better cars earlier, I'd have bought better paintings earlier'), the name-dropping in his Sunday Times restaurant column, the reputation he has for throwing his weight around. And, last but not least, the rubbishy later films.

Winner, who is in a sunny and avuncular mood today, likes to remember the good reviews, not the bad, but even he has to admit that not all have been favourable. 'Of course I've had some real stinkers,' he concedes eventually, adding, rather darkly, that he believes his peculiar form of celebrity has cast a long shadow over his last few productions. Recently, he says, the critics have had 'a real go at me, not at the movies'. It's nothing like a family home, more a bachelor pad along the proportions of Versailles, with some comfy touches: two large oils of him on the stairs and an impressive number of Winnie the Pooh and Arthur Rackham originals.

There are eight bears and Humpties in his vast bedroom, along with five telephones, three arrangements of stargazer lilies and two televisions.

When he agrees to give me the famous tour, his pride in the house is set against a cultivated carelessness. Entering one of the sitting-rooms, he throws open the French windows that lead on to the garden. When he moves on, I start fumbling to close them, to keep the heat in, but Winner looks at me as if I'm bonkers and says I really shouldn't bother, someone will be coming round to tidy up after us in a moment.

The same thing happens with the piped music in the steam-room and the lights that illuminate the indoor pool - he leaves them on, because he can. It is rather grotesque, as is his habit of bellowing 'Dinah!' over the banisters when he wants assistance from his receptionist. But, oh, it is mysteriously difficult to dislike a man who remarks: 'Oh yes, the dear departeds' when you spot, in one of the nine bathrooms, a table bristling with framed photographs of his exes.

There are photographs everywhere. When I ask about his mother, Helen, he presses her likeness into my hand. 'Absolutely beautiful. Spoke like a duchess. There she is, bless her. Nice, little, white-haired lady. She was a killer. If she decided she wasn't happy about something, she was acid.'

Winner doesn't say much about his father, a north London property developer who assembled quite a fortune, but he talks about his mother, who lost most of it at a Cannes casino, with fascination and awe. She never gave him much attention when he was a small and odd-sounding boy (at 14, he was writing a syndicated newspaper column and interviewing people like Louis Armstrong but she was always more interested in the previous night's poker scores).

After George's death, in 1972, things turned nasty. Having gambled away £8m, she pursued her son's inheritance through the courts, getting through 11 firms of solicitors. At one point, she made over her jewellery to her son but then soon afterwards told a friend that he had stolen it and she was going to the police. When he rang up to confront her, she asked if she could have it back. 'So I said, "Of course you can have it back, dear, I'll bring it back immediately". And that, I must say, for some reason made me feel that I couldn't take it anymore. It was too painful.' He spoke to her on the phone (she never knew how upset he was and wouldn't have remembered it anyway) for the next six months and then she died. 'I definitely loved her,' he says, sadly.

The evidence suggests that Winner has never been quite so sure of his feelings for anyone else. He tends to keep his lady friends at arm's length - only one ('Seagrove') actually moved in. He met Georgina eight years ago when she applied, unsuccessfully, to become his receptionist, but they only started stepping out in 1999, when his last girlfriend, Vanessa, decided the party was over and she wanted a family (Winner has a low sperm count).

'I remembered Georgina and called her, as one does if one is a lonely bachelor, which I have been for longer than almost anyone else on the planet. However pathetic you may be, you still try to make dates. It's that or watch the spin-dryer.'

Ageing, he says, isn't fun. He is offended by his stomach in the mirror ('I think, "How dare you look like that?"') and would be lost without his three hair restoratives (he's very proud of his cloudy white coif, and says that one of his worst habits is combing it in restaurants). Every time a relationship ends, and he seems to be fairly passive in the break-ups, he feels less alluring. 'It becomes more frightening. I used to think I was always very ugly, but when I look at old photographs I see that I was actually very beautiful. And every year you're getting older and fatter. Yeah, I think I have reached a point now where I'd quite like to settle down. But another side is very fearful of it.'

Could Georgina be the one? 'Well, she's a lovely girl. Eastern Europeans have a wonderful eccentricity. That's something that may happen. Or it may not. Let's put it like this - I would put money either way.'

Winner's relationship with Ryan, Georgina's four-year-old son, sounds complicated. When Winner and Georgina go holidaying in 'posh hotels', Ryan visits Dinah's family in Cheshire. 'To have a whole family environment in the country, horses and dogs and the sea, it has been a wonderful thing for him, to bring him out.'

It becomes obvious that the little boy is not a frequent visitor to Winner Towers, partly because Winner 'doesn't want to get too involved in case something goes wrong', and also because 'a four-year-old in this house, with all the antiques... it would send me into... he's a lovely kid'.

Boys! One wonders how Georgina copes with the pair of them.

The world according to Winner

On Margaret Thatcher 'She transformed this nation from a country that was ridiculed and despised abroad into one that was respected.'

On films generally 'Today's movies are more fun, quicker-witted, and all-over better than they ever were.'

On his film Death Wish ' Death Wish changed the whole context of cinema. It's the most copied film of all time, from Robocop to Rambo .'

On The Weakest Link 'Contestants willingly go forth to be humiliated by this strange, Dracula-like figure: a sarcastic headmistress dealing with idiot children.'

On going knickerless 'It's disgusting. It means that, frankly, you defecate on to your trousers.'

On actors 'Actors are very shy and insecure people who get their gratification by impersonating people who are not shy or insecure.'

On theft 'I stopped stealing when I was 17... Now, although I take towels, soap, cutlery from hotels, and airplanes, I ask permission first!'

On his school (St Christopher's, Letchworth) 'A Quaker, socialist, do-good, open-toed-sandals, Bernard Shaw-type school.'

webTitle: Wilde's sex life exposed in explicit court files

fields.headline: Wilde's sex life exposed in explicit court files
fields.standfirst: Under the hammer: unpublished witness statements tell of 'rough' teenage boys and soiled sheets
fields.trailText: Under the hammer: unpublished witness statements tell of 'rough' teenage boys and soiled sheets.
fields.byline: Vanessa Thorpe and Simon de Burton
fields.body:
Explicit documents prepared for the Oscar Wilde libel case have come to light, offering a revealing new glimpse of the double life led by the celebrated Irish writer.

The shocking witness statements, previously unseen, were drawn up by employees at Day Russell of the Strand, solicitors for the defence in Wilde's disastrous 1895 legal action against the Marquis of Queensberry. Most of the papers were filed away and never used in court.

While Wilde is remembered today as the dandy-about-town, sporting bespoke suits and habitually wearing a green carnation in his buttonhole, these statements - from chamber-maids, valets, bell-boys and even a lamp-wick seller portray his private life in lurid detail.

Seedy descriptions of Wilde's bedroom are included in the damaging file, which was instrumental in Wilde's downfall and formed the background for one of the most famous cases in British legal history.

Wilde took legal action against the Marquis, father of his lover, Lord Alfred Douglas, after he found a visiting card left by Queensberry at the Albermarle club. It was inscribed with the words: 'For Oscar Wilde posing Somdomite [ sic ]'.

The 52 pages of statements from 32 witnesses have never been published and are hand-written on heavy sheets of paper. They were picked up in a London junk shop for a pittance during the Fifties by a private collector whose widow is now selling them at Christie's on 6 June. The historic bundle, wrapped in pink string, is expected to fetch £12,000.

Among the more sordid details are those revealed by Margaret Cotta, a chambermaid at the Savoy Hotel, a favourite rendezvous for Wilde and his series of young male 'renters'. Describing a prolonged visit to the hotel by Wilde and Alfred Douglas, who was affectionately known as Bosie, Miss Cotta said she found a 'common boy, rough looking, about 14 years of age' in Wilde's bed, the sheets of which 'were always in a most disgusting state... [with] traces of vaseline, soil and semen'.

Instructions were given that the linen should be kept apart and washed separately. Miss Cotta added that a stream of page boys delivering letters were usually kissed by Wilde, who then tipped them two shillings and sixpence for their trouble.

Thomas Venning, a manuscripts specialist at Christie's, said the documents provided a new account of Wilde's undoing and had 'very detailed sexual content which was only mentioned in the trial euphemistically'.

The statements also show Wilde's carefree attitude to discovery. Wallis Grainger, an apprentice electrician from Oxford, told how Wilde took him to a cottage in nearby Goring-on-Thames which he had rented and where he wrote An Ideal Husband.

On the second or third night, said Grainger, Wilde 'came into my bedroom and woke me up and told me to come into his bedroom which was next door... he worked me up with his hand and made me spend in his mouth'. The former butler of the Marquis of Queensberry was in the next room.

On another occasion, during the Goring regatta, Gertrude Simmons, governess to Wilde's two sons, reported seeing him 'holding the arm of a boat boy called George Hughes and patting him very familiarly'. During the same visit she came across a carelessly discarded letter to Wilde from Bosie which was signed 'your own loving darling boy to do what you like with'.

Another statement came from a 20-year-old called Fred Atkins, who Wilde had met at the Café Royale. Atkins said Wilde 'took me to the hairdresser and had my hair curled'. Wilde later took him off to Paris as his secretary, Atkins said. The job involved 'writing out only half a page of a manuscript which took about 10 minutes' after which Wilde 'made improper proposals'.

Queensberry had used detectives to track down a circle of male prostitutes, and some of their statements are among those being sold. Wilde's action against Queensberry opened on 3 April 1895 at the Old Bailey but collapsed with a not guilty verdict. At noon on 5 April, the evidence gathered by solicitor Charles Russell was immediately forwarded to the Director of Public Prosecutions and Wilde was arrested on a charge of gross indecency.

On 24 May, after two further trials, he was sentenced to two years' imprisonment with hard labour, which broke his health. After his release he lived abroad as a bankrupt under the pseudonym Sebastian Melmoth. He died in Paris on 30 November 1900.

On 24 May, after two further trials, he was sentenced to two years' imprisonment with hard labour, which broke his health. After his release he lived abroad as a bankrupt under the pseudonym Sebastian Melmoth. He died in Paris on 30 November 1900.

webTitle: Land of hype and glory

fields.headline: Land of hype and glory
fields.trailText: Land of hype and glory
fields.body:
Any day now, London's literary pages will be full of news about the 2001 Orange Prize for Fiction. The trophy itself (for the best novel of the year written in English by a woman, regardless of nationality, age, country of residence or subject) will not actually be awarded until 5 June.

That will not stop Orange, an upstart newcomer to the world of literary prizes, from surrounding the launch of this year's prize with a flotilla of ancillary events designed to maximise media coverage. It has already scored quite a few column inches by persuading both Rosie Boycott and Kate Adie to help judge the prize. High-profile jurors have become essential to a well-run literary prize these days, though it must be admitted that neither Ms Boycott nor Ms Adie are quite in the Mariella (Booker) Frostrup class.

What Orange may lack in celebrity wattage, it more than makes up for in home-grown energy. Thus, on 10 May, it will announce its short list. Rah! This epochal moment will be accompanied by the now customary announcement of the betting by the in-house littérateurs at William Hill and Ladbrokes. Absolutely! Across the known world, students of new fiction will be logging on to www.orangeprize.com for details.

Next, on 3 June, three Orange Prize judges will recommend their 'Great Reads' to the Hay Literary Festival. Yo! A few hours later, at the same festival, some of the short-listed writers will read from their work. Hallelujah!

With tension mounting, and the women's fiction-reading public scarcely able to contain itself, the eve of the announcement, 4 June, will be marked by 'Orange Readings at the British Library', another 'unique opportunity' to hear the short-listed authors read from their novels and discuss their work. Wow!

By the time Rosie Boycott actually arrives at the microphone to announce the winner to the expectant world, and hand over a cheque for £30,000, Orange will have extracted every last drop of publicity from the bitter lemon of contemporary women's fiction.

If 2000 is anything to go by, Orange will also have made sure that anyone who is anyone in the world of books has been invited to one of the most lavish events of the year. For the partygoers of Grub Street, the future's bright and the future's orange.

This year, possibly buoyed up by its recent good press, Orange has taken the logic of its brand-promotion to extremes.It has done everything it can to popularise its prize. It has bombarded the literary press with fascinating initiatives. It has sponsored an alternative judging panel of men, chaired by novelist and critic Paul Bailey, presumably to determine if there is, after all, such a thing as an Orange book that might appeal to boys as well as girls. In the present feverish atmosphere of innovation, it would come as no surprise to hear that next year's award will be adjudicated underwater.

Six years ago, when the telecommunications giant launched this prize to promote its image, it was just another milestone on the annual road to the big, end-of-year literary prize events, like Booker and Whitbread. Now, it has become its own destination. In the process, it has forced those senior prizes to raise their game and sharpen their presentation.

Never mind that many women writers (and some of its chosen judges) deplore Orange's location of their work in a ghetto. Never mind that the prize has yet to identify a major new writer of genuine significance. (In hindsight, last year's decision to give the prize to Linda Grant in preference to Zadie Smith seems at best mistaken, at worst downright perverse.)

Never mind, that Orange has elbowed its way to the front of the pack by a canny mixture of chequebook waving and self-promotion. The fact is that it has become a force to be reckoned with, and has done so in an astonishingly short time. A year in the world of books is worth at least five civilian equivalents.

A literary prize is an oxymoron, of course (literature is not about prizes). There's no doubt, though, that, for all its absurdity, Orange does more good than harm. This year's prize will introduce thousands of readers to novels from all over the English-speaking world they might otherwise have never heard of. It will bestow on half-a-dozen lucky competitors the one thing writers need: the kind of money that buys time.

Literary, musical and artistic creativity in England generally gets a rough ride. In the world of books, perhaps only the poets enjoy widespread public appreciation. If literary prizes like Orange are the price the creative community has to pay to attract the attention of the book-buying public, then hype becomes the flipside of glory.

robert.mccrum@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Steve Heighway: the man who scored Liverpool's goal in the 1971 FA Cup Final

fields.headline: Steve Heighway: the man who scored Liverpool's goal in the 1971 FA Cup Final
fields.standfirst: FA Cup final special
fields.trailText: Steve Heighway is probably best remembered for scoring the first goal in the 1971 FA Cup final, in the first minute of extra time. Heighway, the Dublin-born winger and economics graduate, cut in from the left to surprise Bob Wilson at his near post, prompting BBC commentator Kenneth Wolstenholme to exclaim: 'Why didn't he just do that two minutes ago?'
fields.body:
Steve Heighway is probably best remembered for scoring the first goal in the 1971 FA Cup final, in the first minute of extra time. Heighway, the Dublin-born winger and economics graduate, cut in from the left to surprise Bob Wilson at his near post, prompting BBC commentator Kenneth Wolstenholme to exclaim: 'Why didn't he just do that two minutes ago?'

Charlie George is now the most famous goalscorer from that final, though Heighway went on to score a goal and finish on the winning side in 1974, and set up two of the goals in Liverpool's first European Cup victory in 1977.

But the 1970-71 season was certainly a memorable one for Heighway - in September he became the Republic of Ireland's youngest international when he played against Poland, aged 22.

He stayed at Anfield through much of their European glory years, leaving in 1981. Heighway was never a prolific scorer, but he created so many goals down the years for those around him. He ended his playing career with the Minnesota Kicks and was so impressed with the American way of life he stayed on to coach youngsters, until he was head-hunted for his old club by Kenny Dalglish in 1988.

'I wasn't all that interested, initially,' he said. 'I was happy living in Clearwater, and as a family we had more or less emigrated. But Kenny sold me on his policy switch. He said the club wanted to rededicate themselves to youth because transfer prices were becoming prohibitive, and he needed a coach to take charge.'

Robbie Fowler, Steve McManaman, Michael Owen, Dominic Matteo and others are testimony to the success of the Liverpool youth scheme, and from a poky office at Melwood, Heighway has now graduated to running a state-of-the-art Academy in Kirkby, intended to produce Anfield stars for years to come. A far cry from the situation that confronted him on his return to England.

'Things have improved immeasurably since then. Maybe I was spoiled in America, but I can still remember the shock of coming back to Liverpool and discovering that a small club like Clearwater was better organised at youth level than most of the biggest professional clubs in England.'

fields.headline: 'I've been a fan myself and I feel you're giving them something back. If you score and just run back to the halfway line it's absolute bollocks'
fields.standfirst:
The Gunners' 1971 Cup hero Charlie George
FA Cup Final special
fields.trailText: Amy Lawrence on the Gunners' 1971 Cup hero Charlie George
fields.body:
Football supporters will forgive talented players most indiscretions so long as they try. So long as they have pride in the shirt. For Arsenal fans and Charlie George this was a given. He was one of them; he had the skills, he had the swagger, he had the Arsenal tattooed on his heart, and he made that dreamlike, quantum leap off the terrace and on to the pitch.

George was wonderfully unique. Although he wasn't the only elusive maverick floating through football in the early 1970s, he was the only one who played for the team he had loved ever since he could remember loving anything. In the summer of 1953, with England in the throes of street parties to honour the Queen's coronation, George the toddler went out to play dressed up as Jimmy Logie, the wizard who crafted Arsenal's attack of the day. Little did Mr and Mrs George realise that their boy would one day become the King of Highbury.

A vintage shot from football's 1971 collection of gimmicky photographs depicts George in full regalia - shimmering robe over his kit, jewelled crown atop his lank hair, sceptre in one hand and FA Cup in the other. His expression is something to behold, a cross between, 'What the 'eck's this all about, I quite like being a king, as it goes', and 'This is a right laugh.' Nothing fazed him. 'I wasn't really a shy person,' he says, master of understatement. 'I never felt out of place. I've always mixed with people a bit older than myself and as a kid I always played with older people so I never felt inferior. Once you step over the line you get a buzz, you know? In a funny way it's a cockiness from knowing what I could do when I played football and I always had confidence in my own ability. There wasn't anything I didn't think I could do with a ball. That was my philosophy.'

He breezed into the dressing room oozing the cheek of the Artful Dodger and the arrogance of Top Cat. Not only did he enter into the banter immediately, he started plenty. 'He was just Charlie off the terraces when he was walking about in an Arsenal blazer,' remembers Frank McLintock, the skipper of that 1971 Double-winning side. 'If he didn't like somebody he'd let them know, You're a tosspot and all that, and he never lost his brashness at all. He was a right outspoken sod, but that's what made him a special player.'

His social impact was nothing compared to the shockwaves he caused at the training ground. Some of the experienced pros had never seen anything like him. His party piece was to launch the ball into orbit, eye it indifferently as it sped down, then kill it stone dead. A doddle. He had swank, he had subtlety of touch, he had substantial thighs, assets that fused to give him the power to unleash those trademark missile shots. George sprayed passes around with the ease of Beckenbauer, knocked volleys over his shoulder and into the roof of the net like Best, swerved past challenges like Cruyff... McLintock and McNab glanced at each other in amazement... and then he swore like a trooper. Good old Charlie, all the skill in the world and none of the sophistication.

George's distinctive style made a statement: I don't care, I don't pose, I just let it all happen. Without even trying the rebel was perpetuating his own myth. But strip away the layers of bravado and way down in the pit of George's stomach was evidence of nerves. 'I used to be physically sick before games,' he admits. 'Frank said to me years ago, "I know there's a lot of pressure on you because you're a local lad." I never actually felt it but I couldn't eat before a game because I used to burn a lot of acid up in my body. Once I was out there I was OK. I've never felt in awe of anybody, never ever in my life. There was nothing that any footballer could do that I never felt I could do. Whether that was right or wrong it's a good attitude to have.'

His unwavering belief endeared him to his team-mates. If he was having an average game compared to the grandiose heights he could achieve, Bob Wilson used to get hold of him at half-time, urging him, coaxing him, pushing him to find the magic. 'He had an amazing ability, even if he'd played badly, to remember the one great ball he'd hit,' says Wilson. 'Charlie had the strut at 19.'

Don Howe, who coached that Arsenal side, was full of praise for George. 'They talk today about these players dropping off - Zola, Cantona, Bergkamp - we were doing that 30 years ago with Charlie George,' he says. 'And he was superb. Yes, he scored great goals, but he was the crucial link between the back and the front as well.' As for Charlie, he couldn't care less where he played as long as he played. 'I could play either up front or midfield. It didn't matter, I always felt football was easy. If you gave me the ball I would do the work. I only wanted the ball, then I would do whatever you wanted me to do with it.'.

The FA Cup was the perfect platform for Arsenal's virtuoso. The roulette wheel of knockout competition stimulated his creativity and stoked his con viction. Under the spotlight of the big occasion reputations are created or killed. With each round in 1971, so George's reputation grew. Having got back into the scoring groove in the fourth round against Portsmouth, he netted winners in the next two stages. And a couple of them were the kind of gems only George could unearth.

Maine Road was not the most appetising draw for Arsenal, especially on a surface like a swimming pool. 'I don't know whether Malcolm Allison had flooded it at the time, I think they had a couple of players injured,' George recalls, 'but when it rains in Manchester... it rains.' The game was played under the floodlights on a ghastly night. McLintock felt it was time to play mind games with the joker in Arsenal's pack, just in case he wasn't feeling inspired. 'I hope you play well tonight, Charlie,' warned the captain. 'I was talking to Malcolm Allison and he doesn't rate you at all. He reckons you can only last about 30 minutes, he thinks you'll die a death - typical cockney.'

Charlie turned the air in the dressing room blue, then promptly went out and upstaged City's stars Franny Lee, Colin Bell and Mike Summerbee, with a stellar performance that included two goals. McLintock, of course, hadn't spoken to City's coach before the game and he took great delight in telling Allison and George afterwards.

The semi-final pitted Arsenal against Stoke, the team whose 5-0 demolition job had rocked the them in the league earlier in the season. Nightmare start. Two-nil down at half-time and on the way to another drubbing. What's more, both goals were gifts, one from Peter Storey and the other from George with a wayward backpass. It was an afternoon ruled by nerves and Arsenal were losing theirs. In the dressing room at half-time crockery was smashed, tempers soared, and Arsenal emerged refocused. Peter Storey demonstrated all his deft talent with a fierce, long-range drive to make it 2-1, then all his deadly nerve with an injury-time penalty. The Double dream remained alive.

The replay was a one-sided affair. No nerves this time. And George soon got over Hillsborough clanger: 'The first touch I got was a 60-yard backpass to the goalkeeper. I was very conscious of what had happened in the previous game and I did it just to prove to myself that everything was going to be all right. You get over something. You made a mistake but you've got to get on with it, you're not going to change the course of history because whatever's happened happened. We won the game 2-0, quite comfortably in the end.'

George always was something of an enigma. How else do you begin to explain his movements after the league title-winning night at White Hart Lane? The quintessential Arsenal man, born in Islington and bred on the North Bank, having just played in the most liberating derby any Gooner could ever witness... what did he do after their 1-0 win, when the team coach drew up at Southgate? He hopped on the Tube and went home. The lads hit the boozer, his old man and fiancée were out looking for him to help their favourite boy paint the town red and white. And Charlie went home. He just felt like it, so he did.

Enigmatic? I'll say. Little wonder moody pubescents all over London wished they could be like Charlie George. And frivolous nymphettes wished they could be with Charlie George. And bashful housewives wished they could mother Charlie George. And that's before even mentioning what Charlie meant to the Arsenal faithful. He was one of them, and he was living out all of their fantasies.

In the midst of the madness in the visitors' dressing room at White Hart Lane God knows how anyone heard the telephone ring. 'Bill Shankly here, put that man Bertie Mee on the line,' commanded football's mastermind. 'A tremendous performance Bertie, magnificent. You may even give us a game on Saturday.' Mee, we can safely assume, was in the mood to take on anyone. And Charlie was in the mood to go home to his mum and dad's flat. Were you saving yourself for something Charlie? 'I don't know what for,' he says, with a teasing laugh.

Shankly wasn't the only one to indulge in mental trickery. 'We got him back at the final,' Bob Wilson recalls. 'As we'd been at Wembley twice before, we knew that because of the drill with the Royal party they keep you waiting in the tunnel with the cameras on you for far too long. You can wet yourself there, some players really lose it. We refrained from going out. The FA official knocked on the door. "Sorry, we're not ready," said Bertie. "Just doing my team talk." The second knock and Frank made out he had a problem with a stud. The Liverpool lads were out there for ages and Shanks knew exactly what we were up to. We saw him fuming when we came out.'

George, having vomited his jitters out in the dressing-room lavatory, was as imperious as ever. His first match at Wembley was beamed to 400 million around the world. 'I wasn't nervous. I just wanted to go and get started so we could get the game over, win the Cup and go and have a drink,' he says.

Liverpool got their noses in front through Steve Heighway in extra time. Then play Brian Moore: 'Radford, back over his head. Kelly is right in there, playing much more as a striker in this extra time... AND IT'S THERE! GEORGE GRAHAM! It's George Gra ham who got the touch and makes it 1-1!' In fact it was George Graham who sold the greatest dummy of all time, kidding everyone in the stadium that he'd got the final touch. 'It didn't matter, we'd scored,' grins Charlie. 'Pushing forward and trying to score in extra time is very difficult. It was so hot, like a cauldron. The heat was so intense it was unbelievable. The day absolutely drains you.

'The 90-minute period I've played as well as anyone, but in extra time I was tired. I swapped over and moved up front, I think Geordie [Armstrong] dropped back. I was a little bit knackered but I could always find the strength to hit one from 20-30 yards. It was never a problem. It was easy for me to hit a ball, no matter how far.' Brian Moore: 'Graham. Radford. Charlie George. Radford. Oh, Charlie George, who can hit 'em... OH WHAT A GREAT GOAL CHARLIE GEORGE! WELL WHAT A FABULOUS GOAL BY GEORGE! CLEMENCE HAD NO CHANCE WITH THAT!'

It was stunning. And what followed was equally staggering: Charlie was floored by his own knockout blow. It remains one of the game's enduring images, imprinted on the minds of football fans regardless of club. There is Charlie, a symbol of everything that is precocious about football and life, lying flat out with his arms outstretched on the Wembley turf. The best thing about it is the look on his face. It's as if he's saying, 'Well what did you all expect? It just happened, didn't it?'

Charlie is as casual about it as ever. 'I've been a supporter myself. I always feel you're giving them something back. If you score and just run back to the halfway line it's absolute bollocks. There's no feeling. I always felt the rapport with the crowd. I enjoyed it - if you don't there's no point in playing.'

That night Charlie didn't slope off home - he went mad. Critics say George never fulfilled his true potential. He could have ended up playing for Barcelona. He ended up playing for Dundee United. He shrugs. 'I could have been a better player I suppose, people seem to have said that about me. I'm quite happy about my life, I don't complain about anything, just sort of get on with it.'

So George drifted about, from one shenanigan to the next. One of his fingers is missing, which he claims is the result of a lawnmower accident. It's debatable whether even the lawnmower believes him. He always was a rogue.

Now he's back where he started, a face going about his business in Islington, watching the Arsenal on Saturdays. Wherever he goes he's still patted on the back for that goal. If you had a pound for every time it's been mentioned to you, eh Charlie? 'People recognise you scored the goal which enabled the club to win the Double,' he says. 'No matter where I go now - I watch Arsenal approximately 80 per cent of games home and away - I'm recognised and I enjoy it. 'I've been a supporter and then I played and now I'm a supporter again. I only watch Arsenal.'

With each round in 1971, so George's reputation grew. Having got back into the scoring groove in the fourth round against Portsmouth, he netted winners in the next two stages. And a couple of them were the kind of gems only George could unearth. Maine Road was not the most appetising draw for Arsenal, especially on a surface like a swimming pool. 'I don't know whether Malcolm Allison had flooded it at the time, I think they had a couple of players injured,' George recalls, 'but when it rains in Manchester... it rains.' The game was played under the floodlights on a ghastly night. McLintock felt it was time to play mind games with the joker in Arsenal's pack, just in case he wasn't feeling inspired. 'I hope you play well tonight, Charlie,' warned the captain. 'I was talking to Malcolm Allison and he doesn't rate you at all. He reckons you can only last about 30 minutes, he thinks you'll die a death - typical cockney.' Charlie turned the air in the dressing room blue, then promptly went out and upstaged City's stars Franny Lee, Colin Bell and Mike Summerbee, with a stellar performance that included two goals. McLintock, of course, hadn't spoken to City's coach before the game and he took great delight in telling Allison and George afterwards. The semi-final pitted Arsenal against Stoke, the team whose 5-0 demolition job had rocked the them in the league earlier in the season. Nightmare start. Two-nil down at half-time and on the way to another drubbing. What's more, both goals were gifts, one from Peter Storey and the other from George with a wayward backpass. It was an afternoon ruled by nerves and Arsenal were losing theirs. In the dressing room at half-time crockery was smashed, tempers soared, and Arsenal emerged refocused. Peter Storey demonstrated all his deft talent with a fierce, long-range drive to make it 2-1, then all his deadly nerve with an injury-time penalty. The Double dream remained alive. The replay was a one-sided affair. No nerves this time. And George soon got over Hillsborough clanger: 'The first touch I got was a 60-yard backpass to the goalkeeper. I was very conscious of what had happened in the previous game and I did it just to prove to myself that everything was going to be all right. You get over something. You made a mistake but you've got to get on with it, you're not going to change the course of history because whatever's happened happened. We won the game 2-0, quite comfortably in the end.' George always was something of an enigma. How else do you begin to explain his movements after the league title-winning night at White Hart Lane? The quintessential Arsenal man, born in Islington and bred on the North Bank, having just played in the most liberating derby any Gooner could ever witness... what did he do after their 1-0 win, when the team coach drew up at Southgate? He hopped on the Tube and went home. The lads hit the boozer, his old man and fiancée were out looking for him to help their favourite boy paint the town red and white. And Charlie went home. He just felt like it, so he did. Enigmatic? I'll say. Little wonder moody pubescents all over London wished they could be like Charlie George. And frivolous nymphettes wished they could be with Charlie George. And bashful housewives wished they could mother Charlie George. And that's before even mentioning what Charlie meant to the Arsenal faithful. He was one of them, and he was living out all of their fantasies. In the midst of the madness in the visitors' dressing room at White Hart Lane God knows how anyone heard the telephone ring. 'Bill Shankly here, put that man Bertie Mee on the line,' commanded football's mastermind. 'A tremendous performance Bertie, magnificent. You may even give us a game on Saturday.' Mee, we can safely assume, was in the mood to take on anyone. And Charlie was in the mood to go home to his mum and dad's flat. Were you saving yourself for something Charlie? 'I don't know what for,' he says, with a teasing laugh. Shankly wasn't the only one to indulge in mental trickery. 'We got him back at the final,' Bob Wilson recalls. 'As we'd been at Wembley twice before, we knew that because of the drill with the Royal party they keep you waiting in the tunnel with the cameras on you for far too long. You can wet yourself there, some players really lose it. We refrained from going out. The FA official knocked on the door. "Sorry, we're not ready," said Bertie. "Just doing my team talk." The second knock and Frank made out he had a problem with a stud. The Liverpool lads were out there for ages and Shanks knew exactly what we were up to. We saw him fuming when we came out.' George, having vomited his jitters out in the dressing-room lavatory, was as imperious as ever. His first match at Wembley was beamed to 400 million around the world. 'I wasn't nervous. I just wanted to go and get started so we could get the game over, win the Cup and go and have a drink,' he says. Liverpool got their noses in front through Steve Heighway in extra time. Then play Brian Moore: 'Radford, back over his head. Kelly is right in there, playing much more as a striker in this extra time... AND IT'S THERE! GEORGE GRAHAM! It's George Gra ham who got the touch and makes it 1-1!' In fact it was George Graham who sold the greatest dummy of all time, kidding everyone in the stadium that he'd got the final touch. 'It didn't matter, we'd scored,' grins Charlie. 'Pushing forward and trying to score in extra time is very difficult. It was so hot, like a cauldron. The heat was so intense it was unbelievable. The day absolutely drains you. 'The 90-minute period I've played as well as anyone, but in extra time I was tired. I swapped over and moved up front, I think Geordie [Armstrong] dropped back. I was a little bit knackered but I could always find the strength to hit one from 20-30 yards. It was never a problem. It was easy for me to hit a ball, no matter how far.' Brian Moore: 'Graham. Radford. Charlie George. Radford. Oh, Charlie George, who can hit 'em... OH WHAT A GREAT GOAL CHARLIE GEORGE! WELL WHAT A FABULOUS GOAL BY GEORGE! CLEMENCE HAD NO CHANCE WITH THAT!' It was stunning. And what followed was equally staggering: Charlie was floored by his own knockout blow. It remains one of the game's enduring images, imprinted on the minds of football fans regardless of club. There is Charlie, a symbol of everything that is precocious about football and life, lying flat out with his arms outstretched on the Wembley turf. The best thing about it is the look on his face. It's as if he's saying, 'Well what did you all expect? It just happened, didn't it?' Charlie is as casual about it as ever. 'I've been a supporter myself. I always feel you're giving them something back. If you score and just run back to the halfway line it's absolute bollocks. There's no feeling. I always felt the rapport with the crowd. I enjoyed it - if you don't there's no point in playing.' That night Charlie didn't slope off home - he went mad. Critics say George never fulfilled his true potential. He could have ended up playing for Barcelona. He ended up playing for Dundee United. He shrugs. 'I could have been a better player I suppose, people seem to have said that about me. I'm quite happy about my life, I don't complain about anything, just sort of get on with it.' So George drifted about, from one shenanigan to the next. One of his fingers is missing, which he claims is the result of a lawnmower accident. It's debatable whether even the lawnmower believes him. He always was a rogue. Now he's back where he started, a face going about his business in Islington, watching the Arsenal on Saturdays. Wherever he goes he's still patted on the back for that goal. If you had a pound for every time it's been mentioned to you, eh Charlie? 'People recognise you scored the goal which enabled the club to win the Double,' he says. 'No matter where I go now - I watch Arsenal approximately 80 per cent of games home and away - I'm recognised and I enjoy it. 'I've been a supporter and then I played and now I'm a supporter again. I only watch Arsenal.'

webTitle: Football: Can Liverpool do the treble?

fields.headline: From anorexia to medal binge?
fields.standfirst: Can Liverpool do the treble?
fields.trailText: Can Liverpool do the treble?
fields.body:
The theory is simple enough. At the start of the season, as every player will tell you and the manager has grown tired of stressing, Liverpool's priority was to qualify for a Champions League place. Becoming the first Anfield side to reach three cup finals in the same season was not on anyone's agenda, but that is how it has turned out. The club's priority remains the same, and the general consensus now is that Liverpool will take what comes in the FA and Uefa Cup finals but would be devastated to miss out on a top-three Premiership finish. Yet being blasé about cup finals is easier said than done, as Michael Owen is not afraid to admit.

'It's true the league has been the priority all along, and still is,' he said. 'But the closer you get to a cup final the more it takes precedence over anything else. Now these two finals are so close, we can't wait to play in them.'

It should not be forgotten that Liverpool are not quite Manchester United yet. They no longer reach FA Cup finals every other year or thereabouts, and are not so familiar with the old tin pot as to treat it with contempt. Indeed, only Robbie Fowler and the injured Jamie Redknapp still survive from the side that lost to Manchester United in their last final appearance five years ago, so regarding one of English football's great occasions as a mere distraction is a tall order for the present Liverpool side.

Especially its English contingent. Vladimir Smicer is happy enough to admit he only picked up on the significance of Cardiff on Saturday from the animation he observes in his team-mates. 'Back home in the Czech Republic, more people are impressed that we have reached the final of the Uefa Cup,' Smicer said. 'The FA Cup is not such a big thing there, and I didn't realise how big it is here at first, but I do now.'

The significance of Cardiff is not lost on Owen and Fowler, who are anxious to bulk out medal collections which look anorexic in comparison to those of comparable Liverpool players of the recent past. 'Losing in 1996 was the worst feeling I've ever had as a professional footballer, and it has taken a long time to get to another FA Cup final to try to make amends,' Fowler said. 'I don't want to say which of the two remaining finals I'd rather win. Call me greedy, but I'd like to win both of them.'

As captain Fowler would set some sort of record if he gets to lift all three trophies, whereas Owen, after sitting out the entire Worthington Cup final, would simply be glad of a game. One way or another, rotation always crops up in discussions with Liverpool strikers. There are three of them, four if you include Jari Litmanen and five if you count Nick Barmby, so someone always has to miss out. Gérard Houllier can give you chapter and verse on the realities of the modern, 14-man game - from substitutes winning the Champions League for Manchester United to French replacements tipping the balance in the Euro 2000 final against Italy, not forgetting his own match winners from the bench in the semi-final against Wycombe Wanderers - but no amount of statistics can make a professional player feel happy about missing out on a major final.

'If you are a footballer you want to play,' Owen said. 'I'm no different, and it isn't easy when you're not selected, but we can understand the situation. I don't think many people could play 50 or 60 games in a season [the FA Cup final will be Liverpool's 61st game, with another two still to go], and we've been getting the results, so you can't argue.'

Owen tends to be used sparingly by England these days too, but does not believe Liverpool's squad rotation is affecting his international chances. 'It's a fact of life at most big clubs now, it's not as if we're the only ones doing it,' he said. 'I don't think Sven-Göran Eriksson expects every player to play in every game, in fact he's probably glad to see us get a bit of rest. If you look at Manchester United, they rotate Andy Cole and Teddy Sheringham all the time, but they both made the last England squad. I don't see it as a problem.'

Owen also reports little in the way of problems from his previously troublesome hamstring this season and is as pleased with his fitness as his form. 'Footballers are always vulnerable when they are coming back from injury, trying to get back into the swing of things after a lay-off,' he said. 'That's the danger period, and obviously when you are out for a while, it knocks you back a bit. That's what has been happening to me, I've had a few ups and downs, and I just need to get back to a consistent level. When I've been 100 per cent fit all year I've played well. I might not be quite there yet, but I was pleased with my form the other day against Bradford - the more I play the stronger I feel.'

Latest intelligence from Soho Square is that Eriksson thinks Owen may be the answer to England's longstanding problem on the left. The striker does not dismiss the suggestion out of hand. 'I think I've scored more goals with my left foot this season that ever before, certainly more than with my head or my right foot,' he said. 'So maybe it's worth a go, I can't say until I've tried it. I'm only 21, I don't think I'm the finished article yet. It's possible that given the chance I could become more of an all round player, I don't know.'

Liverpool will be talking to Owen at the end of the season about an extension to his contract, which still has two years to run. 'There's no need to go into all that now, except to say I definitely want to carry on being a Liverpool player,' Owen said. That should be all right then. 'We are happy and proud to have Michael Owen at this club,' commented Houllier. 'We would definitely like to keep him.'

webTitle: Amy Lawrence on Ashley Cole

fields.headline: Boy Cole comes up a peg or two
fields.standfirst:
Arsene Wenger only moved him into the senior dressing room this season, but Ashley Cole is playing like an old master
FA Cup Final special
fields.trailText: Arsene Wenger only moved him into the senior dressing room this season, but Ashley Cole is playing like an old master
fields.body:
At a football awards dinner three years ago Arsène Wenger sat next to an agent who had a number of young Arsenal players on his books and they small-talked away - this was pleasure, not business - until the time came to make their farewells. 'Goodnight Mr Wenger,' said the agent. 'You just look after the boy Cole,' was Wenger's loaded reply.

No young prodigy ever comes with a guarantee that he will make the grade, but those in the know were in no doubt Ashley Cole had all the credentials. That said, nobody expected his rise to be quite this meteoric: frequently chosen ahead of a Brazilian international for his club, an outstanding performer in the Champions League, in comfortable possession of his country's No3 shirt - all before he has even thought about moving out of his mum's house or upgrading his faithful Renault Clio. He won't even allow himself to admit he belongs in the first team yet. After all, Wenger only told him to move his gear into the senior dressing room at the start of the season.

'I really didn't expect all this,' he says, the thrill still genuine as he contemplates his whirlwind arrival. 'Even training with these guys, let along playing with them, is a great experience for me. They have taken me in, told me I'm good enough to be here, they are encouraging me, and hopefully I'll stay here for a long time.' He wants to emulate the 13-year stranglehold one of his heroes, Nigel Winterburn, put on the left-back position at Arsenal. Before the veteran left for West Ham last summer, the pair used to watch each other: Cole studying Winterburn to try to pick up tips, and Winterburn observing Cole to give his heir apparent a boost and pointers to improve his game.

The apprentice takes after the old master. Like Winterburn, he is as dependable and tenacious as a well-trained guard dog seeing off unwanted visitors. Who needs experience when you have talent and temperament? The 20-year-old Cole, who handled provocative taunting in Valencia, and a barrage of bottles and lipstick cases in Albania, seems blissfully immune to pressure. 'You can't let anything intimidate you or it will effect your game,' he says. 'You really can't get scared when you are a player. I've learned that you have to be strong, you can't let anything overawe you.'

Cole's increasing aplomb is pretty bad luck for Silvinho, whose status as Winterburn's ideal replacement is eroding with every game his young rival at left back notches up. The friendly competition between the two is intriguing and while they currently have a mutual appreciation society, they won't happily share one spot in the team in the long term. During the course of the season Wenger's favour has noticeably shifted. Silvinho was undisputed first choice at the start, Cole has made three times as many starts since the New Year. Not once has he let his side down. 'Ashley does not need people saying, "Do this" or "Go there". He knows, he knows,' says Silvinho, admiringly.

Defensively, the snappy and perceptive Cole has the edge and, although Silvinho is blessed with greater offensive trickery, Cole - whose promise as a prolific striker first drew Arsenal's attention - intends to emulate the best of the Brazilian left-backs. 'I like Roberto Carlos, the way he attacks, and I'd love to have a strike like him,' he drools. 'He's got natural talent, but I think if you train hard enough you can be nearly as good as that.' Music to Arsenal ears, as anyone who has seen their stray set pieces recently will testify. And England won't be discouraging him either.

Liam Brady, Arsenal's head of youth development, believes there is a lot more to come: 'Ashley has self-belief but crucially, he believes in himself quietly. That is one of the vital ingredients for progress. He has no airs and graces and no ego. He's under Arsène's wing now and Arsène has a good track record of helping players to add to their game.'

And what of those criticisms that his right foot is non-existent? 'Highly talented players don't need a right foot, they use the outside of the left foot very effectively instead. Have you ever seen Roberto Carlos or Maradona use their right foot? Ashley knows he has to work on his right foot but he's only 20 for God's sake.'

Brady is protective of Cole, the symbol that the youth programme he set up five years ago is bearing fruit. Looking at improvements in that area by Manchester United, Liverpool and latterly Leeds, was crucial (before Cole, the last youngster to make a lasting impression at Highbury was Ray Parlour nine years ago). 'Ashley is an inspiration to the other boys,' adds Brady. 'We tell them he didn't have any guarantees, but he relished the challenge and now look where he is. In the Arsenal first team and in the England team. It's an incredible story.'

Three years ago he was in the party of young pros taken to Wembley to watch the first team in the FA Cup final, remembering, 'All the reserves and youths went to watch, and we won. Good eh?' This time, the club have organised a train to take their youngsters to Cardiff and Cole will think of them when he's on the coach to the Millennium Stadium. He may now socialise with Thierry Henry and Sylvain Wiltord, but he still hangs out with the friends he left behind a year ago, young players striving to make an impression and follow in his eager footsteps. Says Cole: 'I try to help them out, go to the session with them and tell them how important it is to train well. That's what people used to tell me.' Ashley Cole, a mere slip of a lad, almost sounds like the old man of the Arsenal back four.

webTitle: Down - but already making plans to return

fields.headline: Down - but already making plans to return
fields.trailText: So that's it. Coventry City are down from the Premiership and we will be playing our football in the Nationwide next season. And I will be labelled as the manager who took them out of the top league for the first time since 1967.
fields.byline: Gordon Strachan is defiant after relegation heartbreak
fields.body:
So that's it. Coventry City are down from the Premiership and we will be playing our football in the Nationwide next season. And I will be labelled as the manager who took them out of the top league for the first time since 1967.

Disappointed, of course I am, but we have to live with that. And live with it we will. Not only that, I am determined to make our exile from the elite as short as possible. I have to say that defeat was hard to take at Aston Villa because we took the fight to them so well. In the end we just could not hold on to our lead. But boy, we tried.

For obvious reasons, it is difficult for any club to face up to the possibility of going down. But there is no point in burying one's head in the sand and, to give Coventry the best chance of recovering from such a setback, our chairman Bryan Richardson and myself started preparing a relegation contingency plan almost six weeks ago.

This is not the first time we have gone down this road. The other occasion was four seasons ago, when our Nationwide League blueprint was rendered unnecessary through that remarkable 2-1 win at Tottenham which enabled us to retain our Premiership place on the last day. Had we gone down then, I think that the extent to which we had prepared ourselves would have given us a good chance of quickly getting back. It is the same this time.

The major problem for relegated clubs concerns the vast financial gap between the Premiership and Nationwide League. The headache of maintaining the contracts of your top players on a much lower income is particularly pronounced in the case of comparatively small clubs such as Coventry. It's Catch 22, in that while it is necessary to reduce one's wage bill, it is generally the highest-earners - and your most saleable playing assets - who can provide the key to getting you back into the top flight.

In that respect, Bryan Richardson and I are agreed that even in the First Division, it will be essential for us to retain as many of our quality players as we can. I say 'even' because at one time, this level tended to be looked upon as a place where skill could not properly flourish. Under the old League set-up, it was often said that teams could not 'play' their way out of the Second Division - they had to claw their way out. I had personal experience of this during my short spell in the Second Division with Leeds under Howard Wilkinson. Basically, we looked upon our approach as a 'horses for courses' one. One only has to look at the two teams who have gained automatic promotion this season - Fulham and Blackburn - to appreciate the point. Both are excellent footballing teams who hardly look as if they will need extensive surgery in order to look the part in the Premiership.

As I have said, we would not have been in this position had we been able to sign John earlier. I cannot believe any team have experienced as many missed chances as we have. John, in addition to overcoming this problem, has also lifted the whole team through his overall play.

Craig Bellamy, John's Welsh international col league, has benefited from his presence as much as anyone. webTitle: FA Cup's final fling

fields.headline: FA Cup's final fling
fields.standfirst:
In 1971, Arsenal and Liverpool served up a memorable Wembley occasion. They meet once more with the competition in decline, but there's a way to make it great again
FA Cup Final special
fields.trailText: It was one of the most memorable FA Cup finals, if not one of the best. After 90 goalless minutes, Arsenal overhauled Steve Heighway's near-poster for Liverpool through Eddie Kelly/George Graham's dribbler and Charlie George's scorcher to claim the Double in extra time. Thirty years on, how the English game needs another day to remember from the same two proud, prestigious clubs.
fields.body:
It was one of the most memorable FA Cup finals, if not one of the best. After 90 goalless minutes, Arsenal overhauled Steve Heighway's near-poster for Liverpool through Eddie Kelly/George Graham's dribbler and Charlie George's scorcher to claim the Double in extra time. Thirty years on, how the English game needs another day to remember from the same two proud, prestigious clubs.

There was a time when nostalgia wasn't so popular. Those were the days. The Cup has always had a natural resonance, but to look back in anorak now seems an even more popular pastime. Could it be because the past offers comfort as we see the competition's status annually eroding, like the English coastline by global warming and rising seas, when confronted by European footballís tide of commercialism?

It is hard to bear for those of us brought up to believe that the FA Cup knocks spots off all other knockout competitions, that it matters more than any similar domestic competition, its glorious final moments transmitted to a waiting world and etched forever in our consciousness. Even we devotees and jumpers-for-goalposts traditional ists are beginning to have our doubts, however.

The feeling has grown, coinciding with the growth of the Champions League, that the tournament has become a transported sideshow, rather than showpiece and last leg of the dual attraction, under the Twin Towers, of an English season. It seems but one small step up from the League Cup and nowhere near as significant as that third place in the Premiership. Third. Who used to remember who came third? Even losing Cup semi-finalists were more easily recalled.

Remember how it used to be on Cup final day? A quick trawl through the papers - 'It's our Cup, says Shanks', for the northern edition; 'It's our Cup - Bertie Mee', for the south. Then the mid-morning TV kick-off, with the players in the team hotel ('Ooh, they look nervous'), followed by Meet the Players' Wives ('She's never a natural blonde, that one'). To top it all off, Tarby's Bar, where the professional scouser would stage a mock argument with Kenny Lynch. Come to think of it, some things have changed for the better.

And then, when the Cup was won, the sadness that the season was over would hit you. That won't happen this year, of course. The FA, grasping at any idea to recover its trophy's lustre rather than having a strategy, fit it in between the last two league games, rather than as finale. Even this concedes that it was becoming an afterthought in need of rethinking. You can bet the players of all but the two teams involved are cheesed off; they are normally long gone, watching - if vaguely interested - in some Florida bar with cable television.

When Adam Crozier assumed the post of chief executive at the FA, he vowed to restore the Cup's place in English footballing culture. He and they have made some progress, such as in returning rounds to their time-honoured dates, but the issue of replays within the same week seems to have gone away. This year, for the third time, no replay of the final is scheduled if the scores are level after 120 minutes. Penalties will settle. That just cannot be just and proper - even if both clubs, their minds elsewhere, probably prefer it. And what a sad comment that is.

The FA must be approaching this year's final with some trepidation. In the build-up, the issue of Wembley has returned to haunt them ahead of their first foray away from north London in 78 years, apart from the 1970. It shows how fanciful was the notion that this country could put on a World Cup, beset as it is by the current no-can-do mentality.

Naively undeterred, last week the FA confirmed that they would like to host the World Club Championship of 2003. Quite apart from the fact that they have little chance, with Spain hosting the next tournament and the subsequent one likely to go to another continent, they would be better employed in putting their own house in order. That, besides the FA Cup, includes the grassroots game and should be sufficient call on their time, money and personnel in the current climate.

The first thing is to get next Saturday's event right and negotiate its literal pitfalls. The Millennium Stadium pitch was relaid only last week, such poor condition has it been in. Imagine something going wrong next week - chunks of turf having failed to take, for example - and holes appearing when Martin Keown slips Emile Heskey an early calling card. What a message to the world about supposedly open-for-business Britain that would be.

And please let us not have one of those delayed kick-offs that seem to occur only in this country; unless, that is, public safety is an issue. The pressure will be on an aged infrastructure to transport fans to and from Cardiff but the signs have not so far been good, with many attending previous events reporting nightmare journeys.

You even wonder - and hope you are wrong even to suggest it - whether fans themselves are too fussed these days about the Cup final, especially when the second feeling after getting a ticket is anxiety about how you might get there and back. We can dismiss those jealous Manchester United fans who think next week's game a contest of also-rans, but it seems that even Arsenal's and Liverpool's have caught the mood of their clubs' managers and believe Champions League qualification to be paramount.

That, given modern circumstances, may well be the professional duty of Arsène Wenger and Gérard Houllier. At least we are fortunate that both men, though coming from a country where the cup is indeed small pommes de terre, do appear to recognise the place that the FA Cup holds - or held - in this nation's heart. Wenger quickly saw it as his Arsenal won the Double. Houllier saw it as far back as the 1960s when a student in Liverpool and an avid Koppite.

As for the players, there are in this year's final just about enough homegrown ones who cling to the concept of the Cup's magic - in Tony Adams and Gary McAllister, for example - and overseas ones who understand its significance - Dennis Bergkamp, injured for Arsenal's last appearance. You can only hope that the overseas Cup virgins in both camps appreciate the vibe from them. For as well as a generation of young supporters growing up not cherishing the Cup, we are in danger of cre ating a new breed of managers and players, even English ones, for whom the Cup is low on the priority list.

It used to be that every player wanted to make the final line-up. In the week before, they would be on tenterhooks and talk of their hopes. Groin strains would be back-page leads. In the week after, the spurned would speak of their anguish. Next week, we may even see some - rotation - given that Liverpool have the Uefa Cup final five days later.

So for fans, managers and players, if the FA are serious about making the Cup matter again, rather than presiding over its disintegration into the consolation prize for top clubs' reserve teams and middling Premiership sides, there is a simple solution in their own hands.

It is, after all, within their gift to award the third Champions League place to the FA Cup winners, rather than the third-placed in the Premiership. If you can't beat them, join them. Let's try the idea and see the effect on the big clubs and the knock-on benefits for the smaller ones.

In the meantime, let us hope for the drama of 1971. In recent years, Middlesbrough, Newcastle United (twice) and Aston Villa have failed to turn up for the final. As spring threatens to arrive to replace a gloom-riddled winter of discontent and disaster, the English game, the country indeed, needs to put its best foot forward.
