webTitle: Feisty Leeds face one more fiesta in Europe

fields.headline: Feisty Leeds face one more fiesta in Europe
fields.trailText: David O'Leary was in surprisingly chipper mood after Wednesday's goalless draw with Valencia; possibly because it was his forty-third birthday, maybe because Leeds United had once again managed to live with supposedly superior opponents, but most likely because 90 minutes from a Champions League final with no goals conceded is not a bad place to be for a naive young manager with no previous experience.
fields.body:
David O'Leary was in surprisingly chipper mood after Wednesday's goalless draw with Valencia; possibly because it was his forty-third birthday, maybe because Leeds United had once again managed to live with supposedly superior opponents, but most likely because 90 minutes from a Champions League final with no goals conceded is not a bad place to be for a naive young manager with no previous experience.

Real Madrid would swap places with Leeds for a start. Not to mention Manchester United and Arsenal. It is worth remembering too that when Manchester United won the thing two years ago, they travelled to Turin for the second leg of their semi-final with a 1-1 scoreline from the visit of Juventus to Old Trafford. The Italian team's superiority that night had been overwhelming, and Manchester United were grateful for the late Ryan Giggs goal, which gave them a semblance of parity and a glimmer of hope, but 1-1 was not a result that left anyone but Alex Ferguson looking forward to the second leg.

'We deserved criticism after being thoroughly outplayed in the first half,' the United manager said. 'But it was a different game when we denied space to Zinedine Zidane, and I was genuinely optimistic about going to Turin.'

Rightly, as it turned out, because although Juve scored twice in the first 15 minutes, United found the away goals rule counted heavily in their favour. Once Roy Keane pulled a goal back, Ferguson's team needed only one more to be in a winning position, and in the event scored two. The point is that 0-0 after the home leg is by no means a bad result, indeed some would argue it is the best result of all.

Taking any sort of lead into the second leg always introduces the dilemma of whether to defend it or try to increase it, and invariably alters the way a team performs. Consider the difficulty Leeds experienced in defending a 3-0 advantage in the quarter-final against Deportivo. Leeds don't have to think too hard about how to approach their second leg, they just have to score at least as many goals as Valencia to go through. Home advantage must make the Spanish team favourites, but Valencia do not specialise in bunches of goals or swarming attacks like Barcelona, Real Madrid and even Deportivo, and any team capable of winning 4-1 in Anderlecht and scoring twice at the Bernabeu must fancy their chances of finding the net at some stage in the tie.

'I know we are capable of scoring away goals, and if we get just one in the second leg it could make all the difference,' O'Leary said. 'I'm not trying to pretend I wouldn't prefer to be going there with a lead, but at the end of the day we are 90 minutes from the final and the tie isn't over. There is everything to play for, and it could still turn out to be a great night for us in Valencia.'

Leeds can succeed, O'Leary feels, if they play the game and not the occasion. This is the Irishman's current buzz-phrase, old favourites like 'naive young manager' and 'we're just a bunch of nobodies' having been jettisoned for fear of being interpreted as false modesty, and because no one knows what it means. It does sound good though, whether it makes sense or not, and seems to sum up Leeds' admirable determination and distaste for reputations.

As Brian Clough reminded us all on television only last week, the Leeds United who reached the European Cup final in 1975 had a distaste for reputations too. As Clough saw it, the side that Don Revie created and Jimmy Armfield inherited had a distasteful reputation, although it is grossly misleading to characterise Leeds as the only cynical team around at a time when everyone else was playing the beautiful game. There certainly was a ruthless edge to Revie's teams - they did not so much play the game or the occasion as the opponents and the ref eree - but every team featured hard men then and all Leeds were really guilty of was exploiting the laxity of the laws more successfully than anyone else.

Nostalgia is permissible for those days when men were men, pitches were mudheaps and defenders had the referee's blessing to neutralise skill with ill-timed tackles from behind, but you would not watch it for long at today's prices. Fifa's rule changes and refereeing guidelines have quite rightly put the emphasis back on skill, pace and athleticism, and the best teams now are the ones who can cope with the technical demands of the modern game while retaining passion and if possible a combative edge. That is partly why Italian teams have struggled in the Champions League recently, while Spanish and English sides have been in the ascendancy. It is also why Leeds have emerged so strongly in the past couple of years, because O'Leary has managed to combine feistiness and flair more successfully than anyone else.

Manchester United and Arsenal, the last two teams to win the Premiership, both did so with a mixture of aggression and ability, though both have experienced difficulty keeping the former quality under control. It is not just a matter of the disciplinary problems that have beset Keane and Patrick Vieira, more that those players appear to be working to different agendas to their team-mates, who are perceived to be coasting or not pulling their weight. Keane has just imperiled his Old Trafford popularity by going public on this very point, which illustrates how difficult it is for managers to keep an edge to their team without wanting to condone over-aggression.

Whether by luck or good judgment (probably the latter since he made David Batty his first buy and instantly promoted Alan Smith) O'Leary has got this balancing act just right. At Elland Road everybody works, everybody fights, yet Leeds are not cynical or dirty and have some of the most skilful players in the league. A good match for Valencia, in other words. 'We work very hard on getting to know players, getting the best out of them,' O'Leary said. 'I only want workers here, I'm not into kissing mega-stars' rears. My kind of mega-star is one that plays for the team, like Gaizka Mendieta.'

Hector Cuper was suitably impressed. 'We have just played a very ambitious team, but there will be more space for us in Valencia,' he said. 'I don't think Leeds will play such an attacking formation away from home.' Don't bank on it, Hector.

Fifa's rule changes and refereeing guidelines have quite rightly put the emphasis back on skill, pace and athleticism, and the best teams now are the ones who can cope with the technical demands of the modern game while retaining passion and if possible a combative edge. That is partly why Italian teams have struggled in the Champions League recently, while Spanish and English sides have been in the ascendancy. It is also why Leeds have emerged so strongly in the past couple of years, because O'Leary has managed to combine feistiness and flair more successfully than anyone else. Manchester United and Arsenal, the last two teams to win the Premiership, both did so with a mixture of aggression and ability, though both have experienced difficulty keeping the former quality under control. It is not just a matter of the disciplinary problems that have beset Keane and Patrick Vieira, more that those players appear to be working to different agendas to their team-mates, who are perceived to be coasting or not pulling their weight. Keane has just imperiled his Old Trafford popularity by going public on this very point, which illustrates how difficult it is for managers to keep an edge to their team without wanting to condone over-aggression. Whether by luck or good judgment (probably the latter since he made David Batty his first buy and instantly promoted Alan Smith) O'Leary has got this balancing act just right. At Elland Road everybody works, everybody fights, yet Leeds are not cynical or dirty and have some of the most skilful players in the league. A good match for Valencia, in other words. 'We work very hard on getting to know players, getting the best out of them,' O'Leary said. 'I only want workers here, I'm not into kissing mega-stars' rears. My kind of mega-star is one that plays for the team, like Gaizka Mendieta.' Hector Cuper was suitably impressed. 'We have just played a very ambitious team, but there will be more space for us in Valencia,' he said. 'I don't think Leeds will play such an attacking formation away from home.' Don't bank on it, Hector.

webTitle: An end to Biggs' exile

fields.headline: Curry and beer flight set to end Biggs' exile
fields.trailText: A private plane carrying English beer, curry and Marmite is expected to leave Rio de Janeiro today to bring Great Train Robber Ronnie Biggs home after 35 years on the run.
fields.byline: Tony Thompson, Burhan Wazir and Alex Bellos in Rio
fields.body:
A private plane carrying English beer, curry and Marmite is expected to leave Rio de Janeiro today to bring Great Train Robber Ronnie Biggs home after 35 years on the run.

The Foreign Office issued the ailing 71-year-old gangster with an emergency passport allowing him to make a single journey from Brazil to Britain.

A Scotland Yard spokesman said: 'He's still a wanted criminal and action will be taken as soon as he lands.' Biggs, who has suffered two strokes, told the police last week that he wanted to fly home and give himself up.

A spokesman for Brazil's Federal Police said the plane, chartered by the Sun newspaper, was due to leave Rio International Airport at 4pm today.

Foreign Secretary Robin Cook personally checked that there would be no delay in issuing the documentation to let Biggs return.

A Foreign Office spokesman said: 'Clearly if someone is wanted for questioning here and wants to come back and hand themselves in, we would want to ensure there was no delay, and in the event there was none.'

His return, whether to jail, hospital or freedom, will end a half a lifetime on the run for Biggs, who escaped from a London prison in 1965, two years after helping to pull off one of the most famous robberies in British history.

He had served 15 months of a 30-year sentence for his part in the robbery of a Glasgow-to-London mail train.

The raid netted more than £2.6 million and became an instant legend. The robbers bludgeoned the train driver Jack Mills, who died six years later, possibly from the effects of his injuries.

Biggs says he has none of the robbery money. He won the right to live in Brazil permanently after fathering a son, Michael, there 26 years ago. The Brazilian authorities repeatedly denied British requests for his extradition.

Kevin Crace, a family friend, said Biggs was 'very excited' at the prospect of coming home. Crace had spoken to Michael who told him 'the old Biggs sparkle' had appeared in his father's eyes.

The endgame began three weeks ago when Biggs had his telephone cut off. With his health failing and his finances low, he knew only desperate action would keep him alive.

The Sun was happy to oblige: if Biggs returns to Britain to face the music, Michael, who is brokering the deal, will benefit by an estimated £100,000.

After persuading Biggs to email a senior detective at the Yard with the news and pose for a series of photographs as he said 'goodbye' to Rio, the paper was ready to begin publishing its scoop.

The Sun had originally planned to fly Jack Slipper the policeman who arrested him, out to Brazil, reunite the old enemies and photograph the subsequent 'arrest'

The retired detective, now 79, respectfully declined to be part of any such stunt. Despite the offer of financial incentives, the paper still claims the higher moral ground. 'We are proud to be bringing a wanted criminal back to face justice,' said a spokesman.

The deal demands absolutely exclusivity and all of Biggs' friends and family have been sworn to secrecy about the whereabouts of the ageing gangster until his departure. 'He is in a safe location' is all that Crace, who is negotiating the London end of the deal, would say.

fields.headline: Growing up alone - Miyongere's story
fields.standfirst:
'Life in the refugee camp is very hard'

More on the Unicef Appeal:

fields.trailText: 'Life in the refugee camp is very hard': the story of Miyongere, a 17-year old refugee from Burundi now in Tanzania.
fields.body:
At 17 Miyongere lives with her two brothers in a small mud hut house in the Karago camp. She arrived from Burundi after her grandfather passed away. Their parents and older brother were killed in 1996 and since then she has raised her brothers alone. Life in the camp is very hard. Dependent on food aid, with no opportunity for formal work, and with boredom and frustration rife, girls are particularly vulnerable.

Although she does not want to admit it, Miyongere's pregnancy is starting to show. Neighbours openly gossip that she has a bad reputation. A social worked explains that it is sadly common for young girls, trying to support their families, to sleep with men in an effort to supplement their food rations.

Desperation often drives young girls into prostitution and they must also confront daily threats of rape and sexual abuse. Counselling services have been set up in the camp to provide some level of support for women who have been raped, but it is still difficult to ensure that such crimes are properly punished and the women protected.

While collecting firewood, one young girl, who lived alone, was raped by four men. At the time she was pregnant and supposed to be getting married. The fiance left her. Despite the fact that her attackers live in the camp, only one has been arrested. With the help of the counselling and protection services, she is being moved to another camp.

Source: UNICEF Tanzania, from the forthcoming UNICEF UK Growing Up Alone report. Reproduced by kind permission of UNICEF

webTitle: Kevin Mitchell - Crozier's smooth sell

fields.headline: Crozier's smooth sell
fields.standfirst:
If Crozier persuades his clone in 10 Downing Street to save Wembley, he might qualify as salesman of the year, writes Kevin Mitchell.
Observer Wembley special

National stadium online debate: have your say
fields.trailText: If Crozier persuades his clone in 10 Downing Street to save Wembley, he might qualify as salesman of the year, writes Kevin Mitchell.
fields.body:
If anyone can persuade Tony Blair that it is his Government's duty to save Wembley Stadium for the nation - public responsibility of the old Socialist kind - it might, ironically, be Adam Crozier, a modern, young Blairite with practised spinning skills.

In a bunker-like conference room at the Football Association's headquarters on Friday afternoon, the FA's smooth chief executive looked anything but the isolated object of ridicule some commentators had painted him as recently. He wore a forgettably ordinary suit, his crisp, white shirt knotted by an elegant blue tie, as his eyes settled on a clutch of inquisitors from the Sunday papers. Crozier has been a whipping boy for the tabloids since the FA announced they were pulling out of the interminable Wembley fiasco, and he was hitting back, in the nicest possible way.

He was going to set the record straight, to 'move forward', as he said repeatedly in marketspeak, and perhaps a few details 'might be helpful'.

These were selling tricks he'd refined at Saatchi's where, in the power vacuum created by the departure of Charles and Maurice, he was sucked to the top ahead of his time from the relative calm of middle-management. Once installed as joint chief executive, he 'restructured'. But, as a former colleague of Crozier's said yesterday: 'He did it quietly. His talent is people management, client handling. He's intelligent, very low-key, quietly spoken. And he's slick, manipulative, and political. Probably centre-left.'

Sounds like the Prime Minister. Almost.

Crozier is one of those people who doesn't have to know everything about his subject to convince you to buy it. He gets in other people for the detail. (When we asked him how long the FA Cup might be held in Cardiff, he said they had options for 'three or four years'; it was left to his press aide Paul Newman to remind him it was actually five years.)

What Crozier is selling Blair, then, is a partnership between the FA and the Government to turn Wembley into an Olympic-class stadium, primarily used for football but adaptable enough to house other events and 'less well-off sports', as he put it. He thinks they'll buy it. If they don't, Crozier goes back in the public stocks.

'The truth is that every one needs to hold their hands up and say that they made mistakes,' he confided, 'right back to the decisions that were made five or six years ago. This isn't about what's happened in the last few months. This is a result of decisions taken over a long period of time.'

Such moderate rhetoric, such admirable spreading of collective responsibility, comes across as a welcome contrast to the megaphone style of Ken Bates, who stormed away from his disastrous stewardship of the Wembley project, spitting incomprehensible insults in all directions. However, the fact that Crozier has been lobbying - unsuccessfully, it seems - to have Bates removed from the FA's governing board should tell you that, below the calm waters, there is still some fierce paddling going on.

When Crozier arrived at Soho Square, he strongly disagreed with the Bates plan for Wembley. Bates wanted a grandiose, hotel-driven complex, football-only, very much in the image of his Chelsea Village, and he convinced the Culture Secretary, Chris Smith, to drop the platform option that would have been needed for a concealed athletics track. Unfortunately he also succeeded in frightening off the City, who smelled dissent and doubt.

He had no luck in making Kate Hoey toe his line, however, and last week produced one of his least funny soundbites, recommending the Sports Minister should be shot, an unfortunate if unwitting observation only hours after her father had died.

Now, though, young Adam has to get his hands dirty. He has to convince Blair to raid the exchequer if Wembley is not to be ground into the dust. He will play the history card and the Olympic option.

He pointed out that the saga started in 1995 when the FA took over Wembley from the English National Stadium Trust, telling the Conservative Government they could deliver the football but no money. 'And that was agreed between the Government and the FA,' he says.

That much you can't argue with. Also, for all the talk about 'the billions washing about in football', the FA are not the Premier League. Crozier says the Government appreciate the distinction. The FA make their money selling the FA Cup and the England team. Their wider remit is to look after football, from the grassroots to the top; whether or not they have always done that properly is not central to this argument, but Crozier is entitled to point out that this is their overriding responsibility.

Crozier says the old understanding between the FA and the Government persisted until last November. There had been confusion over how to fix Wembley, he conceded, but people were going roughly in the same direction. Then, it went badly wrong in a hurry.

Crozier is probably right when he says the Dome factor didn't help. There were problems with the Millennium Stadium in Cardiff, too. There was a general perception that 'things were out of control'. The banks got jittery. If the FA had gone ahead with the project alone, he said, they risked going bankrupt. The professional response was to stop and think again.

'It became clear that, effectively, what the banks in the City were saying was, "We want someone absolutely on the hook for the money, we want someone to take the risk," because as we all know, frankly, banks don't take risks; they like other people to take the risks. And what they said was they wanted full financial recourse to the FA. In other words, they wanted the FA to stump up all of the money and pay all of the interest. At that point, as many of you know, we made a number of changes to the leadership of the project.' Exit Bates. Loudly.

The FA worked it out it would cost them £125 million in equity, plus £55m a year to make the current Wembley plan work. They couldn't do it, Crozier says. So the salesman went to work on New Labour's conscience. What they could afford, with a partner, was £100m up front, and £20m a year for three years.

'We know from Brent Council that there are something like 15,000 jobs, either directly or indirectly, related to the building of the stadium, and the whole regeneration of the Wembley area either succeeds or it doesn't on the basis of this stadium.'

That takes care of the socialism, then.

'Secondly, the one thing that the Olympic stadiums in Italy and Germany, the national stadium in France, the Olympic stadium in Sydney, the new one that's been announced in Ireland, and frankly any national stadium in any country in the world, the one thing they have in common is they're all built by governments, not by private organisations.' And they lose money. Sydney is soon to go into insolvency. This was starting to sound distinctly Soviet.

According to the Crozier blueprint, the Government could buy in to Wembley, stay for a few years, sell up and get out with a profit. Whether Blair will go for it or not should be decided when the Government's task force and the FA meet on Tuesday. The FA reckon there is a good chance the Government will opt for an Olympic-class stadium and bid for the 2012 Games. They want the Government - or Sport England, if the Lottery rules can be adjusted - to buy up the 44 acres next to the stadium and turn the whole complex into something special.

The last piece in Crozier's plan is very Old Labour. He says the Government should be prepared to do what governments in France and Australia do: take a bath on a national stadium. If this Scottish charmer can persuade his clone in 10 Downing Street to lose millions to save Wembley after the disaster of the Dome, he might qualify as salesman of the year.

And his old Saatchi colleague says: 'He could sell it to Blair, no problem.'

webTitle: UNICEF appeal: what you can do

fields.headline: Growing up alone - what you can do
fields.standfirst:
How governments and citizens can help the world's most vulnerable children

More on the Unicef Appeal:
Horrific statistics reveal toll of war on children
Miyongere's story
The countries where children are most vulnerable
fields.trailText: Jo Bailey of UNICEF UK calls for the British government, and citizens, to take action to help the world's most vulnerable children.
fields.body:
The majority of casualties in conflict since the end of the Cold War have been civilians. Whatever the nature of armed conflict, children and families suffer profoundly.

Of the world's 40 million displaced people, 20 million are children; in the last ten years 2 million children have been killed by conflict and 6 million have been injured or disabled. The world is now a more violent place for children than at any time since the Second World War.

Conflict damages children, not just in terms of their physical well-being - and the impact on shelter, food and healthcare - but because of the equal, and often longer lasting, damage to their hearts and minds. Even when children's experience of conflict does not leave physical scars, its impact, for example in family separation, can be no less profound.

UNICEF's new 'Growing up alone: childhood under siege' campaign, to be launched at the end of May, seeks to explore the impact of conflict and to show how the UK government can take concrete action now which can halt the terrible damage.

We are calling on the government to tighten UK arms legislation to prevent the small arms which fuel armed conflict falling into the wrong hands; to end the recruitment and deployment of under-18s in the armed forces; and to grant refugee and asylum-seeking children the same rights as other children in the UK.

You can play a part too by adding your voice to the campaign. Visit our website at www.unicef.org.uk and help to prevent children growing up alone because of conflict.

webTitle: News in brief

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Plane touches down in Rio to bring home Ronnie Biggs
fields.body:
Plane touches down in Rio to bring home Ronnie Biggs

A plane chartered by a newspaper to bring Great Train Robber Ronald Biggs home to Britain landed in Rio de Janeiro last night. Ailing Biggs, 71, has applied for a temporary passport so that he can end more than 35 years as a fugitive, a spokesman for the Sun said.

On board the aircraft were Biggs's fellow train robber Bruce Reynolds, as well as his favourites: a curry, a six-pack of beer and a jar of Marmite. Biggs vowed last week to return 'at the earliest opportunity', the paper reported. An answering machine message at the fugitive's home in Rio said only that he would be 'away until the twelfth'.

Mandelson faces enemy

John Booth, 54, a former Labour Party subordinate of Peter Mandelson, and now a bitter personal enemy, is to oppose him at Hartlepool in the general election.

A former contributor to The Observer, Booth was dismissed from Labour's press office in 1986 after a stormy association with Mandelson who was then Director of Communications. They have not spoken since. Booth will almost certainly face expulsion from the party for opposing an official Labour candidate. He intends to fight under the banner Genuine Labour.

Graphics award for Observer

The Observer 's graphics team picked up a major award in the prestigious Malofiej Awards for world-wide excellence in communication graphics in newspapers, magazines and the internet. The award, for 'exceptional explanation and coverage of the Kursk disaster', was presented at a ceremony in Pamplona, Spain.

Runaway girl safe in Italy

A 15-year-old schoolgirl who ran off with a teacher from her school a year ago has written to her parents from Italy saying she is safe and well. Katherine Baillie, now 16, wrote that she has been living with maths teacher Paul Tramontini, 33, has been well treated by him and is looking forward to returning home soon.

Divorcee Tramontini skipped bail and disappeared with Katherine on 26 April last year. Earlier, he had been charged with the abduction of Katherine after they ran away together for five days. He was a maths teacher at Katherine's school, Mayfield comprehensive in Portsmouth.

Agatha Christie anniversary

To mark the twenty-fifth anniversary of Agatha Christie's death, the Palace Theatre in Westcliff-on-Sea, Essex, is to stage all 23 of her plays in a single season.

Curried cheese

fields.bodyText: Plane touches down in Rio to bring home Ronnie Biggs A plane chartered by a newspaper to bring Great Train Robber Ronald Biggs home to Britain landed in Rio de Janeiro last night. Ailing Biggs, 71, has applied for a temporary passport so that he can end more than 35 years as a fugitive, a spokesman for the Sun said. On board the aircraft were Biggs's fellow train robber Bruce Reynolds, as well as his favourites: a curry, a six-pack of beer and a jar of Marmite. Biggs vowed last week to return 'at the earliest opportunity', the paper reported. An answering machine message at the fugitive's home in Rio said only that he would be 'away until the twelfth'. Mandelson faces enemy John Booth, 54, a former Labour Party subordinate of Peter Mandelson, and now a bitter personal enemy, is to oppose him at Hartlepool in the general election. A former contributor to The Observer, Booth was dismissed from Labour's press office in 1986 after a stormy association with Mandelson who was then Director of Communications. They have not spoken since. Booth will almost certainly face expulsion from the party for opposing an official Labour candidate. He intends to fight under the banner Genuine Labour. Graphics award for Observer The Observer 's graphics team picked up a major award in the prestigious Malofiej Awards for world-wide excellence in communication graphics in newspapers, magazines and the internet. The award, for 'exceptional explanation and coverage of the Kursk disaster', was presented at a ceremony in Pamplona, Spain. Runaway girl safe in Italy A 15-year-old schoolgirl who ran off with a teacher from her school a year ago has written to her parents from Italy saying she is safe and well. Katherine Baillie, now 16, wrote that she has been living with maths teacher Paul Tramontini, 33, has been well treated by him and is looking forward to returning home soon. Divorcee Tramontini skipped bail and disappeared with Katherine on 26 April last year. Earlier, he had been charged with the abduction of Katherine after they ran away together for five days. He was a maths teacher at Katherine's school, Mayfield comprehensive in Portsmouth. fields.trailText: How the impact of conflict, poverty and HIV place children in triple jeopardy of growing up alone.
fields.body:
The three main causes of children growing up alone are conflict, acute poverty and the HIV/AIDS epidemic. Children are most vulnerable where all three of these factors are present at once.

The UNICEF report will show how, of 51 countries where conflict is present today, the infant mortality rate is above 90 per 1000 live births in twenty countries, and in thirteen of these the adult HIV infection great is also above 2 per cent of all adults. webTitle: Hearts pushed aside

fields.headline: Hearts pushed aside
fields.trailText: Rangers fi their place in the Champions League qualifiers with an ultimately comfortable victory which further hampered Hearts' pursuit of a Uefa Cup place. But it was a fractious game too: both teams ended it with 10 men, with first Rangers captain Barry Ferguson and then Hearts defender Steven Pressley being shown red cards.
fields.body:
Rangers fi their place in the Champions League qualifiers with an ultimately comfortable victory which further hampered Hearts' pursuit of a Uefa Cup place. But it was a fractious game too: both teams ended it with 10 men, with first Rangers captain Barry Ferguson and then Hearts defender Steven Pressley being shown red cards.

Hearts, who needed to take at least a point to keep fourth-placed Kilmarnock in their sights, made three changes to the side who drew 1-1 at Kilmarnock. Out went Grant Murray, Lee Makel and Andy Webster, with Kevin McKenna, Thomas Flogel and Robert Tomaschek replacing them.

Rangers made a single change in the wake of their 3-0 home defeat by Celtic last Sunday, with Billy Dodds replaced by Claudio Reyna.

The home side started strongly and Rangers goalkeeper Stefan Klos was called into action when McKenna tried his luck from long range. The German had to scramble low to his right post to prevent the ball creeping in.

Rangers' reply almost brought the first goal when Arthur Numan crossed from the left to the onrushing Fernando Ricksen and it needed a good stop by goalkeeper Antti Niemi to thwart him.

Niemi is the current Scottish Premier League player of the month and he showed why in the 21st minute. Tore Andre Flo manoeuvred his way into a shooting position and his effort took a bad bounce off the scarred turf and hit the Finn straight in the face. The ball rebounded to Rod Wallace in front of goal yet somehow Niemi was able to make a point-blank save from the striker's instinctive shot.

Rangers did make the breakthrough, though, in the 29th minute when Jorg Albertz's firmly struck free-kick went in off the far post.

But just two minutes later, Dick Advocaat's side were down to 10 men, when Barry Ferguson went in hard and late on Pressley. Referee Hugh Dallas showed the Rangers captain a straight red card.

Ferguson's dismissal revived memories of the previous Tynecastle game, in which Rangers won 1-0 but finished with nine men.

Despite being a man down, though, Rangers finished the half on top and in the 37th minute Albertz hit the far post from a free-kick again but this time the ball rebounded back to Niemi instead of going in the net.

Hearts made two changes after the break with Cameron and Steven Boyack being replaced by Lee Makel and Juanjo. And it was the Spaniard who set up Hearts' equaliser in the 47th minute with a cross from the right that Klos misjudged. He could only push the ball out to Adam, who deflected the ball in from close range.

Parity did not last, however, and Rangers regained the lead after Albertz touched a free-kick to Lorenzo Amaruso, whose drive was too strong for Niemi to hang on to. Wallace duly converted the rebound.

The next moment of drama was not far away. Pressley was sent off for his second bookable offence in a matter of minutes, this time chopping down Albertz as the German motored towards goal.

Hearts began to throw men forward in search of an equaliser but were caught twice by swift counter-attacks. The first came in the 79th minute when Konterman's clearance from his own penalty area reached Flo, and he sent Albertz through to hammer the ball past Niemi.

Six minutes later the German repaid the compliment with a long ball that put Flo through to poke the ball past the exposed Niemi.

webTitle: No Opposition, no problem

fields.headline: No Opposition, no problem
fields.standfirst:
But Labour still has a lot to prove
Special report: Labour party
Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: May 6, leader: But Labour still has a lot to prove.
fields.body:
At last. This week the election will be called. Labour will seek a renewal of its mandate, the phoney war will be over and proper political battle will begin.

Or not. Already we know the main contours of the argument and the likely result. Tony Blair and Gordon Brown will parade their handling of the economy. Foundations have been laid, they will say, but there is more to do. They will guard their flanks against the Conservatives on Europe and asylum-seekers. For his part, William Hague will make as little impact in the next four weeks as he has in the last four years.

We deserve better. An effective Opposition would be highlighting how limited New Labour's progress has been, and how Britain's deep-seated economic and social problems are becoming entrenched - their seriousness masked by economic recovery. Our productivity gap with major competitors has widened; our public investment has fallen; inequalities of income and wealth are more marked; our transport system is a world laughing stock; our delivery of public services remains poor; our workers have fewer rights than their European counterparts. This should be fertile ground for any Opposition. However, the Tories are disabled by their own poverty of ideas. Their attachment to discredited Thatcherite nostrums only underlines their fundamental unattractiveness.

New Labour is the lucky party; the custodians of an economic recovery that it has been canny enough not to upset. Its defenders argue that the character of democracy is changing. Governments now have to negotiate constantly with their citizens and powerful interest groups in a media contest in which government is at a disadvantage, so that clarity of purpose and decisive leadership is more difficult. But these important arguments do not excuse Labour's reluctance to open up a national conversation, set the agenda and offer ideas about how to create a better society.

This election campaign could offer such an opportunity. Labour should be arguing for a fair taxation system with which to finance high-quality public services. It should be insisting that treating workers well is central to economic efficiency. It should be offering improved and universal social protection, for policies designed only for the poor become branded as poor policies. It should be arguing aggressively for equal opportunity notwithstanding gender, race and sexuality. It should be recognising that companies and communities should husband the environment. It should be insisting that rehabilitation as much as punishment characterise our criminal justice system. It should be insistent that Britain be open to the world, operate a fair immigration system and be constructive in building Europe. Sadly, with its habitual anxiety to be all things to everyone, we fear that New Labour will not argue any of these issues during the coming days with the vigour it should.

webTitle: World in brief

fields.headline: World in brief
fields.trailText: Divers struggled to recover the bodies of 100 people trapped after a ferry capsized in the harbour Goma on Lake Kivu in the Democratic Republic of Congo.
fields.body:
Lack of fuel hinders recovery of bodies in ferry accident

Divers struggled to recover the bodies of 100 people trapped after a ferry capsized in the harbour Goma on Lake Kivu in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Officials said they were ill-equipped to deal with the disaster. Lack of heavy lifting gear and fuel for recovery boats slowed the operation.

Iran radical's election hopes

A leading figure in the 1979 seizure of the US embassy in Iran announced his candidacy for presidential elections on 8 June. Ibrahim Asgharzadeh, a former revolutionary student who is on the Tehran city council, said he would work for greater democracy if elected.

Protester dies in Zambia rally after police fire tear gas

One person died after Zambian riot police fired tear gas to break up a victory rally in Lusaka organised by dissident members of President Frederick Chiluba's ruling party.

The rally came a day after Chiluba bowed to pressure from inside and outside his ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) and scrapped plans to run for an unconstitutional third term amid moves by disaffected supporters to impeach him.

The 3,000-strong rally was under way when police in riot gear charged the crowd, firing volleys of tear gas. Some police armed with automatic rifles fired rounds over the heads of the crowd.

Apology over saucy snaps

Shawne Fielding, wife of the Swiss ambassador to Germany, Thomas Borer, has apologised over provocative pictures of herself which appeared in a German magazine.

M&S protest

Workers at Marks & Spencer's stores across France held a one-day strike to protest against closure.

Farm children resist asthma

A study of 800 children in Switzerland and Austria found farm children had better resistance to asthma and hay fever than city children because longer exposure to plant germination built up their immune systems.

Bush hacked

The White House website was brought down for several hours after an attack by Chinese hackers.

webTitle: The big issue: MS

fields.headline: Letters to the Editor
fields.standfirst: MS: a suitable call for treatment
fields.trailText: I read J.K. Rowling's article about her mother's decline and death from Multiple Sclerosis at the age of 45 (Review, last week) with great sympathy since my son suffers from the same disease.
fields.body:
I read J.K. Rowling's article about her mother's decline and death from Multiple Sclerosis at the age of 45 (Review, last week) with great sympathy since my son suffers from the same disease.

Unlike JKR's mother, my son was diagnosed within months of the symptoms appearing - thanks to his private health insurance scheme - but in terms of health care has experienced the same neglect as her mother. In my son's case he was told: 'You have MS. Take evening primrose oil and go away and live your life.' From that moment, two years ago, any help he has received has been paid for by him.

At first we thought that treatments were not available. But they are: the National Institute for Clinical Excellence is blocking the use of beta interferon because of its cost, though the drug is readily available in European countries and is less expensive there.

Ten years on, as J.K. Rowling pointed out, nothing positive has been done by government to help sufferers from this disease, and what is available is denied them.
K.E. Hallam
Wolverhampton

 I was diagnosed with MS in November 2000. This was just a few weeks after NICE had delivered their verdict that beta interferon was too expensive to be prescribed for new sufferers. Until I read Ms Rowling's article, I had thought that the bill to the NHS would run into hundreds of million pounds. I was so surprised to be told that the cost to the NHS to give the drug to all sufferers with MS who would benefit would be only £46 million.

My neurologist has agreed that I would meet the criteria for prescription of the drug if he was able to do so. There are no MS nurses in my region of Hertfordshire, and all I have received from the Department of Health is an assurance that they recognise that it is an extremely debilitating and distressing chronic disease but there is nothing that can be done for me.

MS is not life threatening for most people as it was to Ms Rowling's mother but it has absolutely wrecked my life.
Angela Johnson
Hemel Hempstead, Herts

 While having every sympathy with J.K. Rowling, I fear that association by celebrity may give some conditions a disproportionate share of sympathy and charity. My husband has recently been diagnosed with age-related macular degeneration - the major cause of blindness/low vision in the Western world. There is no treatment (except in rare situations) and no cure. Vision can be lost almost immediately or over a period of years. Early symptoms can be slight but ultimately catastrophic (a barely noticeable distortion of vision if present only in one eye, or a small black spot in the visual field).

A minority of people can have their sight saved or the onset of the disease postponed by laser treatment. In practise this is almost impossible within the NHS where it can take three months to get a first appointment with an ophthalmologist.
Sandra Semple
London WC1

Mind the facts

 Ben Summerskill and Edward Helmore (News, last week) are right to point out that some UK papers are 'happy to set the hare running on stories promoting a Family Values agenda' and to cite as alarmist the Daily Mail's story headlined 'How daycare can make a toddler grow up unruly'. Unfortunately, though, the caption to the illustration repeats one of the Daily Mail 's most parent-scaring mistakes.

Whatever the findings concerning the development of children cared for in nurseries in the cited study, they cannot be generalised to children cared for by childminders because this is an American study and registered childminding, the most-used form of out-of-home care for British under-fives, does not exist in the United States.
Penelope Leach
London NW3

Pasta dish

Could Cristina Odone (Comment, last week) pop over to Rome and tutor my Italian girlfriend on the 'ancient code of the mediterranea'. She laughs at my white legs rather than my jokes, and while she may quite possibly be indulging in an affair, the nearest she comes to domesticity is when she asks me to pay our cleaner. Can I have some sugo on my pasta please, Cristina?
David Pickering
Roma, Italy

Cane and enable

 Blair's New Labour world is truly a world standing on its head. Rather than bribe the bribable to procreate with a £500 bounty, would it not be better to create a safe society with soul into which decent people actually want to bring up children? Rather than resort to the immoral and futile attempt to bribe the young away from early yobbism with a CD and a pair of trainers, would it not be better to reintroduce the cane for youngsters who misbehave? Churchill offered blood, sweat and tears for victory - not spin, deception and bribery.

How low can politics sink? Bedroom sleaze sells little more than newspapers - Blair's New Labour sleaze is selling the soul of the nation. Can this really be the best man to win the next general election?
Richard Franklin
Brighton

It's not working

 Andrew Rawnsley (Comment, last week) is surely taking a spin too far in suggesting that this Government has already achieved full employment.

From the end of the Second World War to the mix-Sixties, we had, with brief exceptions, unemployment rates of 2 per cent or less, and the threat of half a million unemployment would require urgent corrective action. In contrast, we now have a million people unemployed and claiming benefit, with several hundred thousand others unemployed under the broader Labour Force Survey criteria.
Colin Crouch
Harrow Weald, Middlesex

French games

 When Stuart Jeffries states that historically the French have enjoyed participating in sports more than their British neighbours, he is totally wrong (World, last week). The reverse is true.

The French for most of the twentieth century considered sport to be a waste of time. Our French professor told us after the war: 'Vous aimez jouer avec un ballon mais nous les Francais nous aimons jouer avec les idees.' Thus the French have become the most technologically advanced country in Europe. Their rate of productivity is 40 per cent better than ours.

In the Seventies French schools made a determined effort to introduce PE and games into the schools by making them compulsory. However, this measure was met with a deluge of 'excuse' notes from pupils' parents. Many of the stars of French sport are from recent immigrant communities - North African and West African.
Alban W. Mason
Colwyn Bay, N. Wales

African tragedy

 Philip Hensher, in his review of Dennis Altman's 'Global Sex', states that 'the prevalence of heterosexual Aids in sub-Saharan Africa has been widely attributed to the resort to sodomy as a firm of birth control'.

The transmission and widespread prevalence of HIV in Africa is now, and always has been, inextricably linked with socio-economic, cultural and epidemiological factors predisposing to the rapid spread of HIV. Not least, these include widespread migratory working practices, large movements of refugees following national unrest, enhanced trade routes, and the pre-exis tence of numerous other sexually transmitted diseases. To target a single sexual practice as the main instigator of HIV in Africa is both factually untrue and a denial of the broader issues fanning the flames of this pandemic.
Ian Hodgson
University of Bradford

American bullies

 Thank goodness for Nick Cohen and for Lindis Percy! But when will any of our politicians have the backbone to stand up for British and European interests against this latest manifestation of US imperialism?

I had hoped that 'Son of Star Wars' would be a step too far but no. It seems that, whoever is in the White House, our governments, regardless of party, will kowtow to them, even when it means violating international treaties, jeopardising our security, and isolating us from the concerns of our nearest neighbours and partners in Europe.
M.M. Gilchrist
Cupar, Fife

Caborn's folly

 Am I the only reader unpersuaded by [Trade Minister] Richard Caborn's attempt to refute Gregory Palast's attack on Gats (Business, last week)? There has been far too much information emerging concerning the potentially disastrous effects of free-trade negotiations on public services. Mr Caborn is either disingenuous or misinformed; I don't know which is more dangerous.
Ellie Weld
Twickenham, Mddx

Gray's sin

 I have no difficulty with Muriel Gray not liking religions (Review, last week); no doubt she has honed her analysis on the whetstone of her Glaswegian upbringing. Unfortunately, Ms Gray wears her dislike of religions, and Catholicism in particular, on her rather grubby sleeve. Far be it from me to suggest that Ms Gray is nothing more than an old-fashioned, Saturday night Glaswegian bigot masquerading as a fiction writer, but her offensive approach to the subject can only lead reasonable people to assume that Ms Gray's mouth has developed far ahead of her intellect.
Michael Conroy
High Wycombe, Bucks

Ingrams late

 It is clear Richard Ingrams is not a mobile phone user or he would know that his 'prediction' that mobile phone manufacturers would adopt a policy of 'built-in obsolescence' is itself obsolete (Diary, last week).

Not only has there been the endless introduction of new operating systems, from analogue to digital to WAP with more to come, but the phones themselves seem to be regarded as disposable. I have a Motorola less than three years old. The phone works fine, but the battery no longer recharges. A new battery would cost me £49.99, less than a new phone.
Stephen Butcher
Ballymena, Co. Antrim
fields.bodyText: I read J.K. Rowling's article about her mother's decline and death from Multiple Sclerosis at the age of 45 (Review, last week) with great sympathy since my son suffers from the same disease. Unlike JKR's mother, my son was diagnosed within months of the symptoms appearing - thanks to his private health insurance scheme - but in terms of health care has experienced the same neglect as her mother. In my son's case he was told: 'You have MS. Take evening primrose oil and go away and live your life.' From that moment, two years ago, any help he has received has been paid for by him. At first we thought that treatments were not available. But they are: the National Institute for Clinical Excellence is blocking the use of beta interferon because of its cost, though the drug is readily available in European countries and is less expensive there. Ten years on, as J.K. Rowling pointed out, nothing positive has been done by government to help sufferers from this disease, and what is available is denied them. K.E. Hallam Wolverhampton  I was diagnosed with MS in November 2000. This was just a few weeks after NICE had delivered their verdict that beta interferon was too expensive to be prescribed for new sufferers. Until I read Ms Rowling's article, I had thought that the bill to the NHS would run into hundreds of million pounds. I was so surprised to be told that the cost to the NHS to give the drug to all sufferers with MS who would benefit would be only £46 million. My neurologist has agreed that I would meet the criteria for prescription of the drug if he was able to do so. There are no MS nurses in my region of Hertfordshire, and all I have received from the Department of Health is an assurance that they recognise that it is an extremely debilitating and distressing chronic disease but there is nothing that can be done for me. MS is not life threatening for most people as it was to Ms Rowling's mother but it has absolutely wrecked my life. Angela Johnson Hemel Hempstead, Herts  While having every sympathy with J.K. Rowling, I fear that association by celebrity may give some conditions a disproportionate share of sympathy and charity. My husband has recently been diagnosed with age-related macular degeneration - the major cause of blindness/low vision in the Western world. There is no treatment (except in rare situations) and no cure. Vision can be lost almost immediately or over a period of years. Early symptoms can be slight but ultimately catastrophic (a barely noticeable distortion of vision if present only in one eye, or a small black spot in the visual field). A minority of people can have their sight saved or the onset of the disease postponed by laser treatment. In practise this is almost impossible within the NHS where it can take three months to get a first appointment with an ophthalmologist. Sandra Semple London WC1 Mind the facts  Ben Summerskill and Edward Helmore (News, last week) are right to point out that some UK papers are 'happy to set the hare running on stories promoting a Family Values agenda' and to cite as alarmist the Daily Mail's story headlined 'How daycare can make a toddler grow up unruly'. Unfortunately, though, the caption to the illustration repeats one of the Daily Mail 's most parent-scaring mistakes. Whatever the findings concerning the development of children cared for in nurseries in the cited study, they cannot be generalised to children cared for by childminders because this is an American study and registered childminding, the most-used form of out-of-home care for British under-fives, does not exist in the United States. Penelope Leach London NW3 Pasta dish Could Cristina Odone (Comment, last week) pop over to Rome and tutor my Italian girlfriend on the 'ancient code of the mediterranea'. She laughs at my white legs rather than my jokes, and while she may quite possibly be indulging in an affair, the nearest she comes to domesticity is when she asks me to pay our cleaner. Can I have some sugo on my pasta please, Cristina? David Pickering Roma, Italy Cane and enable  Blair's New Labour world is truly a world standing on its head. Rather than bribe the bribable to procreate with a £500 bounty, would it not be better to create a safe society with soul into which decent people actually want to bring up children? Rather than resort to the immoral and futile attempt to bribe the young away from early yobbism with a CD and a pair of trainers, would it not be better to reintroduce the cane for youngsters who misbehave? Churchill offered blood, sweat and tears for victory - not spin, deception and bribery. How low can politics sink? Bedroom sleaze sells little more than newspapers - Blair's New Labour sleaze is selling the soul of the nation. Can this really be the best man to win the next general election? Richard Franklin Brighton It's not working  Andrew Rawnsley (Comment, last week) is surely taking a spin too far in suggesting that this Government has already achieved full employment. From the end of the Second World War to the mix-Sixties, we had, with brief exceptions, unemployment rates of 2 per cent or less, and the threat of half a million unemployment would require urgent corrective action. In contrast, we now have a million people unemployed and claiming benefit, with several hundred thousand others unemployed under the broader Labour Force Survey criteria. Colin Crouch Harrow Weald, Middlesex French games  When Stuart Jeffries states that historically the French have enjoyed participating in sports more than their British neighbours, he is totally wrong (World, last week). The reverse is true. The French for most of the twentieth century considered sport to be a waste of time. Our French professor told us after the war: 'Vous aimez jouer avec un ballon mais nous les Francais nous aimons jouer avec les idees.' Thus the French have become the most technologically advanced country in Europe. Their rate of productivity is 40 per cent better than ours. In the Seventies French schools made a determined effort to introduce PE and games into the schools by making them compulsory. However, this measure was met with a deluge of 'excuse' notes from pupils' parents. Many of the stars of French sport are from recent immigrant communities - North African and West African. Alban W. Mason Colwyn Bay, N. Wales African tragedy  Philip Hensher, in his review of Dennis Altman's 'Global Sex', states that 'the prevalence of heterosexual Aids in sub-Saharan Africa has been widely attributed to the resort to sodomy as a firm of birth control'. The transmission and widespread prevalence of HIV in Africa is now, and always has been, inextricably linked with socio-economic, cultural and epidemiological factors predisposing to the rapid spread of HIV. Not least, these include widespread migratory working practices, large movements of refugees following national unrest, enhanced trade routes, and the pre-exis tence of numerous other sexually transmitted diseases. To target a single sexual practice as the main instigator of HIV in Africa is both factually untrue and a denial of the broader issues fanning the flames of this pandemic. Ian Hodgson University of Bradford American bullies  Thank goodness for Nick Cohen and for Lindis Percy! But when will any of our politicians have the backbone to stand up for British and European interests against this latest manifestation of US imperialism? I had hoped that 'Son of Star Wars' would be a step too far but no. It seems that, whoever is in the White House, our governments, regardless of party, will kowtow to them, even when it means violating international treaties, jeopardising our security, and isolating us from the concerns of our nearest neighbours and partners in Europe. M.M. Gilchrist Cupar, Fife Caborn's folly  Am I the only reader unpersuaded by [Trade Minister] Richard Caborn's attempt to refute Gregory Palast's attack on Gats (Business, last week)? There has been far too much information emerging concerning the potentially disastrous effects of free-trade negotiations on public services. Mr Caborn is either disingenuous or misinformed; I don't know which is more dangerous. Ellie Weld Twickenham, Mddx Gray's sin  I have no difficulty with Muriel Gray not liking religions (Review, last week); no doubt she has honed her analysis on the whetstone of her Glaswegian upbringing. Unfortunately, Ms Gray wears her dislike of religions, and Catholicism in particular, on her rather grubby sleeve. Far be it from me to suggest that Ms Gray is nothing more than an old-fashioned, Saturday night Glaswegian bigot masquerading as a fiction writer, but her offensive approach to the subject can only lead reasonable people to assume that Ms Gray's mouth has developed far ahead of her intellect. Michael Conroy High Wycombe, Bucks Ingrams late  It is clear Richard Ingrams is not a mobile phone user or he would know that his 'prediction' that mobile phone manufacturers would adopt a policy of 'built-in obsolescence' is itself obsolete (Diary, last week). Not only has there been the endless introduction of new operating systems, from analogue to digital to WAP with more to come, but the phones themselves seem to be regarded as disposable. I have a Motorola less than three years old. The phone works fine, but the battery no longer recharges. A new battery would cost me £49.99, less than a new phone. Stephen Butcher Ballymena, Co. Antrim

webTitle: 'How was Blair's first term for you?'

fields.headline: 'How was Blair's first term for you?'
fields.trailText: Germaine Greer
fields.body:
Germaine Greer

It takes a bit of time to put your finger on what's up with New Labour. They are such a strange government. They seem to do it all with mirrors, and everything is so unstraightforward. The Robinson scandal just goes on and on. Can't we simply find out if he was a crook or not? The Government is trying, just like Diana, to use the media to get its message across. I am disgusted with it. I feel so sorry for Nick Brown. He will take the blame for foot and mouth while Tony Blair will take all the credit. And Cherie Blair, wandering around gazing into Tony Blair's eyes like all she wants to be is impregnated by him again. I can't bear it. But we don't have an alternative. We have a bunch of entirely useless Tories. I didn't vote for Labour at the last election, although they like to think that I did. I wish there was a way we could register the depth of our disgust and teach them the error of their ways and get them to stop mucking around. All this populist crap on fox-hunting; seizing a minor issue to gain public approval.

Lord Blake

Tony Blair has delivered on the constitutional reform that he promised and Gordon Brown has managed to sustain the economic boom he inherited from his Conservative predecessors. But in 1997 we were told that taxation would remain constant. Although income tax has not changed, other levies have increased the tax burden. Blair's promises on the NHS and education remain nothing but promises, and law and order is in no way better than it was.

Dinos Chapman, artist

Let me try and say this politely. It's Thatcherism gone soft - the death of politics and the birth of a homogenised society. Particularly in the art world, we've seen the rise of churches of culture like the Tate Modern Cathedral, which thrive on the idea that the same type of culture is good for everyone.

Graham Norton

It's people's job to hate them now because they are the Government. For years it was easy to like Labour because they weren't in power. But now people are duty-bound to hate them.

Baroness Williams

Fundamentally it is a government which is in tune with the networked world. It is relatively young in tone and has a great strength in communications. I'd give them a B+. They are a rather efficient government, despite being sometimes schizophrenic. Tony Blair has a genuine conscience and sense of social justice, but on his shoulder is this Beelzebub telling him he must win elections. I would fault them severely on liberal issues, like prisons and asylum seekers. And in foreign affairs, they have allowed one of the most important issues of the past decade to be commented on by Alastair Campbell, who seems to think something quite different from Tony Blair. It shows that democratic accountability matters very little among them.

Ben Pimlott, historian

Despite mishaps, the 1997 to 2001 Labour government will be remembered as the most trouble-free and reassuring in British history, largely because of a mix of good leadership and good economic luck, with the bonus of an inadequate Opposition. It has held on to its middle-ground support which is the more remarkable because in a curiously modest way it has turned out to be more socialist than its macho self-image would have us believe.

Stephen Bayley

There has never been such a dishonest and incompetent government in living memory. I can't think of a single issue that they have handled well. What appals me is the dishonesty and hypocrisy. Blair pretends to be benign but is authoritarian. Margaret Thatcher was repulsive and sanctimonious, but not hypocritical. We have no effective Opposition, because there are no real beliefs for them to oppose.

Rory Bremner

I remember when Tony Blair took over from John Major, I thought, 'My God, what on earth am I going to do now?' But that's OK... I now realise that's exactly what he was thinking.

webTitle: Crime blitz heads Blair poll drive

fields.headline: Crime blitz heads Blair poll drive
fields.standfirst:
Mandelson urges new vision for election campaign
Special report: Labour party
Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: A tough package of crime measures aimed at tackling serial offenders by giving them longer sentences is to be made the launch pad for Tony Blair's electoral appeal to Britain's middle ground.
fields.body:
A tough package of crime measures aimed at tackling serial offenders by giving them longer sentences is to be made the launch pad for Tony Blair's electoral appeal to Britain's middle ground.

On Tuesday, hours before the election is called, Jack Straw, the Home Secretary, will say that people who repeatedly appear in court charged with the same offences can expect to spend more time in prison.

He will also announce a reparations system whereby criminals will repay or repair the damage caused by their crimes. Victims will be allowed to suggest what the reparation should be, from financial compensation to community service orders.

The crime review will be the last announcement the Government makes before the Prime Minister visits the Queen to ask for a dissolution of Parliament. The general election will be held on 7 June.

Blair will start the campaign with an appeal to 'aspirational Britain', after fears were raised at the highest levels of the party that the Government had lost its vision ary element. The Prime Minister will use a keynote speech next Sunday to try to inject a degree of passion into the Labour campaign, which some of the party's most senior figures believe is in danger of losing its way. He has taken charge of a new introduction to the manifesto in which he will say Labour is the party for those who have ambitions to better the position of themselves and their family. He will also personally launch a 'pledge card' to put the improvement of secondary schools at the centre of Labour's campaign. It is likely to promise an increased ratio of staff to pupils in all of England and Wales's secondary schools.

A new pledge on improving the health of the nation will replace the issue of hospital waiting lists. Pledges will also be made on crime and the economy.

Writing in today's Observer, Peter Mandelson enters the campaign debate, by urging a more radical vision for the party and saying that the Government cannot simply get by on a record of competence.

'Britain needs more than competence from its Government,' Mandelson said. 'It needs a reforming New Labour administration with a range of coherent policies, rather than patchwork initiatives, that can both tackle the very worst social and economic problems and give every individual and family the chance to get on and realise their ambition.

'Ambition must be the New Labour compass for the second term and beyond. A second term Government cannot simply be about the completion of "work in progress". It is about inaugurating a new age of ambition in our country, a compelling vision of a different kind of society.'

Yesterday the Prime Minister's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, said that Blair would call an 'election Cabinet' tomorrow to put the finishing touches to the manifesto, the clearest indication yet that the election will be called on Tuesday. 'We have to fight this election as though it is on a knife-edge,' he said. 'We take nothing and nobody for granted.' He said the Prime Minister would tell the specially convened Cabinet he wanted to paint a new vision for Britain that will enthuse the public.

In a bid to bolster the party's support among middle-income earners, Blair has told party staff Labour must send out the message that it will offer support to all those who want to get on in the world.

During the campaign he will say that, far from distancing himself from the New Labour brand, he wants to govern under the banner he first launched before the last general election in 1997.

Blair has told close allies he will promise to serve a full term as Prime Minister if it becomes an election issue.

'If he keeps being asked about it, then he will have to say something. We don't want it becoming a distraction,' said one senior aide.

There have been reports that the Prime Minister would consider stepping down after three years of the next Government, particularly if Britain successfully joins the euro.

webTitle: Sorry, Alastair, what was that crack about Four-Eyes?

fields.headline: Sorry, Alastair, what was that crack about Four-Eyes?
fields.body:
Monday: Gosh. Only a few days to go before we finally sound the gun for the election. Pulses beginning to race, nerves tautening: personally, I haven't felt this excited since the day they introduced triangular teabags with little drawstring thingies - or maybe it was that day I read a bit of a book about concrete. Tony is only four thousand squillion percentage points ahead in every poll, including the one that showed Hague would win more votes if he were to change his name to William Teabag, and change his body and head to that of a teabag. (Mind you, we shouldn't sneer: dear Gorbals Mick - Mr Speaker Martin to you - is coming in for increasing amounts of stick for his attitude to the esteemed leader of the Opposition. I suppose his last Hague putdown - 'If my dog had a face like that I'd shave its arse and teach it to walk backwards' - wasn't exactly Churchillian.) Anyway, quiet rejoicing at it all being so obviously in the bag. In four short years, I keep being told, we have vanquished Conservatism.

Tuesday: Four short years. Four short, happy little inspiring years. I look around me, wanting to savour a snapshot of the day, to save a memory of what we are, what we have achieved.

Tony has just congratulated the police for having bravely tackled a crowd of people with dodgy armpits, protected by little more than full body armour, batons, riot shields, dogs, horses, tactical control vehicles, the Government, the law, big business and a few more hundred thousand armed police up the side streets behind them. The Daily Mail has praised Tony; we did much better then the German police, apparently, so that's something to be proud of: for let's face it, those guys used to really know how to control a crowd!

Rupert Murdoch has been in to visit Gordon and left, beaming, happy that we won't start taxing anyone or joining the euro or being left wing or anything.

Tony has, with only the mildest prompting from Alastair, just congratulated George Bush on reversing the global peace process of the past 25 years and making China even more terrified and therefore dangerous than it was before. I think they made a Chinese 'election' joke on the telephone.

Wednesday: And Jack Straw and Ann Widdecombe are arguing about who has been most successfully nasty to asylum-seekers.

And our dear chum Geoffrey Robinson has been caught pocket-stuffing (again).

And the Tube isn't working properly because we won't give it any money because we don't have any that's not earmarked for bribing the nation; the trains ditto, Wembley ditto. But Tony has a new pair of specs, and we saved Phoenix the calf.

Vanquished. Utterly vanquished.

Thursday: Tony and Co poring over today's articles summing up Ken's first year in power. He has, it seems, achieved nothing at all, made no difference: a few glossy brochures, a lot of spin and a half-remembered row over a pigeon or something. Looks of grudging admiration all round at this singular triumph. They might have him back in the party.

Friday: Finally, we seem to have stopped killing things, and polls show that the countryside doesn't really hate us after all, or at least not as much as they still hate Hague for not being Thatcher or something, so that's all right then I suppose, and we can look forward to a big happy march on London from them some time soon, in which the Metropolitan Police, sponsored by the Daily Mail , will herd them into a street for seven hours and beat them up. And then there's the election too! Joy.

webTitle: Blair basks in Sun's shine

fields.headline: Blair basks in Sun's shine
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Labour party
Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: May 6, Peter Preston: It is, naturally, the Sun wot wins it. No election passes without Britain's most important (or self-important) paper casting a supposedly decisive vote.
fields.body:
It is, naturally, the Sun wot wins it. No election passes without Britain's most important (or self-important) paper casting a supposedly decisive vote. And so it is again. The Sun says: 'The fact is that people like and trust Blair' and 'things can only get better, Tony'. And it adds: 'We could be about to witness one of the lowest moments for the Tory party in recent times - a second humiliation on the trot'.

Those of us old enough to remember Kelvin Mackenzie's 10th anniversary as supreme tabloid editor also remember the happy birthday telephone calls which flooded in. One from Fergie, Duchess of Pork; another from Prime Minister Major. The Sun 's victims, real or potential, do not bite back. They are required to grovel or fawn.

Kelvin's successor, David Yelland, probably feels so loved today. Who's that on his private line? Anji Hunter for No 10? Big Ally Campbell? Whatever became of what we used to call the Tory press?

Take a smattering from the Sun through the past few days. First, a Saturday 'Sunsus' which shows how its readers overwhelmingly love Blair. Then another oleaginous avalanche of pro-New Labour coverage. Hague's handling of the race row has been 'abysmal'. He 'just doesn't get it'. Nor, apparently, do the whingeing citizens of Dover who don't understand that 'the massive influx of asylum seekers has rescued the port's dying tourist trade'.

Feeling dicky about the election? Brace up. An exclusive Sun poll - from Mori - shows you increasing your majority to 227.

And after the triumph, some tricky jugglings in your Cabinet, Prime Minister? Fear not: Kavanagh has it sussed. Out with Derry Irvine, Margaret Jay, Mo Mowlam, Ann Taylor and Chris Smith. In with Liz Symons, Pat Hewitt and Estelle Morris. Make Jack Straw king of environment and David Blunkett Home Secretary. Shunt John Prescott into Cabinet Office limbo and send Lord Gus Macdonald to Trade.

Keen observers may reach two, unstartling conclusions. One is that the No 10 machine is courting Yelland and Kavanagh - which means Rupert Murdoch - with rare fervour, feeding them stories and sticky embraces. (Who'd be the Mirror 's Piers Morgan - doomed to be nice to Labour by duty and history?) Another is that, come 8 June, the swaggering Sun will have 'won it' again.

But perhaps we're entitled to be a little more thoughtful. Consider the 'Sunsus'. You can play devious word games (see how the Mail goes around stirring up apathy), but there's no point giving yourself a bloody nose.

Rupert Murdoch, a welcome guest in No 10 last week, has settled for playing cheerleader - and eschewing chicken and egg debates. Will it last, though? webTitle: 20-year hunt for kidnapped Irish soldier almost over

fields.headline: 20-year hunt for kidnapped Irish soldier almost over
fields.trailText: A breakthrough has finally been achieved in a 20-year investigation into the disappearance of an Irish soldier in Lebanon.
fields.body:
A breakthrough has finally been achieved in a 20-year investigation into the disappearance of an Irish soldier in Lebanon.

Kevin Joyce has been 'missing presumed dead' since April 1981 - the United Nations' only missing-in-action 'blue beret'.

The Inisheer-born private was kidnapped from his UN observation post in south Lebanon by a Palestinian faction a year before the Israelis invaded the region.

Until now, those behind the abduction and suspected murder of the soldier, who was 19 at the time, have refused to admit responsibility.

However, a spokesman for the Irish Defence Forces has confirmed that talks are under way aimed at finding Joyce's remains.

The Irish battalion of Unifil has only seven months left to find the missing soldier's remains - the unit finally pulls out of Lebanon in November.

'Negotiations are still going on,' he said. 'There has been contact with a number of groups. The Irish battalion are dealing with this.'

The battalion is working with the Maronite Bishop of Tyre and the Lebanese Minister for Missing and Displaced Persons, Senator Mirwan Hamadi.

It is understood that Palestinians from refugee camps in south Lebanon have agreed to discuss the whereabouts of Joyce's remains - the first time anyone has admitted knowledge about the missing soldier.

John Laffery, president of the army's union, PDFORRA, travelled to south Lebanon with Joyce's family last week to oversee the investigation into his disappearance.

'This is a festering sore for the Defence Forces,' he said. 'Every soldier that has served in Lebanon over the past 21 years owes to Kevin Joyce that we do everything to find him. Talks are under way and we hope his remains can be found before the Irish battalion pulls out in November.

'All the Joyce family want is to take Kevin's remains back to Ireland so he can be given a Christian burial on Inisheer.'

Joyce's comrade, Hugh Doherty, was shot dead during the raid on their post near the village of Dyar Ntar on 27 April 1981. Pte Doherty, who had just turned 20, was shot three times in the back. Joyce meanwhile, according to UN intelligence reports, was taken to a Palestinian refugee camp in Tyre.

He was shot dead a few weeks later following a gun battle between Palestinians and UN soldiers in south Lebanon. The shoot-out at Deir Amis between the Palestinians and Fijian blue berets sealed Joyce's fate. The young Irish solder was killed in retaliation for the deaths of several Palestinian militiamen.

Further investigations by Irish UN officers over the following 12 months established that a Lebanese man working for a Palestinian faction, Abu Amin Dayk, led the gang that killed Doherty and seized Joyce.

Dayk himself was executed in May 1984 by the Shia Muslim Amal militia for alleged crimes against local Lebanese. He was publicly hanged near the village of Marrakeh.

One Irish officer who tried to track Joyce down actually met Dayk shortly before Amal arrested him.

'Dayk was in his mid-thirties. He was of slight build. He had black hair and spoke in a very deep monosyllabic tone,' the former officer said. 'I remember during that meeting he appeared to be very nervous. You could tell that he was aware that his enemies were closing in.

'It was weird being in the same room as the man we suspected had been behind the Dyar Ntar attack. He was very uneasy during the meeting. He kept looking out the window. When people like Dayk sought a meeting with Unifil you could be sure their power was waning.'

Over the years Irish investigators were fed various red herrings about Joyce's disappearance , including that he was killed in an Israeli air raid on the Ein Hilweh refugee camp during the 1982 invasion and that he had defected to the Palestinian side and started fighting with the guerrillas.
