webTitle: Fight for the Right

fields.headline: Fight for the Right
fields.standfirst:
Blair's sudden interest in crime and asylum reveals how nervous his election team is about losing Middle Britain

Full coverage of Election 2001
Special report: Labour party
Special report: Conservative party
fields.trailText: Blair's sudden interest in crime and asylum reveals how nervous his election team is about losing Middle Britain. By Kamal Ahmed and Gaby Hinsliff.
fields.byline: Special report by Kamal Ahmed and Gaby Hinsliff
fields.body:
The last announcement of Tony Blair's Government will be pregnant with significance. It will not be about education or health or the economy, but about the one problem which has been a constant and nagging thorn in the side of the party: crime.

After months of work by John Halliday, one of the Home Office's brightest civil servants, Home Secretary Jack Straw will finally announce the outcome of the Government's sentencing review on Tuesday. It will be peppered with New Labour language of rights and responsibilities, tougher sentences, reparations paid by the criminal to affected communities or individuals, harsher penalties for the 'persistent 100,000', the group that the Government says accounts for nearly half of all crime. Its language will be uncompromising.

Three days ago Blair wrote an article about being tough on asylum seekers for the Times. On the first Sunday of the general election campaign, he will speak about Labour being the party for 'aspirational Britain'. He is planning a speech on patriotism and British identity. With three days to go before the election is called, a pattern is emerging: Labour fears that the campaign will be hijacked by subjects that are not its natural territory. It fears a fight on the Right.

If Labour has learnt one lesson from its wilderness years, it is this: if your opponents decide to fight on an agenda that you are not comfortable with, the worse thing you can do is ignore it.

Blair, advised by his chief pollster Philip Gould, has said that wherever Tories go during the campaign, he will not be afraid to follow them. There are no taboo subjects.

Today is Blair's 48th birthday. He will spend the morning at Chequers before travelling to London in the evening. Tomorrow, a 'political cabinet' has been called at No 10 to discuss the manifesto. Blair will announce that a million copies of a shorter magazine will also be sent to wavering Labour voters setting out the Government's record. Election fever will grow.

On Tuesday, Straw will make his announcement on crime. Blair then has a 24-hour window in which he will call the election, either later on Tuesday or on Wednesday.

Five weeks ago, when Blair decided to delay the election because of foot and mouth, he faced an uncertain time. Labour critics thought the disease could derail the Government, that it would spiral out of control and the hiatus would allow time for tales of economic gloom to start dominating the headlines. That such thoughts could dominate - with the party so far ahead in the polls that Ladbrokes' odds are now 40 to one on for a Blair victory - reveals one essential truth about those inside the Government bunker: they suffer from chronic twitchiness.

But then came the Tory leadership implosion, followed closely by the Tory race implosion and Blair's circle breathed a sigh of relief. 'We were fortunate,' admitted one key aide. 'We thought it might be a damaging time but actually the Tories made all the political weather for all the wrong reasons for them and the right reasons for us. I think we are actually going into the campaign stronger than we would have been a month ago.'

Downing Street used the five-week delay to try to shore up areas where the public remains suspicious about the Government's record. It feeds the drift rightwards. First Blair made a speech on tackling yob culture, saying that petty criminals would be made to clear up their own graffiti. Then came announcements on health, modernising hospitals and improving care for expectant mothers. He finally confirmed the go-ahead for the baby bond for new parents.

Then, last week, came the Times article on asylum, saying there should be faster removal of those who abuse the system and that the burden of taking asylum-seekers should be shared more equally across Europe. The subject is likely to come up again and again during the election, with the Tories constantly trying to increase the heat. They have mapped out 13 days during the campaign when Europe will be pushed as their main issue. The other days will concentrate on law and order and asylum. Blair has asked Roger Liddle, his foreign affairs adviser in Downing Street, to draft a speech for him saying something 'grand' on patriotism and Britishness and anchoring New Labour as comfortable with the Union Jack. David Miliband, head of the No 10 policy unit, will argue that Britain needs to rediscover its confidence. Blair plans to make the speech in the middle of the campaign.

Blair has told officials that he wants to try to engage some of the enthusiasm that swept him to power. He has taken over writing the first chapter of the manifesto, to inject it with his desire to push for an 'aspirational Britain', to show that he is still the man to look after the interests of Middle Britain. It will be the key theme of his first speech of the campaign next Sunday. An appearance on Breakfast with Frost has been pencilled in and it will be the first push towards 7 June, election day.

Party strategists know the centre ground is where elections are won and lost and that the right-wing agenda is often the popular agenda. The concern is that Labour has mislaid 'the vision thing'. In Downing Street they are worried. Some of the messages are getting confused.

With only 10 days to go before the manifesto is published, there are still bracketed sections where the final wording has not been agreed. In health, where a decision has been taken to dump the waiting list pledge, they are still crunching numbers to see what type of promise they can come up with. Labour is trying to pull the campaign agenda onto its territory of public services and the economy. It knows it will be a struggle and has targeted the BBC to get movement. 'You know when you are getting close to an election, the letters start arriving,' said a BBC executive.

The Tories know their only hope is in keeping the debate as narrowly focused as possible. By banging on the Euro-drum, on asylum, on crime, Hague hopes to drown out the rattling sabres in his own party. His fear is that, during the campaign, leadership rumours will start flourishing.

A small example popped up on Thursday. Michael Portillo's press spokesman bumped into the Mirror journalist Paul Gilfeather who asked him what was happening. Malcolm Gooderham tartly retorted that the only thing a Labour-supporting paper like the Mirror would write about was the men hired to follow Hague around in silly masks.

Gooderham insists it was a sarcastic comment. He awoke to accusations that he had stabbed Hague in the back by bringing the leader's humiliation to the paper's notice.

In the feverish atmosphere surrounding Hague with talk of leadership battles and rifts, it only takes such trivialities to start trouble. Privately, senior figures will do their damnedest to distance themselves from Hague if it appears he is hurtling towards an even larger defeat than that of four years ago. Labour polling reveals that people who didn't vote Labour last time because they felt the party couldn't be trusted could turn out for Blair this time. Labour is trying to silence any talk of a bigger landslide, but many at Millbank believe it will happen. 'We are fighting this election as if it is on a knife-edge,' Campbell insisted yesterday.

Skirmishes on the Right will begin today, with Shadow Foreign Secretary Francis Maude deployed to administer a stiletto between Robin Cook's ribs over the Foreign Secretary's crowning as president of the Party of European Socialists in Berlin tomorrow. Maude believes he can make hay from a document signed by three Labour MEPs condemning the US for being 'drunk with power' and calling for EU states to strengthen integration.

The next day Hague will attack 'rotten boroughs', aimed at embarrassing Labour and the Liberal Democrats with tales of their local councillors embezzling cash, refusing to fly the Union Jack and condemning the national anthem as 'imperialistic'.

The Tory manifesto was finished three days ago, Hague's wife Ffion has booked time off work to accompany him for every day of his tour, and his chief of staff Seb Coe has ensured his leader's gym schedule brings him to the peak of fitness.

Ed Young, another Portillo aide, will manage Hague's battlebus in an overt demonstration of the two men working in tandem, while Portillo and Maude have been jointly entrusted with managing policy announcements. The unswervingly loyal Michael Ancram and Andrew Lansley will run the 'war room' at Smith Square.

Hague wants to fight on the Right: crime, asylum, Europe. Labour fears that the dreaded ' Daily Mail agenda' will drown out their message and they will have to fight on the Right's territory. Hence Blair's article on asylum and the action on crime. Blair has a few hours at Chequers left before returning to London. Then the battle starts.

webTitle: The rogue states

fields.headline: The rogue states
fields.standfirst: Observer special report: The Bush files
fields.trailText: Iran
fields.body:
Iran

Iran insists that it has the right to possess chemical weapons in the light of Iraq's use of those weapons against it in the Iran-Iraq war. Iran is also suspected of seeking to develop nuclear weapons.

Israel

Unsafeguarded nuclear activities in Israel have led supplier nations to impose strict controls on nuclear-related exports to Israel. Israel is not a party to the NPT. However, it has announced that it will abide by the guidelines of the Missile Technology Control Regime. Israel is also a signatory of the CTBT.

Source NAI: 'Nonproliferation, Arms Control and International Security'

www.llnl.gov/nai/default.html

India and Pakistan

Tests in 1998 by India and Pakistan confirmed the nuclear capabilities of these two countries. Neither country has signed the Non-Proliferation Treaty.

Libya

Libya has attempted to build nuclear, chemical, and biological weapons facilities. Libya's ties to a wide range of sub-national groups raise concerns about its role in state-sponsored terrorism.

North Korea

North Korea continues to be a threat to regional stability in East Asia. Severe economic deprivation could motivate North Korea to supply weapons and missile technology to other states.

Iraq

The 1991 Gulf War revealed that, despite the fact that Iraq was party to the Non-Proliferation Treaty and other international agreements, it had built formidable programmes in nuclear, chemical, biological weapons and ballistic missiles. Despite years of intensive inspection and monitoring activities by the UN Special Commission, there is little assurance that Iraq has abandoned its ambitions for weapons of mass destruction.

webTitle: Blair scrapped damning public services report

fields.headline: Blair scrapped damning public services report
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Labour party
Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: Tony Blair secretly scrapped an official report detailing how Britain's public services are still failing under New Labour amid fears that it would give ammunition to the Tories so close to an election.
fields.body:
Tony Blair secretly scrapped an official report detailing how Britain's public services are still failing under New Labour amid fears that it would give ammunition to the Tories so close to an election.

According to leaked memos obtained by The Observer, Blair's officials had drafted an astonishingly candid confession that Britain's schools, hospitals, criminal justice system and core services lacked 'sufficient sustained investment', suffered from staff shortages, low pay and poor leadership, and let down their users.

The NHS was forced to use 'obsolete and unreliable equipment' for diagnosis in the early years under New Labour, the draft notes, while users had been 'expected to fit in with nine-to-five opening hours and a culture based on "put it in writing" and "turn up at the time shown".'

The frank assessment of Britain's crumbling infrastructure - written for a green paper on public services - would not only have given the Tories ammunition, but risked another clash with public-sector workers aggrieved by past criticisms. But the paper was shelved days before publication - even after Blair himself had publicly heralded it in a newspaper article - when aides decided it was still too weak.

Memos from the heart of Downing Street reveal Number 10 was unhappy with it, while senior civil servants are understood to have feared it was too 'political' so close to polling day.

The leaks on the eve of an election campaign are embarrassing for Labour, which is making public services a key theme. Last night the Tories said they showed the Government had run out of ideas.

'This paper has clearly died - most likely they were desperately casting around to make it work and they realised they would end up with something embarrassingly thin,' said Andrew Lansley, shadow cabinet spokesman on public services. 'What is singularly lacking is any reason why public services are going to be more effective in future.'

However Labour insiders argue the best ideas are being worked into the manifesto.

The first note, sent on 16 March by Blair's principal private secretary Jeremy Heywood to Cabinet Ministers' private offices - warns that the document, due for publication on 27 March, is not up to scratch. It looks 'too much like a set of discrete departmental initiatives' with no coherent theme and needs more examples of its key idea, devolving power to public servants, he adds.

Nevertheless, four days later, writing in the Guardian, Blair promised to publish within the week a government paper to 'both set out our reforming approach and make clear our commitment to public services and public servants.'

Nothing materialised, and a second memo from Heywood early in April, after the election was delayed, makes clear he is still unhappy with the paper. He asks trusted Cabinet Office policy wonk Geoff Mulgan to redraft it 'to strengthen the overall thesis and the "next steps".'

Attached is a draft dated 28 March, entitled 'Modernising Public Services' and containing the key chapter entitled: 'Public services: what has gone wrong?'

It admits that 'public service delivery today does not match up to the vision set out in chapter two [of the paper]' and lists the 'problems that stand in the way'.

webTitle: Striptease gold rush

fields.headline: Career girls drop everything to join striptease gold rush
fields.standfirst: Taking your clothes off for cash is turning respectable
fields.trailText: Taking your clothes off for cash is turning respectable, reports Paul Harris.
fields.body:
Andrea Ellery-Doe was bored with the daily routine of her job managing a chain of greetings card shops. The work was hard, the hours long and the pay average.

Her solution was far from mundane: she handed in her notice, joined a table-dancing club and now takes her clothes off for a living. But Ellery-Doe, 28, has no regrets. 'The stigma is disappearing. And it is much better than my old job,' she said.

She is just one of many young professional women flocking to the booming table-dancing and stripping industry. The clubs have begun to shed their seedy reputation and are attracting women who would never before have considered such a career.

With qualifications in retail management, Ellery-Doe was at first hesitant about becoming a table-dancer at Bournemouth's For Your Eyes Only club, but within months she had qualified for the finals of Showgirl 2000, the table-dancing equivalent of the Oscars. Her mother and sister watched her perform.

'At first they were a bit shocked when I gave up my "respectable" career, but now that they see the reality of the industry, they are very supportive,' she said.

Now Ellery-Doe is using her wages to help pay for a degree course in photography at Bournemouth University. When she graduates in two years, she will be among the few students to be relatively debt-free.

The trend is clear. Taking your clothes off is going mainstream. When For Yours Eyes Only wanted dancers at its newest club in London's Mayfair, it placed advertisements in Cosmopolitan and Elle. Hundreds of women phoned in to inquire about auditions. Among them were bankers, nurses, students and estate agents.

'It is not frowned upon anymore,' said Glenn Nicie, operations director at For Your Eyes Only. 'It is seen as more of a career move and a chance to make some very good money.'

The company currently runs four clubs in London, one in Bournemouth and one in Southampton, but has plans for more in Newcastle, Manchester and Cardiff. At the same time Peter Stringfellow, the doyen of Britain's table-dancing scene, plans to expand from his London club in'to Manchester, Birmingham and Leeds.

'The girls see themselves like athletes or professional footballers,' Stringfellow said. 'They can't do this for ever, but can make a lot of money while their careers last.' He employs 120 dancers at his club, where competition for jobs is fierce, with only about one in 20 applications successful.

The boom in venues and the huge profits to be reaped have even attracted American lap-dancing supremo John Gray, who set up his first Spearmint Rhino club at the age of 18. Gray now owns Rhino clubs in Birmingham and London and expects to pull in £180,000 a week from each of his British venues.

Cashing in on the boom is one former British stripper, Jo King, 42, who has just set up the London School of Striptease. She currently conducts one-to-one lessons, but is hoping to rent a studio 'within months' to hold proper group workshops. 'Eventually a proper academy of my own would be my dream,' she said.

Women are attracted by the huge amounts of money that can be made: top table dancers can earn up to £1,000 a night. They also work flexible hours and act as freelance agents. For many, it offers a chance to generate savings that more conventional careers never will.

Michelle Smith, 31, has table-danced at Stringfellows for the last three years. Now she plans to use the cash she made to go back to her native Australia and set up her own business renovating and sell ing old houses. 'It has been a really good career for me. We are not being exploited, it is our own decision to do this,' she said.

But there are dangers. While some clubs and chains consider themselves part of the entertainment industry, there are other operators firmly within the sex trade which fulfil the stereotypes of the past.

Some clubs can cross over the line into exploitation and prostitution. 'There are bad apples out there who can undo all the work we are doing and try to drag the industry back into the gutter,' Nicie said.

But for King, whose stripping career spanned almost two decades, the industry going mainstream is a long-awaited goal. As well as professionals, she says, many of her clients come to her to please a partner or as a self-confidence exercise. The popular image of strippers from Hollywood movies such as Striptease, starring Demi Moore as a struggling single mother, no longer paint a true picture.

'I would love a film that shows a lawyer becoming a stripper because she can earn a lot more money. Wouldn't that be refreshing?'

webTitle: Fan's death sparks war on bigotry

fields.headline: Fan's death sparks war on bigotry
fields.trailText: Cara Henderson knew little about the brutal reality of sectarianism in Glasgow until a school friend was murdered after a football match. Now she leads a battle against bigotry that has reached the Scottish Parliament.
fields.body:
Cara Henderson knew little about the brutal reality of sectarianism in Glasgow until a school friend was murdered after a football match. Now she leads a battle against bigotry that has reached the Scottish Parliament.

Henderson was 15, a pupil at the city's exclusive Glasgow Academy, when Mark Scott, whom she had dated the previous year, was killed.

Scott was walking home from a game at Celtic Football Club's Parkhead ground in 1996 with friends. A man with a knife approached him and slashed his throat.

Although his jacket covered the team shirt he wore, Scott's attacker saw enough to assume he was a Celtic supporter and a Catholic. In court it emerged that close relations of the killer, Jason Campbell, had links to Protestant paramilitary groups.

More than five years later, Henderson campaigns against the religious prejudice that becomes particularly evident when Rangers and Celtic football clubs meet. And she is backing a proposed Bill that aims to make sectarian discrimination and intimidation as unacceptable as racism.

Using Section 33 of the 1998 Crime and Disorder Act as a template, Donald Gorrie, a Liberal Democrat Member of the Scottish Parliament, has tabled additional legislation in Scotland. 'I've exchanged the word racial for sectarian,' he said. 'I always thought it was bizarre that while the Act dealt with people who were beastly to others because of their race it did not deal with those who were beastly to others due to religious bigotry.'

Work carried out by Henderson, now 21, has helped catapult the issue into the public consciousness. Two years after Scott was killed by Campbell, she went to St Hugh's College, Oxford, to read history.

The then Rangers vice-chairman, Donald Findlay, resigned after he sang a sectarian song at a party. Henderson, back in Glasgow for the summer, launched the campaign group Nil By Mouth and took a message of tolerance round schools, churches and the football clubs. Following her graduation last year Cara Henderson returned to Glasgow and, in forging links with the clubs, has stepped up the efforts of Nil By Mouth. The Millennium Commission last year granted £402,000 to a partnership of Nil by Mouth, the football clubs, the Catholic Church, the Church of Scotland, and the city council.

Yet the struggle to overcome ingrained attitudes remains a long one. After a game between Rangers and Celtic last year there were 60 arrests. Of those, 13 were related to stabbings. Yet Henderson maintains the clubs have made an effort. 'People jump on them because they are the most visual example of the problem - but this is a much wider issue than the football clubs. They are merely a symptom of sectarianism, not a cause.'

webTitle: Conman picks Satan alias

fields.headline: Playboy conman picks final alias: Satan
fields.standfirst: After 10 years on the run, under countless false identities, Christopher Rocancourt faces justice at last
fields.trailText: After 10 years on the run, under countless false identities, Christopher Rocancourt faces justice at last. Ed Vulliamy reports.
fields.body:
Some knew him as a friend of Bill Clinton and heir to the Rockefeller family. To others he was son of Sophia Loren, nephew of movie director Dino de Laurentis or friend of Dodi al-Fayed. The swindler, whose real name is Christopher Rocancourt, charmed his way across America from Hollywood to the Hamptons, pursued by police for larceny and conning the rich.

The Rocancourt mystery has captured the imagination of crime writers during his 10 years on the run. But last week, in a Vancouver courtroom, the dashing Rocancourt mask was peeled away to reveal the face of an alleged monster - a violent thug and rapist who told one of his alleged sexual assault victims: 'I am the devil and you are going to have Satan's child.'

Rocancourt was hunted by the FBI and police in New York and LA, but it was Her Majesty's Royal Canadian Mounties who finally picked him up on 20 April on Vancouver Island, for allegedly defrauding a local businessman of $200,000. On Friday this Houdini of the justice system was refused bail, having jumped it twice in LA and the Hamptons. 'This is the end of the line for you,' said Judge John McCarthy. 'You are detained.'

Tomorrow the case continues with an extradition request by the US, at a hearing from which the judge has banned journalists.

Rocancourt, 33, was born in the French fishing village of Honfleur and grew up in orphanages. He allegedly made his criminal debut in a 1991 robbery on a jewellery store in Geneva, for which he was picked up in Las Vegas and sent back to face trial. Prosecutors were unable to prove his part in the robbery, and sentenced him to banishment from Switzerland until 2016.

He moved to Beverly Hills and adopted a playboy lifestyle. He lived in the deluxe Regent Beverly Wilshire hotel and married a Playboy centrefold model, Pia Reyes, while keeping another model, Rhondda Rydell, as mistress. Under adopted names including Christopher Loren and Christopher De Laurentis, he cruised the best clubs, did a business deal involving perfume with singer Jermaine Jackson and befriended actor Mickey Rourke. None of his new friends knew he was under investigation for illegal diamond dealing in Zaire.

He was arrested in 1997 for possession of a loaded weapon after a shoot-out along Santa Monica Boulevard, freed on $175,000 bail, and vanished.

Last year he turned up in the upmarket Hamptons as Christopher Rockefeller. He was widely toasted in Dom Perignon - his hosts unaware that he was wanted as a 'dangerous repeat criminal' for swindling $800,000 in Wall Street investment schemes. He boasted of his properties, ate at the right restaurants and conned elite businessmen into loaning him money against investments that never arrived. He left unpaid bills totalling millions at prestigious hotels.

Ignorance of fine wines proved to be his undoing. When Rocancourt announced his intention to buy five expensive paintings by fashionable Spanish painter Gines Serran-Pagan, the artist offered him the only red wine he had left in the house, a cheap table wine. 'I was embarrassed to be giving cheap wine to a Rockefeller,' he later recalled, 'but he starts sniffing it and says, "It smells like a great Bordeaux".'

The suspicious artist laid on a fake 'celebrity' dinner for Rocancourt, just around the time the Hamptons police were catching up with him, too.

After being arrested on 2 August, Rocancourt was again released, on bail of $45,000 - and again disappeared. While on the run he had the gall to call the New York Times and give an interview. 'I am not a criminal,' he said. 'I steal with my mind.'

After he was caught last month it came as a surprise in New York and LA when the Canadian prosecutors slapped the sexual assault charge on to the indictment. The victim was a 24-year-old, who appeared unidentified last Wednesday during the bail hearing. She said she had struck up a friendship with Rocancourt before he assaulted her on 4 April on a Vancouver Island golf course.

Passing himself off this time as a racing driver whose father had been a Gestapo officer convicted at Nuremberg, Rocancourt took her for a stroll. When the woman refused to divulge her financial information, Rocancourt allegedly became 'enraged' and pounced, shouting his 'Satan' threat, later pointing a gun at his victim and telling her to keep quiet about the attack.

webTitle: Second Dingo attack

fields.headline: Dingoes attack British backpackers days after boy mauled to death
fields.trailText: Two female British backpackers were attacked by wild dingoes three days after a nine-year-old boy was mauled to death by dingoes at the same Australian resort, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Two female British backpackers were attacked by wild dingoes three days after a nine-year-old boy was mauled to death by dingoes at the same Australian resort, it emerged yesterday.

Queensland state Prime Minister Peter Beattie said both women were bitten and scratched when attacked by a male dingo at a campsite on Fraser Island on Thursday.

Schoolboy Clinton Gage was mauled to death and his seven-year-old brother was bitten extensively by at least two dogs near the remote Waddy Point campsite on the island off Queensland last Monday.

The dogs believed to have been responsible for that attack were killed the same day, while the animals involved in the attack on the British tourists were put down yesterday as part of an island-wide cull of at least 28 dingoes.

The attack on the British women has strengthened the government's resolve to continue with the cull despite criticisms from Aboriginal leaders. 'This last attack confirms, as far as I'm concerned, the need for the cull that we went through,' Beattie said.

'Children are more important than dingoes and I will not pull back from the culling, nor will my government.'

One of the tourists, identified only as Katherine, was bitten on the legs and buttocks after she fell while the dingo was chasing her. She said it happened so fast she didn't even see the dingo lunge at her. 'I don't know where it came from,' she said.

Although the cull was due to end by last night, a government spokeswoman said state rangers would continue to target dogs which came into townships and campsites on the island and were considered dangerous to locals and tourists.

The state earlier rejected pleas from Aborigines and conservationists to halt killing of the dingoes.

Aboriginal elder John Dalungadalee Jones and environmentalist Lyndon Schneiders, who went to court to try to halt the cull, expressed disappointment at the verdict.

The Ngulungbara people refer to the wild dogs as brothers in nature and fellow hunters. 'This is our brother, the dingo,' said Jones.

'How would you feel if 30 of your brothers were knocked off? It's a tragic event a child losing its life, but I do not believe it required this level of response.'

The authorities said they were now looking at long-term management of the risk, including plans to stop tourists feeding the dingoes by imposing fines of up to A$1,500 (£540).

The world heritage-listed Fraser Island, which is about 160 miles north of Brisbane, is home to about 160 dingoes. They are considered the purest type of dingo in Australia and a protected species.

Each year they are joined on the island by about 300,000 tourists, who are often blamed for feeding the dogs and encouraging human contact.

The Ngulungbara people refer to the wild dogs as brothers in nature and fellow hunters. 'This is our brother, the dingo,' said Jones. 'How would you feel if 30 of your brothers were knocked off? It's a tragic event a child losing its life, but I do not believe it required this level of response.' The authorities said they were now looking at long-term management of the risk, including plans to stop tourists feeding the dingoes by imposing fines of up to A$1,500 (£540). The world heritage-listed Fraser Island, which is about 160 miles north of Brisbane, is home to about 160 dingoes. They are considered the purest type of dingo in Australia and a protected species. Each year they are joined on the island by about 300,000 tourists, who are often blamed for feeding the dogs and encouraging human contact.

webTitle: Could Zoe's dad be innocent?

fields.headline: Could Zoe's dad be innocent?
fields.standfirst: New investigation queries stepfather's conviction for murder of nine-year-old
fields.trailText: New investigation queries stepfather's conviction for murder of nine-year-old.
fields.byline: Amelia Hill, John Ashton and Evans's mother, Sandra
fields.body:
Vital evidence not heard during one of the most notorious child murder cases in recent years could prove that the man convicted of the crime is innocent and the true killers are still at large, according to a fresh investigation.

Nine-year-old Zoe Evans disappeared from her home in Warminster, Wiltshire, in the early hours of 11 January 1997 after being tucked up for the night by her mother, Paula.

Despite launching Britain's biggest search for a missing person, it took police six and a half weeks to find Zoe's body, in a badger sett less than half a mile from her home.

The post-mortem found that the child had died from asphyxiation - her T-shirt was pushed into her mouth to stop her screaming.

Miles Evans, Zoe's stepfather, who was 27 at the time of the disappearance, was arrested five days after her disappearance when his bloodied T-shirt was found close to the burial scene. Two weeks later, the former soldier was charged with murder.

Evans has always protested his innocence and, although the Court of Appeal announced last week that it would consider his case, he has continued to insist on a full retrial to clear his name.

According to new evidence to be revealed this week, a retrial may prove that Evans could not have murdered Zoe. The investigation points to two other possible suspects whose names were withheld from the original trial because of lack of evidence. It will attempt to prove that Zoe's body was only placed in the badger sett a few days before it was discovered by police; if successful, it could clear Evans's name.

'The prosecution claimed the six-week delay was because the body was originally fully buried and was only later pulled out by animals,' said Steve McDonnell, editor of the Meridian Television Focus programme, to be screened this week.

But five weeks before the body was discovered, a team of Metropolitan Police officers with dogs trained to search for bodies was told not to look in the area around the badger sett, because it had already been searched.

'Evans's movements from the morning after Zoe's disappearance were fully accounted for,' added Ashton. 'So, if the body was put there after that point, he could not have been responsible for the murder.'

The investigation also found that two youths seen roaming around Warminster on the night of Zoe's disappearance, who were later accused of raping a young woman that same night, could have been near Zoe's home at the time she disappeared.

One, identified as Youth A, had a conviction for indecent assault. When questioned by police shortly after the murder, he denied knowing Zoe but later changed his evidence, conceding that he was familiar with the child because she was a schoolfriend of his sister.

The new investigation has also uncovered two witnesses who did not appear in the original trial. They say they saw two men, one bearing a close similarity to Youth A, disposing of a full bin liner in bushes the morning after Zoe's disappearance.

'The men were acting very suspiciously,' said Loretta Pritchard, a local hairdresser. 'They had a bin liner that they were trying to deposit in the trees and one was walking off while the other was looking around, making sure that no one was watching them.'

She reported her sighting to the police but a brief search by an individual officer found nothing. Five days later, however, Pritchard saw someone resembling Youth A for a second time. 'He came back and deposited something else in the same place,' she said. 'He was very furtive.'

Mike Schwarz, Miles Evans's lawyer, said: 'Evidence has now come to light that poses serious questions about the movements and activities of Youths A and B on the night of Zoe's murder. The jury should have heard about those questions and, if they had done, they might have had another account consistent with Miles Evans's innocence.'

Evans's mother, Sandra, maintains her belief in her son's innocence. 'It takes a very clever person to lie for four years and to keep that lie going and not to crack,' she said. 'I'm his mother and I can say that he's not the brightest person but he has not changed his story from the day he was arrested. That takes a clever person. And I don't think he would be able to do it.'

webTitle: Foot and mouth's unlikely winner

fields.headline: Foot and mouth's unlikely winner
fields.standfirst:
The canny Lib Dem Rural Affairs Minister has kept the disease largely at bay in Scotland and gained the respect of farmers. Arnold Kemp reports

Special report: Scottish parliament
fields.trailText: The canny Lib Dem Rural Affairs Minister has kept the disease largely at bay in Scotland and gained the respect of farmers.  Arnold Kemp reports.
fields.body:
Foot and mouth may almost have run its course but the man in charge of the battle in Scotland refuses to declare the epidemic over. Ross Finnie is too canny for that.

This owlish chartered accountant from Greenock, sometimes called 'Captain Mainwaring' by friends and foes alike, is an unlikely political star but that is what he has become.

In a room in the Scottish Parliament, he taps the table for emphasis: 'I don't want the tail of this outbreak to be the progenitor of the next.'

Finnie has had a 'good war' while his counterpart, Agriculture Minister Nick Brown, has blinked under a withering media onslaught, often supplanted in his direction of the crisis by Tony Blair who toyed with diluting the slaughter policy with vaccination.

By contrast Finnie, enjoying freedom of action as a Lib Dem Minister in Britain's first peacetime coalition government, has exuded a quiet authority and held to a consistent policy line. He told London bluntly Scotland would not vaccinate and put its future export trade at risk.

And English commentators have begun to say that the Scottish model of a department of rural affairs, which sets farming in a wider economic and environmental context, points the way forward for England, too, where Maff is generally discredited as the tool of agribusiness.

Finnie, 54, resists the contrast with Brown. Like all such comparisons, he says, it is odious. Scotland has been lucky. The outbreak has largely been confined to Dumfries and Galloway. And Scotland has short lines of communication. 'It's a heck of a different proposition from sitting in Smith Square and trying to control Cumbria.'

But yes, he says, a lot of it is down to hard work and close co-operation with the 'stakeholders' - the farmers, hauliers, abattoirs and so on. One of the first things he did as a new Minister, long before the outbreak, was to build a new relationship with the Scottish farmers' union. 'I inherited a situation where there seemed to be a deep suspicion of government.'

So there was a 'slightly better sense of trust' when difficult decisions had to be made. He taps the table again. 'No one liked taking them. They were hard, hard decisions. But it was better for me to be able to announce them in the knowledge that the stake holders, with all sorts of misgivings about the misery it was going to cause, felt it was the right direction to go in.'

For a while he was mocked in some Scottish papers as the tool and 'tartan' face of Maff and it is true that a civil servant from the Scottish Executive was dispatched to London in a liaison role. But Finnie insists that the decisions were taken in his own office on the basis of Scottish scientific evidence.

When London began to talk about vaccination - planting stories in the lobby that it was imminent - Finnie dug his heels in. There were signs that the cull policy was beginning to work. The idea was that vaccination could be used on 'the perimeter ring'. But, he points out, that would not have stopped the outbreaks in Wigtown or Jedburgh. 'So to suggest this was the answer to the mother's prayer was really far-fetched.'

He continues: 'We simply, on a regular basis, took the evidence. I was quite clear that if we were going to defeat this I had to be fully informed. We had to have a clear policy and that had to apply to farmers in unambiguous terms.'

Was he by implication criticising London? 'No. I don't want to. I have a job to do _ We recognised - there's no point in being pig-headed about this - that we're in the United Kingdom and that the disease knows no borders.'

If the English had vaccinated, 'confusions' would have arisen 'particularly with the proximity of Cumbria'.

Wasn't it odd, though, that no sooner had Maff spared Phoenix the calf than the Scottish Executive did the same for Porky, a Vietnamese pot-bellied pig kept as a pet by a couple in Dumfries and Galloway?

Finnie bristles slightly. 'That's very different. I made no exception at all for the pig in Scotland. It was highly fortuitous that we had changed at midnight, two days previously, the regulations of how we were going to deal with the cull. That change in the regulations saved Porky.

'People had made a huge sacrifice by having their animals slaughtered in serious farming; it would have been absolute anathema to me to have destroyed that trust by making a single exception.'

When environment was added to Finnie's rural development portfolio after Sam Galbraith's decision to stand down earlier this year, there were howls of outrage from conservationists. These grew in volume last week when Finnie declined to order a public inquiry into salmon farming and its methods.

A conflict of interest? 'Och,' he says, 'not at all. There are always conflicts. The question is: what are you going to deliver? You have to engage with the people who are trying to promote a better environment, but you also have to engage with the players. I think I have a crucial role as an interlocutor.'

As for fish farming, 'we've put in place eight or nine things we want to happen, to investigate or change the practice of fish farming. For me to have said I need a public inquiry would involve me saying that the eight or nine things ain't working.'

The SNP and the Tories in the Scottish Parliament say the Lib Dems will be punished by voters for having 'taken the soup' with Labour in the coalition. Finnie, not surprisingly, doesn't agree. 'The proof of the pudding will be in the eating and that will be tested in two years' time' - the Scottish elections of 2003.

After all, the voters declined to give any party an overall majority. 'I hope they will regard it as having been better for political parties to have respected the will of the people and not pretended that the election didn't happen and that you just carry on governing regardless.'

The Lib Dems, he adds, will be 'able to campaign on a basis that we have never ever done before, certainly not since 1920-something. We can go into this election saying that was our manifesto and some 80 per cent of it has been delivered. And so you have to look at the Liberal Democrats in a very different way, as a party that has actually been in government.'

webTitle: Holy bones give faith a lift

fields.headline: Holy bones give faith a lift
fields.standfirst: Britain to be next stop on world tour after saint's relics captivate Ireland
fields.trailText: Britain to be next stop on world tour after saint's relics captivate Ireland.
fields.byline: Nick Paton Walsh and Nicola Byrne, Dublin
fields.body:
The Roman Catholic Church is considering plans to allow the remains of an inspirational French saint to tour Britain after visits to Russia, France and Ireland sparked frenzied scenes of religious fervour and an upsurge of Catholics, young and old, returning to their faith.

For a Church battered by decades of scandal and dwindling congregrations, the story of St Thérèse of Lisieux has emerged as an unexpected success for the Vatican in its efforts to shed a tarnished image and usher disillusioned Catholics back into the fold.

Thérèse was born on 2 January 1873, at Alençon France. One of nine children, she took her vows at 17 and died of tuberculosis seven years later. Described by Pope Pius X as 'the greatest saint of modern times', she was declared a Doctor of the Church by Pope John Paul II in October 1997 - becoming only the third woman out of 32 people so honoured. Ironically, for a Church opposed to the idea, her ambition was to become a priest.

Before she died, she wrote an account of her life. The book, The Story of a Soul, was edited by one of her sisters and became a symbol for people who persevere through daily, minor troubles. It was translated into 50 languages and was avidly read by singer Edith Piaf and author Jack Kerouac.

The remains of St Thérèse were taken on a tour of her native France in 1994 before travelling abroad in 1997 - the centenary of her death. The casket, presented on behalf of the people of Brazil upon her beatification in 1923, went first to the South American country and has now visited 23 states with bookings for what has been dubbed her 'world tour' already taken for 2005.

The relics are halfway through a 75-day tour of Ireland. The organisers of the Irish leg predict more than one million people will see the casket containing half of the saint's skeleton - the rest remains in France - during the countrywide tour. The relics have drawn large crowds since their arrival more than a month ago.

Last week the French organisers of the visit said there was considerable interest in organising a British tour. A spokesman for the Catholic Church in London said yesterday an invitation was being considered.

Thérèse could prove a magnet to Britons searching for meaning in their lives. While there are 4.1 million Catholics in England and Wales, only 8 per cent attend church regularly.

'Thérèse stands for the quotidian grind that we all suffer from, and the eventual beatification that can be found in it,' said Sheridan Gilley, a reader in theology at Durham University. 'So she has a huge number of followers who are not Catholic.

'The role of relics in the life of English Catholics has been played down,' said Gilley, adding that they would receive an enthusiastic welcome in Britain. 'Thérèse is the saint to approach with the daily trials and tribulations we all face. She stands for the holiness of small things.'

In Ireland, the streets have been thronged in scenes not witnessed since the Pope's visit in 1979. Traffic has ground to a halt out of respect for the 'Thérèsemobile', the Mercedes people-carrier that transports her casket around each diocese. 'The visit has succeeded beyond our most optimistic expectations,' said Father Linus Ryan, one of the organisers. 'There is a certain supernatural divine magnetism about it all.'

webTitle: Binman Benji sues jewellery empire heir

fields.headline: Binman Benji sues jewellery empire heir
fields.trailText: He is best known for rummaging through the dustbins of the rich and famous. But Benjamin Pell has betrayed an appetite for Hollywood glory in a bizarre legal action launched against John Mappin, an heir to the Mappin and Webb jewellery empire.
fields.body:
He is best known for rummaging through the dustbins of the rich and famous. But Benjamin Pell has betrayed an appetite for Hollywood glory in a bizarre legal action launched against John Mappin, an heir to the Mappin and Webb jewellery empire.

'Benji the binman' has been a legend in Fleet Street since the Sunday Times and other papers began to base exclusives on his smelly but newsworthy discoveries. And when the idea arose to make a movie about his life, he jumped at the chance.

But his dream has turned sour. Pell is accusing Mappin of hoodwinking him out of nearly £80,000 with empty promises to turn his story into 'the biggest movie of all time'.

He says he handed the money over to pay the travel costs and expenses of an American 'filmmaker' introduced to him by Mappin. He claims the man, allegedly described by Mappin as 'the most powerful person in Hollywood', turned out to be a hairdresser whom Mappin met at a Scientology meeting.

Pell says nothing came of the movie. He wants his money back and is accusing Mappin of fraudulent misrepresentation. Mappin denies the allegations and says he is going to file a counterclaim against Pell.

Thanks to his muckraking activities, Pell, 36, is no stranger to the courts. A former trainee solicitor who lives with his parents in Hendon, north London, he first attracted attention in 1997 after searching through the bins of Elton John's manager and discovering details of the star's finances. He took his scoop to the tabloids and has been repeating the trick ever since. His victims range from girl band All Saints to Lottery company Camelot and Philip Gould, a key aide to Tony Blair. Pell's new adversary is almost as colourful. Mappin's business interests include a local newspaper company in London and Camelot Castle, a King Arthur-themed hotel in Tintagel, Cornwall.

Mappin, 36, has also been involved in a number of film projects in the US and is currently embarking on a new career as a pop star. According to Camelot Castle's website, his first album, Silence, will soon be available.

Pell's legal claim, submitted to the High Court in London, says Mappin first proposed the idea of the film in June 1999. Mappin allegedly said the movie would be based on Pell's life story and would be 'a $10 million blockbuster', but that it could only be made properly by one man - William Iain Jones.

Mappin allegedly said Jones had introduced John Travolta to Quentin Tarantino 'and secured him the part in Pulp Fiction'. Pell claims that Mappin offered to introduce him to Jones. But he says he was told he would have to pay the US producer £10,000 in consideration for his time.

Pell also says he was told Jones could not be expected to stay in 'any old motel', and handed over a further £3,375 to cover accommodation costs. Pell claims he first met Jones a few weeks later at London's Four Seasons Hotel. At that point, he says, an agreement was struck and Jones filmed him at work as a prelude to the movie project.

According to Pell's statement of claim, Mappin later persuaded him to pay additional sums totalling more than £53,000 to cover Jones's expenses. Meanwhile, he says, Mappin assured him that Jones was busy at work on the project in California.

By March 2000, Pell says he was becoming suspicious. When Mappin allegedly asked him for a further £40,000, he refused. He accuses Mappin of 'creating a sham appearance that a bona fide film was being made' to get as much of his money as possible.

Pell also says Jones 'was neither well-known nor well-connected nor highly influential nor trustworthy nor experienced' as a producer. 'In fact, Mr Jones was not a qualified film producer at all; rather, he was a hairdresser.'

Pell was not returning calls last week. Mappin maintains the movie is still being made and Pell's money was used for the purpose intended. He admitted Jones was a hairdresser but said he was also a 'keen and enthusiastic film producer starting his career' who had studied filmmaking formally. Mappin added: 'I will be vigorously defending this claim.'

He says he handed the money over to pay the travel costs and expenses of an American 'filmmaker' introduced to him by Mappin. He claims the man, allegedly described by Mappin as 'the most powerful person in Hollywood', turned out to be a hairdresser whom Mappin met at a Scientology meeting. Pell says nothing came of the movie. He wants his money back and is accusing Mappin of fraudulent misrepresentation. Mappin denies the allegations and says he is going to file a counterclaim against Pell. Thanks to his muckraking activities, Pell, 36, is no stranger to the courts. A former trainee solicitor who lives with his parents in Hendon, north London, he first attracted attention in 1997 after searching through the bins of Elton John's manager and discovering details of the star's finances. He took his scoop to the tabloids and has been repeating the trick ever since. His victims range from girl band All Saints to Lottery company Camelot and Philip Gould, a key aide to Tony Blair. Pell's new adversary is almost as colourful. Mappin's business interests include a local newspaper company in London and Camelot Castle, a King Arthur-themed hotel in Tintagel, Cornwall. Mappin, 36, has also been involved in a number of film projects in the US and is currently embarking on a new career as a pop star. According to Camelot Castle's website, his first album, Silence, will soon be available. Pell's legal claim, submitted to the High Court in London, says Mappin first proposed the idea of the film in June 1999. Mappin allegedly said the movie would be based on Pell's life story and would be 'a $10 million blockbuster', but that it could only be made properly by one man - William Iain Jones. Mappin allegedly said Jones had introduced John Travolta to Quentin Tarantino 'and secured him the part in Pulp Fiction'. Pell claims that Mappin offered to introduce him to Jones. But he says he was told he would have to pay the US producer £10,000 in consideration for his time. Pell also says he was told Jones could not be expected to stay in 'any old motel', and handed over a further £3,375 to cover accommodation costs. Pell claims he first met Jones a few weeks later at London's Four Seasons Hotel. At that point, he says, an agreement was struck and Jones filmed him at work as a prelude to the movie project. According to Pell's statement of claim, Mappin later persuaded him to pay additional sums totalling more than £53,000 to cover Jones's expenses. Meanwhile, he says, Mappin assured him that Jones was busy at work on the project in California. By March 2000, Pell says he was becoming suspicious. When Mappin allegedly asked him for a further £40,000, he refused. He accuses Mappin of 'creating a sham appearance that a bona fide film was being made' to get as much of his money as possible. Pell also says Jones 'was neither well-known nor well-connected nor highly influential nor trustworthy nor experienced' as a producer. 'In fact, Mr Jones was not a qualified film producer at all; rather, he was a hairdresser.' Pell was not returning calls last week. Mappin maintains the movie is still being made and Pell's money was used for the purpose intended. He admitted Jones was a hairdresser but said he was also a 'keen and enthusiastic film producer starting his career' who had studied filmmaking formally. Mappin added: 'I will be vigorously defending this claim.'

webTitle: Biker death sparks new feud

fields.headline: Biker death sparks new feud
fields.standfirst: Denmark fears a return to Hell's Angels gang conflict in wake of bizarre murder
fields.trailText: Denmark fears a return to Hell's Angels gang conflict in wake of bizarre murder.
fields.body:
It has been dubbed the 'Orient Express' killing. Denmark may be an unlikely place for a grisly gangland slaying, but Claus Bork Hansen was riddled with 26 bullets in a murder that some fear could herald the resumption of vicious warfare between Hell's Angels gangs.

The frenzied nature of the killing, now being considered by a Copenhagen court, was unusual in itself but there was something else strange about the terrible execution. Investigators found evidence suggesting Hansen, formerly a leader of the infamous Bandidos biker gang, was gunned down by five different assassins.

The detective in charge of the inquiry, Kurt Jensen, might follow in the footsteps of Agatha Christie's sleuth, Hercule Poirot. In Murder on the Orient Express, the motley cast of suspects all turn out to have had a hand in the stabbing of the American passenger, and it would seem Hansen was dispatched in a similarly collective fashion.

Returning home to his house in the Vanlose suburb of Copenhagen a month ago, having been out for a meal with his girlfriend, he was ambushed as he went to unlock his front door.

Nineteen shots from a single pistol thumped into his body, including the coup de grace which smashed his skull at point-blank range as it slumped to the pavement. At the same time seven other bullets struck the biker, who was thought to have been under investigation for protection racketeering.

The killers, believed to number as many as five, sped off in a stolen black Audi which was later found burnt out. The various weapons used to kill Hansen turned up, but many had been partially destroyed in a crude attempt to do away with the evidence.

But the rare and exotic nature of the weapons used persuaded Copenhagen's finest investigative minds that this was not the work of amateurs. The bloodied pistol was a 9mm Norinco Chinese model, while police uncovered four other distinctive weapons: a 9mm Star gun, a Czech-made 9mm Taurus gun and two pump-action shotguns - a Winchester Stainless marine and a CBC Remington, both of which had been manufactured to order in Brazil.

Police were quick to charge a 29-year-old social worker with supplying the murder weapons to the unknown killers, only inexplicably to release him later. A 40-year-old suspect - with links to organised crime - has now been charged with the murder of Hansen, but his accomplices remain at large.

According to the newspaper Berlingske Tidende, the unidentified suspect, who police believe delivered the killer shot to Hansen as he lay on the ground, protests his innocence. Police did not have to look too hard to find him, because they realised he was already in prison for an unrelated offence.

It was feared the killing might signal a resumption of the bloody 'Biker Wars', which swept through Scandinavia in the 1990s, when the Bandidos fought their rivals, the Hell's Angels, with the loss of about 25 lives. But some investigators say Hansen may have been bumped off by his former comrades in the Bandidos, with whom he is alleged to have fallen out.

Hansen received death threats connected with a fraud scam. He is said to have turned down police protection.

Sources familiar with Scandinavia's violent biker gangs, the European branches of their feared American counterparts, say Hansen, once the leader of the Hedehusene Copenhagen chapter, had got on the wrong side of his former biker friends.

But if Hansen's execution is the beginning of another wave of biker violence, often connected with feuding over drug dealing, then the police face a serious problem.

webTitle: Berlusconi attacks 'foreign plotters'

fields.headline: Berlusconi attacks 'foreign plotters'
fields.standfirst: Election rests on whether Italy believes claims of a 'commie plot'
fields.trailText: Election rests on whether Italy believes claims of a 'commie plot', reports Rory Carroll from Rome.
fields.body:
Italy is in turmoil over an election that has mutated into an unprecedented contest between Silvio Berlusconi and the international media.

Condemnation of the centre-right opposition leader has swelled to a cacophony, which could prove decisive at the polls next Sunday. Berlusconi has hit back with accusations of a foreign plot orchestrated by business rivals, leaving voters deafened and the ruling centre-left all but forgotten.

Newspapers and magazines from Britain, Germany, Spain and the United States have sailed into uncharted water with a combined assault that could determine who rules the world's sixth-largest industrialised economy. Accusations that Berlusconi, 64, was a crook and ineligible for office because of his media empire have electrified Italy, which has long genuflected before the supposed wisdom of the foreign press. Issues such as jobs, crime and illegal immigration have faded as the tycoon has launched counter-attacks, beseeching Italians not to believe character assassins.

Analysts say the outcry is likely to sway a significant number of voters. But which way? Pollsters are struggling to calculate the impact. Francesco Rutelli, the government's candidate for Prime Minister, is euphoric.

He hailed the foreign intervention as the 'real turning point' of the campaign. The French left-wing daily Libération splashed a photo of his rival in a Mussolini-type pose. The headline was in Italian: 'He is dangerous.'

He could not wish for more august hatchet-men: apart from Libération they include the Economist, Financial Times, International Herald Tribune, Wall Street Journal, Le Monde, El Mundo and the Süddeutsche Zeitung.

They have hammered him for a slew of corruption allegations that tainted his rise to becoming the world's 14 richest man, according to Forbes magazine.

Above all they have hammered him for not offloading his three television networks, which give unrivalled influence over public opinion. 'Why Silvio Berlusconi is unfit to lead Italy,' said the headline in the Economist, which Berlusconi is suing.

Süddeutsche Zeitung weighed in: 'Never in a European democracy has such a man stood for election. Such a man represents a danger for Italy and a challenge for Europe.'

El Mundo even reported that Spanish judge Baltasar Garzón, who indicted Pinochet, has asked Italy to lift Berlusconi's parliamentary immunity from prosecution. The judge is investigating allegations of tax fraud.

Every day heralds fresh grief for Berlusconi. What makes it so damaging is that many of the critics are pro-business right-wingers. They cannot be dismissed as communist plotters. So one would think. But Berlusconi has done precisely that.

He accused the Economist of trying to help its former Rome correspondent, Tana de Zulueta, retain her senate seat with the ruling Democrats of the Left. This allegedly made her a communist and the magazine a communist sympathiser. 'I think the Italian people have understood that the left is desperate, will do anything and will launch these attacks in all sorts of different directions,' said Berlusconi.

At first many Italians mocked his logic, but as more publications joined the assault the mood changed. The international press seemed less a font of objective wisdom and more like a bully. Pride was pricked. 'I'm left-wing but I'm not going to genuflect just to be kicked in the face. Italy is being patronised and insulted,' said one columnist.

Rome cafes buzzed with the theory that big business in Europe was trying to stop Berlusconi turning Italy into a serious competitor. Giovanni Agnelli, the head of Fiat and no fan of Berlusconi, said: 'The newspapers have addressed themselves to our electorate as if it were the electorate of a banana republic.'

Last Saturday's opinion polls, the last that could be published under election laws, showed the centre-right coalition leading by 4 per cent. Rutelli claims to have caught up and some analysts suggest the government has an outside chance of retaining a majority in the senate.

Thanks to a coalition with the Northern League and National Alliance, Berlusconi seems almost certain to take the chamber of deputies. If he wins, it will be left to historians to decide if it was despite, or because of, the international press.

webTitle: French agony over Algeria 'Gestapo'

fields.headline: French agony over Algeria 'Gestapo'
fields.trailText: France was plunged into a rancorous examination of its imperial past last night as the country agonised over whether its leading politicians knew of a so-called French 'Gestapo in Algeria' that committed atrocities during the colony's war for independence.
fields.body:
France was plunged into a rancorous examination of its imperial past last night as the country agonised over whether its leading politicians knew of a so-called French 'Gestapo in Algeria' that committed atrocities during the colony's war for independence.

General Paul Aussaresses, 83, admitted in a book published on Thursday that he and his men tortured and summarily executed Algerian guerrillas and civilians in the Fifties with, he alleged, the blessing of the French government.

Aussaresses was in charge of undercover operations during the battle of Algiers in 1957 at the height of the war for Algerian independence.

In the most telling accusation, Aussaresses pointed the finger at François Mitterrand, Justice Minister at the time and later France's President, saying he was well aware of the practices and condoned them.

French historians and journalists are now complaining that it has been impossible to confirm or falsify Aussaresses's allegations because government archives con cerning the 1954-62 war of independence remain closed.

It was only on 26 April that Prime Minister Lionel Jospin ordered the government's archives to be opened to historians. The result is likely to be a spate of books and a fraught debate over French wartime excesses.

As early as 1955, a French magazine spoke of 'Our Gestapo in Algeria' but, at peace accords signed in 1962, both the Algerian FLN and the French Republic agreed to draw a line under these excesses.

For nearly four decades since there has been a conspiracy of silence - now rudely interrupted by Aussaresses's unrepentant memoir.

He admits to personally killing 24 Algerians. Aussaresses said: 'Torture's efficient. The majority of people crack and talk. Then, most of the time, we kill them.'

Historian Jean Lacouture said: 'I get the feeling that this old soldier is trying to glory in what he did. He's bragging about these crimes.'

Successive governments have played down allegations of officially sanctioned use of torture by French forces and avoided calls for a formal inquiry, an official apology or criminal action against those involved.

webTitle: Leader: the drinking laws

fields.headline: Last orders
fields.standfirst: Time, gentlemen, please, for drinking
fields.trailText: Among vices, Thomas de Quincey ranked drink between murder and incivility. Once it was the curse of the working classes but for many it now points the way to European sophistication.
fields.body:
Among vices, Thomas de Quincey ranked drink between murder and incivility. Once it was the curse of the working classes but for many it now points the way to European sophistication. Aspirants toil in kitchens over the Mediterranean cookbook, insisting that the basil is fresh and the olive oil extra virgin and choose their wines with care.

But all too often the real world falls woefully short of our ideals. The evidence may be found in any city centre on a Sunday - litter, vomit and broken glass. Do we really want more? The Government is now dazzling the electorate with visions of round-the-clock licensing. Yet the Scots are having doubts about their liberal laws and the French are turning to mineral water.

The old complaint that it's a long time between drinks is a lugubrious statement of the way the world is and, perhaps, sadly, has to be.
