webTitle: Ambition and New Labour

fields.headline: Ambition and New Labour
fields.standfirst:
It was once a dirty word in the political lexicon. Not any more. Rather, argues Peter Mandelson as campaigning for the next general election becomes more intense, it must be the watchword for New Labour as it pursues its aim to be a true reforming social democratic party

Special report: Labour party
Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: It was once a dirty word in the political lexicon. Not any more. Rather, argues  Peter Mandelson  as campaigning for the next general election becomes more intense, it must be the watchword for New Labour as it pursues its aim to be a true reforming social democratic party.
fields.body:
Competence is the foundation of New Labour's success in government. In the past four years, we have buried the deeply held public doubts about Labour's fundamental ability to govern. There has been no 1976 IMF crisis, no 1966-67 devaluation crisis, no 1947 convertibility crisis, let alone the collapse of 1931. The stigma of mid-term breakdown that dogged Labour throughout its history has finally been banished.

Gordon Brown's magisterial command of the economy has been an outstanding success for this administration. There were early complaints about excessive discipline in spending but, correctly, we gave priority to the control of inflation, sustainable public finances and creating the conditions for a full employment society. As a consequence, there has been a seismic shift in British politics. The mantle of competence, the ability of governments to implement their policies while responding effectively to unexpected crises, slipped from the Conservatives after the 1992 ERM crisis and has been confidently assumed by New Labour since 1997.

Yet competence is never enough. It is a foundation, not a goal in politics. As a modern social democrat, I strongly believe there is a deeper purpose to our political objectives - to transfer to the majority the opportunities and life-chances previously available only to the privileged few. But more fundamentally to grant every individual the right to self-fulfilment and expression that is a basic requirement of social justice.

Britain, therefore, needs more than competence from government. It needs a reforming New Labour administration with a range of coherent policies and programmes, rather than patchwork initiatives, that can both tackle the worst social and economic problems and give every individual and family the chance to get on and realise their ambition. Ambition must be New Labour's compass for the second term and beyond.

No politician would declare that they were 'against' ambition. Mrs Thatcher claimed to stand for ambition, yet she destroyed opportunities for millions of people by ill-conceived social and economic policies that drained prosperity and hope from thousands of communities, not least my town of Hartlepool.

'Ambition' is conventionally associated with political projects of the Right. It is about upward mobility, earning more and progressing up the social ladder. That is why the centre-Left has stuck to social democratic goals of 'equality', 'solidarity' and 'fraternity'. These terms supposedly illuminate the contrasts with the interests and values of the Right.

Yet these 'traditional' goals have often been a cul-de-sac for the centre-Left. They have manifested themselves in opposition to council house sales, a levelling-down approach to education, an unreformed welfare system and hostility to private enterprise. By the early 1980s, Labour had created the impression that we were hostile to ambition itself. But the notion of ambition, both for the individual and society, is at the heart of modern social democracy. We should be confident in articulating our belief in ambition to the general public.

A second-term Labour Government cannot simply be about the completion of 'work in progress'. It is about inaugurating a new age of ambition in our country, a compelling vision of a different kind of society, weaving together the rightful quest for material affluence with a deeper striving for better relationships, stronger families, a vibrant culture, genuine tolerance and diversity and, ultimately, a new balance between work and other aspects of life.

What exactly do social democrats mean by promoting ambition? First, it is clearly more than satisfying the instinct to get on in the market economy, though business enterprise is an important means of realising ambition. New Labour needs to promote the idea that personal success is not judged only in terms of financial worth.

Being ambitious is about individuals enhancing their sense of self-respect and well being, maybe in 'conventional' forms of work, but also by volunteering, caring and following creative or intellectual pursuits. What concerns social democrats is that the means of realising personal ambition are shared equally.

Equally important is being ambitious for our society, not just removing harsh and intolerable social injustices, but promoting a culture where people genuinely have equal worth. A New Labour second term needs to translate our goal of ambition into realistic policies capable of practical implementation. It means investing in those things that liberate individual potential.

Education is the obvious starting-point. Under the Conservatives, spending on education fell dramatically as a proportion of national wealth. Labour has reversed that trend. Primary school results have improved dramatically, secondary school results more slowly.

In the second term, radical change must continue, not just through investment in schools, though this is essential. There must be greater flexibility not just in employing teachers and staff, but in varying the curriculum and providing an alternative vocational route for 14- to 18-year-olds that is held in equal regard to the A-level system. Raising the quality of new entrants to teaching is also crucial.

Another area in which to liberate potential is the creation of an active welfare state. 'Work for those who can, security for those who cannot' is central to reviving personal ambition. Welfare is not about a safety-net or a hand-out, but about helping people to help themselves and widening participation in employment. But the definition of work needs to be broader, encompassing non-paid employment in caring and volunteering.

This could mean a new agency combining work and benefits, but this must be based on developing the concept of employability, not returning to the old agenda of 'work to welfare' or pretending that the Government can 'create jobs'. The DFEE has now established an enviable reputation in business and commerce for pioneering both employability and welfare to work.

On pensions, shared responsibility through the new stakeholder schemes, and helping individuals to build up financial resources, of which the 'baby bond' scheme is an excellent starting point, are important building blocks. But we need to do more. It involves investment to transform adult skills, especially in IT. It means enabling more people to start up their own businesses with venture capital and enterprise grants.

Widening personal ambition does not mean cutting back the welfare state. It involves greater state support, more intelligently targeted, 'tailormade' solutions and active prevention rather than passive intervention when welfare problems have already grown.

Finally, New Labour must promote social entrepreneurship. The deeply complex problems of urban and neighbourhood disintegration pose problems of a fundamental kind. We need to give people the tools and resources to find solutions to their own problems within local communities.

We must address not just the poverty of individual expectations from families trapped on benefits, but the poverty of hope that comes from demoralised communities. The Government's radical tax-benefit reforms are set to conquer child poverty for a generation. The task for the second term is to transform the fabric and social condition of Britain's neighbourhoods so that young people have a decent and supportive local environment in which to grow up.

We have strong programmes to build on, including the New Deal for Communities and the excellent ideas provided by the Social Exclusion Unit. We must revive the culture of civic leadership in Britain. There is a risk of having too many disconnected central government initiatives and we need to channel money to local projects.

The spirit of ambition must radiate from our country and create greater respect for Britain in the world. Britain can give a lead in two urgent tasks: resolving the conflict over the Kyoto accord on environmental sustainability, and offering ideas for a multilateral framework for arms control. An ambitious society does not retreat into narrow isolationism.

Ambition is a far-reaching concept and a distinctive goal for social democrats. Our task is to define it in the centre-Left's terms. Anthony Crosland, the leading Labour theorist of postwar social democracy, famously argued in The Future of Socialism : 'We do not want to enter the age of abundance only to find that we have lost the values that might teach us how to enjoy it.'

The creation of a truly ambitious society is a worthy goal for a second-term New Labour government. The coming election campaign gives us the chance to make the case for social democratic ambition with clarity and conviction.
fields.bodyText: Competence is the foundation of New Labour's success in government. In the past four years, we have buried the deeply held public doubts about Labour's fundamental ability to govern. There has been no 1976 IMF crisis, no 1966-67 devaluation crisis, no 1947 convertibility crisis, let alone the collapse of 1931. The stigma of mid-term breakdown that dogged Labour throughout its history has finally been banished. Gordon Brown's magisterial command of the economy has been an outstanding success for this administration. There were early complaints about excessive discipline in spending but, correctly, we gave priority to the control of inflation, sustainable public finances and creating the conditions for a full employment society. As a consequence, there has been a seismic shift in British politics. The mantle of competence, the ability of governments to implement their policies while responding effectively to unexpected crises, slipped from the Conservatives after the 1992 ERM crisis and has been confidently assumed by New Labour since 1997. Yet competence is never enough. It is a foundation, not a goal in politics. As a modern social democrat, I strongly believe there is a deeper purpose to our political objectives - to transfer to the majority the opportunities and life-chances previously available only to the privileged few. But more fundamentally to grant every individual the right to self-fulfilment and expression that is a basic requirement of social justice. Britain, therefore, needs more than competence from government. It needs a reforming New Labour administration with a range of coherent policies and programmes, rather than patchwork initiatives, that can both tackle the worst social and economic problems and give every individual and family the chance to get on and realise their ambition. Ambition must be New Labour's compass for the second term and beyond. No politician would declare that they were 'against' ambition. Mrs Thatcher claimed to stand for ambition, yet she destroyed opportunities for millions of people by ill-conceived social and economic policies that drained prosperity and hope from thousands of communities, not least my town of Hartlepool. 'Ambition' is conventionally associated with political projects of the Right. It is about upward mobility, earning more and progressing up the social ladder. That is why the centre-Left has stuck to social democratic goals of 'equality', 'solidarity' and 'fraternity'. These terms supposedly illuminate the contrasts with the interests and values of the Right. Yet these 'traditional' goals have often been a cul-de-sac for the centre-Left. They have manifested themselves in opposition to council house sales, a levelling-down approach to education, an unreformed welfare system and hostility to private enterprise. By the early 1980s, Labour had created the impression that we were hostile to ambition itself. But the notion of ambition, both for the individual and society, is at the heart of modern social democracy. We should be confident in articulating our belief in ambition to the general public. A second-term Labour Government cannot simply be about the completion of 'work in progress'. It is about inaugurating a new age of ambition in our country, a compelling vision of a different kind of society, weaving together the rightful quest for material affluence with a deeper striving for better relationships, stronger families, a vibrant culture, genuine tolerance and diversity and, ultimately, a new balance between work and other aspects of life. What exactly do social democrats mean by promoting ambition? First, it is clearly more than satisfying the instinct to get on in the market economy, though business enterprise is an important means of realising ambition. New Labour needs to promote the idea that personal success is not judged only in terms of financial worth. Being ambitious is about individuals enhancing their sense of self-respect and well being, maybe in 'conventional' forms of work, but also by volunteering, caring and following creative or intellectual pursuits. What concerns social democrats is that the means of realising personal ambition are shared equally. Equally important is being ambitious for our society, not just removing harsh and intolerable social injustices, but promoting a culture where people genuinely have equal worth. A New Labour second term needs to translate our goal of ambition into realistic policies capable of practical implementation. It means investing in those things that liberate individual potential. Education is the obvious starting-point. Under the Conservatives, spending on education fell dramatically as a proportion of national wealth. Labour has reversed that trend. Primary school results have improved dramatically, secondary school results more slowly. In the second term, radical change must continue, not just through investment in schools, though this is essential. There must be greater flexibility not just in employing teachers and staff, but in varying the curriculum and providing an alternative vocational route for 14- to 18-year-olds that is held in equal regard to the A-level system. Raising the quality of new entrants to teaching is also crucial. Another area in which to liberate potential is the creation of an active welfare state. 'Work for those who can, security for those who cannot' is central to reviving personal ambition. Welfare is not about a safety-net or a hand-out, but about helping people to help themselves and widening participation in employment. But the definition of work needs to be broader, encompassing non-paid employment in caring and volunteering. This could mean a new agency combining work and benefits, but this must be based on developing the concept of employability, not returning to the old agenda of 'work to welfare' or pretending that the Government can 'create jobs'. The DFEE has now established an enviable reputation in business and commerce for pioneering both employability and welfare to work. On pensions, shared responsibility through the new stakeholder schemes, and helping individuals to build up financial resources, of which the 'baby bond' scheme is an excellent starting point, are important building blocks. But we need to do more. It involves investment to transform adult skills, especially in IT. It means enabling more people to start up their own businesses with venture capital and enterprise grants. Widening personal ambition does not mean cutting back the welfare state. It involves greater state support, more intelligently targeted, 'tailormade' solutions and active prevention rather than passive intervention when welfare problems have already grown. Finally, New Labour must promote social entrepreneurship. The deeply complex problems of urban and neighbourhood disintegration pose problems of a fundamental kind. We need to give people the tools and resources to find solutions to their own problems within local communities. We must address not just the poverty of individual expectations from families trapped on benefits, but the poverty of hope that comes from demoralised communities. The Government's radical tax-benefit reforms are set to conquer child poverty for a generation. The task for the second term is to transform the fabric and social condition of Britain's neighbourhoods so that young people have a decent and supportive local environment in which to grow up. We have strong programmes to build on, including the New Deal for Communities and the excellent ideas provided by the Social Exclusion Unit. We must revive the culture of civic leadership in Britain. There is a risk of having too many disconnected central government initiatives and we need to channel money to local projects. The spirit of ambition must radiate from our country and create greater respect for Britain in the world. Britain can give a lead in two urgent tasks: resolving the conflict over the Kyoto accord on environmental sustainability, and offering ideas for a multilateral framework for arms control. An ambitious society does not retreat into narrow isolationism. Ambition is a far-reaching concept and a distinctive goal for social democrats. Our task is to define it in the centre-Left's terms. Anthony Crosland, the leading Labour theorist of postwar social democracy, famously argued in The Future of Socialism : 'We do not want to enter the age of abundance only to find that we have lost the values that might teach us how to enjoy it.' The creation of a truly ambitious society is a worthy goal for a second-term New Labour government. The coming election campaign gives us the chance to make the case for social democratic ambition with clarity and conviction.

webTitle: Leader: back this boycott

fields.headline: Back this boycott
fields.standfirst: The campaign against Exxon goes on
fields.trailText: Politics is just one repository of power in the modern world. In a global economy, multinational companies exert an influence - responsible or not - which was unthinkable a century ago.
fields.body:
Politics is just one repository of power in the modern world. In a global economy, multinational companies exert an influence - responsible or not - which was unthinkable a century ago. And just as electors may enhance their sense of disenfranchisement if they fail to vote, so consumers all too often fuel their own frustration by ignoring the power they can exert too.

Two weeks ago, we reported international fury at the support from oil company Exxon for President Bush's abandonment of America's commitment to the Kyoto protocols. We commended a boycott of petrol stations owned by Esso, Exxon's UK arm, as an appropriate response for those who shared that anger. Now that boycott is to become a national campaign, backed by the 500,000 members of Greenpeace and Friends of the Earth. It could well succeed. It was a student campaign which caused Barclays Bank to effect a humiliating retreat from South Africa 15 years ago. More recently, it was pressure from Sheila McKechnie, inspiring director of the Consumers Association, which led to substantial reductions in British car prices.

Too often, we lament the tiny influence that individual purchasers can exert on big businesses. We forget that once-acclaimed virtue of collective action. None has been more assiduous in deriding it as archaic than the commercial interests which used to be the victims of its potency. But collective action is not just a virtue in the political arena or the workplace. It has a critical place in the post-industrial world too, as Exxon may be about to discover. Consumers of the world unite. Unity is strength.

webTitle: And pigs will fly

fields.headline: And pigs will fly
fields.standfirst: In future, politics will be about policies, not spin. So Alastair told me
fields.trailText: May 6, Arnold Kemp: In future, politics will be about policies, not spin. So Alastair told me.
fields.body:
Politics and parody are converging; life imitates art and Rory Bremner. Phoenix the Calf is spared the bolt and Porky the Pig is enshrined as an untouchable Empress of Blandings.

Spin gone mad? Apparently not. Rural affairs Minister Ross Finnie told me last week that it was all purely coincidental. Cull regulations had been changed just in time to save the lives of the calf and the pig. And I see no reason to disbelieve him when he said he had an iron will to make no exceptions: on Friday, the men from the ministry put to death five pet sheep in Whithorn after a high-profile fight by their owner to save them.

But the Government cannot have been surprised by the media's reaction, which was to assume that the black arts of spin had been once more deployed. The spinner wronged is in the position of the boy who cried wolf. During the first Blair administration, we have seen spin taken to new levels of sophistication, though there is comfort to be found in the fact that it frequently goes awry. Perhaps that is why an apparently chastened Alastair Campbell, the Prime Minister's press secretary, made an appeal for more serious political coverage when he addressed the Newspaper Press Fund lunch in Glasgow on Friday.

He belied the adjectives usually hung on him by commentators. He was not at all abrasive. He was charming, amusing and thoughtful, played the pipes and offered some interesting reflections about what we call news and the insatiable voracity of the media for titbits.

Northcliffe's dictum, that news is something that somebody somewhere doesn't want published and all the rest is advertising, still largely holds good. But it needs to be qualified. The commoditisation of information has grown apace and agents like Max Clifford are news brokers. It is now possible for people to be famous for being famous. And the press itself is sometimes the story - the Sun 's mission to bring Ronnie Biggs back to Britain proving that the dottier kinds of chequebook journalism are not dead.

And, as Campbell noted, there is a tendency for the media to be more interested in what is about to happen than in recording the events themselves. A million words have been written about the impending Hollywood strike but how many will be expended on the drearier details of the settlement? This is one way in which the press, no longer the purveyor of primary news, can elude the challenge of television and radio.

Campbell himself has exploited this appetite for futurism often enough. The Government's information machine habitually feeds out bonbons of what is to come to favoured papers.

In his guise of repentant sinner, Campbell said that if the Government won a second term, it was his 'hope and expectation' that spin would become 'less important still' and said readers had a greater interest in policies and issues than generally believed by editors.

It is a view I share but from which many newspapers appear to be in retreat. As Campbell noted, the broadsheets and the tabloids have converged. For this loss of seriousness, marketing departments have to take some of the blame. Over the years, they have pressed for the 'feminisation' of news agendas in the quite mistaken, and indeed, insulting belief that women, who, in my experience, are among the most assiduous of readers of news pages, are only interested in such matters as garden furniture, interior decoration, personal health or the emotional lives of celebrities, though all these topics, with the possible exception of garden furniture, are worthy of a place on the agenda.

But there is, perhaps, a greater challenge for political journalists. It is genuinely difficult for them to dramatise politics in anything other than terms of confrontation. Westminster is based on that principle and the baying rituals of Prime Minister's Question Time are its highest, or lowest, expression.

Ross Finnie believes that one of the reasons the Scottish Parliament got a bad early press is that journalists were unable to break old habits. The idea of two parties in a coalition confused them and so they sought stories in the form with which they were most familiar, even if the consequences were sometimes trivial to the point of absurdity.

If politicians were to change their habits, if our politics were to become consensual and undogmatic, how would our press respond? I suspect that we are now beyond redemption, hopelessly hooked on our diet of Sturm und Drang , and that the Alastair Campbells of this world, no matter how charmingly they speak of their good intentions, could as easily give up spin as Lord Emsworth could have sent his beloved empress to the slaughterhouse.

webTitle: A tricky time for borrowers

fields.headline: A tricky time for borrowers
fields.standfirst: In a time of low inflation savers are the real winners. It's borrowers who should be aware. By Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: In a time of low inflation savers are the real winners. It's borrowers who should be aware. By Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
Savings accounts

Headline rates will be lower when inflation is low. In real terms, however, savers are likely to be better off. In the late Seventies National Savings paid 15 per cent but, since inflation was higher than this (18 per cent in 1980), savers were actually getting a negative return. Nowadays, with inflation at 2.3 per cent, savers in accounts paying 5 per cent are getting 2.7 per cent in real terms.

Equities

Returns on equities are likely to fall in the long-term even if, in the short term, the prices jump when the Bank of England base rate is cut. The authors of the Financial Services Authority's paper on low inflation say: 'Over the longer term, it will be associated with lower nominal investment returns. Lenders and investors do not have to be compensated so much for the erosion in the real terms of the principal [as they would in a period of high inflation].'

The fact that the FSA's growth estimates, which pensions firms must use in their sales material, are now 5, 7 and 9 per cent for the coming years indicates the regulator's view on likely investment returns. At the beginning of the Nineties, when inflation was often three or four times the current level, the equivalent figures were 8.5, 10.75 and 13 per cent.

Actuary Ronnie Sloan accepts the likelihood of lower returns on equities.But he says: 'In real terms, it would still seem reasonable to expect returns of between 4 and 5 per cent. When inflation was 7 per cent, people were often getting 13 per cent. But if inflation is 2.5 per cent, you're only going to get 7 per cent.'

Guaranteed annuities

Annuities guaranteeing to pay above the prevailing rates can become extremely valuable, as the crisis-ridden Equitable Life knows to its cost. The insurer agreed to pay above 12 per cent. This did not appear high at the time of the guarantee but is now getting on for double the going rate. Other insurers entered into these contracts but seem better able to pay their debts than Equitable.

Pensions

High inflation has always been the enemy of pensioners and anyone else living on a fixed income. The Pensions Law Handbook 2001, published by the law practice Eversheds, says: 'The basic state pension is falling in relative terms year by year, since it is indexed to prices rather than earnings, and will eventually be worth less than 5 per cent of national average earnings.

'This problem is exacerbated by the fact that people in personal pensions and in occupational money purchase schemes have to buy an annuity. Most have opted for a level annuity, which means they are getting the same monthly payment after 30 years as they did in month one.

'But there has been widespread recognition of this problem and various factors are conspiring to help. A period of low inflation will mean that the value of pensions will erode more slowly. But if they can afford it, pensioners can delay buying an annuity until their seventy-fifth birthday. Meanwhile, they can put their pension fund into an income drawdown plan, drawing some income while leaving most of the fund to continue growing.'

However, most professionals suggest this is potentially risky, and that drawdown plans should be taken out only by people with a fund of £250,000 or more who can withstand some risk. Research by Money Management magazine shows that some of these plans, which are still fairly new, have underperformed their annuity equivalents by nearly 25 per cent.

A huge concern for new pensioners is the way that annuity rates have tumbled as a reaction to falling inflation and lower interest rates. A £100,000 fund would have bought annual annuity income of £11,000 in 1990 for a 65-year old married man; a decade later, the annual income would have been just £6,000. Although there is a slight recovery in annuity rates now, the general trend in interest rates throughout the European Union is down.

Money Management magazine warns : 'Ironically, this could, in turn, mean that by delaying annuity purchase, income drawdown may actually reduce pension entitlements and develop into another sorry scandal.'

Bonds

Getting into a good fixed interest deal is ideal if you can do it just before interest rates fall. Many people benefited from this in the past but often more by luck than judgment since rates are hard to predict.

If your calculation is wrong, and you buy a gilt (a Government stock such as a Trea sury bond), you will see its capital value fall if interest rates rise. Its final redemption value will not change, but its value on the market if you decide to sell before redemption will decline. This is because other assets will be able to offer comparable or better returns. Many insurance company products are bonds.

Rates on guaranteed income bonds (GIBs) have gradually fallen to the extent they are no longer an attractive proposition, according to financial adviser Baronworth. In April, however, rates improved and some of them are now competitive.

With-profits bonds allow investors to take 5 per cent of their original investment each year and defer the tax for up to 20 years. But if investment returns are low, the investors may be eating into the capital when they take out their annual 5 per cent. The Financial Services Authority is extremely concerned about these products and warns that the past performance rates, which companies use to sell their products, are very high compared to current projection rates and may well not be sustainable in future.

Salaries

Pay rises are closely linked to inflation. Wage settlements have averaged 3.3 per cent a year so far during 2001, according to Incomes Data Services, but they could drop to 3 per cent or even below that if the inflation rate dips below 2 per cent, as seems possible.

Mortgages and debt

Don't be fooled into thinking that low inflation is good for borrowers. Certainly, you are borrowing at low rates but you do not see your debts become smaller each year compared to your earnings as you do during high inflation. High inflation will, in effect, pay off most of your debt, leaving you just to worry about meeting the interest payments.

In times of very low inflation, where asset prices fall, homeowners will be left with loans that are higher than the value of the asset they used the loan to buy. The consensus from economists is to repay your debt as quickly as possible. Howard Davies, chairman of the FSA, expressed his concern last December about the continuing rise in loans at high income multiples: above three times income for a single person or 2.5 times income for joint borrowers.

House prices

House prices could be underpinned by low inflation if more young people want to buy. In theory, they would be attracted to bricks and mortar since the burden of debt is pushed away from the monthly interest payments, which are low, to the time of mortgage redemption, which could be 25 years away for those choosing an interest-only loan.

Of course, problematic low inflation which turns into problematic deflation can lead to negative equity, but this possibility is not being suggested as likely now.

webTitle: Lost my job, but what a great house

fields.headline: Lost my job, but what a great house
fields.standfirst: Economic downturn is starting to bite, but not for estate agents.  Tracey Boles on a brisk start to the buying season
fields.trailText: Economic downturn is starting to bite, but not for estate agents. Tracey Boles on a brisk start to the buying season.
fields.body:
House prices appear to be shrugging off worries about job losses and a faltering economy, at least for the moment.

The start of this year's spring buying season coincided with the stock market crash and a string of job cuts across the country. But a clutch of statistics out last week show that buyers have not been frightened away.

Prices are not rising at levels of this time last year but the Nationwide building society says the market is 'healthy and stable' .

Prices across the country rose by 0.8 per cent in April, according to Nationwide's index. This was down from 1.4 per cent in March and contrasts with a 1.7 per cent increase recorded by rival Halifax during April.

But mortgage industry sources believe that the Nationwide's index may have been skewed by a fall-off in mortgage deals resulting from changes to the building society's mortgage range.

Mortgage brokers claim that borrowers are shying away because Nationwide no longer offers deeply discounted products, even though its rate for existing borrowers is lower.

Nationwide says the aver age price tag on a house this month is £86,244 -in contrast to £1,500 50 years ago. House prices were still 10 per cent short of the level reached at the height of the late-Eighties boom. But the society says recent reductions in mortgage rates should fuel further growth.

'Despite an expected weakening in the economy the market remains on course to achieve our forecast of a 7 per cent rise in house prices this year.'

Further cuts in interest rates could push house prices up even higher, although the impact of lower borrowing costs could be softened by the slowing economy.

Rival Halifax is more bullish, saying that consumer confidence will hold up for the rest of the year, again due to the lower interest rates.

New home loan figures also hit a record high recently, further defying analysts who foresaw a downturn in the housing market as the global economy faltered.

The British Bankers' Association says new mortgage lending grew 28 per cent during March to £7.65 billion, the highest level since 1997 and well beyond any seasonal upturn as homebuyers rushed to take advantage of the competitive deals on the market.

The BBA says the figures suggest we are either in, or about to enter, a housing boom. It says consumer confidence is high as a result of falling interest rates, the prospect of possible further rate cuts to come, and the price war between major mortgage lenders. The strong upswing in the mortgage market could last for several months, according to the BBA, particularly as the latest figures do not take into account April's base rate reduction, which will have further improved affordability.

But the big lenders are more cautious, believing falling employment levels in the coming months could dent homebuyers' confidence. Any softening in the housing market is likely to hit London first because prices in the capital have doubled in the past five years.

The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (Rics) is also more cautious than the BBA. It is expecting 'more of the same' from the housing market and acknowledges that while the house market has come under many positive influences they are set against a backdrop of uncertainty. A spokesman says: 'The circumstances are right for a rise: good affordability, a shortage of supply and plenty of demand. But there are lot of uncertainties around with the election, the American slowdown and foot and mouth.

'They may prompt some people to put their houses up for sale and some people to hold off. The end result is stability.'

It is not just well-off Londoners and those in the South-east driving the market. Regional home-buying has fed into it too, with borrowers in the north of England and East Anglia experiencing double-figure house-price inflation, according to the Rics.

Property experts say sellers within the boundaries of the Lake District National Park could 'ask for what price they want'. Other hotspots identified by Rics include Yorkshire and Hum berside. So if it is a good time to buy which areas should you choose?

Mortgage rates are at their lowest levels since the sixties and there are many cheap fixed-rate deals on offer. David Hollingworth of broker London and Country says: 'It is so affordable at the moment. Rates are so low and they may not be that way forever.'

Rics says to do your research and find out why house price have suddenly gone up in a particular area before you go there - the rises may or may not be sustained. 'It may be due to local issues such as a factory gaining a reprieve or a new one opening. Talk to chartered surveyors to find out.'

A website that tracks prices, www.hometrack.co.uk, can keep you up to date on which areas are most sought after, although its index is not a hard and fast guide to future performance.

fields.headline: Killing the king of cocaine
fields.standfirst: For 20 years, the world's richest and most ruthless drug baron was considered untouchable. At least until the authorities discovered his one fatal weakness - his love for his son. Here, in the final extract from his book, Mark Bowden describes how another father and son team, this time on the right side of the law, finally closed the net on Pablo Escobar
