Here, in the final extract from his book, Mark Bowden describes how another father and son team, this time on the right side of the law, finally closed the net on Pablo Escobar.
fields.body:
The First War 1989-1991
In time, no one in Colombia knew Pablo Escobar better than Colonel Hugo Martinez of La Policía Nacional de Colombia (PNC), even though the two men had never met. The tall, tac iturn man who was nicknamed Flaco (Skinny) knew Pablo better than even the drug boss's closest family members and henchmen, because there were things he would say and do before his associates that he would not before his family, and there was a side of him that his family saw that he showed to no one else. The colonel saw it all. He knew Pablo intimately. He recognised his voice, knew his habits, when he slept, when and how he moved, what he liked to eat, what his favourite music was. The colonel knew what kind of shoes Pablo wore (white Nikes), what kind of sheets he liked on his bed, the preferred age of his sexual partners (girls of 14 or 15, usually), his taste in art, his handwriting, the pet name he had for his wife (Tata), even what kind of toilet he preferred to use - since he had new facilities installed in all of his hideouts, and they were always the same.

In the world's most dangerous country, the job of going after Pablo was the most dangerous position of all - and it belonged to Colonel Martinez. With the new bonanza of American assistance, Colombia's President Barco had created special police units, one of which was based in Medellín and was dedicated to hunting down the drug lords José Rodríguez Gacha, the Ochoa brothers and Pablo Escobar. It was called the Bloque de Búsqueda, or Search Bloc. This was the command given to Colonel Martinez. Nobody wanted it. It was considered so dangerous that the PNC decided the command would be rotated monthly.

Pablo practically owned Medellín, his home city, including enough of its police force that one of the rules for this newly constituted Search Bloc was that it could not contain even one native of the region, for fear he would secretly be on Pablo's payroll. Instead, the national police had assembled a collection of men from different units.None of them was familiar with one another or with the city, and they had no local sources or informants.

Within the first 15 days, 30 of the colonel's 200 men were killed. Despite elaborate precautions to protect the men and hide their identities, Pablo's army of henchmen picked them off one by one, often with the help of the Medellín police. They shot them down on the street, on their way home from work, even at home with their families when they were off duty. The funerals for these slain officers left the PNC reeling. At police headquarters in Bogotá, the top command considered pulling the plug on the Search Bloc. The colonel and his top commanders asked that they be allowed to stay. While the killings grieved and frightened them, it also angered them and hardened their resolve. It was to be seriously tested.

During a weekend trip home to see his family, the colonel was surprised when a retired police officer, someone he had known since his days in the academy, arrived at his door.

'I come to talk to you obligated,' the retired officer said with a pained expression. Martinez asked what he meant. 'If I did not agree to come talk to you, they could easily kill me or my family,' he said. Then he offered the colonel a $6m bribe from Pablo Escobar to call off the hunt. Better yet, the officer explained, 'Continue the work, but do not do yourself or Pablo Escobar any real damage.' Pablo also wanted a list of any snitches inside his own organisation.

Sometimes the fate of an entire nation can hinge on the integrity of one man. The bribe came at the lowest point in the colonel's career. He had been given a suicide mission, one with little chance of success. He attended funerals almost every day. The national police had con structed special funeral chapels in Medellín and in Bogotá just to handle the demand.

And for what? Martinez could not even see the wisdom in going after Escobar. Cocaine was not Colombia's problem; it was the norteamericanos ' problem. And even if they did away with El Doctor, as the US insisted, it was not going to curb the cocaine industry.

Here was a generous ticket out. Six million dollars. Enough money to support himself and his family in luxury for the rest of their lives. But the colonel's gut rebelled against it. He cursed at his former friend, and then his anger turned to pity and disgust.

'Tell Pablo that you came but did not find me here, and then leave this matter as if it had never occurred,' he said.

Martinez had known other police officers who took bribes, and he knew that money was just the hook on El Doctor's line. Once he had accepted the bribe, Pablo would own him, just as he owned his friend who had approached him with the offer. After he dismissed his old friend, Martinez drove to police headquarters and informed his commander General Octavio Vargas of the bribe. They agreed it was a good sign.

'It means we're getting to him,' said Martinez. They were - in part because they had a new kind of help...

The Americans are coming

Various American agencies had been working out of the embassy in Bogotá for years, relying on more conventional ways of gathering intelligence. The CIA had its own long-standing connections, but they had always been oriented more toward the Marxist insurrections in the hills. The counternarcotics stuff had only recently been redefined as a CIA mission, and there were plenty of chiefs back at headquarters who were not sold on the idea. But the agents in Colombia were fully engaged. With deep pockets and a reputation for secrecy, the spy agency was already playing on murderous rivalries between the Cali and Medellín cartels.

There was another unit, a secret unit headed in Bogota by an army major who, at least according to his current identity papers, was named Steve Jacoby. Members of the unit were new kinds of species, surveillance experts selected and trained by the army to provide 'operational' intelligence, things like: how many doors and windows does the target building have? Where did their target like to eat dinner? The unit was called Centra Spike. Its speciality was finding people. Eavesdropping on radio and telephone conversations from the air, they were capable of pinpointing the origin of a radio or cell-phone call with amazing accuracy within seconds.

Pablo in 'prison' - though not for long

By the end of 1990, Pablo's life was also a nightmare. Colonel Martinez had come close to catching him several times and had chipped away at the people around him. The deaths of his cousins and brother-in-law, the surrenders of the Ochoas... his organisation was falling apart. The man who just a year earlier had dozens of luxurious estates to chose from was now sleeping some nights in the woods in the mountains, running to stay ahead of his determined pursuers. He dared not speak by radio or telephone, so he sent messages by courier. He had neither the time nor the means of controlling his cocaine business, so every month that he spent on the run he lost money and standing. By the end of the year, he saw only one sure way out of his predicament. He would escape - into the arms of the Colombian government.

Pablo would turn himself in, after negotiations between his lawyers and the government. Pablo insisted on being seen not as a criminal but as a revolutionary. He was not seeking a role in the government, but in return for putting down his arms he expected significant concessions. It was simple power versus power, his guns, bombs and sicarios (henchmen) against the state's. By now the issue was only incidentally connected to drug trafficking. Pablo was playing a dangerous game, because if the colonel and Centra Spike succeeded in finding him first, he would most likely be killed or, if not, extradited immediately. He had been indicted in three states in the United States. The alternative being worked out by his lawyers may have been the most generous plea bargain of all time. He would have his own special 'prison', which would be built in his home-town of Envigado on a hill called La Catedral, on land that he owned. He would pay to have it built. The guards in the prison would work not for the Bureau of Prisons but for the government of Envigado, which Pablo effectively controlled. The only inmates would be his closest associates and henchmen.

It was not a normal prison in other ways. Pablo, for instance, did not feel obliged to actually stay. He rarely missed an important pro soccer game in Medellín - police would block off traffic to allow Pablo's motorcade easy access to and from the stadium he had built years before - and he was sighted shopping in a fashionable Bogotá mall over the Christmas holidays. In June 1992 he celebrated the first anniversary of his imprisonment with his friends and family at an Envigado nightclub. Pablo considered such excursions minor... he did, after all, always come back. He had made his deal with the state and intended to honour it - even if he did put one over on his jailors now and then.

To pass time, the inmates lifted weights, rode exercise bikes and played soccer. Pablo would play for hours at a time. He always played centre forward, even though he wasn't the quickest or most skilled player and he had a bad knee. His men always let him win, sometimes arranging for him to kick the winning goal. If Pablo grew winded, which was often, he would wave in a replacement until he caught his breath, and then he'd plunge back in. Prison guards served drinks to the inmates on the sidelines and doubled as waiters in the bar afterward.

Throughout the first year of Pablo's imprisonment, the US embassy, the press and many government officials - including Mendoza - had urged the president to end the charade. Everyone knew La Catedral was no prison. Effectively, it was a state within the state. The surrender agreement had been a capitulation to violence, pure and simple, a deal with the devil. Still, most of official Colombia was happy to live with it. Pablo was like a dangerous snake that had been driven into a hole. The prevailing attitude was: before, Pablo Escobar ruled Colombia; now he rules Envigado, so leave him alone.

However, after much indecision, the president decided he had to act. He first sent justice minister Eduardo Mendoza to negotiate with Escobar, followed by a special armed unit when Escobar decided he would amuse himself by holding Mendoza hostage. By this stage, because of radio and TV reports, Escobar and the rest of the country knew that armed forces were massing around his prison. Any hope for surprise was gone. Even so, after the special forces attacked, chaos ensued... and Pablo escaped. In fact, it turned out that he had walked out. He and his brother Roberto had led a small group of his men uphill, past the camouflaged cabanas, cut a hole in the wire fence and walked over the top of the hill - and right past soldiers either too friendly or too intimidated to stop them. The 'tunnel' spoken of in the intercepted phone conversations was, of course, the inmates' sarcastic term for the covered truck that had been used to roll contraband - women, weapons, money, alcohol - up and down the mountain, right under the disinterested noses of prison guards. The war against the government quickly resumed.

The revenge of Los Pepes

By the end of 1992, 12 major players in Pablo's organisation had been killed in 'gun battles' with the Search Bloc. There was always a steep price to pay for these victories. Through the first six months of the hunt, more than 65 police officers had been killed in Medellín, many of them Search Bloc members whose identities were supposed to be a state secret. Often these men were killed in their homes or travelling to and from the academy, which demonstrated that Pablo knew not only their identities but also their work shifts and home addresses. Pablo was offering a $2,000 bounty for killing Medellín policemen, and it was working.

What the authorities needed was some extralegal muscle, some hands-on players who didn't mind crossing the lines of legality and morality that Pablo so blithely ignored. The drug boss certainly didn't lack for bitter enemies, but they had no commonality. They ranged from some of the wealthiest and most powerful families in Bogotá to rival street thugs in Medellín and Cali, a 'civilian militia'. Acquiring the name Los Pepes, they initiated a controlled bloodbath, controlled because all of the victims had one thing in common - Pablo Escobar. As the murders and fearful surrenders mounted, Los Pepes publicly offered cash rewards for information on Pablo and his key associates, and began broadcasting threats against the drug lord's family.

What if someone were to give them a push, some organisation, some money, some intelligence, some training, planning,and leadership? Los Pepes were so perfect they were... well, too perfect. Officially the American Embassy was silent on the appearance of Los Pepes, but those at work in the fight against Escobar - including Centra Spike - were not displeased. And why should they have been? What could be better than a homegrown vigilante movement against Public Enemy Number One? Why not spread a little fear on Pablo's side for once? As the lawlessness accelerated, no one from Washington questioned it, or questioned America's commitment to the pursuit. Civilian overseers from the Clinton administration were new in office, and knew next to nothing about what the US military was doing in Colombia. People were always getting killed by one faction or another...

Closing in for the kill

Young Hugo Martinez looked nothing like his father. He was short, stocky and dark where his father was tall, fair and slender. He shared his father's keen intellect, but was also a visionary, an infectious leader, the kind of man who could convince other people to follow him even when only he understood where they were going. When he got talking about technical matters that often only he understood, Hugo flushed with pleasure. He would grab sheets of paper and a pencil and begin making scratchy diagrams of his ideas. After studying at the National Police Academy in Bogota, he was placed with an electronic-surveillance unit that had been given a new portable direction-finder by the CIA.

In the first three or four months after Pablo's escape, Colonel Martinez banned all cell-phone use in Medellín and closed down all repeater stations for transmitting signals, which forced people to use standard phone lines and limited radio communications to point-to-point - that is, the radio operators could not use repeaters to amplify and relay signals over long distances, so the only effective way to communicate between two radios was for there to be a clear line of sight between the transmitter and receiver. The idea was to isolate Pablo. He was too smart to use normal phone lines, but if he tried to communicate through the uncluttered airwaves he would be much easier to find. Pablo responded by using messengers. He resumed regular radio communication only in the spring of 1993, as he grew increasingly concerned about Los Pepes and began scheming to get his family out of the country. Pablo found places where he could see the top of the apartment building Altos del Campestre, where his family was living under heavy guard, and he spoke most often to his son Juan Pablo. The chase had boiled down to a contest between two men and their sons. Pablo's son was his weakness. The colonel's son might yet prove to be his strength.

On 26 November, the US embassy learned that Pablo's wife and children were planning once more to flee Colombia. They were going to fly to either London or Frankfurt. The family had become increasingly desperate. They had been under around-the-clock protection by agents from attorney general de Grieff's office ever since the failed effort to fly Juan Pablo and Manuela to Miami in March. In the intervening months, Los Pepes had killed members of their extended family and burned most of the family's properties. The vigilante group seemed to be toying with the Escobars, picking off cousins, in-laws and friends, including some who had been living in Altos del Campestre, demonstrating that they could hurt Pablo's wife Maria Victoria or Juan Pablo. The rocket-propelled grenade that had been fired at the building in October was more like a warning than an actual attempt on their lives. It felt like the threat was closing in. The Colombian government was officially protecting Pablo's family, but they were also effectively holding them in place. So long as Pablo was worried about them, his voice would keep popping up on the radio.

The final shootout

On 2 December 1993, Pablo awoke shortly before noon, as was his habit, and ate a plate of spaghetti before easing his widening bulk back into bed with his wireless phone. Always a heavy man, he had put on about 20lb living on the run, most of it in his belly. 'On the run' didn't accurately describe it. He spent most of his time lying low, eating, sleeping, talking on the radio. He hired prostitutes, mostly teenage girls, to help him while away the hours. He had trouble finding jeans that would fit him. To get a waist size to accommodate his girth he had to wear pants that were a good 6in too long in the leg.

The light-blue pair he wore on this day were turned up twice in a wide cuff. He wore flip-flops and had pulled on a loose blue polo shirt. Prone to stomach disorders, he might have been feeling the effects of his birthday revelry the night before. On this afternoon, the only other person in the house was his bodyguard Alvero de Jesus Agudelo, known as Limón. The two others staying with them, his courier Jaime Rua and his aunt and cook Luz Mila, had gone out after fixing breakfast. At one o'clock, Pablo tried to phone his family, posing as a radio journalist, but the switchboard operator at the Tequendama, per his instructions from Colonel Martinez, told him they had been instructed to block all calls from journalists. He was put on hold, then asked to call back, but finally he got through on the third attempt, speaking briefly to Manuela and then to Maria Victoria and his son.

Hugo and his unit had been closing in on Escobar, monitoring his calls. Hugo had driven out of the parking lot in pursuit as soon as his friend on the switchboard at the Hotel Tequendama had alerted him that Pablo was on the line.

The signal pointed Hugo straight ahead. The line on the screen lengthened and the tone in his earphones grew stronger as they proceeded up the street. They drove until the signal peaked and then began to diminish, the line pinching in at the edges of the screen and the tone slightly falling off. So they turned around and crept back the other way more slowly. The line stretched gradually until it once again filled the screen. They were in front of a block of two-storey houses. There was no telling which was the one that housed Pablo. They cruised up and down the street several more times. Hugo stopped staring at his screen and instead stared intently at the houses, one by one.

Until he saw him.

A fat man in the second-floor window. He had long, curly black hair and a full beard. The image hit Hugo like an electric shock. He had only seen Pablo in pictures, and he had always been clean shaven except for the mustache, but they knew Pablo had grown a beard, and there was something about the man in the window that just clicked. He was talking on a cell phone and peering down at traffic. The man stepped back from the window. Hugo thought he had seen a look of surprise. The face of Pablo Escobar assembled slowly in Hugo's brain. For a split second he was confused, disbelieving. Him! He had found him! Years of effort, hundreds of lives, thousands of futile police raids, untold millions of dollars, countless false leads and man-hours, all of the false steps, false alarms, blunders... and here he was at last, one man in a nation of 35m people, one man in a rich, ruthless, and regimented underworld he had virtually owned for nearly two decades, one man in a city of millions where he was revered as a legend.

Hugo leaned out of his van and called to the car behind him, 'This is the house!' It was in the middle of the block. Hugo suspected Pablo had been spooked by their white van cruising slowly down the street, so he had told his driver to keep on going down to the end. Shouting into the radio, Hugo asked to be connected to his father. 'I've got him located,' Hugo told him. The colonel knew this was it. Those were words he had never heard before. He knew Hugo would not be saying it unless he had seen Pablo with his own eyes.

'He's in this house,' said Hugo. He explained excitedly that only he and one other car were there. He thought Pablo had seen him and that his gunmen were probably on their way. He wanted to clear out, fast. 'Stay exactly where you are!' Colonel Martinez ordered his son, shouting into the radio. 'Station yourself in front and in back of the house and don't let him come out.' Then the colonel got word to all his units in the area, including those still thrashing through the office building blocks away, and told them to converge on the house immediately. Hugo's two men got out of the car and positioned themselves against the wall on either side of Pablo's front door. Hugo drove the van around the block to the alley, counting the houses until he could see the back end of Pablo's. Terrified, with weapons ready, they waited. It took 10 minutes.

There was a heavy metal front door. Martin, one of the lieutenants assigned to the Search Bloc assault team, stood ready as his men applied a heavy steel sledgehammer to it. Martin had not worn his bullet-proof vest today, and he had a moment of anxious regret, just as the hammer crashed into the door. It took several blows before it went down.

Martin sprinted into the house with the five men on his team, and the shooting started. In the din and confusion, he quickly sized up the first floor. It was empty, like a garage. There was a yellow taxi parked toward the rear, and a flight of stairs leading up to the second floor. One of Martin's men stumbled on his way up the stairs, and everyone stopped momentarily. They thought the man had been hit.

Limón leaped out a back window to the orange tile roof as soon as the team burst through the front door. The way the house was constructed, there was a back roof surrounded by walls on three sides that could be reached by dropping about 10ft from a second-storey window. Limón hit the tiles and began running, and as he did the Search Bloc members arrayed in the street behind the house opened fire. There were dozens of men up and down the block with automatic weapons, some of them standing on the tops of their cars. Limón was hit several times as he ran. His momentum carried him right off the roof. He fell to the grass below. Then came Pablo. He stopped to kick off his flip-flops, then jumped down to the roof. Having seen what had happened to Limón, he stayed close to one wall, where there was some protection. The shooter on the roof overhead could not get a clear shot directly down at him, so there was a break in the firing momentarily as Pablo quickly moved along the wall toward the back street. No one on the street had a clear shot at him yet. At the corner, Pablo made his break.

He went for the crest of the gently sloping roof, trying to make it to the other side. There was a thundering cascade of fire and Pablo fell near the crest. He sprawled forward, dislodging orange tiles. The shooting continued. Martin's team inside the house had found the second floor empty. When he stuck his head in the open window to look out on the roof, he saw a body and then heard an eruption of more gunfire. He and his men fell prone on the floor and waited as rounds from the street below crashed through the window and into the walls and ceiling of the room. Martin believed he and his men were taking fire from Pablo's bodyguards. He shouted into his radio, 'Help! Help us! We need support!'

Everyone was shooting on automatic from below. Rounds chewed up the brick walls around the enclosed rooftop. It felt as if it took minutes for the shooting to die down, for the Search Bloc to realise they were the only ones shooting. Finally, it stopped. The shooter on the second-floor roof shouted, 'It's Pablo! It's Pablo!'

Men were now scaling the roof to see. Someone found a ladder and placed it under the second-floor window, and others climbed down from it. Major Aguilar grabbed the body and turned it over. The wide bearded face was swollen, bloody, and wreathed in long, blood-soaked black curls. The major grabbed a radio and spoke directly to Colonel Martinez, loudly enough for even the men on the street below to hear. ' Vivá Colombia ! We have just killed Pablo Escobar!'

Extracted from Killing Pablo - The Hunt for the Richest, Most Powerful Criminal in History by Mark Bowden (£16.99, Atlantic Books, published 21 May).
fields.bodyText: The First War 1989-1991 In time, no one in Colombia knew Pablo Escobar better than Colonel Hugo Martinez of La Policía Nacional de Colombia (PNC), even though the two men had never met. The tall, tac iturn man who was nicknamed Flaco (Skinny) knew Pablo better than even the drug boss's closest family members and henchmen, because there were things he would say and do before his associates that he would not before his family, and there was a side of him that his family saw that he showed to no one else. The colonel saw it all. He knew Pablo intimately. He recognised his voice, knew his habits, when he slept, when and how he moved, what he liked to eat, what his favourite music was. The colonel knew what kind of shoes Pablo wore (white Nikes), what kind of sheets he liked on his bed, the preferred age of his sexual partners (girls of 14 or 15, usually), his taste in art, his handwriting, the pet name he had for his wife (Tata), even what kind of toilet he preferred to use - since he had new facilities installed in all of his hideouts, and they were always the same. In the world's most dangerous country, the job of going after Pablo was the most dangerous position of all - and it belonged to Colonel Martinez. With the new bonanza of American assistance, Colombia's President Barco had created special police units, one of which was based in Medellín and was dedicated to hunting down the drug lords José Rodríguez Gacha, the Ochoa brothers and Pablo Escobar. It was called the Bloque de Búsqueda, or Search Bloc. This was the command given to Colonel Martinez. Nobody wanted it. It was considered so dangerous that the PNC decided the command would be rotated monthly. Pablo practically owned Medellín, his home city, including enough of its police force that one of the rules for this newly constituted Search Bloc was that it could not contain even one native of the region, for fear he would secretly be on Pablo's payroll. Instead, the national police had assembled a collection of men from different units.None of them was familiar with one another or with the city, and they had no local sources or informants. Within the first 15 days, 30 of the colonel's 200 men were killed. Despite elaborate precautions to protect the men and hide their identities, Pablo's army of henchmen picked them off one by one, often with the help of the Medellín police. They shot them down on the street, on their way home from work, even at home with their families when they were off duty. The funerals for these slain officers left the PNC reeling. At police headquarters in Bogotá, the top command considered pulling the plug on the Search Bloc. The colonel and his top commanders asked that they be allowed to stay. While the killings grieved and frightened them, it also angered them and hardened their resolve. It was to be seriously tested. During a weekend trip home to see his family, the colonel was surprised when a retired police officer, someone he had known since his days in the academy, arrived at his door. 'I come to talk to you obligated,' the retired officer said with a pained expression. Martinez asked what he meant. 'If I did not agree to come talk to you, they could easily kill me or my family,' he said. Then he offered the colonel a $6m bribe from Pablo Escobar to call off the hunt. Better yet, the officer explained, 'Continue the work, but do not do yourself or Pablo Escobar any real damage.' Pablo also wanted a list of any snitches inside his own organisation. Sometimes the fate of an entire nation can hinge on the integrity of one man. The bribe came at the lowest point in the colonel's career. He had been given a suicide mission, one with little chance of success. He attended funerals almost every day. The national police had con structed special funeral chapels in Medellín and in Bogotá just to handle the demand. And for what? Martinez could not even see the wisdom in going after Escobar. Cocaine was not Colombia's problem; it was the norteamericanos ' problem. And even if they did away with El Doctor, as the US insisted, it was not going to curb the cocaine industry. Here was a generous ticket out. Six million dollars. Enough money to support himself and his family in luxury for the rest of their lives. But the colonel's gut rebelled against it. He cursed at his former friend, and then his anger turned to pity and disgust. 'Tell Pablo that you came but did not find me here, and then leave this matter as if it had never occurred,' he said. Martinez had known other police officers who took bribes, and he knew that money was just the hook on El Doctor's line. Once he had accepted the bribe, Pablo would own him, just as he owned his friend who had approached him with the offer. After he dismissed his old friend, Martinez drove to police headquarters and informed his commander General Octavio Vargas of the bribe. They agreed it was a good sign. 'It means we're getting to him,' said Martinez. They were - in part because they had a new kind of help... The Americans are coming Various American agencies had been working out of the embassy in Bogotá for years, relying on more conventional ways of gathering intelligence. The CIA had its own long-standing connections, but they had always been oriented more toward the Marxist insurrections in the hills. The counternarcotics stuff had only recently been redefined as a CIA mission, and there were plenty of chiefs back at headquarters who were not sold on the idea. But the agents in Colombia were fully engaged. With deep pockets and a reputation for secrecy, the spy agency was already playing on murderous rivalries between the Cali and Medellín cartels. There was another unit, a secret unit headed in Bogota by an army major who, at least according to his current identity papers, was named Steve Jacoby. Members of the unit were new kinds of species, surveillance experts selected and trained by the army to provide 'operational' intelligence, things like: how many doors and windows does the target building have? Where did their target like to eat dinner? The unit was called Centra Spike. Its speciality was finding people. Eavesdropping on radio and telephone conversations from the air, they were capable of pinpointing the origin of a radio or cell-phone call with amazing accuracy within seconds. Pablo in 'prison' - though not for long By the end of 1990, Pablo's life was also a nightmare. Colonel Martinez had come close to catching him several times and had chipped away at the people around him. The deaths of his cousins and brother-in-law, the surrenders of the Ochoas... his organisation was falling apart. The man who just a year earlier had dozens of luxurious estates to chose from was now sleeping some nights in the woods in the mountains, running to stay ahead of his determined pursuers. He dared not speak by radio or telephone, so he sent messages by courier. He had neither the time nor the means of controlling his cocaine business, so every month that he spent on the run he lost money and standing. By the end of the year, he saw only one sure way out of his predicament. He would escape - into the arms of the Colombian government. Pablo would turn himself in, after negotiations between his lawyers and the government. Pablo insisted on being seen not as a criminal but as a revolutionary. He was not seeking a role in the government, but in return for putting down his arms he expected significant concessions. It was simple power versus power, his guns, bombs and sicarios (henchmen) against the state's. By now the issue was only incidentally connected to drug trafficking. Pablo was playing a dangerous game, because if the colonel and Centra Spike succeeded in finding him first, he would most likely be killed or, if not, extradited immediately. He had been indicted in three states in the United States. The alternative being worked out by his lawyers may have been the most generous plea bargain of all time. He would have his own special 'prison', which would be built in his home-town of Envigado on a hill called La Catedral, on land that he owned. He would pay to have it built. The guards in the prison would work not for the Bureau of Prisons but for the government of Envigado, which Pablo effectively controlled. The only inmates would be his closest associates and henchmen. It was not a normal prison in other ways. Pablo, for instance, did not feel obliged to actually stay. He rarely missed an important pro soccer game in Medellín - police would block off traffic to allow Pablo's motorcade easy access to and from the stadium he had built years before - and he was sighted shopping in a fashionable Bogotá mall over the Christmas holidays. In June 1992 he celebrated the first anniversary of his imprisonment with his friends and family at an Envigado nightclub. Pablo considered such excursions minor... he did, after all, always come back. He had made his deal with the state and intended to honour it - even if he did put one over on his jailors now and then. To pass time, the inmates lifted weights, rode exercise bikes and played soccer. Pablo would play for hours at a time. He always played centre forward, even though he wasn't the quickest or most skilled player and he had a bad knee. His men always let him win, sometimes arranging for him to kick the winning goal. If Pablo grew winded, which was often, he would wave in a replacement until he caught his breath, and then he'd plunge back in. Prison guards served drinks to the inmates on the sidelines and doubled as waiters in the bar afterward. Throughout the first year of Pablo's imprisonment, the US embassy, the press and many government officials - including Mendoza - had urged the president to end the charade. Everyone knew La Catedral was no prison. Effectively, it was a state within the state. The surrender agreement had been a capitulation to violence, pure and simple, a deal with the devil. Still, most of official Colombia was happy to live with it. Pablo was like a dangerous snake that had been driven into a hole. The prevailing attitude was: before, Pablo Escobar ruled Colombia; now he rules Envigado, so leave him alone. However, after much indecision, the president decided he had to act. He first sent justice minister Eduardo Mendoza to negotiate with Escobar, followed by a special armed unit when Escobar decided he would amuse himself by holding Mendoza hostage. By this stage, because of radio and TV reports, Escobar and the rest of the country knew that armed forces were massing around his prison. Any hope for surprise was gone. Even so, after the special forces attacked, chaos ensued... and Pablo escaped. In fact, it turned out that he had walked out. He and his brother Roberto had led a small group of his men uphill, past the camouflaged cabanas, cut a hole in the wire fence and walked over the top of the hill - and right past soldiers either too friendly or too intimidated to stop them. The 'tunnel' spoken of in the intercepted phone conversations was, of course, the inmates' sarcastic term for the covered truck that had been used to roll contraband - women, weapons, money, alcohol - up and down the mountain, right under the disinterested noses of prison guards. The war against the government quickly resumed. The revenge of Los Pepes By the end of 1992, 12 major players in Pablo's organisation had been killed in 'gun battles' with the Search Bloc. There was always a steep price to pay for these victories. Through the first six months of the hunt, more than 65 police officers had been killed in Medellín, many of them Search Bloc members whose identities were supposed to be a state secret. Often these men were killed in their homes or travelling to and from the academy, which demonstrated that Pablo knew not only their identities but also their work shifts and home addresses. Pablo was offering a $2,000 bounty for killing Medellín policemen, and it was working. What the authorities needed was some extralegal muscle, some hands-on players who didn't mind crossing the lines of legality and morality that Pablo so blithely ignored. The drug boss certainly didn't lack for bitter enemies, but they had no commonality. They ranged from some of the wealthiest and most powerful families in Bogotá to rival street thugs in Medellín and Cali, a 'civilian militia'. Acquiring the name Los Pepes, they initiated a controlled bloodbath, controlled because all of the victims had one thing in common - Pablo Escobar. As the murders and fearful surrenders mounted, Los Pepes publicly offered cash rewards for information on Pablo and his key associates, and began broadcasting threats against the drug lord's family. What if someone were to give them a push, some organisation, some money, some intelligence, some training, planning,and leadership? Los Pepes were so perfect they were... well, too perfect. Officially the American Embassy was silent on the appearance of Los Pepes, but those at work in the fight against Escobar - including Centra Spike - were not displeased. And why should they have been? What could be better than a homegrown vigilante movement against Public Enemy Number One? Why not spread a little fear on Pablo's side for once? As the lawlessness accelerated, no one from Washington questioned it, or questioned America's commitment to the pursuit. Civilian overseers from the Clinton administration were new in office, and knew next to nothing about what the US military was doing in Colombia. People were always getting killed by one faction or another... Closing in for the kill Young Hugo Martinez looked nothing like his father. He was short, stocky and dark where his father was tall, fair and slender. He shared his father's keen intellect, but was also a visionary, an infectious leader, the kind of man who could convince other people to follow him even when only he understood where they were going. When he got talking about technical matters that often only he understood, Hugo flushed with pleasure. He would grab sheets of paper and a pencil and begin making scratchy diagrams of his ideas. After studying at the National Police Academy in Bogota, he was placed with an electronic-surveillance unit that had been given a new portable direction-finder by the CIA. In the first three or four months after Pablo's escape, Colonel Martinez banned all cell-phone use in Medellín and closed down all repeater stations for transmitting signals, which forced people to use standard phone lines and limited radio communications to point-to-point - that is, the radio operators could not use repeaters to amplify and relay signals over long distances, so the only effective way to communicate between two radios was for there to be a clear line of sight between the transmitter and receiver. The idea was to isolate Pablo. He was too smart to use normal phone lines, but if he tried to communicate through the uncluttered airwaves he would be much easier to find. Pablo responded by using messengers. He resumed regular radio communication only in the spring of 1993, as he grew increasingly concerned about Los Pepes and began scheming to get his family out of the country. Pablo found places where he could see the top of the apartment building Altos del Campestre, where his family was living under heavy guard, and he spoke most often to his son Juan Pablo. The chase had boiled down to a contest between two men and their sons. Pablo's son was his weakness. The colonel's son might yet prove to be his strength. On 26 November, the US embassy learned that Pablo's wife and children were planning once more to flee Colombia. They were going to fly to either London or Frankfurt. The family had become increasingly desperate. They had been under around-the-clock protection by agents from attorney general de Grieff's office ever since the failed effort to fly Juan Pablo and Manuela to Miami in March. In the intervening months, Los Pepes had killed members of their extended family and burned most of the family's properties. The vigilante group seemed to be toying with the Escobars, picking off cousins, in-laws and friends, including some who had been living in Altos del Campestre, demonstrating that they could hurt Pablo's wife Maria Victoria or Juan Pablo. The rocket-propelled grenade that had been fired at the building in October was more like a warning than an actual attempt on their lives. It felt like the threat was closing in. The Colombian government was officially protecting Pablo's family, but they were also effectively holding them in place. So long as Pablo was worried about them, his voice would keep popping up on the radio. The final shootout On 2 December 1993, Pablo awoke shortly before noon, as was his habit, and ate a plate of spaghetti before easing his widening bulk back into bed with his wireless phone. Always a heavy man, he had put on about 20lb living on the run, most of it in his belly. 'On the run' didn't accurately describe it. He spent most of his time lying low, eating, sleeping, talking on the radio. He hired prostitutes, mostly teenage girls, to help him while away the hours. He had trouble finding jeans that would fit him. To get a waist size to accommodate his girth he had to wear pants that were a good 6in too long in the leg. The light-blue pair he wore on this day were turned up twice in a wide cuff. He wore flip-flops and had pulled on a loose blue polo shirt. Prone to stomach disorders, he might have been feeling the effects of his birthday revelry the night before. On this afternoon, the only other person in the house was his bodyguard Alvero de Jesus Agudelo, known as Limón. The two others staying with them, his courier Jaime Rua and his aunt and cook Luz Mila, had gone out after fixing breakfast. At one o'clock, Pablo tried to phone his family, posing as a radio journalist, but the switchboard operator at the Tequendama, per his instructions from Colonel Martinez, told him they had been instructed to block all calls from journalists. He was put on hold, then asked to call back, but finally he got through on the third attempt, speaking briefly to Manuela and then to Maria Victoria and his son. Hugo and his unit had been closing in on Escobar, monitoring his calls. Hugo had driven out of the parking lot in pursuit as soon as his friend on the switchboard at the Hotel Tequendama had alerted him that Pablo was on the line. The signal pointed Hugo straight ahead. The line on the screen lengthened and the tone in his earphones grew stronger as they proceeded up the street. They drove until the signal peaked and then began to diminish, the line pinching in at the edges of the screen and the tone slightly falling off. So they turned around and crept back the other way more slowly. The line stretched gradually until it once again filled the screen. They were in front of a block of two-storey houses. There was no telling which was the one that housed Pablo. They cruised up and down the street several more times. Hugo stopped staring at his screen and instead stared intently at the houses, one by one. Until he saw him. A fat man in the second-floor window. He had long, curly black hair and a full beard. The image hit Hugo like an electric shock. He had only seen Pablo in pictures, and he had always been clean shaven except for the mustache, but they knew Pablo had grown a beard, and there was something about the man in the window that just clicked. He was talking on a cell phone and peering down at traffic. The man stepped back from the window. Hugo thought he had seen a look of surprise. The face of Pablo Escobar assembled slowly in Hugo's brain. For a split second he was confused, disbelieving. Him! He had found him! Years of effort, hundreds of lives, thousands of futile police raids, untold millions of dollars, countless false leads and man-hours, all of the false steps, false alarms, blunders... and here he was at last, one man in a nation of 35m people, one man in a rich, ruthless, and regimented underworld he had virtually owned for nearly two decades, one man in a city of millions where he was revered as a legend. Hugo leaned out of his van and called to the car behind him, 'This is the house!' It was in the middle of the block. Hugo suspected Pablo had been spooked by their white van cruising slowly down the street, so he had told his driver to keep on going down to the end. Shouting into the radio, Hugo asked to be connected to his father. 'I've got him located,' Hugo told him. The colonel knew this was it. Those were words he had never heard before. He knew Hugo would not be saying it unless he had seen Pablo with his own eyes. 'He's in this house,' said Hugo. He explained excitedly that only he and one other car were there. He thought Pablo had seen him and that his gunmen were probably on their way. He wanted to clear out, fast. 'Stay exactly where you are!' Colonel Martinez ordered his son, shouting into the radio. 'Station yourself in front and in back of the house and don't let him come out.' Then the colonel got word to all his units in the area, including those still thrashing through the office building blocks away, and told them to converge on the house immediately. Hugo's two men got out of the car and positioned themselves against the wall on either side of Pablo's front door. Hugo drove the van around the block to the alley, counting the houses until he could see the back end of Pablo's. Terrified, with weapons ready, they waited. It took 10 minutes. There was a heavy metal front door. Martin, one of the lieutenants assigned to the Search Bloc assault team, stood ready as his men applied a heavy steel sledgehammer to it. Martin had not worn his bullet-proof vest today, and he had a moment of anxious regret, just as the hammer crashed into the door. It took several blows before it went down. Martin sprinted into the house with the five men on his team, and the shooting started. In the din and confusion, he quickly sized up the first floor. It was empty, like a garage. There was a yellow taxi parked toward the rear, and a flight of stairs leading up to the second floor. One of Martin's men stumbled on his way up the stairs, and everyone stopped momentarily. They thought the man had been hit. Limón leaped out a back window to the orange tile roof as soon as the team burst through the front door. The way the house was constructed, there was a back roof surrounded by walls on three sides that could be reached by dropping about 10ft from a second-storey window. Limón hit the tiles and began running, and as he did the Search Bloc members arrayed in the street behind the house opened fire. There were dozens of men up and down the block with automatic weapons, some of them standing on the tops of their cars. Limón was hit several times as he ran. His momentum carried him right off the roof. He fell to the grass below. Then came Pablo. He stopped to kick off his flip-flops, then jumped down to the roof. Having seen what had happened to Limón, he stayed close to one wall, where there was some protection. The shooter on the roof overhead could not get a clear shot directly down at him, so there was a break in the firing momentarily as Pablo quickly moved along the wall toward the back street. No one on the street had a clear shot at him yet. At the corner, Pablo made his break. He went for the crest of the gently sloping roof, trying to make it to the other side. There was a thundering cascade of fire and Pablo fell near the crest. He sprawled forward, dislodging orange tiles. The shooting continued. Martin's team inside the house had found the second floor empty. When he stuck his head in the open window to look out on the roof, he saw a body and then heard an eruption of more gunfire. He and his men fell prone on the floor and waited as rounds from the street below crashed through the window and into the walls and ceiling of the room. Martin believed he and his men were taking fire from Pablo's bodyguards. He shouted into his radio, 'Help! Help us! We need support!' Everyone was shooting on automatic from below. Rounds chewed up the brick walls around the enclosed rooftop. It felt as if it took minutes for the shooting to die down, for the Search Bloc to realise they were the only ones shooting. Finally, it stopped. The shooter on the second-floor roof shouted, 'It's Pablo! It's Pablo!' Men were now scaling the roof to see. Someone found a ladder and placed it under the second-floor window, and others climbed down from it. Major Aguilar grabbed the body and turned it over. The wide bearded face was swollen, bloody, and wreathed in long, blood-soaked black curls. The major grabbed a radio and spoke directly to Colonel Martinez, loudly enough for even the men on the street below to hear. ' Vivá Colombia ! We have just killed Pablo Escobar!' Extracted from Killing Pablo - The Hunt for the Richest, Most Powerful Criminal in History by Mark Bowden (£16.99, Atlantic Books, published 21 May).

webTitle: Weight training

fields.headline: Weight training
fields.trailText: Hindsight is a valuable thing, not least when it comes to dieting. Having spent many, many years crash-dieting, a surprising number of the patients who seek my help now bitterly regret having ever started starving themselves in the first place.
fields.body:
Hindsight is a valuable thing, not least when it comes to dieting. Having spent many, many years crash-dieting, a surprising number of the patients who seek my help now bitterly regret having ever started starving themselves in the first place. So before you resolve to eat nothing but cabbage soup, or to take slimming drugs, remember that the diet industry would have starved to death years ago if such measures worked in the long run. Indeed, the inventors of all those 'wonder' diets don't actually want them to work in the long term, because that would mean that you'd only have to follow them once, wouldn't it?

As boring as it may sound, the only effective way of losing weight is to enjoy a well-balanced diet - which means dispensing with faddish regimes such as food combining - and to exercise regularly. As for the supplements that claim to raise your metabolic rate: the only way of doing this safely is through exercise. It's important to take the right sort of exercise, however, as some activities can leave you feeling exhausted, sick and as heavy as before. These are typically short-duration, high-intensity types of exercise, such as squash and sprinting, that merely burn off sugar to fuel an active body.

The most effective kinds of weight-losing exercise are walking briskly for at least 20 to 30 minutes, or cycling, jogging and swimming, all of which involve a less intensive workout, which means that you will be able to keep active for longer, thereby raising your metabolic rate and prompting your lungs and heart to deliver sufficient oxygen to your muscles to enable them to burn off fat. It will take at least six weeks before you notice any results.

If you still can't resist embarking on a, say, pre-summer crash diet, take note of the following dangers and downsides before you do so. First, having seen hundreds of long-term dieters in my practice, I can attest to the fact that if you lose weight at a faster rate than 1kg a week on a sustained basis, something strange seems to happen to the metabolic rate (physiologists don't really understand why this happens). As soon as you start eating more than the 500 or 800 or so calories a day that you've been restricting yourself to in order to slim, not only do the pounds pile back on at great speed, but they do so in the form of fat, making any subsequent attempts to lose weight that much harder.

Eating too little will also significantly reduce your energy levels, often to the extent that you won't be able to exercise at all because your body will have become so malnourished. You'll feel lousy and increasingly tetchy (dieters are notoriously avoided at the workplace), and your concentration will be compromised. Worse still, if you ingest fewer than 1,000 calories a day, eventually you may actually start hallucinating because your body begins to produce ketones, a form of emergency fuel the body produces when it's deprived of another energy source. Ketones also cause you to lose vital calcium from your bones, which can be particularly serious for people under the age of 20, when strength is still being built into the bones in preparation for the years ahead. Their bones may become so fragile that they end up developing osteoporosis (brittle-bone disease), either when they're still young or, in the case of some women, when they hit the menopause.

Teenage girls may stop menstruating if they either lose too much weight or lose a lot rapidly, thereby triggering hormonal changes, and if menstruation is interrupted on a continuous basis, it will compromise not only bone health but also the ability to have children. Anaemia, too, is very common among teenagers who restrict their food intake in search of the so-called 'perfect' body. Crash-dieting usually involves reducing your intake of red meat, green, leafy vegetables and other iron-rich foods (and many teenagers would in any case prefer a slimming shake or bar, or a small portion of junk food, to a steak and salad, which would be far healthier for them), thereby causing the body to become deficient in this nutrient (and many others) which is essential for growth and development, as well as maintaining healthy blood and an effective immune system.

My message, then, to all weight watchers is: stop pinning your hopes on dubious 'wonder' diets and start exercising regularly and eating small, well-balanced meals instead. Keep your intake of fat, sugar and alcohol low; eat plenty of vegetables, fruits, lean proteins, pulses and fibres; drink lots of water; eat slowly, and really savour your food. I have your best, long-term interests at heart, so believe me when I tell you that as much as I would love to trumpet the news that a new blood-type or psychological-profile diet works, I can't - they don't. Such diets are merely short-term solutions that have been primarily devised to line their promoters' wallets.

Jane Clarke is a state-registered dietician. If you would like her to answer any questions or address any issues in this column, please write to Jane Clarke c/o Life magazine, The Observer , 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER or email her at :life@observer.co.uk. Please note that Jane Clarke cannot enter into any personal correspondence.

webTitle: First the bricks, then the clicks

fields.headline: First the bricks, then the clicks
fields.standfirst: Travel firm EBookers has defied internet orthodoxy. Profile of Dinesh Damija by  Faisal Islam
fields.trailText: Travel firm EBookers has defied internet orthodoxy. Profile of Dinesh Damija by Faisal Islam
fields.body:
Dinesh Dhamija knows a thing or two about terrifying descents. As European head of Royal Nepal Airlines a decade ago, he would jet in and out of Katmandu nearly once a fortnight. Planes landing at the airport need to negotiate a hairy, spiralling approach to the runway, and there have been several crashes.

Perhaps this experience prepared him for Ebookers' cliff-like drop in stock market value, dragged down last year along with every other company bearing the dotcom suffix. Surely it's been a tumultuous year?

'For dotcoms yes, but not for us,' he says curtly. So Ebookers is not really a dotcom? 'We come from the industry,' he explains. 'Our relations, contracts, and buying power are all in the travel industry.'

Dhamija has been involved in this sector for more than 20 years. He started out in 1980, operating an agency from an 80-metre-square booth at Earl's Court Tube station. Three years later that venture grew into Flightbookers, which spun off its internet arm, ebookers.com, in 1999.

Despite his protestations, the market has treated Ebookers as a dotcom. This suited the company when it shared in the upturn, after flotation on the Nasdaq and the German Neuer Markt 18 months ago. But when sentiment turned, Ebookers was not immune from the fortunes of the tumbling internet sector.

But now, according to US research company Phocus-Wright, Ebookers is the No 1 online travel agent in Europe. The company has just listed on the London Stock Exchange, and is already trading 50 per cent above last month's issue price.

'Our strategy is completely different from everyone else's. Our strategy is going into each country and buying content, which is negotiating fares, buying licences, buying people with language skills and local knowledge, and buying fulfilment - none of the others want to do that,' he says.

Normally airlines sell directly to consumers at published fares - branded tickets that are rarely sold at a discount. Other passengers can get on the same flight more cheaply by purchasing a negotiated fare - a bargain-basement fare branded not by the airline, but by a travel agent. The agent can mix and match outward and return portions.

Travel agents need to be licensed in each country in which they wish to sell negotiated fares, and need to develop direct relationships with airlines. 'The strategy is the most important thing - to buy the licences, you need one bricks-and-mortar agent in each country. There are only 10 to 15 agents per country who get negotiated fares.'

Rather than set up anew in each European country he had targeted, Dhamija used the initial flotation proceeds to snap up 11 agencies with contacts and contracts in place.

'We didn't buy just any company, only those with the licences. Lastminute started companies in six countries, which is of no use to man nor beast,' he argues. 'There's no way you're going to do it organically in this business; it has to be acquisition - you need critical size. To make a profit you need $250-350m in sales.'

Dhamija was in a better position than most to pick off those valuable targets. 'I ran Royal Nepal right across Europe, and that's what gave me the contacts to go and buy those agents,' he says.

So Ebookers has run an aggressive Cisco-esque acquisition strategy across Europe. It now has arrangements with some 120 airlines, and call centres with local expertise in 11 countries. Integrating these assets is difficult, but Dhamija believes this network is 'a huge barrier to entry for everyone else' - particularly US online agents. 'They won't have a chance,' he says.

'They can't deal with languages and can't deal with 12 legal and audit systems. The European market is completely different.' Nor is Dhamija worried by the launch of websites by coalitions of airlines. 'The airlines' portals won't sell negotiated fares - it would wipe out their own brands.'

Dhamija doesn't really see himself as part of the 'digerati'. 'Dapper travel industry grandee' would be a better description of this Cambridge law graduate, son of Indian diplomats.

He fell into the travel industry by accident. 'It could well have been shoe-making,' he says. That booth at Earl's Court, operated with his wife and a friend, quickly turned into three booths, which by 1983 had become Flightbookers.

Its entanglement with the internet in 1996 - the first travel agent with an interactive website - was 'pure fluke'. 'I had a friend who developed something in Germany. He said,"Why don't you try it out?" and at first I said, "Don't waste my time". Then he installed it free of charge and the bookings just started coming in.'

Due to a lack of City enthusiasm for the internet, EBookers was not originally listed in London. But demand for shares in Germany and the US was strong; the original issue was 14 times oversubscribed.

'It's a battle going public, it's pretty traumatic,' Dhamija says. 'We had 72 meetings in 12 days in eight countries during that November.'

Now, having driven through most aspects of the original business plan, he is beginning to see its fruits. Ebookers' reported sales have beaten forecasts in every one of the six quarters since the original listing. Last week's figures showed an impressive doubling in year-on-year sales to $48.7m. Pre-tax losses for the quarter were $11.9m, but the company is on course to be cashflow-positive by the beginning of next year.

The brightest piece of news was the near doubling in website visits year-on-year to 10.1m, whereas marketing costs have more than halved to $2.4m.

These statistics are probably more important for long-term growth potential than sales growth. It suggests that brand recognition is strong.

It also suggests that Ebookers' strategy of building a customer base offline through acquisition, then tempting them online, is beginning to work. Dhamija calls this strategy 'bricks and clicks'.

'It's simple,' he says. 'For customer acquisition, the bricks method is much cheaper than the clicks method. You don't achieve this through advertising in newspapers or on radio, but by buying companies so those millions of sales are customers.

'But to fulfil, the cheapest way is clicks. So you build people on the bricks path and then you give them a discount on the clicks path, which is an easy job - £2 or something. So it is bricks and clicks, and not clicks and bricks - which is the Amazon model.'

This turns the original internet orthodoxy on its head. Dhamija argues that it is more expensive to acquire customers over the internet, or through traditional advertising means, because they tend to be unprofitable,fickle, bargain-hunters.

By building a critical mass of European customers, and steadily migrating them to his website through discounting, the scope for sustained revenue growth is greater. And the more customers Ebookers has, the greater its bargaining power with those 120 airlines.

Dhamija is also looking at outsourcing some of his clerical and technology work to India, as part of a drive to halve cash burn to $1.5m a month. The strategy should lead to profits by 2002.

'I won't be taking my foot off the pedal until we've made a profit,' he says. Having negotiated a tricky landing, Dhamija is now anxious to show that Ebookers can handle an equally difficult take-off.

But he's used to that.

Profile

Subject: Dinesh Dhamija

Born: Canberra, Australia

Job: Chief executive, EBookers

Education: Fitzwilliam College, Cambridge

Hobbies: Golf and travel

webTitle: Vodafone spending plans could mean a costly call

fields.headline: Vodafone spending plans could mean a costly call
fields.trailText: If the market is as keen on telecoms shares as the response to the £3.5 billion placing by Vodafone suggests, Sir Christopher Bland should waste no time in launching British Telecom's rights issue. Far from grumbling at the issue - priced at just 6 per cent below the opening price on the day it was carried out - the City positively lapped it up. Indeed, so enthusiastic was the market that Vodafone upped the amount from the £3bn originally planned.
fields.body:
If the market is as keen on telecoms shares as the response to the £3.5 billion placing by Vodafone suggests, Sir Christopher Bland should waste no time in launching British Telecom's rights issue. Far from grumbling at the issue - priced at just 6 per cent below the opening price on the day it was carried out - the City positively lapped it up. Indeed, so enthusiastic was the market that Vodafone upped the amount from the £3bn originally planned.

Alas for BT, this does not mean the City is no longer jittery about the level of telecoms debt and investment commitments. But it is realistic about what needs to be done. The spending spree which ended last summer has left too many telecoms companies with too much debt and too large a spending commitment to build their global networks. BT is merely the biggest British example of a distressed operator, but there are plenty of others around the globe.

If there is to be any hope of a return on the investment made to date - never mind the spending to come - the networks have to be finished and the infrastructure assembled. The only sensible thing for investors to do, therefore, is to back those companies which seem to have the final headroom and the industrial clout to get that done.

The City is betting that Vodafone is one of these. Doubling its stake in Japan Tele com makes strategic sense and, while some question its need to mop up BT's 17.8 per cent stake in Spanish Airtel given that it was already the majority shareholder, it does at least tidy up some loose ends. Vodafone could have financed the acquisitions with debt. On its own definitions, its borrowings at 31 March were around £7bn. Add the debt in joint-venture companies - which Vodafone does not consolidate, but the debt agencies do - and that is approaching £20bn.

Without a placing, therefore, there was a high risk that it would have lost its triple-A rating, which would have had serious repercussions both for its rates and for its ability to raise funds in future.

Japan Telecom alone needs as much as £5bn to complete its network. Multiply that by at least 10 to get the interna tional figure, and the ability to tap the debt markets in future is clearly crucial.

The placing should also ensure that Vodafone retains the flexibility to act should any other bargains appear. Vodafone's shares have all but halved in the past year as the investors began to grasp just how much investment the industry was gobbling up - and to fret about whether there would be the returns to justify it.

Vodafone's placing provides some reassurance about its ability to finance its spending plans but it has yet to demonstrate it can make money from them. The shares are likely to remain volatile until there is evidence that the global telecoms dream can become a profitable reality. Cautious investors should steer clear.

Nothing to lose

The problem with corporate restructuring is that, so often, it simply whets the appetite for more. David Thomas and his team at Whitbread may be feeling rather pleased with themselves for selling the group's brewing and pubs businesses in short order. Now, however, the City is wondering whether the restaurants deserve their place in the group.

It is not hard to see why. Beefeater and Brewers Fayre were respectable but hardly spectacular. Up to 90 of the former will be rebranded as Out and Outs - lighter, modern and more upmarket, without the feeling of being part of a chain, says Whitbread - and other formats are being tried for the remaining 150 or so in the chain.

Unfortunately, however, customers have a way of spotting chains very quickly - and avoiding them like the plague, as Whitbread has too often found to its cost. The result is a never-ending series of brand relaunches, which start with a bang but quickly become tired.

That is clearly the problem with Café Rouge and Bella Pasta, which only managed to maintain sales. Shedding the worst performers did give a fillip in the final quarter, when sales from ongoing sites were up 5 per cent. But Whitbread itself admits that they, along with TGI Fridays, may not manage to justify their position in the group long term - which requires a £10 million annual contribution to profits. Costa Coffee - and that old banker, Pizza Hut - were the exceptions, producing healthy results. But how long can the caffe latte phenomenon last...

Elsewhere, the results were solid enough. Conversion of the Swallow hotels (acquired last year) to Marriotts is proceeding well and producing the promised uplifts in revenue per room; the foot and mouth panic is showing signs of abating, judging by the most recent occupancy rates; and David Lloyd Leisure is still packing in the health fanatics.

Later this month Whitbread is to return £1.1bn, 230p a share, of the proceeds of the pubs and brewing sale to shareholders, so there is no point selling now. The shares have recovered, but are still at a big discount to the market, reflecting City scepticism about its ability to meet its own 10 per cent growth targets. Until there is more evidence, the shares are a hold.

Still no chemistry

Imperial Chemical Industries is another much-restructured business. In the past five years it has sold and bought at a dizzying pace as it chased the holy grail of the chemicals industry: immunity from, or at least resilience within, the economic cycle. First-quarter results suggest it is succeeding slightly better than had been expected when it announced full-year figures three months ago. As it proudly boasts, only National Starch suffered from the US downturn and, even there, the performance was better than in the fourth quarter of last year.

Quest, the fragrance and flavours business, and paints both shrugged off the downturn and reported an improvement on last year in the US.

That is not bad, given the violent swings investors used to have to suffer when ICI was an old-fashioned chemicals business. But a flat trading profit is hardly something to get excited about, albeit that it is only a three-month period. The long-term targets of 4 to 5 per cent organic growth are not spectacular either - assuming they can even be achieved. The shares are a hold at best.

webTitle: Sting in a not so cruel month

fields.headline: Sting in a not so cruel month
fields.trailText: When one considers that the US economy threatened to 'hang in rags' for much of the year, April proved a decent month. It took a few days for things to look positive again after it had played the very rewarding bear in most of the global stock markets for the previous three months. But there were a few signals to encourage the faint-hearted, including a curve ball in the form of an amazingly upbeat US GDP growth figure of 2 per cent for the first quarter.
fields.body:
When one considers that the US economy threatened to 'hang in rags' for much of the year, April proved a decent month. It took a few days for things to look positive again after it had played the very rewarding bear in most of the global stock markets for the previous three months. But there were a few signals to encourage the faint-hearted, including a curve ball in the form of an amazingly upbeat US GDP growth figure of 2 per cent for the first quarter.

But then last week, reality gave the market a slap in the form of a depressing non-farm payroll number of -223,000 and a frightening unemployment rate of 4.5 per cent. Gladiators have to remember that 'one swallow does not make a summer'.

As for the June FTSE position, which was bought at 5,890 on 27 April for 'election reasons' - well, David Schwartz wagged his authoritative finger at us. He warned that May can be an awful month after a strong April, so the Gladiator lost his bottle and sold at 5,950. Just look at it now. The option position on the US indices is hopelessly underwater, but the situation is not irrevocable as it is a long-term market and these indices could easily slide during the summer - aided and abetted by further poor employment news.

Telecoms, and in particular, Vodafone and BT have been all the rage this week. UBS Warburg, Goldmans and Deutsche Bank seem to have found placing £3.5 billion of Vodafone shares with the institutions relatively painless at 194p to pay for their acquisition of BT's 20 per cent stake in Japan Telecom.

The following day, Vodafone's share price slipped virtually to the price of the placing. The market knows the cost of 3G licences and how. But what no one knows is the cost of networking. There is a perception that broadband may take too long to make a contribution and the price on many of these companies is too reliant on expectation. The sector overall has dropped 55 per cent from its peak, with BT and Cable & Wireless in free-fall, and there may be a further decline. So, the telecom sector index has been sold at 4,490 at 3.45pm on 3 May 2001.

It is not all doom and gloom, and the Gladiator has been encouraged by sound analysis from schwartz- trends.com to buy the life assurance sector. There are seven component stocks, with CGNU, the Prudential, Legal and General and Old Mutual the most influential. So their boots have been filled at the same time as the telecom sell at 6,755, and progress will be monitored.

The jury remains 'out' on certain parts of our portfolio. Looking at our European bank investments, we bailed out on Thursday for a modest profit for two reasons. First, it looks as though Wim Duisenberg is not going to play ball on interest rates, which was part of the gladiatorial strategy. Second, the vibes coming out of the US on bank shares were not encouraging, with bad debts and bankruptcies threatened later in the year.

On 10 April, the troops bought BNP Paribas at €95.60 (£153), ABN/AMRO at €22.50 and Deutsche Bank - which produced decent figures on Thursday - at €85.25. The positions were sold off at €98.00, €22.70 and €92.00, respectively. They settled for that return, as there is more than just a feeling of post-prandial neurosis in the air.

Sadly some of this profit was surrendered on EasyJet, sold at 397p on 27 April. This share had shot up to 418p last Thursday. Warriors are used to taking punishment, so they took it on the chin. The position was duly cut.

Carphone Warehouse has not moved from 124p and Atlas Airways is off a smidgen from $25.62 to $25.24, so they will be offered every opportunity to fall from grace. The utility 'short' in Scottish Power, United Utilities and Severn Trent has hardly moved down a penny in three weeks, so it will be left to a fresh New Labour administration to do its worst.

Finally, the Gladiator is at all times a pragmatist, so having bought New Labour seats at 376 a few weeks ago, he decided to take a small profit by selling at 388 and he will review the situation next week after fresh polls from NOP and Mori.

The Gladiator is the nom de plume of a professional spread better.
