The option position on the US indices is hopelessly underwater, but the situation is not irrevocable as it is a long-term market and these indices could easily slide during the summer - aided and abetted by further poor employment news. Telecoms, and in particular, Vodafone and BT have been all the rage this week. UBS Warburg, Goldmans and Deutsche Bank seem to have found placing £3.5 billion of Vodafone shares with the institutions relatively painless at 194p to pay for their acquisition of BT's 20 per cent stake in Japan Telecom. The following day, Vodafone's share price slipped virtually to the price of the placing. The market knows the cost of 3G licences and how. But what no one knows is the cost of networking. There is a perception that broadband may take too long to make a contribution and the price on many of these companies is too reliant on expectation. The sector overall has dropped 55 per cent from its peak, with BT and Cable & Wireless in free-fall, and there may be a further decline. So, the telecom sector index has been sold at 4,490 at 3.45pm on 3 May 2001. It is not all doom and gloom, and the Gladiator has been encouraged by sound analysis from schwartz- trends.com to buy the life assurance sector. There are seven component stocks, with CGNU, the Prudential, Legal and General and Old Mutual the most influential. So their boots have been filled at the same time as the telecom sell at 6,755, and progress will be monitored. The jury remains 'out' on certain parts of our portfolio. Looking at our European bank investments, we bailed out on Thursday for a modest profit for two reasons. First, it looks as though Wim Duisenberg is not going to play ball on interest rates, which was part of the gladiatorial strategy. Second, the vibes coming out of the US on bank shares were not encouraging, with bad debts and bankruptcies threatened later in the year. On 10 April, the troops bought BNP Paribas at €95.60 (£153), ABN/AMRO at €22.50 and Deutsche Bank - which produced decent figures on Thursday - at €85.25. The positions were sold off at €98.00, €22.70 and €92.00, respectively. They settled for that return, as there is more than just a feeling of post-prandial neurosis in the air. Sadly some of this profit was surrendered on EasyJet, sold at 397p on 27 April. This share had shot up to 418p last Thursday. Warriors are used to taking punishment, so they took it on the chin. The position was duly cut. Carphone Warehouse has not moved from 124p and Atlas Airways is off a smidgen from $25.62 to $25.24, so they will be offered every opportunity to fall from grace. The utility 'short' in Scottish Power, United Utilities and Severn Trent has hardly moved down a penny in three weeks, so it will be left to a fresh New Labour administration to do its worst. Finally, the Gladiator is at all times a pragmatist, so having bought New Labour seats at 376 a few weeks ago, he decided to take a small profit by selling at 388 and he will review the situation next week after fresh polls from NOP and Mori. The Gladiator is the nom de plume of a professional spread better.

webTitle: Sisters are doing it for themselves

fields.headline: Sisters are doing it for themselves
fields.standfirst: One in 10 men has a sexual problem and it spawns a billion-dollar business. But what about the 43 per cent of women who say they don't enjoy sex? Jessica Berens meets the Berman sisters, doctors who are dedicated to ensuring girls come out on top
fields.trailText: One in 10 men has a sexual problem and it spawns a billion-dollar business. But what about the 43 per cent of women who say they don't enjoy sex? Jessica Berens meets the Berman sisters, doctors who are dedicated to ensuring girls come out on top.
fields.body:
Peace in heaven and glory in the highest; navel gazing has descended 12 inches. What are we looking at? We are looking at labial arteries, bulbospongiosus muscle and pudendal nerves. We are look ing at a collection of muscles and nerve-endings that are, or should be, responsible for those pleasurable contractions that lie at the centre of culture (or advertising, as it is now known) but whose exact physiological anatomy remains a mystery - to you, to me and to the medical profession. We are looking at the vulva, a place that has been explored and navigated and photographed but for which there is still no map. It is as if everyone has been driving around for ages and still has not found where they want to go. A bit like Birmingham.

It was only three years ago that the Australian urologist Helen O'Connell discovered that the clitoris extended three-and-a-half inches into a woman's body, making it a far larger and more complex organ than it had been originally perceived. And it was also only three years ago that American sex therapist Laura Berman was told not to say clitoris on a British television programme.

The clitoris - an organ designed purely for pleasure - has 8,000 nerve endings. But are we having fun yet? No we are not.

The emergence of Viagra in 1998 turned the company Pfizer into a multimillion- pound organisation. The success of the drug not only revealed the extent of male impotence (or erectile dysfunction, as it is more politely described), but more importantly it made the subject less embarrassing. In 1999, the Journal of the American Medical Association reported a survey which showed that while one in 10 men were experiencing sexual problems, the numbers went up to four in 10 in women. Forty-three per cent.

Sex-sated culture still deifies the female body as a lifeless mammarian goddess, but the woman inside that body is reporting record levels of sexual disinterest. Libidos are low, orgasms are not forthcoming and the consequence is physical pain, emotional distress and insoluble relationship problems. These 'disorders' are now medically termed as FSD - female sexual dysfunction.

No, we are not having fun yet.

Welcome to the University of Los Angeles Medical Centre. I wait for the Berman sisters in the Elmer Belt Conference Room at the Centre for Urology in Westwood. There are black-and-white photographs of various 'fathers of urology'. There is the magazine of the American Urology Association whose front page leads on stories about 'androgen deficiency in the ageing male' and the forthcoming meeting of the Society for the Study of Impotence. And, on the wall, a framed cystoscope - a terrifying appliance that looks like a cross between a clarinet and a cake icer. Lord knows where it is supposed to go. Not anywhere near me, I hope.

This is a manly atmosphere, but urology, until now, has been a manly concern. Indeed, one of the reasons why the American Food and Drug Administration is loath to sanction the sale of Viagra to women (despite much demand) is because there has been so little scientific research into the physiology of female genitalia.

The siblings arrive. They are attractive, blonde and smiley, and this is good because it means they won't scare the straights. They are enjoying something of a success in America, partly, perhaps, because they are blonde and smiley, nice Jewish girls from the Upper East Side, partly because they are well-qualified, and partly because they are in the right place at the right time.The zeitgeist is on their side.

There has been publicity. The Bermans understand publicity and they are good at it (appearing on Oprah and various chat shows with nerveless aplomb), knowing, no doubt, that increased awareness of their work not only eases the path towards helpful grants, but also creates a more relaxed atmosphere around the discussion of 'wimmin's parts'.

Laura, 32, is a sex therapist. Jennifer, 36, is a surgeon who decided to specialise in urology because she enjoyed the procedures (which, in general, offer a high rate of recovery for acute conditions), because it offered a lifestyle that allowed her to be a mother (she has a 16-month-old son) and because, as a field of research, it offered the potential for discovery. While working in residency in Maryland, she found that the path to reconstructive surgery of the female pelvic floor was hampered by a lack of knowledge about nerve endings - that is, the relationship between the spinal cord, the uterus, the vagina and the clitoris was still unknown - which explains why so many women who have had pelvic surgery and hysterectomies are suffering from desensitisation.

Jennifer is fascinated by the mechanics of female sexual response; she provides the clinical perspective, while her sister investigates the emotional roots of the problem. And, since they believe that most disorders are the result of both, they are uniquely positioned to provide a realistic picture and to advise on suitable treatment. Laura is perky in a blue jumper; Jennifer is ER in a white coat.

Jennifer is happily married to Greg, a public-health specialist. Laura is divorced with a four-year-old son. 'My ex-husband had self-esteem problems. My intellect and success made him feel inferior. Eventually I left the marriage,' she explains.

Both Bermans are small and neat, though Laura insists that Jennifer has body-image problems. 'I'm not a big dieter,' she says, 'but if I spend too much time with Jennifer I start to get psycho with, "Am I fat?" and, "How does my butt look?"'

Jennifer pinches her younger sister. 'She is very self-conscious about her arms.'

Laura: 'We got fat in college.'

Jennifer: 'Our mother was very buff... remember, we used to have to hide when we ate cream cheese?'

Laura: 'It wasn't cream cheese. We used to sneak down and eat ice-cream sundaes.'

Jennifer: 'And there was the chocolate she hid in the freezer.'

This cues wild laughing, and I observe that their façade of sanity is obviously a grotesque illusion to which there is more wild laughing followed by the general agreement that mothers pass on to their daughters how they feel about their bodies.

'I guess the bottom line is that we are women and we understand what women go through,' says Laura.

They began life in Park Avenue, New York, but moved as teenagers to Georgia, where their father, a colon-rectal surgeon, ran his practice. Their mother had surrendered her career in finance to raise her family.

Jennifer: 'That sort of impacted on Laura and me in terms of a career passage.'

Laura: 'She wanted us to be emotionally and financially independent. She used to put me to bed making me promise to be president.'

Jennifer: 'That didn't work, so now our sons are going to be presidents.'

As a teenager, Jennifer began to read Judy Blume, an American author specialising in novels for adolescents about the progress from childhood to sexuality, which described both masturbation and orgasm. Her father found Forever and ripped the book in half.

Laura: 'He didn't do that for me!'

Jennifer: 'He probably didn't know you were reading it.'

Laura: 'He did! Mom knew I was reading it. I remember we were in the dentist's office and this mother got mad at her for letting me read it and she said, "As long as she reads, I don't care what she reads..."'

Sex, in the Berman household, was discussed openly, but the overriding message was that they should avoid it if possible. Laura: 'From early on, there was the message that we should not be sexual until we were in the context of a healthy, loving relationship.'

Jennifer: 'They did not encourage us to go out and sexually experiment at all.'

Laura: 'There are two components - one is about feeling at ease with your sexuality and the other is acting on it by putting yourself at risk of pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases. These were very separate issues in our house, and I still think that in order to be sexually responsible you need to first feel good about yourself and your sexuality, and I think they are responsible for that.'

It quickly became apparent that Jennifer was going to become the doctor; Laura could not stand the sight of blood, while Jennifer took to medicating her horse. Jennifer's research into subjects such as nitric oxide takes her to places that make her sister shudder - working on cadavers, for instance, in order to study the female genitalia. I ask her about her reaction to her first dead body.

Jennifer: 'It was Uncle Ed. He was in an open casket.'

Laura: 'The only thing I remember about Uncle Ed is the thumb wrestling.'

Laura trained to be a sex therapist at the New York University Medical Centre. 'I was exposed to everything under the sun,' she says. 'I talked to peep-show workers and prostitutes. I went to gay bars and S&M meetings. I had to confront every value I had, question it, analyse it and understand it. I found working with sex offenders very hard. And some of the paraphilias. One woman had an antenna fetish, I remember. She was a radio-repair woman. My threshold for shock was a lot higher than some of my colleagues, but now I am never shocked.'

She moved to Spain with her husband and worked as a sex therapist there until her marriage broke down, leaving her with no immediate prospects. Jennifer, meanwhile, had taken a job in Boston and invited her to work with her. They founded a clinic for women's sexual health in 1998, then moved to California last year. Now they run two clinics a week and see around 40 new patients a month. The average age is 45, but there have been 18- and 80-year-olds. The women come from all over America (and the world) and, though predominately heterosexual, they represent a diverse ethnic spectrum.

The sisters have outlined the categories that define female sexual dysfunction in their book For Women Only. It falls into four parts. One of these is hypoactive sexual-desire disorder, the symptom of which is a basic lack of interest. The causes can be various - anti-depressants, for instance, are known to lower the libido. They may also be emotional in their base, or the physical result of menopause, which can cause dryness. Sexual-arousal disorder, meanwhile, is characterised by the physical inability to maintain lubrication, by decreased sensation and, sometimes, by diminished blood flow to the vagina or clitoris. Orgasmic disorder is the inability to reach climax despite stimulation. This can be caused by a number of things including trauma (such as sexual abuse or a physical accident), hormonal deficiency or damage incurred during pelvic surgery. Finally, sexual-pain disorder is intense discomfort experienced during penetrative sex. It may have its origins in emotional causes, in surgical procedures or, again, in the onset of menopause.

Treatments vary and many of them are still in experimental stages. The Bermans have participated in clinical trials for Viagra and remain enthusiastic about its prospects, despite some disappointing statistics. They also believe that testosterone is important in governing libido and sexual response.

Some women arrive with their partners; some do not. Who are they? They are Janet, 35, mother of two from Boston who, having been sexually abused by her brother at the age of seven, could only reach orgasm by self-stimulation. When it came to her husband (whom she loved) she shut down. Her husband was talking about divorce. 'Shutting down', say the Berman sisters, is a common 'survival' response. Viagra did not work for Janet. Therapy and anti-depressants did.

Debra, 31, and her husband Scott, a couple from New York, had four children and were experiencing a common problem - unequal libidos. Debra was exhausted; Scott wanted sex. We all know the scenario. A lowering of the female libido is particularly common after the birth of a second child. Debra had put on weight and felt ashamed of her body. The Bermans encouraged Scott to stimulate his wife with a vibrator (she had never masturbated). They observed healthy pelvic blood flow, engorgement and lubrication. They tested her blood for lowered testosterone levels, a common cause of lowered libido. Testosterone can be prescribed as a solution, but some women avoid it, not wanting to take a hormone about which relatively little is known. Debra, however, was found to have normal levels. The Bermans suggested that the couple take time away from the children in order to focus on each other, and referred them to a therapist. They also prescribed a low-dose testosterone cream and Viagra. The couple began to make progress.

Carla, 44, a mother of three, had under gone uterine-artery embolisation - a surgical procedure for the treatment of fibroids, during which plastic particles are injected into the uterine artery in order to block blood flow to the fibroids. The result was that having enjoyed satisfying orgasms, Carla had lost her ability to achieve a satisfying climax.

The Bermans concluded that the surgery had affected the vaginal arteries and, consequently, the blood flow to her pelvis. They recommended aerobic exercise. Carla's condition improved. She is now executive director of the National Uterine Fibroid Foundation.

The solutions are not always so simple. Ann and Charles were in their seventies. They had grown apart within their marriage, but Charles wanted to restore the intimacy that they had lost. Ann, post-menopausal, had lost interest in sex. She was also angry with her husband, who had engaged in a number of extra-marital affairs. She did not want to undergo a physical examination nor did she want to take hormones. Nor, however, did she wish to live alone. The Bermans told them that couple therapy would help them work through the anger that fulminated at the centre of the relationship; but the couple remained in limbo, unable to make a decision as to which direction to go. Change is frightening and, at 70, very difficult.

The patient who presents herself to the Centre for Pelvic Medicine is a brave woman. She must be ready to discuss the most intimate details of her sex life with Laura, whose questions will be about everything from masturbation to the possibility of sexual abuse suffered in childhood.

Then there is a range of tests conducted by Jennifer. Her equipment is designed to assess PH levels, vaginal elasticity, clitoral sensation and pelvic blood flow, but it looks as if it has been stolen from the set of Dead Ringers. The EROS CTD (clitoral therapy device) is a battery-operated vacuum designed to increase the blood flow to the clitoris by sucking on it with a 'CARess Cup'.

The TSA 11 NeuroSensory Analyser was developed to research the effect of neurological disorders (such as multiple sclerosis) on the female genital organs. It is a black probe attached to various wires and clamps, described by the manufacturers as an 'intra-vaginal vibratory insertion unit'. Jennifer admits that, yes, they do make women nervous, but then the women are also keen to find the root of their problems.

The 3D 'surround-around' video glasses are more fun in a sci-fi kind of way. They are fitted with an erotic video, the patient self-stimulates with a vibrator, and the post-orgasmic effects are assessed by a vaginal probe and ultrasound, in order to compare them against the data gathered in the initial tests.

This brings us, not unnaturally, to the subject of pornography. In many ways, the Berman sisters are the logical follow-up to the thinking initiated by women such as Annie Sprinkle and Nina Hartley 10 years ago. Sprinkle, a New York performance artist, gave shows in which members of the audience were encouraged to look at her cervix with the aid of a torch and a speculum. Hartley, a porn star, made 'instructional' videos. Both represented the pro-porn feminist idea that it was important for women to take control of their sexuality, enjoy it and, as a result, undermine the macho phallocentricity that dominated it.

Laura Berman is aware of and likes the work of both these performers and appreciates what they have achieved. Now she is in the ironic position of helping to legitimise porn by providing erotica for women in a clinical/experimental setting, where the environment is official and formal rather than low-rent and sleazy. She is hampered somewhat, not only by the complexity of an individual's arousal (the female erotic imagination knows few limits), but by the paucity of suitable material.

'It does not matter to us what turns them on,' says Laura. 'Only whether they are conflicted by it. Who am I to tell a woman how to express herself? The only issue I have is that most men get their primary sex education from porn films which are geared to men and do not necessarily reflect what women want. So, unless he is with a woman who is able to educate him, he could be with 300 women and never know.'

In America, the Berman sisters are seen as representing the next stage of the feminist movement, a movement that has been somewhat stagnant of late, impeded as it is by dull old ideas that are unable to counteract the commercial power of regressive imagery. The battalion of Bridget Jones clones marches forward. They want to be married. They want to be thin. They do not want to think.

Detractors may observe that to emphasise female sexuality is to conform to male thinking - that is, a woman must have sex in order to be happy and there is something wrong with her if she does not. And it could easily be argued that our expectations are far, far too high. There are other things to do, after all - gardening, singing, art... History tells us that women who have avoided domestic ideals are the ones that have contributed the most to the currency of ideas.

Nevertheless, the ability to have an orgasm is fundamental. Laura Berman believes that sex can reduce stress, enhance mood and increase self-esteem.

'Sexuality is a central part of who we are,' she says. The physical reality is that the more sexually active a woman is, the better the blood flow to her genitals, which means less risk of vaginal atrophy. Then there is the sociological point that says in a time of high divorce rate (and its consequences) there is good reason to encourage happy sexual relations. Sex is cited again and again as a root cause of marital and relationship breakdowns; improve on these problems and you contribute to a healthier picture of society.

'There are medical, emotional and relational causes for sexual function complaints,' Laura continues. 'These can be attended to to help women have more fulfilling sex lives.'

The Bermans are coming to London this month to publicise their book. They are looking forward to it.

'Is there riding? asks Jennifer, perking up.

'You can go round and round a public park if you like,' I reply.

The interview is at an end. I leave them arguing about who has lost the vibrators.

'I thought you had them!'

'No, you have.'

'I'm sure they were with you.'

'No, they weren't...'

For women only: The Bermans on the history of sex

Why does the field of women's sexual health lag 30 years behind that of men? Why haven't women received the same attention? To understand the present we have to consider the past. Little is known about sexual behaviour in ancient times, but from the time of earliest recorded history, about 3,000BC, women were considered as property, valued only for reproduction. Adultery was not only a sin but a trespass against a husband. In ancient Greece, a woman was simply called 'gyne', which meant 'bearer of children'. While the Greeks viewed women as chattels and the Romans considered infertility as grounds for divorce, the Christian church after the fall of Rome went even further. The church fathers deemed sex unsavoury and women a threat to male salvation. Nothing, said St Augustine, brought 'the manly mind down from the heights more than a woman's caresses and that joining of bodies'. Procreation with such 'temptresses' was to be accomplished by passionless, purposeful intercourse.

Even as late as the 19th century, women were expected to embrace modesty, personify purity, and lack all sexual desire. The Victorian era transformed the middle-class housewife into no less than a guardian of the public morality. Her place was at home with her children, protecting the family's decency and social position. She endured sex with her husband for procreation, but if her husband was a decent soul he subjected her to his animal urges as infrequently as possible.

Many women readily accepted the view that they were without sexual needs. At the same time, 'hysteria' was apparently pandemic. If the disease was in fact chronic sexual frustration, as Rachel P Maines argues in her book The Technology of Orgasm , an entertaining but serious history of the vibrator, women sought relief through one of the more acceptable outlets: going to the doctor's for their orgasms. Maines writes that Western doctors performed the 'routine chore' of relieving hysterical patients' symptoms with manual genital massage until a woman reached orgasm, or, as it was known under clinical conditions, the 'hysterical paroxysm'. The vibrator, invented by a British physician in the 1880s, was a direct response to doctors who wanted help performing this procedure.

There is also evidence that not all19th-century middle-class women were as Victorian behind closed doors as in public. The cultural historian Peter Gay, for example, has quoted extensively in his work from the diary of Mabel Loomis Todd, a New Englander who revelled in the eroticism of her marriage to her husband. 'We retired at seven and had a magnificent evening,' Mabel Todd wrote in her diary in February 1882. 'I shall never forget it, so I'll not write about it.' The entry was followed by two symbols indicating the couple had intercourse twice that night.

But Mabel Todd was probably the exception. Most Victorian women repressed their sexuality to such a degree that most men and some women viewed prostitution as a necessary evil that allowed the male a natural outlet for his lust. By early in the next century Sigmund Freud was questioning almost every aspect of sex. His ideas were revolutionary and had an enormous impact on attitudes in that they promoted sexual desire. However, in a view which still permeates our culture, he also believed that clitoral orgasms were immature and that vaginal orgasms were 'authentic'.

Writing at the same time as Freud was Havelock Ellis, an English doctor who is less well known but who had a far more positive impact on women's attitudes to sex. Sometimes called the prophet of modern sexuality, he believed that women had strong erotic needs. He also believed that the emphasis on sex as a means of reproduction was a repressive influence on female sexuality. Freud, he once said, 'was an extravagant genius - the greatest figure in psychology who was almost always wrong.'

The 20th century saw radical research by the likes of Alfred Kinsey's Sexual Behaviour in the Human Male and Sexual Behaviour in the Human Female in which Americans were asked to talk frankly about masturbation, premarital sex, extramarital sex and homosexuality. If the findings from men shocked traditionalists - more than a third of adult men said they had had a homosexual experience, for instance - few Americans were ready to hear the news that women were as capable of orgasm as men.

Fifty years on the opposite seems to be true. Women have the pressure of being drawn into sex much earlier in a relationship, with expectations from men that they should be sexual adventurers, or at the very least multi-orgasmic. 'Placed on the defensive, they were rapidly losing the right to say no that 19th-century feminists had struggled to obtain,' write John D'Emilio and Estelle B Freedman in Intimate Matters: a History of Sexuality in America .

And yet we are optimistic. When Bob Dole discussed erectile dysfunction - his own, in particular - on television, men as well as women realised their sexual 'problems' were nothing to be ashamed of. Although we can't yet say that the field of women's sexual health is about to catch up with men's, we can say that women are increasingly deciding that they need the same treatment as men. And once women truly feel entitled to their sexuality, they'll feel entitled to anything.

Readers can order a copy of For Women Only by Jennifer and Laura Berman (£12.99, Virago Press, published 10 May) for £9.99 plus p&p. Freephone 0800 3168 171

As a teenager, Jennifer began to read Judy Blume, an American author specialising in novels for adolescents about the progress from childhood to sexuality, which described both masturbation and orgasm. Her father found Forever and ripped the book in half. Laura: 'He didn't do that for me!' Jennifer: 'He probably didn't know you were reading it.' Laura: 'He did! Mom knew I was reading it. I remember we were in the dentist's office and this mother got mad at her for letting me read it and she said, "As long as she reads, I don't care what she reads..."' Sex, in the Berman household, was discussed openly, but the overriding message was that they should avoid it if possible. Laura: 'From early on, there was the message that we should not be sexual until we were in the context of a healthy, loving relationship.' Jennifer: 'They did not encourage us to go out and sexually experiment at all.' Laura: 'There are two components - one is about feeling at ease with your sexuality and the other is acting on it by putting yourself at risk of pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases. These were very separate issues in our house, and I still think that in order to be sexually responsible you need to first feel good about yourself and your sexuality, and I think they are responsible for that.' It quickly became apparent that Jennifer was going to become the doctor; Laura could not stand the sight of blood, while Jennifer took to medicating her horse. Jennifer's research into subjects such as nitric oxide takes her to places that make her sister shudder - working on cadavers, for instance, in order to study the female genitalia. I ask her about her reaction to her first dead body. Jennifer: 'It was Uncle Ed. He was in an open casket.' Laura: 'The only thing I remember about Uncle Ed is the thumb wrestling.' Laura trained to be a sex therapist at the New York University Medical Centre. 'I was exposed to everything under the sun,' she says. 'I talked to peep-show workers and prostitutes. I went to gay bars and S&M meetings. I had to confront every value I had, question it, analyse it and understand it. I found working with sex offenders very hard. And some of the paraphilias. One woman had an antenna fetish, I remember. She was a radio-repair woman. My threshold for shock was a lot higher than some of my colleagues, but now I am never shocked.' She moved to Spain with her husband and worked as a sex therapist there until her marriage broke down, leaving her with no immediate prospects. Jennifer, meanwhile, had taken a job in Boston and invited her to work with her. They founded a clinic for women's sexual health in 1998, then moved to California last year. Now they run two clinics a week and see around 40 new patients a month. The average age is 45, but there have been 18- and 80-year-olds. The women come from all over America (and the world) and, though predominately heterosexual, they represent a diverse ethnic spectrum. The sisters have outlined the categories that define female sexual dysfunction in their book For Women Only. It falls into four parts. One of these is hypoactive sexual-desire disorder, the symptom of which is a basic lack of interest. The causes can be various - anti-depressants, for instance, are known to lower the libido. They may also be emotional in their base, or the physical result of menopause, which can cause dryness. Sexual-arousal disorder, meanwhile, is characterised by the physical inability to maintain lubrication, by decreased sensation and, sometimes, by diminished blood flow to the vagina or clitoris. Orgasmic disorder is the inability to reach climax despite stimulation. This can be caused by a number of things including trauma (such as sexual abuse or a physical accident), hormonal deficiency or damage incurred during pelvic surgery. Finally, sexual-pain disorder is intense discomfort experienced during penetrative sex. It may have its origins in emotional causes, in surgical procedures or, again, in the onset of menopause. Treatments vary and many of them are still in experimental stages. The Bermans have participated in clinical trials for Viagra and remain enthusiastic about its prospects, despite some disappointing statistics. They also believe that testosterone is important in governing libido and sexual response. Some women arrive with their partners; some do not. Who are they? They are Janet, 35, mother of two from Boston who, having been sexually abused by her brother at the age of seven, could only reach orgasm by self-stimulation. When it came to her husband (whom she loved) she shut down. Her husband was talking about divorce. 'Shutting down', say the Berman sisters, is a common 'survival' response. Viagra did not work for Janet. Therapy and anti-depressants did. Debra, 31, and her husband Scott, a couple from New York, had four children and were experiencing a common problem - unequal libidos. Debra was exhausted; Scott wanted sex. We all know the scenario. A lowering of the female libido is particularly common after the birth of a second child. Debra had put on weight and felt ashamed of her body. The Bermans encouraged Scott to stimulate his wife with a vibrator (she had never masturbated). They observed healthy pelvic blood flow, engorgement and lubrication. They tested her blood for lowered testosterone levels, a common cause of lowered libido. Testosterone can be prescribed as a solution, but some women avoid it, not wanting to take a hormone about which relatively little is known. Debra, however, was found to have normal levels. The Bermans suggested that the couple take time away from the children in order to focus on each other, and referred them to a therapist. They also prescribed a low-dose testosterone cream and Viagra. The couple began to make progress. Carla, 44, a mother of three, had under gone uterine-artery embolisation - a surgical procedure for the treatment of fibroids, during which plastic particles are injected into the uterine artery in order to block blood flow to the fibroids. The result was that having enjoyed satisfying orgasms, Carla had lost her ability to achieve a satisfying climax. The Bermans concluded that the surgery had affected the vaginal arteries and, consequently, the blood flow to her pelvis. They recommended aerobic exercise. Carla's condition improved. She is now executive director of the National Uterine Fibroid Foundation. The solutions are not always so simple. Ann and Charles were in their seventies. They had grown apart within their marriage, but Charles wanted to restore the intimacy that they had lost. Ann, post-menopausal, had lost interest in sex. She was also angry with her husband, who had engaged in a number of extra-marital affairs. She did not want to undergo a physical examination nor did she want to take hormones. Nor, however, did she wish to live alone. The Bermans told them that couple therapy would help them work through the anger that fulminated at the centre of the relationship; but the couple remained in limbo, unable to make a decision as to which direction to go. Change is frightening and, at 70, very difficult. The patient who presents herself to the Centre for Pelvic Medicine is a brave woman. She must be ready to discuss the most intimate details of her sex life with Laura, whose questions will be about everything from masturbation to the possibility of sexual abuse suffered in childhood. Then there is a range of tests conducted by Jennifer. Her equipment is designed to assess PH levels, vaginal elasticity, clitoral sensation and pelvic blood flow, but it looks as if it has been stolen from the set of Dead Ringers. The EROS CTD (clitoral therapy device) is a battery-operated vacuum designed to increase the blood flow to the clitoris by sucking on it with a 'CARess Cup'. The TSA 11 NeuroSensory Analyser was developed to research the effect of neurological disorders (such as multiple sclerosis) on the female genital organs. It is a black probe attached to various wires and clamps, described by the manufacturers as an 'intra-vaginal vibratory insertion unit'. Jennifer admits that, yes, they do make women nervous, but then the women are also keen to find the root of their problems. The 3D 'surround-around' video glasses are more fun in a sci-fi kind of way. They are fitted with an erotic video, the patient self-stimulates with a vibrator, and the post-orgasmic effects are assessed by a vaginal probe and ultrasound, in order to compare them against the data gathered in the initial tests. This brings us, not unnaturally, to the subject of pornography. In many ways, the Berman sisters are the logical follow-up to the thinking initiated by women such as Annie Sprinkle and Nina Hartley 10 years ago. Sprinkle, a New York performance artist, gave shows in which members of the audience were encouraged to look at her cervix with the aid of a torch and a speculum. Hartley, a porn star, made 'instructional' videos. Both represented the pro-porn feminist idea that it was important for women to take control of their sexuality, enjoy it and, as a result, undermine the macho phallocentricity that dominated it. Laura Berman is aware of and likes the work of both these performers and appreciates what they have achieved. Now she is in the ironic position of helping to legitimise porn by providing erotica for women in a clinical/experimental setting, where the environment is official and formal rather than low-rent and sleazy. She is hampered somewhat, not only by the complexity of an individual's arousal (the female erotic imagination knows few limits), but by the paucity of suitable material. 'It does not matter to us what turns them on,' says Laura. 'Only whether they are conflicted by it. Who am I to tell a woman how to express herself? The only issue I have is that most men get their primary sex education from porn films which are geared to men and do not necessarily reflect what women want. So, unless he is with a woman who is able to educate him, he could be with 300 women and never know.' In America, the Berman sisters are seen as representing the next stage of the feminist movement, a movement that has been somewhat stagnant of late, impeded as it is by dull old ideas that are unable to counteract the commercial power of regressive imagery. The battalion of Bridget Jones clones marches forward. They want to be married. They want to be thin. They do not want to think. Detractors may observe that to emphasise female sexuality is to conform to male thinking - that is, a woman must have sex in order to be happy and there is something wrong with her if she does not. And it could easily be argued that our expectations are far, far too high. There are other things to do, after all - gardening, singing, art... History tells us that women who have avoided domestic ideals are the ones that have contributed the most to the currency of ideas. Nevertheless, the ability to have an orgasm is fundamental. Laura Berman believes that sex can reduce stress, enhance mood and increase self-esteem. 'Sexuality is a central part of who we are,' she says. The physical reality is that the more sexually active a woman is, the better the blood flow to her genitals, which means less risk of vaginal atrophy. Then there is the sociological point that says in a time of high divorce rate (and its consequences) there is good reason to encourage happy sexual relations. Sex is cited again and again as a root cause of marital and relationship breakdowns; improve on these problems and you contribute to a healthier picture of society. 'There are medical, emotional and relational causes for sexual function complaints,' Laura continues. 'These can be attended to to help women have more fulfilling sex lives.' The Bermans are coming to London this month to publicise their book. They are looking forward to it. 'Is there riding? asks Jennifer, perking up. 'You can go round and round a public park if you like,' I reply. The interview is at an end. I leave them arguing about who has lost the vibrators. 'I thought you had them!' 'No, you have.' 'I'm sure they were with you.' 'No, they weren't...' For women only: The Bermans on the history of sex Why does the field of women's sexual health lag 30 years behind that of men? Why haven't women received the same attention? To understand the present we have to consider the past. Little is known about sexual behaviour in ancient times, but from the time of earliest recorded history, about 3,000BC, women were considered as property, valued only for reproduction. Adultery was not only a sin but a trespass against a husband. In ancient Greece, a woman was simply called 'gyne', which meant 'bearer of children'. While the Greeks viewed women as chattels and the Romans considered infertility as grounds for divorce, the Christian church after the fall of Rome went even further. The church fathers deemed sex unsavoury and women a threat to male salvation. Nothing, said St Augustine, brought 'the manly mind down from the heights more than a woman's caresses and that joining of bodies'. Procreation with such 'temptresses' was to be accomplished by passionless, purposeful intercourse. Even as late as the 19th century, women were expected to embrace modesty, personify purity, and lack all sexual desire. The Victorian era transformed the middle-class housewife into no less than a guardian of the public morality. Her place was at home with her children, protecting the family's decency and social position. She endured sex with her husband for procreation, but if her husband was a decent soul he subjected her to his animal urges as infrequently as possible. Many women readily accepted the view that they were without sexual needs. At the same time, 'hysteria' was apparently pandemic. If the disease was in fact chronic sexual frustration, as Rachel P Maines argues in her book The Technology of Orgasm , an entertaining but serious history of the vibrator, women sought relief through one of the more acceptable outlets: going to the doctor's for their orgasms. Maines writes that Western doctors performed the 'routine chore' of relieving hysterical patients' symptoms with manual genital massage until a woman reached orgasm, or, as it was known under clinical conditions, the 'hysterical paroxysm'. The vibrator, invented by a British physician in the 1880s, was a direct response to doctors who wanted help performing this procedure. There is also evidence that not all19th-century middle-class women were as Victorian behind closed doors as in public. The cultural historian Peter Gay, for example, has quoted extensively in his work from the diary of Mabel Loomis Todd, a New Englander who revelled in the eroticism of her marriage to her husband. 'We retired at seven and had a magnificent evening,' Mabel Todd wrote in her diary in February 1882. 'I shall never forget it, so I'll not write about it.' The entry was followed by two symbols indicating the couple had intercourse twice that night. But Mabel Todd was probably the exception. Most Victorian women repressed their sexuality to such a degree that most men and some women viewed prostitution as a necessary evil that allowed the male a natural outlet for his lust. By early in the next century Sigmund Freud was questioning almost every aspect of sex. His ideas were revolutionary and had an enormous impact on attitudes in that they promoted sexual desire. However, in a view which still permeates our culture, he also believed that clitoral orgasms were immature and that vaginal orgasms were 'authentic'. Writing at the same time as Freud was Havelock Ellis, an English doctor who is less well known but who had a far more positive impact on women's attitudes to sex. Sometimes called the prophet of modern sexuality, he believed that women had strong erotic needs. He also believed that the emphasis on sex as a means of reproduction was a repressive influence on female sexuality. Freud, he once said, 'was an extravagant genius - the greatest figure in psychology who was almost always wrong.' The 20th century saw radical research by the likes of Alfred Kinsey's Sexual Behaviour in the Human Male and Sexual Behaviour in the Human Female in which Americans were asked to talk frankly about masturbation, premarital sex, extramarital sex and homosexuality. If the findings from men shocked traditionalists - more than a third of adult men said they had had a homosexual experience, for instance - few Americans were ready to hear the news that women were as capable of orgasm as men. Fifty years on the opposite seems to be true. Women have the pressure of being drawn into sex much earlier in a relationship, with expectations from men that they should be sexual adventurers, or at the very least multi-orgasmic. 'Placed on the defensive, they were rapidly losing the right to say no that 19th-century feminists had struggled to obtain,' write John D'Emilio and Estelle B Freedman in Intimate Matters: a History of Sexuality in America . And yet we are optimistic. When Bob Dole discussed erectile dysfunction - his own, in particular - on television, men as well as women realised their sexual 'problems' were nothing to be ashamed of. Although we can't yet say that the field of women's sexual health is about to catch up with men's, we can say that women are increasingly deciding that they need the same treatment as men. And once women truly feel entitled to their sexuality, they'll feel entitled to anything. Readers can order a copy of For Women Only by Jennifer and Laura Berman (£12.99, Virago Press, published 10 May) for £9.99 plus p&p. Freephone 0800 3168 171

webTitle: Plague on both their houses

fields.headline: Plague on both their houses
fields.standfirst: Nick Mathiason  on the events that brought mighty Christie's and Sotheby's to their knees
fields.trailText: Nick Mathiason on the events that brought mighty Christie's and Sotheby's to their knees
fields.body:
In New York, they're calling it a conspiracy by millionaires against millionaires. In London, art world insiders say betrayal, revenge and desperation have brought the world's two most powerful auction houses to their knees.

A crisis is engulfing Sotheby's and Christie's that threatens to turn the art world on its head. Having agreed to pay out £400 million in compensation to art dealers, private buyers and shareholders last year, the future of two of the most famous names in the art world is uncertain. Potential buyers are circling and hasty plans have been implemented by the two firms to slash costs.

If found guilty, the former chairmen of the once-respected businesses could face prison sentences and fines running into millions.

And why? In the dark, recession-hit world of the early 1990s, when auction house sales proceeds more than halved, the US Department of Justice maintains the two firms colluded on raising commission rates, which they took from both buyers and sellers in a desperate bid to salvage profits. It is just what America's 111-year-old Sherman Anti-Trust Act was designed to prevent.

Events seem to indicate collusion. In November 1992, Sotheby's raised its buyer's commission from 10 to 15 per cent. A month later, Christie's followed. In March 1995, Christie's increased its seller's fees from a flat rate to a sliding scale of between 2 to 20 per cent. A month later, Sotheby's did the same.

Two former chief executives of the historic firms have already pleaded guilty to the charges, leaving their chairmen to take the hit.

Christopher Davidge, the London-born former chief executive of Christie's, handed over a 500-page document to US investigators just before Christmas 1999 confirming to them what they had long suspected but could never prove: that leading executives from the two houses met to fix and agree commission rates.

Davidge, having won immunity for himself, promptly resigned and 'went on a world tour', according to a friend. His former employer, Christie's, now under the ownership of French billionaire Francois Pinault, won a similar deal on the basis that it would co-operate with the DoJ.

His counterpart at Sotheby's, Diana 'Dede' Brooks, a 'ball-breaking' New York socialite, last October also admitted the charges. Brooks, who was unpopular in London for 'running Bond Street like it was a subsidiary of New York,' said she fixed commissions with her rival at the behest of her boss, Sotheby's former chairman, Alfred Taubman, aged 76.

Last week, the US Anti-Trust division of the DoJ finally indicted the then two chairmen, Sotheby's Taubman, and Christie's Sir Anthony Tennant, an Old Etonian. Court hearings will begin later this year.

Taubman maintains his innocence; Sir Anthony, 71, has refused to stand trial. He is a British citizen and not only does he maintain his innocence but he refuses to cross the Atlantic, knowing he cannot be extradited.

In much of the art world, there is glee at how the mighty are fallen. 'They had it coming to them,' said one Mayfair art dealer. 'They had this paranoia that only exists in a duopoly. It led them to compete in the most ridiculous ways and spend far too much on overheads.'

Overheads is a euphemism for the huge amounts of cash Sotheby's and Christie's spent on lavish entertainment as they sought to squeeze art dealers by prising private buyers from them.

Dealers maintain it was the aggressively commercial tactics employed by Taubman, a billionaire US real estate developer, and Davidge that proved their companies' downfall.

This downfall has huge ramifications starting this week when, in New York, Sotheby's and Christie's will auction a couple of Monet paintings and a famous Picasso portrait for £50m in what is traditionally the most lucrative season in the impressionist, modern and contemporary art calendar - the spring sales.

But in the Big Apple art dealers are expecting the sales to lack the normal pizzazz. Never mind the economic slowdown, the list of fine art up for sale is smaller than usual. Dealers seem to have lost faith in the houses. And this means Phillips, the third force in art auctions and owned by French luxury brand tycoon Bernard Arnault, could begin to make up lost ground.

Insiders believe that both houses are available at the right price. Sotheby's Taubman still has a controlling stake, for sale through Credit Suisse. The favourite prospective buyer was Arnault's LVMH. But this weekend, a spokesman for the group confirmed to The Observer that the world's most powerful luxury brand group will not be bidding. Officially, Christie's is not for sale. But Pinault faces a potentially ruinous legal tussle against insurance regulators in California for alleged fraud that could see him paying £700m. Christie's may be sacrificed if that case goes against him. Pinault denies all charges.

Whatever happens, Sotheby's and Christie's are both selling their London homes. Christie's could make more than £80m from its Mayfair site; The Observer has learnt that Sotheby's has instructed Knight Frank to sell its Bond Street showrooms.

Combined, these two businesses sell fine art, jewellery, antique furniture and collectables worth more than £2bn and accounting for 90 per cent of the market. There are now calls for the top-end auctioneers to be regulated so this débcle never happens again.

'Breath of air' whistleblower

The life of Christopher Davidge is like a parody of a Jilly Cooper novel.

A working-class boy born in a cramped west London council flat, he saw two generations of his family work in poorly paid jobs at Christie's. Eventually he became the boss of the entire outfit, rescuing it from the shadow of arch-rival Sotheby's. Then he shopped both firms to US investigators.

Davidge, 55, is now believed to be in India - his £7 million severance payoff from Christie's safe. The reputations of the world's two biggest auction houses could, however, prove unrecoverable.

In 1904, Davidge's grandfather Wilfred joined the firm as a porter, aged 12. He worked for Christie's for 40 years, yet his widow received a pension of just 35 shillings per week. A condition was that her son went to work for Christie's.

To add further fuel for resentment, Davidge's father saw his wages halved when he returned from the second world war. Rather than work for such an employer, Davidge junior sold shirts in London's Petticoat Lane market - earning more in a day than his father did in a week. But in the mid-Sixties he was asked to return to the fold 'for a few months'. Within 10 years he ran the print division, and in 1993 he became chief executive.

Railing against the company's 'inept' public-school ethos, his business skills were a breath of fresh air.

But the beginning of the end came in 1998, when French tycoon Francois Pinault bought Christie's for £770m. The pair never hit it off.

Davidge gained immunity from prosecution after handing 500 pages of documents to the Department of Justice. But his precise motives remain unclear.

Some say Pinault 'rumbled' him, others that he felt his redundancy package was too mean - that, in his own way, he was being treated like his father and grandfather.

webTitle: Loafer's Guide: Helmut Newton

fields.headline: Loafer's Guide
fields.standfirst: Helmut Newton
fields.trailText: Helmut Newton
fields.body:
Helmut, eh? Sounds a bit saucy Less of the Mind Your Language-esque schoolboy sniggering, please. Now, would you like to see some really dirty pictures?

Not half! Then don't hightail it to the Barbican. Yes, they're mounting (phnaar phnaar) Work, a show of 200 of Helmut's glossed-out pics of trademarked oiled-up-models-as-predatory-dominatrixes and celebs-as-sexed-up-decadents to mark the old rascal's 80th birthday. It's S&M lite without the M&S knicks - quite a lot of Helm's subjects seem bereft in the underwear department - taken from the pages of Vogue and Harper's (where he started working in the 70s), and the torrid depths of Helm's imagination. But while they hint at more kink than you'll find in the average Afro, Helm's hugely influential fashion stills and vanity portraits are inspired as much by surrealism and photojournalism as top-shelf money shots, 'reflecting the obsessions of human vanity from female exhibitionism to male voyeurism at the highest aesthetic level,' according to the Barbican. JG Ballard, author of Crash and thus no slouch in the art/porn debate, describes Helm as 'one of the greatest visual artists alive today'. Thus: Not Smut. OK?

I'd like to hear old Helmut explain that one And you can. He'll be dropping in at the Barbican for a Q&A session and a chat with Alexander McQueen (another naughty boy who likes to push those pervy envelopes) this Thursday, 10 May, from 1-2pm.

What if I'm so taken with the show that I want to 'relax' (hem hem) with some Helmut at home? Then you're in luck again; happy Helm is the subject of The World's Biggest Book. Sumo , published by Benedikt Taschen Verlag last year, is 3ft high and 1ft wide, weighs in at 66lb and comes with a special trestle-type stand designed by Philippe Starck. Oh, and it costs £1,650.

But I'll have a hernia trying to get that erected! Phnaar phnaar. And it's only fitting: as Helm would undoubtedly say, it's all about exploring that oh-so-thin line between pleasure and pain.

Yes, they're mounting (phnaar phnaar) Work, a show of 200 of Helmut's glossed-out pics of trademarked oiled-up-models-as-predatory-dominatrixes and celebs-as-sexed-up-decadents to mark the old rascal's 80th birthday. It's S&M lite without the M&S knicks - quite a lot of Helm's subjects seem bereft in the underwear department - taken from the pages of Vogue and Harper's (where he started working in the 70s), and the torrid depths of Helm's imagination. But while they hint at more kink than you'll find in the average Afro, Helm's hugely influential fashion stills and vanity portraits are inspired as much by surrealism and photojournalism as top-shelf money shots, 'reflecting the obsessions of human vanity from female exhibitionism to male voyeurism at the highest aesthetic level,' according to the Barbican. JG Ballard, author of Crash and thus no slouch in the art/porn debate, describes Helm as 'one of the greatest visual artists alive today'. Thus: Not Smut. OK? I'd like to hear old Helmut explain that one And you can. He'll be dropping in at the Barbican for a Q&A session and a chat with Alexander McQueen (another naughty boy who likes to push those pervy envelopes) this Thursday, 10 May, from 1-2pm. What if I'm so taken with the show that I want to 'relax' (hem hem) with some Helmut at home? Then you're in luck again; happy Helm is the subject of The World's Biggest Book. Sumo , published by Benedikt Taschen Verlag last year, is 3ft high and 1ft wide, weighs in at 66lb and comes with a special trestle-type stand designed by Philippe Starck. Oh, and it costs £1,650. But I'll have a hernia trying to get that erected! Phnaar phnaar. And it's only fitting: as Helm would undoubtedly say, it's all about exploring that oh-so-thin line between pleasure and pain.

webTitle: With the boundless energy of a convert

fields.headline: With the boundless energy of a convert
fields.standfirst: No more the left-wing firebrand, Peter Hain is now preaching competition at the DTI, writes  Oliver Morgan
fields.trailText: No more the left-wing firebrand, Peter Hain is now preaching competition at the DTI, writes Oliver Morgan
fields.body:
Victoria Street, London, W1 - also known as New Labour's road to Damascus. At the Westminster end of this thoroughfare stands the Department of Trade and Industry's steel and glass headquarters, a building witness to some of the most striking of Labour's political conversions.

Here we have consumer affairs minister Kim Howells, battling daily to smash cartels and ensure consumers are protected by a fully functioning open market. Howells was, of course, a lefty firebrand who spent the Eighties mixing it with the miners in Wales against Thatcherite market reforms.

Here is Alan Johnson, minister in charge of the (commercialised) Post Office, now called Consignia. Johnson was the brains behind the defeat of Conservative plans to make the organisation more - well - commercial.

And, recently arrived, here is Peter Hain, formerly of the Labour left and CND, now minister for energy and competitiveness in Europe, among the most dapper of Tony Blair's lieutenants, and among the most eager to preach the importance of business and competition. So is Hain a true convert?.

When he was appointed in January, not everyone was convinced. One minute Hain was swanning around the world as a junior minister in the Foreign Office; the next he was thinking about new electricity trading arrangements (Neta) and the escalating price of gas. MPs still whisper that Hain is less than chuffed.

But, for the record, he's having none of that. Hain clearly believes he has an important role to play, converting what has often been a technical and sensitive job (dealing with the decline of coal mining, for example) into one where political points can be scored.

'He [Blair] said to me "I want you back in domestic politics, and there are four or five issues that are proving really troublesome",' he says.

'I have always thought that industry and economics was what made the world tick,' continues the former anti-Apartheid radical. 'Although it matters to UK plc whether I form good relations with Malawi, it is certainly important to the economy and to domestic politics whether we get Neta right.'

He is keen to promote controversial areas of policy - taking on oil and gas giants for example - in order to gain credit for dealing with them. And his frequent references to 'his master' suggest that if he isn't taking his lead from Number 10, he wants to be seen to be doing so.

Top of the list is the wholesale price of gas, which rose from 12p a therm in 1999 to a 27p peak a year later, falling back to a current 24p, causing great difficulties for big industrial, commercial and even domestic users.

Officials at the DTI are unsure of the exact reasons, which is why the European Commission is currently investigating.

The Commission is focusing on the gas interconnector between the UK and Europe, which has effectively sucked lower-price UK gas through to Europe where prices are higher, and sucked European prices back to the UK.

EC and UK officials suspect that access to the interconnector may not be as open as it should be. It is owned by some of the larger oil and gas operators and there is suspicion of manipulation.

On top of this, there is concern that some North Sea operators may be manipulating the supply of gas that is fed into the UK.

Hain is not convinced that the big players are playing fair. 'I have asked them to do their best to make sure there are no anti-competitive practices going on. I am not satisfied that, for at least a proportion of the market, that is not happening,' he says.

He believes more transparency is needed, so it is clear how much gas is available, where it is, where it is shipped to, and when it goes into the UK system. Regulator Ofgem is reviewing some of these issues.

However, he adds that, notwithstanding the EC investigation, 'I would not rule out some other action being taken to the Office [of Fair Trading].'

Hain's enthusiasm to see markets working properly has a similar political and opportunistic feel to his colleague Kim Howells' 'rip-off Britain' campaign. In this case ensuring that lower wholesale gas prices help not only companies such as paper millers, and glass and cement manufacturers, but domestic customers, particularly those of independent gas suppliers, who have seen bills rise by up to 6 per cent.

Hain believes Neta, which replaces the discredited wholesale electricity pool, will deliver lower electricity bills to customers by matching demand more accurately with supply, and will also help correct swings in wholesale energy prices. Hain is also keen to step back from Neta, and to look strategically at the UK's energy needs.

The political top line after Tony Blair's recent environmental speeches is to talk up renewable energy. 'I want to be seen as the champion of the renewables sector. I don't think we have been doing enough as a Government on it.'

Hain ensured the Government received credit for the 18 offshore wind farms, designed to deliver 1000MW of power, announced last month. He says he wants to see renewable energy going well above the 10 per cent of UK generation that has been set as a target by 2010.

He points to new technologies such as offshore wind, energy from waste, and to £250m earmarked by the Government to make it happen. Last week he announced £3m for solar housing projects and urged power giants to encourage the uptake of solar power. And, ever in search of the politically painless way out, he cites this target to blunt the impact of the lobbying campaign by the nuclear industry to build new nuclear power stations.

Hain says the future of Britain's energy supply is likely to be the subject of a wholesale review after the election, if Labour wins it. He is sceptical about new nuclear stations. 'I would be very surprised if there was an application [to build], because the economics are not there,' he says.

'What I don't want is an energy policy that becomes only gas and nuclear. I am very interested in what renewable can do if they reach the target.'

One industrialist said of another Labour DTI alumnus, Peter Mandelson, that he was a moderniser and pro-market - apart from a blind spot with coal mining: thus the 1998 energy review, which froze the building of gas power stations and secured a place for coal. Ironically, it is not because of a Government ban that serried ranks of gas power stations are not now being built, but because of the gas market, which has forced up the price to the point where coal has become competitive again and the returns from a dash for gas do not seem so guaranteed.

This must please Hain, MP for Neath, and a man committed to miners past - now claiming compensation for industrial injuries - and present in the same way as the MP for Hartlepool. He says: 'I don't see a future energy policy in the UK without an element of coal.' He believes clean coal technology is vital for the future.

For the moment there seems to be little danger of a coal-free future - against the background of rising gas and oil prices, coal burn increased last year.

However, if Hain is too successful in his campaign to sort out the gas market, the danger to coal could return. But he's a politician. He'll find an explanation - if he's not in the Cabinet by then.

webTitle: Gas giants face competition probe

fields.headline: Gas giants face competition probe
fields.trailText: Energy minister Peter Hain is threatening oil and gas giants with investigation by the Office of Fair Trading into anti-competitive activities in the North Sea.
fields.body:
Energy minister Peter Hain is threatening oil and gas giants with investigation by the Office of Fair Trading into anti-competitive activities in the North Sea.

An investigation would focus on some of the world's biggest energy players and could include names such as BP, Conoco, BG International, Amerada Hess, Gaz de France and International Power.

Hain is concerned about the doubling of gas prices in 18 months, which have seen spot rates rise from around 12p a therm to around 24p now, hitting heavy users and domestic consumers alike.

The increase in UK levels has been blamed on a rise in European prices and the operation of an interconnector between East Anglia and Belgium that allows UK shippers to export UK gas and benefit from higher prices. The link with the Continent has also imported higher prices into the UK.

The European Commission began an investigation into the interconnector in February at the Department of Trade and Industry's request, but Hain says a UK investigation could follow.

Hain said: 'The wholesale gas price increase is causing enormous difficulties for high energy users. I have asked them [oil and gas companies] to do their best to make sure there are no anti-competitive practices going on.

'I am not satisfied that, for at least a proportion of the market, that is not happening. I would not rule out some other action being taken to the Office [of fair trading].'

Hain's view has the backing of officials in the DTI. One said: 'We felt there was enough anecdotal evidence of prices not changing in the market. That was the basis on which we went to the commission. There is still scope for an investigation here.'

The EC investigation has taken evidence from the gas 'shippers' that pump gas into the UK and Europe, who use, and some of whom own, the interconnector. Evidence has been supplied by some 16 UK, French, Dutch German, Italian and Belgian operators.

Concerns about the interconnector include the lack of information about its operation, the speed with which the gas flow can be reversed to match demand at either end, and the ability of all operators to access it.

webTitle: Make or break for football's cable guy

fields.headline: Make or break for football's cable guy
fields.standfirst: Crunch time has come for media giant NTL, says  Jamie Doward . It owes £9bn - and sacking staff is only a start
fields.trailText: Crunch time has come for media giant NTL, says Jamie Doward . It owes £9bn - and sacking staff is only a start
fields.body:
Media wags suggest that Barclay Knapp, the boss of cable company NTL, has given the world a new word. Since his keynote address to last year's Edinburgh TV Festival, when several members of the audience (including Channel 5 supremo Dawn Airey) fell asleep, those looking to sneak off for a kip now talk of 'going for a Barclay'.

The enervating effect of Knapp's speech to medialand's great and the good was perhaps understandable. For years the cable industry has been promising it will come of age, only to disappoint time and again.

But it is now put up or shut up time for the cable guys, not least NTL, which in the past 18 months has gobbled up 11 companies in an attempt to become one of Europe's largest 'complete communications companies'.

There have already been several high profile setbacks this year for the Delaware-based firm, whose shares are listed in New York but whose main operations are in the UK. First, there was the troubled roll-out of digital cable services in Ireland, which led to suggestions that NTL might sell the division. A £300 million rebuilding programme was dropped in favour of a commitment to improving the network. This fol lowed news that NTL had scrapped its £327m deal with the Premier League to show football matches on a pay-per-view basis. NTL's bean counters pulled the deal on the grounds that the company had overpaid.

With debts of about £9 billion, predicted to rise to £12.5bn by 2004, NTL, which is valued at around £10bn, cannot afford to be profligate. A taciturn Knapp shrugs off the debt-laden company tag. 'We're comfortable with those figures,' is all he will say.

Maybe, but last year the company lost nearly £1.9bn. Interest payments alone totalled more than £300m. Earnings - excluding all those annoying but important things that profit-making companies include in their books such as interest payments, tax, depreciation and amortisation - came to around £186m.

With such a low level of interest cover, it is hardly surprising that NTL has been forced to seek new cash lifelines. In January it raised about £125m through a bond issue and last month it secured a £270m loan from US investment giant GE Capital. Analysts at HSBC suggested that without the GE Capital bail-out NTL would have faced a cash crisis within two months.

Knapp says it now has enough cash and credit facilities in place to see it through to November next year. He points out that its capital expenditure is due to fall from a peak of £1.9bn last year to £1bn next year as it completes the building of its new digital network.

It has already told 2,300 staff that they will lose their jobs; further redundancies are expected.

Paring costs is one thing. NTL, which Knapp says will grow margins from 11 per cent now to 26 per cent by 2002, must dramatically start raising earnings streams if is to hit his goal of becoming 'cash flow positive by the end of 2003 or the start of 2004'.

Knapp concedes more cash injections will have to be found to achieve this. 'We will need somewhere between £200m and £400m towards the end of 2002.' Much depends on whether the company can keep its burn rate down to around £80m a month, a figure industry pundits believe could be difficult for a company looking to integrate its systems and acquire new customers.

NTL is now placing heavy emphasis on the bundling of its products - signing up consumers to its digital TV deal and then packaging this with telephony and broadband interactive services - which offer the likes of dial-up multi-choice video on demand - so that it can create a raft of earnings streams. Further offerings to complete the package are likely. 'We're going to have a mobile product which we hope to launch later this year,' says Knapp.

The focus is now very much on being a distributor, rather than a content owner - a markedly different position from the original plan to operate in both markets. 'If we're going to achieve our objective of connecting every household to our service we're not going to be able to invent all the content. We're focused on getting broadband access out there and letting the world decide what it wants to put there,' says Knapp.

Broadband, NTL believes, is its unique selling point. With the roll out of broadband over conventional telephone lines facing serious delays, it believes its 80,000-mile internet backbone is well placed to suck customers away from the likes of BT. NTL also argues that in the UK it scores points over satellite broadcasters like BSkyB, which cannot offer true broadband interactivity.

The City seems receptive to this argument. 'In a convergent, broadband world, where digital television, internet access and telephony services are delivered over a single pipe, we believe NTL has a prime opportunity to become the new incumbent telco in its franchise areas,' analysts at JP Morgan wrote recently.

But the media world jury is still out. 'On paper it's a very special breed, but it's not been able to get to the first fence so far,' said one industry observer.

So far the company has signed up 700,000 homes to its digital service, while 25,000 or so customers have signed up for NTL's broadband offering. The aim is to have 1.25 million digital subscribers and 100,000 broadband customers by the end of the year. Knapp says NTL will hit both these targets.

NTL could point out that its consumer offering is only one string to its bow. It also has a business division - which last year had revenues of more than £500m and a broadcast arm, which carries most of the UK's radio and TV signals. Analysts predict healthy growth for both.

But it is the consumer arm which NTL believes will be its biggest money spinner. The company is looking to take content from AOL Time Warner and Knapp hints that other links are on the cards. 'We're a gateway. We're talking to all the media companies about getting their content onto our network.'

But NTL knows it has a long way to go to catch BSkyB which has more than 5 million digital subscribers. Even troubled ONdigital - newly renamed ITV Digital - has more than 1 million. Some argue the solution could be a link up between NTL and the Continent's largest cable operator, Liberty Media, which would give the combined business a pan-European presence. Of the 4.7 million European subscribers who take NTL in some form, 3.7 million are in the UK. Then there is the oft-mooted suggestion that NTL should merge with UK rival Telewest, an argument Knapp attempts to parry. 'It's the never ending story. It always looks good on paper.'

Alternatively, NTL could sell off its minority stakes in France, Germany and Sweden and focus on the UK. But this is anathema to Knapp: 'Our entire European portfolio is core to our business plan. We set out to build a presence in Europe so we could leverage our experience in the UK. Whether or not we have a majority stake isn't the issue.'

Knapp accepts that it is now make or break time. The cable industry and NTL in particular has an appalling reputation for looking after customers. 'This year we're in a much better state than last. We've sorted out a lot of problems and we're ready to move forward.'

No time for a Barclay, then.

We set out to build a presence in Europe so we could leverage our experience in the UK. Whether or not we have a majority stake isn't the issue.' Knapp accepts that it is now make or break time. The cable industry and NTL in particular has an appalling reputation for looking after customers. 'This year we're in a much better state than last. We've sorted out a lot of problems and we're ready to move forward.' No time for a Barclay, then.

webTitle: Banks hit by meltdown in hi-tech deals

fields.headline: Banks hit by meltdown in hi-tech deals
fields.trailText: The meltdown in the technology sector led to a devastating slump in investment banking activity in the first quarter of this year. The value of merger and acquisitions in the European technology, media and telecoms sector totalled $20.7 billion, compared with nearly $69bn in the same quarter of 2000.
fields.body:
The meltdown in the technology sector led to a devastating slump in investment banking activity in the first quarter of this year. The value of merger and acquisitions in the European technology, media and telecoms sector totalled $20.7 billion, compared with nearly $69bn in the same quarter of 2000.

There were only 339 deals - down from 663 - according to new figures from Broadview, the investment house which focuses on the TMT sector. Their average value fell from $235 million to $135m.

'A lot of companies that were active in 1999 and 2000 are no longer doing anything,' said Victor Basta, Broadview's co-president.

The sector was chiefly responsible for generating a surge in investment bank revenues over the last two years. Soaring values meant new economy companies could use their shares to fund deals which earned lucrative com missions for the big banks.

Basta said the first quarter of last year was a 'high-water mark'. Normally around 450 deals are carried out in the sector in an average quarter.

Further gloom comes with the publication of new figures showing a huge rise in the number of hi-tech companies going into liquidation. A report by accountant PricewaterhouseCoopers shows that these insolvencies rose by 38 per cent in the last three months of 2000, compared with the previous quarter. Overall company insolvencies were up by only 6.7 per cent over the same period.

PwC said the rise for TMT firms reflected a tightening US market and problems with raising capital.

Neville Kahn of PwC warned that the sector's problems were 'gathering pace as overseas investor confidence wanes, over-supply continues and US market conditions become increasingly difficult'.
