webTitle: BT sell-offs pave way for cash call

fields.headline: BT sell-offs pave way for cash call
fields.standfirst: Scale of rights issue now likely to drop to £5bn
fields.trailText: Scale of rights issue now likely to drop to £5bn
fields.body:
BT is to increase its efforts to find buyers for its remaining Asian mobile phone divisions and is now also looking to sell off wireless operations in Canada and New Zealand to raise a further £1 billion to help it pare down debts.

The moves come as the cash-strapped telecom giant prepares to launch a £5bn rights issue.

BT is talking to a number of parties interested in its 20 per cent stake in Smartone, the Hong Kong mobile operator. SingTel of Singapore is thought to be among the frontrunners for BT's stake, having approached the UK firm several months ago. BT is also looking to offload its minority stakes in South Korea's LG Telecom, India's Bharti Cellular, and Starhub of Singapore.

BT also wants to sell Clear Communications, the New Zealand mobile phone operator it owns outright, as well as its 17 per cent stake in Canadian wireless firm Rogers Cantel, which analysts recently valued at around £500 million.

Analysts have speculated that a complete disposal of BT's non-European mobile operations could net the firm up to £1bn, although current market conditions mean a quick sale could see the company receive significantly less.

However, BT will have been cheered by last week's sale of its stake in Japan Telecom, J-Phone, and Spain's Airtel, which netted £4.8bn. Last Friday the company offloaded its stake in Maxis, the Malaysian mobile phone operator, for £350m.

BT is also hoping to raise up to £3bn from the sale of its directories division, Yell, to a consortium led by venture capital firm Apax Partners.

Further deals, to outsource its property division and its van fleet could earn BT up to £3bn more.

If BT completes the dispos als programme it will be on course to meet its debt reduction targets, cutting the amount it needs to raise in a rights issue. In recent weeks speculation has intensified that BT would be forced to ask investors to stump up £10bn.

BT sources now say the pressure is off. While the sources concede a rights issue is still part of BT's plan, the company will now look to raise only around £5bn. The City rumour mill suggests an announcement on the issue could come as early as this Tuesday.

Cutting its debt mountain to size would be good news for BT's chief executive, Sir Peter Bonfield. The BT boss has been widely tipped for the chop following the resignation of the company's chairman, Sir Iain Vallance, last month.

Some in the City speculate that BT's recent flurry of activity may now be enough to prevent the axe falling on Bonfield.

webTitle: Car buyers shun British marques

fields.headline: Car buyers shun British marques
fields.trailText: Leading British car marques are suffering a severe sales slump. Overall sales are rising but motorists prefer to buy imports.
fields.body:
Leading British car marques are suffering a severe sales slump. Overall sales are rising but motorists prefer to buy imports.

Rolls-Royce, Lotus and MG Rover experienced plummeting sales in the first four months of this year compared with the same period in 2000, according to new figures from the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders.

Sales of the famous Norfolk-built Lotus sports cars plunged by 64 per cent. MG Rover, the only one of the three that is actually British-owned, saw sales fall by almost a third to under 50,000. And sales of Rolls-Royces fell by almost half to just 19 cars, little more than one a week.

Yet overall new car sales in the UK were up 3 per cent in the first four months of the year and last month they leapt by 7 per cent to 180,000. A record 77.3 per cent of April sales were imported cars.

Industry sources believed Malaysian-owned Lotus's problems were not caused by a lack of popularity of its sports cars, but by problems at the factory. Lotus is busy producing a sports car for Vauxhall and failed to build enough of its own Elise models to keep up with demand, one source said.

Rolls-Royce is suffering since being bought by the Germans two years ago. Volkswagen owns the sister Bentley marque and is enjoying soaring sales - up 130 per cent last month to 60. But under a special purchase agreement, VW must hand over the Rolls- Royce marque to BMW in 2003. Meanwhile, say industry observers, the more famous brand is being neglected.

MG Rover is said to be suffering from currency issues that favour cheaper imports, as well as the growing trend for private motorists to buy small cars. This has been boosted by rising fuel prices and the reduced road tax on cars with smaller engines .

webTitle: London property lures Arab millions

fields.headline: London property lures Arab millions
fields.trailText: Oil-rich Arabs are poised to invest hundreds of millions of pounds in central London property.
fields.body:
Oil-rich Arabs are poised to invest hundreds of millions of pounds in central London property.

The Observer has learnt that representatives of the Kuwaiti royal family are coming to London next month with a view to spending millions of pounds on prime offices in the capital.

The imminent arrival of the Kuwaitis is part of a growing phenomenon. Already the Saudi Arabian royal family is closing in on a £345 million chunk of Berkeley Square in London's Mayfair, while Syrian-born Simon Halabi, thought to be backed by Arab money, has put the Lanesborough Hotel on Hyde Park Corner under offer at £120m. If that deal completes, it will make the 95-bedroom Lanesborough the world's first £1m-a-room hotel.

Dubai's Crown Prince, General Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktroum, has, over the last six months, been buying real estate around Knightsbridge and Gloucester Road through its Cheval Properties vehicle. Cheval bid aggressively on Berkeley Square and is thought to be prepared to pay up to £320m for Shell-Mex House, the art deco landmark office next to the Thames on The Strand.

Property insiders say 'a quadruple whammy' of high oil prices, plunging equity markets, low interest rates and the escalation of hostilities in the Middle East, is causing Arab investors to take investments out of the region and siphon money from share markets into central London real estate.

'In times of tension, Arabs, like the rest of us, look for the safe option,' said Mike Samuels, head of real estate at Dresdner Private Banking. 'And there's nothing safer than Grade A, prime Mayfair and City property.'

The return of Arabs to London is in marked contrast to their first appearance in the mid-Seventies following the oil crisis.

'People saw them coming a mile off last time,' said a senior property executive. 'They overpaid. This time, they are more savvy.'

webTitle: No use just wishing they were here. UK needs a better tourism strategy, says report

fields.headline: No use just wishing they were here. UK needs a better tourism strategy, says report
fields.trailText: Britain must put more effort into promoting and investing in its tourism industry rather than assuming people will just come. 'The foot-and-mouth crisis has shown this is not true', a leading travel industry body warned this weekend.
fields.body:
Britain must put more effort into promoting and investing in its tourism industry rather than assuming people will just come. 'The foot-and-mouth crisis has shown this is not true', a leading travel industry body warned this weekend.

The World Travel & Tourism Council will this week urge the UK to pay more attention to the importance of the industry when planning government policy and spending - particularly on infrastructure such as railways and airports.

The WTTC will publish forecasts for 2001 predicting that the economic benefits of global tourism will this year amount to 10.8 per cent of world gross domestic product, a total of £2.3 trillion.

The estimate for the UK, made before the foot and mouth crisis hit the industry, is that travel and tourism are proportionately even more important to the British economy, at 12.2 per cent of GDP or £119bn, although it is growing at 2.2 per cent compared with the global average of 4.6 per cent.

These figures are the estimated total of the direct worth of the industry combined with the indirect benefits that the WTTC calculates spin off into the wider economy.

The UK industry directly employs 1.3m people, or almost one job in 20, while indirect employment generated by travel and tourism swells that figure to 3.2m.

Graham Wason, vice-president of strategy and development at the WTTC, said that the promotion of the UK to overseas visitors had improved - but more needed to be done.

'The UK has wonderful scenery, a fantastic heritage and tremendous culture. But it has taken the foot and mouth crisis for senior politicians to realise lost tourism business is worth a lot more than our meat export industry,' he said.

webTitle: Pre-poll rate cut on the cards

fields.headline: Pre-poll rate cut on the cards
fields.trailText: The Bank of England's monetary policy committee is expected to reduce interest rates this Thursday in the face of mounting evidence of a UK economic slowdown. Delay would leave the MPC with the politically delicate decision of whether to cut on the likely election day.
fields.body:
The Bank of England's monetary policy committee is expected to reduce interest rates this Thursday in the face of mounting evidence of a UK economic slowdown. Delay would leave the MPC with the politically delicate decision of whether to cut on the likely election day.

But the doves' attempts to force a larger cut, of 50 basis points, will be undermined by a survey due on Tuesday expected to show strong consumer spending. The British Retail Consortium-KPMG sales monitor for April is expected to show higher sales than for the same month last year. City economists reckon there's a 70 per cent chance of a 25 basis point cut to 5.25 per cent this week.

The MPC cut by 25 basis points in both February and April. Last month the doves wanted a bigger cut, but other members preferred to wait for further evidence of deterioration in the economic prospects before such a move.

Since then, first-quarter gross domestic product figures have shown a sharp slowdown in the economy.

Inflation has persistently undershot the 2.5 per cent target for almost two years, and at the last count, in April, was 1.9 per cent.

The MPC has plenty of scope to reduce rates further. Indeed, the MPC may have to cut to prevent inflation going below the lower bound of 1.5 per cent.

The Chancellor is sufficiently worried about the economic slowdown to have dismissed out of hand suggestions that the inflation target should be lowered to 2 per cent.

Last week, when re-setting the 2.5 per cent target for the coming year, Treasury sources indicated that they were worried a lower target might threaten the MPC's room for manoeuvre, thereby hitting output and jobs.

 George Soros, the financier and philanthropist, has sounded a warning over US economic prospects. He told The Observer: 'I don't think we've seen the worst.'

He warned that though the first phase of the slowdown, an inventory correction, was ending, the second phase - 'a cut in capital expenditure due to a decline in corporate profits' - has not yet fed through to the figures.

webTitle: New threat to Pru's US plans

fields.headline: New threat to Pru's US plans
fields.trailText: Prudential is facing sanctions in America after snubbing an international commission set up to trace insurance policies stolen or lost during the Holocaust.
fields.body:
Prudential is facing sanctions in America after snubbing an international commission set up to trace insurance policies stolen or lost during the Holocaust.

The British insurer is to be warned this week that public finance officials from across America will withdraw investments from Prudential-managed funds unless it joins the commission, which is backed by the US and Israeli governments.

The move is a blow to Prudential's plans in the US, where it is struggling to keep its planned $29 billion merger with American General alive after AIG tabled a rival offer.

The commission says Prudential controlled 7 per cent of the pre-war Polish insurance market and wants it to submit its records to an independent audit.

Since the commission launched in 1998, Allianz, Axa and other European insurers have joined it. But Prudential has repeatedly refused to join, saying it has its own 'robust' system for tracing policyholders.

The threat of sanctions comes from Alan Hevesi, the New York state finance chief who represents more than 900 US state and city finance officials on Holocaust issues. Hevesi will write to Prudential this week demanding it join the commission and giving it 30 days to respond.

The officials he leads control more than $1 trillion in pension funds and used similar boycotts to force Swiss banks to pay Holocaust survivors $1.25 billion in 'Nazi gold' compensation.

Prudential currently has only a small American presence. But a source close to Hevesi's office said: 'If they ever plan to do business in the United States, they can forget it. Prudential certainly intends to expand into the US market, as every global player does. But they are going to face obstacles that other insurance companies will not find here.'

A Prudential spokesman declined to comment on the sanctions threat, but said it had been working to locate policyholders since the war.

He added: 'We fully endorse the aims and principles for which the commission was founded. But we do not believe that success in addressing this issue can only be achieved by being part of the commission.'

webTitle: NTL to slash 3,000 jobs in bid to cut debt

fields.headline: NTL to slash 3,000 jobs in bid to cut debt
fields.trailText: Debt-laden cable TV company NTL is to make more than 3,000 staff redundant this year. Most are likely to come from among its 22,000 workers in Britain.
fields.body:
Debt-laden cable TV company NTL is to make more than 3,000 staff redundant this year. Most are likely to come from among its 22,000 workers in Britain.

The US-based firm, whose main operations are in the UK, announced late last year that 1,300 staff would go. Then papers recently filed with the US Securities and Exchange Commission revealed a further 1,000 cuts. Now senior company insiders say the total to be lost in 2001 will rise to more than 3,000.

NTL, whose debts total more than £9 billion, is to streamline its business following its £8.2bn acquisition of rival Cable & Wireless last year. Confirmation of the new total of redundancies could come this week when the firm unveils its quarterly figures.

In an interview in today's Observer, chief executive Barclay Knapp declined to comment on the prospect of further job cuts but hinted that they were on the cards. 'We're examining every part of our business on a continuous basis. We're not going to make commentary on what is going to happen,' he said.

NTL wants to be cash-flow positive by the first quarter of 2004, and analysts have welcomed its attempts to cut costs. Europe's second largest cable company, NTL is valued at around £10bn on the New York Stock Exchange.

The company now plans to position itself as a 'complete communications' business, offering capacity on its networks to media content firms. This is a significant shift from its earlier plan in which it aimed to 'own' content, such as pay-per-view Premier League Football rights, which it would then sell over its network.

Significantly, NTL is making swingeing cutbacks in its interactive TV division, which will be reduced to a team of 20. At its peak last September it employed more than 100. 'The interactive side is important for us, but what we have found, like everybody else, is a modest amount of interactive sports and news channels is required in the market place,' Knapp said.

The news will raise questions about the future of interactive television, seen last year as revolutionising the future of the medium. Later this week satellite broadcaster BSkyB will announce that Open, its interactive television arm, once seen as a jewel in the company's crown, is to play a reduced role in future plans.

webTitle: Dogged by scandal, Sotheby's puts HQ under the hammer

fields.headline: Dogged by scandal, Sotheby's puts HQ under the hammer
fields.trailText: Sotheby's, the beleaguered auctioneer, is to vacate its historic Bond Street headquarters in a desperate attempt to raise capital, writes Nick Mathiason.
fields.body:
Sotheby's, the beleaguered auctioneer, is to vacate its historic Bond Street headquarters in a desperate attempt to raise capital, writes Nick Mathiason.

The world's second most powerful auction house last week saw its former chairman - shopping mall tycoon Alfred Taubman - indicted by the US Department of Justice for collusion on commission rates with traditional arch-rival Christie's.

It has now instructed property consultant Knight Frank to sell its wood-panelled dealing rooms and warehouses centred on Bond Street.

Sotheby's should rake in more than £75 million from a sale.

News of the move comes as speculation intensifies about who will buy Taubman's controlling interest in his 200-year-old business. New York insiders say Taubman is unlikely to sell until the court case is settled.

Favourites are US leveraged buyout outfits such as KKR - founder Henry Kravis is a Sotheby's board member - or Ron Baron, who holds a substantial stake in the business. LVMH, which owns rival auctioneer Phillips and was considered a favourite by many, this weekend ruled itself out.

Sotheby's and Christie's combined have so far paid more than £400m to art dealers and disgruntled shareholders following the revelation that the two auctioneers privately agreed buyer's and seller's commission rates.

webTitle: Brown's £5bn tax demand

fields.headline: Brown's £5bn tax demand
fields.standfirst: Multinationals take on UK over 'discriminatory' ruling  Deutsche Bank and Total lead battle
fields.trailText: Multinationals take on UK over 'discriminatory' ruling  Deutsche Bank and Total lead battle
fields.body:
Chancellor Gordon Brown may have to refund billions of pounds in tax to multinational companies following a deluge of lawsuits.

BMW, Deutsche Bank and Total Oil are leading a scramble to recover payments of advance corporation tax (ACT) after the European Court of Justice ruled some British tax laws broke EU agreements by discriminating against overseas firms.

Sportswear giant Adidas and the European drugs group AstraZeneca are also among more than 40 companies that have launched multimillion-pound claims.

The legal battle threatens to damage Labour's business-friendly image and will be seized on by eurosceptics as evidence of creeping European tax harmonisation.

Others to have issued High Court writs against the Inland Revenue include the American GM crop firm Monsanto, German electronics group Siemens and Danish brewer Carlsberg. They are relying on the European Court ruling last March that Britain's old system of ACT discriminated against foreign multinationals.

The ruling cannot be contested, and the companies want the money they paid in the Nineties to be returned to their UK subsidiaries.Their British-owned rivals did not have to pay the tax, which has since been amended.

Some estimates put the eventual Treasury bill as high as £5 billion. Total Oil, for example, is claiming £70 million, and Deutsche Bank wants £34m.

More than 40 firms have so far begun proceedings. But Andrew Martel, a senior tax planner at accountant Arthur Andersen, said they represent 'the tip of the iceberg'. Many more were gearing up for legal action. 'We are suggesting to our clients that they issue protective claims or writs,' he said. He declined to name the clients involved.

The Treasury and the Revenue declined to comment on the legal claims, but they are understood to be unlikely to settle the actions before they come before the UK courts.

Officials at the Treasury are understood to be pinning their hopes on the High Court, which is expected to hear a test case later this year.

The European judgment means some reparations will have to be made, but it is up to the UK court to decide how much. It may, for example, restrict the extent to which claims can be backdated.

The Treasury is hoping that the High Court will also decide that the European ruling does not apply to US firms such as Kellogg and Kraft, which have filed claims.

David Heathcoat-Amory, the Tory trade and industry spokesman, said: 'Yet again the Government has got hung up by a European Court decision on a domestic matter. The fact that it could now cost taxpayers billions of pounds adds to the charge of incompetence.'

webTitle: Does my tum look big in this?

fields.headline: Does my tum look big in this?
fields.standfirst: When not changing his T-shirt, today's angry young man is stomping innocent fruit
fields.trailText: When not changing his T-shirt, today's angry young man is stomping innocent fruit
fields.body:
First Class Air Male The Junction, Cambridge
Rambert Dance Company Linbury Studio Theatre, ROH, London WC2

A man's relationship with his T-shirt is a tricky one, especially if the wearer is French. Jérome Bel has devised a three-part solo, Shirtologie, that confronts us with the iconography of clothing. What this means in practice is that a sturdy bloke, Frederic Seguette, solemnly removes layers of T-shirts, doing exactly what it says on the front.

If there is nothing there, he does that; if there is a stave of music, he sings the notes; recites any printed words and when the shirt says: 'Replay', he repeats his actions. We could read all this as a critique of consumer culture or a semiotic analysis of fashion statements. Or just marvel at the way a man yanks a T-shirt over his head, so differently from a woman.

Seguette's seductively minimalist performance punctuates First Class Air Male, an evening of male solos that comes to the Clore Studio Upstairs tomorrow. (Jerome Bel's company tours Britain later this month.)

The other first class performers are Akram Khan, Adam Cooper and Ben Ash. The original idea for the package, put together by DanceEast Dance Agency in Ipswich, was that cutting- edge choreographers should perform their own work. When that proved impractical, Ash stepped in for Wayne McGregor and Cooper for Jan De Schynkel. The contrast in styles and personalities makes an off-the-wall show that deserves a longer tour and a commemorative set of T-shirts.

Ash is the most elusive of the four men, a ghostly apparition in McGregor's Codex. Fragmentary codes of movement are gradually assembled into a dance, waiting to be deciphered. A similar structure underlies Khan's solo, Loose in Flight. He sets out the moves he is going to use, then takes them in unpredictable directions.

Khan's lexicon is Kathak dance, the classical Indian style that gives him such speed and stillness. He is extraordinarily present in performance, as focused as an Olympic sprinter. His feet propel him across the stage while his arms define distances like Blake's drawing of God measuring the universe.

In De Schynkel's solo, Can't Bark, Cooper embodies a very different kind of male power. His is the rage of the dumb brute, taunted by desire and constrained by a collar, chain and tailcoat. Schnittke's music drives him wild; so does a banana, which he stamps into a pulp. Cooper is more dangerous than ridiculous, dancing with a ferocity all too rarely exploited by British-based choreographers.

Christopher Bruce has a go in Hurricane for David Hughes, included in Rambert Dance Company's brief season in the Opera House basement. The programme of mainly new work is a prelude to the company's seventy-fifth anniversary celebrations at Sadler's Wells next month. Hurricane is set to Bob Dylan's song of the same name, telling the story of an American boxer, Rubin 'Hurricane' Carter, who was falsely imprisoned for murder. Hughes dances the role in white-face, turning the black boxer into a commedia dell'arte clown.

It's a strong solo but not a surprising one. The pathos is obvious as Hughes shadow-boxes in his cell. His bandaged fists clutch his skipping-rope noose or reach for the moon like Pierrot Lunaire. His athlete's body protests against emasculation, though Bruce keeps the character a blank pantomime figure, a fey commentator as well as a victim.

Two premieres of works by company members were pleasant but lightweight. Rafael Bonachela's At Any Time, to Bach cello suites, looks like animated doodlings on a video screen. The dancers' stiff-legged gait makes them childish, inexpressive, the shapes between them unrevealing. Glenn Wilkinson's Twin Suite 2 linked couples in double duets and simple counterpoint, with few layers of visual interest, other than Dody Nash's costumes. Bruce's attempts at encouraging in-house choreography are taking an inordinately long time to bear fruit.

The Opera House has been swarming with cameramen as the BBC recorded the Royal Ballet's wonderful Stravinsky programme. TV and DVD versions will not include Agon because the Balanchine Trust is wary of untried casts. Audiences, however, have had the treat of seeing young dancers discover what they can do during the run. Christina Arestis has grown in confidence and Marianela Nunez, who never lacked it, is a Balanchine cracker.

fields.headline: La vida logo
fields.standfirst: Whether Wombles, wrinklies or loft dwellers, last week everyone was jumping on the brand wagon
fields.trailText: Whether Wombles, wrinklies or loft dwellers, last week everyone was jumping on the brand wagon
fields.body:
The Ad Factor, BBC2
News, several channels, Tues
Home Stories, C4
Hollywood Knives, BBC1
Cutting Edge: Bus Pass Bandits, C4

If I ever suffer from a twinge of doubt as to whether television criticism has any intrinsic worth, I can console myself with the knowledge that, professionally, I never have to stoop to using any of the following unphrases: 'Core brand values', 'An upmarket lifestyle product', 'It's all about connectivity', 'Almost by gestalt', 'Be creative, be different, be courageous!','We want it to be very real... and pedantic', or 'they're not very fashionable, which makes them very fashionable' - all of which double-adspeak we enjoyed during The Ad Factor, three consecutive nights viewing from The Open University, subversively scheduled to put viewers in touch with their inner anti-capitalist anarchist.

One part a Through The Keyhole tour of London's studiously 'funky' advertising agencies (desirable loft-style interiors with basketball nets on the back of the doors: 'Hmmm, what sort of speesees works in an orifice like thisss?'), to two parts Pictionary, the programmes revealed the process by which advertising 'creatives' successfully blindsided the corporate suits from Psion, Guinness and Dr Marten. It's likely we were told all sorts of fascinating things that we didn't already know about advertising but, unfortunately, the participants were wide-eyed with the quasi-religious fervour of righteous capitalism and spoke in tongues, so the message got lost in the medium to the point where even Doris Stokes would have failed as a communications partner to exploit the core brand values of a selection of upmarket lifestyle products.

By Tuesday, armed with a well-thumbed copy of Naomi Klein's No Logo, I freed my dog from her Gucci collar (she is strongly aligned with the so-called 'Fluffies' and particularly exercised about the core brand values behind Pedigree Chum's dietary 'recommendations' from those shadowy, elitist 'Top Breeders'), attached her to a piece of biodegradable twine and was all set to travel to Oxford Circus to help the other Fluffies, Wombles, Spikies, Tweenies and Tellytubbies burn down Niketown, when I looked out of the window and spotted great potential for simmering violence as a result of heavy precipitation, so decided to stay in and watch it all on several different TV channels instead.

By mid-afternoon there had been 14 arrests and the atmosphere was merely 'deteriorating', as Michael Todd, The Man from the Met (police, as opposed to the weather office), observed hotly to a cool Huw Edwards, on the BBC, 'this is not lawful protest, these are criminals '. I couldn't agree more: 6,000 police corralling 3,000 people for eight hours with no access to lavatories looked pretty criminal from where I was sitting. By the early evening, however, as the news helicopters battled for airspace with the police and a 'deteriorating atmosphere' segued inevitably into an 'extremely tense' one, I am fairly sure I also heard, on Sky, that 'there are reports coming in that the Wombles have broken through a police line', though I may have muddled my notes with those I wrote for the London marathon.

Every channel I watched was guilty of making a two-part ITV drama starring Michelle Collins out of a small uncrisis: protests invariably morphed into 'riots' before anybody had chucked a brick, while tense talking heads told us that 'there are only a few hours of daylight left to control the crowd' (presumably the pacifist 'Fluffies' were awaiting their moonlit transmogrification into tooth-baring lupines). One of the very few small voices of calm, however, was that of Nicholas Owen, who observed, in the late afternoon, that things were, basically, 'relatively peaceful', which flagrantly sacrificed sensation in favour of straightforward reporting. In future I'd be very careful, Nicholas, if I were you: there's not much room in today's pacy news coverage for calling a spade 'a spade' when you can call it 'a violent tool of mass mole-extermination' instead.

But, as the week progressed I slipped back into my usual lazy capitalist habits and enjoyed the final episode of Home Stories, C4's documentary about Britain's postwar property fetishism. As 40 per cent of all marriages now end in divorce and, soon, 80 per cent of all newly created homes will house single people, we are a nation apparently playing at postmodern, post-nuclear Happy Unfamilies. Take Howard, for example, a youngish single 'internet entrepreneur' (the species formerly known as 'nerd') who sold his house in Eccles to buy a loft apartment in Manchester: with its wood floors and £8,000 home cinema, it looked not unlike the offices of a small ad agency.

As the formerly painfully-hip loft-living experience is exploited by developers like Barratt, who repackage flats as 'loft-style apartments', the whole dubious lifestyle is therefore accessible to consumers whose tastes are far more padded velveteen headboard than Le Corbusier leather chaise longue, so one can't help feeling that, for the loft-pioneers, the core brand value of the Loft Lifestyle Experience may have become somewhat diluted. Indeed, unmarried couple Paul and Catrin are keen recent converts to loft-living, happily shifting their curtains, three-piece suites and shelving units into a big, uncosy space, which made their home look like a vast National Theatre set for an unlikely new production of Whoops, Vicar, There Go My Trousers! (maybe starring Michelle Collins, but probably only on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturday matinees).

Indeed, the obvious conclusion to be drawn from Home Stories is that 'hip urban' is now the new 'unhip suburban', so groovy loft pioneers will soon be selling up in Hoxton and Clerkenwell, and recolonising the desirably dull 'burbs. Here, Tracey Emin will be asked to create a series of embroidered flags for the holes of Surrey golf courses, a fresh influx of TV executives will revamp Neighbourhood Watch schemes to include webcams, 24-hour internet access and phonelines to vote out local misfits, while Alexander McQueen will be delighted to accept an invitation to redesign the staff uniforms at Happy Eater.

The appallingly badly scripted documentary Hollywood Knives ('in showbusiness, your face is your fortune...') nonetheless revealed a few interesting snippets - literally in some cases. For example, I'd never noticed that Frank Sinatra's left ear was higher up and considerably smaller than his right (a mangled forceps delivery, apparently), or known that Marilyn Monroe had been called 'a chinless wonder' in her bit-part days and that her subsequent chin implant was later absorbed into her body. When she returned for a new one, the surgeon told her he 'could not palpate any cartilage subcutaneously' (which was basically a 'no'), while the inference seemed to be that, despite sleeping with Jack Kennedy and having a drug problem, it was a lack of chin that might have pushed her over the edge.

Monroe's modelling agent was the glorious-sounding Emmylyn Snivelly, a very strong contender for Name of the Week had it not been for the plastic surgeon, Rudi Interthiner ('For tventy-five zousand dollahs, Madam, I can make your inters thinner and much more rudi...').

Both were trumped, however, by pensioner Bunty MacSkimming (from Cutting Edge: Bus Pass Bandits), who became treasurer of the impressively-endowed Glasgow Tree Lovers' Society (£80,000 in various building societies and stocks) and then proceeded to empty the branch's coffers before boughing [sic] out.

Despite being described by one of the tree lovers as a 'cheroot-smoking granny... she wasn't like a tree-lover, she was a different specimen', Bunty was obviously trusted simply because she looked like a sweet little old lady. If, on the other hand, she had resembled Hollywood plastic surgeon's wife Rosemary Ashley Eckersely (probably the same age, but with skin so windswept and nose so retroussé she resembled a pug breaking the sound-barrier) and joined the Beverly Hills branch of the Tree Lovers' Society, vain old Bunty would have been considered instantly suspicious. Last week, then, I learnt that 'MacSkimming' is a suitably anarchic modern 'McJob' for restless retirees with time on their hands, and that while wrinkles may brand us as old, they also make us look much nicer than we really are - and wouldn't you love to see the ad campaign selling that as an upmarket lifestyle choice?

fields.headline: It don't mean a thing if it ain't got a Ming
fields.standfirst: Spooks might not be the new Fugees - but the singer might be the new Lauryn Hill
fields.trailText: Spooks might not be the new Fugees - but the singer might be the new Lauryn Hill
fields.body:
Spooks Shepherd's Bush Empire, London W12

Apparently, US rappers Spooks don't mind the Fugees comparisons. Since the latter have shown little inclination to return to the studio, the former will have to put up with the tag for a while yet. The Fugees' formula is not a bad one to copy: mix Lauryn Hill's spunky voice with consciousness-raising rapping and cleverly chosen cover versions to sell truckloads of records.

Spooks followed the template but avoided the temptation to reheat old hits. Their debut album, S.I.O.S.O.S (Spooks Is On Some Other Script), was intelligent and laid-back and it provided two hit singles. The four MCs (Water Water, Hypno, Mr Booker T and Vengeance) trade rhymes with the fluency, but not ferocity, of the Wu-Tang Clan, while charismatic singer Ming Xia adds words and vocal stylings. It's coffee-table hip hop for those who enjoy urban rhymes cleansed of profanity and visceral imagery.

Onstage, however, Spooks keep it real. The four rappers show they can strike a pose and throw hand shapes with the best of them. Tonight's muddy PA, which relegates Ming Xia to a bit player, is partly responsible. Poor Ming looks like she's in the wrong band; her voice isn't powerful enough to cope with the poor PA or her fellow band members.

The subtlety of S.I.O.S.O.S is replaced by pounding funk, supplied by their band, Blueside, who are so brusque you long for the occasional flourish. Spooks' energy levels can't be faulted but what they need is less verve, more style. 'It's nothing at all like the album,' says the woman standing next to me. She's right.

Predictably, attractive young women keen to boogie with the band soon invade the stage when invited to do so by the MCs. It doesn't take a conspiracy theorist to work out what's happening now. A couple of them clearly like the attention; it takes a security man's beefy arm to guide them gently offstage.

It's doubtful whether these dancers are old enough to remember when Spooks' special guest ruled the airwaves, but Public Enemy's Professor Griff still gets a warm reception. The contrast between Spooks and Public Enemy is striking. While both bands share similar political concerns, PE's strident lyrics were matched by an imposing stage presence. In comparison, the cautionary message of 'Things I've Seen', 'The Mission' and 'Karma Hotel' is gentler stuff. Spooks have more in common with Macy Gray. Like Gray, Spooks made it big over here before their career took off in the States. And, like Gray, their crossover sound lacks the rough edges that would make them truly exciting. Maybe they just tried too hard tonight. Anxious to avoid accusations of being 'soft', Spooks went too far the other way.

There is another comparison to be drawn with the Fugees. Lauryn Hill's incendiary London shows a couple of years ago fused slick and soul. True, she was backed by an impeccable 18-piece band, but unshackled from the Fugees, albeit in front of a worshipful audience, her shows were the real thing.

Predictably, the talk at the after-show Spooks party was of how long it would be before Ming herself went solo. Such chatter, of course, provides the unspoken judgment - good, but not good enough.

webTitle: He steals the show, too...

fields.headline: He steals the show, too...
fields.standfirst: A thieving bank clerk premieres at ENO, while multiracial opera puts its money where its mouth is
fields.trailText: A thieving bank clerk premieres at ENO, while multiracial opera puts its money where its mouth is
fields.body:
From Morning to Midnight ENO, Coliseum, London WC2
Carmen Pegasus Opera, Bloomsbury Theatre, London WC1

A fortnight ago, English National Opera found itself artistically in the red with a thin production of Trovatore. Now this capricious company has leapt back into credit with a highly bankable world premiere in which money plays a key role. David Sawer's From Morning to Midnight is based on Georg Kaiser's expressionist play of 1917. A bank clerk steals a fortune and finds his life spinning into rakish descent. Love, desire, family, guilt and God make their appearances like ghouls in a peepshow. The mechanical dullness of life at the cash desk - stamping cheques, ringing up tills, counting money - finds ingenious expression in Sawer's densely textured score. At the start, the cashier, John Daszak, is imprisoned by filing cabinets and routine. Glamour beckons from the other side of the counter. He falls for it.

Sawer, born in 1961, a successful Composer in Association with the Bournemouth Orchestras, is already well established in the concert sphere. His music has a distinctive mix of sharp, wry clarity and persuasive warmth. This is his first full-scale work in the form. Typically, the scoring is rhythmically imaginative and technically agile. Like Birtwistle, Sawer is drawn to low timbres: contrabassoons, alto flutes, cor anglais and a tuba are here offset by the shrieks, bells and whistles of his enormous percussion sec tion (demanding seven players and more than two dozen different instruments, not to speak of the cashier's own fists). A standard-sized string section adds sensuousness and edge, but their music leaves a less dominant impression on first hearing than the swirls, eddies and voluptuous volleys of woodwind, brass and percussion.

The production is crisp and well cast. Richard Jones, who first suggested Kaiser's text to Sawer, is in his element, relishing the clash of humdrum and absurd, pointing up the sour relationship between material wealth and its bankrupting effect on the human soul. In the opening bank scene, finely observed in Steward Laing's designs, the dumb show of messenger boy, fat man, commissionaire and customers - all served by the maniacally tractable cashier - is comic and chilling. From there, we move in quick succession to hotel, nightclub, Salvation Army hall.

The only constant is the cashier himself, an Everyman journeying towards his doom. One of the most musically successful scenes is the fourth (of seven), in which his mother, wife and daughter, every bit as terrifying a trio as Wagner's Norns or Macbeth's witches, circle round him in his madness. The wife is frying chops, the old mother dying in front of the telly, the daughter massacring Tannhaüser on an upright piano (with every seventh note going wrong): in all respects an average suburban scene.

The big set piece is a bicycle race. A crowd in monstrous monkey masks gather in a spectacular velodrome to watch the six-day event. The cashier, desperate to rid himself of the stolen money, offers a huge cash prize. Sawer's music here twirls and reels in a series of aural pirouettes against the roar of 'Go! Go! Go!' on the terraces. The urgent rush of scales and triplets, offstage band and chorus rise and fall with each race. Breathtaking though it is, this scene feels too long and tangential to the drama. A sneaking suspicion remained that having built this elaborate set, all concerned felt the need to exploit it fully. In the Salvation Army hall too, when sinner after sinner confesses to a background of rousing hymns, less would have been more. But these are small complaints in a triumphant evening. Martyn Brabbins, the conductor, teased masterful playing and singing from orchestra and singers alike. The cast, led by the endlessly versatile Daszak and ably supported by, among others, Kathryn Harries, Susan Bickley, Linda Kitchen and Robert Poulton, deserve praise.

Pegasus Opera Company, founded in 1992 after the success of Glyndebourne's Porgy and Bess, describes itself as 'Britain's only multiracial opera company'. There is no reason to doubt the boast. Jessye Norman and a few lesser known black or Asian singers aside, opera the world over remains scarcely more balanced in its racial mix than the Conservative Party. On the evidence of groups such as Ken Burton's London Adventist Chorale (only the most prominent of this country's excellent gospel choirs), the vocal talent exists in abundance. Few make the transition to opera, whether out of choice or through lack of opportunity. Pegasus's founder, Lloyd Newton, believes that opera casting is still riddled with prejudice. Whatever the case, his aim is to offer more chances. The more such singers are brought on, the harder it will be for prejudice to exert itself.

In the company's spirited new Carmen, directed by John Abulafia and conducted by Gregory Rose, youthful energy more than compensates for the unevenness of the voices and the rough edges in the production. These will certainly diminish as the tour progresses (nine venues nationwide between now and 14 June). Purists may object to the reworking of the story and the sometimes bumpy English ver sion: a drug baron and a star boxer replace Bizet's original line-up. Young men urinate on stage, women snort cocaine - not such a novelty in this opera, as anyone who saw Opera North's recent production will recall.

In the title role, Judy Slater (sharing the part with Alison Crookendale), draws on her training as a sprint champion and dancer to give a febrile, physically exciting account. She sings capably, though her voice is not big (Bloomsbury Theatre is hardly a sympathetic acoustic). As Micaela, the rejected girlfriend from home, Alison Buchanan stole the show. This role never fails to touch us. Had From Morning to Midnight even one character with a similarly involving emotional life, Sawer's expert work would have been elevated to another level of artistry. Of all the organs, it is the heart that tends to get the least exposure in contemporary opera.

Pegasus Opera: 020 7501 9501/ www.pegopera.org

webTitle: It's his job to make Jacko hip again

fields.headline: It's his job to make Jacko hip again
fields.standfirst: At $100,000 a song, this man could revive Jackson's career, says  Kevin Le Gendre
fields.trailText: At $100,000 a song, this man could revive Jackson's career, says  Kevin Le Gendre
fields.body:
What will Michael Jackson's album, his first since 1997, be like when it is finally released? Diehard fans hope Jacko can turn the clock back; cynics wonder what colour he'll be on the album sleeve. The big question, however, is not what Jacko will sound like, but what influence his new producers will have. Can they do for him what William Orbit did for Madonna or Dr Dre did for Eminem?

Jackson has recruited the cream of young R'n'B production talent to work on this much-delayed album, hoping that the prolific twentysomethings who now shape US pop can revitalise his career. His principal collaborator is Rodney 'Darkchild' Jerkins, the 23-year-old New Yorker who has pumped out anthems for Whitney Houston, Mary J. Blige and Jennifer Lopez. There's also Kevin 'Shek'spere' Briggs, whose credits include TLC, Mariah Carey and Destiny's Child; and the duo Pharrell 'D.R.U.G.S' Williams and Williams Chase 'Chad' Hugo, aka The Neptunes, who have the most eclectic client base of all, including Kelis, Beenie Man and Limp Bizkit. Jacko has reputedly spent millions on these 'urban' hitmakers; the prolific Darkchild, for instance, is rumoured to charge $100,000 per song.

A steady stream of hits, business sense and a knack of putting the right beat behind a singer have made these producers the kingmakers in contemporary R'n'B. A hot producer's name on a record can have a major effect on sales, regardless of whether Mariah or Mel B is fronting it. Producers such as Jerkins are occasionally given equal billing with the artists, and last year, when Kelis appeared with her multi-coloured mane singing 'Caught Out There', The Neptunes basked in the afterglow.

But uberproducers are nothing new. Michael Jackson wouldn't have become the world's biggest pop star without Quincy Jones, the veteran jazz musician at the helm of Off The Wall and Thriller. The golden age of Motown brings to mind the inventive Norman Whitfield, whose lush string scores have been sampled countless times.

Whitfield and Jones concentrated on arranging and orchestrating, creating rich textural backdrops to serve the solo singer. But those were the days when labels had in-house bands and writers. With the transition of soul into urban R'n'B in the late Eighties, songs became driven by technology rather than musicianship, facilitating the rise of younger, computer-literate producers.

The change became more explicit with the success of Teddy Riley, the man who created 'swingbeat' and revamped Jacko for the Nineties. Riley was succeeded by another studio king barely out of his teens, Puff Daddy.

These producers used hip hop production methods, manipulating snippets of old records and sequenced drum patterns into 'beats', over which a vocal - usually intercut with a few verses by the rapper of the moment - could be dropped.

Record companies now commission tracks from as many as 10 different producers per album in an attempt to make their acts sound as contemporary as possible. The new breed of producers create cutting-edge beats for any singer or rapper. In just a few years, The Neptunes have racked up production and remix credits for more than 40 artists - it took Norman Whitfield a lot longer.

Despite the power they wield, however, it's still hard for a producer to make it as an artist in his or her own right. Even Puffy, an undoubted showman, has seen his solo career slide. Only rap veteran Dr Dre has succeeded where Puffy and others have failed. Like Jones, Dre has kudos when he records under his own name, and his ability to unearth and nurture talent such as Eminem has increased his clout.

The Neptunes should imitate Dre, not Puffy. When their solo album is out later this year, they will not only have to prove that their beats are still state of the art, but will have to make the world forget about the hits they made with Kelis. 'I hate you so much right now!' could be the ironic refrain.

The Neptunes' single 'Lap Dance' is out on May 21

webTitle: There's nothing rotten in this state

fields.headline: There's nothing rotten in this state
fields.standfirst: Sam West is a razor-sharp Hamlet who talks to his audience. Bertolt Brecht just can't compete
fields.trailText: Sam West is a razor-sharp Hamlet who talks to his audience. Bertolt Brecht just can't compete.
fields.body:
Hamlet Royal Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford

Tales from Hollywood Donmar, London WC2

Bewilderness Lyric Hammersmith, London W6

Ghost Ward St Andrew's Hospital/ Almeida, London N1

Sam West has proved his admirers right. It's long been obvious to them that he would be a penetrating Hamlet. And he is. Sceptical and precise, continually turning his insights to his own disadvantage, he's always riveting - and sometimes chilling. This is a prince so sharp he's bound to cut himself.

West's daring forensic coolness is of a piece with Steven Pimlott's modern-dress production, which creates an Elsinore dominated by spies and surveillance, and in doing so makes the visually lush RSC of recent years, with its proscenium arch and billows of parachute silk, look like a long-ago era. In Alison Chitty's design, tall spotlights watch over an empty box, painted all over in Scandinavian grey. The first sight of Hamlet is of a hunched and hooded figure squatting with his back to the audience, snooping on the court.

The Royal Shakespeare Theatre has been reconfigured to tremendous effect. The stage has been extended, built out over the stalls, with a spit of land jutting into the audience: here is Hamlet's 'sterile promontory', a long walkway which ushers in invaders - this four-hour production keeps the political dimension of the play in the shape of Fortinbras.

The rotten state is a vast and echoing space in which characters are isolated, struggling to contact each other over huge distances. At the same time, the audience is much closer to the actors. Soliloquies, addressed to them directly, are arguments rather than lyrical musings. For 'To be or not to be', West marches furiously up to the edge of the stage and puts his question as a matter of urgency. When he talks of guilty creatures sitting at a play, he rakes his eyes over the stalls.

It's a production which makes you think about what it is to be an audience. It does so at the beginning, when a crowd of grey-suited courtiers advances towards the audience clapping. It does so again when a giant rush of electric white light accompanies Hamlet's announcement that 'the play's the thing'. Of course it has faults. The hectic coloured lighting effects which signal changes of mood are overdone (who needs spooky green air to underline the witching hour?). Apart from Alan David's perfectly judged, windbaggy Polonius, the supporting roles are underplayed. And there are several tricks too far: the projection on to a screen of Claudius and Gertrude's reactions during the Mousetrap is one of these. But the central conception holds firm - West is terrific. Anyone even faintly interested in Hamlet must see this production.

The first day of May was a peculiar day to go to Tales from Hollywood. A few streets north of the Donmar, police horses were pawing away at a deserted Tottenham Court Road, while inside the theatre, Christopher Hampton's play, first produced in 1983, was asking what effective protest a dramatist might make against capitalist excesses.

Tales from Hollywood imagines a clutch of Middle European émigré screenwriters loitering together in Los Angeles between 1938 and 1950. Brecht, played to the comic hilt by Phil Davis as a flush-faced explosive nerd, makes the case for polemic in his splenetic speeches. John Crowley's production effectively undermines him by faith fully presenting his statements in the style Brecht favoured, a plod from one placard to the next. Odon von Horwath, brought to understated life by one of the best of Britain's young actors, the infinitely transforming, subtle Ben Daniels, makes what might be called the Hampton case - for obliqueness. Scott Pask's design beautifully sets the action in a swimming pool (there's a plot point to that); it's chased with ripples which could be seen as the shadows of water or the flicker of film.

This is a shrewd and subtle script. It's hard to resist dialogue which tells you that Brecht in Los Angeles felt 'like a sausage in a greenhouse'. It's extremely well served by its actors, in particular the superb Gawn Grainger as the puffed-up and pernickety Thomas Mann. But it's an inward, literary affair and a tame satire on Hollywood. Another in a line of perfectly formed but not biting Donmar revivals.

Sometimes a theatre critic can feel she's living in a parallel universe, as if she's slipped down the back of a sofa and found herself in an 'upholstered underworld' looking up at the webbing 'sagging with the arses of the ungrateful'. Bewilderness, the new show by the Right Size, aka Sean Foley and Hamish McColl, induces this sensation in me. The duo have previously produced a version of a Brecht play that would have made even Christopher Hampton laugh. They've created a wonderful comic drama about being trapped. And now they've devised a piece, which starts with the couple slipping down the back of a sofa, whose mood is modestly comic and whose range of theatrical adventures is immense.

They use huge, floppy puppets and a banjo; they use video which projects pictures of an escape from Hammersmith to the Pyramids; they niftily parody bedtime stories involving middle-class children in pyjamas; they do magic vanishing and reappearing tricks; they have a nice line in surreal effects, such as a fetishistic giant broom with a face beaming in the middle.

The invention isn't in doubt, but what if you feel yourself on the other side of the webbing, looking up at a convulsed audience and feeling mirthless? It's possible to feel frozen in the face of this relentless, talented exuberance - admiring but anxious, as if you'd been watching the Goons with Prince Charles.

Meanwhile, the Almeida is stretching out from King's Cross and away from tailored plays, under the direction of the talented young Ben Harrison. Ghost Ward, a promenade performance, takes you through the long, quiet passageways of the disused St Andrew's Hospital. You look through uncurtained windows and see - apparently floating in the East End landscape - big colour photographs of children's faces.

As you walk between passages of white curtains, you hear the whispers of young patients. The corridors have been hung with signs in hospital type which direct you through an infant's nightmare: 'Roaring children', reads one.

The air is full of breezy laughter from the local children who, together with a few adult professionals, make up the cast.

Sceptical and precise, continually turning his insights to his own disadvantage, he's always riveting - and sometimes chilling. This is a prince so sharp he's bound to cut himself. West's daring forensic coolness is of a piece with Steven Pimlott's modern-dress production, which creates an Elsinore dominated by spies and surveillance, and in doing so makes the visually lush RSC of recent years, with its proscenium arch and billows of parachute silk, look like a long-ago era. webTitle: With fiends like these, who needs enemies?

fields.headline: With fiends like these, who needs enemies?
fields.standfirst: Morgan Freeman goes up against another serial killer, while Tim Robbins turns a computer baron into evil incarnate
fields.trailText: Morgan Freeman goes up against another serial killer, while Tim Robbins turns a computer baron into evil incarnate
fields.body:
Along Came a Spider (103 mins, 15) Directed by Lee Tamahori; starring Morgan Freeman, Monica Potter
AntiTrust (108 mins, 12) Directed by Peter Howitt; starring Tim Robbins, Ryan Phillippe
La Bete (102 mins, 18) Directed by Walerian Borowczyk; starring Sirpa Lane, Lisbeth Hummel

Hollywood has been rushing for months, fearing a screenwriters' strike that might shut down its dream factories. Film famine instead of feast. What to do? Better stockpile, better churn out canned dreams to keep on the shelf. Never mind endings - if you've got a decent premise to start with, get shooting. Which is why, maybe, there will soon be many more movies like Along Came a Spider and AntiTrust.

James Patterson (from J Walter Thompson USA) is a hugely successful ad man turned even more successful thriller writer. He favours machine gun prose and his tales of Alex Cross, detective-cum-psychological profiler, don't let you pause for breath or thought. Thinking could lead to terminal confusion. He specialises in lurid serial killers like Gary Soneji - a berserk mix of Hannibal Lecter and Professor Moriarty. Along Came a Spider was his first bestseller and now, perversely, it's the second to be turned into a movie. Morgan Freeman (who first played Cross three years back in Kiss the Girls) is the cerebral sleuth: Michael Wincott, master of disguise, is Soneji. Let the implausibilities begin.

There's this posh school, see, for the kids of Washington's rich and famous, guarded round the clock by a posse of secret service agents led by a Barbie blonde (Monica Potter). But who's the bearded inspiration of a teacher Chris Woodhead would love, stuffing a Senator's daughter into his book trolley and wheeling her away? Why, peeling off the latex, it's the fiendish Soneji on a kidnap caper. Nobody, however, quite understands what he's up to. Is it a ransom - or a feint? Is the real target a solemn child who appears (mystically) to be President Putin's son catching up on Western computer studies? A guilt-racked Potter and Freeman give chase (in Freeman's case rather too literally as his 63-year-old bones jog around DC). At which point the double crosses and triple crosses accumulate bizarrely.

Morgan Freeman is a great survivor: he survives some pretty dodgy films with his gravitas intact, and he does it again here. Monica Potter is trimly competent. Lee Tamahori directed the brilliant Maori domestic drama, Once Were Warriors, and has learnt to slum his way through action flicks well enough on the other side of the Pacific. As Friday night specials go, this Spider comes along with all the usual E (for excitement) additives. But tosh in, tosh out. Ponder for even a second and the old rope comes apart in your hands.

AntiTrust has a rather more original idea. What if the king of evil for the twenty-first century is - sort of - Bill Gates? Not your actual Gates of course, perish the thought, but Tim Robbins, slimmed down in jeans, playing a chummy computer baron who aims to rule the world from a mansion in Portland, Oregon, monopolising its software and robbing, bribing or murdering brilliant young programmers who threaten his hegemony from their garage workshops?

His greatest coup is a system called Synapse, which unites everything, but he can't get it up and running. Enter Ryan Phillippe, a blank-faced genius from a garage, who begins to harbour suspicions.

Will he and fellow nerd Rachael Leigh Cook crack the conspiracy? Is his girlfriend, Claire Forlani, quite what she seems? What begins as a promising notion swiftly concludes that too many hours watching Phillippe sit at a keyboard is too boring for its target high school audience and opts for thick-ear histrionics. More perfunctory double crosses as the hardware goes down.

Still, Robbins - with his ingratiating grin and sudden rages - is a treat; like Freeman, he carries the weight. Put aside the thought that Hollywood villains can be multimedia monopolists and that idealistic freedom of information rules OK there as though it were Oxford Circus on May day, and AntiTrust is at least a change from slasher movies. But what Peter Howitt (the British director of Sliding Doors) is doing here, heaven alone knows. Perhaps he and Lee Tamahori might have lunch soon and mull over older, better times.

Walerian Borowczyk, meanwhile, is the incarnation of an older - if not, better - time. He came from Poland to Paris after the war and, through the Seventies, became the art house prince of porn. He had a painterly eye with settings, a distinctive camera style and a wicked, erotic imagination. His big hits - like La Bete - helped him for a while to get on the same cinema circuits as Godard and Truffaut. And now La Bete is back, re-issued because the saintly Andreas Whittam Smith has decided that five minutes of pulsating vulvas his predecessors snipped out a quarter of a century ago can safely be put back (before Channel 5 makes a bid for it).

It's a disillusioning reappearance; the years have not been kind. The opening sequence of a black stallion on heat doing the business is as jolting as heretofore, the mordant humour and anti-clericalism still provoke the odd snigger, but goose-pimply porn actresses such as Sirpa Lane (who went on to films such as Nympho Teens of Rome meet Son of the Wolfman, since you ask) never had the talent to match Borowczyk's flair. This beast, like the lustful monster of the title, would have been best left to lie. They may come and come again - but they never come back.

Philip French is away.

webTitle: Abridged too far

fields.headline: Abridged too far
fields.standfirst: Cephalonia and Cruz are gorgeous, and you may even shed a tear, but condensed Corelli isn't the epic it wants to be
fields.trailText: Cephalonia and Cruz are gorgeous, and you may even shed a tear, but condensed Corelli isn't the epic it wants to be
fields.body:
Captain Corelli's Mandolin (105 mins, 15) Directed by John Madden; starring Nicolas Cage, Penélope Cruz, John Hurt

What happens when a big bestseller - full of rich characters, subplots, history and narrative drive - turns into a big (budget) movie? Captain Corelli breaks a string on his mandolin, that's what. Most of the richness, maybe inevitably, is declared surplus to screenplay requirements. Only the central core of romance remains - and that, denuded of supporting ingredients, seems thin and overblown. It drags itself into life: it does not drive.

But pause, first, in search of a fair precision. John Madden's version of Louis de Bernières's novel is no outright disaster. Cephalonia looks beautiful. So does Penélope Cruz. The action sequences towards the end are expertly handled. You won't - especially if you're one of the three people on earth who hasn't read the book - stagger out of the stalls feeling short-changed. You may even contrive a glycerine smear of a tear. The difficulty is in the might-have-beens.

It might (just might) have been possible to keep some of the texture - which means the believability and thus human warmth - of the original. But Shawn Slovo's script never begins to meet that test. Problem one: what language are this ostensible collection of Greeks, Italians and Germans supposed to be talking? Slovo and Madden settle for an all-purpose Eastern Med Esperanto, otherwise dee Eenglish with daa flexeebly transferable accent. Zorbaspeak. That makes any trip into the colloquial fraught with peril. When Corelli, as interpreter, tries to negotiate the surrender of the mayor and town council, what do they say? They say: 'fuck off.' Catch the first bus back to Camden town, mate. The words, time and again, get in the way.

So does the casting. Of course you need stars - you can't live at the box office without them - but internationalism on this scale verges on the ridiculous. An American (Nicolas Cage) as the lead Italian; a Spaniard (Cruz) as the Greek heroine with an Englishman (John Hurt) as her dad and a Welshman (Christian Bale) as her Ionian peasant lover, plus standard Brits doing their Nazi strut as Germans and real Greeks filling in the cracks in between. Problem two: your real Greeks don't look remotely like your phoney Greeks. Wrong colour, wrong bone structure - the differences fill the screen.

Try sinking yourself in the plot, then. Cephalonia 1941; the Italians - an effete gang of opera-loving layabouts - are the main force of occupation. Captain Corelli, a gentle soul who specialises in barber-shop Rossini as well as mandolin plucking, gets billetted with the fragrant Cruz and her wise old doctor dad while Bale is fighting Hitler in the North. Love does its blooming thing. Bale comes back looking baleful. Mussolini throws in the towel as the Germans turn murderously on their erstwhile allies. Add an earthquake for luck and consider: who emotes, wins. The hacking down of de Bernières - changed ending, editing so brutal that at least one crucial character, the gay Carlo who saves Corelli from the firing squad, becomes inexplicable - doesn't help. Nor does the truncation of real history and real time passing into a few glib devices. But then, gradually, it becomes evident that Madden may be trying to bypass all the difficulties and make a picture which - at heart - has very little to do with the book.

Consider his deliberately lush visual style, a constant orchestrating of sun, rocks and flowers. Who does that remind you of? Partly Claude Berri doing over Pagnol for Depardieu and Emmanuelle Beart, but most insistently this is late David Lean, this is Ryan's Daughter à la Greque. Lean had Robert Mitchum, Leo McKern, Sarah Miles and John Mills all turning on the (pretty ludicrous) Oirish, though variously transported from LA, Oz or SW5 - but nobody cared at the time. Here was Romance with sumptuous strings, and a few tremors of the Troubles dropped in for luck. Begin with cliffs, crags, the eternal sea and simple folk fuelled by simple longings and you couldn't go wrong. Synthetic settings with synthetic castings didn't matter if the hankies got drenched anyway.

Madden dutifully follows his French and English mas ters. Most of the interior shots have that Berri gloss, superior Stella Artois without a foot on the beer pump. Get the camera outside and it constantly soars (with Stephen Warbeck's strings). There's very little attempt at specific realism. Cruz is forever wandering through the glades gathering flowers or fruit in a crisp new cotton smock (from Knightsbridge, £200 and up). Cage's lurches into comedy are as over the top as John Mills's loony fisherman. Here is a nowhere island, Ruritania meets Illyria before the tempest of violence. Does Hurt, perhaps, carry a Prospero's wand in his GP's bag?

At this level, after its fashion, Captain Corelli survives gentle scrutiny. If you're not supposed to believe, then settle for a wallow through what you're supposed to appreciate. Will Cage win another Oscar? (Somebody thinks so: the US release comes only with autumn). He doesn't quite deserve to because the lighter, extrovert Corelli is beyond gelling with that blank face best suited for introversion and pain. But give him a nomination for ambition beyond the call of duty.

Is Cruz the next great female star? She's grown thin and birdlike here (almost the only sign of a wartime Cephalonia on short rations) but she remains luminous, with eyes that well with sadness and a mouth that quivers into wondrous malleability. Europe's answer to Julia Roberts. She - and the brooding Hurt - bring a touch of class. Now give her another comedy like Woman on Top and a square meal.

Back to basics, though. Some books are made to be movies, some are not. The inescapable truth about Captain Corelli's Mandolin, whatever its printed allure, is that a successful cinematic transition is almost certainly a bridge too far. The essence doesn't condense. Cut away and there are only loose ends. John Madden has tried, then, to do something else - and he's not enough of a distinctive hand to pull it off entirely. A gallant failure? Better than that: more a flawed, derivative, but occasionally rousing entertainment.

Go expecting little and you may be pleasantly surprised (especially as the second half gathers pace). Go expecting a British masterpiece to recapture the great days of epic romance and hype kebabs hope. Does the earth move here? Only on seismic orders from special effects - and nobody on a decent salary gets hurt.

webTitle: A nice Brit on the side

fields.headline: A nice Brit on the side
fields.standfirst: New York women are desperate to go out with British men - but not,  Tanya  Corrin  discovers,  on account of their old-fashioned charm and courtesy
fields.trailText: New York women are desperate to go out with British men - but not,  Tanya  Corrin  discovers,  on account of their old-fashioned charm and courtesy
fields.body:
I'm not ready to date another New York guy. Most of them seem like some version of my ex-boyfriend, a New York internet entrepreneur. I won't burden you with all the gory details of our messy public breakup. Point is, I think it's time for something more fulfiling.

Michelle, a curvaceous, highly strung, 23-year-old TV producer perfectly sums up the typical first date with a New York guy: 'You sit in some ultra-swank SoHo restaurant until trading resumes. Before the date is over, you know his net worth and which house he's renting in the Hamptons this summer. All the while he's adding up the tab in his head, wondering if it's enough to get him laid. And what's really depressing is he desperately lacks the ability to carry on an intelligent conversation.'

Lisa, a 29-year-old, vivacious, blond dotcom survivor, who sold early and now owns two restaurants and a beach house, agrees: 'If you do make it to a second or third date, you are forced to have the obligatory "Where are we headed?" conversation, followed two dates later by a "I think I'm having a pre-mid-life crisis" confession. That's why I only date British men,' she concludes. (She's currently dating her sixth Brit.) 'With them, there's none of that.'

I started checking around with other girlfriends, especially ones who had started spending less time with 'the girls'. Turns out a number of them are dating Brits. I already knew about Madonna and Candace Bushnell jumping continents, but was amazed that so many of my girlfriends here at home were dipping into the foreign pudding.

Serena is a 34-year-old, streaky blonde, super-smart, serial entrepreneur. Six months ago she fell hard for James, an architect from London, so she sold her company and is now a full- time writer, splitting her time between New York and London.

Lesley, 35, is a toffee-skinned, athletic doctor who just got engaged to Maurice, a British expat and president of a New York record label. Maurice waited four years for her to finish med school and wasn't intimidated by her intelligence, unlike a lot of American guys before him.

Michelle has what she terms a 'British Man Fetish'. She says she goes after them all the time but can never 'get' a British guy. She even attended University College London for seven months, hoping it would improve the odds. It didn't work, she says, because she's 'too aggressive'. Michelle has cultivated numerous male British friends in New York but can never seem to convert any into a date.

Meanwhile, Amy, a 27-year-old writer with almond eyes and fantastic breasts is just coming off a 48-hour fling with a famous British actor. She says it was some of the best sex she has ever had. Amy should know: she's a New York-based sex columnist and author of the book Run Catch Kiss. But I thought the Brits were notoriously bad in bed? Apparently not. It's been a well-kept secret because, sorry girls, there are only so many to go around.

Before we jump into bed, let's cover a few of the basics. What's so special about British men? 'Their accent is a total aphrodisiac,' gushes Amy. (Wait, we're not jumping into bed yet.) 'OK, they're hysterically funny and better educated than American guys.' What else? 'They read literature!' shouts Michelle, 'and you can actually have a conversation with them.'

'They have a feminine side,' chimes in Lesley.

Most American guys are terrified of being called gay and while they're frantically rejecting their own femininity, they can also reject parts of ours. Apparently, British guys aren't like that. 'Just look at the way they dress - they're so stylish!' enthuses Serena. 'They even wear pink!' Then she laughs: 'Sometimes they jumble the clothes, but the accent more than compensates for it.'

Then there's the romance. 'My favourite thing about British men? They treat us like ladies,' purrs Lisa.

'He meets me at the airport with a bouquet of flowers - every time!' sighs Serena. 'After six months of dating he's still opening cab doors and pulling out chairs for me at restaurants.'

I had to ask about the sex. It's been a while for me, so I live vicariously. 'He's gentle, loving and really tuned in,' says Lisa.

'They're up for a lot - much more than American guys,' smiles Lesley contentedly.

'He loves dirty talk and sexual scenarios,' says Serena. 'American guys take sex way too seriously - my boyfriend brings his sense of humour to bed with us.'

Amy confides: 'He gives me a licence to be hedonistic.'

If you're a British guy, you definitely have the advantage in terms of attracting and bedding New York women. I'm probably shooting myself in the foot here, but it's true. So many women admit that they always gravitate across a party or a bar towards a British accent. A moderately attractive and intelligent British guy can get laid every night of the week in New York. You probably don't even have to be that intelligent. And just to be clear, I mean with a different and drop-dead-gorgeous girl each night. Fortunately for us battle-weary women, most British guys aren't like this. By the time you've realised that dating equals sex in New York, you're already in love. With one of us. Just one!

And that's the real clincher when it comes to the New York woman's attraction for British men. Relative to New York guys, British men seem unafraid of commitment. When an American male turns 40, his world comes crashing down. Michelle explains to me that a British guy has already anticipated at the age of 30 what he wants out of life by the time he's 40. So, when he hits 40, he's looking forward, not back. Serena sums it up: 'When you're ready for a real relationship, date a Brit.'

I'm only two months into singledom, but I figure I should get started on British men right away. Maybe it was Lesley and Amy's titillating oral sex claim that did it for me. So how do you date a British guy? As far as I can tell, you go where they go and then just wait for them to come to you. Jennifer explains: 'They always go for a drink at the same place.' This is starting to sound like fishing. Apparently it can sometimes take a long time to catch anything - weeks and even months.

'It can be really frustrating,' says Michelle. 'You can have a great conversation with a British guy and then he doesn't ask for your number. They assume that you'll just show up again.'

'It's dangerous to ask them out,' adds Tara. 'Asking for their number first is kind of emasculating for them,' explains Serena, 'so you have to be patient and go back a few times, you know, regularly.' Which is a pain, if you ask me, because it's really fun to visit new places.

Anxious to get started, I ignore everything I've been told and beg Michelle to set me up with one of her British male 'friends'. She gives me Paul's number. 'Listen, you should know that I really like him but I don't have a chance, so I'll let you have a try.' I think it's kind of weird, but also extremely sweet. 'Should I call him?' I ask, realising that I'm about to break the rules. 'Sure!' she says, 'ask him out!' She is probably being a friend, but I'm starting to wonder if she's setting me up for failure.

Paul is a filmmaker and has only been in New York for a month, interviewing production crews for his next feature. I get him on the phone right away. He seems agreeable and asks if I'd like to meet him in Brooklyn for live music that night. Woah! No American guy would ever ask to meet a girl the same night. The American guy always acts extremely busy, even when he's not. It's psychologically to his advantage to make you wait. Apparently, Paul has plenty of free time and isn't afraid to say so. So, he meets me promptly at 9:15pm outside the subway station in Brooklyn. No American guy has ever done something like that. It's always 'Meet me inside the bar.' He is definitely cute and dressed OK, but not what I'd expected.

There is nothing really wrong with Paul, but for the rest of the date I come up with every reason why it wouldn't work out. He's two inches shorter than me and he's Jewish (he'll eventually want to marry a nice Jewish girl), but the real problem, I decide, is his lack of a British accent. Something about formative years spent in Canada. So is he a Brit or what? Michelle assures me later that he is, but I've talked myself out of him by then.

The following night my girlfriend Cecilia joins me at Centrofly for their weekly Great British House Party. The VIP room is filled with that lilting exotic accent and the cute guy factor is a 10-plus. Natasha, the vivacious publicist for GBH, orders us a round of Raging Bulls.

DJ Penelope Tuesday pumps up the dance tunes and the next thing you know, Saville Row-clad British bankers are dancing on table tops to Blondie's Rapture. Soon I'm laughing with Alistair, a 'real' British architect from London, about his 'yoga dating' mishaps. Three Raging Bulls later, I'm telling this extremely embarrassing story about how I recently wound up painted in liquid latex.

I'm on my fourth Raging Bull. I'm tipsy. No, I'm sloshed. It's 2am. Time to go home before I do something really embarrassing. Think patience. Fishing.

I need to go, but really I want Alistair's number. Instead I say 'Goodbye' and he says 'Nice to meet you.'

What's wrong with me? Truth is, I've got a big fat 'R' stuck to my forehead. Rebound! That's why I pooh-poohed Paul and probably why I dashed my chances with Alistair. I'm rebounding. I'm still hurting and not really ready for intimacy. Not ready for a 'real' relationship. Not even ready for a Brit.

Oversexed and over there

Madonna & Guy Ritchie

After the success of Ritchie's Lock, Stock & Two Smoking Barrels, Madonna called to say she loved the soundtrack, and wanted to release it on her record label, Maverick.

She wined and dined Ritchie on the pretext of business. They married last December in Scotland.

Elisabeth Murdoch & Matthew Freud

Met in early 1997 and left their respective marriages to be together. Soon after the birth of their daughter, Freud left.

Candace Bushnell & Stephen Morris

The 42-year-old creator of Sex and the City and the British businessman have been together for 18 months, and Bushnell divides her time between London and New York.

Angelina Jolie & Jonny Lee Miller

Met on the set of Hackers in New York in 1994 and married two years later. The marriage didn't last long.

Uma Thurman & Gary Oldman

Married when she was 18, he was 30. It lasted for 18 months. Oldman is now going through his third divorce.

Lili Maltese & Henry Dent-Brocklehurst

The Hawaiian model and English aristocrat married in 1998.
