webTitle: Trafalgar's new Nelson

fields.headline: Trafalgar's new Nelson
fields.standfirst: Antony Sher  met Mandela in London last week, and the moment brought back memories of his childhood in South Africa and his own role in the fight against apartheid
fields.trailText: Antony Sher  met Mandela in London last week, and the moment brought back memories of his childhood in South Africa and his own role in the fight against apartheid.
fields.body:
'He's here, he's here.' The word goes round the crowded balcony at South Africa House. A moment earlier, all attention was on the astonishing spectacle below: Trafalgar Square closed off, a stage built over the fountain, the Landseer lions now serving as the set for a pop concert, 30,000 people swaying, dancing, cheering. A light drizzle makes the scene quintessentially English. Pigeons lift into the air on each clap of percussion. Up on our balcony, Ken Livingstone watches them grimly.

Barbara Castle is on a chair, hunched under an umbrella. The great and the good are squashed together up here: Lord Attenborough, Baronesses Amos and Chalker, Greg Dyke, Paul Boateng, Charles Kennedy, Bill Morris, Peter Mandelson. My gaze is fixed on one short figure leaning on the parapet. Ethel de Keyser, who ran Anti-Apartheid, then the British Defence and Aid Fund for Southern Africa (BDAF), now the Canon Collins Trust. She stares down at the square with a tired but contented expression. Who would have thought she'd ever be drinking champagne in South Africa House? Or any of us. This was a building you viewed from the outside only, holding placards and banners, a grim fortress looming over Trafalgar Square. Yet tonight, it's a place of celebration.

Incredible. You blink, you pinch yourself. Particularly now, as the symbol of this remarkable transformation arrives in the room behind us and starts towards the open door. 'He's here!' The High Commissioner, Cheryl Carolus, supports his arm. His walk is careful yet steady. He's wearing a hearing aid but it's clearly a good one for Cheryl is speaking to him quietly, warmly, as she introduces people. She uses the traditional term of respect to address him: 'Tata, please meet... and Tata, this is...' He beams at people. They smile back in a special way, as though a bulb has been switched on inside them. This radiant smile passes round the balcony with him. It's impossible not to think of religious imagery.

Now it's our turn. I thought I'd be nervous but he's too peaceful a presence. 'Tata, this is Antony Sher and his partner, Greg Doran; they're doing the show for us at the Royal Festival Hall.' The show is a sequel to an event we helped organise at Sadler's Wells in 1988: Two Dogs and Freedom. The title was inspired by a remark made by a six-year-old boy in Soweto: 'When I am old I would like to have a wife and two children, a boy and a girl, and a big house, and two dogs and freedom.'

It was just a one-off performance - an anti-apartheid fundraiser, a star-studded gala. Just one of those, yet it marked a big moment for me, the moment when I opened my eyes properly and saw - really saw - the place where I'd been born. During my childhood in the 1950s, Cape Town was a kind of paradise, a sinister paradise where you could have everything you wanted - sun, sea and plenty - as long as you didn't examine your surroundings too keenly. Don't gaze at that island, Robben Island, directly across from the pretty white beaches of Sea Point. Put on dark glasses, lie back in the glorious sunshine. Reach out for that chilled glass of wine, that platter of fresh crayfish. Don't glance at the hand that's serving you, don't worry who they are, what they're feeling. Just eat, drink, close your eyes.

My grandparents fled anti-Semitic persecution in Eastern Europe at the turn of the century and ended up in South Africa. I sometimes wonder if God was playing a practical joke or testing them. You've been the underdog, you've been despised, but here's a different option. You can be the masters, others will be the servants. You can be safe, they'll be frightened and poor. That's the choice; now what will you do?

Well, surprise surprise, they did nothing. A little cross on a ballot sheet - little effort, little commitment - and then that long, lovely lie in the sun.

I didn't begin to wake up until I moved to London in 1968 to attend drama school. Suddenly, I was exposed to British papers, British TV and the recurring image of South Africa House surrounded by demonstrators. Suddenly I heard my country described as an evil place and its system of apartheid as an atrocity. Atrocity? That was a word I knew well. It featured in my readings on the pogroms and the Holocaust. Yet now it was being used about white South Africans. But, hang on a moment, that included my family; it included me.

I quickly lost all trace of my accent. I told people I was British. I refused to visit home. I tried to hide who I was. Which you can't do, of course - you just implode. I needed liberating. And as the slogan goes: liberation equals education.

Ethel de Keyser became my political guru and still is to this day. Sister of the freedom fighter Jack Tarshish, Ethel was then in charge of BDAF, which provided legal and educational fees for people in need back home. Short, dynamic, with wide, smiling almost Oriental features, Ethel was a tireless campaigner. From morning to night - smoking, clutching a cup of coffee, bustling round the BDAF offices - she found ways of raising money for her cause. People mostly said no to her. This was not a word she knew. Eventually they said yes.

It was Ethel who approached me to help organise a gala for them in 1988. I said no. And then yes. For the first time I started meeting the group of South Africans exiled in London, white and black. In fact, it was the first time I was properly meeting any black South Africans. The poet Mongane Serote, the writer Mandla Langa, the musician Jonas Gangwa, his manager, Dali Tambo, the singer Ndonda Khuze. For one reason or another, they'd fled South Africa: Mandla's brother had been murdered by the police. Dali was the son of Oliver Tambo, president of the ANC, forced to operate in exile. All were yearning for home, yearning for the soil but not the system.

They were tired, their skin quite grey from too many British winters. They smoked heavily. When they came along to meetings of the organising committee - and they didn't always (we were sometimes embarrassingly white) - they had a particular, distant look in their eyes. Here they were, joining in discussions about costumes and lighting, programmes and dressing-rooms; they really were very far away from home. They saw the humour in it. I liked that in them.

Them. I'm talking like my family. Them - an arm's length word. Well, yes, no question. It was strange sitting round a table with them at last. I felt relief.

Greg came onboard as director, and the documentary filmmaker Jon Blair recorded the event for Channel 4. Along with the performers already named, an eclectic cast included Bob Hoskins, Archbishop Trevor Huddle ston, Janet Suzman, Pieter Dirk-Uys, Rudolph Walker, the Kinnocks, Harold Pinter, Richard E. Grant, Richard Wilson, Stephen Fry and Spitting Image.

I have two abiding memories of the evening. Images of two Jewish South Africans with very different experiences of their country. The first is of Albie Sachs walking onstage after the scene from David Edgar's Jail Diary of Albie Sachs to hug the actor who has just played him, Roger Rees. Albie can do neither thing easily, walk or hug; this is just seven months after the South African secret service car bomb in Maputo which tore off one arm, blinded one eye and damaged his balance. Yet he's smiling, lifting his good arm in celebration.

The second memory is of myself during the final chorus of 'N'Kosi Sikele' . I'm towards the back of the huge cast, hoping that the C4 cameras can't find me. I'm crying, partly because of the impact of the show and partly because I don't yet know the words of this song, their song.

The Sowetan boy whose words inspired Two Dogs and Freedom is 19 now. Has he got any of the items on his wish-list, I wonder? A wife? A house? Don't know, but he's certainly got the important one: freedom.

In 1990, along with the rest of the world, I watched in wonder as one man walked out of prison and made a miracle happen: a peaceful transition from the Old to the New South Africa. It's the same man whose hand I'm shaking tonight on the balcony of South Africa House. Cheryl Carolus guides him into a side-room. Now Tony and Cherie Blair arrive, with their children, and Cheryl takes them into the room too. A tray with coffee, champagne, and South African snacks follows them in.

Like a great actress, Cheryl has completely reinvented the role of diplomat. She's warm, funny, spontaneous, a terrific enthusiast. People fall in love within minutes of meeting her. I have only one complaint: like Ethel de Keyser, she doesn't understand the word no. When she invited Greg and me to do a follow-up to Two Dogs and Freedom we said absolutely not. Our schedules simply wouldn't allow it. Very flattered to be asked, but no.

So here we are, doing Freedom Too! It'll be a benefit for the Canon Collins Trust. The distinguished South African director Janice Honeyman has come over to help stage the epic. Jazz legend Hugh Masekela is also flying in, as are the great singer, Sibongile Khumalo, the new stand-up whizz-kid, Marc Lottering, two leading actors, Sello Maake ka Ncube and James Ngcobo, and the unique dance group, Tswaragano. Several veterans of the last show are joining the ranks - Pieter-Dirk Uys, Janet Suzman, Richard E. Grant, Richard Wilson, the Kinnocks - as well as the Lion King company, which boasts a large South African contingent.

We're part of the Celebrate South Africa festivities and although the evening will be upbeat in tone, it will also focus on some of the tougher issues in contemporary South Africa: Aids, crime, the work of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission.

On the balcony of South Africa House we all surge to the edge as a tremendous cheer fills the air. Below, the old man has walked onstage. He tries to speak but the people won't stop cheering. He beams at them, they smile back and Trafalgar Square lights up.

My eyes fill. I'm glad to be here. In this building, in the centre of London. I feel at home.

© Antony Sher 2001

Freedom Too! is at the Royal Festival Hall on 27 May. For tickets call 020 7960 4242

Antony Sher's autobiography, Beside Myself, is published by Hutchinson at £17.99.

This was a building you viewed from the outside only, holding placards and banners, a grim fortress looming over Trafalgar Square. Yet tonight, it's a place of celebration. Incredible. You blink, you pinch yourself. Particularly now, as the symbol of this remarkable transformation arrives in the room behind us and starts towards the open door. 'He's here!' The High Commissioner, Cheryl Carolus, supports his arm. His walk is careful yet steady. He's wearing a hearing aid but it's clearly a good one for Cheryl is speaking to him quietly, warmly, as she introduces people. She uses the traditional term of respect to address him: 'Tata, please meet... and Tata, this is...' He beams at people. They smile back in a special way, as though a bulb has been switched on inside them. This radiant smile passes round the balcony with him. It's impossible not to think of religious imagery. Now it's our turn. I thought I'd be nervous but he's too peaceful a presence. 'Tata, this is Antony Sher and his partner, Greg Doran; they're doing the show for us at the Royal Festival Hall.' The show is a sequel to an event we helped organise at Sadler's Wells in 1988: Two Dogs and Freedom. The title was inspired by a remark made by a six-year-old boy in Soweto: 'When I am old I would like to have a wife and two children, a boy and a girl, and a big house, and two dogs and freedom.' It was just a one-off performance - an anti-apartheid fundraiser, a star-studded gala. Just one of those, yet it marked a big moment for me, the moment when I opened my eyes properly and saw - really saw - the place where I'd been born. During my childhood in the 1950s, Cape Town was a kind of paradise, a sinister paradise where you could have everything you wanted - sun, sea and plenty - as long as you didn't examine your surroundings too keenly. Don't gaze at that island, Robben Island, directly across from the pretty white beaches of Sea Point. Put on dark glasses, lie back in the glorious sunshine. Reach out for that chilled glass of wine, that platter of fresh crayfish. Don't glance at the hand that's serving you, don't worry who they are, what they're feeling. Just eat, drink, close your eyes. My grandparents fled anti-Semitic persecution in Eastern Europe at the turn of the century and ended up in South Africa. I sometimes wonder if God was playing a practical joke or testing them. You've been the underdog, you've been despised, but here's a different option. You can be the masters, others will be the servants. You can be safe, they'll be frightened and poor. That's the choice; now what will you do? Well, surprise surprise, they did nothing. A little cross on a ballot sheet - little effort, little commitment - and then that long, lovely lie in the sun. I didn't begin to wake up until I moved to London in 1968 to attend drama school. Suddenly, I was exposed to British papers, British TV and the recurring image of South Africa House surrounded by demonstrators. Suddenly I heard my country described as an evil place and its system of apartheid as an atrocity. Atrocity? That was a word I knew well. It featured in my readings on the pogroms and the Holocaust. Yet now it was being used about white South Africans. But, hang on a moment, that included my family; it included me. I quickly lost all trace of my accent. I told people I was British. I refused to visit home. I tried to hide who I was. Which you can't do, of course - you just implode. I needed liberating. And as the slogan goes: liberation equals education. Ethel de Keyser became my political guru and still is to this day. Sister of the freedom fighter Jack Tarshish, Ethel was then in charge of BDAF, which provided legal and educational fees for people in need back home. Short, dynamic, with wide, smiling almost Oriental features, Ethel was a tireless campaigner. From morning to night - smoking, clutching a cup of coffee, bustling round the BDAF offices - she found ways of raising money for her cause. People mostly said no to her. This was not a word she knew. Eventually they said yes. It was Ethel who approached me to help organise a gala for them in 1988. I said no. And then yes. For the first time I started meeting the group of South Africans exiled in London, white and black. In fact, it was the first time I was properly meeting any black South Africans. The poet Mongane Serote, the writer Mandla Langa, the musician Jonas Gangwa, his manager, Dali Tambo, the singer Ndonda Khuze. For one reason or another, they'd fled South Africa: Mandla's brother had been murdered by the police. Dali was the son of Oliver Tambo, president of the ANC, forced to operate in exile. All were yearning for home, yearning for the soil but not the system. They were tired, their skin quite grey from too many British winters. They smoked heavily. When they came along to meetings of the organising committee - and they didn't always (we were sometimes embarrassingly white) - they had a particular, distant look in their eyes. Here they were, joining in discussions about costumes and lighting, programmes and dressing-rooms; they really were very far away from home. They saw the humour in it. I liked that in them. Them. I'm talking like my family. Them - an arm's length word. Well, yes, no question. It was strange sitting round a table with them at last. I felt relief. Greg came onboard as director, and the documentary filmmaker Jon Blair recorded the event for Channel 4. Along with the performers already named, an eclectic cast included Bob Hoskins, Archbishop Trevor Huddle ston, Janet Suzman, Pieter Dirk-Uys, Rudolph Walker, the Kinnocks, Harold Pinter, Richard E. Grant, Richard Wilson, Stephen Fry and Spitting Image. I have two abiding memories of the evening. Images of two Jewish South Africans with very different experiences of their country. The first is of Albie Sachs walking onstage after the scene from David Edgar's Jail Diary of Albie Sachs to hug the actor who has just played him, Roger Rees. Albie can do neither thing easily, walk or hug; this is just seven months after the South African secret service car bomb in Maputo which tore off one arm, blinded one eye and damaged his balance. Yet he's smiling, lifting his good arm in celebration. The second memory is of myself during the final chorus of 'N'Kosi Sikele' . I'm towards the back of the huge cast, hoping that the C4 cameras can't find me. I'm crying, partly because of the impact of the show and partly because I don't yet know the words of this song, their song. The Sowetan boy whose words inspired Two Dogs and Freedom is 19 now. Has he got any of the items on his wish-list, I wonder? A wife? A house? Don't know, but he's certainly got the important one: freedom. In 1990, along with the rest of the world, I watched in wonder as one man walked out of prison and made a miracle happen: a peaceful transition from the Old to the New South Africa. It's the same man whose hand I'm shaking tonight on the balcony of South Africa House. Cheryl Carolus guides him into a side-room. Now Tony and Cherie Blair arrive, with their children, and Cheryl takes them into the room too. A tray with coffee, champagne, and South African snacks follows them in. Like a great actress, Cheryl has completely reinvented the role of diplomat. She's warm, funny, spontaneous, a terrific enthusiast. People fall in love within minutes of meeting her. I have only one complaint: like Ethel de Keyser, she doesn't understand the word no. When she invited Greg and me to do a follow-up to Two Dogs and Freedom we said absolutely not. Our schedules simply wouldn't allow it. Very flattered to be asked, but no. So here we are, doing Freedom Too! It'll be a benefit for the Canon Collins Trust. The distinguished South African director Janice Honeyman has come over to help stage the epic. Jazz legend Hugh Masekela is also flying in, as are the great singer, Sibongile Khumalo, the new stand-up whizz-kid, Marc Lottering, two leading actors, Sello Maake ka Ncube and James Ngcobo, and the unique dance group, Tswaragano. Several veterans of the last show are joining the ranks - Pieter-Dirk Uys, Janet Suzman, Richard E. Grant, Richard Wilson, the Kinnocks - as well as the Lion King company, which boasts a large South African contingent. We're part of the Celebrate South Africa festivities and although the evening will be upbeat in tone, it will also focus on some of the tougher issues in contemporary South Africa: Aids, crime, the work of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission. On the balcony of South Africa House we all surge to the edge as a tremendous cheer fills the air. Below, the old man has walked onstage. He tries to speak but the people won't stop cheering. He beams at them, they smile back and Trafalgar Square lights up. My eyes fill. I'm glad to be here. In this building, in the centre of London. I feel at home. © Antony Sher 2001 Freedom Too! is at the Royal Festival Hall on 27 May. For tickets call 020 7960 4242 Antony Sher's autobiography, Beside Myself, is published by Hutchinson at £17.99.

webTitle: When the Finn lady sings

fields.headline: When the Finn lady sings
fields.standfirst: Not only is Karita Mattila enough to drive a grown man to tears. She also happens to be one of the world's greatest sopranos
fields.trailText: Not only is Karita Mattila enough to drive a grown man to tears. She also happens to be one of the world's greatest sopranos.
fields.body:
The soprano Karita Mattila - who in my view is simply the greatest singing actress in the world - has been known to combine music with striptease.

At the stuffy Mozarteum in Salzburg last summer, she paused during a song cycle by her Finnish compatriot Jouni Kaipainen to rip off her cloak of golden spangles, then bent down to remove her shoes: not mere exhibitionism, but a way of dramatising Kaipainen's point about the artist's need to shed disguises. Last September, celebrating her fortieth birthday at a concert in Helsinki, she regaled an audience of 12,000 with arias by Wagner, Verdi and Puccini, then changed to a clinging sheath of pink polka dots to bump and grind through songs associated with two earlier bewitching blondes - Dietrich's fatal anthem 'Falling in Love Again' and Monroe's rapacious credo 'Diamonds Are a Girl's Best Friend'. 'I am,' she said to me last week, 'a physical type.'

Arriving in a sedate, murmurous Maida Vale café for our meeting, she proved the point by rehearsing Salome's dance of the seven veils. Off came a silver raincoat, the colour of an astronaut's uniform, to reveal a lilac pants suit; she then unwound a rosy scarf from her precious throat, set down a bag which had cost several crocodiles their lives, fixed me with her luminous eyes, gripped my wrist as if to steady me, and was ready to begin.

I should have brought her a present, but all I could think of to give her was a banana. This year at the New York Met, as the disguised Leonore in Beethoven's Fidelio, she transformed herself into a khaki-clad, crop-headed boy, and entered stumbling beneath the weight of her grocery shopping. Slumped wearily at a kitchen table, she unpeeled a banana and ate it. The action was typical of her compulsion to ground opera in everyday reality. I asked if she would have been offended by such a present. 'No, of course not,' she guffawed. The exotic, orchidaceous Mattila grows out of the soil: she is a farmer's daughter.

From bananas we passed to pinpricks. She had recently injured her knee during rehearsals for the Royal Opera's new production of Tchaikovsky's Queen of Spades, and had to undergo acupuncture.

'I told the doctor I was frightened of the needle, and couldn't even watch him inject it. Then I cried for an hour - it was the emotional pressure. Afterwards I felt so much better!' She might have been describing my emotions when watching one of her enraptured, often crazily intense performances.

I have adored Mattila ever since I first heard her, in Mozart's Così fan tutte, in Houston in 1989. Not long before, she had been the first winner of the Cardiff Singer of the World contest; for the next few years she gave perfect performances of Mozart - vocally serene, dramatically subtle. But was she discontented, unfulfilled. 'I was in my knots! When I see old videos from that time, I am stiff as a dead tree.'

In 1995, during a production of Strauss's Elektra in Salzburg, something happened. Claudio Abbado had persuaded Mattila to risk singing Chrysothemis, whose erotic frenzy challenges the vindictive mania of Elektra. 'I worried about doing it, but Claudio promised to look after me, and when I got on stage for the last scene, I simply sang my heart out.'

Arms flailing, she treated the café patrons to a sotto voce reprise of Chrysothemis's sensual hymn. 'No one told me to sing softer - and it felt so good! Something exploded in me. In Finland I was brought up to think that anything which gave you pleasure must be bad, so I panicked and came straight back to London to see my teacher, Vera Rosza. I thought I must have damaged my voice with all that screaming. But she listened and said,' - Mattila imitates her mentor's Hungarian accent with affectionate finesse - '"Dollink, you are in vantastik vorrm!"'

She has remained in that form ever since. Her trapped, unhappy Elisabeth de Valois in Verdi's Don Carlos at Covent Garden in 1996 was heart-rending. Her whole body sang: that dutiful, ramrod back, and those eloquent hands, clasped in anxiety or dangling in despair. At the Met, her Elsa in Wagner's Lohengrin shone from within, despite the balletic postures prescribed by the director Robert Wilson. In Salzburg, her Donna Anna in Don Giovanni suffered a nervous breakdown while singing Mozart's astral coloratura, destroyed by an illicit love for the libertine who has assaulted her. And in Paris, allowing herself a break from tragedy, she was an irresistibly skittish millionairess in Lehár's Merry Widow, waltzing on high heels.

Lisa in The Queen of Spades is another of her rhapsodic, obsessive creatures, destroyed by a demon lover. 'I understand these Slavic characters, they are very close to me. I once offended a Swedish colleague when she asked me to take part in a concert with a Scandinavian theme. I said, very spontaneously, "But Finland is not Scandinavia". She was most upset. Ah, we Finns are not good diplomats!'

Mattila herself is undiplomatically honest in her professional judgments. She laments the negligence of Luca Ronconi who, having filled the stage of his Salzburg Don Giovanni with vintage cars and steam trains, played with these toys and ignored the characters. She hated last summer's Salzburg Così fan tutte, in which the director Hans Neuenfels made her exercise a pair of canine leather boys in bondage gear. She names and shames other singers - 'so-called artists' - who perform by rote or dodge rehearsals. 'That,' she said, thumping the café table, 'is not good enough! For me the most hated thing is routine. It insults the audience. They pay so much, and they want to open up, to be changed by what we do. They need to be touched.' Mattila always has to act out her meaning: she grabbed my arm again, to signal the transmission of energy that must happen in performance. When Mattila sings, you are seared by a sacred fire. Even across a café table while she's talking, the incandescence is fierce.

Those floods of tears she shed in response to the needle transform pain into joy, just as her singing does. We call the process acupuncture; Aristotle's term was catharsis. The emotional pressure beneath Mattila's fair skin is turbulent, eruptive. Discussing the distress of Leonore in Fidelio - her readiness to sacrifice herself, and her dismay about the harm she does to those she deceives - she paused, a tear squeezed out of the corner of her almond-shaped eye. It slowly travelled down her cheek, testimony to her fervent sincerity.

Later she talked about the last performance of that New York Fidelio, when the chorus members gathered round to say how much they would miss the experience of performing with her, buoyed up on the same ocean of sound. She stopped talking, looked away, then apologised and began to sob. It was as if a tempest had agitated the brittle Maida Vale tea cups. 'I have so much adrenaline, I cry so easily,' she said. So do I during her performances: she is the emotional equivalent of a spring shower, shocking you into new life.

In the frozen North, they call Mattila the Finnish Venus. On New Year's Eve in 1999, she appeared on television during a global relay to sing Sibelius's Luonnotar, an orchestral song about earth's genesis. In it, the Mother of the Waters gives birth to the world; Mattila - a voluptuous goddess in a gold dress, delivering Sibelius's incantations in a voice at once spiritually exultant and carnally wild - looked capable of doing exactly that.

'I used to be so frustrated, so annoyed,' she said. Opera can be so fake. As my husband says, it's really difficult to look intelligent when you're singing! But at last I feel I am overcoming my limits, escaping from the strict, old-fashioned country upbringing I had. I made my mistakes. Now I am beginning to realise what I might be capable of, if I have great directors and conductors to challenge me and help me. Aren't I lucky?' She beamed, aware that her good luck is also ours.

Then she repaired her smeared eyes, gave me two kisses I shall always treasure, and whirled away, still talking. 'I am not able,' she warned me, 'to give short answers'; her talk is as generous and unguarded as her singing. She left me speechless, which doesn't often happen - but music is more eloquent than words, and in any case she had anticipated my last lines before I could utter them. 'Not long ago,' she told me, 'I said to my husband, "You know, I really believe in opera". I didn't always, but now I think it can be complete, it can be everything: music and drama together, with such tremendous power. It is almost a religion. No, it is better, it is religion at its best.' After a disenchanted, agnostic period, I too believe in opera again because I believe in her.

Queen of Spades opens 12 May at Royal Opera House (020 7304 4000)

webTitle: I positively refuse to tell you where I buy my shoelaces

fields.headline: I positively refuse to tell you where I buy my shoelaces
fields.trailText: I suppose the question most writers dread is the one that is asked most often: 'Where do you get your ideas from?' It certainly stumps  me. I've tried meaningful: 'The creative process is, in the end, a mystery.' I've tried cheeky: 'I steal them.' I've even tried honest: 'I have no idea.'
fields.body:
I suppose the question most writers dread is the one that is asked most often: 'Where do you get your ideas from?' It certainly stumps me. I've tried meaningful: 'The creative process is, in the end, a mystery.' I've tried cheeky: 'I steal them.' I've even tried honest: 'I have no idea.'

But it remains a daunting inquiry. It is, however, an innocent inquiry. It normally comes from somebody who's seen or read something you've written; it contains genuine curiosity and must be treated with respect.

Questions from journalists and broadcasters are in a quite different category. There may again be genuine curiosity behind the questions, but this time there is a job to be done. The journalist has a page or two to fill, the broadcaster has airtime to occupy and the writer has a book to sell or a theatre to fill. Thus, there is an alliance of interests, but it is an uneasy alliance.

Sometimes the journalist is trend-spotting. As soon as it was announced that my play, Feelgood, was transferring to the West End, I found myself being asked whether there was a new satire boom. To be honest, I have no idea whether there is a new satire boom or not.

Certainly, Bremner, Bird and Fortune on Channel 4 routinely draw blood at the expense of New Labour. Certainly, the audiences at the Garrick seem to be up for a spot of vicious political comedy. But I suspect this has little to do with a sudden satire boom and much to do with people's reaction to a manipulative and image-obsessed government.

When Her Majesty's Opposition resembles a rather sad offshoot of the Ku Klux Klan under the leadership of a risible Wizard, is it any surprise that the public looks to satirists for a coherent expression of dissent?

The other question that soon follows whenever satire is mentioned is, of course: 'Does satire change anything?' I dread this question, too. I think every writer secretly nurses the hope that he or she might change the world in some small, inexpressible way.

But from secret hope to hubris is only a small step and so I prefer to answer the question by saying (which I also believe) that satire can give people hope, can raise people's spirits. Satire can say to people: 'Look, you were right to be outraged, you were right to feel you're being lied to. Don't stop being angry.'

However predictable such questions may be, they're legitimate questions. It's when journalists want to ask questions about the writer's personal life that I begin to resist. We live in a celebrity-driven culture, in which most people in showbusiness seem happy to put their entire lives at the disposal of the publicist. Thus, a new baby becomes a photo-opportunity, an act of sexual infidelity becomes a tabloid front page and mental breakdown becomes a living soap.

All this is so obviously distasteful that it is fairly easy to resist: the person being questioned simply needs to draw a boundary and make clear to the journalist where that boundary lies. The celebrities who cry 'foul' when they're being harassed by the media are often the ones who have been only too happy to expose their own lives when it suited them to do so.

More pernicious are the seemingly innocent questions which lead to a declaration of lifestyle. You know the sort of thing: My Five Favourite Places to Eat, or Why My Pets Always Go With Me On Holiday, or The 10 Things I Most Enjoy Doing With a Baguette, or Where I Buy My Shoelaces: 'I know this charming little shop just off Brick Lane where they do the most exquisite hand-plaited shoelaces from Brazil.'

I'm at a loss as to why anyone could possibly give a damn about this sort of stuff. I can't really imagine there are readers out there who throw their newspapers to the floor and dash to the phone to book their theatre tickets, shouting excitedly to their partners: 'Darling, we must see that new play by Alistair Beaton - he's got two cats!'

Then, finally, there is the question that writers dread most of all. It comes from Carole Stone: 'Would you like to come to one of my salons?' Well, at least that one has an easy answer.

Feelgood is at the Garrick Theatre, London WC2 (020 7494 5085) till 27 October

As soon as it was announced that my play, Feelgood, was transferring to the West End, I found myself being asked whether there was a new satire boom. To be honest, I have no idea whether there is a new satire boom or not. Certainly, Bremner, Bird and Fortune on Channel 4 routinely draw blood at the expense of New Labour. Certainly, the audiences at the Garrick seem to be up for a spot of vicious political comedy. But I suspect this has little to do with a sudden satire boom and much to do with people's reaction to a manipulative and image-obsessed government. When Her Majesty's Opposition resembles a rather sad offshoot of the Ku Klux Klan under the leadership of a risible Wizard, is it any surprise that the public looks to satirists for a coherent expression of dissent? The other question that soon follows whenever satire is mentioned is, of course: 'Does satire change anything?' I dread this question, too. I think every writer secretly nurses the hope that he or she might change the world in some small, inexpressible way. But from secret hope to hubris is only a small step and so I prefer to answer the question by saying (which I also believe) that satire can give people hope, can raise people's spirits. Satire can say to people: 'Look, you were right to be outraged, you were right to feel you're being lied to. Don't stop being angry.' However predictable such questions may be, they're legitimate questions. It's when journalists want to ask questions about the writer's personal life that I begin to resist. We live in a celebrity-driven culture, in which most people in showbusiness seem happy to put their entire lives at the disposal of the publicist. Thus, a new baby becomes a photo-opportunity, an act of sexual infidelity becomes a tabloid front page and mental breakdown becomes a living soap. All this is so obviously distasteful that it is fairly easy to resist: the person being questioned simply needs to draw a boundary and make clear to the journalist where that boundary lies. The celebrities who cry 'foul' when they're being harassed by the media are often the ones who have been only too happy to expose their own lives when it suited them to do so. More pernicious are the seemingly innocent questions which lead to a declaration of lifestyle. You know the sort of thing: My Five Favourite Places to Eat, or Why My Pets Always Go With Me On Holiday, or The 10 Things I Most Enjoy Doing With a Baguette, or Where I Buy My Shoelaces: 'I know this charming little shop just off Brick Lane where they do the most exquisite hand-plaited shoelaces from Brazil.' I'm at a loss as to why anyone could possibly give a damn about this sort of stuff. I can't really imagine there are readers out there who throw their newspapers to the floor and dash to the phone to book their theatre tickets, shouting excitedly to their partners: 'Darling, we must see that new play by Alistair Beaton - he's got two cats!' Then, finally, there is the question that writers dread most of all. It comes from Carole Stone: 'Would you like to come to one of my salons?' Well, at least that one has an easy answer. Feelgood is at the Garrick Theatre, London WC2 (020 7494 5085) till 27 October

webTitle: Should my friend kick out her daughter?

fields.headline: Should my friend kick out her daughter?
fields.trailText: A friend of mine has recently split up from her husband of 22 years. He has left her for a younger woman who has subsequently had a baby. My friend's daughter, who is 20, has always been independent but since her parents split, she has become very clingy to her mother and moved back to the family home.
fields.body:
A friend of mine has recently split up from her husband of 22 years. He has left her for a younger woman who has subsequently had a baby. My friend's daughter, who is 20, has always been independent but since her parents split, she has become very clingy to her mother and moved back to the family home.

My friend is in a quandary. She needs her own space to sort herself out but feels unable to add to her daughter's insecurity by asking her to leave. Is she right to put her child's feelings above her own, or should she put herself first?
C.B. of Surrey

Leaving home is a critical event in the life of a young adult and her parents and the lead-up can be a bumpy ride for either party. At around 18, restlessness and boredom contribute to confrontational attitudes, while parents become more critical and less tolerant.

The problem is usually resolved amicably because deep down, all parties want the same thing, namely a parting of the ways. So the children move on, welcoming freedom and the chance to make their own mistakes, accepting in exchange a degree of privation and diminished comfort.

A little bit of distance really does makes hearts grow fonder and the pattern is set for excellent long-term relationships. Even if a child thereafter moves back temporarily, the umbilical cord has been severed, an essential individuality achieved.

Your friend has no doubt been through this process satisfactorily before her present crisis. The daughter's behaviour seems an exaggerated response for a 20-year-old to her parents' split.

I wonder if she is doing this to support her mother under the mistaken belief that her presence and support are vital. She may believe that her mother's protests are not to be taken at their face-value, so she is practising a little role-reversal.

If so, they are living in an uncomfortable, double-blind world of mutual misinterpretation. So much domestic pathology arises from misunderstandings that I think the mother would be best advised to come clean about her true wishes.

The morality of the situation depends on whose perspective you adopt. From a detached viewpoint, it is the mother who has endured the loss and the greatest trauma. The daughter has not lost either parent, although the family unity is destroyed, and her sorrow is suffered in sympathy rather than directly. Therefore, the mother deserves priority in acknowledgment of her needs.

If the daughter really is motivated by an unselfish wish to combat loneliness and isolation she will no doubt be relieved to discover that the sacrifice of her own liberty is not necessary. If she has regressed in emotional maturity because of her father's actions, and has moved back to her mother's orbit for her own condolence, then it's time she perceived her mother's greater need.

Besides, at 20, her resilience and powers of coping are significantly greater then at 40 or 50.

Either way, your friend should kindly and firmly explain to her that it's much better to move out to her own space, pick up her own life again, but still exchange mutual support from a comfortable distance.

Readres' replies

This dilemma strikes a chord with me as I was 22 when my parents split up. I was very confused as I understood why my mum had left my dad for someone else but then also fully understood why my dad was so distraught.

I felt as if a bomb had exploded under everything I had ever known and my emotions had lost all their foundations.

I can see why the daughter in the dilemma would run home to mummy for some security in such an unsafe time but it will not do either of them any good.

The one thing I took out of the experience is that everybody in the family has to work out how they feel about the break-up and how they feel towards each of the parties involved.

They have to do this on their own. I felt I was the only one who could understand all sides and therefore had to help everybody. I now realise that was a way of avoiding working out what I felt myself.

If the daughter stays with her mother then she may not see her father's point of view, or her own, which she will have to do eventually. Equally, the mother's views will be confused with those of her daughter and although it will be very hard to ask her daughter to leave, it will just prolong the heal ing process for both of them if she does not.
J.T. of Bristol

Next week's dilemma

I am 25 years old and have just starting seeing a married man of 32. He lives in Birmingham so we only get to see each other every couple of weeks. In June, his wife is going to be away for two weeks, holidaying by herself. He has suggested we go away together during the first of those weeks.

However, it clashes with an arrangement I have made with a close friend. I desperately want to cancel my previous engagement so I can spend some much cherished time with this man who I am only starting to get to know.

Please do not preach to me about the rights and wrongs of seeing a married man. My dilemma is more about how I can justify cancelling my friend in favour of a lover.
M.B. of London

Write to Observer Review or email margaret.cook@observer.co.uk. Views on problems must reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Woman's Journal

webTitle: Quick-fire round

fields.headline: Quick-fire round
fields.standfirst: Simon Hughes, Channel 4's cricket analyst
fields.trailText: Simon Hughes, Channel 4's cricket analyst.
fields.body:
Favourite non-sports TV show as a child?
Wacky Races or Kojak.

Favourite non-sports TV show now?
Father Ted.

Coronation Street or EastEnders?
South Park.

When did you last watch Top of the Pops?
It was Good Friday actually, only a fortnight ago (presented by avid cricket fan Jamie Theakston).

Who are you often mistaken for?
Simon Hughes, the Liberal Democrat MP.

Best moment as a cricketer?
Bowling the last over to win the 1986 Benson & Hedges final. It was pouring with rain, the ball was like a bar of soap, but I managed to hold my nerve to allow only a single with four needed to win off the last ball.

Worst moment as a cricketer?
Bowling the last over to lose the 1989 NatWest Trophy final. Warwickshire required 10, and though it was very gloomy, Neil Smith smote my second ball out of the ground in a moment that has haunted me (and most Middlesex fans) ever since.

Best moment in broadcasting?
Commentating with Richie Benaud for the first time.

Most embarrassing moment as a commentator?
Being run over by the roller while doing a live pitch report. I was bent over pointing at a crack, and with the producer burbling in my earpiece, didn't notice the motorised roller until it nudged me out of the way. Luckily it missed my feet.

If you could change an aspect of your appearance, what would it be?
More hair.

Sporting heroes?
In terms of cricketers it has to be Ian Botham. And also Michael Jordan, the basketball legend.

Favourite cricketer currently playing?
Sachin Tendulkar.

Fantasy desert island partner?
Uma Thurman.

Who's going to win the Ashes this summer?
England.

 Simon Hughes is a cricket analyst for Channel 4; Jargonbusting: the Analyst's Guide to Test Cricket is out now, (Channel 4 books, £12.99).

webTitle: Di Canio wants humble Hammers to play the Ipswich way

fields.headline: Di Canio wants humble Hammers to play the Ipswich way
fields.trailText: Self-sacrifice and humility are not qualities readily associated with Paolo di Canio. Yet these were the words peppering the Italian's review of West Ham's grossly under-performing season, and his prediction that the next could be equally fraught with danger.
fields.body:
Self-sacrifice and humility are not qualities readily associated with Paolo di Canio. Yet these were the words peppering the Italian's review of West Ham's grossly under-performing season, and his prediction that the next could be equally fraught with danger.

Di Canio was not saying anything controversial since his manager Harry Redknapp had just voiced, less colourfully and expressively, the same feelings. Only by becoming "a team" and getting "the right shape", warned Redknapp, can West Ham find safety.

This has been a familiar mantra for Redknapp in recent weeks as each adverse result sent his side closer to the unthinkable. Even this victory over Southampton, releasing West Ham uncomfortably late from the threat of relegation, demonstrated as many weaknesses as strengths.

"You have to be a magician to come up with the right balance," said Redknapp referring to his problem in incorporating the free spirits of Di Canio, Joe Cole and Frédéric Kanouté in a successful framework. And yet after a shambolic first half each of the three conjured a goal.

It worked on Saturday but Redknapp knows it may not against better opponents than Southampton next season, by Premiership teams fortified by a summer of big spending with the new arrivals among those exercising financial muscle.

West Ham's outlay will be more modest but Redknapp's search for "two quality players" will take him round the world next month. He is also confident that the 39-year-old Stewart Pearce will agree a further one-year deal.

Criticisms of Di Canio's away performances saw the Italian go on the defensive here. He believes he can play even better in the next campaign than in his stunning first season with West Ham. But he accepts that so many free spirits hinder the team.

"This is the problem we had this year. Maybe we didn't play like Ipswich, for example. They play with humility, they don't think they are stars. I think we can do what they've done. We must understand next year that we have to play like a squad."

For almost an hour on Saturday West Ham were more a collection of error-prone individuals. Wasteful headers from James Beattie and Kevin Davies, sandwiching a marvellous save by Shaka Hislop from Marian Pahars, spared them even greater anxiety.

Yet this was the prelude to a superbly conceived and executed goal from the hosts. Kanouté passed, Svetoslav Todorov back-heeled and Cole swept an immediate shot into the far corner. The effect was startling: Todorov produced the same trick for Di Canio to shimmy forward for the second and then the Italian delivered his free kick on to Kanouté's head. So West Ham somehow had taken the stylish route to safety.

Man of the Match: Shaka Hislop (West Ham)

webTitle: Sky-high hopes end in shattered dreams

fields.headline: Sky-high hopes end in shattered dreams
fields.trailText: So much for the great escape. While a pre-match snatch of music from the war film of that name seemed to remind Coventry City of what their life had mostly been about, they still finished hanging on the old barbed wire.
fields.body:
So much for the great escape. While a pre-match snatch of music from the war film of that name seemed to remind Coventry City of what their life had mostly been about, they still finished hanging on the old barbed wire.

There were moments when the patches of blue sky above Villa Park mirrored the Sky Blue optimism down below. But for Gordon Strachan's team the day quickly clouded over and the mortal blow to Coventry's 34-year-old status as a top-league club was delivered by an angel of the Colombian, rather than the merciful kind.

The goal scored by Juan Pablo Angel to level the contest at 2-2 nine minutes from time was his first for Aston Villa since John Gregory bought him from River Plate in January for £9.5m. More pertinently, it virtually ended the hope reawakened in Coventry's soul once Moustapha Hadji had scored twice in eight minutes during the opening half-hour.

Paul Merson's beautifully struck winner in the 86th minute, while it ended Villa's last home match on the sort of high note for which their followers have pined for much of the season, was irrelevant so far as Coventry were concerned. They had needed to win and for results elsewhere to favour them to go into their final Premiership fixture, at home to relegated Bradford City, still with a chance of staying up.

On Friday nights Strachan watches Frasier, the psycho-comedy show. This would explain why, after the game, the Coventry manager appeared to be in a state of denial.

He was prepared to talk only about the disappointment of losing the match. About the wider consequence of the result he had nothing to say. This was Mrs Lincoln intent on discussing the shortcomings of the second act.

All Strachan would concede was that losing 3-2 after leading 2-0 summed up Coventry's season. The rewards of playing good football, he said, had been lost through individual and collective errors. True enough, but after all this is how most losing teams carry on.

Gregory was supportive. The Villa manager had a lot of sympathy for Coventry and thought the atmosphere at the end of the match had reflected this. Then again it could also have reflected the mood of Aston Villa fans as they pondered the possibility of next season being as barren of joy as the one just ending.

Coventry's supporters must have suspected something was wrong when their team lay fourth in the Premiership last August. Sure enough, one win and nine defeats in the next 13 matches plunged them into the bottom three and only the recent arrival of John Hartson arrested the decline.

In the Premiership it always helps to have players who can really play and certainly Hartson belongs to this category. In the longer term Coventry's presence in the Premiership was always going to live on borrowed time once the club acquired the habit of letting better players leave while signing lesser players to replace them.

For a time on Saturday it was possible to believe that Coventry were in a false position, so confident and positive was their football. Yet this had to be set against the fact that for the best part of an hour Aston Villa were comically bad, a team of strangers bent on being second to every ball when they were not giving it away.

The loose pass from Gareth Barry which led to Coventry taking the lead typified Villa's end-of-season ennui. John Eustace gained possession and gave Paul Telfer the opportunity to provide the centre from which Hadji headed past David James. Then Hadji gathered a clearance from Paul Williams and outpaced Mark Delaney to increase Coventry's lead with a rising, rousing drive.

Desperate circumstances require desperate measures, so Gregory brought on a real footballer. He had, he explained later, been planning to introduce David Ginola for the last half-hour but Coventry's goals, not to mention "schoolboy errors", had altered that.

It is hard to avoid the impression that Gregory keeps Ginola back as a reward for the supporters' good behaviour. The way some of them were going on behind his back on the Villa bench it was a wonder the Frenchman appeared at all.

When he did, Aston Villa's football made considerably more sense and Paul Merson became an increasing influence. But had Williams and Chris Kirkland not made such a mess of dealing with an innocuous low cross from Delaney, allowing Darius Vassell to score a simple goal in the 61st minute, Coventry might still have won.

As it was, the goal drained the confidence from Strachan's side and now the earlier loss of Telfer with an ankle injury began to be felt. Angel's equaliser was volleyed in after a centre from Gareth Southgate had brushed the head of Barry Quinn and Merson's winner followed a free-kick from Ginola half-cleared by Williams.

The Premiership will miss Coventry in the way that a tallboy is missed after spending years in the spare room. It is noticed more when it has gone than when it was there.

Gregory pleaded eloquently for Strachan to be allowed to stay on at Highfield Road. "I've a tremendous admiration for Gordon as a person and as a manager," he said. "I hope everybody stays calm over there. He's the man to bring them straight back up." For the moment, it seems, Strachan's job is safe.

Gregory's own future at Villa Park will depend on next season bearing considerably more fruit than the promise of an Intertoto Cup run. In the programme his end-of-season message of thanks mentioned everyone bar the stadium cat before it got around to the Villa chairman, Doug Ellis.

Barnsley, Burnley and Grimsby may beckon for Coventry next season but at least it will be different. Neither Gregory nor Villa can afford more of the same.

Gregory pleaded eloquently for Strachan to be allowed to stay on at Highfield Road. "I've a tremendous admiration for Gordon as a person and as a manager," he said. "I hope everybody stays calm over there. He's the man to bring them straight back up." For the moment, it seems, Strachan's job is safe. Gregory's own future at Villa Park will depend on next season bearing considerably more fruit than the promise of an Intertoto Cup run. In the programme his end-of-season message of thanks mentioned everyone bar the stadium cat before it got around to the Villa chairman, Doug Ellis. Barnsley, Burnley and Grimsby may beckon for Coventry next season but at least it will be different. Neither Gregory nor Villa can afford more of the same.

webTitle: Impressive Owen claims hat-trick to knacker Newcastle

fields.headline: Impressive Owen claims hat-trick to knacker Newcastle
fields.trailText: Michael Owen is in severe danger of having more big games than hot dinners. After scoring a hat-trick on Saturday to put daylight between Liverpool and the chasing Champions League pack, the England striker looked ahead to his season's tumultuous finale. The FA and Uefa Cup finals may whet his appetite, he said, but a top three finish remains the priority.
fields.body:
Michael Owen is in severe danger of having more big games than hot dinners. After scoring a hat-trick on Saturday to put daylight between Liverpool and the chasing Champions League pack, the England striker looked ahead to his season's tumultuous finale. The FA and Uefa Cup finals may whet his appetite, he said, but a top three finish remains the priority.

"This is probably the biggest fortnight of games in which I've played since the World Cup," said Owen, whose goal tally for an injury-interrupted campaign stands at an impressive 19. "If we can win one more match we will be in the Champions League. If we don't finish in the top three our main aim at the beginning of the season would be out of the window, but we're now only one very good performance away."

That display should come against Chelsea at Anfield tomorrow night, when a win should guarantee Gérard Houllier's side third place. "There's an air of confidence here now, but all our success is just potential at the moment," added the striker. "If the season stopped now we'd consider it to have been very good, but it could yet be brilliant - a season that no one dreamt of at the start of the year."

Bobby Robson's side should have known better than to visit Merseyside with Owen and Liverpool in such riotous form. The striker has developed a knack of knackering Newcastle - he has scored 12 times in six games against the Toon, most courtesy of blistering pace and a cool finish. The visitors had already survived one scare within the opening two minutes before Markus Babbel split Andy O'Brien and Nicos Dabizas, allowing Owen to advance and clip the ball beyond Shay Given.

"That ruined the first half for us," said Robson. "We'd told our centre-halves not to let Owen get in behind them - he's a will-o'-the-wisp player - but then Dabizas falls asleep, the young boy spins off and slots it away. You've got a story about Michael Owen; I've got a story about defenders not being alert."

Given was lucky not to concede a second in first-half stoppage time when he scuffed a clearance to Gary McAllister. The Scot gathered the gift, deliberated as to how he should unwrap his sixth goal in six games and promptly saw his shot saved.

Having escaped, Newcastle's second half rally reaped no greater reward than a Nolberto Solano header scrambled off the line by Stephane Henchoz but, with Liverpool strangely flustered, Houllier introduced Patrik Berger. Three minutes later the Czech sent Owen scurrying away to sink the black and white revival. Another substitute, Robbie Fowler, lofted the ball from his own half for the 21-year-old to flick in off the far post and claim his second hat-trick ball of the season.

"I feel stronger and faster again," said Owen. "The head injury I sustained at Derby kept me out for a while earlier in the season and trying to get back after a long lay-off is always hard. But now I'm using my pace to break through and score more often. Emile Heskey's reached 20 for the season, and it would be nice to follow his lead.

"In saying that, you don't score a hat-trick without the help of your team-mates. The back four were outstanding and the midfielders were superb; you can make all the runs you want, but if you don't get the ball you don't score."

Of those behind him, Dietmar Hamann played the least eye-catching role yet retained an imperious air, strutting around Anfield with such assurance as to make the visiting fans' cat-calls sound ridiculous. The German, a former Newcastle player, hovered in front of his back four and kept things simple; without Robert Lee, United cried out for someone to emulate his classy but calm head.

"We have improved mentally this season; we're stronger, more focused and disciplined in our game," added Houllier. "The motivation of the team is shown whenever we don't have the ball. There's a real desire and resolve to reach our targets and we're developing all the time. But for the moment the game with Chelsea is another cup final. We've done it once; we can do it again."

Man of the match Dietmar Hamann

The Liverpool central midfielder's defensive duties and busy passes allowed those in front to supply Michael Owen with ammunition. The visiting fans taunted: "There's only one greedy German" as Hamann simply gobbled up possession.

Moment of the match: His tackle in the second minute allowed Emile Heskey to send Owen away. The striker missed, but the tone was set for a profitable afternoon.

webTitle: Boro edge towards uncertain future

fields.headline: Boro edge towards uncertain future
fields.trailText: In a day or a dozen Boro will know, or determine, their fate. They will be safe tonight if Manchester City do not win at Ipswich. Otherwise they must wait to Saturday week to get the draw at home to West Ham that will ensure their survival.
fields.body:
In a day or a dozen Boro will know, or determine, their fate. They will be safe tonight if Manchester City do not win at Ipswich. Otherwise they must wait to Saturday week to get the draw at home to West Ham that will ensure their survival.

Terry Venables said the decision to defer the last round of matches beyond the Cup final was "appalling, very insensitive". It may be crass to have the climax before the crunch but since when has football been sensitive to anything but its own interests?

Boro have much to sort out when they know where they will be in August. Will Venables stay? What about the expensive foreign stars, too? The party line is that all are happy and committed. Others are more sceptical, especially about Christian Karembeu.

The only certainty - again the official line - seems to be that Bryan Robson will stay, as magnet if not truly manager, a draw, with his chairman Steve Gibson's millions, to overseas players impressed by reputation. When he moved aside, Boro had 11 points from 17 games, conceding 28 goals. Venables, mucker or Messiah, bolted the door. Boro have since taken 28 points from 20 games, losing four, letting in 15.

No wonder he was mystified by Bradford's goal that, with Coventry and Derby up elsewhere, heightened the tension. Jamie Lawrence ran from his own half unchallenged to feed the unmarked Wayne Jacobs.

Bradford, who entered the Premiership with a 1-0 win at Boro last season, have at last found the secret of playing freely at this level: if only they had been relegated earlier, they could have started enjoying life sooner. Until Robert Molenaar's groin left them to improvise in central defence they were a half-decent side in a superb three-quarters finished arena, though the Pulse Stadium seems a misnomer. With Benito Carbone and Robbie Blake up and wide, there were more chips than peas.

Their reassessment of needs may be tinged with regret over priorities: stadium before team, convenience before sense in promoting Chris Hutchings as manager of first resort, as if he might be Paul Jewell II. What does it profit a club to gain marble loos but lose marbles and Premier status? They will want to get straight back so as not to look grandly ridiculous.

Jim Jefferies, their would-be saviour, said: "We'll keep the nucleus and look to add three or four mid-20s players. The spirit's terrific. We can't wait for the new season."

The spirit was epitomised by the first-team coach Stuart McCall, at 36 driving, cajoling, arguing, chasing as if he could not bear a moment to be idle. Their point took them clear of Watford's record low of 24. They will get a taste of the new season at Coventry on May 19.

It has not been a good season for Messiahs - Keegan, Kinnear, Jefferies here. Only Peter Shreeves at Hillsborough has lived up to expectation and he always looks more comfortable in caretaker's coat.

Venables was rightly pleased with his late adjustment: the exciting Carlos Marinelli on, Karembeu to full-back, whence his advances could be more selective. From one the Frenchman picked his spot for a stunning equaliser. Venables may just cut the messianic mustard.

Man of the match: Stuart McCall (Bradford)

webTitle: Foxes feast while Spurs still starve

fields.headline: Foxes feast while Spurs still starve
fields.trailText: Forty years ago almost to the day these clubs met in a more meaningful fixture, the FA Cup final. Spurs won it, becoming the first club to complete the league and Cup double in the 20th century, an achievement upon which they still dine out.
fields.body:
Forty years ago almost to the day these clubs met in a more meaningful fixture, the FA Cup final. Spurs won it, becoming the first club to complete the league and Cup double in the 20th century, an achievement upon which they still dine out.

If pickings since then have been rather slimmer, their latest manager Glenn Hoddle is in no hurry to end the famine. "My job really begins when we return for pre-season training in July," Hoddle said, after watching his side slip to their 13th defeat of the season.

And during a first half in which Leicester should have gone a long way towards ending a run of nine successive defeats, several of his players appeared to agree with him - their bodies at Filbert Street but minds already on holiday.

Perhaps, though, that is understandable because several in Hoddle's injury-ravaged side are unlikely to return. The manager has made it clear that in addition to the big names in the treatment room, he is on the hunt for even bigger names to appear on the pitch. Whether that will include Emmanuel Petit remains to be seen, however.

Hoddle, while "hopeful we'll have some new faces in July", will also be hoping he is joined by a familiar one in Campbell. For all the promise of the young centre-backs Anthony Gardner and Alton Thelwell, experience will be needed if Hoddle is to succeed in matching Tottenham's big-club status with a big achievement.

The City strikers Dean Sturridge and Ade Akinbiyi caused the visitors' youthful rearguard all sorts of problems but it was left to a defender, Gary Rowett, to break the deadlock shortly before the interval.

Simon Davies hit a smart equaliser for Spurs as did Stephen Carr after Sturridge had restored City's lead. But there Tottenham's resistance ended as Sturridge set up Steve Guppy to a third, and Robbie Savage converted a late penalty to seal victory.

"I'm very very pleased not only with the win but also the way we got it," said the relieved City manager Peter Taylor. "We could have scored more in the first half if we'd had a bit of luck." Unless Spurs sort out their defence other teams will score plenty.

Man of the Match: Dean Sturridge (Leicester)

webTitle: Phillips bumps into scoring gear

fields.headline: Phillips bumps into scoring gear
fields.trailText: Sunderland followers, accustomed to chanting "Super Kev" in tribute to Kevin Phillips were spoilt for choice. A first home goal from their beloved striker since January 1 came after Kevin Kilbane had set up victory with a superb opener. And then there was Kevin Kyle, making an encouraging first appearance for the club.
fields.byline: John Wardle at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
Sunderland followers, accustomed to chanting "Super Kev" in tribute to Kevin Phillips were spoilt for choice. A first home goal from their beloved striker since January 1 came after Kevin Kilbane had set up victory with a superb opener. And then there was Kevin Kyle, making an encouraging first appearance for the club.

But it was another Kevin who dictated that Sunderland removed one of their rivals from the chase for a Uefa Cup place. Charlton's substitute Kevin Lisbie reprieved the home side when he misdirected a header after being left in space six yards from goal.

"It was an important miss," grimaced Charlton's manager Alan Curbishley, but he shared the blame around his team. "The defence has been our problem. We've let in too many goals and that might explain why we are not in the top six."

That slackness was best illustrated when they failed to spot the danger as Phillips sprinted into space to crisply convert Don Hutchison's cross five minutes after the break.

Two earlier near-misses epitomised how things have gone for Phillips in recent weeks, with his shortage of goals and his wife's return south to prepare for the birth of twins fuelling whispers of a move.

The crowd's response to the overdue goal showed they want him to stay - and his undisguised delight suggested he may oblige. There was no doubt who the goal was dedicated to as Phillips ran back with his arms indicating the babies' bulge. A double, perhaps, would have been appropriate.

"It was a good moment," said the manager Peter Reid, who needs a win at Everton on the final day and hopes Chelsea falter. "The reaction of the crowd and boy himself showed what it meant to everybody."

Phillips said: "When I came here four years ago nobody dreamed of us trying to qualify for Europe and here we are with a realistic chance."

Kilbane did much to keep their prospects alive, setting the tempo with some early runs and producing an exquisite finish for the lead. Mathias Svensson equalised before Niall Quinn and Kevin Phillips earned Sunderland a cushion which became less comfortable as Claus Jensen pulled one back, Mark Fish hit a post and Lisbie missed the target.

webTitle: Future bleak for bitter Bees

fields.headline: Future bleak for bitter Bees
fields.trailText: On a day Barnet and Torquay were destined to experience opposite extremes of emotion, the Nationwide's bottom two shared a bitterness that this relegation decider was necessary at all.
fields.body:
On a day Barnet and Torquay were destined to experience opposite extremes of emotion, the Nationwide's bottom two shared a bitterness that this relegation decider was necessary at all.

Barnet's financial plight, coupled with a substandard stadium, means they may never recover from demotion to the Conference, and if they are doomed to a life of reminiscing about the 10 years when they graced the Football League, there will be a lasting resentment about the manner in which they have gone down.

The battle to decide the winners and losers in the Third Division has been blighted by the cloud of scandal hanging over Chesterfield, whose promotion has been achieved despite a nine-point penalty imposed on them by the League for financial irregularities and fielding an ineligible player.

Justice, in the eyes of those present here on Saturday, would be for Chesterfield to be docked the 78 points they have won in games played by Luke Beckett, the player in question.

This would send Chesterfield down and Torquay's owner Mike Bateson confirmed his club will lead the fight to have Barnet reinstated at the Spireites' expense, though it represents merely a glimmer of hope.

"There is a group of Third Division chairmen who are intensely dissatisfied with the League's handling of the Chesterfield affair," Bateson said. "Action will be taken and there are several options open to us. We will consult a barrister to see what his views are but I think we can do it within the Football League rules.

"There's a minimum of eight clubs involved and I'd like to think that nearly every club in the Third Division will support it. There's tremendous horror at what has gone on. Barnet are, to the best of my knowledge, an honourable club and it's sacrilege that they should be the ones to go out."

Yet, despite their best intentions, it seems inconceivable that the League will allow the deep wounds caused by the Chesterfield saga to be reopened. Barnet's chairman Tony Kleanthous seemed resigned that his fight to save the club was over when he said: "At least we played to the rules in getting relegated."

The return to the Conference will hit Barnet hard. Already losing £500,000 a year, the club can expect to lose half that again and relegation will be all the harder to take in the knowledge that it could have been so different. In November Barnet were eighth and aiming for the play-offs before the disastrous appointment of Tony Cottee as manager put the club in freefall.

Barnet will also be hampered by their need for a new stadium which meets the League's requirements of a 6,000 capacity. Even if they win the Conference next season they may not be allowed back up.

John Still, who moved upstairs to make way for Cottee but came back down with 10 games to go, refused to lay the blame for relegation totally with the former England striker, but admitted his appointment had proved a fatal mistake.

"Tony had his own ideas but they didn't work. The players became unfit, disorganised, and lost so much confidence that some of them were on their knees almost frightened to kick a ball in training.

"The strength that I have is knowing what the players can do. They were a top-seven group of players at the start of the season and they still are. It's like having a top-quality racehorse, a Derby favourite and you feed it all the wrong stuff and don't train it properly and it doesn't perform to its potential. But these players have it in them to bring this club back."

Still insisted that no players would be leaving and this is vital if they are to challenge for an immediate return. They must also recover mentally after coming so close to beating Torquay on Saturday.

After the home side's goalkeeper Lee Harrison had been carried off in the first minute and Jason Rees and Kevin Hill had given Torquay a 2-0 lead, Barnet's fate looked to have been sealed. Darren Currie then missed a penalty for Barnet before David Graham increased the visitors' lead still further.

Surely that was it, but with the Underhill slope and a strong wind in their favour, Barnet piled on the pressure in the second half, rewarded with an own goal from Ryan Green and a close-range finish from Greg Heald. It was too little, too late, and now an even tougher struggle begins.

"Tony had his own ideas but they didn't work. The players became unfit, disorganised, and lost so much confidence that some of them were on their knees almost frightened to kick a ball in training. "The strength that I have is knowing what the players can do. They were a top-seven group of players at the start of the season and they still are. It's like having a top-quality racehorse, a Derby favourite and you feed it all the wrong stuff and don't train it properly and it doesn't perform to its potential. But these players have it in them to bring this club back." Still insisted that no players would be leaving and this is vital if they are to challenge for an immediate return. They must also recover mentally after coming so close to beating Torquay on Saturday. After the home side's goalkeeper Lee Harrison had been carried off in the first minute and Jason Rees and Kevin Hill had given Torquay a 2-0 lead, Barnet's fate looked to have been sealed. Darren Currie then missed a penalty for Barnet before David Graham increased the visitors' lead still further. Surely that was it, but with the Underhill slope and a strong wind in their favour, Barnet piled on the pressure in the second half, rewarded with an own goal from Ryan Green and a close-range finish from Greg Heald. It was too little, too late, and now an even tougher struggle begins. Man of the Match: Jimmy Aggrey (Torquay)

webTitle: Christie's hit and miss carry Smith home

fields.headline: Christie's hit and miss carry Smith home
fields.trailText: In Jim Smith's formative years in management he once remarked that he wanted his teams to play their football like Tony Bennett sings his melodies, professionally and in perfect harmony. Having croaked like a karaoke singer for much of the season, Derby will be relieved to have found their voices at the right time.
fields.body:
In Jim Smith's formative years in management he once remarked that he wanted his teams to play their football like Tony Bennett sings his melodies, professionally and in perfect harmony. Having croaked like a karaoke singer for much of the season, Derby will be relieved to have found their voices at the right time.

The law of gravity may have finally caught up with Coventry but, if the demise of football's great survivors has sent a collective shudder through those clubs hoping to establish themselves as worthy Premiership citizens, Derby's gatecrashing of Manchester United's title party should go some way to redressing the balance.

It was, admittedly, their immense fortune to come across Sir Alex Ferguson's side on a day when they scarcely attempted to conceal their end-of-season apathy but this was still an act of escapology audacious enough for Smith to acclaim it as the most significant achievement of his career.

Given that there is still a fortnight of the season to play, it perhaps lacked the final-day soap opera that has been Coventry's speciality over the past three decades.

Yet Smith, having devoted more than half of his life to this unforgiving profession, is not prone to making rash statements. Ignoring for a moment the sense of triumphalism that comes with denting Old Trafford's superiority complex, let it not be forgotten that Derby, racked by injuries and suspensions, have recovered from a seemingly impossible position in mid-November when they were the only team in England without a league victory.

Now, for the sixth consecutive year, they can look forward to breathing in the rich Premiership air. "Considering everything that has happened, this has to go down as my greatest ever achievement," said Smith. "Most of all, it means this club will have been in the top division for longer than at any other time over the last 20 years and that makes me incredibly proud."

There has never been a concerted campaign to have Smith removed from office but, unlike others of the managerial brethren, this durable old Yorkshireman is not susceptible to bouts of selective hearing. Hence the sporadic outbursts of voluble dissent at Pride Park this season have not passed him by and he has heard the reasoning behind him taking a new role, allowing a younger man to take the helm.

"I would have stayed if we had gone down but this is a precarious business and I suppose it could have been taken out of my hands," he added. "As long as I am enjoying the game I will never quit and, believe me, I am still enjoying it. Feelings like this make you glad to be involved, and that's why I still love it.

"No one gave us a prayer of getting anything here but we've come through with 13 senior players missing and we're safe, at last. Now we must build for the future. We don't want to put ourselves through this again and, to be honest, I don't think my nerves could cope with it."

All in all, however, Smith will reflect that once Malcolm Christie had spun beyond Ronnie Wallwork after 34 minutes to arrow a left-foot drive into the top-right corner of Fabien Barthez's net there were fewer nerve-shredding moments than he could have dared anticipate.

Instead United seldom threatened to break from their torpor, with no one in midfield to match the guile of Derby's Stefano Eranio and insufficient penetration in attack to breach a visiting defence superbly marshalled by Chris Riggott.

Smith stood open-mouthed and clasping his head in disbelief when Christie, a boyhood United fan who grew up with posters of Mark Hughes and Bryan Robson on his bedroom walls, inexplicably missed from four yards. But as news of Coventry's capitulation came through, nine months of anguish were gazumped by one joyous moment of exaltation.

United were presented with the Premiership trophy and, once the players had done the usual lap of honour, Ferguson gave his acceptance speeches from a gaudy red-gold stand in the centre of the pitch. Everyone was happy and the champagne flowed. But this was Derby's day.

Man of the match: Stefano Eranio (Derby County)
