webTitle: Disappointed Blues married to inconsistency

fields.headline: Disappointed Blues married to inconsistency
fields.trailText: As Chelsea embarked on a lap of honour at the end of this final home game of the season, the chant that greeted them was not the one they had envisaged hearing when the campaign began. No gloating rendition of "champions, champions". Not even a "we're in Europe, we're in Europe, you're not" as Everton trudged off the pitch.
fields.body:
As Chelsea embarked on a lap of honour at the end of this final home game of the season, the chant that greeted them was not the one they had envisaged hearing when the campaign began. No gloating rendition of "champions, champions". Not even a "we're in Europe, we're in Europe, you're not" as Everton trudged off the pitch.

Instead, the players had to parade around Stamford Bridge to a rousing chorus of "there's only one Mrs Zola". The fact that the only achievement the crowd could find to celebrate was the permission of an ageing striker's wife this week to let her husband stay at the club for another two years summed up Chelsea's anti-climactic season.

After making it through to the Champions League quarter-finals, winning the Charity League and thumping West Ham 4-2 in the season's opening game, "we thought we could challenge all the way," said Dennis Wise.

But the west London branch of the Ferrari and Porsche owners club were beaten in the next match by the division's worst team, Bradford, and their season veered badly off course thereafter.

Now Claudio Ranieri's expensively assembled bunch of under-achievers find themselves still requiring two points from their remaining two games - away at Liverpool and Manchester City - to guarantee participation in next season's Uefa cup. Otherwise it could be the dreaded Intertoto, beginning in July.

Saturday's victory kept alive their chances of avoiding that ignominy. But the manner of it - good only in parts - echoed their problem all season: inconsistency.

"Undefeated against Manchester United, Arsenal and Ipswich but 18 points dropped to Sunderland, Leicester and Charlton is the key to failing to reach the Champions League,'' ventured the Chelsea chief executive Colin Hutchinson. He might have added, too, the defeats at struggling Bradford Everton and Middlesbrough.

But Chelsea fans can rest easy. After conducting a government-sized public enquiry, the manager has hit upon a remedy. ''After eight months Claudio Ranieri has completed his assessment of the players at all levels,'' pronounced Ken Bates. ''You can expect a lot of movement both in and out over the next few months.''

Watching Saturday's Jeckyll and Hyde performance one could see the attraction of a clear-out. After Everton had taken an early lead - Kevin Campbell caught the home defence dozing with an unmarked header from Steve Watson's cross - Chelsea played the sort of sublime football they are frustratingly so capable of.

Flowing attacks full of flicks, tricks and one-touch improvisation placed the visiting goal under heavy siege. In the space of four minutes around the half-hour Chelsea grabbed the lead and could have scored more.

First Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink's brilliant turn past Michael Ball allowed him to flick the ball beyond Paul Gerrard, then after a glittering build-up involving Wise, Zola and Eidur Gudjohnsen, Hasselbaink scooped the ball over the keeper for his 22nd goal of the season.

But Chelsea then went into their shell as Everton, despite having already saved themselves from relegation, emerged for the second half with more purpose, and Ranieri unbalanced his attack with the substitution of Eidur Gudjohnsen. Luckily for Chelsea, Everton lacked the quality to fully capitalise on their growing dominance. Liverpool, in the next game, will be less forgiving.

Man of the match: Gustavo Poyet (Chelsea)

webTitle: Trauma of the TV quiz

fields.headline: Trauma fear for children on TV quiz
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The competition will be fierce and the standards high but the filming will have to be over by bedtime.
fields.body:
The competition will be fierce and the standards high but the filming will have to be over by bedtime. Britain's latest prime-time TV quiz from the makers of Who Wants to be a Millionaire? will pit child against child in the ultimate battle of young wits.

The Brainiest Kid in Britain , to be presented by Carol Vorderman, has been created by Celador, the production company behind Millionaire . The show is ITV's latest attempt to win back the ground gained by BBC's The Weakest Link.

But although producers insist that all possible care will be taken to make the event fun, others at Celador admit that great pains have been taken to create an atmosphere of intense competition.

'There's never been a children's quiz show like it before,' said one. 'This is designed to be focused and intense. The children are encouraged to compete in a way they're not in other children's quizzes. Those quizzes aren't really taken seriously by the contestants but this one will be.'

Regional tests to find 24 finalists aged between 11 and 12 will start next month, but the programme has already been heavily criticised by experts for treating children like 'dancing monkeys' and they have warned that contestants could suffer lasting psychological trauma.

Similar shows on US television have been attacked for their pressurised formats. 'It's common sense that you don't put children as young as this in these situations,' said Dr Peter Congdon, director of the Gifted Children Information Centre. 'There's no way I'd allow my children to do it. To fail on prime-time television is traumatic enough for adults but for a child to fail like that could cause serious psychological trauma that could stay with them for the rest of their lives. It's like dancing monkeys. It's the exploitation of children by television and by their parents.'

The show, which will be screened in August, will select a single winner from the 24 contestants over three quick-fire rounds in which the children are given five seconds to answer up to 20 questions at a time.

The winner will receive a trophy and the title, the Brainiest Kid in Britain. The questions will cover a range of categories including general knowledge and the child's own specialist interest.

'There can only be one winner in this show but children are naturally competitive and they understand that 23 of them will have to lose,' said Colman Hutchinson, executive producer of both Brainiest Kid and Millionaire. 'Children are very resilient. It's part of life to lose and they understand that.'

Dr David George, an expert in gifted children who has been employed by Celador to vet the programme design, admitted that he had to overhaul the producers' vision.

'There was a lack of understanding of what children could and could not cope with,' he said. 'The real pressure will come after the prize has been won. The winner will have this ridiculous title to carry around and will inevitably suffer potentially damaging and traumatic intrusions from the media into their private life, not to mention the pressure of jealousy and expectation they will experience from their family, friends and teachers.'

webTitle: Media diary

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Who will Brillo rub out next?
fields.body:
Who will Brillo rub out next?

Much blood on the carpet at the Barclay brothers' newspaper business, run, apparently, by avid Diary reader Andrew Neil. Last week, the Barclays' commercial director Stephen Tait walked out of the Edinburgh offices for the final time, having failed to achieve Neil's hopelessly overambitious targets. Tait's departure comes days after Susan Douglas, former Express editor and devoted Neil helper over many years, quit to spend more time with her young family, and do more work with US publisher Condé Nast. Apparently the long-running antipathy between Neil and Douglas's husband, the glam-academic Niall Ferguson, helped clinch her decision. Diary learns that there is a book running on who will be next to carry the can for Neil's extravagant waste of the brothers' money. What odds for 'Brillo' staying at the helm, now that he's running out of scapegoats?

NY Post's sinking feeling

A distinct shift of editorial style seems likely at the New York Post following the resignation of Xana Antunes. Diary readers will recall that the much-liked Antunes has been replaced by one Col Allan, an Australian bruiser Rupe Murdoch keeps caged up in Sydney until he thinks some poor newspaper needs roughing up a bit. Apparently, Col's party piece during his time as editor of Sydney's Daily Telegraph was to break off news conferences in order to urinate publicly in the sink. His nick-name - 'Col Pot' - seems well-earned.

The Beeb has bespoke (by email)

Our west country (south) correspondent rings with urgent news that repudiates ill-founded claims that Diary (with a staff of 47) must make cutbacks like everyone else in these increasingly difficult times. Our man tells us that BBC reporters lucky enough to have done stirring voice-to-camera stuff in front of burning cow pyres in Devon have received urgent emails from Auntie. In said electronic missives, Mrs Beeb exhorts her brethren to burn their suits asap for fear of contagion, or some other word Diary doesn't understand. The hacks can then claim their char-grilled vestments back on expenses. Apparently, a lot of BBC hacks wear Armani these days.

Faith lost in Money Channel

Diary is dismayed that it seems to have jinxed top personal finance pundit, Adam Faith. Last week we offered the ageing crooner ( note for younger readers, a pop star in the days when McDonald's wasn't around ) the job of Diary chief of production. But following the shock offer, which rocked the media world, Adam's pension plan, also known as the Money Channel (note for everyone, a digital TV service watched by a handful of pensioners in Romford) has hit the buffers and the station's future is uncertain. To test whether Diary has hitherto unknown powers we are offering a job - chief leader writer (European affairs, Hair and Make-up) to one A Neil. Could be a nice little earner if this works, what with Diary's bet in the Barclay brother's sweepstake.

Pots and kettles

Sources in the media world suggest that James Rubin, Bill Clinton's former US assistant secretary of state, who last week joined City spinmeisters Brunswick, is being lined up to get Diary's much-prized PR account. Apparently Diary was taken with Rubin after he recently told The Obs that the difference between the US and the UK press was that the latter had a habit of printing lies on its front pages.

Strong words, but understandable from a man whose previous employer was a paragon of veracity. Diary would just like to say that, truthfully, it has not had sexual relations with that woman.

Back to basics

Diary hears Sunday Times business hacks spent an enjoyable few hours last week learning how to write features under the tutelage of Bob 'Golddust' Tyrer. Bob, a hack of many years, was parachuted in to help junior Wappettes make their 1,500 words on the machinations of Mammon tighter and brighter.

It's not often we encourage our five readers to go and buy other newspapers but, in the interests of empiricism, we want to know if Bob's visit was worthwhile. If readers notice an improvement we'll be on the blower to Bob straightaway. We're never too proud to learn.

webTitle: Why it's all over for Nova

fields.headline: Why it's all over for Nova
fields.standfirst:
Celebrities sell, but now freebies sell more. Former Marie Claire editor Liz Jones reveals the savage world of women's magazines

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Celebrities sell, but now freebies sell more. Former Marie Claire editor Liz Jones reveals the savage world of women's magazines
fields.body:
On the sixteenth floor of IPC's headquarters on London's Southbank, large letters spelling the name 'Nova' had been hung above the entrance to the editorial offices. A few months ago, some wag removed the 'N'. Last Wednesday morning, that prophecy came true.

Almost a year to the day since its launch, it was indeed over for Nova, the title that was intended to be a cutting-edge fashion magazine for women in their early twenties. The editor, Jeremy Langmead, who'd been on board for just six months, and his team of 20 were told that the June issue would be the last. 'I left a good job to join Nova,' said Jeremy on Friday when I phoned him to commiserate. Indeed he had left the Sunday Times, where he was editor of the Style section. 'It was a crazy but fun few months, but at least I left Nova with a shoe collection to rival Imelda Marcos's.'

Jeremy has had a magazine fold beneath him before. It was back in 1990 and we were both working at Mirabella, a title for women in their thirties that lasted precisely 10 issues. But launching a magazine today makes those halcyon times of 10 years ago seem like a walk in the park.

I've just finished two years as editor of Marie Claire (the current issue, featuring the girls from Hear'Say, is my last), and when Jeremy joined my stable - Southbank Publishing at IPC - we traded stories from the front line of the battle for readers and advertisers in an increasingly crowded market. That market had already seen the launches of not just Nova but Eve, Aura, The Fashion, Pop and Bare.

As an editor, you learn very quickly what works on your cover. And, for better or for worse, what works at the moment is celebrities (as well as a smile, the colour red, and lots of cover lines). I put that into practice fast on Marie Claire with my first cover in July 1999, featuring the Appleton sisters from All Saints. I put a model on the cover a few issues later and sales dropped.

Vogue, too, has found that celebs work best - even though it has its pick of the supermodels. A Robbie Williams cover was its bestseller last year. But Jeremy Langmead had proudly said that his readers were not interested in Jennifer Lopez's bottom or Jennifer Aniston's hair. And for a style-savvy fashion bible there aren't that many stars who fit the bill. Actress Chloë Sevigny, perhaps?

At one of the endless focus groups he was subjected to (editors stand weeping on one side of a mirror watching readers maul their mag), one reader piped up with a suggestion: 'They should let Posh Spice write a feature.' It was mooted by management that Nova 'go down the celebrity route', an idea that made Jeremy blanch.

This time last year everything seemed to bode well for Nova: The launch team, under the first editor Deborah Bee, spent more than a year working on the dummy. The TV advertising campaign - with hip young boys and girls throwing eggs at each other - was spot on. Bee's first cover, featuring Brazilian model of the moment Ana Claudia in a modern take on Twiggy, was stunning.

But then it all started to go wrong. The magazine was deemed too masculine, too wordy, too esoteric. There were no signposts to tell you what the pages were about.

The fashion director, Venetia Scott, and her partner, the photographer Juergen Teller, were both hugely talented but hard to control. One particular fashion shoot, where accessories were photographed on grotesque bodies at an American nudist camp, didn't go down too well in the notoriously conservative fashion capital of Milan.

The death knell for Nova was the undignified scramble for readers in the spring of this year. We saw the launch of Warners' InStyle in March and Condé Nast's Glamour in April, both offshoots of hugely successful American titles. If you had taken a stroll along the newsstand of your local WH Smith in April, you would have seen Vogue, with a celebrity style supplement attached to its waist; New Woman, with a free personal organiser; and Nova, with a free novel. Only Marie Claire, with its Bridget Jones theme, was unpromoted.

Circulation has over the past few years become more an issue of how much money is spent on promotion than on how good a publication is. Readers go with the gifts, not the magazine. As editors, we can't tell if our magazines are working because sales are so distorted by the freebies.

All this competition should be great for creativity: who can secure the best cover, the funniest writers, the most original ideas. But when a free bag is in the offing, even a cover showing a naked Jennifer Aniston and Brad Pitt would have trouble competing.

'They promoted Nova before they got it right,' said one IPC marketing executive. 'Get your product right first!' InStyle's first cover was a beaming Julia Roberts - an old American InStyle cover shot recycled for the British market. Glamour , too, can use the clout of its giant American sister magazine - and others in the Condé Nast stable - to procure celebrities and stories. Here again Nova was at a disadvantage.

At Marie Claire, up against so much American competition, we decided to trust our Britishness - using less airbrushing, fewer Oscar gowns, and more mouthy, homegrown stars of the likes of Geri Halliwell (an issue that sold out, incidentally). But on magazine shelves, which are nowadays all so girly and frivolous, Nova seemed somewhat alien.

When the magazine launched, its unique selling point was single-sentence cover lines - for example 'Kate gets personal'. Its cover stars remained unsmiling and moody-looking. But nowadays, when the average time spent choosing a magazine and lifting it off the shelf is about three seconds, the covers make or break a magazine. You need lots of cover lines, and they all have to be compelling.

What killed Nova wasn't just its lack of readers - unsurprising when you look at the above - but the lack of advertising. For a fashion magazine, advertising means Milan, home of the big hitters including Armani, Versace, Prada, Gucci and the rest.

I remember when I first joined Marie Claire and went to Milan to meet the incredibly svelte, well-groomed and well-dressed women at Prada. I proudly recited the extraordinary circulation figures of the latest Marie Claire. 'Ah, but you are too mass-market. We prefer niche magazines,' I was told. Persuading Prada and Gucci to buy space in Marie Claire took two years; Jeremy was given four issues. It's an extraordinary Catch-22 situation: you need sales for profit and to please some advertisers, but for those all-important labels you also need to be cool and exclusive, using the right photographers and the models of the moment.

Nova certainly succeeded there (the gorgeous Karolina is on the cover of the latest and last issue; she was on Vogue the month before). But Nova, like Marie Claire, was handicapped by the Condé Nast stranglehold on lucrative contracts with star photographers like Mario Testino, Nick Knight and Steven Klein.

Even young, up-and-coming photographers often won't work for you because they want to hold out for Vogue and that lucrative advertising campaign. Model agents, too, won't let the top girls do a cover before they have appeared on Vogue - and will wait for that chance, even if it never happens. Against such odds, it's amazing Nova lasted as long as it did.

Now that Jeremy and I have left the world of magazines to become civilians again, I am reminded of what happened when we were booted out of Mirabella .

Having hired Jeremy from St Martin's, I felt very responsible for him. He was sure he wouldn't work in the industry again and I asked him what he wanted to do instead.

'Painting,' he replied. So I hired him to decorate my flat. It took him more than two months because he was so inept. It was only recently he told me he'd meant canvases, not walls.

Weeklies: Volume sales up 23.3 per cent

webTitle: 'Dear Tracy' by Timothy McVeigh

fields.headline: 'Dear Tracy' - by mass killer Timothy McVeigh
fields.standfirst:
In a letter to Observer reporter Tracy McVeigh, Oklahoma bomber Timothy McVeigh, who faces execution in 10 days, talks about the 'triggers' that led him to kill people

The McVeigh letters: Why I bombed Oklahoma

Read Tracy McVeigh's original article in Observer Life Magazine: Dead man talking
fields.trailText: In a letter to Observer reporter Tracy McVeigh, the Oklahoma bomber, who faces execution in 10 days, talks about the 'triggers' that led him to kill people
fields.body:
Timothy McVeigh, the Oklahoma City bomber due to be executed in 10 days, has given The Observer an exclusive insight into the 'triggers' for him to murder 168 people.

In a remarkable letter, McVeigh said he wanted to explain his reasons for bombing the federal government building in 1995. Nineteen of his victims were children.

McVeigh, due to die by lethal injection, wrote the letter to me two weeks after The Observer 's Life magazine published an account of his life that included photographs of him and his family. Calling me 'my distant relative', he joked: 'The pictures were far better than most people have used.'

McVeigh urged me to contact his close friend, Bob Papovich, who was 'someone I have been discussing the "why?" with.'

'Ask him to sumnate [sic] the info I've sent him,' he said. 'Ask specifically for my three-page letter, 'Why I bombed the Murrah building".'

Right-winger Papovich, a close friend of McVeigh's and his co-conspirator in the bombing Terry Nichols, was surprised to get a call. 'I don't know what Tim's playing at,' Papovich said.

'One minute he's telling me the letters he writes are off-the-record, not for publications, then he gets you call me. I guess as his time gets closer he wants the story out.'

Papovich runs his own campaign against the US federal government's 'tyranny and oppression'. He believes Nichols is innocent of involvement, and criticised McVeigh for resorting to 'violence to solve a problem'.

Despite his initial qualms, Papovich obliged and yesterday faxed the letter to The Observer. In it, Gulf war veteran McVeigh, 33, makes it clear he has absolutely no regrets over the atrocity, disappointing those still hoping for last minute remorse.

'Borrowing a page from US foreign policy, I decided to send a message to a government that was becoming increasingly hostile by bombing a government building and the employees within that building who represent that government,' he wrote.

He described how he waited 'patiently' for two years for justice for the 75 people who died during a botched federal raid on the Davidian cult headquarters at Waco, Texas, in 1993.

But his forbearance ran out. 'I reached the decision to go on the offensive - to put a check on government abuse of power, where others had failed in stopping the federal juggernaut running amok. Foremost, the bombing was a retaliatory strike, a counter attack,' McVeigh wrote.

'It was at this time, after waiting for non-violent checks and balances to correct ongoing federal abuses and, seeing no such results, that the assault weapons ban passed and rumours surfaced of nationwide, Waco-style raids scheduled for spring 1995, to confiscate firearms.'

McVeigh points out that the rumours turned out to be true. Government papers obtained by US media proved that raids on right-wing groups had been planned by agents of the FBI and the Bureau for Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms.

'For those who dimiss such concerns as "paranoia" you need to look at the facts as they existed and further reflect that the Waco raid was not imaginary - it was a real event,' McVeigh wrote.

He described how a Jekyll and Hyde transformation came over him. He was no longer'little Timmy', and assumed a new personality: 'I again became the hard-core soldier who was trained to kill by my own government.'

On Friday Papovich recieved a further letter from McVeigh, asking: 'How do you know I don't agree with the non-violent philosophy? Did it ever occur to you that I mindfully emulated the behaviour of our government, to make a statement in itself?

'By killing me they prove who they are. They make my point for me'

At his home in Decker, Michigan, just a few miles from Nichols' farm where McVeigh first learnt to make bombs from fertiliser, Papovich insisted his friend was 'a compassionate and caring guy' who was preventing his family or friends from witnessing the execution to spare their anguish.

'He told me I'd be pissed at him when I found out who he had invited to the execution,' said Papovich.

Yesterday the final surprise was revealed when US writer Gore Vidal said he had accepted McVeigh's macabre invitation. Vidal, who is on assignment for Vanity Fair, spoke sympathetically of McVeigh and told The Observer: 'McVeigh regarded the government as having committed a number of crimes. He was a highly decorated soldier in the Gulf war who became disillusioned about how it [the US government] treated Iraqis and and its own troops, through the use of chemicals.

'He is very intelligent and well-read, particularly on constitional law, and as I read it, acted out of a sense of justified grievance against the government. I would have preferred it if he had choosen an empty building.

'That's why I'm willing to overcome my abhorrence of capital punishmen to witness his execution.'

This week McVeigh's former lawyer Stephen Jones will publish his own account of the bombing, claiming his ex-client was a pawn in a bigger conspiracy. But McVeigh, fell out with Jones during his trial, dismisses this and insists he alone detonated the 4,800lb bomb.
